title: Sonesta Appoints Officers
description: Several changes in the top management of Sonesta International Hotels Corporation, formerly Hotel Corporation of America, were announced yesterday. Roger P. Sonnabend, formerly president, becomes chairman of the board and treasurer, continuing as chief executive officer of the company. Also elected were Paul Sonnabend, executive vice president, as president and chief operating officer; Carl Albers, formerly vice president, executive vice president; and Stephen Sonnabend, formerly vice president, senior vice president and secretary.

title: MARKET IS MIXED AT QUARTER'S END
The Economy at Midyear
description: At midyear the United States economy is sliding into a recession. Unemployment, which reached 5 per cent of the labor force in May, almost certainly climbed higher in June. With hundreds of thousands of young people entering the job market at a time when employers are laying off workers, unemployment will go higher this summer and threatens to hit 6 per cent by the end of the year.

title: MYERS TRIUMPHS IN JUNIOR TENNIS
description: Mark Harner, an unseeded player from Clifton, N. J., was on his way to a possible upset of topseeded John Peckskamp of Cincinnati when rain halted their match at the start of competition yesterday in the 18yearsandunder section of the North Atlantic junior tennis championships at Columbia's Baker Field courts.

title: 5th Ave to Be Shut To Vehicles in Test
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that Fifth Avenue would be closed to all but crosstown traffic from 42d to 57th Street for four successive Saturdays beginning July 11.

title: Censure Backed for 12
description: A hearing examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission has ruled that 12 investment company management concerns violated the antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws by selling shares in the Douglas Aircraft Company after being tipped off by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc.

title: Sports of the Times
description: The quality of mercy is not strained. droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven upon the undeserving noggin of Denny McLain. The suspension of the great Detroit Tiger pitcher will come to a kindly end tonight and he will return from exile to pitch against the New York Yankees before a sellout crowd in Tiger Stadium and millions of curious televiewers.

title: Screen: 'Virgin and the Gypsy' Opens
description: "The Virgin and the Gypsy," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is an immensely romantic movie that minds its old fashioned manners with style and critical intelligence. It stars Joanna Shimkus, who has the face of a fair, slightly wacky Madonna, and Franco Nero, who has very black hair, intensely blue eyes and an insolent gaze, and it is the first feature film to be directed by Christopher Miles, a 31-year-old Englishman who knows exactly what he's doing. There's not a bad or really pretentious moment in the movie.The film is an adaptation of the D. H. Lawrence novella, published after the author's death in 1930, about a rector's independent minded daughter, Yvette, and the lower-class male, a spin-off from Lady Chatterley's confident lover, whom fate, in the form of a flash flood, turns into the instrument of her sexual emancipation.Although "The Virgin and the Gypsy" was apparently written near the end of Lawrence's life, it can be read as seminal Lawrence. The gypsy is little more than a spinster's daydream, described mostly in terms of what his loins and his hips are up to. (They are, variously, "quick," "alert" and "fine." Yvette's spirit of rebellion, fed by some mysterious (at least, to Lawrence) desire to be sexually conquered by a male who can never be possessed, is not so different from Gudrun's in "Women in Love," which the author began in 1913.At the same time, however, in "The Virgin and the Gypsy" Lawrence created a cast of complex, proper, inhibited middle-class characters, as well as a specific time (the mid-1920's) and place (North Country England) with an economy of exposition and dialogue that probably was out of reach of the younger writer.Miles and his screen writer, Alan Plater, have used the novella almost as if it were a scenario, and because the original is so direct and slim (120 pages), they have gotten most of it on film, with the exception of some ironies that separate the novella from more ordinary women's fiction.For a film whose narrative line depends largely on suppressed passion, hurt feelings and inarticulate longings, the movie is remarkably straightforward. Yvette and her older sister, Lucille (Harriet Harper), return from school in France to live at the rectory with their father, made impotent years before when his wife eloped with a younger man; their old-maid aunt, who eats a single potato at each meal, and their terrifying grandmother, who, when she isn't doing crossword puzzles or screaming for her Horlick's, is reminding the girls of the bad blood they inherited from their mother.The movie is one of lovely, funny vignettes of life at the rectory, of outings and country dances and amateur the-atricals, all punctuated by Yvette's fantasies about the gypsy, whom she has met, quite by chance, and who never exists in the movie as a character with a name, but only as a presence. A key difference between the novella and the film is that, at the end of the novella, there is every indication that Yvette will stay on at the rectory, quietly chipping away at pillars in the middle-class temple that confines her, until it comes falling down around her ears and her (by that time) bobbed hair. In the movie, she literally escapes.Miles never forces his presence on the film, shooting most of it in conventional long-shots, medium shots and medium close-ups, seldom using the sort of tight close-ups that might allow us to see the essential blandness of it all. The performances are completely true to the sense and spirit of the pieces, especially those of Miss Shimkus and of Honor Blackman as Mrs. Fawcett, Yvette's rich, outcast divorce friend who is horrified by Yvette's dreams of a gypsy lover. Mr. Nero has to glower quite a lot, and he glowers with conviction."The Virgin and the Gypsy" is satisfying because it realizes its goals, which are modest. I trust people will not stay away under the impression that it is, in some way related to "The Lustful Turk."

title: Move to Abandon Ban Against Busing Rejected by House
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI)  The House, heading toward another big desegregation fight with the Senate, voted today to stand by its proposed ban on forced school busing and its attempt to legalize courtrejected freedomofchoice school integration plans.

title: U.S. Asks Toxin Ban By Geneva Conference
description: GENEVA, June 30 (Reuters)  The United States today formally proposed the inclusion of toxins in a British draft convention to outlaw biological weapons now before the 25nation Geneva disarmament conference.

title: Charles Elliott, $38.80, Wins By Six Lengths at Monmouth
Pacers Help America's Cup Yachts
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 30 (UPI) Two former participants in the America's Cup races joined three American yachts and a French 12Meter off Newport today as the contenders prepared for trials to pick a defender and challenger for the coveted trophy.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Charge Called Unfair by the White House
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Nixon Administration, stung by an accusation that it was antiNegro, responded sharply today, labeling the charge as unfair and disheartening.

title: Colombo Is Accused Of Contempt on L.I.
Aid of 1Billion a Year Is Termed Way to Head Off Bankruptcies
S.I.U. AND 8 AIDES INDICTED IN PLOT
description: The Seafarers International, Union and eight of its officers and employes were indicted by, a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of conspiring to contribute $750,000 to Republican and Democratic political campaigns in 1968.

title: A Ranch's Specialty: The Care and Feeding of 30,000 Minks
description: BERLIN, Md.  His name is Charlie Brown. He has mischievous little eyes, chatters a blue streak and is an expert pickpocket. He wears a honeybrown coat of the world's rarest mink and, because he is so appealing and mildmannered for his breed, he has been allowed to keep it. Charlie is a 3yearold Kojah mink.

title: PRESS SUIT FILED IN CHATTANOOGA
description: CHATTANOOGA, June 30The Times Printing Company, which publishes The Chattanooga Times, filed a $21million countersuit today against The Chattanooga NewsFree Press Company and its publisher, Roy McDonald.

title: Yankees, Waiting for McLain, Are Divided on His Condition
description: DETROIT, June 30The New York Yankees flew here today to open a threegame series against the Detroit Tigers, but their eyes were fixed firmly on the main eventthe return of Denny McLain to the major, Leagues tomorrow night.

title: U.S. ROLE OPPOSED IN COFFEE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters) Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, today opposed extending United States participation in the International Coffee Agreement, charging that Brazil had violateri it.

title: Control of Radioactive Wastes In Sea Urged at Experts'
description: ATTARD, Malta, June 30Experts attending a conference here on problems of the sea have been calling fervently for international controls on radioactive wastes.

title: Firm Cutting Costs
description: Faulkner, Dawkins & Sullivan, one of Wall Street's topranked institutional brokerage houses, will initiate a major costcutting program today in response to sluggish conditions in the stock market.

title: Deficit in'71 Budget Is Expected to Soar By Over $7Billion
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Congressional action and inaction are threatening to add more than $7billion to the budget deficit for the fiscal year that begins tomorrow a new official tally disclosed today.

title: Targets in Jordan Attacked
description: TEL AVIV, June 30 (Reuters)  Israeli jets attacked guerrilla targets in Jordan today following earlier rocket attacks on the Israeli border village of Beisan, a military spokesman said here. All planes returned safely from the 30minute raid, he added.

title: State Labor Council Votes, 21, to Back Rockefeller in Race
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 30 The 29member executive council of the State A.F.L.C.I.O. recommended by a 2to1 margin today that the organization's state convention, meeting Sept. 2 to 4, endorse Governor Rockefeller for reelection.

title: U.S. PULLOUT FAILS TO STIR ASIAN REDS
description: HONG KONG, June 30The withdrawal of United States troops from Cambodia prompted no immediate plaudits from the Communist countries in Asia.

title: Roundup: Senators Stifle Red Sox to Williams's Joy
description: The Washington Senators are not going to go anywhere in the American League Eastein Division, but they are certainly raising hob with the socalled contenders.

title: PETERSON ROUTED BY 3 HOMERS IN 3D
description: DETROIT, June 30While everybody was talking about Denny McLain tonight, the Detroit Tigers hit three home runs in one inning, made five double plays and ground out a 53 victory over the New York Yankees.

title: Elimination Tag on Tiger Bout Assailed by Griffith's Manager
description: A note of discontent was injected yesterday into the nontitle 10round bout between Emile Griffith of New York and Dick Tiger of Nigeria, scheduled for Madison Square Garden on July 15.

title: G.O.P. State Body to Meet
description: ALBANY. June 30 (UPI)The 360member New York Republican State Committee will meet July 7 in the ThruwayHyatt House here to elect officers and conduct other party business. Chairman Charles T. Lianigan announced today.

title: MR. HAGAN IS CITED AT ADDONIZIO'S TRIAL
description: TRENTON, June 30The key witness in the extortion trial here of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and five other defendants testified today that a man he referred to only as Mr. Hagan had made arrangements for him to visit the campaign headquarters of Abraham D. Beame in the 1965 New York mayoral campaign.

title: Minnewaska Park
description: That enticing strip of woodland lakes, waterfalls and forest glens in the Shawangunk Mountains of Ulster County  adjacent to the privately protected and equally beautiful Lake Mohonk tractis to become Minnewaska State Park after all instead of something like Minnewaska Homes or Shawangunk Manor. The New York Legislature, which appropriated money to buy a sizable part of the land; the bank that agreed to stay the auctioneer's hammer while negotiations crept along; and, above all, the Nature Conservancy, which bought the Minnewaska property pending the state's purchasethanks to all of these, this large natural parkland has been saved from the developers for the permanent refreshment of the people of the state.

title: Nixon to Get Pollution Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Tune 30 (UPI) The House passed and sent to the White House today a bill to continue major antipollution programs for another two months, after they expire with the end of the current fiscal year. The Senatepassed measure was approved by the House without. debate. The measure would continue existing clean air and solid waste disposal programs for 60 days without change.

title: U.S. to Sell Two Yachts
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 30 (AP)The two former Presidential yachts, the Patricia and the Julie, which wil be sold here July 21, were opened today for inspection, the Defense Supply Sales Office announced. The Patricia is now at the Washington Navy Yard and the Julie at the Coast Guard Base in Miami Beach.

title: Poland Shuffles Cabinet
description: WARSAW, June 30 (AP)Vice Premier Marian Olewinski and three ministers were dropped from their posts today in a reshuffle of the Cabinet.

title: Advertising: Blacks Press Commercial Use
description: There is a feeling among some black performers, and they've reported it to the City Commission on Human Rights, that there's been a slackening in the effort to use minority group people in commercials. The commission, according to a spokesman, is looking into the matter, but so far has come up with no substantiation.

title: J. I. Case to Close a Plant
description: ROCKPORT, III., June 30 (AP)Officials of the J. I. Case Company announced today that its Rockford plant would cease operations, effective July 24, as a result of declining production. and sales. The company, which has its headquarters in Racine, Wis., is a manufacturer of farm implements and heavy machinery.

title: LUTHERAN UNITY HELD IMPERILED
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 30A victory here for women's rights was viewed today as a threat to the Lutheran unity movement.

title: Foreign Affairs: The Status of Soviet Jews
description: MOSCOW  If the position of Soviet Jews is not so bad as the West imagines, it is surely not so good as the regime pretends. Were the Government suddenly to grant them pennission to leave, the great majority would probably remain; but it is not a happy community.

title: Women's Lib Headquarters
description: There is no sign, just a symbol and a bell at the side of the entrance to the loft building at 36 West 22d Street. The motifthe palm of a hand with four fingers raised within a circle and cross peace symbol  is the mark of the women's liberation movement, whose communications center is housed on the second floor.

title: DARTMOUTH, PENN POISED AT HENLEY
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, June 30 (UPI)Dartmouth, and Pennsylvania lead a contingent of 10 American crews competing in the annual fourday Henley royal regatta opening tomorrow.

title: At I.S. 201, We've Turned the Corner
description: Two and a has years ago, teachers spoke of Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem as a jungle. An air of bedlam prevailed at the modern, windowless school, and teachers brandished yardsticks to discipline children who got out of control in the classrooms and corridors.

title: Emergency Is Declared In Chilean Student Rioting
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 30 (AP)Northern Chile is under a state of emergency as a result of student riots that spread throughout the country from Santiago, the capital.

title: Theater: Anthony Perkins Directs Steambath
description: God is blackHe really is! That, I suppose, is the thinking, or at least the nub of the thinking, In Bruce Jay Friedman's new comedy, Steambath, which opened last night at the Truck and Warehouse Theater.

title: Navy Gets Army Base
description: BOSTON, June 30 (AP)The Boston Army Base was turned over to the Navy today, leaving this city without an Army post for the first time since the Revolutionary War.

title: Wilkins, at N.A.A.C.P. Convention, Calls on Negroes to Reject Racial Separatism
description: CINCINNATI, June 30Roy Wilkins urged Negroes today to reject again those ideas being put forth that advocate a separation of the races.

title: Plane Hijacking Curbs Backed by World Parley
description: MONTREAL, June 30 The International Civil Aviation Organization urgently called on all countries today to unite behind a strong security program to protect planes and passengers from hijackers, saboteurs and armed attackers.

title: A NEWSPAPER BILL CLEARS HOUSE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) The Newspaper Preservation Act won formal clearance today for early House action, and its sponsors forecast House approval. A similar bill has been passed by the Senate.

title: Britain and 3 Others Offer Cases to Common Market
I.B.M. Shows 2 New Computers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced yesterday a new family of computers, the IBM System/370, but Insisted that it was not a fourth generation.

title: NASA Official Selected
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Richard C. Clark McCurdy, 61 years old, former president and chief executive officer of the Shell Oil Company, will become associate administrator for organization and management at NSA Oct. 1.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. To Wed Felicia Sarnof
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and Mrs. Felicia Warburg Sarnoff, former wife of Robert W. Sarnoff, board chairman and president of the RCA Corporation, will be married here this morning. Only members of the families will attend the ceremony.

title: Blazes Break Out At 3 Woolworths And Grand Union
description: Fires broke out shortly after 7 o'clock last evening in three F. W. Woolworth stores in Manhattan. No one was reported injured.

title: Jones &
description: CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) An increase in the prices of two types of extra reinforcing steel was announced today by Jones & McKnight Steel, Inc.

title: FORD TAKES LEAD IN HIPKINS SAILING
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., June 30 Jonathan G. Ford of the Riverside (Conn.)) Yacht Club won both races by comfortable margins today and took 2point lead for the 19th annual Long Island Sound men's sailing championship and the Commodore Hipkins Trophy. The one race remaining in the roundrobin series will be sailed tomorrow.

title: SCHOOL MILK PLAN EXTENDED FOR YEAR
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 30 (UPI)President Nixon announced today that he had reluctantly permitted the extension of a $120million school milk program he had criticized as outmoded and of little help to the Door.

title: Four Tora Premieres Set
description: Tora, Tora, Tora, the 20th CenturyFox dramatization of the events leading up to and including the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, will have simultaneous world premieres here, Los Angeles, Tokyo and in Honolulu on Sept. 23. The film will begin reservedseat runs at the Criterion Theater here.

title: SENATE APPROVES POSTAL BILL 7610
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, July 1A weary Senate voted early today to revamp the nation's postal system and give postal workers an 8 per cent pay rise, retroactive to April 16.

title: MINERS ON STRIKE WIN COURT APPEAL
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (UPI)  A threejudge Federal panel reversed today a decision given in Pittsburgh last Thursday that ordered thousands of, striking coal miners in western Pennsylvania back to work.

title: State's Liberal Abortion Law Takes Effect Today Amid Prospects for Initial Delays
description: The nations most liberal abortion law goes into effect in New York State today amid controversy and confusion over how many women will seek abortions, how an abortion can be obtained, how much it will cost and whether the hospitals will be able and willing to meet the demand.

title: Fruits of Cambodia
description: The most important result of the American incursion into Cambodia which ended yesterday is not the dubious military achievement claimed by the President in his lengthy report from San Clemente but the political reaction on Capitol Hill as reflected in Senate passage of the CooperChurch amendment.

title: School Decentralization Begins Test of Its Viability
description: Like most of the 60,000 teachers in the city school system, Stephen Ware, a 27yearold fourthgrade instructor at Public School 41 in Greenwich Village, cleaned out and straightened up his classroom yesterday.

title: MINNEW ASKA MOVE BY STATE IS HAILED
description: NEW PALTZ, N. Y., June 30 The state's decision to acquire the Lake Awosting portion of the Minnewaska resort area and the Shawangunk Mountain escarpment for park. purposes was hailed today as one of New York State's finest conservationist victories.

title: Judith Heineman Bride of Teacher
description: Miss Judith Nancy Heineman, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Florentine of the Bronx and Miami and the late Bertram Heineman, was married last night to Joseph Shuldiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Shuldiner of Crompond, N.Y. Rabbi Edward Heisler performed the ceremony at the International Hotel of Jamaica, Queens.

title: McCormack Linked To Pressure Tactic
description: A university official testified here yesterday that House Speaker John W. McCormack had personally asked him to admit the son of a convicted labor racketeer during a conversation in which a Federal official held out the possibility of increasing the university's Federal research contract.

title: Ailey Dancers Name Director For Fund Unit
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, threatened with dissolution by a financial deficit last April, has named Douglas Blair Turnbaugh chairman of the Dance Theater Foundation, Inc., nonprofit taxexempt corporation that will seek sustaining funds for the interracial moderndance troupe.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Museum Plan Opposed

title: SloanKettering Picks Aides
description: The SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research yesterday announced the appointments of Dr. Jack J. Fox and Dr. F. Kingsley Sanders as vice presidents. Dr. Fox is a section head of the biological chemistry division at the SloanKettering research facility in Westchester County, and Dr. Sanders is chief of the cell biology division.

title: I.O.S., Ltd., Is Hopeful on Future
description: TORONTO, June 30  The new management of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., told shareholders today that the worst of the company's troubles were behind it and that it is now looking for new partners who can infuse capital and managerial talent.

title: MAILERS AND PAPERS RESUME PACT TALKS
description: Theodore W. Kheel, mediator in the continuing newspaper dispute, met yesterday with negotiators for Mailers Union No. 6 and representatives of The New York Times, The Daily News, The New York Post and The Long Island Press in a new effort to resolve their protracted dispute.

title: Vatican Curia Is Truly Multinational; Italian Membership Is Now a Minority
description: ROME, June 30  The Roman Curia, the administrative arm of the Vatican that has been controlled by Italians for centuries, has become a genuinely multinational body as part of the updating of the Roman Catholic Church initiated by Pope John XXIII.

title: Sheilah Rae, Actress, Is Betrothed
description: GLENCOE, III., June 30Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Bernstein have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheilah Bernstein, to Dr. Elliott George Gross, a neurologist. He is the son of Mrs. Max Gross of Long Beach, L. I., and the late Mr. Gross.

title: 5 TEXTILE MILLS SUED ON PRICING
description: WASHLNGTON, June 30 (AP) The Justice Department accused five textile companies today of conspiring with wholesale and retail dealers to eliminate competition in the retail sale of trademarked bedding.

title: Panel Votes to Open U.S. Courts to Consumer Suits
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The Senate Commerce Committee voted today to open the Federal courts to a broad range of class action suits by consumers against unfair business, practices.

title: Policeman Convicted of Perjury in Corruption Case
description: A New York policeman was found guilty yesterday of lying to a Bronx grand jury about his meetings with policy gamblers to collect protection money from them.

title: Open to Bistate Toll Rise, Cahill Says
description: Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey said yesterday that he was willing to consider increasing auto tolls on Hudson River crossings if a satisfactory plan was devised to use the added revenues for masstransit projects.

title: L. I. Nuptials Held For Mrs. von Glahn
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 30Benjamin Ludlow Jr., orchestra leader, composer and choral director, known as Ben Ludlow, and Mrs. Martha Lohrke von Glahn of Oysfer Bay were married here this evening in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: HOGAN SEEKS RULE ON NONJURY CASES
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan has asked the state's highest court for an emergency order to halt what he called the chaotic and uncertain situation created in the New York City Criminal Court by a United States Supreme Court ruling on jury trials.

title: Article 2  No Title
Cut in World Coffee Crop Forecast for Next Season
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Agriculture Department forecast today a sharp cut in the world coffee crop for the 197071 season.

title: U. S. SETS A RISE IN MEAT IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Nixon Administration announced a modest increase today in the level of permitted meat imports in the year 1970 as a whole, but with some rollback in the second half from firsthalf levels.

title: Amex Declines Again, but Most Drops Are Slight
Executive Changes
description: Richard J. Blakinger has resigned as president and ti director of the Hamilton Watch Company, and Arthur B. Sinkler has been named to perform the duties of the office until he is formally elected on July 9. The latter will continue as chairman the board.

title: Mrs. Nixon's Peru Trip Ends With Hospital Call
description: LIMA, Peru, June 30Mrs. Richard M. Nixon's goodwill trip to earthquakestricken. Peru ended today. Before boarding the Presidential jet she spent her final hours in Lima at a hospital visiting children who had evacuated from the main earthquake zone.

title: Senate RollCall
Assembly in Laos Votes Its Confidence in Premier
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 30 (AP)The National Assembly gave an informal vote of confidence today to the Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma. The vote followed reports of increasing rightist pressure because of recent North Vietnamese advances in southern Laos.

title: LONG DEBATE ENDS
MEXICANS TRIUMPH IN SOCCER HERE, 10
description: Cruz Azul, the soccer champion of Mexico in the 196869 season, blanked the New York GreekAmericans, 10, at Gaelic Park, the Bronx, last night, in the first of the twogame, totalgoal series of the Central and North American playoffs.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee of experts on demographic aspects of de velopment10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Boy Who Befriended a Retarded Child and Found a Cause
description: Kenneth Robinson found being an honor student rather lonely. He says he felt alienated from people his own ageuntil he met Stanley Crump, who is mentally retarded. Stanley, the son of Kenneth's family pediatrician, proved loyal, free of prejudice and not ashamed of expressing his feelings in a hug.

title: Insolvent Mill Factors Agrees To Sell Assets and Liquidate
description: The Mill Factors Corporation, an insolvent finance company that was once considered Tiffany of its industry, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell substantially all of its assets to James Talcott, Inc., and then liquidate.

title: Support From Service Union
description: Governor Rockefeller was also endorsed yesterday by Joint Council 11 of the Service Employes International Union. Richard F. Chancellere, president of the 110,000member organization, sent the Governor a telegram saying that the group would actively work for his reelection.

title: Slayer of Airman Gets Life
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, June 30 (AP)Steven Lyle Craig, 20 years old, was sentenced today to life imprisonment for the slaying of a former Air Force Academy airman from a Buffalo suburb.

title: LAST U. S. TROOPS LEAVE CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30The last American advisers and support troops withdrew from Cambodia today, 63 days after major allied operations began against North Vietnamese and Vietcong sanctuaries.

title: Badillo Rival Challenges Primary Result in Court
description: The election of Herman Badillo for the Democratic nomination in the new 21st (Triborought) Congressional District was challenged in Supreme Court yesterday by Peter F. Vallone, Mr. Badillo's closet rival in the June 23 primary.

title: Clav Shaw Case Continued
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 30 (AP)A hearing on a motion to dismiss perjury charges against Clay L. Shaw was continued indefinitely in state court today until District Attorney Jim Garrison, who was reportedly ill, could testify. Two days after Mr. Shaw's acquittal March 1. 1969, on charges he conspired to murder President Kennedy, Mr. Garrison charged him with lying on the witness stand.

title: City Paid $75Million in 1969 In Fees to Private Consultants
description: The city has vastly expanded its use of private consulting contracts, which are awarded without competitive bidding and are usually unknown to the public.

title: Mrs. Elizabeth M. Marjorthanks Is Married to John Clement Bair
description: WESTON, Conn., June 30 Mrs. Elizabeth Morris Marjoribanks, widow of the Rev. George Marjoribanks, was married here this afternoon to John Clement Bair. The Presbyterian ceremony was performed by the Rev. Albert Campbell at the home of the bride's twin, DuBois S. Morris Jr.

title: An Archetypal Tory
description: LONDON, June 30He moves and speaks gently. Slight, balding and immaculately tailored, Anthony Barber is the archetype civil servant and Conservative party official.

title: Deaths
HOSPITALS UNION REJECTS 2 OFFERS; STRIKE TODAY SEEN
description: The city's private nonprofit hospitals made two new pay offers to their 25,000 nonprofessional employes yesterday, but the union representing the workers rejected both offers as inadequate.

title: Truckers Talk of City Embargo Unless Protection Is Improved
description: An embargo on all deliveries by truck within the city was threatened yesterday unless Mayor Lindsay and the Police Department took steps to give drivers more protection against assault and robbery.

title: Consumer Activism Up in Poor Nations
description: BADEN, Austria, June 30 Asian and African housewives, angered over maggots in chocolates, filthy milk containers and rotted meat, are stepping up pressure against fraudulent practices and uniting in militant consumer groups, an international meeting of consumeraffairs specialists here was told today.

title: Community Colleges
description: The Carnegie Commission in its latest report has restated an educational fact on which most experts agree in principle: if open access to higher education is to become a reality, the twoyear community colleges will have to shoulder a major share of the burden. Without these local institutions, the cost fitting great new masses of high school graduates into the existing fouryear colleges and universities would be prohibitive. Moreover, academic quality on the traditional campuses would be diluted by the flood of diverse and unsorted human material. The commission's tenyear goal is establishment of at least 230 new twoyear colleges, in addition to the expansion of many existing ones.

title: Senate RollCall on Cambodia Curb
NIXON'S VETO OVERRIDDEN ON MEDICAL BUILDING BILL; SENATE'S VOTE IS 76 TO 19
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Senate voted 76 to 19 today to override President Nixon's veto of the threeyear, $2.79billion authorization bill extending the HillBurton program of construction and modernization of medical facilities.

title: Reynolds Metals Unit Sets Joint Venture in Germany
description: RICHMOND, June 30 (AP)Reynolds International, Inc., a subsidiary of the Reynolds Metals Company of Richmond and Vereinigte AluminiumWerke of Bonn, West Germany, announced today plans for construction of a jointly owned alumina plant near Stade, West Germany.

title: Japan's Payments Posted $78Million Deficit in May
description: TOKYO, June 30 (UPI)Japan's overall balance of payments for May registered a deficit of $78million, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Draft Moratorium Request By Bayonne Mayor Denied
description: BAYONNE, N. J., June 30There will be no moratOrium on the drafting of men from this city into the armed forces.

title: Main Stress of the Report Is on Credibility
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The main point of President Nixon's final report on the Cambodian operation today was that he has proved himself a man of his word who ought now to be trusted by his people at home and taken seriously by his adversaries abroad.

title: AARON AND CARTY SMASH HOME RUNS
description: CINCINNATI, June 30With more dirt in the stands than on the field, the Cincinnati Reds opened their new but unfinished S45million Riverfront Stadium tonight.

title: Lindsay Appoints New Director of Budget After Hayes Resigns
description: Edward K. Hamilton, who has held key economic posts with the Federal Government, was named by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to succeed Frederick O'R. Hayes as head of the Budget Bureau.

title: Text of the President's Report Upon Completion of the U.S. Operation in Cambodia
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 30 (UPI)Following is the text of President Nixon's report on the newly completed American military operation in Cambodia, made public today at the Western White House:

title: Dance: Limon's Traitor
2 Plainfield Police Shot at Fire Scene
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 30 Two city, policemen were shot early this morning in the predominantly Negro West End after responding to a small fire in a store. City officials contended that the fire had been staged deliberately to lure the police into the sniping.

title: GROUP WILL STUDY BANKRUPTCY LAWS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Creation of a commission to study and recommend the first major overhauling of the nation's bankruptcy laws in 32 years was approved today by the House.

title: Superintendent Is lnstalled At Coast Guard Academy
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., June 30Rear Adm. John S. Thompson became superintendent of the United States Coast Guard Academy in a formal ceremony today.

title: Truck Convoy, U.S. Gift, Is Driven Into Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 30Forty American trucks were driven today from South Vietnam to Cambodiathe most publicized gift of United States aid to Cambodia so far. The trucks carried about 1,000 Vietnamese soldiers of Cambodian descent as well as supplies.

title: Scoff Selects Agency For 3d Senate Race
description: For his third Senate race, Senator Hugh Scott, the minority leader, has cast his eyes northward and chosen Lois Holland Callaway.

title: Text of White House Telegram Replying to N.A.A.C.P. Head's Criticism of Administration as AntiNegro
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Followzng is the text of a te,egram from Leonard Garment, special consultant to Predent Nixon, to Bishop Stephen G. Spottswood, chairman of the Board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, replying to a speech by Bishop Spottswood last night that was critical of the Administration's racial policies:

title: Books of The Times
description: Well, the bad news keeps on arriving, in the form of what one used to be able to describe as messages from the female mind. Now that Sisterhood is upon us, though, only a sexist can refer to the female mind without trundling in subordinate clauses about exploitation, hormones, the primordial hunting party and television commercials. All of which is to the good, except for book reviewers who try to slide through their lead paragraphs on a slippery generalization. Here, then, are two first novels, both of them accomplished, and both of them written, happenstantially, by women. Still, the (spiritual) news is bad.

title: May Manufacturers'
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Manufacturers inventories held stable in May while new orders rose, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: NICHOLAS R. JONES
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., June 30  Nicholas R. Jones, a former New York lawyer, died at the Montclair Nursing Home here tonight. He was 90 years old and lived in Glen Cove.

title: Seurat's Les Poseuses Auctioned for $1Million
description: LONDON, June 30  Les Poseuses, a small painting by Georges Seurat, founder of the French neoimpressionist school, was auctioned today at Christie's for $1,033,200.

title: Car Racing Season Approaches Peak With Unusual Twin Bill
description: The next couple of weekends should be among the season's best in motor racing, with major events scheduled by all the principal sanctioning organizations. Michigan International Speedway will run an unusual Twin 200's doubleheader Saturday for United States Auto Club cars.

title: Little Smuggling Found In Kennedy Drug Drive
description: On a typically busy Friday recently, 9,451 passengers passed through the customs gates at Kennedy International Airport, where a steppedup baggage inspection system designed to stem the flow of narcotics has been in effect since early June.

title: Rev. R. H. Buche And Miss Martin Are Wed Here
description: The marriage of Miss Margaret Jean Martin to the Rev. Robert H. Buche, pastor of Trinity Presbyterian Church here, took place in Christ Chapel at the Riverside Church yesterday. The Rev. Robert C. Martin Jr., cousin of the bride, performed the Presbyterian ceremony.The bride is the daughter of Mrs. George Urquhart Martin of Pittsburgh and the late Rev. Dr. Martin, former pastor of the First United Presbyterian Church in Steubenville, Ohio. The bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William F. Bucher of Slater, Iowa. His father was a farmer.

title: Prices on London Stock Exchange Close Higher
Carlos to Doff Track Shoes for Eagles'
description: The Philadelphia Eagles are expected today to sign John Carlos, the sprinter, to a contract and thus begin the conversion of a great athlete from one sport to another. Carlos, winner of two Olympic medals and a world recordholder, will not have much time since the contract is to be for one year. The pact is for around $30,000 and thus Carlos will take a cut. After being chosen on the 15th round of the National Football League draft last January, Carlos set his price at $1million.

title: NEW ROLE BARRED
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 30President Nixon today announced the successful completion of the American incursion in Cambodia, ruled out the use of American troops there in the future and suggested that the country's defense would be left largely to the Cambodians and their Asian allies.

title: NEWTON IS SOUGHT BY PANTHER DEFENSE
description: NEW HAVEN, June 30The defense asked today to have Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, brought here from prison in California to testify in behalf of Lonnie McLucas, a Panther on trial in connection with the kidnapping and murder of a fellow party member.

title: U.N. Unit Advances Session To Decide on Building Funds
description: GENEVA, June 30  The United States was victorious today in its campaign to have United Nations agency speed its decision on whether to advance $10million toward construction of the proposed $80million extension to the United Nations headquarters in New York.

title: 36YEAROLD STAR VANQUISHES ROCHE
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 30Ken Rosewall beat Tony Roche in four enthralling sets today, John Newcombe came out of the abyss to lick Roy Emerson in five and, if anything is sure in tennis, Rosewall will face Roger Taylor and Newcombe will meet Andres Gimeno in the Wimbledon tennis semifinals on Thursday.

title: ANTICRIME FUNDS VOTED BY HOUSE
U.S. Gets $43.7Million In German Offset Accord
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters)  The United States Treasury said today that it received from the West German central bank a deposit of $32million in mixed claims awards and a mutual security loan repayment of $11.7million.

title: JUNIOR GOLF WON BY PHILADELPHIA
description: DEAL, N. J., June 30Once again the Philadelphia junior girls intercity team proved too strong for either New York or Boston, as it won the Mrs. Frank Enos Trophy for the fourth straight year today.

title: FOX TO NEGOTIATE FOR $25MILLION
description: The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation announced yesterday it will negotiate with theEquitable Life Assurance Society past the June 30 takedown date established in an agreement made in December, 1968, for a contemplated $25million loan.

title: Foe of Bias in Broadcasting Is Hopeful
description: Negotiations between broadcast licensees and community groups seeking programing responsive to community needs and the elimination of discriminatory hiring practices will become routine in the foreseeable future, it was predicted yesterday by the Rev. Everett C., Parker, director of the Office of Communication of the United Church of Christ.

title: Shaker Spirit Drawings Recall an Era
description: HANCOCK, Mass., June 30 One of the most exquisite and least familiar forms of 19century American religious artthe socalled Spirit drawings of the Shakersis currently the subject of an unusual exhibition in the handsomely restored Brick Dwelling of the Hancock Shaker Village. The exhibition marks the 10th anniversary of the establishment of the Hancock Shaker Village as a public historical museum.

title: Miss Jane Gottlieb Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Jane Gottlieb and Jordan R. Lefko will be married in August.

title: Rowena McGill Becomes Bride
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., June 30 Miss Rowena McGill, daughter of Dr. William James McGill, chancellor of the University of California at San Diego, who will assume the presidency of Columbia University, was married here on Saturday to Thomas B. Springer.

title: 11 PITCHES RETIRE 3 HITTERS IN ROW
description: In baseball, the best relief pitchers are those who throw strikes, as the managers like to say.

title: MRS. VINCENT E. SMITH
description: Mrs. Virginia Beck Smith, the wife of Dr. Vincent E. Smith, a philosophy professor at Sarah Lawrence College, died Monday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. She had suffered fractured skull in a fall at her home, 17005 Croydon Road, Jamaica Estates, earlier in the day.

title: Text of the Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Following is the text, as amended, of the amendment to fly foreigri military sales bill offered by Senators Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, and John Sherman Cooper, Republican of Kentucky, adopted today by the Senate:

title: A $2,110 Daily Double Liberty Bell's Biggest
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 30Liberty Bell race track had its biggest thoroughbred daily double today when Market Beat ($42.60) and Bob's Doria ($44.60) triumphed for a $2,110.60 payoff.

title: Draft Lottery for Youths Born in 1951 to Be Conducted Today
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Selective Service System will hold its second draft lottery tomorrow amid indications that the random selection process is finally functioning smothly.

title: Brooklyn Bank Alters Name
description: The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, the nation's second largest savings bank, will change its name today to the Dime Savings Bank of New York, The action reflects the fact that two of its six offices and more than half its customers are now outside Brooklyn it said.

title: Market Place:
description: Perhaps the gloom over rising wage costs and sliding profits has been overdone. That's the line the Argus Research Corporation is taking in its Weekly Staff Report, just out.

title: P.S.C. CRITICIZED ON UTILITY COSTS
description: The State Commission of Investigation disclosed yesterday that it had investigated the State Public Service Commission's supervision of electric and gas utilities last year and had, in effect, found its work inadequate in holding down costs.

title: CITY WATER RATES INCREASED BY 75%
description: Shrugging off protests by the brewing, laundry and dairy industries, the Board of Estimate Yesterday voted an acrosstheboard increase of 75 per cent in water rates.

title: COURTROOM NEXT ON INTEGRATION
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 30The Federal Government officially ended today negotiations over desegregation with school districts in the South, 16 years and 1 month after the Supreme Court ruled that racial discrimination in the classroom was unconstitutional.

title: BILL BOLAND IS 2D IN 5THRACE MILE
description: The exacta, in only its second day as part of the betting program of the New York Racing Association, registered a bignumber return yesterday in one of the feature races at Aqueduct.

title: Barge Leaks Fuel in Bay Area
description: MARTINEZ, Calif., June 30 (AP)  A barge being loaded with jet fuel for shipment to San Francisco Bay area airports ruptured today and leaked 600 gallons of kerosene into the Carguinez Straits before workmen stopped the leak. A spokesman for the Shell Oil Company said the fuel would be dissipated in Suisun Bay and that the remainder of the 630,000 gallons was being pumped into another barge.

title: Senate, 5042, Rejects Ban On Arms Aid for Greece
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Senate has rejected a move to ban further arms shipments to the Greek military regime.

title: Richard Wright, Executive Of Carl Byoir, Dies at 57
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., June 30Richard A. Wright, vice president and account executive at Carl Byoir & Associates, a public relations firm, died at a hospital today after suffering a heart attack while visiting friends here. He was 57 years old and lived at 5240 139th Drive. Woodside. Oueens.

title: New Books
description: Rockets in Ursa Major, by Fred Hoyle and Geoffrey Hoyle (Harper & Row, $4.95). Science fiction.

title: O.A.S. Assails Political Terror As a Crime Against Humanity
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters)The Organization of American States today formally condemned terrorism, political kidnapping and extortion as crimes against humanity and the principles of international relations.

title: Egypt Reports Downing 4 Israeli Planes
description: CAIRO, June 30The United Arab Republic reported today that its antiaircraft forces along the Suez Canal had shot down four Isaeli fighterbombers, including two supersonic Phantoms, and that three Israeli pilots had been captured.

title: Chrysler Alters Minicar Design; Delays It to 1972
description: DETROIT, June 30  The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it had abandoned its minicar design in favor of a new design, but that its introduction would be delayed until 1972

title: PRICE OF FUTURES FOR SILVER RISES
description: Silver futures prices rose yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange despite a drop in the prices at the Government's auction in Washington.

title: H.E.W. Offers Charlotte School Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Nixon Administration has proposed for the Supreme Court's consideration a school desegregation plan for Charlotte, N. C., that would prescribe a Northernstyle de facto pattern for the Southern city.

title: Track Supervisor Keeps Rain From Scratching Goshen Card
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., June 30Billy Haughton drove A.C.'s Orion to victory in the E. H. Harriman Challenge Cup No. 45 and Stanley Dancer guided Keystone Memento to the top prize in the Debutante Stake No. 24. But the real hero of today's Grand Circuit harness racing matinee at the 133yearold Historic Track was a 55yearold man who never even had been on a sulky.

title: Bank Bill Talks Recessed
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters)  The Senate Banking committee, which is holding executive meetings to draw up a onebank holdingcompany bill, recessed its hearings until a week from today. The Committee is reported to have several votes pending on key issues of the bill.

title: Maudling, in Ulster, Asks Law and Order
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 30  The British Home Secretary, Reginald Maudling, began a twoday visit here today and, giving little comfort to Northern Ireland's restive Roman Catholic minority, stressed that his first concern was the restoration of law and order.

title: U. S. Indicates Flexibility On a Coalition in Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, June 30With President Nixon placing renewed emphasis on diplomatic efforts to end the Vietnam war, the State Department today indicated more flexibility in the United States approach to the formation of a coalition Government in Saigon.

title: Storm Clouds Over Germany
description: West Germany's coalition has survived one crucial testsince its recent setbacks in three state elections, but the longerrun political outlook in Bonn remains unpromising.

title: Student to Run for House
description: CONCORD, N.H., June 30 (AP)  Mike Dombroski, 28 years old, a University of New Hampshire graduate student, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination to oppose Rep. Louis C. Wyman, Republican of New Hampshire.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President issued his statement on United States policy in Cambodia.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M.

title: Greyhound Wins Decision on Armour
description: A Department of Justice request to enjoin the Greyhound Corporation from exercising control over Armour & Co., the meatpacking company, was denied yesterday by a Federal judge in Chicago.Judge Julius J. Hoffman, who rejected the contentions of the Government agency and dismissed its complaint, said that the department was free to file a separate action if it believed Greyhound was in violation of any antitrust laws. The department had charged that Greyhound's acquisition of Armour control last month violated 1920 consent decree barring meat packers from expanding into certain food lines.

title: YIELDS DROP AGAIN IN CREDIT MARKET
H. LeVan Richards, 70, Is Dead; Umpire for Tennis Tournaments
description: WASHINGTON, June 30H LeVan Richards, a prominent tennis official for many years until his retirement in 1965 died today in George Washing. ton Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: Miss Blinder, Student, Is Wed
description: At Temple Young Israel of Forest Hills, Queens, last night, Miss Medinah Blinder, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Samuel Blinder of Albany, was married to Charles Popper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Popper of New Rochelle, N. Y. The bride's father, rabbi of Congregation Sons of Abraham in Albany, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Rabbi Philip Weinberger.

title: NASA Plans Extensive Changes on Apollo to Eliminate Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Extensive changes costing $10million to $15million will be made to Apollo spacecraft before men can be sent to the moon again, the National Aeronotics and Space Administration said today.

title: Modern Art Museum Names Film Curator
description: Donald Richie has been appointed curator of the film department of the Museum of Modern Art. The 46yearold film historian, author, critic and former resident of Japan, has just completed a year's term as visiting curator of the department, which is headed by Willard Van Dyke.

title: O'Herron Sees Payrolls Assured, but Gorman Is Gloomy on Survival
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Penn Central Transportation Company closed its books last night with approximately $35million in its depository banks and expects no problem with its payrolls of $20million a week for the foreseeable future. This reassurance was given Congress today by the company's executive vice president for finance, Jonathan O'Herron.

title: Carmine Abbatiello Aspires to Top Driving Honors
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 30 Eight years after Carmine Abbatiello and Rex Pick, a pacer, team up, Abbatiello is still going strong. Rex Pick is, well, just going.

title: Gravel Says Group Urges Killing of Dovish Senators
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, told the Senate tonight that an organization calling itself the National Socialist White People's partythe former American Nazi party was urging the assassination of several dovish members of the Senate.

title: $520Million Asked
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The new schedule of sales commissions that the New York; Stock Exchange formally proposed today to the Government would add $520million annually to the gross revenues of brokers, according to the exchange's estimates.Proportionally, firms that dot a retail business with the public will reap the largest share of the rise. Their increased gross earnings were estimated at 35 per cent by the exchange, compared with a 15 per cent increase for firms whose primary business is with large institutional investors such as banks, pension and mutual funds and insurance companies.

title: Rabbi Appeals for Funds To Set Up Jewish Colleges
description: FALLSBURGH, N. Y., June 30The head of the largest Jewish Orthodox rabbinic body in the Western Hemisphere called upon Jewish welfare funds and federations today to establish 10 Jewish colleges in major cities to arrest the decline of Jewish cultural and spiritual life.

title: Arnold Constable Reports Resignation of Chairman
description: Isaac Liberman has resigned as chairman of Arnold Constable, Inc., the Fifth Avenuebased retail chain announced yesterday.

title: ASIAN CURRENCY PUSHED BY GROUP
description: MANILA, June 30 (UPI)A move was under way today to establish an Asian currency to spur interregional trade and reduce dependence on the United States dollar and other currencies

title: Until Appeal, McSorley Is Still Male Ale House
description: Federal Judge Walter R. Mansfield granted permission yesterday to McSorley's Old Ale House to continue denying entry to women, as it has for more than a century.

title: Spain's Parliament Gets Scandal Data
description: MADRID, June 30  The Spanish Cortes, or Parliament, met in secret session today for the first time in its history to hear a report that criticized one member of the Cabinet and two former members in a huge financial scandal.

title: N.E.A. FIGHT LOOMS OVER PAROCHIAL AID
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 Another dispute over public spending to help parochial schools loomed today as the million member National Education Association opened its 108th annual convention.

title: Liberal Party Elects
description: The Liberal party announced yesterday the reelection of the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington for another twoyear term as state chairman. Among the vice chairmen reelected at its State Committee meeting Monday night were David Dubinsky, Alex Rose and Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello.

title: Buckley Urges April 1 Ban on Draftees in Vietnam
description: James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for United States Senator, strongly urged President Nixon yesterday to announce that no draftee would have to fight in Vietnam after April 1.

title: FREEDOM IN PERIL LIBRARIAN WARNS
description: DETROIT, June 30  The president of the American Library Association called today for more vigorous responses to what he characterized as a growing threat to intellectual freedom stemming from hysterical charges and counter charges.

title: Turkey Further Reduces OpiumCultivation Area
description: ANKARA, Turkey, June 30The Turkish Government, in compliance wtih American and international requests, today reduced from nine to seven the number of provinces where the cultivation of the opium poppy is legal.

title: Bridge:
description: STOCKHOLM, June 30The United States representatives fought their way back into contention in the fourth session of the world pair championship here tonight after starting slowly in the earlier sessions.

title: 3 Main Whaling Countries Will Keep Antarctic Quota
description: LONDON, June 30Representatives of Japan, Norway and the Soviet Union, the three main whaling countries, have agreed here to maintain the present catch limit of 2,700 whale units for the Antarctic.

title: Boyle Urges Enforcement Of U.S. Mine Safety Laws
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The head of the United Mine Workers has appealed to President Nixon to enforce the m?? safety laws and end what he called deliberate footdragging by the Interior Department and its Bureau of Mines.

title: Plan to Buy Back Used Bottles Set
description: The Glass Container Manufacturers Institute announced a nationwide program yesterday to buy used bottles, at a penny pound, and reuse them in the manufacture of new ones.

title: DEMETRIOS PATILIS OF GREEK JUNTA, 57
description: ATHENS, June 30 Lieut Gen. Demetrios Patilis, retired Second Deputy Premier of Greece, died in an Athens military hospital today of a cerebral hemorrahage. He was 57 years old.

title: Czech Diplomat Defects to U.S. After Prague Calls Him Home
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Czechoslovak Embassy's scientific affairs officer has defected to the United States, reportedly upon receiving orders to return home after 18 months in Washington.

title: A Matter of Principle
description: Public accounting is a curious profession. Above all else, an accountant wants his imprimatur to be taken as mark of credibilityan assurance to creditors, investors and the general public that a company's affairs have been fairly and properly reported in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.

title: Loew's Sets Operating Net Peak But Stock Deals Cut Its Income
description: Loew's Theatres, Inc., which will become Loew's Corporation at the fiscal yearend, achieved record operating earnings for the three and nine months ended May 31 before taking into account its losses from securities transactions.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Chaparrals Obtain Moore From Colonels in Trade
description: DALLAS, June 30 (UPI)The Texas Chaparrals of the American Basketball Association got Gene Moore, a 6foot9inch center, from the Kentucky Colonels today, but the price proved high.

title: PictureTelephone Service Is Started in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, June 30A major stride in the development of communications was taken today with the start of commercial Picturephone calls. An executive of the Bell Telephone System expressed the view that the economic and social impact of electronic facetoface communication would equal that made by the introduction of telephonic voice conversation in New Haven in 1878. Mayor Petor F. Flaherty dialed the Inaugural call from the stage of an auditorium in the building of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania. The 5by5inch screen on his Picturephone set, which looks like a small portable television, remained blank. Redial, Mr. Mayor, a Bell official called out. He did. The smiling image of John D. Harper, chairman of the board of the Aluminum Company of America, flashed clear and sharp in black and white onto the screen from his office in sharp in black and white onto building.

title: Met Begins Its Free Park Series With Anne Moffo in Lucia Role
description: The placid trees around Central Park's Sheep Meadow and the brilliantly lit skyscrapers in the background scarcely suggested the wilds of Scotland, but last night Donizetti's music was soaring through the area to tell an audience of many thousands that Lucy of Lammermoor was going mad because her love for Edgar of Ravenswood had been thwarted.

title: Nasser and Podgorny Ask Peaceful Mideast Solution
description: MOSCOW, June 30  President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union tonight joined in advocating a peaceful settlement of tensions in the Middle East.

title: GEORGE M. PERKINS
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., June 30George M. Perkins, director of network radio programs for the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., died yesterday at United Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 128 Betsy Brown Road.

title: 2 IN BIRCH SOCIETY ELECTED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, June 30 (AP) Two Republican members of the John Birch Society were elected tonight to fill unexpired terms in Southern California Congressional districts.

title: Free Film Festival Set for 7 Parks
description: Jonathan Kaplan has a can of film and a good deal of hope. B. William Kostecke has a can of beer and a good deal of money. August Heckscher had a vague dream and a good deal of park space.

title: WHITE MAN HEADS POLICE IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, June 30  Kenneth A. Gibson, who will be sworn in as Newark's first black Mayor tomorrow, named a white policeman today to the post of Police Director, one of the most sensitive positions in this city, where racial tensions were heightened by the bitter mayoral race.

title: Another Big Crowd
description: Another remarkable streak the Mets have going is this: There have been 13 straight crowds of 30,000plus at Shea stadium. In all, the paid attendance has exceeded 30,000 19 times in the last 24 home dates and, since the first real Met winning streak 13 months ago, 51 times in the last 78 dates.

title: Bond Stores Selects President
description: James Posner has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Bond Stores, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Bond Industries. Bond Stores, which had sales of $82.8million in the nine months ended April 30, operates 147 retail clothing stores and four manufacturing plants.

title: War in Cambodia Perils Oxen of Fossil Species
description: A living relic of the early evolution of modern cattle is threatened with extinction by the fighting in Cambodia, according to a report by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature.

title: NEGRO PASSED OVER BY THE GIRLS NATION
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 1 Vicki Lynn Miles, a Negro who was elected last month as governor of Oklahoma Girls State, has been passed over by officials of the American Legion Auxiliary in choosing delegatesto Girls Nation.

title: Sachs, Los Angeles Broker, Discontinues Operations
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) The Sacks Investment Company, a small securities concern dealing primarily in overthecounter stocks, is the sixth Los Angeles stock brokerage company to go out of business this year.

title: Witness Says a Detective Took $5,000 Reward in Theft Case
description: An official of Montgomery Ward testified yesterday that he had given three brown envelopes containing $5,000 in cash to Detective Tobia Spina in the bar of a midtown hotel.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President was in Los Angeles preparing for his discussion of foreign affairs later in the evening with the three major broadcasting networks. He signed a bill raising the national debt ceiling by $18billion to $395billion. The President signed Executive orders implementing a major reorganization of his White House staff.

title: Another Shop Is Joining the Trend
description: Following what he believes to be a trend in the business, Bob Fiore is closing down Chappell, Fiore, Endelman, the ad agency he helped to found in 1967, to open (with James Walsh) Fiore & Walsh, a Durelv creative bag.

title: CHECKTHEFT RING REPORTED BROKEN
description: Five members of an alleged checksterling ring that reportedly cashed $500,000 In stolen welfare checks in the last two years, were arrested here yesterday by Investigation Department detectives.

title: Soviet Suggests New Plan To End Mideast Conflict
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 1The Soviet Union has put forward new suggestions for a settlement of the Middle East conflict, and informed Western sources described them today as a substantial move forward.

title: Court Denies War Is Unconstitutional
description: A solders's contenuon that combat activities in Indochina were unconstitutional because Congress had not declared war was rejected yesterday by a Federal judge in Brooklyn.

title: Article 1  No Title
SWEIG TRIAL TOED OF VISIT TO S,E.C.
description: Dr. Martin Sweig told the Federal grand jury that indicted him here that he had visited the Securities and Exchange Commission with an executive who wanted a trading ban lifted from his company's stock. But, he insisted, he went for one reason only: He wanted to see the S.E.C.'s new headquarters in Washington.

title: Rockwell Gets Contract
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) The North American Rockwell Corporation has obtained a $34million subcontract from the Boeing Company of Seattle for work on the supersonic transport program.

title: GIBSON, SWORN IN, CALLS FOR UNITY
description: NEWARK, July 1Kenneth A. Gibson, a product of rural Alabama, was inaugurated today as the first black mayor of Newark. He immediately appealed for unity from all persons interested In the future of the city.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: F. D. Roosevelt Jr. Weds Mrs. Sarnoff
description: Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr. and Mrs. Felicia Schiff Warburg Sarnoff were married here yesterday in a brief civil ceremony at the chambers of State Supreme Court Justice Frederick Blacker, an old friend of the bridegroom's, who officiated.

title: Arthur B. Baer, 75, Headed St. Louis Department Store
description: ST. LOUIS, July 1Arthur B. Baer, former president and executive committee chairman of the Stix, Baer & Fuller department stores, died today in hospital, apparently of a stroke. He was 75 years old.

title: Where Birth and Abortion Cases Meet
description: Ten of 14 women who applied for care at Harlem Hospital's obstetrics and gynecology clinic yesterday wanted abortions and often made their need known only after a great deal of hesitancy as nurses delicately questioned them.

title: Arms for the Colonels
description: President Nixon will make a mistake if he interprets the Senate's narrow rejection of an arms embargo against Greece as a signal for fullscale resumption military aid to the Athens junta. Some Senators probably voted against Senator Hartke's ban on arms sales only because they were unwilling to tie the President's hands on a security matter, not because they wanted to help entrench the Papadopoulos regime.

title: OneMan Grand Jury Studies Shootings by Connecticut Police
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 1  An unusual oneman grand jury investigation was ordered here yesterday into the fatal shooting of two Groton, Conn., brothers in a state police stakeout, and the suicide by hanging of a narcotics suspect in a. cell in a state nonce barracks.

title: Former Senator Overheard In 3 Government Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) The Justice Department disclosed today that Government agents monitoring wiretaps to gather foreign intelligence overheard former Senator Daniel B. Brewster, Democrat of Maryland, on three occasions.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: In Canada
description: MUSQUARO LAKE, Quebec Rain, fog and sharp winds blowing from almost every quarter of the Compass bedeviled us during three of our four days of fishing, and most of the brook trout and ouananiche (landlocked salmon) we took were small by Musquaro Lake standards.

title: Building Bombed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) A bomb was thrown through a back door of the InterAmerican Defense Board building early today. The chauffeur's room and an adjoining bathroom were damaged. No one was injured.

title: Cards Sign Son of Sievers
description: ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP)Robin Sievers, son of Roy Sievers, the former St. Louis Browns slugger, signed a contract today with the St. Louis Cardinals for an estimated $15,000 bonus. The 18yearold plays third base.

title: Penn Four Triumphs Easily at Henley

title: New Chief of the Navy

The senior officer returned the greeting and flashed an ironic erin. Today, as he assumed the position of Chief of Naval Operations, Admiral Zumwalt became the commanding officer of his former superior and 696,000 other men who compose the active strength of the Navy. He will have few men to call boss.

title: Screen: 'Junie Moon' at the Beekman:Liza Minnelli Stars in Preminger Film 3 Self-Styled 'Freaks' Set Up a Home
description: Otto Preminger's "Tell Me That You Love Me, Junie Moon," which opened yesterday at the Beekman Theater, is about three gallant, self-styled "freaks" who set up housekeeping together in a broken-down bungalow that comes complete with a banyan tree in the backyard, a hoot owl in the banyan tree, a Peeping Tom next door, and a rich, spooky landlady who dresses like a World War I ace in leather helmet, leather jacket, tinted goggles and long, flowing scarf.Half of the face of Junie Moon (Liza Minnelli) has looked like Lon Chaney's Phantom of the Opera (or, at least, it is supposed to look that way) ever since a traveling salesman topped off their date by knocking Junie Moon into the mud and then pouring battery acid over her. Arthur (Ken Howard) is tall, blond and very handsome, but aside from the fact that he has an occasional seizure and sort of lopes when he walks, you'd hardly know that he suffers from a progressive neurological disorder that is turning his body into mush.In some ways the most pathetic member of the trio, perhaps because he seems the most resolutely self-contained, is Warren (Robert Moore), a red-bearded, barrel-chested homosexual who likes to make brownies and to use words like "divine" to describe things on the order of swimming trunks. Warren has been confined to a wheel-chair ever since he was 17 when, during a hunting trip, he made a pass at a friend who promptly shot him in the spine.In the course of Marjorie Kellog's tiny, moving novel, Junie Moon, Arthur and Warren, abandoned by their families, their friends and, to a large extent, the world, discover self and love so quietly and unobtrusively that the reader feels he has made the discovery himself. In the film, based on a screenplay by Miss Kellogg, there is never any doubt that the process of discovery is being led by Preminger.Much like one of the dispassionate doctors in Junie Moon's state hospital, who displays his patients to visiting medical men without ever listening to the patients' complaints, Preminger displays his characters without ever revealing them, or letting them reveal themselves. In "Junie Moon," the people never seem more important than the things Preminger places around them, like the hoot owl and the scroungy old dog Arthur befriends, or more important than the theatrical lighting, which makes real locations look like studio backdrops, and the clever techniques (flashback scenes are printed from unsqueezed anamorphic footage).This sense of display, which is not to be confused with visual spectacle, works quite well in movies of melodramatic event ("Hurry Sundown," "In Harm's Way," "Anatomy of a Murder"), but it is completely inappropriate for movies dealing with such private emotions as loneliness, embarrassment and suddenly recognized friendship. These things are difficult to see when you look at them directly; they have to be discovered out of the corner of the eye.Preminger doesn't direct movies as much as he makes frontal assaults on them. It's no accident that the most vivid moments in "Junie moon" are either the most cruel or the most bizarre, not because Preminger is cruel and bizarre, but because they fit into his melodramatic view of things. Junie Moon, shivering and feeling slightly silly, being forced to do a strip tease in a cemetery, in the dead of night, for a kinky boyfriend, while the soundtrack alternates between delicate Bach and something that sounds like old Stan Kenton.If anything, however, Preminger has been too sparing of our feelings. Miss Minnelli's Junie Moon is an exuberant, appealing misfit, but she really doesn't look very badly mangled (at one point in the novel Miss Kellogg describes her nose as a trench). Ken Howard's Arthur is so nice and healthy, if a bit shy, I couldn't believe he suffered from anything worse than a bad charley horse. By softening these edges, Preminger has, ironically, denied his characters the terror that is their right, and the affection that is ours.The most appealing person in the film is a beautifully commonplace fishmonger, played by James Coco, an aging bachelor who befriends Junie Moon and her friends and, much to his own surprise, falls in love with the very odd girl. I also liked Moore, who speaks his lines (fast, theatrically) like a director of Broadway comedies, which he is "Promises, Promises," "The Last of the Red Hot Lovers")."Tell Me That You Love Me, Junie Moon" is not an unintelligent film, but it is so cool and ordinary that it almost made me nostalgic for "Skidoo," which was epically bad but the obvious work of a brazenly gifted director.

title: HONOR AMERICA AIDE SCORES 2 NETWORKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 J. Willard Marriott, chairman of the executive committee for Honor America Day, criticized tonight the American Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System for not planning to give live coverage to his group's July 4 entertainment program.

title: Observer: A BlueRibbon Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, July 1After the President's expansion of the.war into Cambodia had created intense controversy throughout the country, President Nixon announced that he would look into the Cambodian invasion at the end of June and report to the people.

title: Bridge

title: 5 Presidents Agreed: Bruce Is a Giant
description: When he retired in March, 1969, after eight years as United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James'sthe longest any one had held that postDavid K. E. Bruce, was America's senior Ambassador. Before the London assignment he had been Ambassador in Paris and Bonn, At the age of 72, he is the only man ever to have served in this country's three leading embassies in Western Europe.

title: Fewer Merger Plans
description: CHICAGO, July 1 (UPI)Corporate merger activity lightened in the first half of 1970, but many companies cleaned house, disposing of unwanted division's and product lines.

title: Lear Siegler Gets Job
description: Lear Siegler, Inc., has received a fiveyear Air Force contract for aircraft and aerospace systems maintenance valued at $50million. The company said this was the fourth consecutive call contract it has received from the Air Force.

description: PHIADELPHIA, July 1Mike Manganello moved into a firstplace riding tie today with Marty Fromin by winning three races at Liberty Bell race track. Each has 19 victories.

description: WASHINGTON, July 1Congressional experts agreed today that the most difficult issue in the way of, prompt final action on the Post Office reorganization bill was the union shop for postal employes.

description: Production of motor vehicles by the four major United States manufacturers in June was more than 3 per cent higher than output in the comparable 1969 months.

description: BOSTON, July 1 (AP)The Knights of Columbus indoor track meet is ending its 44year history because of financial problems.. The event, held in Boston Garden, has drawn fewer and fewer fans over the Iast few years.

description: Samuel R. Pierce was sworn in yesterday as general counsel of the Treasury Department by Secretary David M. Kennedy.

description: The S.S. Kresge Company and the Interstate Stores Corporation, the first major retail chains to report June sales, had gains of 18.1 per cent and 7.4 per cent, respectively, over the yearago month.

description: The economist of the country's leading investment banking firm asserted yesterday that longterm interest rates have passed their peak. Albert M. Wojnilower, vice president of the First Boston Corporation, gave this unhedged view at a press luncheon to announce publication of the firm's handbook of, Government securities, a biannual booklet put out for institutional investors.

description: ROME, July 1  President Nixon's new envoy to the Vatican, Henry Cabot Lodge, started out on a lowkey mission in hotel suite today.

description: DETROIT, July 1Denny McLain returned to baseball tonight after a fourmonth suspension for bookmaking activities and received two standing ovations from a sellout crowd of 53,836 persons in Tiger Stadium.

description: MIAMI, July 1 (AP)A San Francisco to Miami National Airlines jet was diverted to Cuba today with 39 persons aboard, including two crew members who have been on other forced flights to Havana.

description: STANTON, Del., July 1 (AP) Walter M. Jeffords Jr.'s Abdallati, an oddsonchoice in the mileandasixteenth grass feature at Delaware Park, survived a claim of foul today to give the favorite followers their fifth success of the afternoon.

description: NEWARK, July 1 (AP)A fire that officials believe was set by arsonists swept through two threestory frame buildings here early today, killing six persons, four of them children.

[In Cairo, the authoritative newspaper Al Abram reported that Mr. Nasser had extended his visit to Moscow until next week.]

description: BONN, July 1Further opposition to Chancellor Willy Brandt's policy of rapprochement with Eastern Europe was stirred today after a newspaper published the last installment of what it termed as the secret text of a draft treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: NIXON AIDES PUSH WELFARE REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The Nixon Administration has begun a rescue mission to get its welfare reform program reported out of a hostile Senate Finance Committee.

description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell and his wife, Martha, were hosts today at a swinging 100th birthday celebration for the usually staid Justice Department.

description: LOS ANGELES, July 1President Nixon announced tonight the appointment of David K. E. Bruce to head the United States delegation at the Paris talks on Peace in Vietnam.

title: Savings Outflows Trail Last Year's At Quarter's End

description: Nineteenyearold Eleanor Patterson, a college student who is a Roman Catholic and lives with her parents on the East Side, arrives at Metropolitan Hospital, 1901 First Avenue, alone. Unmarried, she is 15 weeks along in her first pregnancy. She did not use contraceptives and said she was turned off by mechanical devices, but might be interested in taking birth control pills.
