description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 1Brazilian authorities today stormed a Brazilian jet airliner that had been grounded here by hijackers who threatened to kill the passengers one by one.

title: New Knowledge of Drugs Is Explored
description: When do drugs become toxic? How is a safe dosage determined for any drug? Why does each individual react to drugs differently? How do drugs interact with one another in the body? How do certain drugs produce tissue damage?

description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)Justice Department lawyers celebrated their agency's 100th birthday today with a plea by a former employe of the department, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, to put fair administration of justice above winning cases

description: HONG KONG, July 1 (AP)North Vietnam charged today that the United States, despite the withdrawal of its ground troops from Cambodia, was prolonging the war in Southeast Asia by aiding antiCommunist forces.

title: Jazzmobile Begins Season in Harlem on a High Note
description: It may have gone unnoticed in the rest of the boroughs, but yesterday was Jazzmobile Day in Manhattan, and in honor of the occasion Harlem rocked to some of the hottest jazz this side of Basin Street.

title: GOSHEN TROT WON BY NEYELE RASCAL
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., July 1This was a day for Grand Circuit competition on the 133yearold Historic Track.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: The Guam Doctrine in essence contemplated that Asians shall fight Asians, if war be needed, for the attainment of American strategic objectives. But your June 25 editorial Seoul Resists Koreanization finds it a discouraging augury for the Administration's Vietnamization (read Asianization) program that. South Korea, protected and nurtured by the United States for twenty years, seemingly cannot_bear gradual reduction of the U. S. garrison force of 64,000 men down to a token ground force with residual air support.

title: They're Working Their Way Through Jail
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa.The tall graying man is an Annapolis graduate with a background in law. For the last eight months he has been working as a teacher at a local high school here. During this period he has also been an inmate a the Bucks County jail.

title: BRITON TRIUMPHS BY 63,119,1210
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 1It will be Mrs. Margaret Court against Mr. Billie Jean King for the women's title at Wimbledon on Friday, just as everybody knew all along.

title: Norman Tulchin, Business Aide, Weds Miss Alice Berc Robinson
description: Miss Alice Berc Robinson and Norman Tulchin were married here at noon yesterday by Rabbi Judah Cahn in his study at the Metropolitan Synagogue.

title: Britain Gives Assurances On Common Market Talks
description: BRUSSELS, July 1 (Reuters) Britain assured the ambassadors of Commonwealth and European Free Trade Association nations today that she would keep their governments closely informed of progress in negotiations with the Common Market.

title: Sports of The Times
description: DETROIT, July 1His hair had been bleached blond by the Florida sun and his smile betrayed his delight as Denny McLain arrived in the Detroit Tigers clubhouse. Outside, the humidity of the late afternoon seeped through Tiger Stadium, but Denny McLain, his suspension ended by decree of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, was happy to be working again.

title: ALLIES IN SWEEP NEAR PNOMPENH
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 1 (AP)  More than 5,000 South Vietnamese troops swept areas north of Pnompenh today as over 800 Vietnamese soldiers of Cambodian descent arrived in a 40truck convoy to bolster the Cambodian capital's defenses.

title: Motorcyclist Dies in Chase
description: A 24yearold motorcyclist was killed yesterday during a wild chase of more than five miles through three sections of Staten Island. The victim who was shot by the police in the shoulder and fell from his motorcycle, was identified as David Manahan of 383 Britton Avenue, Concord. He was pronounced dead an arrival at Staten Island Hospital.

title: S.E.C. Hearings Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to hold public hearings before acting on the New York Stock Exchange's request for permission to allow brokers to charge higher fees.

title: Anna W. Dickinson, Smith 1970, Engaged to Richard Booth Platt
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., July Miss Anna Wilson Dickinson, a 1970 graduate of Smith College, and Richard Booth Platt, who was graduated last year from Yale, are planning to be wed Oct. 10.

title: Weis, Voisin, Cannon, Inc., Is Cutting Salaries by 10%
description: Weis, Voisin, Cannon, Inc., brokerage house with 19 offices in the United States, has informed its employes that their salaries would be reduced 10 per cent. A memorandum to personnel said the salary cut was caused by conditions in the industry.

title: MILLS ADVOCATES NEW IMPORT CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has asked the Nixon Administration to explore the possibility of a general trigger mechanism that could lead to ?? quotas on any product experiencing a disruptive increase in imports.

title: Chess:
description: The recently published 70th Annual United States Open Championship, 1969, by Jack Spence, includes 124 games, selected from the entire roster of 1,188 from the 12round Swiss tourney at the Hotel Lincoln, Lincoln, Neb.

title: EXMAYOR J. H. MAGEE OF BELLEROSE DEAD
description: James H. Magee, who was Mayor of Bellerose, Queens, from 1932 to 1964, died Tuesday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola. He was 82 years old and lived at 74 Ontario Road, Bellerose.

title: Policemen Wounded In Jersey Disorder Dies After Surgery
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 1The death this afternoon of one of two policemen who was shot by snipers shortly after midnight Monday while protecting firemen at a blaze produced new tensions in this racially ocdarized city of 45.000.

title: Police in Argentina City Win Pay Rise by a SitIn
description: ROSARIO, Argentina, July 1 (Reuters)  The police returned to work today after gaining wage increases from provincial authorities during a 21hour sitin at police headQuarters.

title: National Lead Lifts Price Of Antimony Oxide by 25c
description: The National Lead Company raised the price of antimony oxide yesterday by 25 cents pound, to $1.63. The higher costs of materials was cited.

title: Justice and Juries
description: The jury is so venerated in the United States that denial of the Benefits of Trial by Jury was one of the complaints in the Declaration of Independence; the Constitution the jury system is covered by an article and no fewer than three amendments. The guarantees of trial by jury are firm though the methods are flexible; it is this characteristic combination that makes of the Constitution a living document.

title: Maudling Asserts Tories Back Ulster Reform Plan
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 1The British Home Secretary, Reginald Maudling took a determinedly optimistic view of Northern Ireland's sectarian troubles today and called the tense situation a mixture of danger and hope.

title: SCHOOL LIBRARIAN ASKS FEDERAL AID
description: DETROIT, July 1  Almost half of the nation's 92,000 elementary schools lack adequate library facilities because they cannot afford to hire trained personnel, the American library Association was told today.

title: 2 Films Reflect Sound and Fury of War
Bengals Get Chiefs'
description: KANSAS CITY, July 1 (AP)Hank Stram, Kansas City Chiefs coach, announced today the Chiefs had traded Caeser Belser, a safetyman to the Cincinnati Bengals for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: Another Piece of Moon Missing at Space Lab
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has reported that another piece of the moon is missing.

title: Board Chairman Picked By Shell Oil Company
description: The election of David H. Barran as chairman of the board of directors of the Shell Oil Company was announced yesterday. He succeeds Monroe E. Spaght, who will continue as a director.

title: Navy Gets Bermuda Air Base
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters)The United States Air Force today turned over its Kindley Base in Bermuda to the United States Navy for antisubmarine patrols by longrange aircraft. The base now will be called the U. S. Naval Air Station, Bermuda.

title: Published Truth on Sealed Trial Held Libelous
description: ALBANY, July 1 (AP)  The Court of Appeals held today that truth could not be used as absolute defense in libel and invasion of privacy cases that involved the publication of material that courts had ordered to be secret.

title: Dalegates to Consumer Parley Test Their Ideas in Austrian Spa's Shops
description: BADEN, Austria, July 1 Shortly before dusk Miss Mitsuko Tabuse walked along the Ringstrasse and stopped at one of the half a dozen wooden stalls selling fruits and vegetables.

title: Dues Checkoff Kept as Sanitationmen Bar Strike
description: The Lindsay administration agreed yesterday not to cancel the union dues checkoff of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association if the union held off any strike action until April 1, 1973.

title: Honor America Day in State
description: ALBANY, July 1 (AP)Governor Rockefeller has proclaimed Saturday, July 4, Honor America Day in New York State. He said in a statement today that there is no more fitting place than the Empire State in which to reaffirm, in song and ceremony, our love of country, our devotion to America.

title: CHRYSLER WIDENS BANKCREDIT LINE
description: DETROIT, July 1The Chrysler Corporation said today it had arranged a substantial increase in its bank credit line for its subsidiary, the Chrysler Financial Corporation.

title: Advertising: Life's Answer to Look's Cuts
description: If you have been waiting to see what Life would do to counter Look's announcement that it was cutting back its circulation to 6.5 million by early next spring with 80 per cent of it in the 60 top markets, well here it is.

title: 10,000 Tires Recalled
West German Output Gains
description: BONN, July 1 (Reuters)The economics ministry said today that German industrial production in May rose 7.5 per cent over April on a daily average basis and was 10.8 per cent above the level of May 1969. This reverses the trend of April, when the ministry spoke of a slackeningoff in economic activity.

title: West Point '74 Reports
description: WEST POINT, N. Y. (AP)The United States Military Academy class of 1974 reported to duty today, the largest class in West Point's history. Frederick Borman, son of Frank Borman, the astronaut, a West Point graduate who joined the Air Force and commanded the Apollo VIII and Gemini VII missions, was among the 1,378 new cadets. The class contains 40 blacks and 13 other members of minority groups.

title: New Safety Standards
description: Effective yesterday, all homes for the aged, homes and residences for adults, residential hotels for senior citizens and similar facilities in the state must meet minimum safety, space, occupancy, health, welfare and other requirements, the State Department of Social Services said yesterday.

title: PHOTOCOPY PRICES INCREASED BY ZEROX
description: The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday that, effective Aug. 1, it would put into effect price increases ranging from onefifth of a cent each for copies produced on the Xerox 2400 to an increase of $5 in the monthlyuse charge for the models 914 and 720.

title: President Regrets Overriding of Veto; Urges Fiscal Care
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 1The White House issued another plea today for fiscal responsibility and said Congress would have to bear the consequences of costly legislation.

title: Abortions Begun in State Under Liberal New Law
description: Scores of abortions were performed in hospitals throughout the state yesterday on the day a new state lawthe nation's most liberal on abortionswent into effect.

title: POSITIONS HARDEN IN WNEW WALKOUT
description: The strike by engineers and technicians against the Metromedia, Inc., television stations here and in Washington is in its sixth week, and neither side appears ready to alter its position on the prime issuethe manning of automated and computerized equipment.

title: Board Defeat Angers Cornfeld
description: TORONTO, July 1Bernard Cornfeld charged today that the new management of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., had deceitfully caused him to lose his seat on the board of directors of the mutual fund and financial empire he founded.

title: DOCTORS HERE GET ABORTION LESSON
description: About 80 doctors attended teachin here yesterday to learn how to do abortions safely in their offices or in clinics.

title: ExInmates of Belsen Mark '45 Liberation
description: BERGEN, West Germany, July 1 (AP)Three hundred Jews, former inmates of the Nazi BergenBtlsen death camp, commemorated the 25th anniversary of their liberation today with a procession of silence beside mass graves of many of the camp's 50,000 victims.

title: SUSPEND JUDGE, DRIVERS DEMAND
description: A controversy over the $94,335 Realization Trot, won by Pridewood at Roosevelt Raceway last Saturday night, deepened yesterday. The National Association of Harness Drivers asked that the track's presiding judge, John Cashman, be suspended.

title: Excerpts From Moynihan's Statement to Urban Coalition on Nixon Welfare Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Following are excerpts from a statement by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, counselor to the President, on the Administration's welfare program, delivered today before representatives of business at a briefing arranged by the Urban Coalition Action Council:

title: 25 to 30% Pay Rise Averts Strike at Private Hospitals
description: Nonmedical hospital employes will receive pay increases of 25 to 30 per cent over two years as a result of a lastminute settlement early yesterday that averted a walkout at 34 nonprofit, private institutions.

title: Sihanouk Ends Korea Visit
description: TOKYO, July 1 (UPI)Prince Norodom Sihanouk left North Korea by train today for Peking, the seat of his government in exile, the North Korean press agency reported.

title: Mir Retains Fleet Lead 600 Miles From Tahiti
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP)  The 78foot ketch Mir continued to lead the 14boat fleet in the Los AngelestoTahiti race today, and the 54foot sloop Widgeon held the handicap lead as the race entered its final stage.

title: State Warns on Eating Fish Taken From St. Lawrence
description: ALBANY, July 1The State Conservation Department reported today that, on the basis of laboratory data received relative to mercury contamination of fish, it is advising fishermen not to eat fish taken from the St. Lawrence River.

title: Leonard lnskip, 69, Dies; Electrical Engineer at Bell
description: RIPTON, Vt., July 1Leonand S. Inskip, a former electricalprotection engineer at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., died at his home here yesterday. He was 69 years old.

title: LICENSE RENEWALS IN MEMPHIS OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 Black Community organizations in Memphis petitioned the Federal Communications Commission today to deny license renewal for two television stations here, on the ground that the stations hiring and programing are discriminatory. The stations are WREC and WHBO.

title: SIR LAURENCE DUNNE, EISLER CASE FIGURE
description: LONDON, July 1 (Reuters)Sir Laurence Dunne, who as London's Chief Magistrate refused to extradite Gerhard Eisler to the United States, died yesterday while on a fishing vacation at Stockbridge. He was 76 years old.

title: Javits Favors New U.S. Agency
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits called on the Nixon Administration yesterday to take the lead in creating a new Government agency to help tide companies over what he termed the liquidity crisis now.facing the financial markets.

title: Theater: Chronicles of King Henry VI
description: The Wars of the Roses have come to Central Park and will remain there all summer provided Joseph Papp, New York's own truepenny Shakespearean, wins his own private war for his New York Shakespeare Festival against the forces of darkness. Mr. Papp needs lots of money right nownot next week but this week. I would be failing in my duty as a critic if I did not point this out instantly.

title: Armstrong Leads With Left
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Neil A. Armstrong, the first man on the moon, started to take an oath of office today With his wrong hand on the Bible. Dr. Thomas O. Paine, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, swore him in as NASA's deputy associate administrator for aeronautics. Put your right hand on the Bible, Dr. Paine, said. Mr. Armstrong obeyed and raised his left hand. Dr., Paine quickly corrected his instructions amid laughter.

title: Public Works Head Installed
description: Alfred C. Maevis, former chief engineer of the Transit Authority, was sworn in today as the city's Public Works Commissioner. He succeeds Frederick A. Davidson Jr., who resigned to return to private industry. The post pays $35,000 a year.

title: SPERRY BUTLER
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 1Sperry Butler, a partner in the law firm of Albertson, Simmons & Butler, died today at New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived at 40 Lord Kitchener Road.

title: Pilots'
description: The Air Lines Pilots Association, which threatened last year to stop flying into jet airports that the organization contended lacked adequate equipment for coping with crashes and fires, has reported that 23 of the 27 fields specified had already installed or ordered such equipment.

title: In The Nation: OneTwo Punch in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Seldom if ever has a President suffered the sort of onetwo punch with which the Senate smote Mr. Nixon on Tuesday passing the CooperChurch amendment on Cambodia and overriding the President's veto of the health aid bill, 76 to 19.

title: PROJECT DROPPED BY ALEXANDER'S
description: Alexander's Inc., one of New York's largest retail chains announced yesterday that its plans for a new store at 96th Street and Broadway had been defeated by zoning problems and community opposition, and that It was dropping the project.

title: Senate Hearing Postponed
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters)  A Senate Commerce Committee meeting was postponed today at the request of Senator Marlow W. Cook, Republican of Kentucky, a committee member. The committee is considering the Administration bill that would guarantee up to $750million of loans for financially troubled railroads.

title: CHERYL TOUSSAINT SCORES ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1Cheryl Toussaint of the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn won the 440yard event in the United States of America girls track and field championship at the University of California, Los Angeles, today. Running despite an inflamed tendon, Miss Toussaint led from gun to wire and won by 12 yards in 54.4 seconds.

title: P.B.A. Moves to Bar Corruption Inquiry
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association served notice yesterday that it would ask the State Supreme Court to prohibit a special commission formed to investigate charges of corruption in the Police Department from doing its job.

title: OUSTED RED TEACHER SUES U.C.L.A. FOR JOB
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1Angela Davis, the Communist party member who has been dropped as an assistant professor of philosophy at the University of California, Los Angeles, filed suit today in the United States District Court in an effort to win her job back.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Show at the Modern Raises Questions
description: Would the fact that Governor Rockefeller has not denounced President Nixon's Indochina policy be a reason for you not to vote for him in November? This question not the sort one is usually invited to entertain in an art exhibitionis, quite literally, the first question a visitor to the new Information exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art is asked to consider. The exhibition, organized by Kynaston McShine, associate curator of the museum's Department of Painting and Sculpture, is said to be an international report on recent activity of young artists. It opens to the public today.

title: $104MILLION RISE IN PHONE CHARGES GRANTED BY P.S.C.
description: The State Public Service Commission approved a $104.9million rate increase for the New York Telephone Company yesterday and at the same time said it would order the utility to make refunds to customers on an interim increase granted last February.

title: CAMBODIAN CHIEF REVAMPS CABINET
description: PNOM PENH, Cambodia, Thursday, July 2Premier Lon Not announced shuffling of his Cabinet today, enlarging it and broadening its base among Cambodia's elite. The move had been expected for some time and is not considered to reflect political unrest.

title: Spending for New Construction Continued Downtrend in May
description: WASHINGTON, July 1New construction expenditures fell in May to their lowest level since 1968, despite the rise in construction costs, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Nicaraguan Slain Policing HondurasSalvador Truce
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters)  A Nicaraguan truce observer was killed today along the troubled border between Honduras and El Salvador, officials of the Organization of American States here said.

title: Paris Raises Minimum Wage
description: PARIS, July 1 (Reuters)The French goverment today raised the minimum hourly wage from the equivalent of about 64.6 cents to 67.3 cents. The move, affecting about 750,000 workers, followed a costofliving increase of onehalf of 1 per cent in May.

title: JOHN M. KNIGHT
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 1John M. Knight, holder of number of patents on automobile seats and railroad car equipment, died at a nursing home in Neptune yesterday.. He was 90 years old and lived here at 1007 Fifth Avenue.

title: JACK BE LON, 40, ACTOR AND SINGER
description: Jack De Lon, a Broadway actor and singer, died Sunday in St. John's Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived at 3513 76th Street in Queens.

title: Kennecott Adds Director
description: The election of John Jeppson to the board of the Kennecott Copper Company was announced yesterday. Mr. Jeppson is president and chief executive officer of the Norton Company, Worcester, Mass. He is a graduate of Amherst College in 1938 and holds honorary degrees of doctor of science from Amherst and doctor of laws from Clark University.

title: Israel Appeals to Britain
description: LONDON, July 1 (AP)Israel called on Britain's new Conservative Government today to help block what she termed deepening Soviet penetration in the Middle East and charged that Russians based in Egypt were helping the Arab war effort. Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel made the appeal in a 50minute meeting with Foreign Secretary Sir Alec DouglasHome of Britain.

title: COCACOLA ACCUSED OF TRICKING PUBLIC
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission accused the CocaCola Company today of tricking its customers in a Big Name Bingo promotional game last year.

title: Budd Sues on Metroliners
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) The Budd Company filed suit here today to collect a lion balance it said was due on 49 Buddmade Metroliner railroad cars purchased by the Lease Financing Corporation and leased to the Penn Central.

title: LUTHERANS ALTER 2 KEY CONCEPTS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 1  The Lutheran Church in America radically altered today its traditional concept of confirmation and first communion.

title: NASA TO PREPARE BRIDGE TO MARS
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., July 1After years as Apollo's poor relation, an old project with the new name Skylab has taken moonflight handmedowns and come up with a roomy orbiting workshop that is expected to catapult the United States into an era of space voyages lasting months and even years.

title: Chicago Symphony Opens Ravinia
description: CHICAGO, July 1History may wonder what strange compulsions drove the American people, not notably an artworshiping race, to search endlessly for the acoustically perfect symphonic hall, like medieval alchemists in their search for the philosopher's stone.

title: PRO GOLFERS FACE TIGHTER CONTROL
description: LONDON, Ontario, July 1Stricter control over United States golf professionals competing in foreign events was, predicted today as conflicts on the international schedule reduced the strength of the field for tomorrow's start of the 61st Canadian open.

title: Argentine, Town Is Raided
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, July 1 (Reuters)  Fifteen masked bandits with submachine guns and walkietalkie radios took over the nearby town of La Calera for nearly two hours today while they robbed the local bank of $25,000. In a note the bandits said they were members of the Montoneros Command, a Peronist group that claimed responsibility for the kidnapping a month ago of a former President, Pedro Eugenio Aramburu.

title: WHITE ACADEMIES TERMED INFERIOR
description: WASHINGTON. July 1 Southem segregationists are impairing the education not only of black children in public schools, but also of their own children, who are being sent to inferior segregation academies, the Senate Equal Educational Opportunity Committee was told today.

title: Health Care for Tomorrow
description: A lastminute settlement yesterday averted the strike that had threatened, in contravention of law, to close down the city's private nonprofit hospitals. A few hours later Mayor Lindsay formally handed over control of eighteen municipal hospitals to the new quasiindependent Health and Hospitals Corporation. The chance conjuncture of these two events illuminates important aspects of the health care problem, which is now rapidly becoming one of the most discussed and most politically sensitive issues on the national agenda.

title: Laraine Harriet Silver Affianced
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., July Miss Laraine Harriet Silver, a Columbia Law School student and a summer associate with Lord, Day & Lord, New York law firm, will be married Aug. 29 at the Plaza Hotel in New York to Peter Jay Rothenberg, a lawyer with Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, lawyers in New York.

title: Avco Corp. Profits Show Sharp Decline
description: The Avco Corporation suffered a sharp decline in earnings for the second quarter and first half of this year, the company's report disclosed yesterday.

title: Looting by Saigon Units Stirs Cambodian Hatred
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 1Looting and pillage of Cambodian towns by South Vietnamese troops is increasing and has become a serious problem here at a time when the two countries, traditional enemies, are trying to establish an alliance against North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces.

title: Sisco and Dobrvnin Meet
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Joseph J. Sisco, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs discussed the Middle East today with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrvnin of the Soviet Union.

title: Market Place:
description: No one can blame you if you're sick and tired of hoping the stock market will start tramping uphill in sustained and satisfying quickstep march for a few months.

title: GOLDBERG PLANS A BUSY SUMMER
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, the DemocraticLiberal nominee for Governor, said yesterday that he would conduct an active, vigorous campaign throughout the summer.

title: Eisenhowers in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, July 1 (AP)David and Julie Eisenhower arrived in Tokyo today to represent President Nixon at United States day at. Expo '70 in Osaka Friday.

title: Returning Pitcher Is Overwhelmed By Fans'
description: DETROIT, July 1Denny McLain acknowledged tonight that he was overwhelmed by the standing ovations accorded him in Tiger Stadium.

title: Yugoslav Boxers Beat U.S.
description: BELGRADE, July 1 (AP)The Yugoslav national boxing team defeated the amateur team of the United States, 1210, today in an unofficial match.

title: PRESIDENT TAKES OATH IN GUATEMALA
description: GUATEMALA, July 1Col. Carlos Manuel Arana Osorio, an antiCommunist guerrilla fighter who was elected President in a free election took office before Guatemala's Congress today with a pledge of social reforms.

title: Alaskan Squeeze Play
description: The Trans Alaska Pipeline System has rejected financial responsibility for a road from Alaska's Yukon River to the North Slope oil fields. A consortium eight oil companies formed to build a pipeline from Prudhoe Bay to Valdez, TAPS will not risk inevitable stockholders suits by paying for a road until and unless the Interior Department issues it a permit proceed with the pipeline which that road would serve.

title: Books of The Times
description: These letters record a friendship of more than 40 years duration and are unsurpassed in closeness, mutual concern and sustained sweetness. Such empathy between writers is certainly rare, and though in one or two places the chord that joined them frayed a bit, it never snapped. Even at the very end, up to the time of Brooks's death, the letters could not have shown more concern or more consideration. Their relationship endured because both were good men. They had an instrinctive aversion to any act or word or gesture that would inflict pain or diminish the spirit of the other. This makes for a certain blandness in the writing, but it did wonders for them as writers. Each buoyed up the other; each offered assurance, consolation, guidance and occasionally criticism. They helped one another and others in their circleWaldo Frank, Lee Simonson, Alfred Kreymborg, Paul Rosenfeldin dozens of ways. They talked up one anther's books, found apartments or living quarters, helped secure grants or jobs, aided in literary projects, signed one anther's manifestos and, in short, did all that could be required of them as citizens of the republic of letters.

title: Judge in Suffolk Is Exonerated Of Conflict of Interest Charges
description: Suffolk County Supreme Court Justice Arthur M. Cromarty was cleared by the Appellate Division yesterday of conflictofinterest charges in connection with a realestate syndicate. The ruling found that the allegations were not substantiated by the evidence.

title: ItalianAmericans Elect
description: Alfred E. Santangelo has been elected president of Americans of Italian Descent, Inc., succeeding Philip Vitello, a lawyer who held the post for two years. Mr. Santangelo served as Representative from the 18th Congressional District from 1957 to 1962 and as State Senator from 1946 to 1956.

title: GOVERNOR REQUESTS CATV STUDY BY P.S.C.
description: ALBANY, July 1 (AP)Governor Rockefeller asked the State Public Service Commission today to undertake a comprehensive investigation of community antenna television systems and report back to him by Dec. 1.

title: Personal Finance
description: The perennial struggle of man to come to terms with credit card companies has taken a moral turn recently.

title: Libyan Methanol Plant Set
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Libyan National Oil Corporation will start building in 1973 a 1,000tonaday methanol plant near Benghazi, Libya, they announced today. Libyan National is owned by the Government. Methanol is a form of industrial alcohol used in manufacturing.

title: Draft Order by Birthdays
WHEAT FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: With soybeans and wheat leading the downtrend, futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade were generally lower yesterday in mixed trading.

title: LAX AUDITING LAID TO SMITHSONIAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The General Accounting Office issued today a report to Congress that was sharply critical of the financial management of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Interco, Inc.
description: Interco, Inc., the largest American shoe producer, which has diversified into hardware, apparel and department store operations, reported yesterday increased sales and earnings for the six months ended May 31. Net income of $12,872,379 equaled $1.54 a share on sales of $357,822,163, compared with $12,414,651, or $1.47 a share, for the prior year's period, when sales were $347,975,688.

title: TV: Today's Flintstones
description: The Flintstones have been transported from the Stone Age to Southern California, Fred Flintstone isn't called Fred anymore and his Buddy Barney Rubble isn't Barney. Now they're Ed Huddles end his neighbor Bubba McCoy, heroes of a cartoon series, Where's Huddles?, turned out by the HannaBarbera animation factory in Hollywood.

title: Erazo Named to City Post
description: Joseph R. Erazo, a 35yearold lawyer who has served as legal counsel and consultant to several antipoverty agencies, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as Commisstoner of the Manpower and', Career Development Agency.

title: A Dutch Outlet for Banned Soviet Writers
description: That is the first stanza of the song Don't Wait for Me, which will itself almost surely see the light of publication some day. With hundreds of other songs in manuscript form, it rests in a folder on the top floor of the house at Amstel 268.

title: Amex Prices Dip for 8th Day; Drop Is Slim on Small Volume
description: Yesterday's session on the American Stock Exchange brought the eighth consecutive decline in the index. However, it was a very small one with the index nudged down to 20.04 from 20.06 the previous day. Furthermore, the decline came on small volume, totaling 1,812,540 shares compared with 2,374,985 on Tuesday.

title: Cards'
description: ST. LOUIS, July 1 (UPI)Eric Harris, thirdround draft choice of the St. Louis Cardi?? and a former defensive backfield star at Colorado, underwent surgery today to repair a torn ligament in his right knee. Harris suffered the injury Saturday night in the Coaches AllAmerica game in Lubbock, Tex.

title: Bonn's Budget for 1971 Estimated at $25Billion
description: BONN, July 1 (Reuters)Informed sources said that the Finance Committee of the West German Cabinet agreed today on a budget for 1971 of 100.1 billion deutsche marks, or $25.2billion.

title: 2 Women Who Decided on Abortions, but for Different Reasons
description: At 44, Mary Smith is an attractive, honeyhaired housewife who has been married close to 20 years and is the mother of two sons, John, 18, and Eric, 17, to whom she is obviously devoted. Hers is a close marriage, made more so, perhaps, by Eric's defective heart, a condition that has plagued the boy since birth.

title: Belgian Bicycle Victor
description: BAMIEESJN, France, July 1 (AP)  Joseph Spruyt of Belgium outraced Leo Duyndam of the Netherlands today in a final sprint to win the afternoon portion of the fifth leg of the Tour of France bicycle race.

title: MAILERS AT PRESS DELAY PUBLICATION
description: Mailers Union No. 6 held a union meeting during working hours at The Long Island Press yesterday, halting operations for about an hour.

title: Film: 'Boatniks' Opens at Ziegfeld:Robert Morse Is Star of a Marina Tale Phil Silvers Appears as a Comedy Thief
description: I've never seen a good movie about boating. Except for a few moments of Polanski's "Knife in the Water" and the lovely flotilla of Cal 20's that Preminger uses during the closing credits of "Skidoo," I've almost never seen anything good about boating in a movie. And in general, despite world-shattering advances in the art and politics of the cinema, movie boating remains at the level of that 30-year-old masterpiece (I forget the name) in which Bette Davis takes her sloop into a storm and sails through several complete circles without ever jibing or coming about.Norman Tokar's "The Boatniks," which opened yesterday at the Ziegfeld, isn't a good movie about boating, and it doesn't really try to be. It isn't good situation comedy either, though it does try to be. The only advantage of its assumed subject (weekend boating) and particular locale (Newport Beach and Balboa, a crowded southern California yachting inferno) is that there are a lot of small boats to look at to help you pass the time between the depositing and the withdrawal of each verbal or visual gag."The Boatniks" concerns a young Coast Guard ensign (Robert Morse) who does nothing right but who nevertheless wins a beautiful marina maiden (Stefanie Powers) and foils the overwater and underwater escape plans of three comic jewel thieves (Phil Silvers, Norman Fell and Mickey Shaughnessy).Along the way, he also enrages his commander (Don Ameche), resists the profferred temptations of an aging playboy (Wally Cox) and his sybaritic power cruiser, and alternately sinks and swimsalways with the aim of provoking the nervous laughter that in the view of the amusement brokers seems to pass for good clean fun.I'm sure that good, or at least bearable, movies have been made along the lines of "The Boatniks," and probably with casts less competent than this rather attractive one. The trouble is not that Phil Silvers' dialogue, for example, consists 98 per cent of one-liners, but that they are such dull one-liners, so obvious and without sustaining wit.And the young lovers, who never make love; and the plot windfalls, which rarely make senselike the many humorless vignettes and all the plastic pleasure craft on Newport Baypoint toward that moment in mass production when the forms are still imitated, but the spirit has been lost.

title: Roundup: Cubs Win One With Durocher off Air
description: It was as if Leo Durocher's nightly radio program had been the Jonah of the Chicago Cubs.

title: STOCK PRICES GAIN IN A DULL SESSION
description: The stock market edged higher yesterday in the opening session of the third quarter. Among the gainers were glamour and bluechip issues, as well as chemical and drug stacks.

title: France Makes Drug Addiction A Medical, Not Legal, Question
description: PARIS, July 1Drug addiction in France will be treated from now on as a medical rather than a penal matter, under legal changes voted by Parliament before its adjournment for the summer.

title: Failure Seen by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, July 1Tass, the official Soviet press agency, said tonight that the United States military operation in Cambodia had been a failure.

title: Shearson, Hammill Elects Executive Vice Presidents
description: Shearson, Hammill & Co., the brokerage concern, announced yesterday that H. Blair Phillips and David Teiger formerly first vice presidents, had been elected executive vice presidents in conjunction with the previously announced elevation lof Alger B. Chapman Jr. to the concern's presidency.

title: Ford Captures Hipkins Trophy;
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 1 Jonathan G. Ford of the Riverside (Conn.) Yacht Club won the 19th annual Long Island Soun men's sailing championship by 21/2 points today when the threeday regatta ended with one race in a 9to15knot northerly breeze off the Pequot Y.C.

title: U.S.BACKED LOANS TO BUILD NEW TOWNS
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) The Department of Housing and Urban Development granted today $54million in loan guarantees to two more planned communities, one in Maryland and the other in Illinois.

title: LTV Reduces Bank Debt By More Than $35Million
description: DALLAS, July 1 (Reuters)LingTemcoVought, Inc., has reduced its bank debt by more than $35million, James J. Ling, President, said today.

title: Dr. Gertrude Rand, 84, Dead; Researcher on Human Vision
description: STONY BROOK, L L, July 1Dr. Gertrude Rand Ferree, who conducted research on human vision with her husband, the late Dr. Clarence E. Ferree, died yesterday in her home on Erland Road. She was 84 years old.

title: Excerpts From the Interview With President Nixon on American Foreign Policy
description: Q. Mr. President, in your report on the Cambodian operation yesterday, you said you were going to emphasize the route of negotiated settlement again. A. Have you had any signal from Hanoi that they are more willing to talk than they have in the past and, B. Do you have any new propoisals to put to them to make a negotiated settlement more attrartive?

title: Senate Approves Tough Federal Standards for Manufacturers'
description: WASHINGTON, July 1A bill establishing stiff Federal standards to insure clarity and fairness in warranties covering automobiles, appliances and other consumer goods was passed today by the Senate.

title: Germany Tightens The Requirements On Bank Reserves
description: BONN, July 1Fulfilling a twoweekold announcement, West Germany's central bank today raised minimum reserve requirements by 15 per cent, thus taking 3billion marks (about $808million) out of circulation.

title: Penn Central Told to Pay Freight Bills for All June
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1The Penn Central Transportation Company was ordered today by Federal Judge John P. Fullam to pay other railroads any sums it owes those linessome 300for freight service they handled for the Penn Central during all of last month even though the carrier on June 21 went into reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Wendy Norris, Paris Student, Is Bride Here
description: St. James Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Wendy King Norris to Cpl. Richard Hooker Wilmer 4th, who is serving with the Marine Corps at Quantico, Va.

title: Europeans Caution U.S. About Imports
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)  The Common Market has cautioned the United States against proposed legislation to set quotas on textile and prob ably shoe imports.

title: Rx for Child's Learning Malady
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 2 A few months ago Jackie. D., a 6yearold boy with big brown eyes, was so bad that his mother was at her wit's end.

title: Capp Says He Cannot Run
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 2 (UPI)Al Capp, the cartoonist, said today that he would not be able to oppose Senator Ed ward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, in the Novem ber election because of the state's voter registration laws. Mr. Capp, a registered Demo1 crat until recently, did not change his party affiliation in time to meet the. requirement that a candidate be a regis tered party member for one year.

title: Middletown G.I. Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today that Pfc. John A. Ringholm of Middletown, N. Y., of the Army, had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: NEW SOVIET ENVOY LIKELY FOR CHINA
description: MOSCOW, July 2  Diplo matic sources said today that Communist China had agreed to accept a new Soviet Am bassador in Peking.

title: Election Fraud Is Charged In Court Action by Powell
description: Charging that fraud and ir regularity weer involved in his loss of the Democratic party's nomination for reelection last week, Representative Adam Clayton Powell on Thursday, filed suit to force the holding of a new primary election in the 18th Congressional District.

title: EASY RIDER WINS IN OPEN JUMPING
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 2 Barney Ward's Easy Rider captured the first open jumper class today as the fourday Gaudeamus Farms horse show got under way.

title: No Urgency at I.C.A.O.
description: An emergency meeting of the International Civil Aviation Organization in Montreal has produced some strongly worded resolutions that may help somewhat to spur the maddeningly lethargic pace of international efforts to control aerial hijacking.

title: India Is Feeling Impact of Computers
Bridge:
description: STOCKHOLM, July 2 Two young Austrian players, Fritz Babsch and Peter Man hardt of Vienna, became clear favorites to win the 1970 world pair champion ship at the end of play here tonight.

title: NEWCAR SALES CLIMBED IN JUNE
description: DETROIT, July 2Newcar sales laSt month made their strongest showing of the year, with the four manufacturers to day reporting dealer deliveries of 799,791 Americantype cars against 798,057 sold last June.

title: N.E.A. INVESTIGATES KENTUCKY SCHOOLS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 2The National Education Asso ciation, holding its 108th con vention, ordered today an investigation of the Kentucky school system.

title: THIRD INCREASE SET IN U.S. SUGAR QUOTA
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today an increase of 400,000 tons in the United States sugar quota for 1970, the third increase in a month.

title: Blast at Recruiting Center
description: An incendiary device ex ploded at the Navy and Marine recruiting center at Fordham Road and Grand Concourse in the Bronx early yesterday morning. No one was injured, but the blast blew the Marine Corps emblem from the front window of the booth and dam aged the airconditioner.

title: Gen. Wheeler Feted on Retirement
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) With thanks from President Nixon and a well done from Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, Gen. Earle G. Wheeler retired from the Army today after a record total of six years as chair man of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: BRITON DEFEATED IN A 4SET MATCH
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2At long last, Ken Rosewall is in another Wimbledon tennis final. Sixteen years after he first made it, the 35yearold Australian snapped Roger Tay lor's amazing upset streak to day and will meet a country man, John Newcombe, Satur day for the AllEngland singles championship.

title: CITY'S SUMMER AID TO TOP $30MILLION
description: The city's summer antipoverty program starts Monday with more than $30million available to serve 1.5 million disadvan taged children'and adults.

title: RIGHTIST STATION LOSES ITS LICENSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Sta tion WXUR in suburban Phila delphia, which has been in legal difficulty for four years be cause of its ardently rightwing political broadcasts, lost its li cense today by a unanimous order of the Federal Commu nications Commission.

title: Roundup: Expos Get. Fat On Baternan's Heavy Hits
description: John Bateman, baseball's perennially overweight catch er. set two personal records last spring by being fined $800 for weighing too much and then sweating off 35 pounds to get down to Man ager Gene Mauch's prescribed limit.

title: Chuvalo Agrees to Fight Foreman in Garden Aug. 4
description: George Chuvalo, the Cana dian heavyweight champion, agreed yesterday to oppose George Foreman, the 1968 Olympic champion who is un beaten in 20 bouts as a profes sional, in a 10round bout Aug. 4 in Madison Square Garden.

title: Volkswagen Would Offer American Safety Devices
description: WOLFSBURG, Germany, July 2 (UPI)Kurt Lodz, chairman of Volkswagen, Europe's larg est automobile producer, said today he favored the introduc tion of safety features and ex haust pollution controls in Eu rope based on existing Ameri can methods.

title: New New Soviet Stand Reported
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2The latest Soviet proposals on the Middle East accept the concept that Arab governments will have to curb guerrilla ac tivity against Israel when state of peace is attained, dip lomatic sources said here today.

title: On Army Post, Sons May Be Rebels, but They Still Say Sir
description: FORT BENNING, Ga.The Stars and Stripes, almost immobile in the still and heavy heat, shades many of the door ways; the houses, Mediterraneanstyle and nondescript assemblyline, glisten with care. When a newcomer arrives, women in shorts and minis, prim prints and pants, cross their generous and groomed lawns, under an awning of trees, with welcoming casseroles and cakes.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Herschel D. Newsom Dies at 65; Led National Grange 18 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) Herschel D. Newsom, an In diana farm boy who rose to international prominence as an agricultural leader, died here today of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and had been a member of the Tariff Commis sion since late 1968.

title: SOVIET STAR RUNS FAST 800 METERS
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R., July 2 (AP)A 22yearold Kiev student ran the 800 meters in 1 minute 45.5 seconds today, the best time for the distance this year.

title: Mayor Postpones Proposal For Buying Papp Theater
description: Mayor Lindsay will submit the budget modification to the Board of Estimate for the pur chase of the New York Shake speare Festival's Public Theater on July 23, instead of next Thursday.

title: PENN, DARTMOUTH LOSE THEIR RACES
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, Eng land, July 2 (AP)Yale Uni versity, Pennsylvania's four without coxswain and a school boy crew from Absecon, N. J., kept United States hopes alive in the Royal Henley Regatta today after the Penn and Dart mouth College heavyweight eights lost to English opponents in the Grand Challenge Cup.

title: Court Orders an Investigation Of a Nassau Justice's Conduct
description: An investigation into the con duct of a State Supreme Court Justice, Michael M. D'Auria of Nassau County, was ordered yesterday by the Appellate Di vision, Second Department.

title: Army Court Voids Mutiny Conviction Of 12 at Presidio
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The Army Court of Military Review threw out today mu tiny convictions against 12 sol diers who were involved in a 1968 sitdown demonstration at the San Francisco Presidio stockade. It said the evidence was insufficient.

title: The New York Times July 3, 1970
TEMPLE FESTIVAL GETS FOLK MUSIC;
description: AMBLER, Pa., July 2 sampling of the singing and dancing at the Festival of American Folklife, being pre sented in Washington by the Smithsonian Institution through Sunday, was sent up to the, Temple University Music ,Fes tival and Institute last night for a program called Music and Dance of Grassroots America.

title: F.C.C. RAISES FEES TO COVER SERVICES
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)  The Federal Communica tions Commission adopted to day a new schedule of fees for its services. The new fees are designed to pay the commis sion's way in full for the first time. They include annual per mit fees on both broadcasting and cable TV operations.

title: Brazil Site of Zone Net Final
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July (Canadian Press)  The Davis Cup American zone final be tween Canada and Brazil will be played in Sao Paulo, July I8 20, the Caadian Lawn Tennis Association announced today.

title: Investment Outlook Stable
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (Reu, ters)  Administration econo mists said today that United States business investment plans for this year, on present evidence, represent at most a zero growth over 1969 and pos sibly a fractional decline.

title: Young Violinists Tuning Up With TV
description: Straddling his chair in front of a television set, Robert Gellerman, age 11, watches critically as the closeup image of a handhis own  approximates the art of violin vibrato.

title: Man Held as Slayer Is Accused in Jersey I Of 6 More Murders
description: CAMDEN, J. J., July 2A 38yearold man in jail awaiting trial on one homicide charge was charged today with six more murders in Camden be tween February and September, 1969.

title: JOBLESS RATE OFF, BUT BASIC PICTURE REMAINS THE SAME
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The nation's unemployment rate fell In June to 4.7 per cent of the labor force, the Labor Depart ment reported today, but offi cials said that the underlying employment situation was es sentially unchanged from that of other recent months.

title: LENDING BY BANKS MIRRORS SQUEEZE
description: The cumulative effects of the liquidity squeeze in Wall Street were clearly evident during the week ended Wednesday, bank ing figures published yesterday showed.

title: LIBRARIANS URGE SECRECY ON DATA
description: DETROIT, July 2  A com mittee of the American Library Association has held that rec ords of books withdrawn from libraries must be considered confidential and should not be yielded to investigative agen cies without a court order.

title: French Repeal Regulation
description: PARIS, July 2 (Reuters)The French Finance Minis try said today that a Bank of France regulation obliging French commercial banks to deposit the equivalent of their Foreign currency holdings over certain quota levels is repealed, effective immediately.

title: MITCHELL SUPPORTS PEACEFUL PROTESTS
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July (AP)  Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that the police could not expect politica demonstrations to be conduct ed like prayer meetings.

title: K. of P. Elects Golden
description: Elliott Golden, chief assist ant district attorney of Kings County, has been elected grand chancellor of the 87,000mem ber Grand Lodge of the Knights of Pythias, the organization an nounced yesterday. Mr. Golden has been a member of the or ganization for 26 years.

title: Dollar Flow Into West Germany Slows as Mark Gains in Strength
description: PARIS, July 2The flow of dollars into Germany, a sign of both weakness of the dollar and strength of the mark, slowed to a trickle today, but an air of nervousness lingered over the exchange markets.

title: 2,000 Youngsters Of Fresh Air Fund To Start Vacations
description: More than 2,000 children in The Fresh Air Fund's Friendly Town program will be leaving this week for free vacations at the homes of families in 12 Eastern Seaboard states.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, marriages, births and engagements may be tele phoned to OXford 53311 until 11 P.M. in suburban offices. 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday Newark (201) MArket 33900; White Plains (914) WHite Plains 95300; Hempstead (516) 1Vanhoe 36660; Commack (516) 5435400; Stamford (203) 3497767

title: Cooperation in Science
description: Supporters of international scientific cooperation have won another important victory. The decision in Washington and Moscow to permit American scientists to work at Serpukhovsite of the world's largest nuclear acceleratorand to have Soviet scientists do research at Batavia, 111.where an even larger atom smasher is being builtis a major step forward. The secrets of the atomic nucleus which these giant machines are seeking to unravel have nothing to do with the ideological, political and economic divisions of mankind. It is encouraging that responsible policy makers on both sides act on that understanding even in the present period of SovietAmerican tension.

title: New Guatemalan Chief
description: GUATEMALA, July 2Col. Carlos Arana Osorio, who was sworn in yesterday as President, was his coun try's military attach in Washington in 1966 when he read that 15 members of a Guatemalan Army had been killed in an ambush by left wing guerrillas.. My blood boils, he re called recently. It seemed that Guatamala was headed toward Communist take over, as in Cuba.

title: U.S. Protests the Expulsion Of 2 Newsmen From Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) The State Department today protested the recent expulsion of two United States corre spondents from Moscow and accused the Soviet Union of trying to intimidate American newsmen.

title: PLEASANT VALLEY AQUEDUCT VICTOR
description: Pleasant Valley demonstrated a definite liking for the turf yesterday, as she scampered to victory in the feature race at Aqueduct. The 3yearold filly, owned by Charles Mistretta, aced in front most of the way to take the 1 1/16mile event in the grass by threequarters of a length over Hill of Spring, with Day of Reckoning next in be field of nine.

title: Plane Crashes in Lagoon In the Capital, Killing Two
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)  A twinengine air freight transport carrying at least two canisters of radioactive mate rial crashed into a Potomac River lagoon today, killing its twoman crew.

title: Brazil Says 4 Rio Hijackers Sought to Free 40 in Prison
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July (Reuters)  Four hijackers overwhelmed by troops in an airport assault here yesterday were trying to force the release of 40 political prisoners, the Brazilian Government said to day.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Soybean futures prices ad vanced sharply in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday but prices eased to wards the close under profit) takine.

title: Ousted Dublin Minister Cleared of Arms Charge
description: DUBLIN, July 2A former Cabinet minister, who was dis missed in May amid reports of a plot to provide arms for the Roman Catholic minority in neighboring Northern Ireland, was cleared today of a charge that he had conspired to import arms and ammunition illegally.

title: Ambassador Bruce to Paris
description: Having drawn back from a wider confrontation Indochina, President Nixon has taken an encouraging step toward reviving the Paris negotiations. His ap pointment of David K. E. Bruce to head the United States delegation at the Paris peace talks is a useful advance.

title: Cage Reopens Tonight
description: The Barbwire Theater pro duction of The Cage, which closed last Sunday at the Play house, 357 West 48th Street, is being reopened tonight at the Actors Playhouse, 100 Seventh Avenue South.

title: 30Nation Consumer Unit Divided on Pollution Issue
description: BADEN, Austria, July 2 International efforts to link the growing consumer movement with the fight against pollution met a harsh response today from African and Asian na tions.

title: LAW AND ORDER
description: Orderly Universe,

title: 4 A's Elect O'Neal
description: Frederick O'Neal has been unanimously elected interna tional president of the Associ ated Actors and Artistes of America, succeeding the late Conrad Nagel. The group known as the 4 A's is an inter national body of, eight enter tainment unions. Mr. O'Neal is also serving as president of Actors Equity Association, post held since 1964. He is the first Negro to head both or ganizations.

title: RAYMOND V. BRENDES
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 2Raymond V. Berendes, treasurer of Trifari, Krussman & Fishel, jewelry manufacturers in New York, died today at a hospital here. He was 62 years old and lived in Barrington.

title: Article 4  No Title
Parley Finds Most U.S. Dumps Unsafe for Pesticides'
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Communities should not col lect stocks of restricted pesti cides for disposal without Fed eral guidance, the National Con ference on Pesticide Problems has warned.

title: Israeli Planes Resume Attacks Against Missile Bases in Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, July 21Israel to day renewed her air strikes against antiaircraft missile sites in Egypt.

title: In Golf These Days, Pony Tails and Fancy Pants Are Par for the Course
California's Senate Continues Deadlock By Blocking Budget
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July (UPI)Democrats refused to night to approve Gov. Ronald Reagan's $6.59billion compro mise budget and sent Califor nia into a third day without program to spend tax money.

title: HERMAN GERING, 64, PLASTICS EXECUTIVE
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., July 1 Herman Gering, former exec utive vice president and treasur er of Gering Plastic Products, Inc., now owned by Monsanto Company, Inc., died today at Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark. He was 64 years, old and lived at 15 Crest Circle.

title: F.A.A. Backs ,$36,000 Study Of a Floating STOLport Here
description: The Federal Aviation Admin istration has awarded a $36,000 contract to American Airlines to explore the feasibility of building a small floating STOL port in the Hudson River off Manhattan.

title: Meetings by Mailers Delay Distribution At 2 Papers Here
description: Mailers stopped work at The Daily News last night to hold shop meeting, delaying the printing and distribution of the first edition of the paper.

title: Petty Qualifies for 11th Spot
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 2 (AP)Richard Petty earned a $125 birthday present on a hot, muggy Daytona Interna tional Speedway today when he led the secondday qualifying for the Firecracker 400. On his 33d birthday, Petty turned a 187.574 mile an hour lap around the 2.5mile track for the 11th starting spot in Satur day's $95,000 stock car race.

title: GUN BUFFS OPPOSE MANSFIELD DRIVE
description: BILLINGS, Mont, July 2The gun buffs, who are thick as jack rabbits in the Big Sky country, have undertaken to make things difficult for Sena tor Mike Mansfield as he runs for reelection this year.

title: British Gold Reserves Up Despite Loan Payments
description: LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) Britain's official gold reserves rose by 10 million ($24mi1 lion) last month to a total ofl 1.16 billion (2.789billion).

title: WALTZ TIME FIRST IN GOSHEN STAKE
description: GOSHEN, N.Y.. July 2 The mood of the chalk players at Historic Track today matched the weather  dark,I dreary and threatening.

title: Peking Gives Sihanouk A Triumphal Welcome
description: PEKING, July 2 (Agence FrancePresse)Prince Noro dom Sihanouk of Cambodia was given a triumphal wel come today when he re turned to Peking from a 17 day official visit to North Korea.

title: O'Dwyer Gives Endorsements To Goldberg, Ottinger Drives
description: Paul O'Dwyer yesterday an nounced his endorsement of Arthur J. Goldberg and Richard L. OttinRer.

title: Edith. T. Baikie, 62, Headed State Education Agency
description: Edith T. Baikie, executive director of Governor Rockefel ler's Committee on the Educa tion and Employment of Wo men, died. Wednesday after long illness at Nassau Hospital Mineola.. She was 62 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: Fishing Reports
description: AREA AAnglers are tak ing bluefish (4 to 12 pounds) in quantity in the Klondike Banks area chumming with cut bait. Spoons, anchovies and smelt also are being used effectively at night as well as during the day. The quan tity of fluke has increased in recent days, with party boats returning to Brielle with 15 to 30 fish. Trollers are taking some school tuna along Manasquan Ridge. On the beaches, fishermen, using lures mostly, have been tak ing some striped bass from Sea Girt to Bay Head.

title: Conviction Overturned In Desecration of Flag
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP)  Pennsylvania's Su preme Court says that it is legal under state law to dese crate the American flag if the desecration takes place at a political demonstration.

title: Canada Auctions Bills
description: OTTAWA, July 2 (Canadian Press)The Government today auctioned $150million of new 91day Treasury bills at an av erage price of 98.542 and aver age yield of 5.94 per cent, compared with last week's 98.541 and 5.94 per cent. To day's $40million of 182day bills brought 97.136 and 5.95 per cent, against last week's 97.118 and 5.98 per cent.

title: Bank of America In Australian Deal
description: Financial institutions led the merger parade yesterday.

title: Union Endorses Rockefeller
description: HERHONKSON, N. Y., July 2 The New York State Fire Fighters Association, which says it has 28,000 members, today endorsed Governor Rock efeller Lieutenant Governor Malcolm Wilson and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz for reelection in convention here.

title: City Receives $532,000 Grant To Seek Cut in Auto Pollution
description: New York City has received a $532,000 grant to demon strate how motor vehicles that give off relatively small amounts of pollution perform under urban driving conditions.

title: Dartmouth Appoints a Dean
description: HANOVER, N. H., July (UPI)David V. Ragone of the CarnegieMellon University in Pittsburgh has been named dean of the Thayer School of Engineering at Dartmouth Col lege. The appointment of Mr. Rayone, 40 years old, was ef fective yesterday.

title: Davis Cup Nations Reject a Bid To Open Play to Contract Pros
description: LONDON, July 2 (Reuters)The Davis Cup nations rejected today a proposal that the com petition be opened to all classes of players.

title: Mountbatten, 70, Has a Shaky Time at Ceremony
description: LONDON, July 2 (UPI)Princess Anne saw it first today: the ordeal of Earl Mountbatten of Burma.

title: $130,000 Bahamas Open Is Added to Pro Golf Tour
description: The Bahama Islands open, a new $130,000 event, was added yesterday to the pro golf tour for Dec. 10 through 13 at the King's Inn and Country Club, Freeport, but the $130,000 Sports City open, slated for Sept. 1013 at Pine Plains, N. Y., has been canceled.

title: P.S.C. Head Sees Improvement In Phone Service in City Area
description: ALBANY, July 2Telephone service in New York City and its suburbs is getting better, but it will not improve sub stantially until late this year, according to the chairman of the Public Service Commission, Joseph C. Swidler.

title: Market Place
description: Remember those flyby night landdevelopment com panies that used to sell land under six feet of water? The industry has come a long way since then. But not so far that stocks of the publicly held land companies are immune to stock market reversals.

title: Chief, the Friendly War Dog, Likes Copter Rides
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2The war dogs, too, are out of Cambodia.

title: HEATH WILL PRESS FOR CUT IN TAXES AND UNION REFORM
description: LONDON, July 2  Britain's new Government put tax cuts and laborunion reform at the head of its program today.

title: WOOLWORTH'S SALES SHOW RISE OF 14.2%
description: The F. W. Woolworth Com pany reported yesterday that consolidated sales in the 26 weeks ended June 27 rose 14.2 per cent, to a record $1,086, 723,047 compared with $951, 185,075 in the 1969 period.

title: Grace Buys Retail Chain
description: W. R. Grace & Co.'s Hatco group announced yesterday the acquisition of the Herman's Sporting Goods stores here and in Paramus, N. J., for an un disclosed amount. Herman Steinlauf, chairman and found er, and Leonard Steinlauf, president of Herman's, will con tinue to operate the store group

title: JERSEY JURY TOLD OF DEFECTIVE PIPE
description: TRENTON, July 2The pro secution's key witness in the extortion conspiracy trial here of Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and five other defendants testified today that Newark might have to spend extra millions of dollars on sewage treatment because in ferior pipe was installed in 1965 as part of a kickback scheme.

title: Damage at State U. In Student Unrest Is Put at $518,000
description: ALBANY, July 2 (AP)Dam age at 18 of the State Universi ty of New York's 26 state operated colleges and centers totaled $518,500 in the 196970 academic year, according to report released today. It put most of the blame on student radicals.

title: Record Income for Half Reported by U.S. Trust
description: The United States Trust Company reported yesterday that net income rose 11.7 per cent to a record $4.18million in the first half of 1970 from $3.74million in last year's period. This was equivalent to $1.99 a common share, up from $1.78.

title: Books of The Times
description: In 1917 the Grand Duchess Olga, eldest daughter of the Czar, escaped from Russia. She went to Queen Marie of Rumania, where she found solace with a blond Ru dolph Valentino who passed as a Byzan tine Prince. They moved to Berlin, where the Grand Duchess won notoriety for the excesses of her salon. A thousand schemes later, she engi neered the fall of a British Govern ment. Its grateful successor reward ed her with all the Russian royal jew els on condition that she never set foot in Europe again. She decided on exile in Egypt where, as her lov er put it, claims and temptations can exist happily side by side and the Beyond is not too far away. The royal party arrived in Cairo in 1925.

title: Indiana Campers'
description: RICHMOND Ind., June 30 State Route 227 is a slender ribbon of blacktop meander.. ing through the fields of soy beans, oats and kneehigh corn north of this city of 44,000.

title: City Rights Aide Named
description: Luis F. Quinones yesterday was appointed deputy director of the community affairS divi sion of the city Commission on Human Rights. Mr. Quiniones has been a member of the com mission staff since 1961 and has been active in community work in East Harlem, the Bronx and the Lower East Side.

title: Landlords Bid Mayor Veto New City Rent Program
description: Organized landlords urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday to veto the new rent control pro gram approved by the City Council last Saturday.

title: Trading in Shares of 1.0.S. Resumes Today in Canada
description: MONTREAL, July 2 (UPI)Trading in shares of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., will re sume tomorrow on both the Toronto Stock Exchange and the Montreal Stock Exchange, a spokesman for the Montreal exchange said today.

title: Volume of Futures Trading Climbs 11.8% in 6 Months
description: CHICAGO, July 2 (UPI)Ev !erette B. Harris, president of the Chicago Mercantile Ex change, said today that trading volume on the exchange set a record in the first six months of 1970.

title: Bush to Pilot Quebec Aces
description: QUEBEC, July 2 (AP)Eddie Bush was named today as coach of the Quebec Aces of the American Hockey League for the 1971 campaign. He re places Turk Broda.

title: Jane Amler Is Wed to Physician
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 2Miss Jane Frances Amler and Dr. Lawrence A. Lewis were married here this evening at the home of the bride's pa rents by the Rabbi Murray Grauer.

title: Padraic Colum in Hospital
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass , July 2 (AP)Padraic Colum, the Irish poet and author is in Spring field Hospital after what doc tors described as a mild cerebral vascular accident. Mr. Colum, who maintains an apartment in New York, suf fered the accident June 23 dur ing a writers conference in Suffield, Conn., and was ad mitted to the hospital the same day.

title: Arms Seized in London Raid
BANKRUPTCY ACTS FOUND INCREASING
description: The Milo Electronics Corpo ration, listed on the American Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that it plans to file a Chapter XI petition for ar rangement undert the Bank ruptcy Act.

title: Three Productions Set for Broadway In Coming Season
description: Plans have been announced for the Broadway production of two musicals and one drama in the new season.

title: These Toxic Times
description: Some of the dangerous consequences of American chemical proficiency engaged both the legislative and judicial branches of government this weekwith no better than a fiftyfifty outcome for the country.

title: Jersey Youth Wins Saber Crown
M'CORMACK GIVES REPORT ON SWEIG
description: House Speaker John W. Mc Cormack told a Federal judge and jury here yesterday that he had been unaware that per sons he regarded as friends were misusing his office for the benefit of commercial clients.

title: BILLS ARE SOLD BY U.S. TREASURY
description: The Treasury, wasting little time to borrow more money as the Government's new fiscal year got under way, sold $2.5 billion of bills yesterday.

title: Travelers Crowd City's Highways and Terminals
description: The great Independence Day rush from New York began last night with the usual jam ups on highways and huge crowds at the city's bus, rail and air terminals.

title: Judge Is Named for Inquiry Into Hobart College Incident
description: ALBANY, July 2 (UPI)Gov ernor Rockefeller today named Justice T. Paul Kane of Cobble skill to preside over an extra ordinary term of State Supreme Court for an investigation of confrontation betweeen the police and 150 students and faculty members of Hobart and William Smith Colleges.

title: Pompidou Warns Israel and Urges Big Four Action
description: PARIS, July 2  President Pompidou warned Israel today that time was working against her and issued a pressing ap peal for a Middle East settle ment through concerted action by the Big Four powers.

title: GRAHAM DEFENDS PATRIOTIC RALLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Sponsors of Honor America Day sought today to show that the July 4 celebration would be nonpolitical, neutral on the war and an occasion at which long haired youths and hard hat patriots would feel welcome.

title: 7 PATRIOTS'
description: BOSTON, July 2 (AP)The Boston Patriots and Harvard University announced today substantial agreement for the use of Harvard Stadium by the National Football League club for its seven home games in 1970.

title: COMMONWEALTH REPORTS '69 LOSS
description: The Commonwealth United Corporation had an estimated net loss last year of about $61 million, including extraordinary losses and losses from discon tinued operations, it was re ported last night.

title: Stage: The Wars of the Roses, Part 2
description: Deep In Central Park, The Wars of the Roses are get ting bloodier. Joseph Papp's besieged, beleaguered and all but bereft New York Shakes peare Festival is presenting at the Delacorte Theater Shakespeare's Henry VI, Parts I, II & III combined into two evening called The Wars of the Roses. This Shakespearean excursion into 15thcentury English history is completed by Richard III, which offers the com plete story of striving dy nasties of York and Lan caster.

title: Shultz, Hodgson and 2 Budget Agency Aides Sworn
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 2 (AP)President Nixon presided at a quadruple oath taking ceremony today that marked the formal beginning of an Administration plan to reform handling of the Fed eral budget.

title: Power Policy Needed
description: The warnings of brownouts ahead for the New York metropolitan area have given ample notice of the unsatisfactory margin of reserve electric power available for the summer months. Now the bad news that Consolidated Edison's nuclear power plant Indian Point will be out of commission until Sep tember must further intensify public concern.

title: Sy Oliver's 9Piece Band at Riverboat
description: When Tommy Stagg and the Majority, a smooth, tight ly organized rock quartet, finishes a set at the River boat and the young dancers who have been Shifting and pumping through mutual solo routines drift off the floor, Sy Oliver's ninepiece band takes the stand and an older group of dancers step out to do an older, closecontact form of dancing.

title: Draft at 18 Urged By Young Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, July 2  A conference of young advisers to the Selective Service System recommended today that the draft age be lowered to 18, that student deferments be eli minated and that an allvolun teer force ultimately be created.

title: Six Favorites in a Row Score at Delaware Park
description: STANTON, Del., July 2 (AP) Carrying the silks of the track president, Baird C. Brit tingham, Show Of Strength drove home first by threequar ters of a length in the 1 116th mile Roman Patrol Purse at Delaware Park today.

title: Paisley Is Suspended From Ulster Parliament
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, July 2 (Reuters)The Rev. Ian Paisley, the Protes tant Unionist extremist, was suspended from the Parlia ment today after heated ex changes with the Speaker.

title: 2 WOMEN SHARE U. S. OPEN LEAD
description: MUSKOGEE, Okla., July 2 (AP)Donna Caponi, the de fending champion, and Carol Mann took different routes to arrive at the same spot today twounderpar 69and shared the first round lead as the United States Women's Open golf championship.

title: Regal Fox Wins in Florida
description: MIAMI, July 2 (AP)Regal Fox rallied from last place to win a four horse photo finish by a neck today in the sixth race at Tropical Park. The win ner ran 5 furlongs in 1:05 35 and paid $22.40, $6.40 and $3.60 for $2 across the board.

title: Greek Orthodox Vote to Use Vernacular in Liturgy
description: The Greek Orthodox Archdio cese of North and South Ameri ca voted overwhelmingly yes terday to permit the substitution of English and other vernacular languages for Greek in its liturgies.

title: CAMBODIANSNS TRAIN IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam July 2The first contingent of Cambodian troops to be trained in South Vietnam being instructed at Lamson in Pantry training center neat Nhatrang in central Vietnam South Vietnamese military sources said here today.

title: INSURANCE PLOT IS LAID TO 7 HERE
description: Four doctors, a former union official and two other persons were arrested here yesterday on charges of stealing thou sands of dollars from an in surance company.

title: Sound of Music Sweetens Jones Beach
description: A lone star rode the windy darkness above the Jones Beach Theater on Wednes day night and remained fixed over The Sound of Music. No wonder. The sound and sight of the show were sim ply stunning.

title: A CIVILIAN JUDGE BARS ARMY TRIAL
description: ATLANTA, July 2  A Fed eral judge rulled today that a soldier accused of atrocities at Songmy could not be tried by courtmartial until a threeman civilian judicial panel had de cided on the legality of the Vietnam war and the consti tutionality of the Army's Uni, form Code of Military Justice.

title: ABORTIONS RISING IN CITY HOSPITALS
description: New York City's municipal hospitals reported that they performed 49 abortions yester day, the second day of opera tions under a new state law allowing terminations of preg nancy by choice.

title: ANDRETTI UNHURT IN CRASH AT TRIAL
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 2 (UPI)Mario An dretti, former U.S.A.C. driving champion, escaped injury today when his turbocharged Ford Hawk crashed and burned after the qualifying trials for Satur day's 200mile race at the Mich igan International Speedway.

title: Strolling Met Couldn't Move In Canio's Cart
description: The Metropolitan Opera is not exactly a band of stroll ing players these summer weeks, but it does move from one place to another to en tertain different communi ties, and there was a singular appropriateness about its presentation of Pagliacci in Brooklyn's Prospect Park on Wednesday night.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: It has been reported that Se cret Service computers file the names of persons who partici pate in antiU. S. Government demonstrations, who make statements about officials which are irrational or embarrass ingall of these categories defined by the Secret Service itself.

title: SOME FRENCH UNITS ARE LEAVING CHAD
description: FORTLAMY, Chad, July (Agence France Presse) France today began the phased withdrawal of some of her 3,500 troops from this north central African nation, which has been torn by guerrilla war for years.

title: F.T.C. Alleges Deception By a Cosmetics Concern
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The Federal Trade Commis sion today charged, the makers of Holiday Magic Cosmetics with deceptive practices, price fixing and restraint of trade.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE SHOWS 1.5% DROP
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Freight traffic on United States, railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended June 27 were both befi low the volume in the corre sponding week of last year.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Commerce Department today estimated last week's depart ment store sales at $697.million, up 8 per cent above the year earlier $639million. Last week's retail store sales totaled about $7,110,000,000, up 2 per cent from $6.98billion.

title: WALL AND ARCHER SHARE 2D POSITION
description: LONDON, Ontario, July 2Just as he did in the first round six years ago, C. L. (Gibby) Gilbert of Miami led the Cana dian open golf championship today. He carded a seven underpar 65, establishing course record at the London Hunt and Country Club.

title: '76 BACKING GOES TO PHILADELPHIA
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Con gressional sources said today that a Presidential commission would probably recommend that Philadelphia be selected to hold an international exposition in 1976, the 200th anniversary of the Declaration of Independ ence.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Oil Prospects Stir Norwegians
