Women knew even way back in ancient times that the pure juices of the lemon could accomplish wonders. in softening, smoothing and clearing their complexions, and could bring the goldenbright look of shimmery sunshine to their hair when used as a rinse.

title: 15,000 Commuters To New Hampshire Are Now Taxed 4%
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 4 (AP) About 15,000 persons who work in New Hampshire but live outside it became liable this week for a new 4 per cent commuters income tax.

title: Reds Defeat Astros, 30, as McGlothlin Wins 11th With Help From Granger
description: CINCINNATI, July 4 (UPI)Wayne Granger went in to pitch tonight with the bases loaded and two out in the ninth inning and retired Doug Rader to preserve Jim McGlothlin's 11th victory of the season as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Houston Astros. 30.

title: Police Identify Stewardess Killed in Long Island City
description: A young woman who was shot to death last Sunday in Long Island City was identified by the police yesterday as Suzanne M. Sawyers, a 22yearold American Airlines stewardess from Clearmont, Mo.

title: Coins
description: THIS is the time of the year when many numismatic clubs recess for the summer and it presents a splendid opportunity for the collector to check his needs, scan through catalogues in his quest for bargains and catch up on reading new books.

title: Kerr on The Dirtiest Show in Town
description: CONFESSION is good for the soul, so I am going to confess that I laughed once during The Dirtiest Show in Town. Happened after a boy and a girl had had a spot of sex at their first meeting. He was dressing and he paused long enough to say This meaningful relationship has been the high point of my afternoon.

title: Heads Sharecroppers Fund
description: James M. Pierce of Charlotte, N. C., a longtime union leader in the South, has been appointed executive director of the National Sharecroppers Fund. which promotes selfhelp and legislation for the rural poor.

title: Stegen Wins CrossCountry At Walden
description: WALDEN, N. Y., July 4Arthur Stegen of New Paltz, a former track star at Moorhead State College, Minnesota, won the twomile crosscountry run in the second annual Walden Fourth of July road races today.

title: PICTURE CREDITS 1HARRY REDL FROM BLACK STAR
description: 5HARRY REDL FROM BLACK STAR

title: Muskie's Timetable: Out of Indochina In 18 Months
description: WASHINGTON. WHEN President Nixon took office, most Americans hoped that his Administration would find the key to the Vietnam problem. We wanted to end our preoccupation with the war and get on with unfinished national business. Unfortunately, the Administration has not found the key, and the war in Indochina continues to dominate our lives. Having invaded Cambodia in an attempt to score dramatic military gains, the Administration finds itself ever more tightly bound to the war and its consequences. We cannot pry ourselves loose by force of arms, and we cannot dictate the peace.

title: Conservation Work At Fishkill Is Aided By Fresh Air Fund
description: Fresh Air Fund campers at the fund's Sharpeville Reservation near Fishkill, N.Y., will get some firsthand experience in conservation work this summer, thanks to one of nature's more voracious pests, the gypsy moth caterpillar.Staff members at the 3,00Uacre reservation have organized a campaign to defend the heavily wooded area against infestation by the bugs. Aiding them will be the campers, many of them children whose only previous experience with the insect world had been limited to the common house fly and the omnipresent urban cockroach.

title: Norfolk to Seek Slice Of the Cruise Sailings
description: NORFOLK, Va., June 27Norfolk has been getting the crumbs of the cruise trade, and a port official here is pushing for a real slice.

title: Helene Mueller, Dr. F. M. Weld Plan to Marry
description: Miss Helene Singleton Mueller, a nurse consultant in the department of human ecology at the Cornell University Medical College, and Dr. Francis Minot Weld, chief resident in the New York Hospital department of Internal medicine, will be married here Sept. 26.

title: Mary Jo Balassone Is Bride of a Lawyer
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 4 In the chapel of the Congregational Church here today, Miss Mary Jo Balassone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Balassone of Great Neck, was married to Lawrence W. Bierlein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Bierlein of Kettering, Ohio. The Rev. George Gerald Parker performed the ceremony.

title: Agnew Retorts to President of A.B.A. Who Called for Restraint
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)In a chainreaction of criticism Vice President Agnew struck back today at Bernard Segal president of the American ?? Association.

title: Strike Front Keeps Its Cool
description: THERE'S been a seasonal cooling, but summer's coming has not put the New York Art Strike on ice. Its plans and boisterous actions against the Four Horsemen of the 70's Racism, Sexism, Repression and War  continue on a number of farflung fronts, from the walls of local galleries to the banks of the Grand Canal. We're involved in an allout war on war! cried one militant, handing out peace buttons in front of MOMA.

title: Dance
description: THE other day my friend Charles Payne, the editor and publisher of the Ballet Theater souvenir books, very kindly gave me a collection of them from the immediate postwar days onward. They make fascinating contemplation en masseold pictures, new pictures, forgotten pictures.

title: Norman, Is That You Laughin?
description: EVEN though he has Laughin, that big bonanza of television still going strong for him, George Schlatter is preparing to enter movieland. Schlatter said that he had acquired film rights to Norman, Is That You? early this year shortly after the comedy had ended its brief Broadway stand, and that the playwrights, Ron Clark and Sam Bobrick, with a Schlatter assist, have iust completed adapting it me screen. It's their first movie script, Schlatter said with some satisfaction, and it will be film first for me, too.

title: Donnie Allison Pilots Ford to Victory in Firecracker 400 at Daytona Beach
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. (AP) July 4Donnie Allison, using a borrowed engine in his Ford, drove to victory in the Firecracker 400 when a Ford teammate, David Pearson, blew a tire 17 miles from the wire.

title: APARTMENTS GET TRASH CRUSHERS
description: Metropolitan Life, one of the city's biggest landlords, has begun replacing 122 incinerators at three housing developments in Manhattan Stuyvesant Town, Peter Cooper Village and Riverton  with compactors.

title: Three Sculptors in a Plastic Mode
description: AT the OwensCorning Fiberglas Center, 717 Fifth Avenue, a handsome summerlong exhibition by three contemporary sculptors has become, unfortunately, a posthumous tribute to one of themthe German born American artist, Eva Hesse, who died May 29 at the age of 34 at the outset of a brilliant career. The exhibition, entitled simply Trio, has been sponsored by the plastics company to illustrate the adaptability of reinforced plastics to a variety of sculptural manners  from the distinctive abstract modes of Miss Hesse and Tony DeLap to the erotic realism of Frank Gallo.

title: ABRAHAM J. SCHWARTZ
description: Abraham J. Schwartz, manufacturer of men's and boys clothing, president of A. J. Schwartz & Co., died Friday in Manhasset (L.I.) General Hospital. He was 76 years old and listed at 8530 Somerset Street, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: BEAGLE CAPTURES 5TH BEST IN SHOW
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., July 4 A black, tan and white 15inch beagle, Ch. Kings Creek Triple Threat, owned by Lullaby Kennels and Torn Foy Jr. of North Attleboro, Mass., won his fifth bestinshow award today at the 22d Farmington Valley Kennel Club fixture on the grounds of the Farmington Valley Polo Citzb. There were 1,253 dogs in the competition.

title: Amioka Brothers Reap Fistful of Awards From Judo
In Pnompenh, Beer Flows Like Beaujolais
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 4  It was hot dogs hamburgers and canned beer today at the Cercle Sportif as the last social bastion of France in Indochina fell to the United States.

title: A Synthetic Suture Called Compatible With Human Tissue
description: LONDON. July 4Development of a synthetic surgical suture that is absorbed by the body and is compatible with human tissue was announced here this week.

title: Cocker Spaniel Is Considered A Hunter, Not Pet, in Austria
description: In America, the cocker spaniel ranks No. 10 among the breeds registered with the American Kennel Club. From 1936 to 1952, it was No. 1. In Austria, the smallest sized member of the spaniel family is No. 5 of all breeds. Furthermore, whereas in the United States the cocker is chiefly a pet and shown in the breed ring, in Austria he is considered a gun dog and is No. 3 of all the hunting breeds. Much of the success the cocker spaniel is enjoying in the Alpine country can be attributed to two women breedersMrs. Barbara Englaender of Grinzing and Mrs. Inge von HauschkaTreuenfels of Vienna.

title: City Bill to Require Unit Pricing Planned by Queens Councilman
description: Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky says he plans to in troduce legislation that would uphold the City Consumer Affairs Department's right to require retail food merchants to post unit prices.

title: Patricia Wilde, R. E. Anderson To Be Married
description: SANTA PAULA, Calif., July 4Mr. and Mrs. George I. Wilde have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Delphine Wilde, a 1969 graduate of Stanford University, to Richard E. Anderson, a secondyear student at the Stanford School of Medicine.

title: Harold McGraw Sr., 80, Dies; Publisher and a Civic Leader
description: Harold W. McGraw Sr., a retired vice president of McGrawHill, Inc., and chairman of the executive committee of the West Side Association of Commerce, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital after a two months illness. His age was 80.

title: Kalliwoda, Koczwara, Kuhlau, Etc.
description: BERTINI, Briccialdi, Bazzini, Bishop; Herzogenberg, Herold, Hiller, Hummel; Kalliwoda, Kuhlau, Kummer, Koczwara; Poniatowski, Pechatschek, Ponchiellithe names read like a litany. They are a few of the cornposers whose works will be performed at this year's Newport Music Festival, which will again be devoted to a revival of music of the Romantic era. Of course there will be some wellknown names on the programsVerdi, Brahms, SaintSaens, Beethoven but for the most part the festival will exhume the forgotten. It will be presented in appropriate sites, the music rooms of the great mansions at the Rhode Island resort.

title: Economic Lag Threatens G. O. P. Chances in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 With Election Day only four months away, President Nixon's management of the economy is threatening to lessen the Republican party's slim chances of gaining control of the Senate.

title: 3 SKIPPERS SCORE DOUBLE VICTORIES
description: CENTERPORT, L.I., July 4Three skippers backed up victories this morning as 75 yachts sailed in the first two of three races conducted by the Centerport Yacht Club on Northport and Huntington Bays today.

title: Ailing Health System Needs More Than Money
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal dollar looms large in American health careand is likely to loom larger, but the Government seems caught in the classic AliceinWonderland predicament  the more money the Administration puts in, the more is needed. In short, as the Red Queen said to Alice: It takes all the running you can do to keen in the same place.

title: O'Brien Breaks Record For 3,000Meter Chase
description: BERLIN, July 4 (UPI)Kerry O'Brien of Australia set a world record in the 3,000meter steeplechase in track and field meet in Olympic Stadium today with a clocking of 8 minutes 22 seconds.

title: U.S. Business
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 4A study shows that a proposed 1.8mile midcity tunnel linking the Penn Central and Reading Railroad terminals could open up 94,000 new jobs for Philadelphians during the next 15 years.

title: Linz Plays 11 Tie
description: BREMEN, Germany, July 4 (UPI)Linz of Austria scored in the 90th minute to gain 11 draw in Intertoto Cup soccer with Werder Bremen today.

title: Doubts About Use Of Air Power in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia  The bombing never stopped their troops and supplies from getting through before, and it won't stop them now.

title: The Gay People Demand Their Rights
description: Andr Gide once wrote that he was obsessed and haunted... expending [himself] crazily to the point of utter exhaustion. Other homosexuals have described the terrible shame: and loneliness that shadowed their existence. No such complexes interfered with the march in New York last Sunday of thousands of men and women who hoisted their silk banners high and chanted, Say it loud, Gay is proud.

title: A Talk With Konrad Lorenz
description: KONRAD Z. LORENZ, author of On Aggression, is a founding father of ethology, the systematic study of animal behavior and the subject of dispute over whether its findings explain the social (and antisocial) behavior of man. In this interview with Frederic de Towarnicki of the French magazine L'Express, Dr. Lorenz ranges over a broad spectrum of ideas, from the plight of 20th century man to his personal vision of the universe. The translation is by Stanley Hochman.

title: ESCAPADE IS VICTOR IN ENSIGN SAILING
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., July 4Gene Rogers's and Joseph Schejbars Escapade defeated 13 Ensign class boats today as 36 sailed in the Sea Cliff Yacht Club competition at Hempstead Harbor.

title: House Unit Returns Home; Backs Cambodia Operation
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) Twelve members of the House of Representatives returned today from a trip to Southeast Asia with a bipartisan majority report that the United States incursion into Cambodia had been a military success.

title: That New Air Fare TaxIt's Sly
description: BY MIDNIGHT tonight, at the end of the first five days of the 10year life of the Airport and Airway Development Act of 1970, air travelers will have paid into the newly created Airport and Airway Trust Fund $7,595,255, give or take a few dollars. The give or take is because that figure was worked out without a computer, taking the estimated annual receipts from the new Federal taxes on air transport of people only6554.6million  and dividing it by 365 to strike a daily average.

title: The Friendly Islands
Bettenhausen Wins in Michigan As Leading Johncock Spins Out
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 4Gary Bettenhausen won the Michigan 200 today after Gordon Johncock, who had been leading nearly all the way, lost it in a sensational spinout with only nine laps to go. Johncock was not injured.

title: DODGERS SCORE OVER GIANTS, 72
description: SAN FRANCISCO July (AP)Bill Sudakis and Tom Haller batted in Los Angeles first five runs today to pace the Dodgers to a 72 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: What's New in the Theater
description: BOESMAN AND LENA, a play by Athol Fugard, was hailed by two critics, turned down by four and approved with reservations by four. Clive Barnes: Athol Fugard has written some fine plays, but certainly none better than the amazing Boesman and Lena, which on its opening instantly became the bestacted play in New York. In both The Blood Knot and in Hello and Goodbye, Mr. Fugard has suggested a more than common talent. In Boesman and Lena he is through suggesting: he is shouting from the roof. It is a strange, bitter, disturbing and, in a sense, beautiful play about human deprivation and human survival. Boesman and Lena are Cape Coloreds, neither white nor black, and fairly low down in South Africa's racial hierarchy. Mr. Fugard is constantly holding our atten tion with fresh insights into these two derelicts, making us care desperately, about them. John Berry's staging is wonderfully telling. Ruby Dee as Lena is giving one of the finest performances I have ever seen. Her eyes, her voice, her manner, her entire being have a quality of wholeness that is rarely encountered in the theater. James Earl Jones is almost as remarkable as Boesman. South African authorities have refused Mr. Fugard a passport to leave his native land. However, nothing better than Mr. Fugard's writing has come out of South Africa in years. For Walter Kerr, see Page 1.

title: Grant to Fight Pollution
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 4 (AP) Gov. Walter R. Peterson Jr. announced today a $368,000 grant from the New England Regional Commission to abate pollution, of the Nashua River in Massachusetts and New Hampshire.

title: Horne Run Production Livelier
description: There is a dramatic increase in hitting in major league baseball this season, but it has taken some strange forms.

title: THOUSANDS VOICE FAITH IN AMERICA AT CAPITAL RALLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 Thousands of persons of various political persuasions turned out here today for Honor America Day and, in Fourth of July pageantry and confrontation, expressed both the divisions and the promises of the United States on its 194th birthday.

title: Brooklyn Girls Again Shatter World Record in Mile Relay
description: LOS ANGELES, July 4  For the second successive day, the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn lowered its own world record in the onemile relay today at the United States women's track and field championships at the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: McQueens Are Separated
description: LE MANS, July 4 (AP)Steve McQueen, the actor, and his wife of 14 years have separated, a secretary for the Solar Film Production Company reported today. Mr. McQueen is here to star in a film on the 24hour Le Mans auto race. The secretary said Mr. McQueen and his wife, the former Neile Adams, made their decision to separate a few days ago. She specified it is not a divorce. The couple has two children.

title: A Talk With Konrad Lorenz
Stubborn, Smoky Blaze Damages Businesses in Times Square
description: A spectacular fouralarm blaze that resisted the efforts of 170 firemen for more than three hours last night burned out a Times Square amusement arcade and heavily damaged a Chinese restaurant and a bar and grill in the same building.

title: Other Timetables
description: .... as a result of the success of the Cambodian operations, Secretary Laird has resumed the withdrawal American forces from Vietnam. Fifty thousand of the 150,000 I announced on April 20 will now be out by Oct. 15.

title: WORDS ARE FOCUS OF NEW TV SERIES
description: On the theory that a rich vocablulary is the prerequisite of a meaningful education and a better job, the Manpower Education Institute in cooperation with the State University of New York will start a television program series in color beginning tomorrow called For the Love of Words.

title: Heath: Tough Battles Ahead for Policies
description: LONDON  Imagine the United States Government two weeks after the 1968 election: The new Republican Administration has taken over, filling every Cabinet and subCabinet office. President Nixon has delivered his first State of the Union address. Major foreign policy shifts are under way, and the new. Secretary of State has gone to his first big international conference. The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare has put into effect a sharp change in education policy.

title: Mooncoin Castle
description: Jeremy is an elderly jackdaw who refuses to accept the news that Mooncoin Castle will be torn down to make room for supermarket. After all, in addition to the fact that a great many rooks, crows, and jackdaws call it home, the castle has seen centuries of throbbing Irish history and has its own curseridden ghost, one Patrick de Lucy.

title: TROOPS IN BELFAST CONFISCATE ARMS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland July 4British troops seized large amounts of arms and ammunition here today in a housetohouse search of a predominantly Roman Catholic section where five civilians were killed in rioting last night.

title: Article 1  No Title
SOVIET, RUMANIA LEAD WRESTLING
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, July 4 (Canadian Press)The favored Soviet Union and highlyrated Rumania emerged undefeated today in the preliminary rounds of GrecoRoman competition at the world amateur wrestling championships.

title: July Dream
description: If there is any time in the year when a man must realize that the earth doesn't belong to him, it is July. Actually, the situation is the other way aroundman belongs to the earth, is a part of the vast living community that thrives here. Hard as this is to accept, it is easier in July when man is so obviously outnumbered on every hand, by birds and insects and animals and, of course, by plants. Even so, man lives in relative comfort here so long as he is willing to work at it. Especially in midsummer in July.

title: Kerr on The Wars of the Roses
description: WHAT did Shakespeare dare take time for? That's the one question you keep asking yourself, in mild horror and muted humor and with great fascination as you watch the appalling tumble of The Wars of the Roses (Shakespeare's Henry VI, Parts I, II and III crushed into two evenings) at Joseph Papp's Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: Angels Preparing a Halo for Wright
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 4Clyde Wright, a laconic southpaw from the Tennessee hills, is making a surprise bid to become the second 20game winner in the 10year history of the California Angels.

title: GOLFING FAMILIES TEE OFF TUESDAY
description: The golfers of the Metropolitan district, men, women and juniors, have ample opportunity for tournament play this week and two family events start the ball rolling on Tuesday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: THE BOY FRIENDSandy Duncan sings in the musical which celebrates its 100th performance at the Ambassador Friday.

title: Commemoratives
description: ISRAEL has postally commemorated the 50th anniversary of Keren Hayesod, a fund raising organization founded before establishment of the State to aid its colonization; the development of its aircraft industry, and its role as host to international yachting races. The stamps are multicolored.

title: Purchasing Agents Cite Price Rises
description: Purchasing agents, who are especially sensitive to, inflationary trends, find that the rate at which prices of industrial commodities has been rising slowed noticeably in June, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: A Few Members of Manson's Family Still Stay at Movie Ranch, Awaiting His Return
description: LOS ANGELES, July 4JV year ago there were about 45 members of the hippie family that lived a communal existence on a crumbling movie! ranch in the arid, boulderstrewn mountains at the northern end of the San Fernando Valley.

title: Those of You Who Are Over 50...
description: IWAS born in 1942. Recently I attended revivals of two plays of the 1930's  Clifford Odets Awake and Sing! at the Bijou and Room Service, by John Murray and Allen Boretz, at the Edison  and was startled, as I often am by movies of that mysterious decade, by the terrifically high level of their energy and sophistication. It brought to mind what a friend once suggested to me as we were watching a particularly exquisite 30's movie on TV, that the 30's were somehow truly sold out by the 40's, that, even as it installed the United States as an imperial world power, World War II smothered something (what?) that had been aborning in the American spirit. I remember that the thought made me feel suddenly at once envious of my parents and exasperated with them.

title: Article 7  No Title
Photography
description: SAN FRANCISCO. TWO exhibits presented in New York earlier this year  The New Realism: Four San Francisco Photographers, at The Witkin Gallery, and Photography into Sculpture, at the Museum of Modern Art  served notice on the photographic world that the West Coast was witnessing a resurgence of photographic activity, a renewal of energy so significant that even now, though it has not yet fully coalesced, its impact on the medium promises to be as strong is was that of the f/64 group several decades ago.

title: Dr. Thomas B. Symons Is Dead; Agriculturist and Educator, 89
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Dr. Thomas B. Symons, agriculturist and educator, died today at Prince George's General Hospital in Cheverly, Md. He was 89 years old and lived at College Park. Md.

title: Red Sox Convert Rainouts Into DayNight Programs
description: BOSTON, July 4 (UPI)The Boston Red Sox have rescheduled three earlier postponed games, creating daynight programs on the new dates.

title: Widow and Foundation Share Financier's Estate
description: PITTSBURGH, July 4 (UN)Richard King Mellon, financierphilanthropist who died last month, bequeathed half of his estate to his widow and the other half to a foundation bearing his name.

title: Miss Elizabeth W. Dore Plans Marriage to George W. Adams
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Dore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Wilkes Dore, to George Webster Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander B. Adams of Rowayton, Conn.

title: The Double Dream of Spring
description: John. Ashbery takes his title, The Double Dream of Spring, from painting by de Chirico; and so puts us on warning that we are stepping through the looking glass into those deep perspectives and receding landscapes of the mind. He leads us, once we are prepared to follow, to yearnedfor, difficult states, free of casual distraction. To reduce all this to a small variant,/ To step free at last, miniscule on the gigantic plateau/ This was our ambition: to be small and clear and free. Sometimes explorers, sometimes pilgrims, the speakers in these poems are certain in varying degrees of being able to shake off the clutter of a world which, wryly phrased, could not be better.

title: BICULTURAL MOVE LOSES IN BRUSSELS
description: BRUSSELS, July 4The Belgian Cabinet of Premier Gaston Eyskens was defeated late yesterday in its effort to change the constitution to end the quarrels between the country's Dutchspeaking Flemings and Frenchsneaking Walloons.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: Concerning Louis Nizer's article (What to Do When the Judge Is Put Up Against the Wall, May 5a study of the use of disruptive courtroom tactics in controversial trials) and your many recent articles concerning radical youth and the generation gap, I refer you to an article in the Columbia Law School News, April 17, reporting on a talk given by attorney William Kunstler at the Law School:

title: 50 Interconference Games Set For N. F.L. Preseason Action
description: Fifty of the 75 preseason games in the National Football League this summer will be of the interconference kind, matching team from the newly aligned National and American Conferences. These games will be played over period of six weeks, beginning Aug. 7 and ending Sept 13. The regular season opens Sept. 18. There is one prior gamethe Kansas City Chiefs, the professional champions, oppose the College AllStars in Chicago on July 31. That game will be telecast nationally as will Baltimore at Kansas City, Aug. 14; Minnesota at Houston, Aug. 22; the Giants at Pittsburgh, Aug. 28; Green Bay at Oakland and the Jets at Minnesota, Aug. 30; Kansas City at Dallas, Sept. 5, and the Jets at Dallas, Sept. 13.

title: DEANE EDWARDS OF HYMN SOCIETY
description: RYE, N. Y., July 4The Rev. Dr. Deane Edwards, president emeritus of the Hymn Society of America, died at his home here yesterday. He was 35 years old.

title: Two Alcoholics Anonymous Speakers Say Marijuana May Be Less Harmful Than Alcohol
description: MIAMI, July 4Spokesmen for two organizations working to combat alcoholism said at an Alcoholics Anonymous convention in Miami today that in some respects marijuana may be less dangerous than alcohol.

title: Headliners
description: It was her first foreign trip alone, and from a diplomatic standpoint, a sensitive one. But Pat Nixon carried it off with aplomb. The President's wife flew last week to Peru with two planeloads of relief supplies and donated funds for victims of the recent earthquake. She impressed Peur vians by visiting relief organizations and a children's hospital, and taking a dangerous flight into the mountains to talk with survivors and rescue workers in devastated towns. President Juan Velasco Alvarado, whose relations with Washington have been strained since he seized power in 1968, couldn't have been more moved by Mrs. Nixon's visit, according to Taylor G. Belcher, the United States Ambassador. President Nixon said his wife's mission had been in effect, people speaking to people despite differences between governments. vians by visiting relief organizations and a children's hospital, and taking a dangerous flight into the mountains to talk with survivors and rescue workers in devastated towns. President Juan Velasco Alvarado, whose relations with Washington have been strained since he seized power in 1968, couldn't have been more moved by Mrs. Nixon's visit, according to Taylor G. Belcher, the United States Ambassador. President Nixon said his wife's mission had been in effect, people speaking to people despite differences between governments.

title: Drug Cases Swamp Doctors in Georgia At Rock Festival
description: BYRON, Ga., July 4 (UPI)Declaring the drug situation out of control, doctors at the Atlanta International Pop Festival pleaded for state and Federal help tonight and urged authorities to declare the entire festival a health disaster area.

title: In the Service Of Their Country
description: As we know, a man can be imprisoned in this country for refusing to killif the killing is part of an official war and (until the Supreme Court recently qualified the matter) if his conscience is not buttressed by An official religion, that is if he really insists on standing outside the regulations of our culture. Despite the general alienation of our times, very few young men have ended up in this predicament, in part because the Government is reluctant to produce martyrs, in part because so many other loopholes out of the army exist.

title: A'S TOP ANGELS, 74; HUNTER POSTS 13TH
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 4 (UPI)Reggie Jackson knocked in four runs with a homer and a single and Jim (Catfish) Hunter became the first American League pitcher to win 13 games, tonight as the Oakland Athletics posted a 74 victory over the California Angels.

title: Nancy S. Holt, R. H. Stowell Are Betrothed
description: HAMPTON, Va., July 4Miss Nancy Sayer Holt, a candidate for a master's degree in classical archeology at the University of Pennsylvania, and Richard Hinman Stowell, who received an M.B.A. degree from the university's Wharton School of Finance and Commerce will be married here Sept. 12 in historic St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: California Trip
description: In the introduction to this book of photographs, Dennis Stock calls California This free wheeling potpourri of search, the head lab where America experiments with new ideas and styles. It is a clich, but valid one, as Mr. Stock demonstrates in 99 stark images of the nation's largest state.

title: Britain's English Texts Offend Europeans at Market Sessions
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 30It was one of those little incidents that in most places except the heart of the European Economic Community, would probably go unnoticed.

title: Star quality
description: It may be a shaggy play on words but one wit, in speaking of gelatin desserts, stated that many are cold but few are frozen. Among the best the gelatin desserts are the Bavarian creams, and not the least of their virtues is their infinite variety. They range from basic vanilla to the novelty of Nesselrode to chocolate, which is choice. A Bavarian creamor bavarois, as it known in Frenchis not difficult to make and an excellent dessert for summer.

title: GEORGE D. CRAVES
Paper Mill Pact Reached
description: NATCHEZ, Miss., July 4 (AP)The International Paper Company and union representatives announced today agreement on a threeyear contract covering 10 Southern pulp and paper mills. Spokesmen for the company and the International Brotherhood of Pulp and Paper Mill Workers said several unions involved had accepted the contract. No further details were disclosed.

title: Cambodian Economy Is Badly Hurt by War
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 4Tourism and the rubber industry are ruined, rice export has been badly hurt and the Cambodian householder is now paying more than twice as much as he used to for the charcoal with which he cooks his food.

title: New Posters of Flag
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) Postmaster General Winton M. Blount has ordered that a new patriotic poster depicting the American flag he supplied to all United States post offices. The poster, to be made available to the public for 25 cents, carries a painting of the flag and the words: this is our flag he proud of it.

title: Wedding Is Held For Mrs. Angulo
description: NORTH GARDEN, Va., July 4Mrs. Carolyn Bonin Angulo, formerly of New York, was married here today to Lamed Donaldson Randolph, a widower. The ceremony at Oakmont, the bride's country home, was performed by the Rev. Benjamin Farley, a Presbyterian minister, and attended only by members of the immediate families. The Rev. John L. Wright Jr., an Episcopalian, assisted.

title: Dr. Rosina Berry Is Bride on L.I.
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., July 4Dr. Rosina Otis Berry, a resident physician at Roosevelt Hospital in New York, and Richard Wayne Dixon, a supervisor at the Bell Telephone Laboratories, were married here this afternoon in a wedding that offered the 450 guests an opportunity to blend the weekend's marriage festivities with traditional Fourth of July celebrations.

title: LIBERTY BELL RACE WON BY ELLEN GIRL
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) Ellen Girl and Kilts N Kapers won the two divisions of the Bryn Mawr Stakes at the Liberty Bell race track today.

title: ABOUT RIGHT WINS JUMPER LAURELS
description: NEWBURY, Mass., July 4Sam Magid's About Right squeezed through to the intermediate jumper championship at the Quid Newbury horse show today without the benefit of a single blue ribbon.

title: Mercury in Industrial Wastes Held a Menace to Bald Eagles
description: Mercury from industrial pollution has been added to the list of environmental menaces for the dwindling number of bald eagles, the country's national bird.

title: A Night at the Opera, Or What's Wrong with the Met?
description: WHAT would I do if I were to direct the Metropolitan Opera now? It would have been easier to have answered this question a few years ago before the ultimate principle of Pharaonic stupidity had materialized in the new building at Lincoln Center. We owe this felony to the collusion of a formidable operatic brain trust and an architect chosen obviously because he matched the ideology of that brain trust.

title: Vesper Oarsmen Win Senior Eights Race by 2 Lengths on Schuylkill River
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 4Despite a steady morning drizzle and a threat of heavy showers in the afternoon, the Schuylkill navy and Quaker City officials today staged their centuryolds, Independence Day rowing jamboree.

title: FoodStamp Plan Enlarged by State; City to Join Sept. 1
description: Thirtynine more of the state's welfare districts started a food stamp program for the poor last week, but state officials expressed concern that would take a sizable educational effort to get welfare recipients to participate.

title: Old Enmities Fan Jordan Strife
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 4 On Saturday, June 6, a member of the Jordanian Army's elite special force known as Saiqa, or Thunderbolt, was walking past the main mosque in downtown Amman when two commandos of the Popular Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine challenged him to show his identification.

title: Allan, 16, May Earn Black Belt During Tour of Japan
description: I practiced a little judo when I was in Hawaii, but not enough to talk about, said Ted, who was born in Maui, Hawaii, to Japanese parents, and migrated to New York, where he married. The family lives in Mount Vernon.

title: Spouting Horn, $10.60, Rallies to Capture Dover Stakes at Delaware Park
description: STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP) Walter D. Fletcher's Spouting Horn, rallying from next to last, won the $24,800 Dover Stakes by 1 lengths at Delaware Park today.

title: $700,000 Awarded in Suit
description: DETROIT, July 4 (AP)  A former member of the Wayne State University track team and his wife have been awarded $700,000 by a jury as a result of an accident that paralyzed the Detroit man. The jury awarded 36 year old Ruben Porter $500,000 and his wife $200,000 in the suit against Uniroyal Inc., the General Motors Corporation and Jefferson Chevrolet, a dealer. Mr. Porter alleged the tire was defective on his 1962 Corvette, which crashed April 5, 1963.

title: Program Under Way Here For the Slightly Retarded
description: An experimental program to help people who are slightly retarded through psychoanalytically oriented treatment has begun at the Karen Homey Clinic, 329 East 62d Street, with the aid of a $38,550 Federal grant.

title: New Bonn Law Gives Custody Of Illegitimate Baby to Mother
description: BONN, July 4A law went into effect this week making Illegitimate children the wards initially of their unmarried mothers rather than wards of the state.

title: Miss Barbara Applebaum Is Bride
description: Miss Barbara Applebaum and Stuart Ira Finkel were married here last night at the Terrace on the Park atop the former heliport at Flushing Meadow Park in Queens. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Benjamin Blech of the Young Israel of Oceanside congregation on Long Island.

title: Recommended New Titles
description: BEYOND THE MELTING POT, by Nathan Glazer and Daniel Patrick Moynihan. (MIT Press, $1.95.) New edition of a modem classic sociology: a study of the Negroes, Puerto Ricans, Italians and Irish of New York City. What's happened since it originally came out 1963 is discussed in a long new introduction, the message of which is grim.

title: LongHairs Clash With CrewCuts at Capital Rally
description: WASHINGTON, July 4As dark fell tonight on the grounds of the Washington Monument, long haired, young people surged into a crowd of crewcut young people.

title: Janet Verner Is Wed to Dr. Mark Platt
description: BOSTON, July 4Miss Janet Verner was married here this evening to Dr. Mark Platt. Rabbi Burton L. Padoll performed the ceremony in the SheratonPlaza Hotel.

title: ExCongressman'sSonRuns
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 4 (AP)Everett Royal Johnson 61yearold son of a former South Dakota Congressman has tiled for the Republican nomination to the House in Maryland's sixth District,

title: In Brief
description: Self acknowledged dilettantism is an ideal defense against historians, philosophers and other academic critics. It is a way to be wise and modest at the same time, witty with disarming unpretentiousness. Be

title: New Windsor: Where Washington Scored His Finest Victory
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y.  It was the winter of 178283. Cornwallis's defeat during the Yorktown campaign more than year earlier had been the last major conflict  and to generations of high school history classes since then, the Revolutionary War was over.

title: In the Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: To THE EDITOR: Although the rule book seems to confirm in a backhand way the out call on the catch Ron Woods of the Yankees made off Carl Yastrzemski of Boston June 20 by saying that when a fielder falls into stands or dugout after a catch time shall be called, it is a ruling that appears to leave the play in a sort of baseball twilight zone.

title: Dr. W. B. Paley to Wed Vicki Kreutzer
description: ROSLYN, L. I., July 4Mrs. Samuel Kreutzer has announced the engagement of tier daughter, Miss Vicki Kreutzer, to Dr. Winston B. paley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morrison Paley of New York.

title: HOLMBERG TO HEAD CHATTANOOGA TIMES
description: CHATTANOOGA, July 4A. William Holmberg has been elected president of Times Printing Company, publishers of The Chattanooga Times, and has been named a member of its board of directors.

title: Budget Deadlock Ends in California After Senate Vote
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 4 The State Legislature ended its budget deadlock today and sent a $6.6billion spending program to Gov. Ronald Reagan for 197071. The state's worst fiscal crisis had appeared to be in the making before the impasse was broken.

title: South Vietnamese Accept A Cambodian Ambassador
description: SAIGON South Vietnam, July 4 (Reuters)South Vietnam has agreed to the appointment of Thoutch Vuttmi as the new Cambodian Ambassador here a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. The new Ambassador was formerly with the Cambodian Embassy in Peking.

title: Philip C. Duschnes Is Dead; RareBook Dealer Was 73
description: Philip C. Duschnes, a rarebook dealer who helped to establish collections at universities and libraries across the country, died here yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Science/Medicine
description: The trouble with the Greeks, according to Dr. Robert R. Wilson. was that they did not build accelerators.

title: Miss Eileen R. Cooney, Teacher, Married to Timothy A. Hogan Jr.
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 4Miss Eileen Regina Cooney, who teaches French at the Tappan Zee High School in Orangeburg, was married here this morning to Timothy Aloysius Hogan Jr., a manager in the administrative services division of Arthur Andersen & Co., the auditing firm in New York.

title: The Nation
East German Said to Set 20Kilometer Walk Record
description: BERLIN, July 4 (AP)  An East German, Peter Frenkel, established a world record for the 20kilometer walk today when he wa5z clocked in 1 hour 25 minutes 50 seconds, the officials East German news agency, ADN, reported. as The previous record was listed as 1:26:45.8 by Gennadi Agapov of the Soviet Union. Frenkel was competing in an East German meet at Erfurt.

title: Nell Kimball
description: Nell Kimball always gave a customer his money's worth, right from the day she arrived at a St. Louie brothel in 1867a green, yeasty teenager determined never to return to her father's hardscrabble Illinois farmto the zenith of her career in turnofthecentury New Orleans as proprietor of a fine twentydollar luxury house with clean pretty whores. These are her memoirs, set down in the twenties and thirties and now edited by Stephen Longstreet.

title: The Love That Dared Not Speak Its Name
description: The dilemma of the homosexual as of other members of a minority group is that he is never quite sure whether his condition is a curse or a blessing, whether he has been singled out by a malign destiny to be the carrier of an obnoxious disease, or whether he is a member of an elite who can either flaunt or hide his uniqueness.

title: Livelihood
description: S.P. asks if any reader can identify the following quotation: He who in studying the public good sacrifices his own livelihood defeats his own intentions and is like a brave soldier who indiscreetly rushes into danger and thereby robs his country of a valuable member.

title: Two Men Accused of Holdup; One an OffDuty Policeman
description: An offduty policeman and another man were arrested yesterday morning and charged with robbing three patrons of a social club at 489 Lexington Avenue, Brooklyn, of $80.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television proerams was not available in time to appear in Section

title: Solings Ride Strong Tide of Popularity
description: More than 100 sailors alternately splashed and fried on Galveston Bay last week in five days of racing to determine the winner of the North American Soling championship.

title: FIREBOMBS EXPLODE AT 2 BRITISH OFFICES
description: Firebombs exploded outside the offices of the British Overseas Airways Corporation yesterday morning and outside Barclays Bank on Park Avenue late last night. There were no injuries and only slight damage was done in the two incidents.

title: A TAXICAB CRISIS SEEN OVER FARES
description: A crisis is likely in the taxi industry's labor relations and service to the public unless the city allowea fare increase according to taxi fleet owners.

title: Home Improvement
description: IN ADDITION to the conventional slab of poured concrete or asphalt, there are many other ways that a comfortable and attractive looking terrace or patio can be builtwith or without the use of concrete or mortar.

title: Foreign Affairs: Creaking in the Ice jam?
description: LONDON  It is plain as a pikestaff that Washington is engaged in global diplomatic explorations involving widely separate areas. Apart from the continuing SALT talks in Vienna, which are said to be going well, there are other contacts, both direct and indirect. This may explain why Ambassador Beam returned from Moscow last month for extensive consultations.

title: Gloria A. Maccaro Is Planning Bridal
description: Miss Gloria Ann Maccaro, an elementary school teacher in Brookhaven L. I., and 1st Lieut. Brian Jay Carmines, U.S.A.. who recently completed a tour of duty in Vietnam, plan to be married next month.

title: Mary Louise Gilbert Is Affianced
description: Miss Mary Louise Gilbert and Scott Hale. Reiniger Jr., seniors at Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla., plan to be married in August.

title: Capital Excursion Is a Festive Crusade
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Patriotism and a family picnic atmosphere were combined on a 17car train as it rolled here from New York today as part of the Honor America celebration.

title: Archetypal situations
description: The sophisticated mind and compulsively idiosyncratic prose style of Alejo Carpentier have won his novels, both in the original and in translation, a wide circle of admirers, and there is no doubt that he is one of the halfdozen or so most impressive novelists in Latin America. A Cuban of French stock his novels deploy an essentially European view of tropical America. In all his novels tropical nature is displayed with wideeyed wonder, so much so that a younger Cuban writer, Edmundo Desnoes, has felt Carpentier to be trading too facilely in exoticism. Thus in Los Pasos Perdidos (The Lost Steps, 1956) a disaffected urban intellectual longs to share the paradisical innocence of an Indian tribe he encounters deep in the Orinoco River.

title: 4th of July Observances Abroad Marked by Many War Protests
description: LONDON, July 4 (Reuters)Americans around the world celebrated the Fourth of July today with parades, garden parties and embassy receptions. But in several countries observances were marred by anti American demonstrations.

title: Architecture
description: A TWOWEEK trip through three cities of the American Northwest and Canada is a revealing experience for an effete Easterner. Seattle, Portland and Vancouver, B.C., are experiencing the same terrible pressures and critical changes that are destroying urban identities and values everywhere.

title: High Over Earth, Glider Fliers Find a Bit of Heaven
Gwynedd A. Gowen, Vassar '72, Married in France to Guy Felix
description: Miss Gwynedd Anne Gowen and Guy Felix were married yesterday in the tiny Church of St. Christophe and St. Jacques built in 1501 in VillierssurMarne, France.

title: Crowd Loves America, Not War
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The men and womenand impressively large numbers of young peoplewho came to Honor America at the Lincoln Memorial this morning seemed clearly to be doubters, not militants.

title: Return to Strategy of Maximum Pressure In Vietnam
description: SAIGON  Now that the American portion of the Cambodian war has supposedly ended after two months of operations which President Nixon said will save American and allied lives in the future, American casualties can be expected to go down, right? Wrong.

title: BARNETT NEWMAN, PAINTER, 65, DIES
description: Barnett Newman, the painter and sculptor, died Friday night at St. Luke's Hospital after suffering a heart attack in his home at 685.West End Avenue. He was 65 years old.

title: U.A.R. SAYS ITS FIRE HIT 2 ISRAELI PLANES
description: CAIRO, July 4 (AP)A military spokesman said two Israeli jets, a Phantom and a Skyhawk, were hit today during raids along the Suez Canal front.

title: More Social Action ls Pledged At Greek Orthodox Convention
description: The Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America has ended its weeklong biennial ClergyLaity Congress, pledged to everdeeper involvement in the areas of social action and liturgical reform.

title: A.A.U. Loses Mat Sanction
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, July (AP)The International Wrestling Federation voted today to drop the Amateur Athletic Union as a member and apparently will turn its sanction to the United States Wrestling Federation.

title: ArrowShooter Is Slain By Policemen in Harlem
description: A merchant seaman who reportedly had been shooting arrows at people passing his window in Harlem was killed yesterday by two patrolmen who said he had attacked them with a machete and a kitchen knife.

title: ABORTION DEMAND PREDICTED TO RISE
description: The head of a referral service predicted yesterday that the demand for abortions here under the new state law would be manageable through July, tapering off into August but then become increasingly unmanageable.

title: Axelrod Captures U.S. Title in Foils
description: Albert Axelrod, a 49yearold electrical engineer, became the first man to win the national foil championship four times and the oldest to win the crown when he captured an exciting fenceoff at the Hotel Commodore shortly after midnight this morning.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: AT the midpoint of the year, prospects for the stock market and the economy seem, at best, rather lukewarm. But the bond market, which has been rising lately, offers more hope.

title: $15BILLION PLAN IS SET BY PAKISTAN
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 4Pakistan has begun a $15billion economic development plan, its fourth fiveyear plan. The figure is nearly $6billion more than the estimated total expendiiture on the country's third fiveyear plan just ended.

title: Auto Pollution Tests Set
description: DETROIT, July 4 (AP) American Raceways, Inc., says it has signed a $483,000 contract with the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to test auto pollution at the Michigan International Speedway at Cambridge Junction, Mich.

title: Model Cities Head Wants to Fence Lots to Keep Out Garbage
description: Will an eightfoothigh wire fence keep people from dumping garbage into vacant slum lots?

title: TeenAgers Seeking U.S. Junior Titles at Coast Meet
description: Despite the fact that he has won two National Junior judo titles in a row, Jamie Amioka, 13 years old and 100 pounds, maintains a sense of proportion in his family, and he won't let it be said that he's better than his older brothers, Eric, 15, and Allan, 16.

title: Bridge
description: WHETHER the players of today are better than those of yesteryear is a favorite subject for discussion in many sports and activities. In some  such as golf, swimming and track  standards of measurements are available and it is easy to demonstrate that the oldtimers would be outclassed by the modern stars: There is more room for debate in bridge.

title: CUBS ON TOP, 72, AFTER 106 LOSS
description: CHICAGO, July 4 (AP)Billy Williams's tworun tiebreaking homer sparked the Chicago Cubs to a 72 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today in the second game of a double header. Eight homers were clouted in the twin bill.

title: Crawford Meets Saijo For Featherweight Title
description: TOKYO, July 4 (AP) Shozo Saijo of Japan defends his World Boxing Association featherweight title tomorrow against Frankie Crawford of Los Angeles at Sendai in northern Japan.

title: China Shifts Officers on Border
description: HONG KONG, July 4  Recent personnel changes in Chinese provinces bordering the Soviet Union reflect a steady Strengthening in these areas of military commands and administrative structures that were disrupted by the purges of the Cultural Revolution.

title: Article 4  No Title
Clara B. Van Derzee is Affianced
description: ALBANY, July 4  Mr. and Mrs. Newton Briggs Van Derzee Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clara Bates Van Derzee, to Gordon Lang Jr., son of Mr. Lang of Lake Forest, Ill., and the late Mrs. Harriet Kendig Lang.

title: Movies
description: LEE GRANT is sort of sidling out of the bedroom in the Sherry Netherland suite, in a yellow negligee printed with whimsical flowers, the kind people paste on Volkswagens. Her hair drops to h?? ??houlders like spilling Champale. She wears no makeup, not even around ner eyes, wnich are still rather vague with sleep. It is 2:40 P.M.

title: Summertime Fun
description: BUYING a swimming pool has a lot in common with buying car: The price ranges are similar, purchase of either can be financed, and the extras hike the costs.

title: Common Market Names 2 To Major Posts for Talks
description: PARIS, July 4The European Common Market has given German Socialist and a French Gaullist the key responsibilities in the market's membership talks with Britain.

title: Job Changes:
description: B. P. Russell, president of Crum & Forster, has been appointed chief executive officer also. He succeeds William C. Ridgeway Jr., who continues as chairman of the board and chairman of the executive and finance committees of Crum & Forster and four of its insurance companies.

title: Bankers Rescue Chrysler Amid Developing Gloom
description: DETROIT, July 4The wolf has again been beaten from the Chrysler Corporation's door, and this time the bankers did it.

title: Arabs From States Fighting Israel Visit Occupied Areas
description: TEL AVIV, July 4Arab citizens, of countries at war with Israel have been coming in record numbers to spend their summer holidays in Israeloccupied territory, it was reported here this week.

title: UNITARIANS BLOCK FUND FOR BLACKS
description: SEATTLE, July 4The Unitarian Universalist Association, faced with a choice of austerity for the next two years or funding a separate program for blacks, decided on austerity at its ninth annual general assembly here.

title: Lillian M. Stauffbacher Plans Wedding to Brewster T. Gillies
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 4 Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Stauffacher have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lillian Moss Stauffacher, to Brewster Towl Gillies, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Gillies Jr. of Syosset, L. I. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: HART SEEKS DESIGN TO CUT REPAIR COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, asked Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe today to include designs for lowering repair costs in the $7million in contracts for development of an experimental safety vehicle.

title: Woods Has Broken Thumb
Young Activists Defeated at Library Association's Convention
description: DETROIT, July 4Mrs. Lillian M. Bradshaw, the new president of the American Library Association, said last night that librarians must con sider the relevance of their work to human problems in changing society and become more responsive to the demands of the young.

title: Joyce Hill and W. P. Stoner Wed
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 4Miss Joyce Elizabeth Hill, managing editor of Art and Archeology Technical Abstracts, was married in the Wren Chapel of the College of William and Mary here this afternoon to W. Patrick Stoner, a graduate student at the University of. Virginia.

title: IDA SOYER
description: Ida Soyer, a leading performer with the Tamiris ballet and modern dance company in the 1930's and 1940's and the wife of the artist Moses Soyer, died yesterday at her summer home in Hampton Bays, L. She was 61 years old and also maintained a residence in Manhattan.

title: Point of View:
description: The following article was written by Richard C. Gerstenberg, vice chairman of the General Motors Corporation.

title: SANDERS TO PLAY IN BRITISH OPEN
description: BARRY, Scotland, July 4 (UPI)Doug Sanders and Dave Marr qualified today for the British Open golf championship which starts on Wednesday at St. Andrew's.

title: SIEBERT, RED SOX, TOPS INDIANS, 51
description: BOSTON, July 4 (AP)The Boston Red Sox, paced by Sonny Siebert's twohit pitching and homers by Billy Conigliaro, Mike Andrews, Reggie Smith and Tony Conigliaro. crushed the Cleveland Indians, 51, today.

title: Ky Says U.S. Economic Aid Has Failed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, July 5Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said last night that United States aid to South, Vietnam had failed to promote longrange economic development and was used only to patch over shortterm problems.

title: Personality:
description: John Francis McGillicuddy is 39 years old, a lawyer, a former star defensive back for the great Princeton football teams of the early Nineteen Fifties, and the father of a brood of fivein order, Sean, Faith, Erin, Brian and John.

title: GIBBS CAPS RALLY
description: The New York Yankees ended their longest losing streak of the season at four games yesterday when they scored three times in the seventh inning to defeat the Washington Senators, 42.

title: Letters: Tastes and La Pyramide
description: To THE EDITOR: O WOE to mea pox on Milton Viorst. His article on La Pyramide restaurant in Vienne, France, (Travel Section, June 15) whet my palate's memory. Finally, after two and onehalf years, my husband and I are able to enter other restaurants around the world without saying, But it doesn't begin to compare to the Pyramide. However, thanks to Mr. Viorst, we are once again drooling. Our meal at La Pyramide proved so incomparable that a few days later we drove hours out of our way and pleaded for admittance again to this fabulous restaurant. Two meals there in one weektruly a dream. Driving through France is indeed an eater's paradise. In every village there is at least a onestar restaurant serving a sumptuous meal with, generally, service and a wine to match. Indeed, around Lyons, the gastronomic center, one has a nearly impossible task of choosing.

title: DELAWARE DROPS EDUCATIONAL TV
description: DOVER, Del., July 4The first statewide educational television network in the country has become the first to be scrapped.

title: U.S. Skipper Among Leaders In RoundBritain Sailing
description: PLYMOUTH, England, July (AP)  Twentyfive yachts began a 2,000mile race round Britain today.

title: A Sense Of Strain And Strife In National Mood
description: WASHINGTON  Let the record show that at the age of 194, and in the middle of a war, the United States Government and the most conspicuous friends of its Republican Administration could not safely plan here on a joyous celebration of the Fourth of July until they had banned from their program all mention of the war and all other political matters.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IDID not know the late Frank Silvera well enough to write a proper tribute to this extraordinary man, but we had an experience together that is worth telling about, I think. I know it was part of my education.

title: Women Stay on Small Farms Throughout the Middle West
description: THOMPSON, IowaThe young farm wife is alive and living very well, thank you, in tiny farming communities throughout the Middle West.

title: COLOMBIA TO JOIN CARIBBEAN BANK
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 5Colombia will become the first LatinAmerican country to join the new Caribbean development bank in a move to expand her trade and help the struggling islands of the West Indies. The official announcement will be made tomorrow, according to high Government officials working on the final details over the weekend.

title: Widgeon and Pen Duick III Complete Race to Tahiti
description: LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP)Two more yachts crossed the finish line today in the Los AngelestoTahiti sailing race.

title: Advertising: Enthusiastic Space Peddler
description: Morton S. Bailey Jr., pub lisher of Better Homes & Gar dens, is a second generation space peddler, and loves it.

title: TWO ISRAELI JETS REPORTED DOWN
description: CAIRO, July 5Cairo's mili tary spokesman reported that two more Israeli Phantom fighterbombers were shot down today over the central sector of the Suez Canal and that two crewmen were captured.

title: ALLEGED MAFIOSO TIED TO U.S. ROAD
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) The Government is planning to build a superhighway through a soggy bayou land owned by Carlos Marcello, a reputed Mafia leader, and pay his business empire about $153,000.

title: Meadowbrook Riders Win Northeastern Polo Title
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., July 5The Meadowbrook polo team defeat ed Bethpage, 65, today at Bethpage State Park and won the Northeastern intracircuit 12goal turnament.

title: Employe of BurnedOut Store Charged With Arson
description: A 24yearold security guard was arrested yesterday and charged with setting a fire that blazed for five hours in crowd ed Times Square on Saturday night, injured three firemen, and snarled traffic.

title: CHALLENGE WINS STRATFORD SAIL
Radio
description: Music

title: MRS. WILLIAM C. SEGAL
description: Mrs. Cora Mantel Segal, editor of American Fabrics, a textile publication, died Sat urday night at Bay Shore (L. I.) Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street. Her husband, William C. Segal, is the publisher of the publication.

title: Votes of Week In Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 5Fol lowing are the votes of delega tions from New York, New Jer sey and Connecticut on the ma jor rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.

title: Chief Organizer of Honor America Day Is Hoping to Make It an Annual Event
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  J. Willard Marriott, chairman of the executive committee that organized Honor America Day yesterday, said today that he thought it should become an annual event.

title: Great Falls, Mont.: A Fourth of July With Feeling
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont., July 5  The mayor, a square shouldered man in a dark suit, spoke firmly into the microphones that captured his voice and amplified it to the level of the thunder of doom.

title: Rome:A Mystic, Nihilistic Prize Novel
description: ROMEThe Premio Strega was won Friday night by Guido Piovene with his latest novel, Le Stelle Fredde. The scene was the elegant nymph aeum of the renaissance villa of Pope Julius II, floodlit for the television cameras and filled with an unusually large crowd of writers, movie stars, directors, journal ists, beautiful peo ple and their friends, who cheered wildly at the announcement. The prize, the most famous in Italy, has been awarded every year since 1947, and almost always, strangely enough, to the best book of the last 12 months. As a re sult, the money (1million lire, or 51,600, offered by the Alberti family who manufac ture the Strega liqueur), is not so important as the pres tige and sales generated by the publicity.

title: Barbara Kelly Wed to Ira Lipman
description: Miss Barbara Kelly was married here last evening to Ira A. Lipman, president and chief executive officer of Guardsmark, Inc., a security and protection company here. The ceremony was performed in the ballroom at the Re gency by Rabbi Sanford Selt zer, director of the Northeast Council of the Union of Amer ican Hebrew Congregations.

title: Newcombe Almost Shut Out of Ball
description: LONDON, July 5 (AP)John Newcombe won the men's tennis title at Wimble don yesterday, but that wasn't good enough to get him into the traditional Wim bledon Ball last night.

title: The Chief Awards
description: TERRIER (Justin Mlls, judge)1, Jane Esther Henderson's West Highland White, Ch. DeGo Hubert; 2, Mrs. Charles C. Stalter's Scottie, Ch. Barberry Knowe Spit Fire; 3, Patrick Corless's Kerry Blue, Ch. Calkerry's Determined; 4, Marcia St. Lifer's Bedlington, Ch. St. Lifer's Merri Martin.

title: CHINESE MASSES WORK ON CANALS
description: HONG KONG, July 5The photographs accompanying an article in a recent issue of a Peking magazine, China Recon structs, looked as if they had been taken in an earlier cen tury.

title: Rangel Calls Nixon Honest But Deplores His Policies
description: Assemblyman Charles B. Ran gel termed President Nixon and Vice President Agnew as one of the most honest Presidents and Vice Presidents probably in the history of the United States.

title: Entertainment Events
description: INTERNATIONAL BACH SOCIETY CONGRESS, with Rosaiyn Tureck, di rectorharpsichordist, Ruth Waterman, violin, Sandra Darling, soprano, Lin Maxwell, mezzo soprano, vocal quartet, Lincoln Center LibraryMuseum, 6.

title: Chapot of U.S. Riding Team Wins at French Horse Show
description: LA BAULE, France, July 5 (Reuters)Frank Chapot of the United States won the Prix d'Honneur duPrefet today in a horse show preceding the world equestrian championships.

title: Airline's List of Passengers and Crew
description: MONTREAL, July 5 (UPI)Air Canada made public today the following list of crew mem bers and some of the passen gers aboard the DC8 that crashed at Toronto on a flight from Montreal to Los Angeles:

title: English Cocker Spaniel Takes BestinShow Prize at Walden
description: WALDEN, N. Y., July 5A 5yearold blue roan English cocker spaniel, Ch. Ancram's Simon, the topwinning repre sentative of his breed last year, keeps right on the victorious trail.

title: Brown and Tully Advance To Final of Martin Tennis
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 5Bailey Brown of Bronxville, the defending champion, and Bill Tully of Pelham reached the final of the annual Paul Martin Memorial tennis tournament at the Fox Meadow Tennis Club today.

title: LOCAL TAXES FOUND UP 111% IN DECADE
description: ALBANY, July 5  Local government taxes and assess ments more than doubled in New York State from 1958 to 1968, State Controller Arthur Levitt reported today. The dec ade's rise was from $2.3billion to $4.99billion, or 111.5 per cent.

title: Robb Sagendorph, 69, Publisher Of Farmer's Almanac Is Dead
description: DUBLIN, N.H., July 5Robb Sagendorph, owner and pub lisher of The Old Farmer's Almanac and Yankee magazine, died yesterday at Monadnock Community Hospital in nearby Peterborough following a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Dublin.

title: 11 Firebombs Found Under Police Cars In a Parking Yard
description: Molotov cocktails were found under five police radio cars in a fencedin parking area at Cunningham Park, near Grand Central Parkway in Hollis, Queens. early yesterday.

title: Robin Bonnie Striar Is Married
description: The marriage of Miss Robin Bonnie Striar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Striar of South Orange, N. J., to Neil Steven Rollnick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Roll nick of Miami, took place at the WaldorfAstoria yester day.

title: Youths Battle Park Rangers
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK. Calif., July 5 (UPI)  About 500 young people, stirred by the attempted arrest of a hip pie, threw rocks and bottles at park rangers, looted campsites and overturned automobiles last night at this Sierra Moun tain retreat. Park officials said that about 70 persons had been arrested and that at least three officers were slightly injured.

title: Major League Baseball
description: American League

title: U.S. America's Cup Crewmen Work High and Dry
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 5Sandpaper and hoses were the busiest pieces of equip ment on the America's Cup scene today.

title: Israeli Nurses on Strike
description: TEL AVIV, July 5 (AP)Israel's nurses went on strike for higher pay today. A skele ton staff of nurses dealt with emergency cases only. About 11,000 registered nurses voted to strike after repeated de mands for a 15 per cent wage increase had been rejected by the Government's civil service commission. The average pay of an Israeli nurse is $160 a month.

title: Scores Arrested in Ohio In Resort Town Violence
description: RUSSELLS POINT, Ohio, July 5 (AP)  Scores of young people were in jail or out on bond today after a night in which the police fought youths who rampaged through this re sort town, smashing windows and looting shops.

title: Article 2  No Title
Canada's Indians Fear Shift in Status
description: CUT KNIFE, Saskatchewan Kenneth and Lorna Too tootsis, who live on the Poundmaker Indian Reserve, have not read the Canadian Government's white paper on Indian policy, but they oppose it and they know why.

title: Vietcong Hail Bruce
description: HONG KONG, July 5 (Reu ters)  The Vietcong today joined with the North Viet namese in welcoming the ap pointment of David K. E. Bruce as the new chief negotiator at the Paris peace talks, the North Vietnamese press agency re ported in a broadcast heard here.

title: Wall St. Watches as Merged Firm Opens
description: F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan & Co., one of the nation's largest investment houses, will open for business offi cially for the first time today and all of Wall Street will be monitoring its performance.

title: Sunday Box Scores
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J., July 5David Ross and Torn Hirsch of New York won the New Jersey state senior doubles tennis title today with a 61, 62 vic tory over Dr. Robert Schwartz of Milburn and Ted Cohn of West Orange.

title: City to Get 1,000 Bet Windows in Year
description: At least 1,000 offtrack bet ting windows in 100 wagering parlors are expected to open within a year, according to Howard J. Samuels who was appointed to head the program by Mayor Lindsay on Saturday.

title: Imports Rise as Italy's Auto Output Lags
description: ROME, July 5  Anyone who sees this country's con gested cities and highways would think there is no space for more cars, but every day now 4,000 Italians buy new automobiles. Every fourth car is of foreign make.

title: JAMES C. FLEMING
description: James C. Fleming, a machin ist at The New York Times, died Saturday at Montefiore Hospi tal following surgery for an ulcer. He was 43 years old and lived at 3164 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: Paul Malvey Fiance Of Stephanie Ryan
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., July 5Miss Stephanie Lucy Ryan, a stewardess with United Airlines, and Paul Francis Malvey, who expects to receive a Ph. D. in economics from the Uni versity of Notre Dame next May, plan to be married here next month.

title: Gibson Plans Investigation Unit To Study Newark Departments
description: Newark's city departments face an investigation for cor ruption and financial misman agement and Newark's resi dents face higher taxes if there is not a substantial increase in state and Federal aid. Kenneth A. Gibson, who took office as Mayor six days ago, said yesterday.

title: BUSINESSES AIDED ON SOCIAL GOALS
description: A manufacturing company with difficulty integrating its labor force, a life insurance company anxious to sell to the Negro market and a book pub lisher with a desire to involve its younger employes in the op eration of training programs have all turned to a new con sulting concern in recent months for assistance in deal ing with these situations.

title: Litchfield, Conn., Oarsmen Win 5 Races in Schuylkill Regatta
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5The Litchfield Rowing Association of Connecticut, coached by Bill Stowe of Columbia University, scored five victories today in the fifth annual Philadelphia youth championship regatta on the Schuylkill River.

title: Fighting Utility Rates Is a Busy Field
description: The Sydney County Council and the Victorian State Elec tricity Commission in Australia wish Theodore E. Maynard had never founded the National Utility Services International Pty., Ltd., down under.

title: AMON'S CAR NEXT AND BRABHAM'S 3D
description: CLERMONT  FERRAND, France, July 5Jochen Rindt won the French Grand Prix to day and now has an excellent chance of becoming the first world drivers champion who gets car sick.

title: FRAN'S IMAGE TAKES HORSE SHOW CROWN
description: SPARTA, N. J., July 5Fran's Image, owned by the Lotus Farms of Spring Valley, N. Y., and handled by Holly McBride, won the regular working hunter championship in a hackoff with Mrs. A. Woithe's Winsomeore at the Northwest Jersey horse show today.

title: Major Bills in Congress
description: Bank Holding CompaniesLimiting the nonbanking activities that onebank holding companies may engage in (HR 6778)........................

title: Spokesman for Indians
description: EDMONTON, AlbertaThis year's laurels for political precocity may go to Harold Cardinal, the principal author of a red paper submitted to the federal Government last month by Canada's In dian chiefs.

title: TROOPS IN BELFAST HALT ARMS SEARCH
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 5A British Army spokes man said that all searches for arms had been completed in the predominantly Roman Catholic area of Lower Falls Road here today. The security forces also lifted a 36hour curfew.

title: Typhoon Batters Japan; Expo Cancels Programs
description: TOKYO, July 5 (Reuters)Typhoon Olga, with winds up to 90 miles an hour, battered western Japan today. The high winds caused cancellation of night entertainment programs at the world exposition in Osaka.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Working group on Southern Africa, Commission on Hu man rights3:30 P.M.

title: GUEST'S COLT WINS BY TWO LENGTHS
description: PARIS, July 5Winston F. C. Guest's Gyr won the $273,000 Grand Prix de SaintCloud in majestic style today. Gyr cov ered the 12furlong distance at the Val D'Or racetrack in 2:36.8, the fastest time here in 20 years.

title: Terrorism in the Americas
description: Early last week, the General Assembly of the Or ganization of American States agreed on modest first steps toward collective action against various kinds of terrorism in the Americas. Only one day later, the need for such action was underscored by two airliner hi jackingsone of them abortiveand the firebombing of four LatinAmerican embassies in Washington.

title: TAYLOR TRIUMPHS ON CANADIAN MAT
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, July 5 (UPI)Chris Taylor, the 19yearold giant from Muskegon Junior College in Michigan, took only 25 seconds to pin Art Frechette, of Hamilton, Ontario, today in the heavyweight divi sion of the world amateur wrestling championships.

title: Fugard Opposes Playwrights Boycott of South Africa
description: DURBAN, South Africa, July 3 Athol Fugard does not agree with the theater world's boy cott against South Africa. He believes that it has achieved nothing, except to keep out badly needed ideas.

title: Church in Oyster Bay Plans Fair
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 5 A dog show, a white ele phant booth, book stalls and antique shops will be part of the program for Saturday's fair at Christ Episcopal Church here.

title: CHENOWETH WINS HYDROPLANE RACE
description: MADISON, Ind., July 25 (AP) Dean Chenoweth won the In diana Governor's Cup race for unlimited hydroplanes today for the second straight year, but in a different boat.

title: Maddox Hailed at RightWing Rally in Boston
description: BOSTON, July 5Gov. Les ter G. Maddox of Georgia re ceived a rousing ovation today from 800 John Birch Society members and other ultracon servatives at the eighth annual New England rally for God, Family and Country.

title: Coney Island: Remnants of Fun and Freedom by the Sea Still Pull Crowds
description: Near noon, the IND D trains from the interior of Brooklyn round the screeching curve to Stillwell Avenue with increasing frequency, discharging fresh crowds of pleasure seekers in the sour sea air of Coney Island.

title: Preminger and Sinatra To Make Murder Movie
description: Otto Preminger and Frank Sinatra have joined forces after a 15year interval to co produce the film version of Where the Dark Streets Go, the novel by Dorothy Salis bury Davis published by Scribner's last November. They last cooperated in 1955 to make the controversial but successful The Man With the Golden Arm. Mr. Prem inger produced and directed the film and Mr. Sinatra as the Chicago narcotics addict and gambler of the title.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It is July, 1970, and according to its latest promotional calculations, baseball considers itself 101 years old, because the first team, comprised entirely of professionals signed to fullseason contracts, played in 1869.

title: DualPurpose Funds
description: July 2, 1970

title: Orban Retains National Saber Crown
description: Alex Orban, a 30yearold native Hungarian who immi grated to the United States in 1956, won the national saber championship for the second straight year and third time last night at the Hotel Com modore.

title: Youths, Lured by New York's Siren Song, Scrape By
description: Gary Barnes, 21 years old, came east from Ball State University in Indiana to dis cover what this New York life is all about, but after two weeks of sampling the city's rents and prices he is going home, with regrets, to Indianapolis. James Myron, 20, up from Duke University in North Carolina, is making it here, but just barely, he says, by living out of a 50centsa day locker in the Port Au thority Bus Terminal, taking his meals at pizza parlors and fruit stands and bedding down wherever he can find a welcome in Greenwich Vil lage.

title: 2 Plane Crash Sites Found
description: Searchers found the wreck age yesterday of two planes that crashed in separate acci dents this weekend in New England, according to The As sociated Press. A Massachusetts Civil Air Patrol plane spotted the wreckage of a light plane that crashed Saturday in Pel ham, Mass., and killed the pilot, Charles G. Mackie, 57 years old, of Elyria, Ohio. A patrol spokesman said searchers sighted wreckage in Long Is land Sound near the mouth of the Connecticut River that was identified as being part of a Cessna310 flown Friday by Ray Tally of New Cumberland, Pa.

title: U.S. Again Rules Out a Mideast Force
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 5White House officials said today that in expressing their concern about the Middle East crisis they had not meant to suggest that United States per sonnel would be sent there. Such an option, they said, is not even under consideration.

title: Burglars Take $25,000 At Forest Hills Post Office
description: Burglars broke into the For est Hills Post Office branch at 10628 Queens Boulevard over the weekend, burned open three safes and escaped with $25,000 in checks, currency and stamps, the police reported last night.

title: Results of Nearby Regattas
description: CELEBRITY CLASS1, Todd Kana; 2, George Trough; 3, R. Horwitz. Series winnerKana.

title: Dr. Mario Schteingart, Led B'nai B'rith in Argentina
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 5 Dr. Mario Schteingart, for mer president of B'nai B'rith in Argentina, died today at the University of Michigan Hospi tal. He was 77 years old and lived in Buenos Aires.

title: WIDOW, 58, IS SHOT; BRONX YOUTHS HELD
description: YONKERS, N.Y., July 5Four Bronx youths were arrest ed today in connection with the shooting of a 58yearold Yonkers widow at a bus stop here this morning.

title: Needham, Harper Lists Gains in First Report
description: If you heard that Needham, Harper & Steers, which is not a public company, was issuing its first annual report and you assumed that was be cause they did particularly well, you would have as sumed correctly.

title: Progress at I.S. 201
description: When Intermediate School 201 first entered upon its rebellious course of community control in 1967, all the cards were stacked against its success.
