description: KINGSTON, N. Y., July 9 (UPI)Counsel for promoters of a series of rock festivals said yesterday he had with drawn an Appellate Division motion to vacate a stay against the programs, since those planned for the next two week ends had been canceled.

title: 3 Upstate Firemen Accused Of Having Set 20 Blazes
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y.. July 9 (AP)The state police arrested three members of the town of Providence's volunteer fire company late yesterday and charged them with setting more than 20 fires in their area in the last 18 months.

title: Laver Beats Okker in 3 Sets; Virginia Wade Wins in Dublin
description: DUBLIN, July 9 (Reuters)Rod Laver, the dethroned Wim bledon champion regained some of his shattered confidence to day by overaking Tom Okker of the Netherlands and win ning, 36, 63, 62, in the Irish open tennis tournament.

title: Landlords'
description: A possible turning point in the city's current strike of building service workers takes place today. It will be the public hearing on the City Council's rentcontrol bill, a hearing the Mayor is required to hold before he can sign the measure.

title: Plans for Korea Cutback Approved, Laird Asserts
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, citing budgetary pres sures and the Nixon doctrine, said today that plans had been approved for the removal of some American troops from South Korea.

title: Times Distribution Delayed by Mailers
description: A twohour union meeting of mailers at The New York Times during a working period last night delayed and reduced the distribution of the City Edition, the first, which normally con sists of up to 240,000 copies.

title: 4 STATES MAY LOSE U.S. WELFARE AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) The Nixon administration threatened California and three other states today with a loss of Federal welfare aid and told some 35 other states to remedy similar failings in their welfare systems.

title: STOCKS ARE DOWN ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market closed easier yesterday follow ing news that British dock workers would strike next Tuesday. Word of Government intervention in the dispute came after the close of business.

title: Market Place:
description: Remember the good old pre1969 days when every weekend seemed to bring news of another massive takeover attempt?

title: Amex Deists Louis Sherry
description: The hoard Of governors of the American Stock Exchange said yesterday it was delisting Louis Sherry, Inc., effective with the Opening today. The ex change noted that the company had reported losses in three of its last four fiscal years, which is grounds for delisting. The stork closed yesterday at 1 down .

title: Lady Eaton Dies
description: TORONTO, July 9 (AP)Lady Eaton, widow of Sir John Craig Eaton of the Canadian merchandising chain, died at her home today after a short illness. Her family said she was 91 years old.

title: Sihanouk Says North Korea Offered Him Troops
description: PEKING, July 9  Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that he felt tempted to call in North Korean troops to help liberate his country. He said premier Kim II Sung urged him recently to accept volunteers.

title: LevinTownsend Finds Accord On Repayment of Debt to I.B.M.
description: The LevinTownsend Com puter Corporation announced last night that it had reached agreement with the Interna tional Business Machines Cor poration on a plan of payments to retire the total debt of Levin Townsend to I.B.M. of about $49million.

title: Livingston of Saints Is Casualty Before Football Training Starts
description: Andy Livingston, the New Orleans Saints leading run ner, is the first casualty of the pro football season Working out on Tuesday at the Saints practice field in Metairie, La., Livingston went down when his knee collapsed nine days before the scheduled opening of training camp.

title: A Son Is Born Here To Tohn Slocums Jr.
description: A son was born on June 30 to Mr. and Mrs. John Jer maine Slocum Jr. of New York in Doctors Hospital. The child has been named for his father, who is with the private banking house of Brown Brothers, Harriman & Co.

title: GARY J. RENAUD
description: Gary G. Renaud, a freelance photographer, was killed Sun day when he fell from a motor cycle near Woodbridge, N. J He was 35 years old and lived at 22 Cornelia Street.

title: Excerpts From President's Message on Reorganization of Environmental Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message to Congress today on reorgan ization of environmental agencies:

title: Bond Prices Rally
description: The bond market contiuned to travel yesterday toward lower interest rates, but the road became a little less of the superhighway it had been since midJune.

title: Major League Baseball
description: National League

title: British and American Rivals Blast, Putt and Pray in British Open Golf
FRANCIS V. KUGHLER, LED ARTISTS'
description: Francis Vandeveer Kughler, a painter and former president of the Salmagundi Club for artists, died Saturday at Me morial Hospital after a long ill ness. He was 68 years old. He lived at 2870 Heath Avenue, the Bronx, and maintained studio at the Hotel des Artistes, 1 West 67th Street.

title: Judge Acts in Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., July 9Federal District Judge J. Robert Martin ordered 10 South Caro lina school districts today to work with the United States Office of Education on plans for immediate conversion to unitary, nondiscriminatory school systems.

title: U.S. Urges Prison Reform by Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The United States is trying to persuade the South Vietnamese Government to do away with, the socalled tiger cages at its island prison on Con Son, 140 miles southeast of Saigon.

title: U.S. Aide Named Director Of Police Complaint Board
description: Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday the appointment of Sterling Johnson Jr. as executive direc tor of the Civilian Complaint Review Board. He succeeds Benjamin Ward, who was ap pointed deputy commissioner in charge of departmental trials last month.

title: Court Invalidates 6% Fare Rise Granted to Airlines Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)  The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia invalidated today a Civil Aeronautics Board order od last September granting domestic airlines a 6 per cent fare increase. The order be comes effective in 21 days.

title: Advertising: Agency Buys 3 Magazines
description: TathamLaird & Kudner Advertising apparently has become the first ad agency to purchase an advertising me dium since the American As sociation of Advertising Agencies relaxed its rules last April.

title: Edwin S. Friendly Dead at 86; Headed Publishers Association
description: Edwin S. Friendly, a former president of the American Newspaper Publishers Associa tion whose newspaper manage ment career spannd more then 50 years, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 86 years old on June 15.

title: Bank Executive Slain
description: BOSTON, July 9 (UPI)Ed ward Grenier, 40 years old, ex ecutive vice president of the Mount Vernon Cooperative Bank, was shot to death today during a struggle with a flee ing gunman who had robbed the bank of an undetermined amount of money.

title: In Westport, Arr. 7:37 Is No Certainty
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 9 On a recent workday morning, the 7:37 did not arrive because, as Frank Bonagiuso, the cheerful tick etseller, explained, the en gine caught fire.

title: David Dobin Weds Elayne Lubarr
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., July 9  Miss Elayne Lubarr and David M. Dobin, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Rubin R. Dobin of Lawrence and Herzliya, Is rael, were married this eve ning at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst by the bride groom's father, who is chair man of special projects for the Jewish National Fund of America and chairman of the Far Rockaway Jewish Com munity Council.

title: Median Barrier Installed on Bridge
description: The first section of a 32 inchhigh steel median barrier, designed to prevent headon collisions on the eightlane upper level of the George Washington Bridge, was low ered into place yesterday.

title: Control Commission Backs Peace Efforts by Laotians
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 9 (Agence FrancePresse)  The three members of the Interna tional Control Commission on IndochinaPoland, India and Canadahave just signed their first joint statement on Laos in the eightyear existence of the commission.

title: City Vows to Aid Drivers; Taxi Shutdown Averted
description: The city promised yesterday an allout drive to protect the taxi driver from holdup men, thereby forestalling a daily midnightto6 A.M. shutdown threatened by owners of 6,900 fleet taxis.

title: WILLIAM REEVES, LAWYER, 75, DIES
description: William Harvey Reeves, a lawyer who specialized in inter national law, died yesterday at ColurnhiaPreshyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 273 Harbor Road in Southport. conn., and at 200 East 66th Street.

title: SAILSTONE IS 2D TO 12 FAVORITE
description: Red Reality won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday as a 1to2 favorite. But even the most devoted of his adherents among the 27,861 spectators were willing to concede that the Cragwood Stable's gelding did not win like a 1to2 shot.

title: Books of The Times
description: Once upon a time in The Nation maga zine, commenting on Henry James, Ken neth Rexroth defined a snob as someone who imitates the manners of the class above him, leading at least one reader to wonder whether a Bohemian might be similarly defined as someone who imitates the manners of the class below him. Now steal a glance at the picture of Mr. Rexroth accom panying this col umn. Isn't there something, well undignified about a 65yearold poet, critic, translator, autodidact a n d curmudgeon per mitting himself to be photographed with a sudden sprout of mutton chops and a mane of white hair wrapped up in what looks like an Indian bandanathe unseemly lust of an elder statesman to be with it, what ever it is this month? No. Mr. Rexroth has never been one to stand on his dignity, certainly not in print, and sometimes not even at National Book Award ceremonies. He stands, instead, for the dignity of other people, which is more important.

title: Gunmen Kill Chilean Student
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 9 (Reuters) A young student was shot and killed by uniden tifed gunmen last night during a clash between demonstrators and the police at the end of a 24hour strike called by the leftwing Chilean United Work ers Confederation.

title: Roundup: Tigers Triumph On a Grand Slam Single
description: Denny McLain was the starting pitcher, so he wasn't able to thrill the Detroit fans with another dazzling display of hitting baseballs into the stands.

title: Thant, Opening Parley, Urges Youth of World to Help Reduce Tension
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9The World Youth Assembly opened today with a plea from Secretary Gen eral Thant for idealistic youth to lead the world away from tensionan appeal that was quickly lost under a blanket of wideranging political at tacks coming mainly from leftist delegations. Youthssome in sport shirts with skimpy beards and a smaller number of women variously attired in African cottons, pants suits or miniskirts moved into the seats of the great domed General Assem bly hall usually reserved for highranking ministers and diplomats. For once, the reg ular delegates, who turned out for the opening of the nineday assembly, were seat ed in the rear as silent. On lookers. The youths speeches were unpolished, the events were confused and often con tradictory, and the whole af fair for the moment led no where. But for sheer spirit and verve the youths macle the United Nations  occasion ally wellmannered debate seem faintly like a prayer meeting. A small but seem ingly welldisciplined group of delegates was notably active. Every suggestion to expel groups from South Vietnam, South Korea and Nationalist China was applauded enthusi astically and there were many such motions, mostly from the Eastern Europeans.

title: MONEY EXPANDING AT A SLOWER PACE
description: The pace of monetary ex pansion is continuing gradually to slow, banking data pub lished yesterday showed.

title: Best Choice for Labor
description: Roy Jenkins was the best possible choice for deputy leader of the British Labor party. His election by an overwhelming margin not only augurs well for the future of a party recovering from unexpected election defeat; it is good news on a crucial issue for Prime Minister Heath's Conservative Government.

title: $31,800 TROT WON BY MARLU PRIDE
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 9Marlu Pride, parked out in 1:01 15 halfmile, shrugged off the extra distance and, with Herve Filion sitting noncha lantly in the sulky, easily cap tured the 21st edition of the United States Harness Writers Association Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: Cabinet in West Germany Approves 12% Budget Rise
description: BONN, July 9 (AP)West Germany's 1971 budget, ap proved by the Cabinet today exceeds 100 billion marks of $27billion, for the first time.

title: Boating Outlook
description: WindSouth to southeast, 1020 knots today and to night, south to southwest, 10 15 knots tomorrow and vari able, 10 knots or less, tomor row night and Sunday.

title: Pollution Threatens Extinction of 2 British Sea Birds
description: LONDON, July 9Pollu tion of British coastal waters threatens the existence of two sea birds, the black guil lemot and the razorbilled auk, the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds warn ed today.

title: Two Duos Score 68's to Pace SpeededUp Anderson Trials
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 9 A novel method was intro duced today to vanquish that old golfing bugabooslow play.

title: Jury Picked in Slaying
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 9 (UPI)A jury was selected to day for the murder trial of John Norman Collins, a former university student, charged with slaying Karen Sue Beineman, a coed. last July. Testimony is to begin July 20.

title: Council to Study City's Use of Outside Consultants
description: City Council leaders an nounced yesterday an investi gation of the city's use of out side consultants and at the same time proposed two revi sions in the city Charter that were designed to put checks on the awarding of consultant con tracts.

title: 7 U.S. Wrestlers Capture World FreeStyle Openers
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, July 9 (AP)Don Bohm of Lansing, Mich., was one of seven Ameri cans who won their firstround, matches in the world amateur prestyle wrestling champion ships that opened today. Three Americans were beaten.

title: NEW FEE WEIGHED TO INSURE TRADER
description: WASHINGTON, July 9A special additional charge one all stock transactions, amount ing to 20 cents per $1,000, may ultimately be imposed on investors to finance the pro posed new program of insur ance against brokerage firm failures.

title: Met's New Young Lucia
description: Gail Robinson, a 24yearold soprano who had sung only bit parts at the Metro politan Opera, substituted this summer on tour in De troit in the title role of Lucia di Lammermoor. She did so well, by all reports, that her New York debut in the role Wednesday night aroused more than ordinary antici pation.

title: U.S. Officials Seek to Reassure Parley in Paris on Foreign Aid
description: PARIS, July 9Nixon Ad ministration officials sought to day to convince skeptical of ficials of other developed na tions that the political climate is changing in the United States in favor of larger foreign aid spending. They cited an in crease in toreign aid appro priations last year as a sign.

title: Germans Find U.S. Secrets
description: KITZINGEN, West Germany, July 9 (Reuters)Two youths discovered a United States Army safe with classified docu ments in the Main River, Amer ican military officials said to day. All the documents, marked secret, were still intact, but about $500 in cash and $150 in jewelry were missing from the safe, belonging to an Army unit in this northern Bavarian town.

title: WATER SCULPTURE COOLS E. THIRD ST.
description: If East Third Street stays cool for the next month, some of the credit must go to four water sculptures.

title: Arms and the Man Given in Chichester Is Short of the Mark
description: CHICHESTER, England, July 9Chichester this year is evi dently an unhealthy place for, stars. Pneumonia first struck Christopher Plummer out of the cast of Peer Gynt and now Laurence Harvey has retired from 'Arms and the Man with a broken leg.

title: Goldberg, in Campaign Upstate, rinds Abortion Is Still Big Issue
description: UTICA, N.Y., July 9Arthur Goldberg discovered today that although the most liberal abortion law in the nation wen into effect in New York State on July 1, the issue of abor tion can still be explosive.

title: Jury Finds Sweig Guilty Of Single Perjury Count
description: A jury of four women and eight men last night found Dr. Martin Sweig guilty of one count of perjury and acquitted him on six other counts after deliberating last night and all day yesterday.

title: Radio
description: 9:30 A.M.Noon, WRVR: Just Music: Dantesque Concert.

title: Brooklyn Party Leaders Fend Off Foes
description: Regular Brooklyn Democratic and Republican organization leaders withstood challenges to their leadership in stormy coun ty Committee meetings yester day and last night.

title: Music: Vital Lift for Jazz
description: For the last two years, New Yorkers have come to identify the Preservation Hall Jazz Band as the sixpiece group led by Billie and DeDe Pierce. But while this band has visited New York sev eral times, another Preserva tion Hall Jazz Band, led by Kid Thomas Valentine, has also been on tour. (Actually, at Preservation Hall in New Orleans, the personnel on the bandstand changes from night to night. The touring bands are the two most permanent ly organized groups made up of Preservation Hall musi cians).

title: MILLARD P. WEAR
description: Millard Price Wear, for 38 years on the editorial staff of Variety, the theatrical trade weekly, died yesterday of heart ailment and emphysema. He was 73 years old and lived at 2 Horatio Street.

title: Pistons Get Driscoll of B.C.
description: DETROIT, July 9 (AP)The Detroit Pistons signed today Terry Driscoll, a basketball standout at Boston College. who played last season for team in Bologna, Italy.

title: Amalia Rodrigues Gives A Fado Recital on Love
description: For a few short weeks, Amalia Rodrigues has left her private life as Senhora Cesar Seabra, wife of a weal thy Brazilian and mistress of an 18thcentury house near Lisbon, to sing for New York ers the fados that have brought her international ac claim. Accompanied by three highly accomplished guitar ists, she is offering her bit tersweet songs of love lost, love betrayed, love unrequited at the Chateau Madrid through July 15.

title: Foreign Affairs: Again the Wild Irish
description: DUBLINAll week the Irish Government has been warning foreign ambassadors that a civil war situation is possible in the northern six counties of Ulster, which are attached to Britain, unless London takes pacifying steps.

title: American General Missing in Vietnam With Six in Copter
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9  The United States Army disclosed today that Maj. Gen. George W. Casey, who di rected the withdrawal of the last American ground troops from Cambodia on June 29, has been missing since Tuesday when he took off in his heli copter. An intensive search is under way, an Army spokesman said.

title: ALFRED G. WALTON PASTOR 50 YEAR
description: The Rev. Dr. Alfred Grant Walton, for three decades pas tor of one of New York's larg est churches, died yesterday morning, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 750 East 18th Street, Brooklyn. He was 82 years old.

title: Thai Regime Wins by One Vote on Higher Taxes
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 9 (Reuters) By a margin of only one vote, the Government turn ed back a move in Parliament today to condemn a decree under which import and sales taxes have already been in creased.

title: 300 Youths Roam New Bedford Area, Burning Buildings,
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 9 (AP)All available local po licemen were called to the pre dominantly black West End section tonight when 300 per sons took to the streets, throwing rocks and bottles.

title: CAMPUSES'
description: BOSTON, July 9 (AP) Presidents of state colleges throughout the Northeastern states were told at a confer ence tonight that public reac tions to campus turmoil may hurt financing for colleges and universities far more than even pessimistic educators now acknowledge.

title: Criminal Court Girding For First Trials by Jury
description: On July 20, jury trials will be available for the first time to defendants in New York City's Criminal Court.

title: John Wesley Dean 3d Made Counsel to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) President Nixon announced today that John Wesley Dean 3d, 31 years old, is moving from the Justice Department to the White House as coun sel to the President.

title: LACK OF TRAINING CITED IN DITCHING
description: SAN JUAN, P. R.; July 9The copilot of a jetliner that ran out of fuel and ditched at sea May 2 said today that he had never flown the route be fore and that his employer had repeatedly denied requests for training to prepare him for the flight.

title: AMERICANS SCORE IN 9 OF 10 EVENTS
description: COLOMBES, France, July 9 The United States track team held a little meeting last night after falling behind France, 56 50, on the first day of their dual meet. The discussions paid dividends.

title: Meier Leads by 2 Strokes In Public Links Golf on 142
description: LEMONT, lll., July 9 (AP)Ted Meier of Joliet, lll., 19 years old, shot a 73 today for 2underpar 142 and a two stroke lead midway In the Na tional Public Links golf tourna ment.

title: lzaak Walton League Elects
description: NORFOLK, Va., July 9 (AP) Roy Crockett, 43 years old, of Marion, Ind., was elected to day as national president of the Izaak Walton League of America. He defeated the in cumbent president, Raymond A. Haik of Minneapolis, who was seeking a third term, by a vote of 194 to 192.

title: MAYOR WILL SIGN COUNCIL RENT BILL
description: Mayor Lindsay made it clear yesterday that he would sign into law a rentcontrol bill passed by the City Council. Landlords who have opposed the measure, the Mayor said, precipitated the strike of apart ment house workers.

title: Hospital Union Approves Pact at Einstein Institutes
description: Members of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospitals Union yesterday overwhelmingly ap proved a new twoyear con tract, ending a oneday work stoppage at institutions run by the Albert Einstein Medical College, the Bronx.

title: Senate Panel to Resume Hearings on Welfare Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 Supporters of President Nixon's welfare reform program were encouraged today when the Senate Finance Committee an nounced that It would resume suspended hearings on the leg islation later this month.

title: Jack O'Brine, 64, ExReporter For The Herald Tribune, Dead
description: MIAMI, July 9  Jack O'Brine, a former correspond ent for The New York Herald Tribune and staff writer for the information department of the Radio Corporation of America, died of cancer today in a hospital here. He was 64 years old.

title: NIXON PROPOSES 2 NEW AGENCIES ON ENVIRONMENT
description: WASHINGTON, July 9President Nixon called today for a major reshuffling of Gov ernment agencies to coordinate efforts to understand, protect and enhance the nation's en vironment.

title: Burnett to Do Proposal For Petroleum Institute
description: The Leo Burnett Company will be getting, together a pro posal for an informational and educational advertising program at the request of the American Petroleum In stitute.

title: 8 War Foes Convicted
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 9 (AP) Eight persons convicted of vandalism at the Marion County Selective Service headquarters were sentenced to four years in prison and fined $5,000 each last night by United States Dis trict Judge Cale J. Holder. The defendants are members of an antiwar group called Beaver 55.

title: Peggy Warshaysky Married Here
description: Miss Peggy Warshaysky, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Warshaysky of Nepon sit, Queens, was married here last evening to Joseph Seton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Seton of New York. The cere mony was performed by Rab bi Cyrus Arfa of Central Syn agogue in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre, where a recep tion was also given.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA AOff Manasquan the blues have been con sistently good, according to Jack Kennell at Ken's Land ing in Point Pleasant. Boats traveling about two hours in a 60degree direction have used butterfish and bunkers with success. Fluke also have been good, although south wind recently turned the water cold and ruined the prospects for a day or two Squid, spearing and smelt are being used for this. Farther north, a few king fish are being caught from the beach, with an occasion al 1to1pound blue taken during the dawnordusk period.

title: Ralph Sharp, Former Editor At The Daily News, is Dead
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 8 (UPI) Ralph Sharp, former news editor of The Daily News in New York, died today in White Plains Hospital at the age of 77. He lived at 40 Barker Ave nue here.

title: Park Service Bans Cars From Section Of Yosemite Valley
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif, July 9 (AP)The Nation al Park Service today banned automobile traffic from the east end of Yosemite Valley.

title: XEROX AIDE AND WIFE ARE SLAIN IN VIRGINIA
description: FAIRFAX, Va., July 9 (AP)A personnel specialist with the Xerox Corporation in Washing ton and his wife were shot to death early today in their plush home in Fairfax County. Their 15yearold son was later charged with murder.

title: Concern, Inc.: An Ecology Crusade Waged in Supermarket
description: WASHINGTON, D. C.People who sit near Mrs. Richard Helms at dinner parties are very likely to find themselves worrying about the percentage of phosphates in detergents.

title: New Medal Is Awarded to Wheeler
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)  President Nixon today awarded a newly created military honor, to be known as the Defense Distinguished Service Medal, to Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, who has retired as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Cairo Tells of Missiles
description: CAIRO, Friday, July 10Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, editor of Al Ahram and Min ister of National Guidance, dis closed today that two Egyptian attempts to move antiaircraft missiles to the Suez Canal zone had been suicidal because of Israeli air attacks. But the third attempt, completed recently, was a startling success, he wrote.

title: ADDONIZIO DENIES ALE ON THE STAND
description: TRENTON, July 9  Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, took the stand in his own defense here today at his trial on charges of conspiracy and extortion. He denied all charges of wrongdoing and said repeatedly that the prosecu tion's key witness against him had lied.

title: Administration Seeking to Bar Cuts in Cuban Refugee Funds
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The Administration began a fight today against Congres sional efforts to scrap the Cu ban refugee program and di vert its funds, about $120mil lion a year, to help poverty stricken Americans.

title: ORIOLES DEFEATED IN 7 INNINGS, 75
description: BALTIMORE, July 9  The New York Yankees finally got out of Baltimore tonight with victory to their credit but it was a long, hard, wet struggle that didn't last quite eight innings. The game was called because of rain, as a 75 Yan kee decision with one out and a man on second in the home half of the eighth.

title: Rogers Says Red China Is Key to Indochina Peace
description: TOKYO, July 9Secretary of State William P. Rogers described Communist China today as the key to the future of Indochina and said that peace settlement could be worked out very quickly if Peking showed enough interest.

title: Keough Leaves Hospital
description: KANSAS CITY, July 9 (AP)Joe Keough, outfielder for the Kansas City Royals, was re leased yesterday from St. Luke's Hospital, where he had been confined since June 28 with a broken leg. He is expect ed to be lost to the Royals for the remainder of the season.

title: Soviet to Study Any U.S. Offer on Space Cooperation
description: MOSCOW, July 9  The president of the Soviet Aca demy of Sciences said today that the Soviet Union would give maximum attention to specific proposals from the United States for cooperation in space exploration.

title: Chemical N.Y. Corp. Lifts Profit 1.5%
description: Three more of New York's giant hank holding companies reported secondquarter earn ings yesterday showing small gains for two of them and a small decline for the other.

title: Agnew, in Denver, Unperturbed As Fixtures Break Into. Speech
description: DENVER, July 9Vice Presi dent Agnew promised today that his rhetoric would be calm when he spoke to 700 persons at a meeting of the Education Commission of the States.

title: Spain Jails a Hijacker
description: MADRID, July 9A military court in Saragossa today sen tenced an 18year old Spanish student to six years and one day in prison and ordered him to pay $240 in damages on charges of hijacking an air liner between Madrid and Sa ragossa.

title: Kite Wins Western Medal
description: WICHITA, Kan., July 9 (AP) Tom Kite, a 20yearold col lege student from Austin, Tex., won medalist honors by an eightstroke margin today in the Western amateur golf tour nament. He had a record 273 for the four rounds of medal play. Match play begins to morrow.

title: CORNFELD FORMING SEPARATE COMPANY
description: LONDON, July 9 (Reuters)Bernard Cornfeld, who founded the Investors Overseas Services mutualfund empire, announced tonight he was forming a new company. His announcement came one week after he was voted off the I. 0. S. board of directors.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The New York Mets will pay tribute tomorrow to the man who invented them, Charles Dillon Stengel. What's that? He didn't invent them? Oh, well, it certainly seems that way. He presided as a midwife of sorts at the birth of the Mets, then nurtured this puniest offspring through the harrowing underprivileged years and final ly stepped aside to watch this creature of his imagination become champions of the world.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE FOR SECOND DAY
description: Stock prices advanced brisk ly yesterday for the second straight day as an increase in institutional activity sent trad ing volume higher.

title: Dockers in Britain Vote National Strike for Tuesday
description: LONDON, July 9 (Reuters)  Britain's 47,000 longshore men today voted to start national strike Tuesday.

title: PROFIT RECOVERY IS SHOWN BY G.E.
description: The General Electric Com pany made a recovery in the second quarter with an 8 per cent increase in earnings and a 2 per cent rise in sales, ac cording to the semiannual re port issued yesterday by Fred J. Borch, chairman.

title: U.S. COURT WIDENS RIGHTS OF HOLDERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Cor porate shareholders have broad rights to participate in corpo rate decisions that have social impact and any denial of those rights has to he based on clear ly stated reasons, the United States Court of Appeals here has held.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices edged ahead again yesterday in light trading on the American Stock Exchange. The adavnce, modest as it was, marked the second straight day of improvement after 11 consec utive declines.

title: Pacers Sign Greg McDivitt
description: INDIANAPOLIS,July 9 (AP) The Indiana Pacers of the American Basketball Associa tion announced today the sign ing of a 6foot9inch forward, ?? McDivitt of Ohio Univer

title: Senate Approves a $9Billion Appropriation Measure for the Veterans Administration
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The Senate has approved a $9billion appropriation for the veterans Administration that includes $1.8billion for medi cal care. This is $105million more than President Nixon re quested and the House ap proved.

title: Two Menus for Thrifty Cooks
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Stockton, Gerken Renamed To Junior Davis Cup Squad
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (AP)Dick Stockton of Garden City, L.I.; F. D. Robbins of Salt Lake City and Paul Gerken of East Norwalk, Conn., are the only holdover members on the, 1970 Junior Davis Cup squad named today by the United States Lawn Tennis Associa tion.

title: Culebra and Goliath
description: Can anyone really believe that the only suitable target area in the entire Atlantic Ocean for testing new generation of guided missiles and glide bombs is a 7,000acre island off Puerto Rico which 726 Ameri can citizens call home? So says the United States Navy, which already owns a third of the island Culebra and now intends to lease and eventually buy another third.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Silvester Wins 4th in Row In Discus Throw in Sweden
description: VAESTERVIK, Sweden, July 9 (AP)Jay Silvester, the Ameri can who holds the world rec ord for the discus throw, beat Ricky Bruch of Sweden tonight for the fourth successive time in international track and field meets in this Scandinavian na tion.

title: Frank Smathers Sr. Dead; Father of Former Senator
description: MIAMI, July 9 (AP)Frank Smothers Sr., father of former Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat. of Florida. died yes terday at the Miami Heart In stitute. He was 88 years old.

title: 65Foot Sculpture Rises in Central Park
description: A bright red 65foot sculp ture called Endless Column, the tallest ever placed out doors in the city, was lifted into the air by an outsize crane and set in place in Central Park yesterday after noon.

title: Widgeon Named Winner Of Yacht Race to Tahiti
description: LOS ANGELES, July 9 (AP)  Widgeon, the 54foot sloop owned and sailed by G. Norman Bacon of Santa Barbara, Calif., was officially designated yes terday as the winner of the Los AngelestoTahiti yacht race.

title: Miss Martha G. Sanson Affianced
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., July 9 Miss Martha Gale Sanson, whose grandfather, the late Benjamin P. DeWitt, was president of the Lawyers Club of New York, plans to be married here Aug. 22 to Alan Lynn Antik of Atlanta, where he is account execu tive with the Marschalk Com pany. advertising agency.

title: Head of C.A.B. Hopeful on Airline Woes
description: The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, Secor D. Browne, says he thinks the na tion's major scheduled airlines are safe for at least a year from cash shortages that could produce an airline crisis simi lar to the Penn Central railroad difficulties.

title: High School Code
description: The Board of Education's policy statement on the rights and responsibilities of high school students is a much needed, if incomplete, effort to clarify issues that have been neglected for too long here and in school systems throughout the nation..

title: HURLER ALSO GETS HIS FIRST HOMER
description: Torn Seaver pitched a three hitter and even hit a home run last night as the New York Mets won their seventh straight game by defeating the Montreal Ex pos, 71.

title: Heir to the Throne Marries in Brunei
description: BRUNEI TOWN, Brunei, July 8 (UPI)  Prince Mo hamed Bolkiah, 21 years old, the heir apparent to the throne of this British protectorate on Borneo, married today in a festive ceremony.

title: Joblessness of Men in City's Poverty Areas Is Triple National Rate
description: Men in their prime employ ment years who live in one of the city's four major poverty areas are three times as likely to be unemployed as men in the same age bracket elsewhere in the nation, according to a survey released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: 150 Youths Rampage Near City Hall
description: A band of youths scuffled with the police, mauled passers by and shouted obscenities in City Hall Park yesterday. Two boys were arrested.

title: U.S. WAR DEATHS Al 3YEAR LOW
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9The United States Command reported today that 61 Ameri cans were killed in action in the Indochina war last week, the lowest toll in more than three and a half years.

title: Block of Northwest Stock Is 2d Largest Ever on Big Board
description: The secondlargest block of stock ever traded on the New York Stock Exchange changed hands yesterday when a whop ping 1.02 millionshare trade of Northwest Airlines, Inc. crossed the tape at 14, down .

title: Family of 3 and a Fireman Die in Jersey Blaze
description: UNION CITY, N. J., July 9A family of three and a fire man died here early this morn ing in a blaze that destroyed a fourstory apartment house at Kennedy Boulevard and 41st Street, near the North Bergen police headquarters across the town line.

title: Black to Oppose Humphrey
description: ST. PAUL, July 9 (AP)Earl D. Craig, Jr. a black instruc tor at the University of Minne sota and an outspoken critic of the Vietnam war, filed yes terday to oppose former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey for the United States Senate nomination.

title: BOARD APPROVES CAPITAL BUDGET
description: In 57 seconds, the Board of Estimate yesterday gave Mayor Lindsay permission to spend the entire capital budget of $1.32billion for the current fis cal year.

title: With Spinach Pie, Poetry Is Offered
description: A selective list of restau rants in New York and vicin ity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost.

title: Reds'
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9  The World Youth Assembly is meeting here, but some of its participants do not appear to be very youthful. Nor are they exactily amateurs in the business of internaional co ferences.

title: AGREEMENT NEARS ON IMPORT QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee neared agreement today on a contro versial bill that would impose quotas on imports of shoes and noncotton textiles.

title: Bridge: Doubler Learns How to Beat Contract, But Hours Too Late
description: In many ways duplicate play for match points is more exciting than rubber bridge. The tournament player knows that he must sometimes crawl out on a tempting limb, seeking a juicy score that may become a zero if he crashes.

title: Theaters Get Dr. King Film; Here July 29
description: King: A Filmed Record From Montgomery to Memphis, the threehour doc umentary about the civil rights work of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., which had a oneday benefit showing on March 24 in 300 cities throughout the coun try, will be released for thea trical engagements in the fall. It has been booked for its initial run at the. Astor Theater, Broadway on 45th Street, to open July 29.

title: SOYBEANS PLUNGE ON PROFIT TAKING
description: Soybean and grain futures again opened higher on the Chicago Board of Trade yester day but profit taking sent prices tumbling. Soybeans closed sharply lower while the grains were off slightly from the previous session.

title: CENSUS WORKERS TALLY COMPLAINTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The Census Bureau counts the population once every 10 years and then prepares itself for angry shrieks. It is hearing them now.

title: MENNE'S 66 LEADS MILWAUKEE OPEN
description: MILWAUKEE, July 9 (AP)Bob Menne turned in a six underpar 66 today and took the firstround lead in the $110,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament.

title: Stunt Man Dies in Plunge
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July (UPI)A Honolulu stunt man, who told a photographer he was sure he could jump safely from the Golden Gate Bridge, plunged 240 feet to his death yesterday in San Francisco Bay. He was Ronald Miller, 27 years old.

title: U.S. AID IS SOUGHT FOR ASBURY PARK
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 9  Gov. William T. Cahill an nounced today that he would ask President Nixon to declare this seaside resort a major dis aster area.

title: Bill Restoring Pueblo Land Is Stalled by Foes in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The bill to restore to the Taos Pueblo Indians of New Mexico their small, sacred Blue Lake and all its 48,000acre watershed ran into strong opposition today from Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, and other members of the Senate Interior Sub committee on Indian Affairs.

title: Agency Seal Joins CleanAir Fight
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)  The Small Business Administration apparently can recognize a trend when it sees one. It has published in the Federal Register the following notice:

title: Hawaii Paper Settles
description: HILO, Hawaii, July 10 (UPI) Tentative agreement has been reached on new contracts for three newspaper unions at the Hawaii TribuneHerald. The agreements were with the Hawaii Newspaper Guild, the International Typographical Union and the Hawaii Pressmen's Union. Details of the contracts were not disclosed.

title: Cardinal Alfrink Sees the Pope In Dispute on Priestly Celibacy
description: ROME, July 10Pope Paul VI received the Roman Catholic Primate of the Netherlands, Bernard Cardinal Alfrink, in private audience today amid unconfirmed reports that the Vatican might make minor concession on issues involving priestly celibacy.

title: Ruth McKinney Engaged to Wed
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 10Mr. and Mrs. George W. McKinney Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Ann McKinney, to Ens. Ronald W. Gerbe, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Gerbe Jr. of North Merrick, L.I.

title: Firestone Is Accused by F.T.C. Of Tire Advertising Deception
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission accused the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today of making deceptive statements on the safety and wear of its tires and of falsely advertising price savings that did not exist.

title: Israel Reports Jets Downed 3 MIG21 s In Dogfight at Suez
description: JERUSALEM, July 10  A military spokesman announced today that Israeli planes shot down three Egyptian MIG21's this morning in a brief but intense dogfight over the Suez Canal.

title: Roundup: Pirates Stop Gibson, Cut Lead
description: The last time Al Oliver saw Bob Gibson, the St. Louis pitcher was struggling to regain the brilliance that had brought him four 20victory seasons in the previous five.

title: ExColombian Official Abducted by Guerrillas
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 10 (AP)A former Foreign Minister uf Colombia, Fernando Londoo y Londoo, was kidnapped by Castroite guerrillas yesterday.

title: HERMAN R. KOSLOFF
description: Herman R. Kosloff, an artist and sculptor, died at Albany Veterans Administration Hospital Wednesday after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 320 East 53d Street.

title: Distant Quakes From ATests Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Government scientists say that they can find no valid evidence that nuclear explosions trigger distant earthquakes, despite the contention of other scientists that they may do so.

title: SONGMY FIGURE BIDS U.S. JUDGE BAR TRIAL
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 10 (UPI) S. Sgt. David Mitchell of the Army filed suit today in Federal Court to block the Army from trying him on 31 counts of assault to commit murder in connection with the alleged Songmy massacre and to have charges against him transferred to a civilian court.

title: 2 Smith Students Convicted
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 10 (AP)Two Smith College women were convicted yesterday in Northampton District Court on charges of growing marijuana in their dormitory room. Carol Cohen, 22 years old, of New Haven, Conn., received a suspended sentence, and Linda Hobbet, 21, of Durham, N. C., was placed on probation.

title: TRUCKERS DISPUTE ROAD CRACK CAUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) The trucking industry denied today that heavy truck traffic was responsible for the cracking of interstate highways and said that a Government investigator's charges just won't hold water.

title: Dayan Is 85 Favorite Tonight In $60,000 Trot at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 10 A sound horseplayer never forgets. Therefore, those who sent $84,330 down the drain when they backed Dayan in his last outing at Roosevelt Raceway may use less money and more caution while gambling on the outcome of tomorrow night's $50,000 American Trotting Championship at the Nassau County oval.

title: City and State Vie For $500,000 Paid In Fines for Strikes
description: The city and the state are in a dispute over which will get the more than $500,000 in fines collected from public employe unions for illegal strikes here in the last three years.

title: Pupils Bring Harlem To Youths at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 10  Fiftytwo Harlem school children  disturbed at the possibility that delegates to the World Youth Assembly might have no opportunity to visit their community  came here today to bring a little Harlem to them, as one child put it.

title: DEMPSEYTEGELER RETRENCHES AGAIN
description: Mitchum, Jones & Templeton, a major regional brokerage house based in Los Angeles, will acquire nine West Coast branches of DempseyTegeler & Co. under an agreement announced yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: JUNKETS DECLINE TO 6YEAR LOW
description: WASHINGTON. July 10 Congressional trips abroad known as junkets to many American taxpayers  cost more than $500,000 in 1969.

title: Mobil to Close a Refinery
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., July 10 (AP)The Mobil Oil Corporation said today it would shut down its refinery here Oct. 1. About 350 employes will be affected.

title: German Reserves Grow
description: FRANKFURT, July 10 (Reuters)West Germany's monetary reserves rose by 1.72million marks to 35,545,000,000 marks in the week ended July 7, the central bank said today.

title: Vienna Arms Talks Continue
description: VIENNA. July 10 (Reuters)Talks between the United State and the Soviet Union on limiting strategic arms continued here today, and conference sources warned against the optimism of some recent press reports suggesting an early preliminary agreement. The negotiators met today for 75 minutes and are to meet again next Friday.

title: Ulster Leader Calls For Restraint by All In Orange Parades
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 10  Maj. James ChichesterClark, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, tonight appealed for restraint during Monday's parades of the Protestant Orange Order in 18 towns throughout the province.

title: NIXON SEEKS LIMIT ON TRADE QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10President Nixon has intervened at a crucial stage of consideration by the House Ways and Means Committee of trade legislation in an effort to limit any mandatory import quotas to textiles.

title: Senate Backs Park Fund
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) The Senate passed today a bill to increase by $20million an authorization for buying and for Everglades National Park in Florida.

title: Unruly Hearing Precedes Signing of New Rent Law
description: Mayor Lindsay signed into law a major revision of the city's 27yearold rent control law yesterday after a raucous fourandahalfhour public hearing.

title: Holiday on Ice Will Buy The Vienna Eis Revue
description: Morris Chalfen, president of Holiday on Ice, has reached an agreement in principle to buy the Vienna Eis Revue for an undisclosed amount.

title: Executive Changes
description: J. Lloyd Langdon has been appointed president of Pet Incorporated's dairy division, succeeding Thomas K. Rappel, who died on June 16. Mr. Langdon formerly was executive vice president and general manager of the division.

title: lavits Is Opposed to Nixon Slate For ForeignInvestment Agency
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Senator Jacob K. Javits has told colleagues on the Foreign Relations Committee that he is prepared to hold up indefinitely the creation of the multibilliondollar Overseas Private Investment Corporation if President Nixon insists on his slate of officers for the new agency.

title: MURDER DEFENDANT ADMITS HE KILLED 7
description: CAMDEN, N. J., July 10  A former junkyard worker confessed yesterday that he murdered six women and a man during an eightmonth period last year.

title: Judith Bob Fiancee Of R. M. Bronstein
description: Miss Judith Elen Bob and Robert Marc Bronstein plan to marry on Sept. 12 in Lebanon, Conn. The announcement of their engagement has been made known by the parents of the prospective bride, Dr. and Mrs. Murray Bob of St. Albans, Queens.

title: HAROLD B. ALLEN, AIDED. MACEDONIA
description: RED BANK, N. J., July 10Dr. Harold B. Allen, former edu cational director of the Near East Foundation, died today after being struck by a car yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: Japan Ranks Second In Use of Computers
description: TOKYO, July 10 (AP)Japan, after the United States, is the second largest user of electronic computers in the world, the Japan Electronic Computer Company said today.

title: Wolfson to Testify on Prison
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) Louis E. Wolfson, the financier who served nine months in prison for illegal stock dealings, has agreed to testify on prison conditions before Senator Thomas J. Dodd's Juvenile Delinquency subcommittee. A subcommittee spokesman said today that Wolfson would testify on conditions at the Federal prison camp at Eglin Air Force Race. in Florida.

title: Edgar Beats Spitz Over 100 Meters In Coast Swimming
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., July 10 (UPI)Dave Edgar turned loose a powerful kick down the stretch today to upset. Mark Spitz, Olympian and Indiana University star, in the 100meter freestyle at the Santa Clara international swim carnival.

title: Samuel Ketive, Randy Kalikow Planning Bridal
description: Miss Randy Lyn Kalikow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Kalikow of New York and Atlantic Beach, L. I., will be married here in September to Samuel G. Ketive. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Ketive of New York and Fort Lauderdale. Fla.

title: HOWARD DRIVES IN 2 RUNS ON HOMER
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Steve Kline, a 22yearold rookie righthander, made his major league pitching debut for the New York Yankees tonight, displaying natural talent and surprising poise.

title: TRIUMPH IS FIRST OF YEAR FOR FILLY
DURRENMATT SUED FOR LIBEL BY HABE
description: GENEVA, July 8Hans Habe, the Hungarianborn novelist, has filed suit for libel against Friedrich Diirrenmatt, the Swiss playwright. The story of the suit has its genesis in Mr. Habe's attack on Harry Buckwitz, the new director of the Schauspielhaus, the Zurich municipal theater.

title: Books of The Times
description: History, or at least the reading of history, can be a consolation. Jon Kimche's review of events in the Middle East from the end of World War I to the present puts the daily reports of bloodletting in that area into perspective. It puts a distance between these daily accounts and the reader. The intensity is lessened. The story on the front page that sounds so full of disaster (and may well be) is scaled down and takes its place in the unhappy history of that region. Eis book makes for grim reading. Yet because the book increases our understanding, its effect is buoyant as if understanding sets the spirit free. It is not another history of the ArabIsraeli conflict, though that contention figures, as it must, in the latter flair or me book. A British journalist and editor of the magazine The New Middle East, he deals rather with the major Arab countries and the European powers with which they were and areenmeshed. The current troubles, he says, can be traced back directly to the political arrangements worked out for the Middle East after World War With the breakup of the Ottoman Empire, Britain especially saw herself as taking over the places where the Turk had once been. Britain argued that not only was her security involved, but that these lands also needed masters and that she was naturally endowed to take on such a role.

title: Coatta to Mankato State
description: MANKATO, Minn., July 10 (UPI)John Coatta, 39 years old, recently released as head football coach at the University of Wisconsin, was named head coach at Mankato State College today.

title: Pollution Foes Stepping Up Attacks on Auto Engine
description: DETROIT, July 10  The engine that has powered American cars for more than half a century is coming under increasingly harsh attack as a dangerous anachronism that will have to be scrapped before the nation can clean up its air.

title: Ann Mottu Betrothed To Jeffrey H. Dobken
description: Mr. and Mrs. Phillippe Mottu of Pully, Switzerland, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Marie Mottu, to Jeffrey Hall Dobken. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Dobken of Ridgefield Park, N.J.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: 8 U.S. WRESTLERS SCORE IN CANADA
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, July 10 (AP)  Fred Fozzard of Stillwater, Okla., stayed in the running today for a second straight championship in the 180pound class at the world amateur freestyle wrestling championships. Seven other Americans also advanced.

title: WILLIAM B. EMERSON
description: William B. Emerson, a retired New York City real estate salesman, died of a heart attack yesterday in East Hampton, L. I. He was 69 years old and lived at Tervell Lane, East Hampton.

title: MISTRIAL ORDERED IN PANTHER CASE
description: JERSEY CITY, July 10The sudden illness of a juror tonight resulted in a mistrial for three Black Panther members being (tried on charges of machinegunning a Jersey City police! station in November. 1968.

title: ROCHESTER MERGER OF BANKS REJECTED
description: William T. Dentzer Jr., New York State Superintendent of Banks, has disapproved a proposed merger of the Dime Banking and Loan Association, Rochester, into the Community Savings Bank of Rochester.

title: THE P.B.A. ENDORSES BUCKLEY FOR SENATE
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yesterday that it was endorsing Conservative, James L. Buckley. for United States Senator.

title: McLaren Sees Loopholes In OneBank Holding Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) A top Justice Department official said today that a onebank holding company bill now before the Senate contained substantial loopholes for conglomerates.

title: French Sailors Chafe Over Slow Boat to Newport
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 10Fog continued to frustrate the America's Cup fleet today, and this time it was cciining from the Pacific as well as the Atlantic.

title: Record 20,982 at Garden See Sammartino Pin Verdu
description: Bruno Sammartino pinned Crusher Verdu of Spain last night in a return exhibition at Madison Square Garden before 20,982 fans, a record for wrestline at the Garden.

title: All the Perfumes of Scotland...
description: LONDON, July 10Ian Grimble, a Scottish historian, has made a marvelously reassuring discovery: Macbeth was innocent. Even better, so was Lady Macbeth.

title: $200Million U.S Orders Go to Lockheed and Units
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and its subsidiaries were awarded about $200million in Defense Department contracts, it was announced yesterday.

title: Owners and Tenants'
Article 1  No Title
Pope to Go on Vacation
description: ROME, July 10 (UPI)The Vatican announced today that Pope Paul VI would leave for his summer residence at nearby Castel Gandolfo after next Thursday but before July 22.

title: Isle of Jersey Strike Brings Declaration of Emergency
description: ST. HELIER, Jersey, July 10 (UPI)The Government of this Channel Island off France declared a state of emergency today as 1,000 Government workers went on strike for a wane increase.

title: Secretary Rogers'
description: Any hope the Administration may have entertained for pursuing a strong proxy fight against the Communists in Cambodia must have been dashed by the responses Secretary of State Rogers has met during his extended Asian tour.

title: CURFEW IS ENDED FOR ASBURY PARK
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 10 Mayor Joseph F. Mattice announced an end today to the 11 P.M. curfew in this riotdamaged city, but some black leaders immediately protested, saying they favored a 6 P.M. curfew.

title: Smuin Gartenfest Retains Its Charm For Ballet Theater
description: Nearly two years ago, Michael Smuin choreographed a charming, wellconstrUcted, plotless ballet to Mozart's Cessation No. 1 in G for American Ballet Theater. Last night at the State Theater, in the first of its two performances this season, that ballet, Gartenfest, proved as charming, wellconstructed and plotless as ever.

title: U.S. Begins New PriceFixing Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 The Justice Department has opened a new study aimed at uncovering evidence of pricefixing on products that are usually handled by local processors and distributors, such as bread. beer and fuel oil.

title: 2 Negro Marines Win Appeals Of Convictions for Disloyalty
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The Court of Military Appeals reversed today the convictions of two Negro members of the Marine Corps accused of disloyalty.

title: Jury in Sharon Tate Case Reported to Be Accepted
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 (Reuters)The prosecution, in a bid to cut short the drawnout jury selection in the Sharon Tate murder trial, told Judge Charles Older today that it would probably accept the jury as presently constituted, according to defense sources.

title: THIEU URGES A HALT TO VETERANS'
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 (Reuters)  After an extraordinary conference of South Vietnam's top military and political leaders, President Nguyen Van Thieu called on dissident war veterans today to halt their protests and give the Government time to solve their problems.

title: Profit Is Off 1.5% At Marine Midland
DR. JACOB HALPERN, AN ENDOCRINOLOGIST
description: Dr. Jacob Halpern, attending physician in internal medicine and head of the endocrine clinic at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn died at the hospital Thursday after a brief illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 403 East 19th Street, Brooklyn, where he also maintained a private practice.

title: Rigo's Partner Testifies for Addonizio
description: TRENTON, July 10The partner of the procecution's key witness testified for the defense today that he was unaware of kickbacks allegedly paid by his companies to Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other defendants on trial here for extortion and conspiracy.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION DECLINES IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, July 10 (AP)United States car production faltered this week because of plantchangeover activities but still managed to maintain a lead over the comparable 1969 figures.

title: A NEWISSUE RISE IS FIRST IN. WEEKS
description: The Environmental Pollution Research Corporation made the first highly successful initial public stock offering in several weeks Thursday, but the newissue market as a whole continued in its longdepressed state this week.

title: Lords Set Hogweed Debate
description: LONDON, July 10 (UPI)The House of Lords today set debate for Tuesday on a giant weed that has escaped from botanical garden and now is described by doctors as a public health hazard. The debate was requested by Lord Vivian, a Conservative party member, to find out what the Government was doing to control and eradicate the plant, known as hogweed.

title: The Songs of John Lee Hooker Charm Fans in Museum Garden
description: John Lee Hooker has, an easygoing, casual attitude as he sits down to murmur his blues and stroke out a guitar accompaniment. But his seeming casualness masks a highly alert and disciplined performer.

title: RISE IS FORECAST IN 1970 CORN CROP
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  The Agriculture Department estimated today that the 1970 corn crop would amount to 4,819,999,000 bushels, 5 per cent more than last year's output of 4,577,864 bushels.

title: Dover Switches Car Races
description: DOVER, Del., July 10 (UPI)The United States Auto Club has canceled its 200mile race for Indianapolis cars at Dover Downs International Speedway on July 19 because the newly laid asphalt has not had sufficient time to cure. A 200mile U.S.A.C. late model stock car race has been substituted on the same date.

title: Gentile and Costello Total 135 To Win Medal in Anderson Golf
East Germans Release Americans Seized at Line
description: BONN, July 10East German authorities tonight released three American tourists who were seized after they accidentally crossed the border. at Schlutup yesterday, the United States Embassy in Bonn reported.

title: Rites Held for Mrs. Simon, Psychiatric Social Worker
description: A funeral service was held yesterday at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, for Mrs. Melly Loeb Simon, a psychiatric social worker who was head of the PayneWhitney Psychiatric Clinic for 18 years.,

title: Morel of Saints Retires
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 10 (UPI)Tommy Morel, former wide receiver at Louisana State who spent last season on the Saints taxi squad, retired today from pro football after only one year. Morel will attend law school at Loyola University and may have an opportunity to become the school's head football coach.

title: MORTON ACHIEVES HIS 10TH VICTORY
description: The New York Mets came to the end of their sevengame winning streak last night when they were defeated, 97, by the Montreal Expos and a rookie pitcher from Kansas who reads books like The Art of Thinking Big.

title: L.I. Youth Kills Himself After Knifing 2 in Family
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., July 10An 18yearold scholarship winner apparently went berserk in his home here today and committee suicide by inhaling ether after allegedly stabbing his mother and brother, the police said.

title: PRICES EDGE DOWN ON LONDON BOARD
MANSFIELD SEES A 2D NIXON TERM
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 Senator Mike Mansfield, the Democratic leader of the Senate, predicted today that President Nixon would win reelection in 1972, as things now appear, despite foreign and domestic problems.

title: China's Jails Still Hold 4 Americans
description: When the Most Rev. James Edward Walsh, unshaven and dressed in faded khaki trousers and an old checked shirt, crossed into Hong Kong yesterday, he left behind four Americans still detained in Communist China's prisons.

title: Ansonia Tenants Fight Crime in Hotel
description: Selfstyled vigilantes now patrol the broad, highceilinged corridors of the Ansonia Hotel, where in better days elegantly gowned ladies and formally attired gentlemen thronged on their way to postopera parties in the suites of Enrico Caruso, Geraldine Farrar and Feodor Chaliapin.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
AMERICAN IN HANOI SAYS HE'S DESERTER
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 10 (Agence FrancePresse)  A young man introduced as United States marine said at news conference here today that he had left his unit in South Vietnam in February, 1969, and had been with the Vietcong until this month.

title: JAZZ PREVAILING AT NEWPORT FETE
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 10Jazz is once again the focal point of the Newport Jazz Festival. Last year, George Wein, producer of the festival, put together a mixture of jazz and rock, which brought criticism from jazz purists and from Newport city officials who were alarmed by the efforts of rock fans to break into Festival Field, where the concerts are held.

title: Article 2  No Title
EUGENE W. CARNEY
description: EDISON, N. J., July 10 Eugene W. Carney, vice president of the DuBois Chemical Division of the W. R. Grace Company, East Rutherford, died yesterday at his home. He was 59 years old and lived at 6 Parkerson Road here.

title: MORE VIOLENCE HITS NEW BEDFORD, MASS.
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 10 (AP)  Sporadic violence broke out again tonight in two black sections of New Bedford, with scattered reports of window smashing and looting of small stores.

title: Jordanians Report Israelis Deported 8 Into the Desert
description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 10 (Reuters)Jordan said today that eight Arabs, all expelled by Israel, had been found in poor condition in the southern desert and had been brought to Amman for medical treatment.

title: Article 4  No Title
Bridge:
description: An obscure area of the game that gets no attention at all in textbooks concerns how best to take advantage of a penalty situation.

title: TREASURY TO SELL TAXPAYING BILLS
description: The Treasury announced yesterday plans to sell $2.25billion of taxanticipation bills next Thursday.The bills, which will be dated July 23, will mature April 22, 1971, but they may be utilized to pay Federal income taxes due April 15, the Treasury said.

title: French Business and Labor Set Fund to Upgrade Worker Skills
description: PARIS, July 10The French Employers Association and four unions have signed a nationwide agreement to set up jobtraining fund under which wage earners could improve their skills or learn new ones.

title: Wright Resigns as Coach
description: MEMPHIS, July 10 (UPI)Jamds Earl Wright resigned today as coach of quarterbacks and receivers at Memphis State University to join a Memphis busitiets firm.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Bond Stores Elects
description: The election of Arthur E. Lasker as a vice president was announced yesterday by Bond Stores, Inc., the apparel chain. Mr. Lasker also has been appointed general counsel and secretary of Bond Industries, Inc., of which Bond Stores is a wholly owned subsidiary. He continues as general counsel, director of real estate and corporate secretary of Bond Stores.

title: U.M.W. Is Ordered to Open Books to U.S. Investigators
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) A Federal judge ordered the United Mine Workers of America today to produce records and documents for inspection and copying by the Departments of Justice and Labor.

title: 2 Arizona Youths Held in Slayings Of 2 New Yorkers
description: TUCSON, Ariz., July 10Two Phoenix youths were arraigned yesterday in Tucson on two counts of murder and one count of attempted murder following the gunshot slayings on Wednesday of two New York men and the wounding of third.

title: Broome of Britain Captures World Horse Jumping Title
description: LA BAULE, France, July 10 (AP)David Broome of Britain won the world horse jumping championship today, riding his horse, Beethoven, and then those of his three opponents.

title: Prof. Erwin H. A mick, 59, Dies; Taught Chemical Engineering
description: Erwin H. Amick, chairman of the Department of Chemical Engineering at Columbia University, died of a heart attack Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 59 years old.

title: Market Place:
description: Does the stock market measure intrinsic value? It certainly does not, as many people who had forgotten have again begun to realize.

title: In Amazonia, The Army Are the Good Guys
description: PORTO VELHO, BrazilAs Brazilians intensify their colonization of the Amazon Basin, the army is the cutting edge of the advance.

title: Senate Votes Again for Tonkin Repeal
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The Senate placed on record today, for the second time in less than a month, its wish to repeal the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, which was cited by President Lyndon B. Johnson as Congressional authorization for the war in Vietnam.

title: 87 Senators Score P.O.W. Treatment In Letter to Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) Eightyseven Senators put aside differences on the Indochina war today to demand that Hanoi end inhumane treatment of American war prisoners.

title: L&M. Closing a Plant
description: Liggett & Myers, Inc., said yesterday it was shutting down its cigarette plant in Richmond, Va., as part of a plan to consolidate operations in Durham, N. C. No timetable was announced.

title: SIFFERTREDMAN PACE QUALIFIERS
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 10Four Porsches and two Ferraris qualified this afternoon for this first six positions in tomorrow's running of the Watkins Glen Six Hours of Endurance, part of the world manufacturers championship.

title: Drumming Up PartTime Jobs for Housewives
description: The chorus of anguish grows louder every year but seldom is heard an encouraging word. I want to work, but parttime, cry the housewives of city and suburb.

title: Suits Filed in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 10  A conservation group initiated legal action in three Federal courts today against 214 Alabama manufacturers, businesses and municipalities, charging them with pollution of streams in violation of the Refuse Act of 1899.

title: KIDNAPPED GIRL, 16, HUNTED IN LANSING
description: LANSING, Mich., July 10 (UPI)The police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation searched today for the 16yearold blonde daughter of a former Mayor and the man who kidnappde her yesterday during a robbery.

title: Motorists'
description: HERSHEY, Pa., July 10The diversion of motorist toll revenues to the New York City Transit Authority was criticized today by a spokesman for motorists.

title: JERSEY COURT LETS INJURED KIN SUE
description: TRENTON, July 10  In two 4to3 decisions, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled to day that members of families may sue one another in automobile accident cases.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS HOLD TALK LINKED TO MIDEAST ISSUE
description: MOSCOW, July 10  The United States Ambassador, Jacob D. Beam, met with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko here today as Moscow published a cautious first evaluation of American peace proposals for the Middle East.

title: Camilla Miner Is Bride Of George D. Smith Jr.
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 10 Miss Camilla Virginia Miner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glen B. Miner, was married this morning to George Dempster Smith, Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Sports of The Times
description: With its new stadiums, baseball presumably is progressing. In a few years, all the major league parks will be virtually identical in shape. But their architecture resembles a giant aspirin tablet, at least to pitchers whose nerves will he jangling after watching doubleplay grounders hop hurriedly through synthetic grass for hits. One of the newest edifices, Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati, will be the cite of the AllStar Game on Tuesday night. you don't see any infield dirt on your TV screen, don't think you've tuned in a billiards match.

title: SOYBEANS LOWER; GRAINS IRREGULAR
description: A waitandsee attitude dominated the trading in soybean futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as a Department of Agriculture crop report due after the close was awaited. It forecast a 5 per cent rise in the 1970 corn crop and a dip for wheat.

title: Is the House a Rubber Stamp?
description: Efforts to reassert the authority of Congress in vital decisions concerning war and peace have in the last few days received a double blow in the House of Representatives.

title: MASSENGALE'S 137 LEADS BY STROKE
description: MILWAUKEE, July 10 (AP)Don Massengale, a nonwinner since 1966, shot this way out of the pack with a fourunderpar 68 today and moved into the lead after the second round of the $110,000 Milwaukee open eolf tournament

title: Rogers in Britain for Talks On Mideast, Asia and NATO
description: LONDON, July 10 (Reuters) Secretary of State William P. Rogers arrived here tonight for a twoday official visit and said his talks with Britain's new Conservative, leaders would center on the Middle East, Indochina and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: New Books
description: Early American Silver, by Martha Gandy Fales (Funk & Wagnalls, $12.50). Historical survey with 250 illustrations.

title: Roche Beats Riessen in Irish Tennis
description: DUBLIN, July 10 (Reuters)Tony Roche beat Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., today and set up an allAustralian men's singles final in the Irish open tennis championships. He will meet Rod Laver tomorrow.

title: MRS. GIRSDANSKY
description: Mrs. Anne M. Girsdansky, widow of Dr. Joseph Girsdansky, a New York surgeon, died here Tuesday at the age of 72. She was formely married to E. E. Cummings, the poet, and Ralph Barton, a founder of The New Yorker magazine.

title: Stock Exchanges Install Computers in Montreal
description: MONTREAL, July 10 (AP)The Montreal Stock Exchange and Canadian Stock Exchange are installing an additional $3million worth of computing systems to triple their capabilities to handle mounting workloads.

title: Two Women Invent Heated Coat
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Two women have received the patent rights to an electrically heated garment that they call the Hotcoat. Having worn models of the coat with comfort, they plan to manufacture it themselves or license a raincoat maker. Patent 3,519,791 was granted this week to Mark T. Basseches and Ely S. Margolis, the golis, who assigned it to Mrs. Marjorie Margolis of New Rochelle and Mrs. Lorraine Shachnow of New York, an advertising writer for Benton & Bowles. Mrs. Margolis and Mrs. Shachnow, old friends whose children have played together, foresaw the need for such apparel. They examined other heated clothing, including vests and socks, but were not much impressed. The patent application was filed by Mr. Margolis, a plastics manufacturer, and Mr. Basseches, a New York patent lawyer.

title: Article 3  No Title
PRESIDENT TO MEET WITH 13 GOVERNORS
U.S. AIDE EXPLAINS NEW DRAFT RULES
description: The associate general counsel of the Selective Service System explained yesterday to nearly 200 lawyers active in defending draft registrants the new rules defining those entitied to the status of conscientious objector.

title: Antiques: Exotic Cottons
description: Indian chintz, the fabric whose popularity almost caused a recession In Western Europe in the 1680's, is the subject of an attractive exhibition at the CooperHewitt Museum.

title: Bills Get Bears'
description: CHICAGO, July 10 (UPI)The Chicago Bears announced today that Virgil Carter, a quarterback, has been waivered to the Buffalo Bills of the American Football Conference. Carter, who has been in the Bears bad graces after a dressingroom tirade against Coach Jim Dooley last year, was passed up by Miami, Pittsburgh and Boston.

title: Train Kills 3 in Maine
description: SMYRNA MILLS, Me., July 10 (AP)A Bangor and Aroostook Railroad freight train crushed to death three persons in sleeping bags on the tracks near this northern Maine community early today. The victims were not immedately identified.

title: ALLSTAR SQUAD NAMES RESERVES
description: BOSTON, July 10 (AP) Brooks Robinson, third baseman of the Baltimore Orioles, and Tony Oliva, outfielder of the Minnesota Twins, were added to the Ameritan League. AllStar squad today as the 28player roster was filled for the annual midseason game with the National League next Tuesday.

title: Lombardi Feeling Fine As He Leaves Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)Vince Lombardi, head coach of the Washington Redskins, left Georgetown University Hospital today and went to his Potomac, Md., home to rest.

title: Music: Visit by Britons
description: One of the finest concerts given in New York this year took place not in any of the concert halls but in St. Thomas Episcopal Church on Thursday night. The performing ensemble was the choir of St. John's College, Cambridge, England, which was making its first visit to this country to appear in churches and festivals in the Northeast. Its high quality was known here, however, through the many recordings it has made for the Argo label.

title: Thais Said to Vow War Aid To Cambodians if Needed
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 10United States sources said today that Thailand had assured the Cambodians of her willingness to come to their defense if necessary.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS THAT BAR BLACKS TO LOSE TAX AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The taxexempt status of private schools that continue to practice racial discrimination in admissions will be revoked under a new policy announced today by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: FrenchTowns Sue Over Airport Noise
description: PARIS, July 10The airport was there first; the builders followed. Are the airlines, then, responsible for the noise that plagues their new neighbors?

title: Saigon Is Investigating Tiger Cage Cells at a Prison
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 (Reuters)  The South Vietnamese Government promised today to abolish the 'tiger cage punishment cells in Con Son Prison if an investigation confirmed the criticism of two United States Representatives and press reports of the mistreatment of prisoners.

title: The Versatility Is Designed In
description: Not everyone knows how to paint their own supergraphics on walls, nor do they necessarily want to keep the same design on view all the time Or so Joe Grimaldi. an artist, believes. Mr. Grimaldi decided, therefore, to devise limited editions of two supergraphics patterns, each of which comes in two basic color combinations on two or six panels so that the parts can be rearranged at will to create a new decorative effect. The pattern, called Action 2 (shown here), comes painted on two 4by6foot panels, in red, blue or purple zigzag stripes on a yelloworange ground; or brown, bone and silver on white ground ($600 the pair). The second arrowlike pattern, called Direction, comes in six 3footsquare panels ($500 the set). It's available in red, blue and purple or yellow, putty and white.

title: South African Asks Change In Naval Pact With Britain
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Atrica, July 10 (Reuters)Defense Minister Pieter Willem Botha called today for revision of South Africa's Simonstown defense agreement with Britain.

title: HONOR AMERICA DAY COST NATION $68,770
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) The big proAmerica rally here July 4 cost taxpayers $68,710, about $14,000 less than November's antiwar demonstration, the National Park Service said today.

title: Columbia Defends A Campus Reactor As Not Dangerous
description: The chairman of Columbia University's nuclear engineering division yesterday unreservedly defended safety measures outlined by the university in its petition to operate a 250kilowatt nuclear reactor on its Morningside Heights campus.

title: WESTCHESTER HIT BY POWER FAILURE
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 10A power failure in west central Westchester County knocked out electrical service to 18,000 homes early this morning in White Plains, Elmsford, Ardsley, Dobbs Ferry, Hartsdale and Scarsdale.

title: Coast Industrialist Spent 1$1.9Million on Senate Race
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 10 (AP)  Norton Simon, the Los Angeles industrialist, reported today that he had spent nearly $2million. in his losing campaign for the Republican Senate nomination in California and that all but $100,000 of it had been is own.

title: 75% of Wilson Pharmaceutical Sold to American Canby L T V
description: The American Can Company has purchased from LingTemcoVought, Inc., its 75 per cent interest in the Wilson Pharmaceutical and Chemical Corporation, whose sales last year were $48million.

title: Fair Trial for Panthers?; Both Sides in Dispute Over Courts Cite Jury Selection in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN  Last April. Yale University's president, Kingman Brewster Jr., aroused the wrath of Vice President Agnew, numerous judges and not a few Yale alumni by saying he was skeptical of the ability of black revolutionaries to achieve a fair trial anywhere in the United States.
