description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) House Democrats contended today that they had achieved a productive legislative record in the 91st Congress despite delaying tactics and lack of full cooperation on the part of President Nixon.

title: Scribner, Vermont Official, to Head City Schools
description: Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the Vermont State Education Com missioner, was named yester day to the new post of Chan cellor of the city school sys tem.

title: 10 Nonsalary Days Off Slated by Control Data
description: Employes in the computer and business divisions of the Control Data Corporation will he required to take 10 days off without pay between Aug. 1 and Dec. 31, 1970, it was announced yesterday.

title: Charles and Anne Begin Informal Visit to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Prince Charles and Princess Anne began an informal but strenuous twoday visit here this afternoon with a redcar pet reception at the White House, a steak and beans sup per at Camp David and a quick tour of Washington's lighted monuments this evening.

title: Store Sales Crow
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The Commerce Department today estimated last week's depart ment store sales at $688mil lion, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $653million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,118,000,000, up 7 per cent from $6,630,000,000.

title: 72 Americans Killed in the War And 729 Wounded Last Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 (UPI)Seventytwo Ameri cans were killed in Indochina last week, raising United States battle deaths for 1970 beyond 3,000, the United States corn mand reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Benefits for Jobless

title: Moore Upsets Cox, 63, 75, In 2d Round of Swiss Tennis
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 16 (Reuters)Mark Cox of Britain, seeded No. 8 lost to Ray Moore of South Africa, 63, 75, today in the second round of the Swiss interna tional clay court tennis cham pionships. Moore was not seeded.

title: Sanok Cards 70 for 142 to Gain OneStroke Lead in Jersey Open
TRIBAL CHIEF HOME AFTER MANILA TRIAL
description: DATAL TUBAYONG, the Philiuuines, July 16Ma Falen, the Ubo chief who was absolved last Monday of murder and banditry charges after a hear ing by President Ferdinand E. Marcos, returned to his people this morning in this mountain top village in the southern island of Mindanao.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA AFrom Barnegat Light to Point Pleasant, N. J., bluefish catches have been particularly good. And the farther out you go, the big ger they get. said Carl Schauf at Barnegat. Trollers have been having much the better of it, bringing in batch es from 3 to 12 pounds. Tuna is also good 20 to 30 miles out, Schauf said. Fluke are being taken off the beaches, but the bay has been a poor spot, with high winds dirtying up the water.

title: L. ABBOTT POST JR.
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 16 L. Abbott Post Jr., vice presi dent in charge of Manufactur ers Hanover Trust's branch of fice at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, New York, died yester day at his home on Point Road, Wilson Point. He was 46 years old.

title: Genoa Beach So Dirty The City Can't Close It
description: ROME, July 16  A city magistrate closed the beaches around Genoa this morning because of pollution but he was overruled this afternoon. A higher official said the pol lution danger was so great that local authorities lacked jurisdiction.

title: Sherwood Forest Echoes Again With the Sounds of Medieval Jousting
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, July 16 (Reuters)  The clash of steel is ringing through Sherwood Forest as this medieval city stages Britain's first fullscale joust ing tournament in 400 years.

title: Soviet Making New Car
description: MOSCOW, July 16 (AP)The auto assembly lines at Gorky switched over today to produc tion of the new Volga passen ger car, the first major design change in 14 years.

title: 64, 63, 63 SCORE IS WORTH $35,000
description: Rod Laver, who says he plays better when I'm nerv ous, beat Ken Rosewall in straight sets last night and won $35,000, the biggest single prize in tennis, in 85 minutes.

title: Kadar's Lenient Brand of Communism Permits Hungarians to Poke Fun at the System
description: BUDAPEST, July 11  At 8:30 P.M. last Monday all over, downtown Budapest the sound, of laughter was competing with the clatter of the yellow streetcars and the rumble of the big, fume  trailing city buses.

title: DEMPSEY BARES LIQUIDATION STEP
description: DempseyTegeler & Co., until recently one of Wall Street's major brokerage houses, dis closed yesterday that it planned to suspend operations and reorganize, perhaps as a much smaller entity.

title: In Memoriam
description: GLEESONAlice Pearson. July 17, 1964. An niversary mass of requiem offered in Latin. NEWPORTVincent. Happy birthday sweet heart, I miss you so. LARUE.

title: STANLEY W. HESSE
description: Stanley W. Hesse, a general partner in H. Hentz & Co., and its floor partner on the New York Stock Exchange, died yes terday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 1085 Park Avenue. He was 59 years old.

title: BOGOTA IS GUARDING AGAINST NEW RIOTING
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 16 (Reuters)  The Government said today that it would declare a state of siege if there was any trouble during the opening of Congress on Monday or during the inauguration Aug. 7 of Presidentelect Misael Pastrana Borrero.

title: Westmoreland Visits Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan July 16 (Reuters)Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Army Chief of Staff, arrived today for a four day visit.

title: Earl Warren Is Writing a Book On Meaning of U.S. Citizenship
description: Former Chief Justice Earl Warren, who led the United States Supreme Court during 16 years of bold reforms, is completing a book on the mean ing and responsibilities of American citizenship.

title: SINGER IS VICTOR WITH A 6HITTER
description: LOS ANGELES, July 16The New York Mets rang up the cur tain on Act Two tonightthe second half of their title defense  and were immediately de feated by the Los Angeles Dodgers, 31.

title: JOHN W. EVANS
description: John W. Evans, who retired four years ago as head of sales service for FoxWells & Co., Inc., textiles, 58 West 40th Street, died Wednesday at the Hempstead (L. I.) Park Nursing Home. He was 83 years old and lived at 26 Haskel Lane, Stony Brook, L. I.

title: Volome Record Also Hit
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., in its first statement since its formation as a holding com pany for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and other diversified operations, report ed yesterday record sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

title: Grand Jury on Police Corruption Returns 2 Contempt Indictments
description: Two men, one with a crimi nal record dating back to the early nineteentwenties, have been indicted on charges of criminal contempt. The indict ments were handed up by a Manhattan grand jury that has been investigating police cor ruption.

title: New York City Soldier Killed
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) The Defense Department re ported today that Specialist 4 Bernard Lynch of Manhattan had been killed in action while serving with the Army in South east Asia.

title: Dayan Tells New Pilots They're Key to Israel's Fate
description: AT AN ISRAELI AIR FORCE BASE, July 16Israel graduat ed a new class of air force pilots today. Pinning on their wings, Defense Minister Moshe Dayan warned that they, rather than the diplomats, would de termine the nation's future se curity.

title: Bombings Here Reaching Gigantic Proportions, Leary Tells Senators
description: WASHINGTON, July 16New York City's Police Commissioner and three associates told the Senate today that a wave of bombings in New York had reached gigantic proportions.

title: Taxi Union Threatens to Strike Unless City Acts to Curb Crime
description: Local 3036 of the New York City Taxi Drivers Union an nounced yesterday that its 39, 000 members would go on strike at 12:01 A.M. Tuesday unless the city takes immediate ac tion to nrotect taxi drivers.

title: Executive Changes
description: Adolf Knul, Joseph P. McCarthy Jr., and Leighton H. Mcllvaine Jr. have been promoted to vice presi dents of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: South Dakota Sioux Attack Alcoholism
description: SISSETON, S. D.The Sisse tonWahoeton Sioux tribe of the Sisseton Reservation in the northeast corner of South Da kota had a drinking problem for years.

title: Film Premiere of Meistersinger Opens Opera Series
description: The Germans have always taken their opera seriously, and when they present opera on films it is with equal seri ousness. On Wednesday night in Philharmonic Hall a series of filmed operas, most of them the product of Rolf Liebermann, got under way with the world film premiere of Wagner's Die Meister singer. The series, which takes in 12 operas, will con tinue until July 27.

title: Football TieUp Enters 4th Day; College All Stars Resume Drills
description: The stalemate In the pro football labor negotiations will go into its fourth day today with no further meet ings scheduled. The commit tees of the National Football League Players Association and the owners remained here, however, each awaiting a compromising move on money issues by the other.

title: 100 FEDERAL AIDES TO ASSUME ROLE IN DESEGREGATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The Department of Justice will send 100 lawyers and other officials into the South next month in an effort to reduce the poten tial for disturbances as hun dreds of school districts un dertake full desegregation for the first time.

title: VINCENT REDDING OF TIMES IS DEAD
description: D. Vincent Redding, adver tising acceptability manager of The New York Times, died yesterday at his home, 1507 Old Country Road, Elmsford, N. Y., after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

title: DR. JOHN H. PEARSON, RESEARCH DIRECTOR
description: Dr. John Herbert Pearson, for many years a director of re search for the General Chemical Company, now the Industrial Products Division of the Allied Chemical Company, died Wednesday of cancer in New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 63 Central Avenue, Glen Rock, N. J.

title: MRS. FREEDMAN QUITS ARTS POST
description: Doris Freedman, who helped set up the Department of Cul tural Affairs of the Parks, Rec reation and Cultural Affairs Ad ministration, resigned yesterday for personal reasons effective next Friday.

title: Kite Flyers Do the Puffing at Windless Coney Island
description: The sun was fitful and the wind a damp sigh, but there was diversion for the deter mined beachsitters of Coney Island yesterday  a New York City deputy commis sioner in a nice blue suit sprinting along the damp sands trailing a gaggle of chil dren and 102 feet of silvery foil.

title: W. GERMANY TOPS U.S. TRACK SQUAD
Nancy E. Underwood, a Model, Betrothed to John Dillon Hay
description: BALTIMORE, July 16Mrs. Robert Haysham Sayre 4th of Whitehall has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Elizabeth Under wood, to John Dillon Hay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Hay of Old Brookville, L. I. An October wedding is planned.

title: Nicklaus Quits Philadelphia Tourney
Moshe Haim Shapiro, 68, Dies; Israel's Minister of the Interior
description: TEL AVIV, July 16Moshe Haim Shapiro, the Israeli Minister of Interior, died to I night. He was 68 years old.

title: Debt vs. Progress in Ghana
description: After hard negotiating in London, Ghana has obtained agreement of fifteen creditor governments for reservicing part of the billiondollar debt that was one of many legacies of Kwame Nkrumah's profligate dictatorship. Ghana's negotiators had to settle for much less than they had asked for, but they will urge Prime Minister Busia to accent the package.

title: Coast Hurler to Join Osaka
description: OSAKA, Japan, July 16 (AP) Ken Washington, a former United States Pacific Coast League player, will join the Osaka Nankai Hawks of the Pacific League next month to help strengthen their pitching staff, the Japanese professional baseball club said today. Wash ington played last season with Spokane.

title: Namath Will Report Late Even if Labor Woes End
description: Even if the pro football labor dispute is settled soon, Joe Namath has been granted permission by the New York Jets to report to training camp a week from Sunday.

title: TV: Plight of the Migrant Worker
description: The statistics became peo ple last night on N.B.C.'s doc umentary white paper, Mi grant.

title: Hospital Clerk Guilty of Theft
description: A former provisional clerk at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx pleaded guilty yesterday to the theft of about $10,000 from the hospital. The Bronx District At torney, Burton B. Roberts, said that the woman, Mrs. Diane Jordon, 28 years old, of 901 East 217th Street, filled out pay claims for nurses who were not working and intercepted the checks before they were delivered.

title: RATES RAISED 15% ON 4THCLASS MAIL
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today in creases averaging 15.2 per cent in rates for mailing fourthclass parcel post and catalogues.

title: Man Who Made Soup From Marijuana Freed
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 16 (UPI)A vil lage justice here dismissed charges today against a man. who grew marijuana plants in the backyard of his home and then used the plant's seeds to make soup.

title: Black Leaders in Asbury Park Call a Boycott
description: ASBURY PARK. N. J., July 16Black community leaders have begun to organize a boy cott of merchants in the down town shopping area of this sea side resort town that was shaken by racial disturbances last week.

title: Elisabeth D. Dupont Plans Bridal
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., July 16The engagement of Miss Elisabeth Durland Dupont to Daniel McLeod Culp Jr.. son of Mrs. Culp of Greensboro, N.C., and the late Mr. Culp, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Radford Du Pont of Lloyd Harbor.

title: Suspended Detective Testifies He Refused a $5,000 Reward
description: A suspended detective testi fied yesterday at his Police Department trial that he never requested or received a reward for the recovery of stolen prop erty from Montgomery Ward.

title: Railroad's Net Surges
description: Two of the nation's largest transportation companies re ported their secondquarter and firsthalf results yesterday.

title: ExPremier Salazar Suffers A Relapse at 81 in Lisbon
description: LISBON, July 16 (AP)  An tonio de Oliveira Salazar the 81yearold former Premier of Portugal, suffered a relapse and is critically ill, his doctor said today.

title: BANK BORROWINGS UP FOR 4TH WEEK
description: Federal Reserve member, banks appear to be responding strongly to reminders by the central bank that it stands ready to lend them money through the discount window should they come under pres sure from their customers banking statistics published yesterday showed.

title: DEFENSE IS ENDED IN ADDONIZIO CASE
description: TRENTON, July 16The de fense rested today in the trial of Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other men charged with extor tion and conspiracy

title: LINDSAY DEFENDS USE OF ADVISERS
description: Mayor Lindsay pledged yes terday to pursue the city's pol icy of expanded use of out side consultants, who, he said, point the way to the future.

title: SUBURBAN BACKS TIE TO WILLIAMS
description: The Suburban Companies an nounced yesterday in Pomona, Calif., that its board had ap proved a merger agreement with the Williams Brothers Company of Tulsa, Okla.

title: Aluminum Concern's 3 and 6Month Net Dips Moderately
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, reported yesterday moderate declines in earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30. A sharp reduction in taxes this year helped to keep the drop in earnings at a moderate level according to the midyear state ment.

title: FUNDS ARE SOUGHT TO CONTROL GANGS
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 16 Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo told a Congressional committee today that the city was in desperate need of out side funds to combat the juve nile gang problem.

title: ASSEMBLY IN SEOUL OPPOSES TROOP CUT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 16  The South Korean National Assembly unanimously voted a resolution today voicing objec tion to United States plans for troop cutbacks in Korea.

title: Roundup: Twins Learn To Err Proves Costly
Ford, in Upstate Talk Says Nixon Watchword Is Reform
description: LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 16 (AP)United States Repre sentative Gerald R. Ford said tonight that the Nixon Ad ministration was committed to the kind of orderly progress through reform that would lead. the nation out of what he called the violent sixties into a decade of human better1 ment.

title: Parley on Campus Unrest Told Snobbish Students Are Cause
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) Campus violence will con tinue as long as snobbish, ar rogant students regard the American people as an enemy in their efforts to solve social problems, Harvard graduateau thor Steven Kelman said today.

title: National Theafer Of Britain Does The Idiot Poorly
description: LONDON, July 16If every one had his own, no doubt Dostoyevsky would belong to the stage, but the National Theater has hardly strengthened this claim with Simon Gray's adaptation of The Idiot. It is the saddest piece of butchery i have seen at this address.

title: Voloshen Said Sweig Aided Conspiracy
description: When Nathan M. Voloshen pleaded guilty to conspiring to misuse the prestige of House Speaker John W. McCormack, he declared that the Speaker's ad ministrative assistant, Dr. Mar tin Sweig, had been aware of what he was doing and helped him do it.

title: MISS LAUGHLIN'S 79 TAKES JERSEY TITLE
description: HAWORTH, N.J., July 16 Ann Laughlin of the Riverton Country Club won the 21st an nual New Jersey State junior girls' golf championship today at White Beeches Golf and Country Club course.

title: Martin Joins Sinatra In Supporting Reagan
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 16 (UPI)Dean Martin, an active fundraiser for the Democrats, has joined the re election campaign of Gov. Ronald Reagan.

title: BonnMoscow Parley Will Start on July 27
description: BONN, July 16The So viet Union and West Ger many have agreed to start formal negotiations on a non aggression treaty in Moscow on July 27, it was announced here.

title: PANTHERS FEARED SAMS, COURT TOLD
description: NEW HAVEN, July 16  A prosecution witness testified to day that Black Panthers at the party's headquarters here at the time of the slaying of Alex Rackley were command ed and terrorized by the only man so far to giye testimony implicating Bobby G. Seale in the crime.

title: Indians Assured of Return on Film Venture
description: The 1,800 Jicarilla Apaches of New Mexico, who are set ting a precedent as the first Indians to back a movie by totally financing a $2million Western starring Kirk Doug las and Johnny Cash, the folk singer, are now sure of some returns on their invest ment. Paramount Pictures announced that it has just acquired rights to distribute the movie, A Gunfight, both in this country and in Canada.

title: Pirates Open Their New Park, But Reds Celebrate 32 Victory
description: PITTSBURGH, July 16 Three Rivers Stadium, major league baseball's newest magnificent ballpark, had a gala opening tonight even though the Pittsburgh Pirates, attired in natty new uni forms, lost to the Cincinnati Reds. 32.

title: General Tire to Increase Prices of Plastic Sheeting
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it would soon raise prices on its plastic film sheeting and coated fabrics because of new labor contracts and other ris ing production costs.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: 31 HURT IN BLAST AT BELFAST BANK
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 16  An explosion exten sively damaged a bank here today and injured 31 persons. Nine of them were hospitalized, four with severe facial and in ternal injuries.

title: 20,000 Campers Flee Riviera Forest Fires
description: PARIS, July 16The pre cious landscape of the Riviera has been scarred this week by vast forest fires fanned by the mistral, the dry wind of southern France.

title: Airliner Crew Training to Balk Hijackers Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (Reuters)  Airliner cabin crews should receive training on how to work together to arrest hijackers, Secor D. Browne, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, suggested today.

title: Deadline for Strike At News Deferred
description: Contract negotiations be tween The Daily News and the Mailers Union continued past a strike deadline this morning as Theodore W. Kheel, chief mediator in the dispute, sought to head off a strike that would shut down both The News and The New York Times today. Local No. 6 had announced that it would strike The News at 12:01 A.M. if it did not have a satisfactory contract. But the union agreed to defer any walk out until 5 P.M. today to study a compromise proposal offered by Mr. Kheel. The nature of the proposal was not made public.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Friday, July 17, 1970

title: Fritz Schmidt, 104, Dies
description: Fritz Leopold Schmidt, a for mer freelance writer, died yes terday at the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples, 1060 Amster dam Avenue. He was 104 years old. Survivors include a daugh ter, Mrs. Melenda Beecroft, and two grandchildren.

title: Chrysler Lists 3Month Profit
description: DETROIT, July 16  The Chrysler Corporation reported today earnings of $8.1million, or 17 cents a share, in the sec ond quarter. This was about fifth of the $41.4million, or 88 cents a share, earned the year before on matching second quarter sales of $1.9billion in both years.

title: Ellen M. Mandel Engaged to Wed Jack Victor Kahn
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 16 Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and Mrs. Mandel have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Ellen Marsha Mandel, to Jack Victor Kahn, who owns and operates a gift shop in the Georgetown section of Wash ington. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kahn of New York, where Mr. Kahn is vice president of the M & A Wares Company, a toy manufacturer.

title: SOLOMON BOROWICK
description: Solomon Borowick, a co founder and assistant director of the New York Schools of Music, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 301 East 69th Street.

title: Ninth Commonwealth Games Begin
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 16 (Reuters)The ninth Com monwealth Games opened to day with a bomb scare, a noisy demonstration and Scottish highland pageantry to welcome 1,900 competitors from 41 countries.

title: New Palomar Telescope
description: PALOMAR MOUNTAIN, Calif., July 16 (AP)A one ton mirror, the optical heart of the first telescope to be added at the milehigh Mount Palo mar Observatory in 22 years, is being installed this week and should be operational by next Monday.

title: $4.4BILLION IN AID TO SCHOOLS VOTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 The House passed today a compromise $4.4billion edu cation appropriation bill that provides $453million more than President Nixon re quested.

title: U.N. WILL DISCUSS SOUTH AFRICA ISSUE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 16The Security Council will meet in urgent session at 3:30 P.M. tomorrow at the re quest of 41 nations concerned that Britain's new Conservative Government will resume the sale of aircraft and arms to South Africa.

title: ExYonkers Officer Denies ConflictofInterest Charge
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 16 (AP) A former Yonkers City Coun cilman pleaded not guilty today to conflictofinterest charges in an indictment growing out of last year's investigation of mu nicipal corruption by the State Investigation Commission.

title: ISAAC J. MORRIS
description: Isaac J. Morris, founder and secretary treasurer of I. J. Mor ris, Inc., undertakers of Brook lyn and Hempstead, L. I., died yesterday in Brookdale Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 58 Cardinal Drive, East Hills, L. I.

title: Meredith Monk's Program
description: Meredith Monk/The House will present a work in two parts at the Connecticut Col lege American Dance Festival in New London on Saturday. Part I of the work, Needle Brain Lloyd and the System's KidA Live Movie, will take place at 4 P.M. and Part II will take place at 9:15.

title: Cleveland's Bombed Rodin To Remain in Damaged State
description: CLEVELAND, July 16 (AP) A 900pound bronze casting of Rodin's statue The Thinker, damaged by a bomb outside the Cleveland Musem of Art March 24, will not be repaired, mu seum officials said yesterday.

title: Liu Hsinchuan Is Identified As Peking Envoy to Soviet
description: MOSCOW, July 16 (UPI)  Authoritiative sources said to day that the new Chinese Am bassador to the Soviet Union would be Liu Hsinchuan, a Deputy Foreign Minister.

title: Boy Friend Revival to End
description: The Boy Friend, the re vival of the Sandy Wilson mu sical starring Judy Came, will end its Broadway run tomorrow night at the Ambassador Thea ter after 122 performances. The show represents an investment of $174,000.

title: TWO ARE ARRAIGNED IN SLAYING AT A.&P.
description: Two suspects in the slaying of the manager of an East Side A. & P. were arraigned in State Supreme Court yesterday on murder charges. Both men Louis Overton and Donald Tan nerwere held without bail by Justice Harold Baer.

title: Foot Is Chosen as Member Of Labor's Shadow Cabinet
description: LONDON, July 17Labor members of Parliament have named Michael Foot a member of the shadow cabinet, making him an official spokesman for the Opposition in the House of Commons.

title: Jersey Killer Sentenced
description: CAMDEN, N.J. July 16 (UPI)  Leroy Snyder, 38 years old, who pleaded no contest to the murder of six women and a man in an eightmonth period, was sentenced today to three consecutive life prison terms. Snyder said when he pleaded last week that robbery was the motive in all but one of the murders, and the sentencing judge quoted a psychiatric re port as calling Snyder a mal ignant psychopath and a threat to society. Prosecutor A. Donald Bigley said Snyder must serve 43 years before becoming eligible for parole.

title: 6 Police Who Refused Bribes Lauded
description: Four narcotics cases in which six policemen refused to take bribes totaling close to $10,0001 were cited yesterday by Dis trict Attorney Burton B. Rob erts of the Bronx as evidence that the overwhelming ma joiity of New York policemen are honest.

title: Judge Curbs Bank On Pennsy Rentals
description: Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Phila delphia continued yesterday restraining order he issued last Friday preventing the Provident National Bank from trying to collect rental payments from tenants of Madison Square Gar den.

title: Advertising: Bates & Co. Executive Vice President Turns in Reins
description: J. Ross MacLennan, thought by many to be the heir ap parent at, Ted Bates & Co.. the world's fourthlargest ad agency, has quit.

title: Italian Government Crisis Plays Out a Familiar Ritual
description: ROME, July 16  In the Rome of the politicians it is an outright disgrace these days to have a tan. It indi cates that one really does not count for much and has plenty of time to loll on the seaside rather than being en gaged from morning until late at night in the ritual of crisis consultations.

title: The Auto Talks Begin
description: General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler have opened their new contract talks with the United Auto Work ers in an atmosphere clouded with concern over inflation, the threat of increasing loss of sales to foreign cars, and criticism of the auto industry for its record on safety, performance standards, and pollution.

title: Nearly Treadless Tires Found on Bus in Fatal Crash
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., July 16 Investigators found almost treadless tires today on the left rear wheels of the chartered bust that skidded off a highway yes terday, carrying seven children to their death and injuring 52 other persons.

title: Court Hears Views On Rock Festival For Powder Ridge
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 16 (UPI)  Residents of rustic Middlefield, and promoters of the Powder Ridge Rock Festival resumed legal skirmishes in Superior Court as preparations were under way for a three day rock festival expected to attract 50,000 youths from July 30 through Aug. 1.

title: Ballet: Versatile Dutch
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, July 16The Holland Festival is the most depend ably surprising of all Euro pean festivals. Each year it manages to produce works that not only are off the beaten track but also worth the diversion. This year it was the staging of a new bal let by the Netherlands Dance Theater, Mutations. This collaboration by the two ar tistic directors of the com pany, Glen Tetley and Hans van Manen, I actually saw after the festival itself, dur ing the current dance festival that the Netherlands Damce Theater offers each year at Amsterdam's Municipal Op era House.

title: Attack on U.S. Rammed Through Youth Assembly Panel, but It Faces Challenge
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16  A denunciation of the United States for its role in Vietnam and what was termed its rapacious policy in Latin America was rammed through a World Youth Assembly panel today by a vote of 181 to 73.

title: Neuwirth Fund to Resume Selling Shares to Investors
description: The Neuwirth Fund, Inc., which has been closed to new investors for the last 15 months, has announced that it has be gun selling its shares to all in vestors on a noload basis un til Oct. 30 and then will begin making sales charges of up to 8 per cent.

title: Tenants in Struck Apartments Threaten to Burn Up Garbage
description: Angry tenants in six large apartment buildings on an Up per East Side block threatened yesterday to set fire to their garbage in the street because the city's sanitationmen have refused to collect refuse while the buildings are being struck by service emploves.

title: COCACOLA DENIES LINK TO FARM ILLS
description: The National Broadcasting Company, following an angry meeting with representatives of the CocaCola Company, altered its documentary on migrant farm workers before the pro gram was broadcast over the N.B.C. television last night.

title: DR. AVERY ASHDOWN; M.I.T. CHEMIST WAS 78
description: BOSTON, July 16Dr. Avery Allen Ashdown, who retired in 1957 as a professor of organic chemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, but served later as a lecturer, died yesterday at the age of 78.

title: Shape of the Future
description: As if another defeat by the National League in the AllStar Game wasn't suf ficient to plunge the American League into deeper dismay and embarrassment, the Americans had to feel a new sense of fore boding as they were confronted by the shape of things to come. The future working against them and they may very well find themselves victimized by prog ress.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Argentine With Dual Citizenship Held Exempt From the Service
description: WASHINGTON, July 16An appeals court reversed today a lower court judgment that or dered the induction of a 21 yearold Los Angeles man with dual United States and Argen tine citizenship.

title: ART GROUP LOSING WESTCHESTER HOME
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 15 For nearly a decade, the West chester Art Society has held classes and exhibitions for its 700 members in a converted sweatshop on the third floor above a General Electric repair store here.

title: LOU LOU IS FIRST IN ETCHES SAIL
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 16 The Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week, devoted the last three days to sailing among the young started what amounted to a stretch run to the finish for the older helms men today and not even the losers had much to grumble about. The wind conditions weren't perfect, but they were close.

title: Vietnam Peace Initiatives
description: Such difference of opinion as may exist between Secretary of State Rogers and Presidential assistant Henry A. Kissinger over the effect of the Cambodian incursion on the prospects for peace in Vietnam less important than need for agreement on a White House policy to get the Paris peace talks moving again.

title: S.E.C. Chief Says Big Board Can Prevent Liquidation Losses
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Comm sion said today that, so far as he knew, the New York Stock Exchange had adequate resources to pre vent financial loss to the cus omers of any exchange mem bers that were going to have to be liquidated in the near future.

title: $50Million Gulf Oil Project Is Approved by South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 16The South Korean Govern ment approved today a $50 million investment and loan project of the Gulf Oil Corpo ration for South Korea's oil refinery and petrochemical in dustries.

title: Fernando Dahmen Jr., 57, Of Chile's Mission to U.N.
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 16Fernando Dahmen Jr., a director of the Chilean Nitrate Sales Corporation and a mem ber of the Chilean delegation to the United Nations, died yester day of a pulmonary embolism at St. Fancis Hospital in Ros lyn. He was 57 years old and lived at 24 Revere Road.

title: G.N.P. STABILIZES AFTER DECLINING FOR SIX MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The nation's total output of goods and services stabilized in the second quarter after hav ing declined for six months, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Kathryn M. Siska Prospective Bride
description: BELLEVILLE, N. J., July 16 Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Siska have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Mary Siska, to Bernard Francis Walters, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Walters of Manhasset. L. I.

title: Abortion Guidelines
description: Lines have been sharply drawn between opposing factions at the Board of Health hearing on the City Health Code amendment to govern abortions under the state's liberal new law. The proposed guidelines emphasize patient safety by requiring that these op erations be conducted primarily in hospitals or other facilities which are well equipped to take care emergencies, an attitude supported by manythough not allgynecologists. Opponents of the amendment fear it will restrict the number of abortions severely, make them relatively expensive and turn abortion, Borough President Percy E. Sutton's words, into an ??obtainable privilege for the middle class and the poor.

title: VOTE ON SECRECY DELAYED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 The House, which has been known to vote billions of dol lars for defense in a matter of hours, continued today to grope its way warily through a Congressional reform bill.

title: Peahead Walker, Grid Coach, ExScout for Giants, Dies at 71
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) July 16  Douglas Clyde (Peahead) Walker, former Wake Forest football coach and recently a scout for the New York Giants of the National Football League, died today at a Char lotte hospital. His age was 71.

title: Rogers, the Constant Negotiator
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Be sides dealing with Russians, Arabs, Israelis and Vietnamese, Secretary of State William P. Rogers is now engaged in periodic negotiations with the White House and, on occasion, even with himself.

title: Police Arrest A Neighbor In Fatal Shooting of Boy
description: A neighbor was arrested yes terday in the death of a 3year old hoy who was shot as he lay in his crib. The neighbor admitted that he had accident ally fired the weapon while sit ting on afire escape across the street from the building in which the baby lived, the police said.

title: '69 BONN FOREIGN AID PUT AT $2.36BILLION
description: BONN, July 16Dr. Erhard Eppler, Economic Cooperation Minister, said today that, in 1969 West Germany spent a larger share of its gross na tional income on aid to develop ing countries than any other nation.

title: FORD SAYS U.A.W. FEEDS INFLATION
description: DETROIT, July 16The Ford Motor Company labeled as in flationary today a demand of the United Automobile Work ers that the union calls a key to halting inflationary wage increases.

title: Foreign Affairs: Britain and a Shrinking U.S.A.
description: LONDONThe basic problem of defense planning under Brit ain's new Conservative Govern ment is how to adjust a small power role to greatpower com mitments in a world where U.S. overseas strength is steadily shrinking.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Unorthodox Educator
description: One of the hallmarks of Dr. Harvey B. Scribner's tenure as Vermont's Commissioner of Education has been his small staff. You've got to wipe out the bureaucracy, he has been quoted as saying.

title: Fifth Avenue Coach Is Cleared on Funds
description: Federal Judge Edward C. Mc Lean yesterday gave S. Hazard Gillespie, court  appointed trustee of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., authority to accept, if he wishes, an addi tional $10.7million, plus inter est, from New York City for intangible assets.

title: Layer Beats Rosewall in Straight Sets in $200,000 Tennis Champions Final
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 16 They finally discovered a way today to keep Intrepid from winning in the America's Cup defense trials. They called off the races.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JULY 17, 1970

title: Doyle Dane Bernbach Adds a Nun to the Payroll
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach which has had its share of firsts in this business, might well have another if no other ad agency has a nun on the payroll. Exnuns do not qualify.

title: U.S. Judge Bars Dismissal Of Charges Against Dowdy
description: BALTIMORE, July 16 (AP) Representative John Dowdy's move to dismiss bribery con spiracy charges was turned down today by Federal District Court Judge Roszel C. Thomsen.

title: COURT BARS MOVE TO HELP TENANTS IN HOUSING STRIKE
description: Mayor Lindsay's administra tion was stopped In State Su preme Court yesterday from taking over services, cutting rents or otherwise acting against landlords of struck buildings, pending a trial on city powers in that court starting Monday.

title: Iceland Buries Leader
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 16 (AP)Flags flew at half staff and shops and offices closed throughout Iceland today as a state funeral was held in Reykjavik Cathedral for Prime Minister Bjarni Benediktsson, his wife, Sigridur, and their 4 yearold grandson, Benedikt Vilmundarson. The three perished last Friday in a fire. Postmaster General Winton M. Blount represented the United States.

title: Jacklin Tops Hickok Poll
description: Tony Jacklin, the first Eng lishman to win the United States Open golf title in 46 years, was an overwhelming winner in the June voting for the Hickok professional athlete of the year award. In the ?? writers and broadcasters, Pele, the Brazilian soccer star, drew 14 firstplace votes and a total of 103 points.

title: REFORMS IN IRAN BRING NEW HOPE
description: TEHERAN, Iran (AP)There is a new feeling of hope and pride in Iran, and it is evident in this sprawling capital with its new office buildings, super markets, freeways and modern factories.

title: Delegates to U.N. Youth Assembly See a Black Militant's Harlem
description: Some 50 participants in the United Nations World Youth Assembly took an unofficial tour of Harlem yesterday that was designed by its organizer, an American black militant, to show them how this country exploits and oppresses its own people.

title: Order of Elks Votes to Maintain WhitesOnly Rule in Its Charter
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 (AP)Delegates to the national convention of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks voted today to retain the lodge's whitesonly membership requirement.

title: STOCKS ARE MIXED ON LONDON BOARD
Joblessness Rises To 6.6% in Canada
description: TORONTO, July 16Can ada's unemployment rate in creased to a nineyear high of 6.6 per cent last month, the Government reported today.

title: Furnishings Encompass Both Modern and Period
description: Modern furniture may sweep traditional furnishings from the American home in the nineteenseventies, as Gerda Clark of Abraham & Straus believes, or it may not. But if it does, this store decorator has a packet of answers to the question of how some traditional touches can be worked into the back Shop grounds of mod Talk ern rooms. In the six settings Miss Clark de vised, which open Monday, on the store's seventh floor, there are such solutions as walltowall frescoes, pilas terflanked windows, ersatz stone walls and fireplace, aluminum grillwork that looks like iron and rococo panels to hang on walls sim ulating the look of French 18thcentury boiserie. Not all of the decorative devices are astronomical in cost. The boiserie, for instance, for the 12 and 10footlong walls, is $475 from the American Wood Column Corporation, 913 Grand Street, Brooklyn.

title: Stevens Textile Announces 2 Plants Will Be Closed
description: FRANKLIN, N.H., July 16 (AP)Officials of the J. P. Stevens Textile Company an nounced today that plants here and in nearby Tilton will be closed by the end of October because of pressure from im ports. because of pressure from im ports.

title: Comedian Enters Gaming
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., July 16 (AP)Buddy Hackett, the comedian, has applied for a license as a Nevada gambler. Mr. Hackett, 46 years old, must undergo a routine hack ground check to win a license for his 2 per cent interest in the Kings Castle hotel casino at Lake Tahoe, a spokesman for the Nevada Gaming Con trol Board said yesterday.

title: No Man's Land Established On SalvadorHonduras Line
description: SAN SALVADOR, July 16 (UPI) A twomile, wide no man's land was established to day along the HondurasEl Salvador border. The two na tions fought a brief but bloody war in July, 1969, over terri torial and economic issues.

title: Riots Continue in Italy
description: REGGIO CALBRIA, Italy, July 16(Reuters)  Thousands of demonstrators armed with iron bars and gasoline bombs fought pitched battles with the police and set fire to several buildings tonight in the third day of violence over the future capital of the newlyformed Calabria region.

title: INSURANCE DEALS LAID TO CITY AIDE
description: The counsel to the city's Youth Service Agency was sus pended yesterday after charges that, against orders, he gave some of the agency's insurance business to a friend.

title: CALIFORNIA EDISON LISTS GAIN IN NET
description: The Southern California Edi son Company reported yester day gains in operating revenues and net income for the June quarter and the first half. Jack K. Horton, chairman and chief executive officer, placed sec ondquarter revenues at $172, 935,000 against $150,055,000 a year earlier. Net income in creased to $29,276,000, or 61 cents a share, from $24,052,000, or 51 cents, in the 1969 period.

title: MSGR. WEISBROD, 74, A PASTOR IN NEWARK
description: ORANGE, N. J., July 16 Msgr. John A. Weisbrod, pas tor of Our Lady of Counsel Ro man Catholic Church in New ark, died in a hopsital here yesterday as a result of a fall in the rectory. He was 74 years old.

title: BRITON EMPHASIZES GAINS FOR MARKET
description: LONDON, July 16Anthony Barber, making his first public address as British negotiator for membership in the European Economic Community, said to day that Britain was not play ing hard to get but she could not accept membership that imposed intolerable burdens.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Highs and Lows

title: On Eve of 2d Fifth Ave. Closing, Lindsay Calls Test a Success
description: Last Saturday's traffic ban on a 15block midtown stretch of Fifth Avenue was a suc cess from virtually every point of view, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

title: HOUSE REJECTS AID TO TRAVEL SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) The House decided today not to expand the United States Travel Service.

title: 3 Found Dead in Icebox
description: CLAREMORE, Okla., July 16 (AP)The bodies of three small children were found yesterday in a closed refrigerator behind a rural home a few miles west of here. The deaths were ruled accidental. The victims were John Dale Coleman 2 years old. Becky Marie, 3, and their brother, Jackie, 6.

title: Washington: For the Record
Baltimore: A City Worth a Trip for Food Alone
description: BALTIMORE  There are few cities in Americaalbeit a precious fewworth visit ing simply because of their restaurants. They would in clude San Francisco, New Or leans, Cincinnati, New York and Chicago. And Baltimore where good food, particularly good sea food, is of great im portance. Following are six of the best restaurants here, rated four stars to none based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: ShortTerm Bond Rates Decline For the Fourth Consecutive Day
description: Shortterm interest rates declined for the fourth con secutive day this weekhelped along by the Federal Re servein spite of a heavy volume of Treasury financing this month, including $2.25 billion yesterday. The em phasis on higherquality cor porate bonds intensified, and a lower medium grade issue yielding 11 per cent did not sell out completely after it was offered to investors.

title: Ron Turcotte Scores Triple, Including Part of $781 Double and $332 Exacta
description: An impressive performance by C. V. Whitney's Bid High was one of the more note worthy occurrences at Aque duct yesterday. Competing in a 5furlong sprint for 2year old fillies, Bid High registered a 3length triumph over Meadowhill's Green Princess.

title: Arlyn J. Zeldman Plans Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Irving Zeldman of Boston and Mrs. Lois Zeld man of Beachwood, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Arlyn Joy Zeldman, to Joel William Greenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Morton Green baum of Yonkers.

title: Halt in Offshore Oil Drilling Is Urged at Federal Hearing
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 16 (AP)  A spokesman for the national Sierra Club asked the Interior Department today to call a halt to all offshore drill ing.

title: A Bad Package
description: After three months of consideration, a SenateHouse conference committee has reported out an anticrime bill for the District of Columbia which has been vari ously characterized as violative of no less than five Constitutional amendments and as a blueprint for a police state. Twenty former Federal prosecutors have found the bill's chief provisions of doubtful constitutionality, questionable necessity and demon strable ineffectiveness.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CHALLENGE OF WORLD POVERTY. A World AntiPoverty Program in Outline. By Gunnar Myrdai. 518 Pages. Pantheon. $8.95.

title: Agnew T Shirts and Watches Yield $25,000 to 2 Charities
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  Vice President Agnew's favorite charities received $25, 000 in donations today as royalties from watches and T shirts bearing caricatures of him.

title: House Panel Votes $207Million in Health Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) The House Appropriations Committee approved nearly $207million today for hospital and health research this fiscal year, the same prograims Presi dent Nixon tried to veto last month.

title: New Airport Power For Waterfront Unit Pushed in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Congressional approval to ex pand the anticrime jurisdic tion of the Waterfront Com mission of New York Harbor to the major airports in the metropolitan area was sought today by most members of Con gress from New York and New Jersey.

title: Dow Surges 11.78 To Recovery High
Public Invited to Visit Ship
description: The Coast Guard's sailing ship Eagle, arriving here this morning, will be open for the public tomorrow and Sunday from 1 P.M. to 4 P.M. and from 5 P.M. to 8 P.M. The training ship will he berthed at the South Street Seaport Museum, on the East River near the Bat tery.

title: MARCUSE TO STAY AT U. OF CALIFORNIA
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 16 (AP)  Herbert Marcuse, the Marxist philosopher, will re main at the University of Cali fornia at San Diego even though his contract expired July 1, his department chair man said today.

title: Morton Scores Democrats' TV Time
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Representative Rogers C. B. Morton, the Republican Nation al Chairman, accused the Dem ocrats today of trying to de stroy the country and Presi dent Nixon by demanding equal television time to answer Mr. Nixon's reports to the na tion.

title: COURT BACKS P.B.A. IN PAYRAISE SUIT
description: The city lost a court de cision yesterday, and the result could cost it at least $200mil lion a year in wage increases for policemen, firemen and oth er municipal employes.

title: Barbara Rockman Is Bride on L.I.
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., July 16  Miss Barbara Diane Rockman was married this evening to Andrew M. Rose at the Great Neck Synagogue by Rabbi Ephraim Wolf.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE FELL 2,6% IN WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage last week were both below the volume of the year earlier week.

title: NASSER FINISHES TALKS IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, July 16 (AP) President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and the Soviet leaders con cluded crucial talks on the Mid dle East today. A communiqu is expected tomorrow after the Egyptian leader leaves.

title: Referendum on War Approved by Senate In Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, July 16 (UPI)A bill drafting a statewide refer endum question for the Novem ber ballot on future United States military action in Viet nam was passed unanimously tonight by the state Senate and sent to the House.

title: BRITAIN DECLARES DOCK EMERGENCY
description: LONDON, July 16  A state of emergency was proclaimed in Britain today as a strike by 47,000 dock workers virtually paralyzed the movement of food, raw materials and other goods through the nation's ports.

title: Bridge:
Soybean Futures Rise, Then Dip
description: After advancing sharply, soy bean futures prices dropped on profit taking and closed lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a rather active session.

title: Court Continues an Order Barring Catskill Festival
description: ALBANY, July 16 (AP)A State Supreme Court justice granted continuation today of a temporary court order blocking a music festival at Mountain Dale, in the Catskill Mountains.

title: PRICES ON AMEX GAIN NARROWLY
description: The American Stock Ex change index continued its up ward march yesterday, closing at 20.07, a gain of 0.08. One of the upward factors was a large number of blocks of stocks crossing the tape at strong prices, an indicator of some re newed interest by institutional buyers.

title: UM. Truce Observer Killed By Egyptian Fire at Canal
description: TEL AVIV, July 16  A United Nations observer was killed and another wounded this afternoon by Egyptian fire across the Suez Canal.

title: British Prince Quits as Diplomat
description: LONDON, July 16 (AP) Prince William of Gloucester, the 28yearold first cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, has re signed from the diplomatic service, the Foreign Office announced today.

title: Cahill's SoninLaw in Line For Promotion in State Job
description: TRENTON, July 16 (AP) Gov. William T. Cahill's sonin law, hired by the state two months ago, is in line for a promotion.

title: P. S.C. Orders Rates to Be Cut For PayPhone Calls in Area
description: The Public Service Commis sion ordered the New York Telephone Company yesterday to cut its rates on coin tele phone calls in the New York Metropolitan area by $2.68 million a year.

title: State U. Refuses a New Paltz Inquiry
description: The State University's board of trustees decided yesterday that a special investigation of the university's College at New Paltz was unnecessary because a regular evaluation of the school will be made this fall by the Middle States Associa tion the regional accrediting agency.

title: DR. VIRGIL FOSTER OF CHURCH COUNCIL
description: Dr. Virgil Foster, former edi tor of The International Jour nal of Religious Education, a publication of the World Coun cil of Churches, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 501 West 123d Street. He was 68 years old.

title: Yanks Beat A's, 41, After 82 Loss
description: Stan Bahnsen, seemingly re freshed after a threeday break for the AllStar game, hurled seven strong innings yesterday at Yankee Stadium to gain a 41 triumph and a split for the Yankees in a doubleheader with the Oakland Athletics.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
Democrat Gets Post
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., July 16 (AP)The New Hampshire Democratic State Committee unanimously elected Harry Makris, 44 years old, of Nashua, as its chairman last night. He replaces Oliva Huot of Laconia, who resigned to support the candidacy of Charles Whitte more for Governor.

title: Pope at Castel Gandolfo
description: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, July 16 (AP)Pope Paul VI re turned from the Vatican today to his summer retreat here in the cool Alban Hills southeast of Rome.

title: Sales Show a Decline
description: The Allied Chemical Corpo ration reported yesterday that its net income in the second quarter totaled $32,411,000, or $1.17 a share, including extra ordinary gains of $20,805,000, or 75 cents a share.

title: International Secretary of the Year Is One in 27,000
description: She is 5feet9, weighs 120 pounds, has brown eyes and brown hair and lives alone in an apartment in Houston. She gets to work at 7:45 A.M., raves about her electric type writer and was selected yes terday from 27,000 potential candidates as International Secretary of the Year.

title: U.S. PANEL SEEKS NEW AUTO ENGINE
description: WASHINGTON. July 16 (UPI)  The Nixon Administra tion announced today a pro gram to develop by 1975 at least two lowpollution alter natives to the regular gasoline auto engine, which is estimated to cause at least half of the nation's air pollution.

title: A Year After Moon Landing: Space Dream and Jobs Fade
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 16A year ago today, as 700,000 people watched Apollo 11 thunder off to ward man's first landing on the moon, an enterprising aerospace engineer rushed through the motel parking lots along the beach here slapping copies of his job resume on every windshield in sight.

title: T.V.A. to Raise Rates
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 16  The Tennessee Valley Au thority announced today it would increase its wholesale power rates because of rising coal costs and interests rates. A T.V.A. spokesman said the new rates were expected to be about 25 per cent higher after the hikes to wholesalers were completed.

title: Letter Charges Torture at Second Vietnamese Prison
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)One of the two Repre sentatives who drew attention to the tigercage cells at Con Son Prison in South Vietnam made public today a letter charging that inmates were tortured and subjected to other inhuman practices at a sec ond orison in Vietnam.

title: An Excerpt From Lindsay's Talk on City Consultants
description: Following is an excerpt from a speech by Mayor Lindsay at the Lotos Club Public Affairs luncheon on the city's use of consultants:

title: At Valentino, No Revolution This Year, But Lots of Exotic and Elegant Designs
description: ROME, July 16  Valen tino's fall collection is not apt to cause riots in the streets, and the closest it comes to the mysterious East is the Russian steppes, but it's very pretty anyway. Being king of the Roman couture is an awesome responsibility, and this one doesn't pull his rank.

title: Mrs. Faught Is Married To B.H. Warburton 3d
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 16 Barclay Harding Warburton 3d, greatgrandson of John Wanamaker of Philadelphia and a wellknown resident here, married this afternoon Mrs. Lore Maria Faught, who has been conducting Yoga classes here.

title: OCEANOGRAPHY UNIT GETS MARINE OFFICE
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., July 16 The Scripps Institute of Ocean ography announced yesterday the formation here of a Center for Marine Affairs.

title: A South Vietnamese Widow Mourns Her Only Son, Killed in Cambodia
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, July 16Her only son, a 21  year  old corporal, was killed in Cambodia on May 29 and the loss makes her tremble and cry out. When Mrs. Dro Huan, a widow who works as a porter in the city of Nhatrang, can afford to take the airplane to Sai gon, it is to see his grave, bring him gifts, and talk aloud to him, as thousands of other Vietnamese Buddhist women have done at other graves.

title: Project May Allow Closer Look at Planet Venus
description: A modification of the world's largest radio telescope that would, in effect, bring Venus as close to the earth as the moon seems likly in view of provisional approval of the project by a House committee.

title: Sarah E. Ward To Be Married
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 16Ralph E. Ward, president and chief executive of Chese broughPond's Inc., and Mrs. Ward have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Elizabeth Ward to William Lawrence Hogan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Hogan of Warren, Pa. An October wedding is planned.

title: Market Place
description: The stormy stock market could not have come at a worse time from a tax view point. Here we are still try ing to limit losses in one of the worst bear markets in history while favorable taxes on capital gains are being whittled.

title: Boston's Finest Art At the Metropolitan
description: The coincidence of two centennial celebrations this yearthose of the Metropoli tan Museum of Art in New York and the Museum of Fine Arts in Bostonhas brought to New York an extraordi nary loan exhibition of 100 masterpieces of painting from Boston's permanent collec tion. The exhibition, which in cludes pictures by Rogier van der Weyden, Rembrandt, Titian, El Greco, Zurburan, Turner, Monet, Degas and Gauguin, is currently on view in the Metropolitan's special exhibition galleries.

title: Many Big Projects Near City Stymied By Public Protests
description: Public opposition to mas sive construction projects is mounting in cities, towns and villages ringing New York City.

title: Reforestation Is Planned as Fires Smolder on Riviera
description: PARIS July 17French of ficials were planning vast re forestation programs today as brush and forest fires smol dered along the Riviera.

title: PAPER PUBLISHERS FIGHT F.C.C. ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)  The American Newspaper Publishers Association said to day it would support a court challenge by three news agen cies of a Federal Communica tions Commission decision on methods of setting rates for leased news wires.

title: Bayonne Concern Gets $10,000 Fine In Water Pollution
description: NEWARK, July 17 (AP)A Federal judge today imposed $10,000 fine for oil pollution of water, the largest such fine by a Federal court, against Bayonne Industries of Bayonne.

title: Body of Argentina's Kidnapped ExPresident Found
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 17 (AP)The Argentine Govern ment announced today that the body of former President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu, who was kidnapped May 29, had been found.

title: MRS. WILLIAM D. HOWE
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Poulson Howe, widow of William David Howe, one of the founders of the pub lishing firm of Harcourt Brace & Howe, died Tuesday at the age of 90.

title: Opera: Liebermann's Filmed Fidelio
description: Rolf Liebermann, whose filmed production of Fi delio was seen Thursday night at Philharmonic Hall, made a reputation at the Hamburg State Opera on the strength of his ability to in ject theatrical life into opera. Strange to say, his color movie of Beethoven's sing spiel proved a dead loss as drama, even by traditional opera standards, and at times turned ludicrous.

title: GENERAL TIRE PLANS VINYL PRICE INCREASE
description: The General Tire Rubber Com pany announced yesterday that its chemical plastics division will increase prices on vinyl up holstery for the furniture in dustry by an average of 5 per cent effective Aug. 15.

title: Pueblo Aim: Deed to Shrine
description: TAOS, N. M., July 16 The Council of Elders, old men with light flannel blan kets, some covering their heads from the blazing mid day sun, came out of an adobe meeting room into the largely deserted street.

title: Food Rationing on List Of British Strike Powers
description: LONDON, July 17The Gov ernment assumed powers today to impose food rationing as it published emergency regula tions to cope with problems that might arise from the na tional dock strike.

title: Ceylon Plans Visa Tax
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 17 The Government of Ceylon hopes to raise nearly $1million a year by imposing a visa tax on foreigners. A bill to he in troduced in Parliament would tax foreigners $68 annually if they wished to stay in the coun try for more than three months.

title: John J. Anthony Is Dead at 68; Radio's Marital Problem Solver
description: John J. Anthony, who en thralled 20 million radio listen ers each week with his speedy solutions to marital problems, on the Good Will Hour, died Thursday evening in San Francisco of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: Battle of the Airbus Enters New Phase Next Week
description: LOS ANGELES, July 17 The twoyearold battle for the multibilliondollar air bus jetliner market will en ter a new phase next week when the McDonnell Doug las Aircraft Company shows off the first of its threeen gine DC10's.

title: AUTO UNION RAISES MEDICAL CARE ISSUE
description: DETROIT, July 17  The United Automobile Workers, attempting to head off the auto industry's efforts to limit its outlay for medical care, urged the manufacturers today to sup port Governmentpaid medical insurance.

title: Winifred Coddington Bride on L.I.
description: GREAT NECK, L. L. July 17Miss Winifred Lanier Coddington and Wray Lan don 3d were married here this afternoon in All Saints Episcopal Church by the Rev. Gary E. Maier.

title: Politically Oriented Rock Fete Begins
description: Thousands of young people, many in sandals, jeans and tie dyed shirts, converged on Ran dalls Island last night for the opening of the city's first po laically oriented rock music festival.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: SUBWAYS' SAFETY A TOPIC OF DEBATE
description: Yesterday's IND subway acci dent in Brooklyn occurred at a time of accelerating debate on the safety of the subway system and increasingly harsh criticism of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that operates it.

title: Salazar Reported Improved
description: LISBON, July 17 (AP)The condition of Antonio de Oli veira Salazar, the former Por tuguese dictator, was improved today after a quiet night, in formed sources reported. Press reports said he had regained consciousness and was able to take light nourishment. The former premier, who is 81, has lived in seclusion since suffer ing a stroke in 1968.

title: Marines Join a Big Sweep Near Danang
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 18  (AP) Some 1,500 United States marines have joined 5,000 South Vietnamese soldiers in one of two sweeps southwest of Danang in northern South Vietnam, the United States command announced today.

title: 2 IN KANSAS CITY JAILED IN KILLING
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 17 (AP)  Firstdegree murder charges were filed today against two Negro men accused of the shotgun slaying of a Kansas City Negro political leader, State Representative Leon M. Jordan.

title: U.S. URBAN LEAGUE TO OPEN MEETING
description: The National Urban League will begin its 60th annual con ference today, calling together supporters of the national hu man rights organization from various parts of the country to map its strategies for the nineteenseventies.

title: Stage: Hedda in London
description: LONDON, July 17Maggie Smith constitutes one of the pleasanter duties in the lives of contemporary drama crit ics. At periodic intervals never too frequentwe are called upon to witness some new extension of her art, and gratefully, if feebly, to stretch our inadequate vo cabularies in her praise.

title: Joan Stolarz Plans To Marry Sept. 19
description: UPPER SADDLE RIVER, N. J., July 17Mr. and Mrs. Walter Stolarz have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Stolarz, to George H. Reese 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reese Jr. of Norwalk, Conn. The wedding is planned for Sept. 19.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Baseball is a little more than halfway through its sec ond season of divisional play in the major leagues. The new setup has proved so successful so quickly that not single bleat is heard any longer against this radical inno vation, adopted two years ago amid much grumbling and prediction of disaster.

title: Gov. Ray to Head Panel
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, July 17 (AP)Gov. Robert Ray will head a panel discussion on the reorganization of state govern ment at the Midwestern Gover nors Conference at Columbus, Ohio, July 22. Appearing with Mr. Ray, a Republican, will be two other Republican Gover nors, Harold LeVander of Min nesota and Edgar D. Whitcomb of Indiana.

title: AUDIENCE RESPONDS TO LES McCANN BAND
description: Rhythm is Les McCann's businessjazz with a strong gospelbased beat. On Thursday night, as part of the Jazz in the Garden series at the Museum of Modern Art, Mr. McCanns quartet poured out its rhythm with such communicative joy that they had the whole garden rockine and clannine.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION

title: U.S. and Mexico Sign Pact for Return of Stolen Art
description: MEXICO CITY, July 17The United States and Mexico to day signed a treaty designed to protect archeological monu ments, colonial churches and historical archives from thieves of antiquities.

title: Paul Harvey Says Agnew Will Take His Job for Day
description: WASHINGTON, July 17, (AP) Paul Harvey, the radio com mentator, said today that Vice President Agnew had agreed to take his job for a day in partial fulfillment of an Agnew am bition.

title: Strong Quake Hits Aleutians
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) A strong earthquake hit the Andreanos group of the Aleu tian Islands tonight, the Na tional Earthquake Information Center reported. A spokesman said the center of the quake, measuring 6.3 on the Richter scale, was 90 miles off the is land of Adak, where there is an American naval base.

title: ORGAN GROUP ENDS ACTIVE GATHERING
description: Mighty Wurlitzers, great and small, have been playing almost around the clock in the New York metropolitan area for the last week as 800 rep resentatives of the American Theater Organ Society happily devoted themselves to 23 or gan recitals and demonstra tions.

title: BANKS' MONEY FLOW IMPROVES IN MONTH
description: The nation's savings banks continued to show improved money flows last month as a result of a decline in net with drawals coupled with the nor mal high amount of interest credlted, the National Associa tion of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

title: President vs. CooperChurch
description: From the time of the framing of the Constitution it has been the generally accepted view of the American system of checks and balances that the President proposes, the Congress disposes. Curiously, for a man who has served in both houses of the legislative branch, President Nixon appears to favor a much narrower interpretation of the role of Congress.

title: Bridge
description: The Fun City Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Associa tion will continue today at the New York Hilton, with the Open Pairs scheduled at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. The final event will be the Mixed Pairs tomorrow at 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.

title: Nationwide Insurance Elects
description: The Nationwide Insurance Companies yesterday named Robert A. Rennie as investment vice president, effective Sept. 1, to succeed J. C. Beall, senior vice president, who will retire.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: *Apprentice.

title: BALLET THEATER IN LABOR ACCORD
description: American Ballet Theater and its dancers have agreed on a threeyear contract providing for increases in wages and bene fits ranging up to 61 per cent.

title: U.N. Youth Assembly Comes to Tumultuous Ending
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17The World Youth As sembly came to a noisy and tumultuous ending tonight after approving a message that re flected the political themes that had dominated and fre quently disrupted its nineday session.

title: Army Engineers Call for Steps To Extend the Seaway Season
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)  Yeararound operation of the St. Lawrence Seaway is technically possible but of du bious economic merit, the Army Corps of Engineers has deter mined in a fiveyear study.

title: ROGERS GIVES SCHEEL BACKING ON POLICIES
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (Reu ters)Foreign Minister Walter Scheel of West Germany won United States endorsement to day of his Government's at tempts to negotiate a non aggression pact with the Soviet Union and of its policy seeking normal relations with Eastern Europe.

title: PROPANE GAS TANKER BURNS AT L.I.R. SIDING
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Saturday, July 18Five workmen were injured late last night when tank car containing propane gas being moved by the Long Island Railroad exploded and caught fire, police said.

title: PAUL DAUBE
description: Paul Daube, known affection ately to sports figures as the Dutchman, died Thursday at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a long illness He was 77 years old and lived at 833 Courtlandt Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Challenge Facing City's New Chancellor
description: New York City, since its con solidation in 1898, has had nine Superintendents of Schools and numerous Acting Superintend ents, including two within the last year. But no previous school head had to face a chal lenge of the magnitude that will confront Dr. Harvey B. Scribner when he takes over as Chancellor (the new designa tion for Superin tendent) on Sept. 1. Dr. Scribner, who has been Vermont's Edu cation Commissioner Tor the last twoandahalf years, will have the responsibility for ad miiistering the 1.1millionpupil city systemthe nation's larg estas it begins its first year of decentralized operation.

title: Black Arrow II Posts Victory For Mackenzie at Larchmont
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 17  In the words of Donald Mackenzie, who won in the International OneDesign Class in today's Larchmont Race Week sailing, in these norther lies, racing is like shuffling deck of cards. The one who is in the right place in the shuffle sets to be the winner.

title: 9 Earlier Accidents Laid To Driver in Bus Crash
description: The driver of a chartered bus in which seven children died Wednesday in a Pennsylvania highway accident had a driving record that included nine auto mobile accidents, the police said yesterday.

title: New Stock Issues In Market Achieve Modest Recovery
description: The strong stock market rally in the last three trading days this week spilled over a bit into the newissue market producing what one trader de scribed as the first substantial reaction we've seen after many months of listless activi ty, declining prices and a dearth of new offerings.

title: ZIOBRO CAPTURES JERSEY OPEN GOLF
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., July 17 ly Ziobro of Ash Brook, a 121yearold senior at the Uni versity of Maryland, won the New Jersey Golf Association's 50th open championship today after a tough battle against Tom Ulozas, the Bamm Hollow professional.

title: $106,400 in Store for the Victor In Hollywood Park Race Today
description: The big money on today's thoroughbred racing program will go to the winner of the $163,900 Hollywood Juvenile Championship at Hollywood Park, Inglewood, Calif.

title: Stock Prices Firm on London Board
Girl Is Slain in Chicago Hotel; Roommate Is Seriously Slashed
description: CHICAGO, July 17 (UPI) An unidentified man slashed the throats of two California girls last night, killing one and leaving the other critically wounded and unable to speak. The attacks took place in the Palmer House where the girls were attending a convention of JapaneseAmericans.

title: ACQUITTAL IS UPHELD FOR 3 IN DETROIT RIOT
description: LANSING, Mich., July 17 (AP)  The Michigan Supreme Court dismissed conspiracy charges against two former De troit policemen and a Negro private guard today in connec tion with the Algiers Motel in cident of the 1967 Detroit riot.

title: COMSAT REPORTS RISE IN EARNINGS
description: The Communications Satel lite Corporation (Comsat) re ported yesterday gains in rev enues and net income for this year's second quarter and first half.

title: Africa: Lessons of a Decade
description: More than a dozen countries of black Africa are observing this year the tenth anniversary of their independence, but two of themthe Congo and Nigeriaare likely to receive almost all the attention.

title: Market Place
description: Judging from comments by observers in the mutual fund industry, not everyone agrees with the method used by one certified public accountant to measure the success of his personal mutual fund holding.

title: Article 2  No Title
Soviet Planes Head for Peru
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 17 (Canadian Press)Five So viet cargo planes, en route to Peru with relief supplies for earthquake victims, made sched uled refuelling stops here today.

title: Nasser Back in Cairo
description: CAIRO, July 17  President Nasser returned from Moscow this afternoon from his 18day visit to the Soviet Union. this afternoon from his 18day visit to the Soviet Union.

title: Dum Spiro Spero...
description: . . . which is to say, While there's life, there's hope. The article by Vice President Agnew that was pub lished in our Topics column last Saturday contained so much good sense that we freely commend it to any one, particularly Mr. Agnew himself, as a guide for the conduct of public discourse. The national climate can only be improved by general agreement to dif ferentiate between the kind of division that embitters and negates, and the division that encourages intel ligent debate.

title: ABORTION REFUSAL IS MADE TEST CASE
description: Presbyterian Hospital was di rected by a Federal Court judge yesterday to explain why it re fused to let a doctor on its staff perform an abortion on an unmarried 18yearold girl who did not have her parents' consent.

title: POLLUTION CODE URGED BY HICKEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel said today that the growing drive to clean up the environment did not have to become a dogeat dog struggle between industry and conservation.

title: Rindt and Brabham Get Top Spots Today In British Grand Prix
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, July 17 (Reuters)Jochen Rindt of Austria collected an award of 100 bottles of champagne for being the fastest driver in practice today for the British Grand Prix tomorrowand then found a rival claimant.

title: Dummy Cabs Part Of New Police Plan Against Taxi Crime
description: Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday that at least 50 policemen would start cruising the streets soon in dummy taxicabs as part of a new drive by the Police Department to cut down on crimes against taxi drivers.

title: Thieu and Lon Nol Confer in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 17  President Nguyen Van Thieu and Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam of South Viet nam visited Cambodia today and met for nearly two hours with Cambodia's three top leaders.

title: Miss America Candidate
description: OLEAN, N.Y., July 17 (AP) Katherine Jean Karlsrud, 18 years old, of Mamaroneck, was chosen tonight to represent New York State in the Miss America pageant in Atlantic City next month.

title: STANLEY WILSON, 53, TVFILM COMPOSER!
description: ASPEN, Colo., July 17Stan ley Wilson, head of creative activities at the music depart ment of Universal City Studios, died Sunday, apparently of heart attack, a day after ad dressing the Aspen Music Festi val on motionpicture theme music. He was 53 years old.

title: British Dock Strike Is His Problem
description: LONDON, July 17Al though only No. 11 in the Cabinet hierarchy, Robert Carr has been thrust by the national dock strike into the front of the Conservative Government's first major test.

title: Blast Near Bronx Club
description: A small explosive device went off on the steps near an Italian American social club at 4557 Third Avenue, the Bronx, at 2:30 A.M. yesterday, causing slight property damage.

title: Susan Mary Byrne To Become Bride
description: WESTBURY, L. I.. July 17 Mr. and Mrs. William F. X. Byrne have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Susan Mary Byrne, to John Francis Picciano, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank E. Pic ciano of New Hyde Park. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: R. A. Vitale to Wed Ellen Abrams
description: The engagement of Miss Ellen Louise Abrams to Rich ard Albert Vitale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cesar B. Vitale of Wallingford, Conn., has been announced by the prospec tive bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Abrams of New York.

title: Vietnam Prisoner Torture Described by U. S. Doctor
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 An American woman doctor said today that she had treated the victims of beatings and tor ture inflicted in a South Viet namese interrogation center that had an American adviser.

title: ACQUITTAL DENIED IN ADDONIZIO CASE
description: TRENTON, July 17After a day of legal argument by law yers defending Hugh J. Addo nizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other men charged with extortion conspiracy, United States District Judge George H. Barlow denied more than 40 defense motions for a directed acquital or a mistrial.

title: 7 Students Given Jail Terms In Voorhees College Roting
description: BAMBERG, S.C., July 17 (UPI) Seven Voorhees College stu dents, convicted yesterday of rioting in the armed takeover of the predominantly black cam pus last year, were sentenced today to prison terms of 18 to 24 months.

title: PUSEY IS HOPEFUL UNREST WILL EBB
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  While serious campus problems will surely continue next fall, there are encouraging signs of new student resistance to vio lence, Nathan M. Pusey, pres ident of Harvard University, told the President's Commis sion on Campus Unrest today.

title: COURT SAYS CITY HAS RIGHT TO ACT IN HOUSING STRIKE
description: Appellate Division Justice Emilio Nunez yesterday gave the city back its power to re store services in emergency situations in the apartment strike. He vacated a State Su preme Court order that had stopped such action pending a trial.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in the war in Southeast Asia:

title: DR. C. B. JOLLIFFE, A RADIO PIONEER, 75
description: OLNEY, Md., July 17Dr. Charles Byron Jolliffe, who had worked for a quarter century as a pioneer in radio and elec tronics, died yesterday here at the age of 75.

title: ElTronics Sues Muscat
description: DEFIANCE, Ohio, July 17 (UPI)ElTronics, Inc., which acquired Defiance Industries Inc., from Victor Muscat of New York last year, has filed suit in Federal court for $6mil lion in compensatory and puni tive damages against Mr. Muscat and his associates, Ed ward Krock and Richard Scholtz. ElTronics already has collected $4.4million in dam ages from Mr. Muscat and an other associate, Robert L. Huf fines, growing out of the Mus cat group's operations while it was in control of the Defiance Industries.

title: 2 SHOOT 69'S, SHARE WOMEN'S GOLF LEAD
