description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 17 (UPI)  Jan Ferraris shot six birdies and Mrs. Jo Ann Carner four today as they shared a one stroke lead with 69's in the ??20.000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association Jaycee open at the end of the first round.

title: Mayo Quits Nixon's Staff for Federal Reserve Job
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  I Robert P. Mayo resigned today las a counselor to President Nix on, barely a month after he was named to the post in a Cabinet shuffle. He will beoome presi dent of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago on July 29.

title: CURBS CONTINUED ON PAY BY PENNSY
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 17  Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court here con tinued for 60 days an order he had signed last Friday re straining the Penn Central Transportation Company from paying any officer or employe, except those in active, full time employment, with assigned duties more than $50,000 a year.

title: RANKIN TO DIRECT POLICE PAY CASE
description: The head of the city's law office was given personal re sponsibility yesterday for an appeal of a decision on police men's pay that could cost the city $200million.

title: SHIFT M EMPHASIS SEEN IN COMECON
description: BUDAPEST, July 17  Pro found changes are taking place in the economic relations of the Communist countries as a re sponse, in part, to efforts to create one giant trading bloc out of Western Europe.

title: Beck Chief Resigns
description: Beck Industries, Inc., which I last week found itself unable to complete a proposed public offering of $15million of con vertible debentures, announced yesterday that Charles F. Mc Devitt has resigned as pres ident and chief executive of ficer.

title: $58.20 FILLY WINS IN AQUEDUCT MILE
description: A New England campaigner  with side trips to New Jer sey and Florida  made her mark on the New York circuit yesterday.

title: Australia Wins Gold Medal in Swim
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 17 (AP)Mike Wenden pow ered Australia's 400meter free style relay team to the first swimming gold medal today in the ninth British Common wealth Games after a contro versy over lane positions.

title: L.I. Car Races Called Off
description: The New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America has canceled a program of National sportscar races that had been scheduled for this weekend at Bridgehampton, (L. I.) Race Cir cuit. The course was severely damaged by heavy rains Wednesday night and Thursday morning.

title: Roundup: Clemente's Arm, Bat Give Reds Neck Pains
description: When Roberto Clemente arrived in Cincinnati last Tuesday, he was angry. Now Cincinnati can be angry with him.

title: ChichesterClark in London
description: LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) Northern Ireland's Prime Min ister, Maj. James Chichester Clark, and his Minister of Home Affairs, Robert Porter, con ferred today with British Home Secretary Reginald Maudling. Earlier Major ChichesterClark called at 10 Downing Street for a brief talk with Prime Minister Heath.

title: BODY OF WOMAN, 75, FOUND IN APARTMENT
description: The body of a 75yearold woman, her hands tied with wire, was found dead yester day in her ransacked coop apartment at 500 Grand Street on the Lower East Side.

title: Goldberg and Ottinger Win Backing of Electrical Union
description: The International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers yesterday announced its endorsement of Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor and Richard L. Ottinger for United States Senator. Both are Dem ocratic candidates.

title: Waterways Group Starts Concert Series Tomorrow
description: The American Waterways Wind Orchestra will open a se ries of free concerts played on barges tomorrow night on the Hudson just below the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: EMIL BROMBERG
description: Emil Bromberg, the retired circulation and production man ager of The Jewish Daily For ward, died last night at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tar rytown, N.Y. He was 84 years old and lived at 3816 Cypress Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: DAYAN 2D CHOICE IN WESTBURY RACE
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 17 Selecting Une de Mai of France to win tomorrow night's $125, 000 International Trot at Roo sevelt Raceway hardly belongs under the heading of a dare devil pick.

title: U.S. and Soviet Press Studies of a Colder Arctic
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are mounting largescale investigations to de termine why the Arctic climate is becoming more frigid, why parts of the Arctic sea ice have recently become ominously thicker and whether the extent of that ice cover contributes to the onset of ice ages.

title: Topics: Vietnam History May Help
description: Our nonvictory in Vietnam will be easier to accept if we can see it in a meaningful his torical context. Without some sense of background, our ac tivities there seem to go on in a vacuum, for no adequate rea sons, and we fill this void of understanding by bringing in slogans and alleging motives from other times and places.

title: Executive Changes
description: Ludlow Miller has been appointed vice president and director of sales for the sugar division of the National Sugar Refining Company, it was an nounced yesterday.

title: DR. CALVITT CLARKE; LED CHILDREN'S FUND
description: RICHMOND, July 17 (AP) Dr. J. Calvitt Clarke, a founder of the Christian Children's Fund, Inc., and former director of various international child welfare organizations, died to day in a hospital here. He was 83 years old.

title: Mrs. Edward P. Alker, 80, Dies; A Breeder and Exhibitor of Dogs
description: Mrs. Ernestine Sierck Alker, a noted dog breeder and ex hibitor for more than 40 years, died Thursday at Doctors Hos pital. Mrs. Alker, who was 80 years old, suffered a stroke on June 6 at the Greenwich (Conn). Kennel Club show. She was the widow of Edward P. Alker, banker and yachtsman who died in 1938.

title: Overseas Airways Sells DutyFree Items Aloft
description: A good Swiss watch sells for about $12 and a fifth of Scotch or a carton of cigar ettes for $3 on charter group flights of Overseas National Airways.

title: Senseless Killing
description: The murder of former President Aramburu of Argen tina is one of the most revoltingand most baffling of the current epidemic of terrorist acts in Latin America. It requires a diseased mind to conjure any connection between the shooting of a defenseless 67yearold retired general and the advancement of revolutionary ideals.

title: Fireworks and a Party Cap Royal Pair's Busy Day
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 18  There were fire works at midnight at the White House for a real and dazzling prince and princess in a party setting that was vintage Walt Disney.

title: U.S. and Agency Bonds
How to Do Something About Crime
description: The first significant legislative fruit of the 1968 Nixon cam paign talk about crime is the District of Columbia crime bill, just emerged from a House Senate conference. Among other things it would empower judges to detain accused men in prison, before trial, on suspicion that they might commit other crimes if released on bail; it would in troduce harsher minimum and mandatory sentences; it would allow the use of evidence ob tained by police intrusion into homes without the usual warn ings.

title: Tiriac Upsets Smith in 3 Sets; Nastase, Ashe and Richey Gain
description: WASHINGTON, July 17At home with heavy duty balls, clay courts and hot weather, Rumania's Davis Cup duo of Ilie Nastase and Ion Tiriac reached the semifinal round today of the $35,000 Washing ton International tennis cham pionships.

title: AIRPORT SETS UP HIJACKER SCREEN
description: NEW ORLEANS. July 17 (UPI)A system designed to de tect potential airplane hijack ers went into operation today tat New Orleans International Airport.

title: Article 1  No Title
Goldberg Held Uninformed On Environmental Matters
description: ALBANY, July 17The chair man of the Joint Legislative Committee on Environmental Management and Natural Re sources charged today that Ar thur Goldberg, the Democratic candidate for Governor, has an appalling lack of knowledge about environmental problems.

title: 100 Students in Saigon Battle Police and Liberate 3 Leaders
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (Reuters) About 100 students battled 30 policemen today and recaptured three of their leaders seized during a protest meeting.

title: Cunningham Work Bows at Festival In Connecticut
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 17The cutting edge of James Cunningham's choreographic sense is irony. He looks for and sees correspondences be tween the characters in Swan Lake, Hindu mythology and those of a primitive society prancing around a gilded niermache calf. Tonight at the American Dance Festival at CVonnecticut College here, he presented the premiere of The Junior Birdsmen. No one who saw it will ever look at Swan Lake with quite the same eyes again. American Dance Festival at CVonnecticut College here, he presented the premiere of The Junior Birdsmen. No one who saw it will ever look at Swan Lake with quite the same eyes again.

title: CHIEFS DOUBTFUL OF FACING STARS
description: Another week of impasse in the pro football labor dispute will imperil the participation of the Kansas City Chiefs in the College AllStar Game on. July 31, Hank Stram, the Chiefs' coach, said yesterday.

title: DR. D. T. NILES, 62, A CHURCH LEADER
description: The Rev. Dr. D. T. Niles, a major Christian leader in Asia for three decades and one of the six current presidents of the World Council of Churches, died yesterday in Vellore, In dia, at the age of 62.

title: Monmouth Jockeys
29 CIVILIANS INJURED BY GRENADE IN GAZA
description: JERUSALEM, July 17A hand grenade thrown at a civilian bus in Gaza this morning ex ploded in the street and injured 29 pedestrians, the Israeli mili tary spokesman announced.

title: Giant Staff Spends Another Day Drilling Rookies With Kindness
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 17The beaches must have been extra crowded this gorgeous afternoon after the Giants called off their sec ond workout.

title: CHICAGO SNIPING KILLS 2 POLICEMEN
description: CHICAGO, July 17 (UPI) Two policemen were killed to night by sniper fire, apparently directed from a highrise pub lic housing building on Chi cago's Near North Side.

title: HIGH COURT RULING ON MILITARY ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP), The Supreme Court has been asked to rule on an appeal challenging the power of United States military courts to try servicemen for crimes commit ted overseas.

title: Austin Gets Lombardi Reins
description: CARLISLE, Pa., July 17 (UPI) Vince Lombardi, recuperating from surgery, designated an as sistant, Bill Austin, as interim coach of the Washington Red skins, until Lombardi, the head coach, resumes full duties. Lom bardi, convalescing at home in Washington, said die would go to the Redskins' preseason camp here when the playerowner dis pute is settled and the team's veterans report to camp.

title: United Nuclear Corp. Foresees A Rise in Need for Power Plants
description: Despite delays in the actual construction of nuclear power plants, nothing has changed our belief that ultimately nu clear electric power is going to grow tremendously and that these delay problems will be resolved, David F. Shaw, pres ident of the United Nuclear Corporation, told 100 stock holders at yesterday's annual meeting in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: OFFICERS SHIFTED BY ADM. ZUMWALT
description: WASHINGTON, July 17(AP) Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the new Chief of Naval Opera tions, has begun bringing in his men at the top.

title: So a Man Can Wear Art on His Sleeve
description: Although any number of witty designers are involved in women's costume jewelry, things have been pretty quiet in the men's field. Short of in heriting his grandfather's sap phires or of haunting antiques shops, a man hasn't had much choice about cuff links, for instance. Well, there's hope. A comparatively new company Shop called Off the Talk Cuff is changing things. The con cern, which is headed by Harold Schulman (who used to own Canterbury Belts) has all sorts of refresh ing ideas about cuff links and tie clasps.

title: Joyce Mart Is Fiancee Of Mark A. Dudelson
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK, LI., July 17Miss Joyce Michelle Mart and Mark Andrew Du delson will be married Aug. 29 at Temple Israel in Great Neck.

title: Alcohol Tax is Suggested As Source for Road Safety
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)  The National Safety Council suggested today that the drink ing man be forced to help pay for highway safety programs.

title: ZICARELLI FACES U.S. TAX CHARGE
description: NEWARK, July 17Joseph (Joe Bayonne) Zicarelli, reputed Mafia captain in North Jersey, had an income of more than $1million in 1967 and 1968, it was charged in an indictment for income tax evasion on which he was arraigned in absentia in Federal Court here today.

title: Comments on Spiro Agnew Topics Column
description: To the Editor:

title: BUILDINGS OFFICIAL RESIGNS CITY POST
description: The top city officials who ga ther in the Mayor's weekly Cab inet meetings learned at yes terday's session that one of their number, Buildings Com missioner John T. O'Neil, was leaving his post.

title: 13 Starters in Irish Oaks
description: DUBLIN, Ireland, July 17 (Reuters)Thirteen horses were listed to start here in tomor row's Irish Guinness Oaks Classic. First prize is worth $49,130. The race for 3year old fillies will be run over 1 miles at the Curragh track.

title: Bob Montgomery, 45, Dies; Broadcaster of Auto Races
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., July 17 (AP)  Bob Montgomery, long time radio broadcaster of stock car races, died today at a Greensboro hospital at the age of 45.

title: Insurance Talks End
description: Merger talks between the Richmond Corporation and the North American Life and Casu alty Company have been ended, according to a joint announce ment from Minneapolis yester day. Spokesmen said that a detailed exploration of the plan disclosed that the originally anticipated advantages to both companies could not be real ized to the extent necessary to justify the affiliation.

title: RALLY CONTINUES; DOW IS UP BY 11.64
description: The stock market rally con tinued in high gear yesterday with several key indicators posting their biggest gains of the week.

title: Riders Injured in Subway Crash Tell of Confusion and Darkness
description: Fourteenyearold Alvin Paige and his friend, Ernest Brooks, 15, took the A train home from a day on the sunny beaches and boardwalk at Coney Island yes terday. Suddenly, at the Hoyt Schermerhorn station, Alvin said, There was this big crash.

title: Violence Over a New Capital Flares Again in Italian City
description: REGGIO DI CALABRIA,. Italy, July 17 (Reuters)The police used tear gas today to disperse stonethrowing dem onstrators in the fourtla con secutive day of viole?? over selection of a regional capital.

title: Device Aids Weightless Space Movements
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 The Serpentuator, a long, snake  like instrument, can move men and tools under weightless conditions around a space station. Hans F.

title: 37 HURT IN CRASH OF TWO IND TRAINS
description: At least 37 people were hurt yesterday when a Manhattan bound E train on the IND line rammed the back of a halted A train near the Hoyt Schermerhorn station in Brook lyn.

title: Senate Votes Housing Measure To Underwrite 7% Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The Senate aproved today a major housing bill that its chief sponsor said could stimulated construction of 1.3 million new homes and provide loans to underwrite $30billion in mort gages.

title: Personal Income Declined in June
description: Personal income declined last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $798.8billion from, $799.8 billion in May, the Com merce Department reported yesterday.

title: MRS. DANIEL J. MOONEY
description: CEDARHURST, L.I., July 17 Mrs. Florence Shannon Mooney, widow of Daniel J. Mooney, cor porate lawyer and one of the founders of the Lawyers Trust Company in New York who was a close friend of the late Alfred E. Smith, died in her sleep at the Rockaway Hunting Club here yesterday. She was 80 years old and lived at 1009 Park Avenue, New York, and at the club for the summer.

title: Miles Davis's Home Is a Study in Curves
description: The sound of Miles Davis's tape recorded trumpet washed over the darkened living room, and Miles Davis. in his stockinged feet, half tripped, half danced across the thick, woolly, wall towall carpeting and eased himself onto the circular couch, illuminated beneath by bare orange bulbs.

title: Kekkonen Visiting Soviet
description: MOSCOW, July 17 (Reuters) President Urho Kekkonen of Finland arrived here today on a fourday official visit. The 69 yearold President is scheduled to pay a visit to Washington a few days after his stay here. He has been a regular visitor to Moscow.

title: Frank Mathews, 64, Aide With Shipping Line Here
description: Frank H. Mathews, executive assistant to the vice president of operations of Farrell Lines, Inc., died in George Washing ton University Hospital in Washington Thursday of a heart attack while attending a meet ing. He was 64 years old.

title: PARKER DELIVERS SINGLE WITH 3 ON
description: LOS ANGELES, July 17 The New York Mets lost their fifth game in a row tonight, and fell 21/2 games out of first place, when Wes Parker's sin gle in the 10th inning gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 10 vic tory.

title: Teamsters Lose Election
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks has defeated the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in a representation election among Railway Express employes, the National Media tion Board said today. The vote was 10,074 to 6,077, with 20,598 voters eligible. The victorious union has represented the em ployes for many years.

title: SCHOOL ABSENTEEISM IS LINKED TO GANGS
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 17 Juvenile gang terrorism keeps 30 to 40 per cent of the stu dents absent daily from some public high schools here, Congressional committee was told today.

title: SENATE CHIEFS ASK CRIME BILL ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) The Senate leaders of both parties cautioned their col leagues today against delaying passage of a District of Colum bia crime control bill that op ponents contend tramples on constitutional rights.

title: ELECTRONIC SENSORS ON MEXICAN BORDER
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Justice Department is employ ing the electronic sensors developed to detect enemy movements in South Vietnam in its own war against narcotics smuggling and illegal entries on the Mexican border, a de partment spokesman said to night.

title: Saigon Units in Cambodia Now Playing G.I.'s Role
description: KREK, Cambodia, July 14 A fourday tour of South Viet namese positions along the bor der in Cambodia reveals strik ing similarities between the South Vietnamese role here and the role of United States forces in South Vietnam during the first years after the 1965 build up.

title: GLENN D. THOMPSON
description: CHATHAM, N. J., July 17 Glenn D. Thompson; an assist ant vice president in the Munici pal Bond department of the brolcerage firm of Loeb Rhoades & Co., died yesterday at the age of 62. He resided at 6 Whitman Drive here.

title: Mitchell Promises Vigorous Defense Of VoteAge Suit
description: WASHLNGTON, July 17 (AP)  Pledging to defend fully and vigorously the Congres sional act lowering the voting age to 18, Attorney General John N. Mitchell began today the Government's part in a suit that may bring a swift constitutional test of the new Voting Rights Law.

title: Dynamite Found on Tracks of West Side Freight Line
description: Eleven and a half sticks of dynamite, without detonators, were found by a trainman at 2 P.M. yesterday at 153d Street and 12th Avenue near the freighttrain tracks of the Penn Central Transportation Com pany.

title: Truck Strike Cited
BRANDON J. DODD
description: Brandon J. Dodd, who retired in 1954 as treasurer of Douglas Leigh, Inc., outdoor advertising specialists, died Wednesday in Colorado Springs, where he lived. He was 85 years old.

title: Dividends Announced
Charles Larsen, 84, Dies; Head of a Baking Company
description: Charles E. Larsen, president of the Larsen Baking Company, Inc., of Brooklyn, who was made a Knight of the Order of St. Olaf of Sweden in 1934 for his philanthropies, died Wednesday in the Rivercrest Rest Home in Wappinger Falls, N. Y. He was 84 years old and lived in the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn.

title: SANDERS, ON 148, FAILS TO QUALIFY
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., July 17  Billy Casper, the Masters charrfpion, said he struggled to tie for 17th place in the British Open last week, but today he scored a 67 to lead the $150,000 Philadelphia Golf Classic with a 36hole total of 135.

title: Plumber Discounts His Paper Victory Over Inflation
description: CHICAGO, July 17Dick Martin, a 32yearold con struction worker, is one of a small number of American hourly wage earners whose incomes have kept them ahead of inflation in the last year or so. But he finds little consolation in that.

title: Torture Is Described at Panther Trial in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, July 17Over defense objections, a statement was admitted into evidence in the trial of Lonnie McLucas to day in which a fellow Black Panther told the police about Ithe torture of a suspected informer in the basement of the nartv's headauarters here.

title: Monte Carlo Needs Fewer Memories, More Tourists
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, July 11Just outside the Monte Carlo Casino the sun is shining down upon the massed ranks of vintage cars, all gleaming bravely, all carrying their nostalgic mes sage of time past.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEES TRADE WAR IN BILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The White House said today that the trade bill being written by the House Ways and Means Committee held the danger of inviting a trade war.

title: F.P.C. WEIGHS RISE IN RATES FOR GAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The Federal Power Commis sion announced plans today for, a legal proceeding aimed at enabling it to put into effect) by early fall a nationwide, temporary increase in th?? prices that can be charged by producers of natural gas.

title: French Mare Is Prime Contender for New Harness Trophy at Westbury
DempseyTegeler Selling Offices in Four More Cities
description: The Rauscher Pierce Securi ties Corporation said yesterday it had agreed to acquire the Kansas City office of Dempsey Tegeler & Company, the bro kerage concern that disclosed Thursday it would suspend operations.

title: Publishers Reach Pact With Mailers
description: A shutdown of The Daily News and The New York Times was averted yesterday when the Mailers Union and publishers reached agreement in principle on a new contract shortly be fore a strike deadline.

title: Antiques: About Glass and Bubbles
description: Not all glass with bubbles is old, but it is hard to find a collector who would be satis fied knowing that a hand some blue pitcher with bub bles he treasures was made near Wheeling, W. Va., three years ago.

title: ALBERT EMELSTHORPE
description: Albert E. Gelsthorpe of New London, Conn., formerly of Chappaqua, N.Y., a retired ad vertising man, died yesterday in the Westerly (R.I.) Hospital.

title: U.S. Assumes the Israelis Have ABomb or Its Parts
description: WASHINGTON, July 17For at least two years the United States Government has been conducting its Middle East policy on the assumption that Israel either possesses an atomic bomb or has component parts available for quick as sembly, reliable sources report.

title: Washington: For the Record
Bath Says Bid Was Lowest
description: BATH, Me., July 17 (UPI) The Bath Iron Works Division of Bath Industries, Inc., of Mil waukee said yesterday it was low bidder on a $51million project to build three commer cial containerships for Ameri can Export Isbrandtsen Lines.

title: JACKSON NEGROES CALL OFF STRIKE
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 17 Black municipal workers here voted late last night to end their strike against the city and to return to their jobs on Mon day.

title: Metropolitan Clarifies Rule On Change for Exhibitions
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art clarified yesterday its four week, experimental payas youwish policy for visitors to special exhibitions. Each visitor to the museum's current spe cial show, Masterpieces of Paintings From the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, must pay something to get in, although the amount is left up to the in dividual.

title: A Question of Labor or Leisure
description: WELLESLEY ISLAND, N.Y., July 17On this tranquil and remote dot on the map in the St. Lawrence River, members of a legislative committee are winding up five days of dis cussions on New York State's election law.

title: JOHN R. MINTER
description: MARION, Mass., July 17 (AP) John R. Minter, a former For eign Service officer and United Nations official, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 76.

title: Graham Says He Went To a Marijuana Party
description: TOKYO, July 17 (AP)The Afnerican evangelist, Dr. Billy Graham, said at a news con ference here today: I have taken part in a marijuana smoking party in the United States despite criticisms against it.

title: Nixon Approves $1 Million In Added Aid for Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) President Nixon has formally approved another $1million in United States arms aid to Cam bodia, bringing the total so far to nearly $9million, the State Department disclosed today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JULY 18, 1970

title: Article 3  No Title
Production of Cars Declined This Week
description: DETROIT, July 18 (AP)  With automakers shutting down some operations for their an nual model changeover, United States auto production fell to 118,090 this week, from 149, 856 last week.

title: Graybeard First to Finish Record Pacific Ocean Sail
description: MAUI, Hawaii, July 17 (Ca nadian PressLol Killam's Van couver ketch, Graybeard, was the first boat to finish today in the VictoriatoMaui yacht race and set the record for elapsed time.

title: SWISS CONCERNS TOLD TO COMPETE
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Justice Department, in an un usual action, has forced two big foreign chemical companies to agree to take steps to offset the reduction of competition in the American market that would result from their merger.

title: AMEX ISSUES POST A BROAD ADVANCE
description: In an advance that was broad but not sharp, stocks on the American Stock Exchange moved up again yesterday. The index stood at 20.19 at the close, up 0.12.

title: Apartment Strike
description: As the strike of building service workers nears the end of its second week, it is exacting an ever greater toll from all affected groups.

title: Treasury Statement
BLEFARY CLOUTS HIS 100TH HOMER
description: The big inning, for which Yankee teams of bygone years were noted, reappeared twice last night at Yankee Stadium andwith Mel Stottlemyre holding the opposition offense in check with eight hitslifted the current Minibombers of the Bronx to a 71 victory over Oakland.

title: ROCKEFELLER CHIDED ON INQUIRY ON POLICE
description: Governor Rockefeller's re sponse to a request that he start an investigation of alleged corruption in the New York City Police Department was labeled inadequate and totally evasive yesterday by Adam Walinsky, the Democratic can didate for State Attorney Gen eral.

title: Szell Cancels Tour
description: CLEVELAND, July 17 (AP) George Szell, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, has can celed his European conducting dates for this summer because of illness. Mr. Szell, who is 73 years old, has been confined to University Hospitals here since midJune.

title: Doesn't Anyone Want Mickey Rooney's Blazer?
description: Two 31yearold entrepre neurs, Jeffrey Joerger, who had the food concession at the Woodstock music festi val, and Michael Make, who revived the Mickey Mouse watch 10 years ago, bought up a lot of furniture and clothes that had been used in Metro  Goldwyn  Mayer movies, with the idea that New York is a city full of movie buffs. And that those movie buffs would jump at the chance to buy these glamourdrenched relics.

title: Sing Sing Is Renamed Under New State Law
description: ALBANY, July 17 (AP) Sing Sing Prison, immortal ized in many a gangster movie of the nineteenthirties and forties, has a new name, the Ossining Correctional Facil ity, and its warden is to be known as the superintendent.

title: WEATHERLY BEATS VALIANT ON FOR
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 17 The clearest, sharpest weather of the America's Cup defense trials produced the most con fused ending today when Valiant withdrew from a race with Weatherly after fouling her trial horse rounding the last mark.

title: Anniuersaries
description: ROCKAFELLOWMae and George Rockafel low of Chadwick Beach Island, N.J., joy fully announce their 50th wedding anniver sary, July 14, 1970.

title: MASTER WILL STUDY 5TH AVE. COACH VOTE
description: Federal Judge Edward C. McLean designated Samuel C. Coleman as special master yes terday in the election of a new slate of directors for Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc. Mr. Coleman will examine the bal lots and proxies and take testi mony on challenges arising from the election of the Devon Committee slate of 10 at the annual meeting last June 15. The judge suggested that Mr. Coleman make his findings and conclusions of law and file report by Sept. 8, if possible.

title: SOVIET, UR ASK POLITICAL ACCORD IN MIDEAST STRIFE
description: MOSCOW, July 17  The Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic called today for a political settlement of the Middle East crisis.

title: American Eagle In Big Fleet For Mackinac Island Race
description: CHICAGO, July 17 (AP)  A fleet of 173, including Ameri can Eagle, America's Cup con tender in 1964 and 1967, will set sail tomorrow north on Lake Michigan in the 63d, 333mile Chicago to Mackinac Island race.

title: A Doctor Testifies on Captain's Wound
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., July 17 (AP)  A physician testified at an Army hearing today that Capt. Jeffrey MacDonald, ac cused of slaying his pregnant wife and two children, could not have stabbed himself with out running the risk of death.

title: Junior Jumper Title At Smoke Rise Won By Diamond Cutter
description: KINNELON, N. J., July 17 Brian Quinn, who never rode jumper until seven months ago, piloted Diamond Cutter to the junior jumper championship to day at the Smoke Rise Horse Show.

title: SUTURES LIFTED BY A CROP REPORT
description: A Canadian crop report, in dicating a cut in acreage, strongly influenced buying of commodity futures on the Chi cago Board of Trade yester day. Prices of soybean futures at the opening rose 3 cents a bushel, while corn futures rose 1 cents and wheat, 1 cents.

title: John Sloane, Investment Banker And New Jersey Planner, Dead
description: John Eyre Sloane, a retired investment banker and former chairman of the New Jersey Planning Board, died yesterday of a stroke in Memorial Hospi tal, Easton, Md. He was 83 years old and lived in Llewel lyn Park, West Orange, N. J., and St. Michaels, Md.

title: Books of The Times
description: Not every hook delivers what it promises in the title. This study of the poet Robert Lowell does. Enough biographical material has been included so that the reader will have something to guide by, but the at tention is on the poet: his development, the changing nature of his achievement, the opposing strengths and failures of his art. No one will come away from this book without a very graphic idea of Lowell's poetic career. The editors, who teach at Skidmore, have assembled balanc ing views. Some of the essays are full of high praise; some are fiercely critical. But with one or two excep tions, notably a piece by Joseph Bennett on Life Studies, the es says always seri ously the work. They do not depend on assertion they buttress their argument by close analysis of the text, by a pertinent knowl edge of the poet's career and of the condi tion of poetry in America today. It is ir ritating, healthily irritating, to read these essays. For whether or not the reader agrees with any single judgment, he is in the end forced to turn back to the poetry. It's a good idea in fact to have the work in front of you. You will find yourself rereading more Lowell than you had in tended.

title: JAMES W. PEASLEE, BOATING AUTHORITY
description: James W. Peaslee, founder of The Boating Industry magazine and a wellknown authority on pleasure boating, died yester day in Benton Harbor, Mich., at the age of 75.

title: Jersey Bank Merger Set
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., July 17 Agreement has been reached on a proposal for the merger of the First National Bank of Mil ford and the National State Bank of Elizabeth, it was an nounced today by Herbert D. Stem, chairman of the Milford Bank, and W. Emden Roosevelt, president of the Elizabeth bank. Directors of the banks have agreed on a plan under which the Milford bank, with $31mil lion in resources, would be bought outright with payment ??

title: THURMOND WARNS POLICY ON SCHOOLS CAN DEFEAT NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 17Sen ator Strom Thurmond struck hard and bitterly at the Ad ministration's school desegre gation efforts today, warning that such unreasonable pol icies might lead to President Nixon's defeat in 1972.

title: FREDERICK GILBERT, TINELIFE EXECUTIVE
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 17Frederick S. (Fritz) Gilbert, vice president and general man ager of TimeLife Broadcast, Inc., died here yesterday after a long illness. His age was 58.

title: In Memoriam
description: BITTERSadie. July 10. Missing you and thinking of you every day. Your loving fam ily, David, Cynthia, Jason & Robin.

title: Westmoreland Sees Chinese
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 17 (UPI) Gen. William C. Westmore land, the United States Army Chief of Staff, met for two hours today with top Chinese National ist military officials on devel opments in Southeast Asia and the Far East.

title: Educator Takes Denver Job
description: Dr. Dumont F. Kenny, who with sevenandahalf years of service as a college president was the senior president in the City University of New York, has resigned to become presi dent of Temple Buell College in Denver. Dr. Kenny joined the university in 1963 as presi dent of Queenshcirough Com munity College, and in 1966 was named the first president of York College, Flushing, Queens.

title: Burtis First in Star Class In Sea Cliff Sailing Series,
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., July 18 Alan Burtis's Guacharo beat John Siljander's Valkyrie for Star Class honors this after noon in the fourth of five races in the Sea Cliff Yacht Club's Commodore series.

title: Penn Hires ExJet Aide
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 18  (AP)  Clyde Washington, former assistant director of player personnel for the New York Jets, was named an as sistant football coach at the University of Pennsylvania to day.

title: Obote Urges Vote Reform
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 18 (AP)  President Milton Obote proposed sweeping changes in the country's electoral system yesterday, suggesting that the President be elected by univer sal suffrage with a countryside secret ballot. Under the present law, the president of the ruling political party becomes presi dent of Uganda.

title: 80Million Years of Accumulated Silence
description: ALAMOSA, Colo.From a distance, the highrise sand dunes and the snow capped peaks look as incongruous as a polar bear in the Sahara. Viewed across the vast and lonely San Luis Valley, the Great Sand Dunes National Monument is an anachronismhuge, barren and stark against a range of timberline mountains. The dunes never look quite real, and when the light plays across them in a certain way, or when a veil of snow descends, or when the wind blurs their features, they seem even less substantialand lost in the accumu lated silence of 80,000,000 years.

title: Miss Linda V. Burns Is Bride Of Stanton FitzGerald Jones
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 18The Presbyterian Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Linda Vreeland Burns to Stanton FitzGerald Jones. The Rev. Thomas S. Mutch Performed the ceremony.

title: Carriages of Yesteryear Will Be Shown at Benefit for Shaker Museum
description: OLD CHATHAM, N. Y., July 18An exhibition of Carriages of Yesteryear will be included in this year's Shaker Museum Festival, to be held on the museum grounds here from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Aug. 1. Mrs. Frederic L. Simmons is chair man of the annual event, in stituted in the summer of 1956 as a benefit for the museum.

title: COLLEGE PROGRAM REPORTS SUCCESS
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 18  A program here for sending dropouts and poorly prepared high school graduates to col lege has been evaluated as a highly successful model for sim ilar programs around the coun try.

title: YALE WILL OFFER TEACHER TRAINING
description: Yale University has an nounced that it will begin of fering academic credit this year for practice teaching in New Haven public schools. Some details of the new program, which eventually may involve as many as 100 Yale undergraduates, have yet to be completed by a special faculty committee, but school officials said it would involve both theoretical and practical work. It will probably run over a student's junior and senior years.

title: CITY WILL SWITCH ITS PENSION FUNDS
description: Within the last few days City Controller Abraham D. Beame has quietly begun a multi milliondollar shift of invest ments in the city's five pension systems.

title: Nixon's Top Economists Favor Stimulative Government Policy
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  Top economists in the Nixon Administration have concluded that the economy is in process of sagging sufficiently below the capacity of its men and machines to warrant a some what stimulative economic pol icy next year.

title: 2 Vietnam Amputees Seized With 21 Kilos of Heroin Here
description: Two Army veterans, double amputees who lost their legs while serving in Vietnam IS months ago, were arrested yes terday along with another man and a woman when six detec tives raided a Brooklyn apart ment and seized 21 kilos of heroin having an estimated re tail value of $5million.

title: Six Baskets of Flowers Put on Kopechne Grave
description: LARKSVILLE, Pa., July 18 (UPI)Six baskets of flowers were placed on the hilltop grave of Mary Jo Kopechne today from her parents, her fellow campaign workers and an anonymous sender.

title: City Rejects Ship Terminal Plan; Port Agency Agrees to Build It
description: The city has rejected a pro posal by steamship lines to build a consolidated passenger steamship terminal on the West Side. However, the Port of New York Authority has agreed to take on the task.

description: The sea doth wash away all human ills, Euripides said.

description: LOS ANGELES, July 18The New York Mets scored three runs in the ninth inning today to defeat the Los Angeles Dodg ers, 43, and end a fivegame losing streak.

title: Tinsley Captures Playoff In U.S. LeftHanclers Golf
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 18 (AP)  Richard Tinsley, who made up a fourstroke deficit on the final round to force playoff, won the National Left handers Golf Tournament today.

title: Fiji Fears Tourism But Can Hardly Wait
description: SUVA. FijiWe don't want to turn Fiji into another Hawaii. The speaker happened to be the Minister of Tourism, a plump, redfaced man named Charles Stinson, but the words could have been uttered by almost any one of the hand ful of Europeans who control the econ omy of the islands. A visitor hears this sentiment so often that before long the hollowed logs that the Fijian boys beat to announce the dinner hour at the resort hotels seem to be relaying the same message:

title: MRS. CARNER LEADS OHIO GOLF WITH 139
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 18 (AP)Mrs. JoAnne Carner, who never has led in amateur or professional golf tournaments, took the sole lead today in the $20,000 Jaycee open with a 70 for a 36hole total of 139.

title: Kindness, Boredom and Terror Mark British Patrols in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, July 14  They si?? glumly behind sandbags cra cluing machine guns and listen ing to the Supremes over tiny transistor radios. They patrol in jeeps along Falls and Shan kill Roads, both littered with barbed wire and smashed bot tles. They step nervously along empty Cunar Street.

title: Caren I. Vignos Bride in Ohio
description: GATE MILLS, Ohio, July 18Miss Caren Ingalls Vig nos was married here this afternoon to Sheldon Brad dock Sturges in St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. W. B. Gallater and the Rev. Calhoun Wick performed the ecumenical service.

title: The Irrelevance Of Being an Actor
description: RELEVANCE and bread. Comfort and commitment. I haven't stopped trying to get it together, you know, within the system. Now that the Weathermen have defined the outer limits for me with an explosive exclamation mark, I must face the fact that I like the system, by and large. It is not only that I don't want to be blown up while stepping out of the ele vator to go read for an enzymedeter gent commercial in the Pan Am building, it's also that I guess I believe in systems, generally, and I know that na matter whose it is, there will always be one. For me, it's largely a matter of how much room in the middle they give the sane ones to do their thing. To me, the theater is a sane thing. Considered in the abstract, it stands on the delicate middle ground between action and reac tion, subtly shadowing both. I remember a photograph in The Family of Man of a dead soldier, lying on his face in a ditch. He is American and the war is Korea, but he could be Viet Cong, Ibo, or Persian. The caption is from Aeschy lus, telling what is important: Who is the slayer? Who the slain? it says. This is what the theater can do.

title: Conversation makers
description: Curries are not only convenient (they can be made a day ahead and are all the better for it), but they serve as conversation pieces when presented in hollowedout pineapples or coconuts. The two curries on this page chicken baked and served in pineapples and lamb cooked in coconutsare excellent prepareahead dishes for summer.

description: ROME. LADIES and gentlemen! In the center ring! For the first time in your liv I ing room (and probably the last time, too) * * * Federico Fellini * * * directing his ONE and ONLY televi sion special! The Clowns ! ! !

title: U.S. Army Marksman Ties For First in British Shoot
description: BISLEY, England, July 18 (Reuters)Sgt. Burl Branham of the United States Army marksmanship training unit at Fort Benning, Ga., finished in a threeway tic for first place in the Donegall Cup competi tion at the National Rifle Association meeting today.

title: BIG MEAT MARKET AN ISSUE IN PARIS
description: PARIS, July 18 A $190 million white elephant has just been ridden onto the French po litical scene by the Opposition, to the Government's embar rassment.

title: Connecticut U. Head Considered For Top Federal Education Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The president of the University of Connecticut, an educator who was once a close associate of Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare, Elliot L. Richard son, is under serious consider ation to head a twoman team that would replace James E. Allen Jr. as Assistant Secretary and Commissioner of Educa tion, a department official said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor I would be very interested to learn the nature of the blatant housing violations that David Yellin complains of in his letter [June 28]. Normally when a tenant has a complaint he makes it to the Buildings Department, which is only too happy to receive it. An inspector is sent to investigate the com plaint. If he finds it justifi able, the owner of the build ing is served with a formal notice of violation.

title: Soviet Raises Farm Pay To Spur Productivity
description: MOSCOW, July 18 (UPI) The Soviet Union today announced major increases in the wholesale prices of meat, eggs, wool and milk products as part of a cam paign to increase the nation's collective farm productivity.

title: Florida Fights PollutionBulls Next
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.It may not be long before matadors and picadors in their gold brocade will be swaggering down Collins Avenue in Miami Beach, giving a practice twirl to their capes now and then. Florida has just become the first state in the Union to legalize bullfight ingthe bloodless, ceremonial type.

title: Ethical Union Sets Parley
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 18 (UPI)The International Hu manist and Ethical Union will hold its fifth congress, the first in the United States, Aug. 49 at Massachusetts Institute of Tech nology.

title: 9:02.45 RECORDED BY SWIMMER, 16
description: EDINBURGH, July 18 (AP) Karen Moras, a 16yearold Australian girl splashed to a worldrecord clocking tonight in the 800meter freestyle swimming final of the Com monwealth Games. Earlier Ian Stewart shattered a dream of Ron Clarke of Australia by win ning the 10,000meter run.

title: LINDSAY IS STRONG IN GALLUP SURVEY
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 18 Mayor Lindsay of New York has shown considerable voter appeal when matched as a Democrat against President Nixon and Gov. George C. Wal lace of Alabama in a national test election, the Gallup Poll said today.

title: LastSecond Pass Clicks
description: MIAMI, July 18 (AP)Terry Murawski'18yard touchdown pass to Art Robinson in the final seconds gave the Miami Dolphin offense a 1210 win over the defense today in a ??.

title: Miss Margaret R. Langan Wed In Greenwich to John Moore Jr.
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 18Miss Margaret Raymonde Langan and John Chester Moore Jr. were married here this noon in an almost com pletely homemade wedding, starting with the ceremony, which they wrote and which the Rev. Vincent O'Connor performed in the St. Timothy Roman Catholic Chanel.

title: Missionary's Ordeal
description: I feel a bit like Rip Van Winkle waking up after a long sleep. That was how the Most Rev. James Edward Walsh reacted last week to regaining freedom after 12 years' imprisonment in Communist China on charges of espionage and subversion. Speaking to newsmen in Hong Kong for the first time since his sudden release on July 10, the 79yearold Maryknoll missionary emphasized that he was not a spy either for the U. S. Government or the Vatican, although after 18 months of grueling interrogation by the Chinese he had signed a confession stating I may have been a spy in the legal sense of your laws. For the most part, Bishop Walsh said, he had been treated with basic human dignity and he was not hitter. After 40 years work among the Chinese, Bishop Walsh said, I could just never feel angry with any Chinese.

title: Criminals At Large
description: It is not wholly astonishing that lawyers should be well numbered among the detectives of crime fiction series, or that somelike Perry Mason or Ar thur Crook (of whom, more below) or Craig Rice's John J. Malone  should invest juris prudence with a greater flexi bility than its founders had intended. But it's a bit ironic that barrister Anthony Mait land, whose purity is exceeded only by the distrust with which the Yard regards him, should so entangle himself in Sara Woods's KNIVES HAVE EDGES (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $4.50). Maitland has a very guilty client who seems to have compounded his predicament by bribing a juror at his trial. While this affair is getting stickier, Maitland devotes a spare afternoon to a case of murder and, of these activities, Anthony's old antagonist Chief Superintendent Briggs natur ally takes the worst possible view. Here is a lively affair with a plot of some substance, though it hangs upon a device that will doubtless beetle purist brows.

title: Dance
description: MONTE CARLO. NOT so many years ago classic ballet was lim ited to a surprising ly few countries. France, of course, Russia, Denmark. It prospered fit fully in Italy, had a brief fling in Austria and was ap preciated in other countries, including Britain and the United States. But it was never indigenous to these other countries. Then things changed. Dance fell from popularity in France, and over a few brief decades Britain and the United States became major powers in the ballet world.

title: Italy Is Pressing Drive on Drugs; Americans Among Those Jailed
description: ROME, July 18  A dozen young Americans, caught in an intensified police drive against drug offenders, are now in Italian jails. Many of them were unaware of the severity of Italy's antinarcotics laws.

title: The problem of oppression, Japanesestyle
description: Dare one suggest that Korea's Richard Kimauthor of the highly acclaimed novel, The Martyredis even better at the nonfiction novel? His new book cannot really be called a book of memoirs, because the first episodein which his parents, in 1933, cross a frozen river into Man churia to escape at least some of the Japanese controloccurs before he is old enough to remember. The fact that he chooses to end his book on the day of the Japanese surrender, before Kim Hsung and his Commu nist regime assume power in Korea, suggests another way in which it is not quite a memoir. It is too selective, too carefully unified around a single theme or mood.

title: 2 Packer Rookies Quit
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., July 18 (UPI)The Green Bay Packers said today two rookies had left the Packers' preseason training camp. Bob Reinhart, a guard and ninthround draft choice who played his college football at Stanford, and an 11thround pick and a linebacker from Humboldt State, Dan Hook, left today. They plan to return to school.

title: NewOrder Index Dropped in May
description: The neworder index of the American Supply and Ma chinery Manufacturers' Asso ciation, a sensitive economic indicator, declined 3.3 points, or 1.9 per cent, to 172.7 in May from 176 in April. It also was 17.1 points or 9 per cent below the index of 189.8 for May, 1969.

title: STATE A.A.U. TRACK TAKEN BY N.Y.A.C.
description: ELMIRA, N. Y., July 18 (AP) The New York Athletic Club swept to an impressive victory today in the 10th annual New York State Amateur Athletic Union track and field cham pionships at Parker Field.

title: Religion
description: As the religion of the Logos or Word, Christianity has al ways leaned heavily on the written and printed word to spread its message. Not sur prisingly, therefore, the cur rent crisis in institutional Christianity has perhaps been most clearly visible in the faltering condition of reli gious publications.

title: L.I. Study Shows an Age Drop In Drug Arrests in One Year
description: MINEOLA. L. I. July 18A study by the Nassau County Probation Department shows that a group of people arrested in the county for drugrelated offenses in 1968 were young er, more often fulltime stu dents, more intelligent, better educated and had higher in comes and better jobs than those involved in a previous study.

title: MRS. BINH ARRIVES FOR VISIT IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, July 18Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, foreign minis ter of the Vietcong's provisional revolutionary government, land ed here today amid a raging controversy over her visit.

title: LEWISOHN TO TAKE CITY FINANCE POST
description: Richard Lewisohn, one of handful of high officials who has been with the Lindsay ad ministration since it started, was appointed Finance Admin istrator yesterday.

title: PEPITONE TO APPEAL FINE FOR BEING AWOL
description: HOUSTON, July 18 (UPI) Joe Pepitone of the Houston Astros said he was injured and could not have taken part in a team workout during the All Star break even if he had at tended.

title: Chagrin Valley Show Offers $25,000 for Open Jumpers
description: The Chagrin Valley Profes sional Horsemen's Associa tion horse show starting to morrow will offer a whopping $25,000 in prize money for the open jumper division.

title: U.S. URBAN LEAGUE TO OPEN MEETING
description: The deputy executive directori of the National Urban League estimated yesterday that 4,000 people would attend the league's 60th annual meeting beginning here today, making it the larg est civil rights forum in this nation's history.

title: Tories Assailed on Arms for South Africa
description: LONDON, July 18Britain's Conservative Government is running into heavy opposition as it seeks to reverse policies of the previous Labor Govern ment and make its own mark in South Africa and the Persian Gulf. Lesser criticism has also greeted Tory defense plans for the Far East.

title: TENANTS ASSAIL PHONE COMPANY
description: The New York Telephone Company, which has been the target recently of numerous complaints of poor service, was accused yesterday by some residents in lower Manhattan of being a bad landlord.

title: Tibbetts Takes Golf Title
description: AMHERST, N. H, July 18 (AP)Warren Tibbetts of Man chester, twotime New England amateur champion, won the 1970 New Hampshire amateur golf title today by heating Jerry Maxfield of Portsmouth on the 39th hole.

title: 1942 Cards Top'55 Dodgers In Computerized Game, 32
description: The 1942 St. Louis Cardinals edged the 1955 Brooklyn Dodg ers, 32, on Johnny Hopp's eighthinning single in a compu terized baseball game presented over NBCTV network yester day.

title: E. RAYMOND SHEERIN
description: E. Raymond Sheerin, a for mer vice president, treasurer and director of the Ingersoll Rand Company, machinery manufacturers, died Friday in BeckmanDowntown Hospital, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Favorable Reply by U.A.R. To Rogers Proposal Seen
description: CAIRO, July 18The United Arab Republic within a few days will give a favorable re ply to the proposal by Secre tary of State William P. Rogers for a ceasefire and a resump tion of peace negotiations, ac cording to an informed source.

title: Cuban Catholics Influence Miami
Extra Police and Buses Assigned to Area in Wake of Racial Clashes Near Erasmus Hall High School
description: Extra police patrols, more buses and staggered hours are among the measures adopted to Wert a repetition of racial tevissons in the East Flatbush, section of Brooklyn, that sur faned when black students at tening summer high school there traveled through white neighborhoods on their way home.

title: Shrunken sweaters
description: For the longer skirt, the smallest sweater makes the greatest top. It's, all a matter of proportionshort and cropped above, long and flared be low. The sweater can be a cardigan, a twin set or a vest; but whatever the style, it should look shrunken.

title: Pullman Elects President
description: Samuel B. Casey Jr. has been elected president and chief executive officer of Pullman, Inc., effective Sept. 15. He will succeed W. Irving Osborne Jr., 65 years old, who will continue as chair man of the board of the di versified manufacturing, en gineering and construction company.

title: There have been lately an unusual number of criminal or questionable actions involving Congressmen, proving that
description: WASHINGTON.

title: WOODWARD'S HIT SNAPS DEADLOCK
description: PITTSBURGH, July 18 (AP) Woody Woodward doubled home the tiebreaking run with two out in the 10th inning and scored on Bernie Carbo's pinch single, giving the Cincinnati Reds a 31 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in a rain prolonged struggle tonight.

title: Nuptials Held For Miss Ladd
description: PITTSBURGH, July 18In the Hiland Presbyterian Church here this afternoon, Miss Sarah Richardson Ladd was married to the Rev. Howard Paul Hoover by the Rev. William M. Aber.

title: Swiss Name a Delegation To Common Market Talks
description: GENEVA, July 18Paul R. Jolles, head of the trade de partment in the Swiss Econom ics Industry, was appointed this week to head a delegation in talks to he held in Brussels this fall on Switzerland's relations with the European Common Market.

title: Judith Marks Engaged
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 18Dr. Herman B. Marks, a pediatrician, and Mrs. Marks have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Judith Gail Marks, to Dr. Stu art Joel Hershon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Hershon of Long Beach, L. I., where Mr Hershon practices law. The future bride is a graduate of Pembroke College of Brown University. Her fianc has de grees from Harvard Univer sity and the New York Med ical College.

title: ALABAMA'S G.O.P. BEGINS STATE DRIVE
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 18 (AP)  Alabama Republicans, their spirits lifted by a leading Republican Senator and a Cab inet member, started a drive to day to make the G.O.P. a for midable party in Alabama.

title: Powder Metals: Big but Invisible
description: Americans ate about 50 tons of iron powder last year in such products as ironen riched tonic, pills and cereals. Consumers bought more than 1,000 times as muchor about 60,000 tons of powder in the form of parts in new cars.

title: Lessons For a Rock Group
description: I WISH that everybody in America who has strong political feelings one way or the other  could go over there and see what it's like. Steve Katz, guitarist with Blood, Sweat & Tears, is describ ing the group's recent State Department  sponsored tour to Poland, Yugoslavia and Rumania. His primary emo tion still is amazement that the Eastern European coun tries were so different from his expectations.

title: Giants Slate Squad Game For Benefit of Post College
description: The New York Giants, will play an intrasquad game Aug. 1 at C. W. Post College in Brookville, L. I., the team's summer home, as a benefit for the college. Starting time is 10 a. m.

title: Craftsmen Spur Revival of Old Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  The bright yellow and blue liquids simmering in the pots on the little stove in the noisy market of Head House Square in Philadelphia's Society Hill section should not be tasted. They are molten wax, ready to be poured into a hole in some sand in a box.

title: Slowdown Broadens, Pa. Finds
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., July 14Pennsylvania's economy weakened consider ably during the second quar ter, according to business analysts at the Pennsylvania State University.

title: Hollywood's Hottest Writer Buck Henry
description: PITY the pooror even the rich Hollywood screenwriter. Un like his compatriot novelists, playwrights, journalists or even po ets, nobody knows his name. Or cares. While every Saturday night moviegoer recognizes the identities of the stars, the substars, perhaps the producer, and certainly the director when the film credits begin to roll, he will probably not notice the name of the person responsible for the primary element, the script. How many people who saw the Academy Award winning film Midnight Cowboy, for example, are aware that the screen play was written by Waldo Salt? Or that the highest fee in Hollywood his tory$400,000was paid to the scriptwriter of Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, William Gold man? Or that F. Scott Fitzgerald con tributed to the screenplay of Gone With the Wind? Or that a line that has been howled over and repeated into classicdom by a whole genera tion of kidsBen, I want to say one word to you, just one word. Plastics was written by one Buck Henry.

title: Top German Judo Squad To Tour Area for 3 Weeks
description: The Russelsheim judo teams of West Germany, one of the best squads in Europe, will ar rive in New York City for a threeweek tour against Metro politan area clubs.

title: Pamplona Festival Attracts Big Crowd Of Foreign Youths
description: PAMPLONA, Spain, July 18 (AP)  Hippies and students have flooded the annual Pam plona festival, made famous by Ernest Hemingway's bored expatriates.

title: Driver Is Attacked On Brooklyn Route; His Bus Hits Autos
description: A Brooklyn bus driver drove with one hand while fighting off an assailant with the other yesterday morning as his ve hicle with 20 passengers aboard careened down a crowded street.

title: Andree Phillips Is a Bride in Rye
description: RYE. N. Y., July 18Miss Andre Phillips and J. Peter Doherty were married here this afternoon in Christ's Episcopal Church, where the Rev. Dr. Wendell Phillips, the rector, who is the father of the bride, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Wendell R. Phil lips, brother of the bride.

title: Mrs. Frances Gates Is Wed to E. N. Carpenter 2d
description: MENDENHALL, Pa., July 18 Mrs. Frances Carroll Brax ton Morgan Gates and Ed mund N. Carpenter 2d of Greenville, Del., were married here this afternoon at Fair Hill, the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon A. Rust. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. C. Frederick Mathias, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Two Masked Men Hold Up A Miniature Train in Texas
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 18 (AP)  Two masked men, one armed with a pistol, held up a miniature train at a city park today.

title: Photography
description: ONE of the most strik ing aspects of the pho tographic scene in Cali fornia is that, diverse and widespread though it may be, it centers almost ex clusively around the schools.

title: Headliners
description: Everybody at the Capitol was stumped. Why, asked Prince Charles, had the bald eagle been chosen as the national bird of the United States? His outspoken sister, Princess Anne, said she thought it had been rather a bad choice. Nobody accompanying the visitors knew the an swer, but Army heraldic experts recalled later that Benja min Franklin had been opposed to the eagle, too, and that George Washington had been credited with selecting the eagle as the national symbol because it is strong and fierce.

title: Wallenda Walks Wire Across Gorge 700 Feet Deep
description: TALLULAH FALLS, Ga., July 18 (UPI)Karl Wallen da, 65 years old, walked briskly today across a high wire 700 feet above the jagged rocks at the bottom of Tallulah Gorge, pausing twice along the way to stand on his head.

title: Art
description: LAST week, during a visit to the Philadelphia Mu seum of Art to see a regional drawing show (because I like drawings and have discovered that in a show of this kind you usual ly see some good ones by names you don't know). I found myself most unexpect edly beset by a had case of bleeding heart for American artists  more specuically for the 999 American artists of dedication and talent who manage to carry on beneath the one in a thousand who makes the grade and the one in many thousands who makes it big.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: There are signs of a re surgence in store volume and retailers have a feeling that an era of better business has begun. Department store sales in the week ended July 11 went 5 per cent ahead of the yearago level. Total retail sales showed a 7 per cent gain.

title: The SeaGreen Horse
description: The stated purpose of this short story collectionto draw young readers to the printed word through the magic of the imaginationfits naturally into the hands of the poet Barbara Howes and her teenage son Gregory, who acted as her con sultant. The unexpected bonus here is that in fulfilling their assignment, mother and son have selected a forum of imag inative fiction that should fas cinate readers of any age.

title: Club's Sale to Help Youth
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., July 18  The Junior Woman's Club of Litchfield will set up its Flea and Antiques Mar ket next Saturday at the White Memorial Foundation, the nature center here. In case of rain, the event will take place the next day. Proceeds of the 50cent ad mission charge for adults and from sales at the white ele phant stalls will help the club give two college grants to local girls on their graduation from high school, four full camperships for local chil dren, and support to youth groups in Litchfield.

title: Plant With Nature
description: READERS of the works of the late Louis Bromfield will remem ber that in his series of books about his experience in farming at Malabar he re peatedly stressed farming with nature rather than against nature. Mr. Bromfield was a man who came to agri culture late in life, became tremendously excited by it and in some ways could al most he characterized as an agricultural mystic.

title: Laura Breckinridge Ten Eyck Is Bride of Nicholas J. Nichols
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 18 Miss Laura Breckinridge Ten Eyck, a descendant of John Cabell Breckinridge, who was Vice President un der President James Buchan an and later a United States senator, was married here this afternoon to Nicholas John Nichols in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: ISRAELIS CRITICIZE ARTICLE IN THE TIMES
description: JERUSALEM, July 18 (UPI) Israeli officials said today that an article in The New York Times on Israeli's report ed nuclear capability was spec ulative and inaccurate.

title: VICTIM'S ROOMMATE UNDER CLOSE GUARD
description: CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) The police maintained a close watch today on Ranko Carol Yamada, 17 years old, as she recovered from attacks by a razorwielding assailant who raped and murdered her room mate in a downtown hotel room.

title: Loretto Mead Is Bride in Stamford
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 18 Miss Loretto O'Brien Mead. (laughter of Rear Adm. States Morris Mead, U. S. N. R., and Mrs. Mead of Shippan Point, was married here this after noon to Robert J. Bradley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Bradley also of Stamford. The Rev. Edmund Hussey performed the ceremony in Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Raymond Shoup of the First Congregational Church of Stamford gave the bless ing.

title: Miss Lisa Rogers Is Betrothed To Ronald Edward Bornstein
description: BUFFALO, July 18Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Heussler have announced the engage ment of Mrs. Heussler's daughter, Miss Lisa Gallatin Rogers, to Ronald Edward Bornstein, who will teach at the University of Dakar in the fall as a visiting Ful bright professor of law and economics.

title: Bonn Economic TuneUp Includes Credit Easing
description: West Germany's Parlia ment enacted antiinflation ary measures last week in cluding a 10 per cent refund able tax increase. At the same time, the country's cen tral bank lowered its dis count rate from 7.5 per cent to 7 per cent.

title: Scott of Red Sox Out With a Broken Hand
description: BOSTON, July 18 (AP) The Boston Red Sox suffered a crippling blow today when Xrays disclosed that their hardhitting third baseman, George Scott, had a broken right hand and would be lost three to four weeks.

title: Bikila, Star of Olympics, Joins W heelchair Games
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 18 (AP)Capt. Abebe Bikila, the barefoot Ethopian runner who twice won the Olympic Games marathon event before he was disabled in a car crash, will take part in the International Paraple gic Games.

title: GLEN COVE WILL BUY TRACT FOR HOUSING
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., July 18 The City of Glen Cove an nounced yesterday that it planned to buy a vacant six andahalfacre plot and resell it to a nonprofit development corporation to construct hous ing for people with low and middle inconies. The project is to cost $1.8million.

title: Number of Defeated Budgets For Schools Drops Sharply
description: ALBANY, July 18Budgets in 82 school districts of New York State were defeated this year as compared with the rec ord 137 budgets defeated in 1969, the State Education De partment announced yesterday.

title: Kekkonen Goes to Kiev
description: MOSCOW, July 18 (Reuters) President Urho Kekkonen of Finland left today for Kiev, capital of the Ukraine, on the second day of his official visit to the Soviet Union. He was accompanied by President Nik olai V. Podgorny, who lived in Kiev 10 years ago when he was chief of the Ukrainian Commu nist party.

title: The writer as romantic and reformer
description: William S. Porter, who wrote under the name of O. Henry, looked on life at the turn of the century and tied up his find ings in pretty ribbons. He com bined curiously the reformer and the romantic, and today his readers must be few.

title: Earthworms Are Good for Compost
description: LAVES and other garden litter can be converted in materialenriched compost more quickly with an earthworm spawn. Earthworms consume their weight daily in soil and or ganic matter and their cast ings contain three times more magnesium, five times more nitrogen, seven times more potash than ordinary soil.

title: More Exciting Than a Cake Sale?
description: THERE is a cluster of towns, most of them small, in the south western corner of New Hampshire. Bearing such typical New England names as Hancock. Keene, Peter borough, Walpole, Dublin, Nelson and Jaffrey Center, they are situated in what is called the Monadnock Region  Mount Monadnock, 3,165 feet high, rises in the middle of it. What is interesting about it is that it supports a very honorable chambermu sic program during seven weeks of the summer. What is more interesting, little ef fort is made to publicize it widely. Placards go up in the various towns announcing the concerts as if they were cake sales being held by the Ladies Aid Society of the lo cal Congregational church. The project is considered purely regional and is treat ed as such, although it has attracted visitors from all over.

title: Medicine
description: Human blood is a commodity that brings about $10million a year at retail in New York's hospitals. It is bought, sold, and traded as if it were high class meat, which it largely is: hu man meat. And half the blood in New York's market comes from donors at commercial blood banks who receive $5 for each pint. The other half comes from volunteers.

title: 3 TWINS' HOMERS TRIM ORIOLES, 63
description: BALITMORE, July 18 (UPI) Harmon Killebrew and Frank Quilici hit tworun homers to produce a fourrun, sixthinning rally today that enabled the Minnesota Twins to a post 63 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in a battle of Ameri can League division leaders.

title: Letters: One Passenger's Scorecard for the 747
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: In This Issue
description: GENERAL

title: European Farm Output Stays High
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)  An Agriculture De partment report on farm pro duction in Western Europe may dampen optimism that United States agricultural ex ports in the fiscal year end ing June 30, 1971, could set a record.

title: FORWARD GAL TIES LIBERTY BELL MARK
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) Aisco Stable's Forward Gal and Dr. Wallace S. Karutz's Lady Herald scored victories today in divisions of the $22,737 Schuylkill Stakes before a crowd of 13,497 at Liberty Bell Park.

title: Darts Top Chiefs in Soccer
description: ATLANTA, July 18 (UP1) The Washington Darts defeated the Atlanta Chiefs, 21, tonight in a North American Soccer League game. With the score, 11, the Darts went ahead fort good on Jerry Browne's goal with an assist from Warren Archbibald.

title: JONATHAN SERXNER, PSYCHIATRIST, DIES
description: Dr. Jonathan Serxner, a psy chiatrist who had served as a medical officer on Polaris nu clear submarines, died Thurs day at his home of injuries suffered earlier in the day in an automobile accident in Brooklyn. He was 32 years old and lived at 108 West 15th Street.

title: Firestone Party in Newport Recreates '62 Fete
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 18 The dance Mr. and Mrs. Harvey S. Firestone Jr. gave at The Elms last night for their friends in the summer colony here bore more than a passing resemblance to the private ball the former chair man of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and his wife gave here in 1962.

title: Bus Driver in Fatal Crash Suffers a Heart Attack
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., July 18 The driver of the chartered bus that crashed 10 miles west of here last Wednesday, killing seven children and injuring 52 other persons, suffered a heart attack last night while under going treatment for injuries at Allentown General Hospital.

title: AGNEWARANA TALK CONFIRMED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) The State Department has confirmed reports of a se cret meeting last month be tween Vice President Agnew and the Guatemalan President, Carlos Manuel Arana Osorio.

title: L.I.R. Gas Tank Car Fire Burns Out After 18 Hours
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I. July 18 A 44,000gallon railroad tank car of liquid propane gas that exploded here last night con tinued to burn until 4 P.M. today.

title: Deer Hunting in Park Asked
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) Representative John A. Blat nik, Democrat of Minnesota, has asked the House Interior and Insular Committee to allow deer hunting in the proposed Voyageurs National Park of Minnesota.

title: A she, Richey Reach Final in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 With surprising ease, Cliff Richey turned back topseeded Ilie Nastase, 63, 6.2, today and reached the final of the $35,000 Washington international ten nis championship.

title: My Dad George 3d
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 18 My Dad George continued to keep alive his streak today as perhaps the most famous loser on the thoroughbred racing scene.

title: Hunt Also Achieves Feat For HitsBy Pitches
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (AP)Ron Hunt of the San Francisco Giants established a National League record to day when he was hit by a pitch for the 119th time in his career.

title: Houseboats Barge In On Leisure Scene
description: HOUSEBOATING has come a long way since Noah's Ark. And except for the likes of Cleopatia's sumptuous barge, it has had a history of utility, not glamour. Only in the last few years have houseboats moved into the world of pleasure boating; as recently as 1968 the largest manufacturer of pleasure boats had not added them to its line. Now that they have, according to spokesman for the company, sales are very strong.

title: Riviera Fires Controlled
description: MARSEILLES, France, July 18 (Reuters) Scores of fire fighters returned here today confident that forest arul brush fires along the Riviera were under control. The authorities said most seemed to he burn ing themselves out despite fresh nit breaks along the coast. About 62,000 ores were razed along the coast and on Corsica.

title: Textbooks Scored By Black Editors As Lacking Appeal
description: Martin Hamer, the adviser for multiethnic services at McGrawHill, told a group of educators last week that be cause textbook publishers had to produce books that dealt with all students, they turned out books that appeal to no students.

title: The Violent Men Of Amman
description: AMMAN, Jordan. Armed Arab commandos guard the bulletpocked villa. They point out the spot where the American military attach was killed by submachine gun fire. The room has not been cleaned since then, and you can tell exactly where he died. He was shooting at commandos with a heavy machine gun, one guard claims, so the commandos had to shoot at him.

title: Write On, Dear Critic, Right On!
description: A FEW simple guidelines inspired by the past theater season, or 19 things every drama critic knows he knows but may need to be reminded of:

title: Bangui to Get Rumanian Aid
description: BANGUI, Central African Re public, July 18 (Agence France Presse)Rumania will build railway line in the central African Republic, President JeanBedel Bokassa, who re cently returned from a trip to he Soviet Union and Rumania, announced here today.

title: Sports Publicist Named
description: NEWARK, Del., July 16 (AP) Edward M. Carpenter, a sports writer from the New Haven Register, has heen named sports information di rector at the University of Del aware.

title: WERT GETS HOMER WITH TWO MEN ON
description: CHICAGO, July 18 (UPI) Don Wert's threerun homer after Carlos May misplayed Bill Freehan's fly ball to left field into a double enabled the Detroit Tigers to score four runs in the first inning today and defeat the Chicago White Sox, 54.

title: Pilot Dies in Airshow Crash
description: LA GRANGEVILLE, N. Y., July 18  (UPI)  A singleI engine stunt plane crashed at an airshow near this Dutchess County community today be fore several hundred spectators. The pilot, Jack Moriarty of Spottville, N. J., apparently died, on impact when the rebuilt AT 6 World War II trainer suddenly dove into a wooded area.

title: The Camera World
description: USING standard 16mm film cartridges, a new subminiature camera recently introduced by Minolta produces a larger super16 negative which in creases the normal negative size by 46 per centfrom 10 by 14mm, to 12 by 17mm. In addition to producing a larger negative (which in creases the likelihood of sharper enlargements) the new camera, called the Min olta 16MG.S is exceptionally compact (11/16 inches wide by 4 inches tall), it weighs only 7 ounces, and it has builtin exposure meter with a shutter that locks auto matically when there is not enough light to insure good exposure.

title: Letters
description: My Testimony

title: NEW LEFT GROUPS IN SESSION HERE
description: Fragmented and splintered organizations of the New Left last week held a meeting de scribed by one of its sponsors as more or less historic.

title: Foreign Affairs: Old Ideas and New Weapons
description: PARIS  For fateful anniver saries, this was the week that was. On July 17, 1936, the twentieth century's first truly ideological conflict, the Spanish Civil War, began. And on July 16, 1945, the first atomic device was exploded at Alamogordo. Einstein remarked that the world would never again be the same.

title: GOLF EVENTS FAIL TO LURE JUNIORS
description: The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association schedules a variety of events early in the season. Committees are ap pointed and, along with Class A and B tourneys, a schedule for junior golfers is also planned. Howeverfor one reason or anotherit becomes more dif ficult each season to get young players to take part in the events.

title: HONGA CAPTURES 2 HUNTER TITLES
description: KINNELON, N. J., July 18 Prosperity suddenly struck Mrs. Diana Coe today after having eluded her for more than two years.

title: Linda Winsor Wed To B. H. Boatner Jr.
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., July 18 Miss Linda Holmberg Win sor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtin Winsor, was married here this afternoon to Bolan Herbert Boatner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Boatner of Sewickley.

title: Crowds Enjoy Closed 5th Ave., But Merchants' Reaction Varies
description: Fifth Avenue, deprived of sunny weather for its debut as a promenade a week ago, was closed to traffic from 42d to 57th Street again yesterday, and drew thousands of visi tors who walked, rollerskated, cycled, danced and blew bub bles under bright skies.

title: Powell Brothers Triumph In Wet Pants Sail Opening
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., July 18 The Powell brothers of the host club dominated two classes to day in the opening race of the weekend invitation regatta of the Wet Pants Association. The fleet encountered heavy seas whipped by a 20knot south west wind.

title: Level of Mercury in Fish Found High at T.V.A. Lake
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 18 An analysis by the Tennessee Valley Authority of fish sam ples collected from 10 lakes on its reservoir system has shown no significant levels of mercury in fish except at Pickwick Lake near Florence, Ala.

title: Shields Is Selected Top Helmsman at Race Week
description: LARCHIVIONT, N. Y., July 18 Cornelius Shields Jr., an out standing 36yearold sailing son of an outstanding sailing father, was singled out as the leading helmsman of the 12d annual Race Week of the Larchmont Yacht Club tonight. He was awarded the Anne Kathleen Cullen Memorial Trophy at a prize presentation dinner for his successes in the Inter national OneDesign Class, which his father, also an in vestment banker, introduced from Norway in 1936.

title: Personality:
