By threatening that George Wallace will sweep the South in 1972 if the Ad ministration continues its slight slip to the left on racial mat ters, General Thurmond has taught a pair of useful lessons.

title: Washington: For the Record
New Books
description: FICTION

title: Pitman Named Head Coach
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. July 20 (UPI)  Robert W. Pitman was appointed head basketball coach at California Lutheran College today.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: *Apprentice

title: City's Summer Look: Little New in 50 Years
description: Fifty summers ago and now. A different world, a different city. Fifty summers ago and now. The same world, the same city.

title: House Passes Loan Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) House passed today a 10 year extension of a program under which commercial fisher men have received nearly $28 million in loans. The measure also broadens the program to permit American Samoan fish ermen to he included among hose eligible for the loans.

title: THEODORE ACKERSON
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 20 Theodore Ackerson, execu tive vice president of the Ber gen County National Bank in Hackensack, died of cancer to day at the Valley Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 100 Crest Road.

title: UPENDRA ACHARYA, INDIA NEWSMAN, DIES
description: NEW DELHI, July 20 (UPI) Upendra Acharya, a 63yearold Indian newspaper executive, died yesterday in the Hindu holy city of Benares.

title: MaryElene Canellakis Is Wed
description: Miss MaryElene Canellakis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Canellakis of Syd ney, Australia, formerly of Peking, China, was married here yesterday to Elmer Gethyn Rees, son of Mrs. William Rees of Llanelli, Wales, and the late Mr. Rees. The ceremony in Christ Chapel at the Riverside Church was performed by the Rev. James H. Holmes.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: While they are taking their pictures, I will say this will be on the record for direct quotation. A transcript will be furnished immediately after the confer ence so you will have it for your stories, if you desire it.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
PRICES OF STOCKS LOWER IN LONDON
Music: Mixed Elements
description: LENOX, Mass., July 20  One of the most interesting aspects of the concerts given by the Boston Symphony at Tanglewood this weekend has been the way in which the artistic directors of the Berk shire Festival have dealt with a reduced orchestra. This is that part of the summer dur ing which a sizable segment of the Boston Symphony has to be in Boston to play the Esplanade Concerts.

title: Nixon Sees a Fair Chance for Welfare Reform
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 President Nixon listed as fair today prospects for Congres sional approval of his welfare reform program as White House agents began lo put on the pressure for needed Repub lican votes.

title: Revenues Also Rise
Strikers in Britain Are Bitter and Bored
description: LONDON, July 20At 7 o'clock this morning the gulls fluttered over the silent, windy Royal Victoria Docks in East London. The dockmen sat quiet ly in the Connaught pub, sip ping beer and peering out at the empty wharves.

title: Advertising: Using Agencies for Fashion
description: Neither Hystron nor Mon santo, two fiber manufactur ers who recently announced they were giving up their agencies in favor of creative and media services, under stands fashion advertising, ac cording to David R. Altman.

title: Books of The Times
description: There hasn't been another American writer of Joan Didion's quality since Na thanael West. She writes with a razor, carving her characters out of her percep tions with strokes so swift and economical that each scene ends almost before the reader is aware of it; and yet the charac ters go on bleeding afterward. A pool of blood forms in the mind. Meditating on it, you are both frightened and as tonished. When was the wound in flicted? How long have we to live? Miss Didion's new novel combines this surgical prose with a crushing fatalism (the title refers to a crap game) that obliges her people end essly to circle themselves, reduc ing their radi uses of possibili ties seeking an exit from the Iand sets It all in the cities of the desert (Los Angeles, Las Vegas). While the result is not exactly pleasant, it seems to me just about perfect according to its own austere terms.

title: Bolivia Reports Guerrillas Seized Town and Hostages
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 20 (AP)A band of guerrillas occupied the small town of Teoponte, 200 miles from La Paz, for several hours yester day, burned the offices of a United States company and took two Germans as hostages, the Government said today.

title: Egypt Reports Downing Israel Skyhawk at Suez
description: CAIRO, July 20The Egyp tian military spokesman said today that Egyptian ground defenses shot down one of 24 Israeli Skyhawk planes raiding the southern end of the Suez Canal zone this morning. He added that an orange para chute was seen descending, presumably on the Israeli occupied side of the canal.

title: 3 on Plane Die in Collision; 93 on Jet Safe Over Spain
description: BARCELONA, Spain, July 20 (UPI)A small plane and a West German jetliner collided over northeastern Spain today. All three persons aboard the light plane were killed, but the airliner, although badly dam aged landed safely.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: 20 Volunteer Jets Test Rusty Skills in Workout
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 20At the snap, Jim Turner, the New York Jets place kicker, who was a college quarterback, retreated and looked for his receiver, but none was open. Instead of throwing a pass, he sheep ishly held the ball.

title: E.E.C. Sets Plan For British Talks
description: BRUSSELS, July 20The Eu ropean Economic Community decided today on tactics in the British membership talks aimed at getting the British unilateral ly to give away their negoti ating position.

title: Detective's Trial in Bronx On Bribery Charge Opens
description: A suspended detective went on trial in the Bronx Supreme Court yesterday on charges that he lied to a grand jury about taking bribes from gamblers.

title: RuralState Governors Alarmed by Drug Use
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 20  Drug abuse, a scourge of urban centers, has become major problem for sparsely set tled prairie states as well, Gov ernors of the Middle West said today.

title: SMOG, TWILIGHT AID RIGHTHANDER
description: LOS ANGELES, July 20 (AP) Bill Singer, using a blazing fast ball in the smoggy late afternoon, hurled a nohitter as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Phillies, 50, today.

title: Mrs. Sandijo Egbert Married At St. Regis to Sheldon Secunda
description: Mrs. Sandijo Egbert of New York and Sheldon. Se cunda of New York and Fair Harbor, Fire Island, were married here yesterday after noon in the St. Regis Hotel in a Jewish ceremony.

title: 200 Gather for Protest At Brooklyn Police Station
description: About 200 persons, some throwing debris and other ob jects, gathered in front of Brooklyn police station last night after two teenaged girls were taken there for question ing following a family distur bance nearby.

title: Van Nostrand Seeded First
description: Manhasset, L.I., July 20 King Van Nostrand of Bright waters, who ranks No. 2 in the division nationally, was seeded first today in the United States claycourt tennis cham pionship for men 35 years and over that starts Friday at the Shelter Rock Club. Tony Vin cent, Dr. Dick Raskind and Bob Barker follow on the seeded list in the field of 104.

title: Vatican Names Press Aide
description: ROME, July 20The Vatican today named as its new press spokesman a layman and pro fessional journalist, Prof. Fed erico Alessandrini, who has been deputy editor of L'Os servatore Romano. He replaces Msgr. Fausto Vallaine, who has been named a bishop.

title: CATV CONCERN SUES ON RIVALS' PERMITS
description: A cable television company initiated action in State Su preme Court yesterday to en join the Board of Estimate from recommending exclusive 20 year contracts for two other cable television companies in Manhattan.

title: ECOLOGY ACTION UPHELD BY COURT
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 20  In a decision hailed by con servationists, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has ruled that ecology should be considered along with other factors in the filling and dredging of coastal wetlands.

title: Mitchell Says Integration Will Not Be 1972 Problem
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that there would be no school desegrega tion problem by the time of the 1972 elections.

title: ROSEWALL IS VICTOR IN WESTERN TENNIS
description: CINCINNATI, July 20 (UPI) Ken Rosewall posted an easy 62, 63 victory over S. Sugi arto of. Indonesia as play, began today in the $25,000 Western tennis championship at the Cincinnati Tennis Club. The Australian was a surprise late entry.

title: COLT BRINGS $67,000 AT KEENELAND SALES
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 20 (UPI)A colt sired by the 1964 Kentucky Derby winner, North ern Dancer, was sold for $67,000 today at the first session of Keeneland's summer thorough bred yearling sale.

title: BIG BOARD PRICES CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Stock prices continued to ad vance yesterday although buy ing interest simmered down in the bluechip issues that led last week's upward move.

title: VISUAL ELECTRONICS FACES FORECLOSURE
description: Four insurance companies have given notice Of intent to foreclose on $2millioh in 15 year notes of the Visual Electronics Corporation, the company said yesterday.

title: Legacy of the Apollo 11 Flight: Verifications and New Discoveries
description: One year ago today, with al most half of humanity straining to catch their businesslike, hel metmuffled exchanges, Neil A. Armstrong and Col. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. lifted off the moon and headed for a rendezvous with their mother ship and the journey back to earth.

title: Tropical Storm Pushes North Through the Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 20 (UPI)A tropical storm with 55mileanhour winds pushed northward through the Gulf of Mexico today, and the Weather Bureau issued a hurricane watch from Morgan City, LA., to Apalachiocola, Fla.

title: Huntley Denies Quotation In Life About the President
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., July 20 (AP)Chet Huntley, the news caster, asserted today that Life magazine incorrectly quoted him as saying the fact that Richard M. Nixon was Presi dent friehtens me.

title: Doctors Decry Health Conditions of Migrant Workers
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 Four physicians who investi gated health conditions of mi grant farm workers attacked Congress, growers and the med ical profession today for the disease, neglect and deprivation they told a Senate hearing they had found.

title: $2.9Million to Aid Minority Builders
description: WASHINGTON. July 20 (UPI)The Urban Coalition announced today the start of a $2.9million project to help black and other minority building contractors in four big cities compete for large construction fobs.

title: Australia Garners 3 More Gold Medals In Swimming, Diving
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 20 (AP)  Karen Moras of Australia won her second gold medal in the Commonwealth Games today by taking the 400 meter freestyle swimming race.

title: 2 Panels to Study Effect Of SST on Environment
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 The head of the Government office developing the super sonic transport announced to day the formation of two ad visory panels on the environ mental problems that have threatened the further develop ment of the aircraft.

title: AROUND THE HORN BEATS GOLDEN OR
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 20 (AP)Around the Horn, owned by H. G. Schneider and ridden by Mike Hole, came from far off the pace to win the $9,000 Affectionately Purse for fillies and mares at Monmouth Park today.

title: HOUSING BILL SETS 1.3 MILLION UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)  The House completed Congressional approval today of a bill designed to generate 1.3 million new housing units, including a unique subsidy plan for middleincome home buy ers. The bill went to the White House for President Nixon's signature.

title: MORTGAGE LENDING DECLINES SHARPLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)The amount of money borrowed for home mortgages dropped by onehalf during the first quarter of 1970, the Fed eral Home Loan Bank reported today.

title: House Members Vote To Take 25Day Recess
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)House members, satis fied that they were well along in their work, voted today to take a 25day recess starting at the close of business Aug. 14.

title: Mrs. Abe Stark Dead at 72; Wife of Borough President,
description: Mrs. Lilyan Goldman Stark, wife of Abe Stark, Brooklyn Borough President, died yester day at Brookdale Hospital after a long illness. She was 72 years old and lived at 10 Plaza Street, Brooklyn.

title: Tories Move Toward Sale Of Arms to South Africa
description: LONDON, July 20  In the face of fierce criticism at home and abroad, the Conservative party Government declared to day that it would consider the sale of arms to South Africa for maritime defense.

title: Firebombing Heavily Damages Crown Heights Jewish Center
description: Fire bombs were thrown at a Jewish community center and a two  family house several blocks away in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn shortly after dawn yesterday. No one was injured, but the front of the community center, at which some antipoverty funds in the area are admin istered, was heavily damaged.

title: First Boston Corp. Elects A New Member to Board
description: The First Boston Corporation announced yesterday the elec tion ms a director of Roland Pierotti, formerly executive vice president and head of the inter national division of the Bank of America.

title: Mitchell Asks New Name For No Knock Authority
description: WASHINGTON, July 20At torney General John N. Mitch ell told a House committee to day that the no knock au thority Federal agents are seeking to strengthen their search powers had become a widely misunderstood catch word.

title: AMEX GAINS A BIT AS VOLUME RISES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange managed to inch ahead yesterday with its index closing at 20.24, up 0.05 from Friday's level. Volume was only a little higher at 2,266,870 shares, compared with 2,617, 120.

title: PLAN TO DEVALUE DENIED BY ITALY
description: BRUSSELS, July 20Italy's Treasury Minister, Emilio Co lombo, told his Common Mar ket colleagues today that it would be an economic error if devaluation were sought as the remedy for his country's financial ailments.

title: NICKERSON SUPPORT IS GIVEN OTTINGER
description: Representative Richard L. Ot tinger, the Democratic candi date for United States Senator, was endorsed yesterday by Nas sau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

title: Opposition in Colombia Disrupts the New Congress
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 20 Violence marked the opening of Congress this evening as opposition members of the Sen ate and House fought and smashed furniture before be ing evicted by the police.

title: Pepsico Vice President Quits Advertising Post
description: Paul W. Moseley, a well known figure in advertising circles, has left Pepsico, where he was vice president, advertising.

title: McGovern Asks Role for Palestinians in Mideast Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 Senator George S. McGovern, seeking to meet criticism that he is dovish on the war in Vietnam and hawkish on the Middle East, outlined proposals today for a Middle Eastern settlement, including participa tion of Palestinian refugee or ganizations in Arab  Israeli negotiations.

title: Federal Lawsuit Charges Job Inequality for Women
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 The Department of Justice sought today to obtain its first court order to stop alleged dis crimination against women in job opportunities.

title: Jury Is Used for First Time in City Criminal Court
description: Yesterday, for the first time, the centuriesold system of trial by jury came to the New York City Criminal Court, but only one jury was selected and only one jury trial begun. It was the case of a man in Queens charged with jostling, or pickpocketing, and though the witnesses were heard yester day, the judge will not charge the jury until this morning.

title: J. Stewart Beck, Headed Regional Auto Financing
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 20 J. Stewart Beck, a vice presi dent of the General Motors Ac ceptance Corporation, died yes terday in Mountainside Hospi tal here after a short illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 9 Capron Lane here.

title: Aramburu Suspect Dead
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 20 (AP) A 32yearold laborer, ac cused of membership in the group that kidnapped former President Pedro E. Aramburu, killed himself last night when the police raided his home. The police said Hector Arturo Diaz shot himself in the head when they entered his home, in Cor dba, to arrest him.

title: GEN. BULL TO LEAVE U.N. POST IN MIDEAST
description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 20 (UPI)Lieut. Gen. Odd Bull of Norway paid a farewell visit today to the Jordanian Foreign Minister, Anton Atalla, and said later that he was concluding his work as Chief of Staff of the United Nations Truce Super vision Organization in the Middle East.

title: Ship Lines Bar Cargoes For British in Walkout
description: Major North Atlantic cargo ship operators stopped accept ing British bound cargoes yes terday as a result of the na tionwide British dock strike.

title: Somewhat in Jeopardy
description: The impasse between the players and owners of the National Football League it could be a strike or a lockout or both has created complications of various descriptions. Not the least of these is the status of the game a week from Friday between the College AllStars and the Kansas City Chiefs, the Super Bowl cham pions, in the annual Chicago showcase.

title: Roman Scout and Naskra Win at Big A
description: Roman Scout and Naskra scored in divisions of the Lex ington Handicap on the turf at Aqueduct yesterday. The former, owned by Mrs. Ada L. Rice, registered his third straight success while Naskra came through for the first time since last winter at Hialeah. The Lexington is at 1 1/16 miles for 3yearolds.

title: Transport News and Notes
description: DEER PARK, L.I.. July 20 The United States Coast Guard has contracted for a new ra dar system that is expected to greatly increase its capabilities for small craft searches and rescues.

title: Market Place
description: The discussion Was friendly but a trifle strained at times.

title: Young Lords in Newark Accuse Police of Brutality in Parade
description: NEWARK, July 20  The Young Lords, accusing the Newark police of brutality during disorders that interrupt ed the Puerto Rican Day pa rade here yesterday, called to day for a civilian review board of police conduct.

title: Styles in Kicking May Vary, but Then So Do Styles in the Holder
91Day Bill Rate Dips to 6.385% At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Crisis in Universities

title: Only 12 Soviet Planes Have Taken Aid to Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, July 20 Reu ters)A Peruvian Air Force spokesman said today that only 12 of an expected fleet of 65 Soviet planes carrying relief supplies had arrived to date.

title: 15Piece Seventh Century Offers Promising New Blends of Sound
description: A 15piece orchestra that ranges, musically, from Ren aissance to rock played at the Village Gate on Sunday. The band, called the Seventh Century (because this is the seventh century, of organ ized, written instrumental music, explained Alan Raph, a bass trombonist, who leads the group), is one of a series of new, contemporary groups that will perform at the Vil lage Gate on Sunday nights.

title: South Africa Sets Oil Hunt
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, July 20South Africa's statebacked oil exploration corporation, Soekor, is to begin a $24million offshore oildrill ing program along 900 miles of South Africa's southern coast line.

title: 2 Cab Drivers Are Robbed In Queens and Brooklyn
description: Two taxi drivers were rob bed yesterday, and one of them stabbed, in Queens and Brooklyn. The incidents oc curred as the taxi industry continued to press for steps to curb such assaults.

title: Indictment in Nixon Threat
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn returned a fourcount indictment yesterday against James E. Schroeder, 24yearold mechanic of 67 Terrace Avenue, Hempstead, L. I., charging that he threatened President Nixon and Vice President Agnew with bodily harm. Secret Service agents arrested him on July 9 and he was held in $250,000 bail. He will be given a hearing Thursday.

title: Thant, Marking Apollo 11 Feat, Accepts Lunar Rock
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 20  Secretary General Thant accepted today a frag ment of lunar rock sent by President Nixon as a gift from all the people of the United States. The four ounce specimen will remain on exhibition at the United Nations.

title: Crew of Apollo 11 Rededicates Moon Landing to World Peace
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., July 20 (UPI)  The Apollo 11 as tronauts celebrated today the first anniversary of man's first landing on the moon.

title: Rockettes' Union Warns Of Strike at Radio City
description: The American Guild of Vari ety Artists has notified Radio City Music Hall that 100orso precision dancers, the Rock ettes, will not work beyond to morrow without a new con tract.

title: NEIL GOLDBERG
description: RANDALLSTOWN, Md., July 20  Neil Goldberg, the mid Atlantic regional manager of I. W. Harper Dickel Distiller Company, a branch of Schen ley Industries, Inc., died yes terday at a summer camp near here. He was 32 years old and lived here.

title: RESEARCH LACKING ON BIGBOARD FEES
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The chief consulting economist for the New York Stock Exchange conceded today, under ques tioning, that no economic study had ever been made to justify the schedule of increases in commissions on stock transac tions that are currently being nmnnsprl.

title: Shankland Takes Honors In ProJunior Competition
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., July 20 Craig Shankland of Middle Bay tied for low pro honors with Sal Ruggerio of Baiting Hollow at 69 and also won the fourth pro_junior tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association at the 6,554yard, par70 Nas sau Country Club today.

title: South Africa to Get First Of 3 French Submarines
description: PARIS, July 20The first of three submarines ordered from France by South Africa in 1967 is to be handed over next Friday at Lorient.

title: SUSAN LEE CURTIS
description: AUGUSTA, Me., July 20 Susan Lee Curtis, 11 years old, elder daughter of Gov. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Curtis, died today in Central Maine General Hos pital, Lewiston.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Those who oppose high seas fishing for the Atlantic salmon gained a little satis faction from the meeting of the International Commission of Northwest Atlantic Fish eries (I.C.N.A.F.) held in St. John's, Nfld., earlier this sum mer, according to Richard A. Buck of Hancock, N. H.

title: Clothesline Art Sale Set
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 20The Guild Hall will re ceive the proceeds of the 24th annual outdoor clothesline art sale here Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. The 2,000 works of art priced from $5 to $100 will be hung on clotheslines in and around Guild Hall, the local com munity and cultural center. Each of the participating art ists donates 50 per cent of the price received for a paint ing to the support of Guild. Hall.

title: SPEED GAUGE ON BUS IN CRASH IS EMPTY
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., July 20 The District Attorney of Lehigh County said tonight that no recording materials were found when the state police earlier today opened a tachographa device intended to measure speedon a bus involved in a fatal accident here last week.

title: Brezhnev's Farm Program
description: Four decades have now passed since Joseph Stalin dragooned Soviet Russia's unwilling peasants into the collective farms. For almost a quarter of a century thereafter the systematic exploitation of the collective farmerswhose produce was annually taken from them at a small fraction of its real valueprovided vast amounts of capital needed for industrialization.

title: Policemen Continue Protest
description: More than 60 offduty police men demonstrated in front of the United States Mission to the United Nations yesterday morning to protest assignments to fixedpost duty at missions and consulates in the 19th Pre cinct. The policemen picketed in civilian clothes for almost two hours at United Nations Plaza and 45th Street. There were similar demonstrations against duty at the missions and consulates last week in front of the precinct station itself.

title: Cairo Said to Seek Support for Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 Arab diplomats say that since President Gamal Nasser's re turn three days ago from his 18day visit to Moscow, lines have been rapidly forming among Arab states between proponents and opponents of a political settlement with Israel.

title: BARRY WOOD, 63, PRODUCER FOR TV
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 20 Barry Wood, whose broadcast career ranged from acting as master of ceremonies on the old Hit Parade radio show to producing the Bell Telephone Hour on television, died at a hotel here yesterday, apparent ly of a heart attack. He was 63 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street, New York.

title: PRICE RISES SLATED BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had raised prices by about 10 per cent on high voltage motorcontrol equipment used in many industries, effective immediately.

title: Foe Seeks to Retake Cambodian Resort
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 20  Enemy troops attacked again yesterday at Kirirom, the ravaged mountaintop resort about 50 miles southwest of Pnompenh that was reoccupied by Cambodian troops only last Friday, the Government's mili tary spokesman said today.

title: At New Jensen's, Be Careful Opening That Silver Door
description: Georg Jensen's huge, silver finished doors swung wide and there were four (out of eight) selling levels crammed full of the classic silver work and jewelry as well as hosts of new modern furnishings, merchandise for which this store is famous.

title: HAMBURGER CHAIN ACCUSED BY F. T. C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)The Federal Trade Com mission accused the McDon ald's hamburger drivein chain today of sponsoring a deceptive $500,000 sweepstakes promo tion in 1968 during which only $13,000 in prizes was awarded. In a proposed consent order, the commission said that Mc Donald's, its advertising agency and the promotion company that organized the sweepstakes should have awarded all the prizes they advertised15,610 items worth $500,000 at retail. Under the proposed order, Mc Donald's would be required to award all prizes offered in any future contests.

title: Pacific Appoints Purcell
description: STOCKTON, Calif., July 20 (UPI)Dick Purcell, whose Cal PolySan Luis Obispo track team has won the National Collegiate Athletic Association college division championship in each of the last three years, was named track and cross coun try coach today at the Un iversity of Pacific. Purcell. 32 years old, replaces Darrell Zim merman.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS HE WILL VETO BILL ON IMPORT QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 President Nixon threatened to day to veto trade legislation if it imposes mandatory quotas on any imports other than textiles.

title: 10 Petty Criminals Killed in Sao Paulo By a Death Squad
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20  The selfappointed death squad of sao Paulo, one of at least three Brazilian vigi lante groups believed to be made up of offduty policemen, has executed 10 men identi fied as petty criminals.

title: YOUNG SEEKS AID FOR NATION'S POOR
description: Whitney M. Young Jr. an nounced yesterday that 25 United States Senators were ready to sponsor a plan for multibillion  dollar domestic Marshall Plan to help the coun try's poor people.

title: JACK BIEGELEISEN
description: Jack Biegeleisen, founder and partner of Biegeleisen & Schour, fur manufacturers, died Sunday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 321 West 78th Street.

title: Removal of Tick Can Stem Paralysis
description: One day after a family picnic and hike in a field, a 3yearold girl became para lyzed and nearly died in Youngstown, Ohio, but her pediatrician cured her rapid ly, simply by removing a tick from her scalp.

title: HUSTLING ROOKIE IMPRESSES GIANTS
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 20 Gary Inskeep worked hard for six months preparing for today, and in 12 hot minutes out on the running track, the hard work paid off.

title: 5 Women Surface After 2Week Stay At Bottom of Sea
description: GREAT LAMESHUR BAY, St. John, Virgin Islands, July 20 (AP)The world's first team of female aquanauts came to the surface today after two weeks of living under water. They were 25 minutes early.

title: Susquehanna Correction On Pasco Bid Is Ordered
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Securities and Exchange Com mission formally ordered the Susquehanna Corporation to day to correct a false state ment that the S.E.C. said the company had made in connec tion with a tender offer, in 1968, for the shares of the Pan American Sulphur Company. The statement had to do with what the company intended to do with Pasco if it, acquired control of it, which Sus quehanna did.

title: Monmouth Ball to Mark a Centennial
description: Guests at the Monmouth Turf Charity Ball and Carni val set for the Monmouth Park Race Track on Saturday are being urged to wear fash ions of 1870. The Centennial Ball is the theme of the bene fit, which coincides with the track's 100th anniversary. The ball is only 23 years old.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
WORK ON AFRICA LINE TO BEGIN IN OCTOBER
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 20 Laying of track for the Peking financed ZambiaTanzania rail way will begin from Dar es Salaam in October this year, Zambia's Development and Fi nance Minister, Elijah Muden da, said here today on his return from Peking.

title: OVERNIGHT CRUISE WON BY MADRIGAL
description: FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., July 20Albert B. Boardman 2d's 46foot yawl, Madrigal, was the Division 1 winner, and Mariah, a OneTon Class sloop under charter to Eric W. Peniston and George M. (Dooie) Isdale Jr., triumphed in Division 2 today in the overnight race that opened the American Yacht Club's 39th annual cruise.

title: U.S. Briefs NATO on Vienna
description: BRUSSELS, July 20 (Reuters) The North Atlantic Council, the top decisionmaking body of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, met here today for the third time in a week with members of the United States delegation to the talks with the Soviet Union in Vienna on the limitation of strategic arms. The meeting prompted speculation that the talks in Vienna had entered a critical phase.

title: 8 TOP TOOTHPASTES CRITICIZED BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  Eight of 10 widely sold brands of toothpaste do not live up to their advertisements as cavity preventers, the Food and Drug Administration said to day.

title: American Attacked in India
description: CALCUTTA, India, July 20 (AP)Arthur T. Row, an American official of the Ford Foundation, was beaten up to day by Maoist youths who burst into his office, the police said.

title: M. H. Krieger to Wed Miss Cahn
description: NEW HAVEN, July 20 Mr. and Mrs. William Cahn have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Susan Cahn, to Martin H. Krieger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Krieger of Brooklyn. The wedding will take place here Seat. 20.

title: REV. BERTIN O'NEILL
description: The Rev. Bertin O'Neill, as sistant pastor of St. Francis of Assissi Roman Catholic Church here, died yesterday at St. Eliz abeth Hospital after a long ill ness. He was 64 years old.

title: PROFIT RISE LISTED BY BANCORPORATION
description: Western Bancorporation, Los Angeles, yesterday reported consolidated net operating in come, before securities trans actions, of $34,821,047 for the first half of this year compared with $31,756,966 in the 1969 period.

title: Finnish Chief Leaves Soviet
description: MOSCOW, July 20 (AP) President Urho Kekkonen of Finland flew home today after lunching with the Soviet Com munist party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev; Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, and President Nikolai V. Podgorny. Mr. Kekkonen spent three days in the Soviet Union conferring with Kremlin leaders and sightseeing in Kiev. He leaves Helsinki Wednesday for an official visit to Washing ton.

title: ABomb Display Aug. 4
description: The New York Cultural Cen ter at 2 Columbus Circle will mount the exhibition Hiro shima and Nagasaki from Aug. 4 through Aug. 10 in ob servance of the anniversary of the atomic bombings of Aug. 6 and 9, 1945. The exhibition, which had appeared at the cen ter in the spring, comprises 70 largescale photographs that re cord the nuclear events of a quarter century ago. The cen ter also is making plans to have the display tour several other American cities.

title: POLICE IN CHELSEA EVICT SQUATTERS
description: A 53hour occupation of a Chelsea tenement was ended early yesterday when the Po lice Department's Special Events Squad evicted more than 50 men, women and children from the fourstory building at 233 West 15th Street.

title: Roundup: Pirate Bull Pen Unable to Match Astros'
description: A strange combination of circumstances cost the Pitts burgh Pirates a game as they fell to the Houston Astros, 54, last night in 12 innings.

title: TAIWAN EXTENDS AIR BASE RUNWAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 The Chinese Nationalist Gov ernment is extending an air field in Taiwan to handle Unit ed States B52 strategic bomb ers but thus far Washington has not thought it proper to ask why.

title: Bonn Aide Hangs Himself
description: BONN, July 20 (UPI)Ernst Wilhelm Blatzheim, 45 years old, an official of the Ministry of Science and Education, ap parently depressed by criticism of his work, hanged himself today, the ministry announced.

title: RIKERMAXSON SETS LAWSUIT AGREEMENT
description: The RikerMaxson Corpor ation said yesterday its law yers had signed a stipulation to settle a class action suit filed by former stockholders concerning the amount paid them in the merger of Maxson and Riker on April 1, 1969. The settlement is subject to court approval, with a hearing scheduled for Sept. 3 in Dis trict Court.

title: M.T.A. CRITICIZED ON CRASH INQUIRY
description: The Mayor's Subway Service Watchdog Commission and the chairman of the Joint Legisla ture. Committee on Transporta tion yesterday criticized the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for its procedures for investigating the IND subway accident in Brooklyn that in lured 37 persons on Friday.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: GENERAL HOST SUED BY GOLDFIELD AGAIN
description: The General Host Corporation reported yesterday that the Goldfield Corporation has filed new claims against General Host and other defendants.

title: SWISS TO ESTABLISH TIES WITH ALBANIA
description: GENEVA, July 20The Swiss Government announced today that it would establish diplo matic relations with Albania.

title: ABORTION DEATH REPORTED BY CITY
description: The city's Medical Examiner described yesterday the first reported death resulting from an abortion since a new state law went into effect permitting a woman to undergo an abor tion with only the consent of her physician. The law, passed by the last Legislature, went into effect July 1.

title: SILVER FUTURES POST SHARP RISE
description: Speculators in the silver market were watching their chart points yesterday. As one broker explained, when the chart points on the upside were pierced new buyers came in with orders. At the same time those who had sold con tracts previously bought to cover their short positions. It was an animated market, the broker noted.

title: MANDARINO WINS DECIDING MATCH
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 20 (UPI)Brazil won the Ameri can Zone Davis Cup tennis final today, 32, when Jose Edison Mandarino defeated Canada's John Sharpe, 61, 60, 62, in the fifth and deciding match.

title: Bridge:
description: The final of the knockout team championship, the prin cipal event at the Fun City Regionals, which ended Sun day at the New York. Hilton, was marked by one of the most remarkable reversals of fortune ever seen in a major contest here.

title: GARELIK ASSAILED ON RENEWAL VOTE
description: Thirteen community organi zations from slums through out the city charged yesterday that the power of the poor to influence urban renewal efforts in their neighborhoods was be ing undercut by The City Coun cil president, Sanford D. Gare lik.

title: MRS. DEWEY, WIFE OF EXGOVERNOR
description: Mrs. Thomas E Dewey wife of the former Governor of New York, died Sunday night in Me morial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, after a long ill ness. Mrs. Dewey, who was 67 years old, lived at 141 East 72d Street and at the family's country home in Pawling, N. Y.

title: Philharmonic Concerts In Park Begin Tonight
description: The New York Philhar monic begins its sixth sea son of free parks concerts tonight in the Sheep Meadow of Central Park. Dean Dixon will conduct the program, with James Oliver Buswell 4th as soloist in the Sibelius Violin Concerto.

title: Major Utility Gains
description: The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries re ported yesterday gains in net income for the three, six and 12 months ended June 30 and for the month of June.

title: Factories' Output Trailing Capacity
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 The nation's manufacturing output fell further below ca pacity in the second quarter of this year, the Federal Re serve Board reported today.

title: Nixon on Spending
description: WASHINGTON, July 20For the second time in three days, the White House gave emphasis today to the simple but radical idea that Congress impose a spending ceiling on itself.

title: River Floods Cracow
description: WARSAW, July 20 (Reuters) Floods from the Vistula River, swollen by four days of prolonged heavy rain, have poured deep into the southern Polish city of Cracow, the Polish press agency P.A.P. re ported today.

title: Miss Galbraith, 1966 Debutante, Is Future Bride
description: WINNETKA, Ill., July 20 Mr. and Mrs. John Galbraith have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Angeline Galbraith to Charles Foster Brown 3d, son of Mrs. Brown Jr. and the late Mr. Brown of Winnetka and Pine hurst. N. C.

title: Volunteers Do TV Ads About the City's Parks
description: A group of ecologically aware young Americans at Ogilvy & Mather have, on their own time, gotten up some publicservice TV spots aimed at keeping the city's Parks clean.

title: Hickel Urges Prosecution To Halt Mercury Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Department of the Interior has asked the Justice Department to take action against large companies on charges of polluting lakes and rivers with mercury. Shiro Kashiwa, Assistant Attorney General for the Lands and Natural Resources Division, was given the list of companies today, it was learned, and will decide tomorrow whether to comply with the request by Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel.

title: India Refuses to Arrest Visiting Vietcong Official
description: NEW DELHI, July 21The South Vietnamese representa tive in New Delhi asked the Indian Government today to ar rest Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, the foreign minister of the Vietcong provisional revolutionary gov ernment. The demand was rejected.

title: Spanish Police, Attacked, Kill 3 at Demonstration
description: MADRID, July 21  Three building workers were killed and six injured today in Gra nada when policemen opened fire on demonstrators after be ing pelted with bricks.

title: TREASURY CHIEF URGES CONGRESS TO CURB SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Secretary of the Treasury Da vid M. Kennedy told Congress today that the responsibility of the executive and legislative branches is to keep fiscal [budget] policy in a relatively neutral position this year to aid in a noninflationary ex pansion of the economy.

title: NIXON ADDS 2 STOPS TO WEST COAST TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) President Nixon will stop at Salt Lake City on his way out to the Western White House Friday and will visit Denver on his way home.

title: $183,000 in Gold Is Hijacked In Bronx by 2 Masked Gunmen
description: A $183,000 gold shipment bound for Manhattan from Westchester County was hi jacked in the Bronx yesterday by two skimasked gunmen who ordered a truck driver and his helper to give up or die.

title: Nixon Confers on War
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (Reu ters)President Nixon today held a National Security Council meeting on the Indochina war. The Paris peace talks were be lieved to have been on the agenda. David K.E. Bruce, the President's new chief negotiator at the talks, was present.

title: 15 NATIONS JOIN IN PESTICIDE PACT
description: PARIS, July 21Fifteen Eu ropean nations have approved a series of measures to protect the European environment against the misuse of pesticides.

title: Foreign Affairs. Advice and Dissent
description: PARISI ran into Senator Jefferson in the Crillon bar and he asked if I'd read his speech. Yes, I said. It seems to me you fellows are getting pretty far into foreign policy. Do you want to take over the State De partment and the White House?

title: REV. T. D. WEDEL, 78, TEACHING MINISTER
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 21 The Rev. Theodore O. Wedel, warden emeritus of the College of Preachers at the Washington Cathedral, died of a heart at tack last night at the Alexan dria Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Loss for Modern Toryism
description: Iain Norman Macleod might have become Prime Minister of Great Britain with better luck in timing, and there would have been no doubt about his Gov ernment's direction. He was the epitome of modern Toryismeven more so than Edward Heath or Regi nald Maudling, with whom he had worked under R. A. Butler to give their party's policies a drastic facelifting and updating in the years out of office after the war.

title: Council Rejects Police Building, Scoring Leary on Consolidation
description: The City Council's Finance Committee refused yesterday to vote an appropriation for con struction of a new building for the 79th Precinct Police sta tion in Brooklyn.

title: Market Place:
description: Can it be that the reason some annual reports are hard to understand is that the companies are not trying to inform but to cover up?

title: British Navy Permits Bit of Sideburn
description: LONDON, July 21Sailors can grow sideburns down to the bottom of their ears and no longer need to have their hair cropped short, the Royal Navy has announced.

title: Negotiators' Quarterback
description: Shortly after his election as president of the National Football League Players As sociation early this year, John Mackey purchased a booklet on how to conduct labor ne gotiations.

title: Landlords Given AirPollution Stay
description: The city suffered another set back yesterday in its battle against air pollution from apart menthouse incinerators when landlords won an order from the state's highest court re straining the city from enforc ing regulations requiring up grading of the incinerators.

title: Public Service Bus Line Agrees To Purchase by Gilhooley Group
description: A new company headed by John J. Gilhooley, a former member of the New York City Transit Authority, has agreed to buy Public Service Coordi nated Transport Company, New Jersey's largest bus company, for $29million.

title: Lithograph Plant in Jersey Fined $15,000 for Pollution
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 21 (UPIA $15,000 fine, was im posed here today against a factory for air pollution viola tions.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Wednesday, July 22, 1970

title: School Chancellor
description: The appointment of Dr. HatVey B. Scribner, the Vermont State Education Commissioner, as Chancellor of the city's public schools removes another element of uncertainty from the future management of the decentralized system. Dr. Scribner comes with strong recommendations as a forceful administrator and inno vator, and he has won special praise for his commit ment to racially integrated schooling. These are highly relevant qualities in any effort to improve education in New York.

title: City to Expand Its Capacity to Shelter Children
description: Acknowledging some pretty crummy overcrowding at the two cityrun children's shelters, Social Services Commissioner Jack R. Goldberg outlined yes terday the city's plans for ex panding its capacity to care for neglected and abandoned chil dren.

title: Municipal Forum Elects
description: The Municipal Forum of New York announced yesterday the election as president of Roger S. Phelps Jr., assistant vice president of the Bank of New York. The organization is made up of about 600 public officials, investment bankers, lawyers and institutional investors en gaged in the municipal bond business throughout the coun try.

title: Anne Hinshaw to Be Married To Raimund G. Vanderweil Jr.
description: NEW VERNON, N. J., July 21Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mc Millan Hinshaw Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Stuart Hinshaw, to Raimund Gerhard Vanderweil Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderweil of Cohasset, Mass. A wedding in October is planned.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: TextileApparel Quotas

title: SPENDERS SCORED BY KEY DEMOCRAT
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 President Nixon's complaints about the big spenders in Congress were echoed today by Representative George H. Mahon, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, in an effort to head off a liberal move for increased health funds.

title: Advertising: R. J. Reynolds to Test Brand
description: R. J. Reynolds, the tobac co company that cares more about good taste than good grammar, am about to launch a new cigarette which they think are almost as best as Winston.

title: U.S. Acts to Avert PileUps
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Federal Maritime Commission issued orders to field repre sentatives in United States East and Gulf Coast ports today to keep a close watch on steam ship terminals for signs of any cargo congestion resulting from the British dock strike.

title: Bill on Environment Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The House Education and Labor Committee approved to day a bill to authorize $45mil lion to improve the teaching of environmental studies.

title: FINCH DENOUNCED BY EXRIGHTS AIDE
description: ATLANTA, July 21  Rob ert H. Finch, the former Secre tary of Health, Echication and Welfare, was described today by a top civil rights official in the Johnson Administration as, a gutless man who presided over the greatest giveaway of human rights in recent mem ory.

title: Cardin Moderne, but Chanel Toujours Chanel
description: PARIS, July 21Pierre Car din showed women how to loo in modern settings, and Gabrielle Chanel, who is in her 80's, seemed like the youngest girl in fashion at the fall openings here today.

title: CAPITAL WARNED ON GAS WAR PACT
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Eight months after President Nixon endorsed the Geneva protocol to ban chemical and biological warfare, the Ameri can delegate to the United Na tions has warned that Wash ington could face a quite em barrassing situation unless the treaty is sent to the Senate for approval soon.

title: Marriages
description: WEILELLIOTon July 14th, quietly at Reigate Bernard Well to Edith Marie (Betty) Elliot widow of Arthur H. Elliot.

title: Jane Bastanchury Gains In Western Amateur Golf
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., July 21 (UPI)Jane Bastanchury, the defender, advanced easily to day, but her Curtis Cup team mate, Cynthia Hill, had a nar row escape from an upset as match play opened in the 70th annual women's Western ama teur golf tournament.

title: Alex Mayer Tennis Victor
description: ST. LOUIS, July 21 (AP) Fourthseeded Alex Mayer Jr. of Woodmere, L.I., defeated Kevin Senich of Parma, Ohio, 63, 62, in the second round of the St. Louis junior invita tion tennis tournament today.

title: Panel Assails City Master Plan As a Public Relations Device
description: The city's master plan has been assailed as unprofessional and more a public relations device than anything else by a panel of professional plan ners.

title: Doctor Says He Is Unable To Set Time of Coed's Death
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 21 (UPI)A pathologist testified unexpectedly at the John Nor man Collins murder trial today that he could not determine the time of death of the former student's alleged victim, a petite 18yearold coed.

title: LIVING COSTS HERE ROSE 0.6% IN JUNE HIGHEST IN NATION
description: The cost of living in the New York metropolitan area rose 0.6 per cent in June, outpacing price rises in the nation as a whole and in the four other largest metropolitan areas.

title: U.S. AND KOREANS BEGIN TROOP TALKS
description: HONOLULU, July 21Offi cials of the United States and South Korea opened a twoday defense conference here today, with American leaders hoping to persuade the Koreans to accept a reduction of onethird in United States troop strength in their country.

title: Bonn's Irresponsible Opposition
description: West Germany's Christian Union parties are break ing with precedent and taking on a heavy responsi bility in refusing to send a representative with Foreign Minister Scheel for negotiations next week on a non aggression treaty with the Soviet Union. The refusal ends a longstanding practice of maintaining a biparti san front on matters of critical national interest.

title: Program by Byrds Shows Inclination To Longer Numbers
description: Hearing the Byrds is always a pleasure. The Los Angeles band was one of the first pro gressive rock groups, formed in 1964, and it remains one of the best. The group appeared Mon day evening in Central Park, as part of the 1970 Schaefer Music Festival.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
New Lehman Corp. Director
description: Lewis P. Seiler, board chair man and chief executive officer of the Associated Dry Goods Company was elected a director of the Lehman Corporation yes terday.

title: 3 Huge Copper Producers Are Accused of Monopoly
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Murray Valene, vice presi dent of the Federal Copper and Aluminum Company of Min neapolis, said today that the three major copper producers, through their conglomerates, had created a giant monopoly of the entire industry.

title: Riordan Is Last Regular To Accept Knicks' Pact
description: Mike Riordan, who rose to prominence as the supersub of the National Basketball Association's world champion New York Knickerbockers, yesterday signed his 197071 contract. Riordan was the last of the club's regulars to agree to terms, Red Holzman, the general manager and coach announced.

title: Bombs Pose Threat To Banks' Security
description: CHICAGO, July 21A tight bank security system cannot provide a guarantee against bomb attacks, William Karl, security officer of the Marine Grace Trust Company said here today.

title: 7 Filipinos Die in Jail Break
description: MANILA, Wednesday, July 22 (Reuters)Seven prisoners were shot and killed by prison guards when they tried to escape last night from the national prison, cast of Manila, prison sources said today. One of three other escapees was recaptured.

title: JULIA LEON OFFERS SONGS OF PROTEST
description: Julia Leon, a young singer from Madrid who looks some what like Joan Baez but carries her own special bag of protest songs, gave her first American performance Monday night at the Folklore Center, 321 Ave nue of the Americas.

title: Article 2  No Title
Salesman Robbed of Gems
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 21 (AP)Louis Frey, a salesman from New York City, told the police he was robbed of $100, 000 worth of diamonds today by two men at Municipal Air Terminal.

title: Charter Buses: Gaps in Regulations
description: The charteredbus crash that killed seven children near Allentown, Pa., last Wednesday has spotlighted wide gaps in Federal and state laws regulating the na tion's boo?? charter bus business. It has also raised new concern among Govern ment safety experts over the crashsurvivability of mod ern buses.

title: Bolivians Declare A State of Siege After Kidnappingsl
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Wednesday, July 22 (Reuters)The Bolivian Governinnt last night decreed a state of seige in the country and announced, it had post poned until noon today a de cision on whether to release 10 leftwing terrorists from prisons in exchange for two West Ger man technicians kidnapped by guerrillas Sunday.

title: In Memoriam
description: DUFFYJames Edmund: Lovingly remem bered on ours anniversary When hearts, whose truth Is proven, Like thine, are laid to earth, There should a wreath be woven To tell the world their worth.

title: MRS. BOWER WINS IN GOLF, 7 AND 6
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 21 Mrs. Albert B. Bower of the Pelham Country Club, the de fending champion who won the medal with a oneunderpar 72 yesterday, led the way through the first round of the 26th an nual Women's TriCounty Golf Association championship tour nament at the Burning Tree Country Club today.

title: POLICE RAID GARAGE FOR STOLEN GOODS
description: The Mak Transportation Cor poration's terminal and garage at 144 King Street in Brooklyn was raided yesterday by the police, who said they found a tractortrailer containing $60, 000 worth of English bicycles that had been stolen Friday from a Brooklyn pier.

title: Miss Svensson Is Bride Of Richard Armentrout
description: Miss Gudrun Svensson, a student at the University of Stockholm, was married in her hometown of Junsele, Sweden, yesterday afternoon to Dr. Richard Weinacht Ar mentrout, an American bio chemist doing research at the Karolinska Institute in Stock holm.

title: Union Carbide Drops
description: The Union Carbide Corpora tion reported yesterday that its earnings declined in the second quarter and first half of the year while sales registered gains.

title: ALGERIANS RAISE OILEXPORT TAX
description: PARIS, July 21Algeria moved today to force French oil companies to increase their tax payments about 50 per cent.

title: LOUIS J. DENNIS, 53, FORMER UNESCO AIDE
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 21 Louis James Dennis, a former administrative officer for the United Nations Educational, Sci entific and Cultural Organiza tion, died Sunday night at Mead owbrook Hospital, of throat can cer. He was 53 years old and lived at 140 Parsons Drive here.

title: JUNIOR GOLF PACE SET BY OSTROWSKI
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., July 21 George Ostrowski, the Long Island Junior champion, led the advance today by winning first and second round matches in the 53d Metropolitan Golf Association junior golf cham pionship at the Nassau Coun try Club. Par for the 6,463 yard course is 35, 3570.

title: Brink's Bandit Transferred
description: BOSTON, July 21 (AP)An thony Pino, 64 years old, the last of the 11man team that robbed Brink's, Inc., of $1.2 million in 1950 left in state prison at Walpole, has been transferred to Deer Island House of Correction to serve a twoyear term for conspiracy to rob.

title: F.B.I. Agent Testifies Panther Told of Shooting Murder Victim
description: NEW HAVEN, July 21  Lonnie McLucas admitted last year that he had fired a shot into the body of Alex Rackley in order to make sure that he was dead, an agent of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation testified here today.

title: New Jersey Man Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The Defense Department said today that Warrant Officer Thomas S. Rogers of Penns grove, N. J., of the Army, had been killed in the war in South east Asia.

title: RIGA IS ASSAILED IN NEWARK CASE
description: TRENTON, July 21  The United States Attorney who is prosecuting Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other men on charges of extortion conspiracy told the jury here today that the defend ants had been guilty of cold blooded, calculating, contemp tuous corruption in the largest city of this state.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON POST PRICE GAINS
MACLEOD VACANCY A TORY PROBLEM
description: LONDON, July 21Prime Minister Heath, in office barely a month, was confronted today with the problem of finding a suitable successor to lain Macleod as Chancellor of the, Exchequer at a time of particu larly pressing economic prob lems.

title: Hope of Revived Coalition In Laos Is Seen by the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The State Department suggest ed to the Senate Foreign Re lations Committee today that a potentially significant move, toward restoration of a coali tion government seemed to be under way in Laos.

title: Une de Mai, Barbablu, Dayan Out of $30,000 Roquepine Trot
BOND YIELDS FALL IN DECISIVE MOVE
Life Says Its Huntley Quote About President Is Accurate
description: An interview quoting Chet Huntley, the newscaster, as saying that Richard M. Nixon as President frightens him was described by Life maga zine yesterday as accurate, according to the Associated Press.

title: House Farm Panel Votes Down Plans For Ceiling on Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The House Agriculture Com mittee tentatively approved to day a bill to continue the basic farm program for three more years, voting down proposals to limit price support payments to individual farmers.

title: Progress. Expected In LongTerm Study Of Marijuana Use
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Scientists expect major prog ress within two years in deter mining whether marijuana has bad effects on persons who use it habitually, the House Ways and Means Committee was told today.

title: Dance: A Ballet Company for Scotland
description: LONDON, July 21Scot tish Theater Ballet, which has just ended a season here at the Sadler's Wells Thea ter, may be remembered by New Yorkers under its ear lier name, and geographic location, Western Theater Ballet. Not much has changed except its title.

title: EARNINGS LAG SEEN BY AIRLINES' GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  The Air Transport Associa tion, speaking for the scheduled airlines, said today that the financial condition is critical in the industry.

title: Revision Reported Sought
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21 The Beirut newspaper Al Nahar reported from Cairo today that Egypt would ask the United States to revise its proposals for a Middle Eastern settlement to state clearly that Israel should withdraw not just from Arab territory but from all Arab territory.

title: Nixon to Visit Mexico Early in September
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (Reuters)  President Nixon announced today that he would visit Mexico early in September.

title: G.M. URGES UNION TO AID COST CUTS
description: DETROIT, July 21  The General Motors Corporation asked the United Automobile Workers today to help cut the costs of fringe benefit programs and combat discipline problems in the plants.

title: Exacta, Cheetah and Grass Coloring. Aqueduct Green
description: A cluster of balloons tug ging at their tether behind the Aqueduct grandstand yes terday reflected a bright new note of optimism on the part of management.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW SLIGHT DROP
description: The American Stock Ex change meandered its way yes terday. While prices were down sharply on the Big Board, the index for American prices dropped only slightly, closing at 20.17 down 0.07.

title: Apartment Workers Return to Their Jobs
description: Apartment house employe, returned to work yesterday, ending a strike that had de prived thousands of New York ers of garbage collection, eleva tor service, hot water and other amenities since July 6.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS LICENSING BY U.S. FOR EXPLOSIVES
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The Nixon Administration an nounced today that it would propose a new explosives con trol act to combat the growing number of bombings in the United States.

title: Miss Grygiel Takes Medal
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 21 (AP)Chris Grygiel of Frank fort shot a twooverpar 78 on windswept Tuscarora golf course today to take the medal in the qualifying round of New York state amateur junior girls golf tournament. Match play begins tomorrow.

title: Occidental Petroleum Buys Grace LatinAmerican Units
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced yester day that it had acquired all of the vinyl film, fabric and related product holdings in Latin America of W. R. Grace & Co. The price was not disclosed. Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental, said the trans action involved six companies in Brazil, Colombia, Venezuela and Mexico. The Hooker Chemical division of Occidental will operate the units.

title: Article 6  No Title
A.E.C. Law Post Is Filled
description: The appointment of Martin M. Samber as chief counsel for the Atomic Energy Commission in the New York operations of fice was announced yesterday by Wesley M. Johnson, office manager. The New York office has responsibility for the Northeast.

title: BERNARD J. THOLE
description: SUMMIT, N. J., July 21Ber nard J. Thole, a lawyer with the Mobil Oil Company in New York for 28 years, died yester day in St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston. He was 79 years old and lived at 10 Temp lar Way here.

title: Article 4  No Title
Lincoln's Death Portrayed at Scene
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  A shot like the one that killed President Abraham Lincoln echoed again tonight in Ford's Theater here.

title: National Daily Newspaper Planned by a Senate Aide
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)Walter Pincus, a former newspaperman and now coun sel for a Senate subcommittee, said today that he planned to join in starting a national daily newspaper for several cities that have no morning publica tion.

title: DECISION PROMISED ROCK FETE BACKERS
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 21 (UPI)  Superior Court Judge Aaron Palmer intends to rule Thursday on the fate of the Powder Ridge Rock Festival in Connecticut.

title: SILVER PRICES DIP ON PROFIT TAKING
description: The upswinging silver mar ket absorbed some quick profit taking yesterday from nervous speculators, and prices dropped about a penny or a little more for most contracts. Even so, the weekold gain of 5 to 7 cents for most contracts was still largely there.

title: RISE IN NET LISTED BY PUBLIC SERVICE
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the six months ended June 30.

title: Soviet Blast Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commis sion said today that it had recorded seismic signals, pre sumably from an underground Soviet nuclear explosion yester day.

title: Strike Affects British
description: LONDON, July 21  Brit ain, a country that produces only half the food it eats, felt the sharp impact of the nation wide dock strike today.

title: Muskie Fears Crime Bill Would Lead to Repression
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, charged to day that sections of a District of Columbia crime hill that per mit noknock searches and expanded wiretapping authority could set a nationwide pattern of experiments in repression.

title: Mr. Nixon's Economic Outlook
description: For an Administration that said it does not believe in jawboning, President Nixon and his top economic aides have been doing a remarkable amount of it this week to convince the nation that the downturn in the economy is over and inflation is fading fast.

title: AGNEW ATTACKS MEMO AS FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, July 21An alleged confidential memo randum linking Vice President Agnew's office with plans to cancel the 1972 national elec tion and repeal the Bill of Rights was denounced today as a fraud by Mr. Agnew.

title: Troop Moves Reported
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 21 (UPI)A fresh North Vietna mese division is apparently moving through southern Laos into Cambodia, Maj. Gen. Quane Rattikoun, commander of the Laotian armed forces, said today.

title: $325,000 IS VOTED TO STUDY POLICE
description: The City Council yesterday approved a $325,000 sixmonth budget for the special fiveman commission investigating charges of widespread corrup tion in the Police Department.

title: A PUBLIC COUNSEL IS KENNEDY GOAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  Senator Edward M. Kennedy wants Congress to charter a new Public Counsel Corpora tion to represent the peoples' interests before Federal agen cies.

title: Russians and Chinese Continue Wide Military Buildup Along Disputed Border
description: HONG KONG, July 21  The Soviet Union and Communist China, nervously eyeing each other across their disputed 4,500mile border, have taken a number of dramatic steps in their military buildup, accord ing to wellplaced analysts of Far Eastern intelligence here and in Washington.

title: JEROME A. LEWIS
description: Jerome A. Lewis, a lawyer with offices at 250 West 57th Street, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after heart sur gery. He was 49 years old and I lived at 336 Central Park West.

title: Sniping Witnesses Moved
description: CHICAGO, July 21 (AP)The Cook County state's attorney's office says witnesses to the sniper slaying of two policemen are being held in protective custody outside Chicago. Wit nesses and informers were credited by the police for the arrest of four persons charged with murder in the shootings of Sgt. James Severin, 38 years old, and Patrolman Anthony. Rizzato, 35, Friday night.

title: Two Scientists Imitate a Basic Life Process in Lab
description: Two chemists at the Univer sity of California, San Diego, report they have imitated in their laboratory a basic life process, the means by which plants convert nitrogen in the air to ammonia as the essential step toward producing lifede pendent proteins.

title: FEDERAL AID URGED ON GRADUATE LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Dr. Philip Handler, president of the National Academy of Sciences, urged today that there be Federal support of all grad uate students.

title: LAWRENCE TO GET UNIT OF TROOPERS
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., July 21 After five nights of street dis turbances and two fatal shoot ings, Gov. Robert Docking de clared a state of emergency in this city today and ordered in a complement of state troopers to help keep the peace.

title: Cambodia Said to Order Royal Family Evicted
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 21 (AP)The Govern ment has ordered the mother of the former Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, to vacate the royal palace by Friday, informed sources said today.

title: ABORTION CURBS PUT OFF BY CITY
description: The Board of Health an nounced yesterday that it would defer action on incorporating its proposed amendment on abortion services into the City Health Code.

title: Opera Film: Zar and Zimmermann
description: Certain operas, It is said, do not travel well, and Albert Lortzing's Zar and Zimmer mann has always been held up as one of the prime ex amples. It is very popular in Germanspeaking countries, and has been ever since its premiere in 1839. But seldom is it encountered on the in ternational circuit. Certainly to most of the Americans who attended the filmed presenta tion on Monday evening in Philharmonic Hall, it must have come as a novelty.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: CAGE

title: Article 1  No Title
Foe Renews Attack on Cambodian Training Camp
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, July 22 (Reuters)  Vietcong and North Viet namese troops last night at tacked a military training camp, a military spokesman said today.

title: City Fights Moth Infestation
description: The Parks Department re ported yesterday that 25 trucks. were being used in the five boroughs to spray street and park trees with Sevin to try and control tussock moths, now mostly in the caterpillar stage. The spokesmen said the infestation was annual and was not of epidemic proportions, although residents in some areas have said that the cater pillars, which can cause an itchy rash, are the most numer ous they can remember.

title: BALDSCHUN GIVES 3 SAFETIES IN 9TH
description: SAN DIEGO, July 21Clay Kirby of the San Diego Padres was lifted for a pinchhitter to night after he had pitched eight hitless innings against the New York Mets.

title: New Fort Polk Commander
description: FORT POLK, La., July 21 (AP)Brig. Gen. John G. Whee lock 3d became commander of the Fort Polk infantry training center in brief ceremonies to day. General Wheelock, 52 years old, succeeds Brig. Gen. Emil P. Eschenberg, who has served as acting commander for the last five months.

title: Phelps Dodge Climbs
description: Sharp gains made by the Phelps Dodge Corporation yielded the highest sales and earnings in its history in the second quarter and first half, according to the semian nual report yesterday of George B. Munroe, president of the nation's secondlargest domestic copper producer.

title: CAPTAIN'S LAWYER MAY SUE ARMY AGENT
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., July 21 (UPI)Dennis Eisman, a de fense attorney for an Army Captain indicated today that he might take legal action against an Army investigator who he charged had thrown him to the ground.

title: Harvard Alumni Unit Elects
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 21 (AP)Roswall B. Perkins, for mer Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, is the new president of the Associated Harvard Alumni, numbering 130,000 graduates. The election of Mr. Perkins, a 44yearold partner in a New York City law firm, was an nounced yesterday by the uni versity.

title: SECRECY IS IMPOSED IN KIDNAPPING DEATH
description: LANSING, Mich., July 21 (UPI)Lansing's police chief, Derold Husby, refused today to disclose the cause of death of Laurie Murninghan, whose body was found yesterday. Mr. Husby said, such information should be known only to the killer and the police.

title: Vietnam to Alter Tiger Cage Cells
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21The Government an nounced today that it had sus pended the use of the tiger cage cells at the prison on Con Son pending improvements.

title: Saunders in Defense of $236,000 Salary Before Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)  The ousted chief of the Penn Central Railroad com plained today it was unfair to picture him as a man who con tinued to draw an exorbitant salary while the line wallowed in a sea of financial troubles.

title: BOMBERS LIMITED TO FOUR SAFETIES
description: The Yankees won't tell their children about last night's 42 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers, in which the Bombers' greatest virtue was patience.

title: Mayor Hails Wagner Choice
description: Mayor Lindsay predicted yes terday that his predecessor, Robert F Wagner, would make a great contribution in draft ing homerule powers for the state's localities. Governor Rock efeller appointed Mr. Wagner on Monday to head a new cornmis sion to draft a homerule mea sure for consideration by the Legislature next year.

title: 24 Banks Agree on Plan For Lockheed Financing
description: The nation's major banks, banding together to help yet another major corporation avoid serious financial difficul ties, have agreed on the outline of a financing package designed to keep the troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in busi ness in substantially its present form.

title: Nixon Signs Arts Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) President Nixon signed a bill today extending Federal sup port of the arts and humanities for three years. Under the bill, the National Foundation on the Arts and Humanities would be eligible to receive $40million this fiscal year, $60million next year and $80million the following year.

title: In Washington, New Kind of Creature
description: A leading example of successful museum decentraliza tion is Anacostia, set up in Washington four years ago by the Smithsonian Institution and bearing the name of the poor and mostly black section in which it is situated.

title: Hurricane Becky Heads for Florida
description: PANAMA CITY, Fla., July 21 (UPI)  Hurricane Becky swirled toward Florida's Gulf Coast beaches today and forecasters said it may have winds up to 90 miles an hour when it hits about 9 A.M., Eastern Daylight time, to morrow.

title: Prisoner Termed an Israeli
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Is raeli and United States officials today acknowledged that an Americanborn pilot was now a prisoner in Egypt, but said that he had been an Israeli cit izen since 1961.

title: Control Over Nuclear Pollution Sought by Midwest Governors
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 21 Midwestern Governors acted today to bring thermal and radioactive pollution under more effective state control.

title: No One Offers to Buy 2 Presidential Yachts
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 21 (AP)The former Presidential yachts Julie and Patricia were decommissioned April 29 by the Government in an econ omy move. It had cost $200, 000 a year to operate the yachts, named for President Nixon's daughters. The yachts were offered for sale, but when it came time to open bids today there were none.

title: Two Lead in Goss Golf
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. 3., July 21Kathy Linney of Plainfield and Mrs. James Whelan of Springdale shared the first round lead in the Elizabeth Goss round robin golf tournament today at the Somerset Hills Country Club.

title: Washington: For the Record
UNSEEDED PLAYER WINS, 61, 36, 64
description: CINCINNATI, July 21 (AP) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., and his sister, Nancy, scored firstround victories to day in the $25,000 Western tenns championships. But Zelj ko Franulovic of Yugoslavia, the fifthseeded player, was up set.

title: Nurserymen Elect Head
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 (UPI)The American Associa tion of Nurserymen elected Har old R. Nickel of Muskogee, Okla., president today, succeed ing William Flemer 3d of Prince ton, N. J. Mr. Nickel was the first president of the Oklahoma Horticulture Council and presi dent of the Western Associa tion of Nurserymen in 1963.

title: British Building Stoned by Hundreds of Zambians
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 21 Hundreds of students stoned the British High Commission build ing here today in protest against London's decision to consider new arms sales to South Africa.

title: U.S. PARAPLEGIC FIVE ROUTS ITALY, 7323
description: STOKE MANDEVILLE, Eng land, July 21(AP)The United States easily defeated Italy, 7323, in, wheelchair basketball today during the third day of the Paraplegic Olympics.

title: A Prosperous Peace
description: It was argued in this space last week that the heavy cost of the Vietnam war, measured in terms of lost output, diminished profits of business, and reduced real wages labor, tends to refute the old Marxist and New Leftist charge that capitalist economies de pend on war to provide pros perity. In response, dissenting readers have made the fol lowing points: Whether the war makes sense for the nation or not, it serves the interests of the powerful military  industrial complex. It is diversionary to attribute this view only to Marx ists; it also represents informed nonMarxist thinking.

title: ROSE FRIED, 74, DIES; ART GALLERY OWNER
description: VALATIE, N. Y., July 21 Rose Fried, owner of the Rose Fried Gallery at 40 East 68th Street in New York for the last 30 years, died at a nursing home here this morning. She was 74 years old.

title: TWO POLICE VEHICLES DAMAGED BY BOMBS
description: Two station wagons being prepared for delivery to the Police Department were dam aged by bombs yesterday.

title: Nancy Walcott, T. W. Peterson Plan to Marry
description: Mrs. Henry Richards Wal cott has announced the en gagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Evelyn Walcott, to Thomas William Peterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. C. Peterson of Brookfield, Wis. Miss Walcott is the daughter of the late Mr. Walcott, who was a realestate broker here.

title: DECISION PUT OFF BY N.F.L. OWNERS
description: The team owners of the Na tional Football League prom ised last night that decisions would be announced today on two pressing points in their stalemated negotiations with the Players Association. The owners will make up their minds about attending a meet ing the players have scheduled tonight with the Federal Media tion and Conciliation Service in Washington, and they will also attempt a decision about the College AllStar game scheduled for Chicago on July 31.

title: ARLEN, SPARTANS DISCUSSING DEAL
description: Spartans Industries, Inc., and Arlen Properties said yesterday that they have begun negotia tions for possible integration of their businesses.

title: GOODELL EXPECTS ROCKEFELLER AID
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., July 21Senator Charles E. Goodell said today that he did not ex pect Governor Rockefeller to disavow a conservative group that is backing the Governor and Senator Goodells's Con servative party opponent, James F. Buckley, in the state election.

title: Lights on in Congress
description: Reformers in the House of Representatives are mak ing progress in their effort to open that chamber's proceedings to more public scrutiny than it has so far been willing to allow. One amendment added to the Pending legislative reform bill would enable anyone to find out, by simply requesting the information, how his Representative voted in those committee sessions where most of the work of Congress is done. Another would allow each committee to decide whether have its hearings televised, with stringent safeguards to protect witnesses and preclude circuses.

title: 50,000 Turn Out in San Juan to Honor a Queen
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 21 Thousands of proud, cheer ing Puerto Ricans jammed the Isla Verde airport today and lined the sixmile route to the capital building to welcome home Marisol Malaret Con treras, Miss Universe of 1970.

title: First Criminal Court Trial By Jury Ends in Acquittal
description: The first jury trial held in Criminal Court here since a re cent United States Supreme Court ruling resulted in ac quittal yesterday for a 30year old man who had been charged with jostling.

title: VATICAN DENIES IT HAS BILLIONS
description: ROME, July 21The Vatican made an unusually long and caustic reply today to widely published accounts of its wealth. But it said more about what it did not own than about what it did.

title: Egypt Marks Completion of Aswan Dam Project
description: CAIRO, July 21  While Israeli fighterbombers con tinued their monthslong pounding of the Suez Canal front today, an event of pos1 sibly greater strategic signifi cance was taking place about 400 miles up the Nile.

title: Bethlehem Steel Is Pessimistic
description: Edmund F. Martin, chairman and chief executive officer of the Bethlehem Steel Corpora tion, has indicated that the secondquarter earnings of the country's second largest steel producer would be just as dis appointing as the de pressed profit in the first three months of 1970.

title: Lon Nol, in Thailand, Expected To Press Request for Support
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednes day, July 22Premier Lon No of Cambodia arrived here this morning on an official visit, his first trip outside his country since he led a coup d'etat March 18.

title: Vienna Arms Talk Due to Go Into August
