description: VIENNA, July 21The Vien na phase of the SovietUnited States talks on the limitation, of strategic arms is now cer tain to last at least until early next month. According to in formed sources, both sides are hopeful that something posi tive will emerge before the recess.

title: Urban League Trustee Predicts Rise in Student Activism in Fall
description: A young trustee, of the Na tional Urban League predicted yesterday that many colleges would operate this fall only as bases for offcampus student activity.

title: SCHOMBURG GROUP SEEKS $8MILLION
description: Frederick O'Neal, chairman of the Schomburg Community. Coordinating Committee, an nounced a fundraising drive yesterday to help finance con struction of an $8million build ing to house a collection of Negro history and literature.

title: FOUR POWERS MEET ON THE BERLIN ISSUE
description: BERLIN, July 21The sixth session of the current round of fourpower talks on the Berlin issue was held today. The rep resentatives of the four vic torious powers of World War 11, which retain responsibility for the divided city, agreed to meet again in September.

title: RICHARDSON ASKS WELFARE REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The Nixon. Administration sent its new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare before a hostile Senate Finance Com mittee today with a long speech on welfare reform and a small bundle of concessions.

title: 3 Women Are First to Testify Under Law to Protect Buyers
description: Three witnesses testified yes terday that a major Brookly chain store sent defective fur niture to them and then got questionable default judgments against them when they refused to make credit payments until the goods had been repaired or replaced.

title: Music: Park Concert
description: The No. 10 buses along Central Park West were do ing a rushing business. Boys and girls were riding, and young marrieds, and quiet elder couples, most of them carrying blankets, or pillows, or lunch baskets. They were taking advantage of the beau tiful, beautiful evening to go to the Sheep Meadow in Cen tral Park for the first of the summer's park concerts by the New York Philharmonic.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: *Apprentice.

title: Jersey Standard Dips
description: Oil company earnings reports released yesterday gave the in dustry a split decision as profit advances and declines came out almost perfectly balanced.

title: Miss Devlin Allowed Work
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 21 (UPI)The Northern Ireland Government said today it would allow Bernadette Dev lin, 23yearold Member of Par liament for MidUlster, to con duct a limited amount of parlia mentary work from jail. She began serving a sixmonth term last month for her role in Lon donderry riots last year.

title: Ruling on Officials
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  A Securities and Exchange Com mission hearing examiner ruled today that information relating to the personal financial situa tions of individual officials of the Lockheed Aircraft Corpora tion could be kept out of the public record of a commission hearing.

title: U.S. Holding Fraud Inquiry On Rice Contract in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 21 (AP)United States officials confirmed today that the Agen cy for International Develop ment has been investigating charges of fraud involving a $1 million rice contract.

title: Troon, 45Foot Sloop, Wins On American Club Cruise
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 21 Kendrick R. Wilson's Troon, a Whitby 45foot sloop which flies the host club's burgee, was the overall winner of today's race on the 39th annual Ameri can Yacht Club cruise. A fleet of 38 sailed 22 nautical miles across Block Island Sound from Fishers Island on the first of four daily squadron runs that count for series trophies.

title: Cairo Reply Expected Soon
description: CAIRO, July 21The au thoritative newspaper Al Ah ram reported today that the Egyptian reply to Secretary of State William P. Rogers's letter proposing a ceasefire and peace talks would be delivered to him in Washington within a few days.

title: An End of Passenger Service Prior to Oct. 1 Asked
description: The Penn Central has ap plied to the Interstate Com merce Commission for author ity to discontinue immediately 24 of 34 trains that it already has proposed dropping but which it had agreed to keep running at least until Oct. 1.

title: Price Index for Nation Rises at a Decreased Rate
Hayden, Stone Reported Planning. Link to Walston
description: Another merger of two major brokerage houses ap pears to be in the works with the report yesterday that an agreement between Walston & Co., Inc., and Hayden, Stone, Inc., is being completed.

title: Roundup: McLain Posts A Painful First Victory
description: Denny McLain finally has his first victory of the season but he also has a badly bruised left shin.

title: DECISION RESERVED IN OCEAN HILL CASE
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn said yesterday that he thought the defunct govern ing board of the former Ocean HillBrownsville demonstration school district in Brooklyn had no right to continue administer ing the threeyearold project. But he reserved decision on move to force the group to vacate its offices.

title: Squatter Movement Grows As Housing Protest Tactic
description: City officials, the courts, a hospital, Columbia University and private landlords were embroiled in a growing squatter movement yesterday as about 170 families illegally occupying apartments in sisted on what they called their Moral right to remain.

title: Black Workers End Jackson Strike
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 21 In another abrupt decision, black municipal workers here ended their threeweek strike today against the city of Jack son.

title: Britain Advances in Bargaining To Be Common Market Member
description: BRUSSELS, July 21Nego tiations for British entry into the European Economic Com munity made a significant ad vance today as a compromise agreement over procedure was reached, setting the course for the talks over the coming months.

title: Books of The Times
description: About the time Grace Kelly was married to Prince Rainer, someone in Hollywood was asked for anecdotes about her and replied: Grace is the sort of person who doesn't allow anecdotes to happen to her. Wallace Stevens seems to have been the sort of person who not only didn't allow anecdotes to happen to him, but who also almost didn't al low life to happen to him  at least the kind of life we romantically as sociate with fine poets. No illegiti macy, drugs, drunkenness, wenching, war, in version, disease, tragedy or even travel. He was born in Reading, Pa., in 1879; went to Harvard in the fall of 1897; left for New York in 1900; failed at journalism and at law; joined an in surance company; moved with it to Hart ford; eventually became its vice president and was eulogized by its house organ on his death 15 years ago as an outstanding attorney in the bond claim field. His wife didn't like his poetry.

title: Robert Penn Warren Gets Book Award
description: Robert Penn Warren, the poet, novelist, journalist and nature lover, was named winner of the National Medal for Literature for 1970 yes terday.

title: Choice of Pennsy Trustees Is Due
description: Federal Judge John P. Fullam is expected to an nounce in Philadelphia today his selection of trustees to operate the Penn Central Transportation Company un der the court's jurisdiction.

title: East Paterson Officials Indicted In Award of Carting Contract
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., July 21 (AP)  Seven current and former East Paterson officials were indicted today jury for a Ber gen County grand ury for al leged violation of bidding laws.

title: Council Appropes Bill Barring Discrimination Against Women
description: A bill to bar discrimination against women in public places, such as restaurants and bars, was passed yesterday by the City Counoil, 34 to 1. The bill will become law after Mayor Lindsay signs it.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 22, 1970

title: 7 COAST POLICEMEN CHARGED IN KILLINGS
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21  (Reuters)  Manslaughter charges were filed today against seven policemen al legedly involved in the killing of two unarmed Mexicans dur ing a search for a murder sus pect in a skid row apartment last Thursday.

title: OTHER UTILITY REPORTS
description: (Periods ended June 30)

title: Soviet Denies It Is Threat To the Existence of Israel
description: MOSCOW, July 21The Pravda denied today that t?? designs on Israel's integrity a?? Communist party newspaper ??he Soviet Union had hostile ??nd affirmed that Moscow sup ported the right of every Middle Eastern country  including Israelto full in dependence.

title: Bridge:
description: Gloomy philosophers who expatiate on the futility of life and the frequency with which great efforts are made to no purpose could find numerous examples in tour nament bridge play. The diagramed deal, a slight modification of a hand played Saturday in the semifinal round of the knockout team championship at the Fun City Regionals here, illustrates this theme.

title: JURY COMPLETED IN MANSON TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21 Jury selection in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three young women was completed today, and opening statements in what is expected to be a drawnout, complex case will begin Friday morn ing.

title: OHIO CONCERN DENIES JOB BIAS ACCUSATION
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, July 21The LibbeyOwensFord glass manu facturing company denied today Government charges of job dis crimination against women.

title: 2 Australian Soldiers Killed By Allied Shells in Vietnam
description: NUIDAT, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 22(Reuters) Artillery shells fired by New Zealanders fell around a pla toon of Australian soldiers last night, killing two and wound ing four.

title: Gross Value of Luce Estate Is Put at Over $103Million
description: A petition filed in Surrogates Court yesterday stated that the estate of Henry R. Luce had a gross value of $103,014,000.

title: Cairo Says One of Pilots Captured in Suez Area Is an American
description: CAIRO, July 21The Egyp tian Minister of National Guid ance said today that one of the Israeli pilots captured on the Suez Canal front was an Amer ican. The Minister, Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, did not name the prisoner nor did he say when the prisoner had been shot down but described him as a Jew who had arrived in Israel at the time when Israel was preparing for the 1967 war.

title: Computer Score Board To Mark Car Standings
description: Two Working Score boards in one season? What have the fans done, besides paying ad mission, to deserve so much? The first one began operation July 12 at Watkins Glen. That is a simple, manually operated affair that lists the lap number and three lead ers. The new one, much more sophisticated is Ontario Motor Speedway's way of keeping the spectators in formed. When the California track opens Sept. 6 with a 500mile race for United States Auto Club championship cars, standings will be electronically posted on three pylons served by a computer that interprets ra dio signals from the race cars.

title: Italy Plans to Sell Isle of Monte Cristo
description: ROME, July 21 (AP)The Italian Government plans to sell the storied island of Monte Cristo to a special watchdog agency to keep adventurers from hunting its treasures of rare wildlife and plants.

title: ATHENS PREMIER IN NEW MINISTRY
description: ATHENS, July 21Premier George Papadopoulos today took over the post of Foreign Minister, left vacant by the death of Panayotis Pipinelis.

title: Hit Without a Worry
description: Willie Mays drilled a ball through the left side of the infield the other day and he had his 3,000th hit as a big leaguer. Thus did he reach another plateau of the many he has scaled during his spectacular career. But this had extra significance because he joined one of baseballs more exclusive clubs, one with a membership of only 10.

title: HERMAN D. KENIN, MUSICIANS' CHIEF
description: Herman D. Kenin, president of the American Federation of Musicians for the last 12 years, and a vice president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., died yesterday in his room at the Hotel Lombardy here, apparently of a heart at tack. He was 69 years old and lived at 14 Northfield Drive, Westport, Conn.

title: COMPANY ACCUSED ON MIGRANT LABOR
description: WASHINGTON July 21 (AP) A Senate committee was told today that migrant farm work er's, the lowest paid in the nation, were exploited by Texas politicians and huge cor porations, such as CocaCola.

title: Use Stanley, 64, Rescued Jews Fromlazi Prisons
description: BOSTON, July 21 (AP)Ilse Stanley, credited with rescuing 400 fellow Jews from German prison camps, died Sunday at New England Baptist Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at Gilmanton Ironworks, N. H., with her husband, Milton.

title: Big Board Will Weigh Rise in Bond Charges
description: The New York Stock Ex change has disclosed that it expects to consider raising the commission schedule for transactions in bonds. The current minimum rates are $2.50 for each $1,000 bond when the price is more than the face amount; $1.25 when the price is between $100 and $999.99; and 75 cents when the price is less than $100.

title: Natural History Museum Offers Student Rates
description: Students with high school or college identification cards will be admitted at reduced rates to three attractions at the American Musem of Nat ural History.

title: Astros' Pepitone Threatens to Retire
description: HOUSTON, July 21 (UPI) Joe Pepitone of Houston said today he was quitting baseball and would ask the Astros to place him on the voluntary retired list.

title: INTERNATIONAL UNIT FORMED BY DIEBOLD
description: The Diebold Group, Inc., management consultants spe cializing in advanced technolo gies, announced yesterday the formation ??f a new company to expand its activities into Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America.

title: Buczek Captures Westchester Open
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., July 21 John Buczek, the former Wake Forest golf captain who turned pro only two years ago, scored the most important triumph of his career today much to his surprise.

title: Dude Rancher Hears Occasional Discouraging Word
description: WOLF, Wyo., July 13  Seven thousand acres of prime pasiure land, rocky slopes, meadows ablaze with wildflowers, a tumbling creek, towerinc, pines and cottonwoods  Eatons' Ranch, the oldest dude ranch in the country.

title: In Sports, Many Are the Uses, and Misuses, of Water
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 21 (Reuters)England won six gold medals to close in on Aus tralia and the Aussies and Ca nadians continued their battle for swimming supremacy at the Commonwealth Games today. Australia has 17 gold medals, two more than England.

title: Palmer Feted in Pittsburgh As Top Athlete of Decade
description: PITTSBURGH, July 21 Arnold Palmer was honored as athlete of the decade at a din ner tonight at the Hilton Hotel.

title: MOSCOW REPORTS GAIN IN ECONOMY
description: MOSCOW, July 21The So viet Union reported today that its economy continued to show a marked improvement in the first six months of this year.

title: Napoleon's Brother Is Named In Suit Over Land in Jersey
description: TRENTON, July 21  Joseph Bonaparte, once the king of Naples and Sicily and once the monarch of Spain, who helped his younger brother, Napoleon, preside over a conquered Eu rope, and who has been dead for 126 years, has been named as a defendant in a suit brought by a cranberry company in Bordentown, N. J.

title: PARK CONCERT ENDED BY ROCKTHROWING
description: The Municipal Concerts Orchestra cut short a concert at a Washington Heights park last night after one or two rocks were hurled at the musi cians half an hour after the music began. No one was hurt.

title: Sandra Woyke To Be a Bride
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., July 21 Comdr. Max Eric Woyke, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Woyke have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sandra Woyke, to Lieut. (jg.) Henry Hopkins Livingston Jr., U. S. N. R.

title: Property of Italians and Jews Confiscated by Libyan Regime
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21 The Libyan Government today confiscated the property of Italians and Jews in the country. The Italians are to receive no compensation, while the Jews will be given Government bonds payable over 15 years.

title: C.B.S. SHUFFLES ITS FALL LINEUP
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday that it had changed the sched ule for six of its fall prime time television programs. Robert D. Wood, president of the network, called the realignment at such a late date unprecedented but added that his network's affili ates had approved the changes without a dissident vote.

title: N.L.R.B. INEPTITUDE ASSAILED BY TOWER
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Senator John G. Tower, Re publican of Texas, accused the National Labor Relations Board today of tragic ineptitude, and urged approval of his bill to transfer to the Federal courts jurisdiction over cases involving alleged unfair labor practices.

title: State to Pay $1Million in Claims Against Infra Bank Branch Here
description: The New York State Banking Department said yesterday that roughly $1million in checks would go into the mails next Tuesday to pay off about 750 creditors and former depositors of the New York branch of Intra Bank.

title: Jim G. Lucas, a Pulitzer Winner For Korean War Coverage, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)Jim G. Lucas, Pulitzer Pilzewinning war correspond ent for the ScrippsHoward newspapers, died early today of abdominal cancer at the Veterans Administration Hos pital. He was 56 years old.

title: Groth Leads Football Run
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., July 21 (AP)Ray Groth, a former Utah quarterback, ran 2 miles today as rookie players went through their annual 12min ute run at the St. Louis Car dinals football training camp. Groth, who will be either a wide receiver or a defensive back, was far above last year's best distance of just under 2 miles.

title: FORD FUND TO AID POLICE IN REFORM
description: The Ford Foundation plans to establish an independent, $30 million agency that would grant money to police departments throughout the country to help them reform their operations and training.

title: City Transit Unit Urges Subway Hiring Reforms
description: A report by the city's Trans portation Administration on the May 20 subway accident in which two persons were killed, attributed the accident to hu man error and recommended a series of drastic reforms in the Transit Authority's hiring and training procedures.

title: Goldberg Proposes 10 New Priorities in the State
description: SYRACUSE, July 21Pre dicting that the disrepair, of our national house would be very much in evidence in the nineteen  seventies, Arthur J. Goldberg proposed 10 areas to night in which we must alter our priorities in New York.

title: WORK PROGRAM SAID TO BENEFIT 153,000
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson says that 153,000 wel fare recipients have been given jobs or training in the first 21 months of the Government's Work Incentive Program.

title: $510,000 Is Paid by McMahon For Brother of Majestic Prince
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 21 (AP)Frank McMahon, the mil lionaire from Vancouver, Brit ish Columbia, set a world record last night when he paid $510,000 for a full brother to Majestic Prince, who won the Kentucky Derby and Preakness for McMahon last year.

title: Reading Co. Reports Loss
description: The Reading Company, con crolled by the Chesapeake & Ohio and Baltimore & Ohio rail roads, announced yesterday a $1,071,000 loss for the three months ended June 30. This was in contrast to a $577,000 profit a year before. The car bier's loss in the six months ended June 30 was $4,940,000, widened from a yearearlier loss of $1.913.000.

title: Soviet Plane's Call Reported
description: KEFLAVIK, Iceland, July 21 (AP)  United States search pilots said today that they had heard a radio distress signal near the southern tip of Green land that had appeared to come from a Soviet cargo plane miss ing since last Saturday with 23 persons aboard. The plane dis appeared on a flight to Peru with relief supplies for earth quake victims.

title: Donor's Heart and Kidneys Implanted in 3 Patients
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 21 (AP)A University of Michi gan surgical team transplanted the heart and kidneys of a 23 yearold Delaware man today into three separate patients.

title: A Correction
description: The caption of a photo graph in The New York Times yesterday showing commit tee members of the Mon mouth Turf Charity Ball and Carnival incorrectly identi fied Mrs. Amory L. Haskell as Mrs. Amory L. Haskell Jr.

title: James N. Rosenberg, a LawyerPainter, Is Dead
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 21 James N. Rosenberg, a lawyer, painter, writer and philanthro pist died at White Plains Hot pital today. He was 96 years old and lived at 457 Mamaro neck Road in Scarsdale.

title: NIXON IS DISPUTED ON IMPORT CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  A leading advocate of import re strictions to protect United States industries said today that President Nixon was not fully informed when he de scribed yesterday why he would veto a trade bill impos ing quotas on products other than textiles.

title: Access to Red Cross Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Rep resentative John E. Moss, chair man of the Foreign Operations subcommittee, urged today that the Red Cross be given full ac cess to all prisons and deten tion centers in Vietnam, North and South.

title: STOCKS PLUMMET ON A BROAD FRONT
Electric Council Elects
description: Dr. E. L. Kanouse, general manager and chief engineer of the Department of Water and Power of the City of Los Angeles, has been elected chairman of the Electric Re search Council, succeeding E. O. George, immediate past president of the Detroit Edison Company. Thomas G. Ayers, president of the Common wealth Edison Company of Chicago, was named vice chair man.

title: Lorraine Grainger Is Wedin Hartford
description: HARTFORD, July 21  When Miss Lorraine Joyce Grainger and Specialist 5 Arthur Pomeroy Day 2d met at the altar of the Episcopal Christ Church Cathedral for their wedding here this after noon, it marked only the 18th day the couple had seen each other since childhood.

title: Metropolitan Asked to Share its Art
description: The Metropolitan Mu seum of Art should sell its recently acquired Lehman Collection to provide a fund for living artists. It should expand into the vacated Cus toms House at Bowling Green, take a floor or two in the new World Trade Center, and create other branches in Harlem, Queens, the Bronx, Lower Manhat tan, Welfare Island and the South Street urban renewal project.

title: Chicago Milk Strike Ends
description: CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) Milk truck drivers and six ma jor Chicago dairies ended their 20day strikelockout yesterday. Details of the agreement were withheld until union members were notified.

title: Ericsson Telephone Order
description: STOCKHOLM, July 21 (UPI) The L. M. Ericsson Telephone Company has obtained a $10 million contract from the Dan ish State Railways to install au tomatic and remote control sig naling equipment in the Copen hagen area.

title: BIG BOARD TELLS WHY FEES DIFFER
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Of ficials of the New York Stock Exchange and the exchange's economic consultants said to day that there were good eco nomic and statistical reasons why the proposed new schedule of sales commissions on stock transactions differs from the one that was proposed by the consultants in February.

title: Barbara Burnham To Marry Aug. 22
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Strauss of New York and St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Strauss's daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Burnham, to Flight Lieut. Dennis John Pike of the Royal Air Force, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Pike of Johannesburg, South Africa. The wedding is planned for Aug. 22 at the Dorchester in London.

title: 45th Chief of Clan Macneil Is Buried in Scottish Castle
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, July 21  Robert Lister Macneil, 45th chief of the Clan Macneil, was buried last night at his ancestral home of Kisimul Castle on the island of Barra in western Scotland.

title: Gibson, Taking Census, Startles Residents of Newark
description: NEWARK, July 1Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson startled a number of Newark residents today by suddenly appearing at their doors accompanied by plainclothes policemen, aides, television cameramen and re porters.

title: PENN CENTRAL FIRE DELAYS HUNDREDS
description: A fire at the Spuyten Duyvil station of the Penn Central's Hudson division delayed hun dreds of Westchester com muters last night.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Volpe Announces a Plan To Train Road Workers
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe announced plans today to train 10,000 workers a year, up to half of them Ne groes, for skilled jobs in high way construction.

title: Market Place:
description: If an investor rails at brokers, is it not fair that a broker be given a chance to rail at investors?

title: Screen: A Comic Parable
BUYER PROTESTS CREDIT CONTRACT
description: A customer who had a couple of shots of liquor be fore signing a nearly illegible installment credit contract and a white French Provincial bed room chest that was repaired by being painted two shades of pink dominated the testimony at a Consumer Affairs Depart ment hearing yesterday.

title: NASA Extends G.E. Job
description: The General Electric Com pany has received a $10million ninemonth contract extension to provide support services for test firing of the Saturn rocket for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Penn Central Stockholder Files a Suit for Damages
description: A damage suit against the Penn Central Company and its officers and directors was filed here in Federal Court yester day by Louis W. Goodkind, a lawyer who said he owned 500 shares.

title: Murder of Police
description: The police have been at the center of so many or the tensions that now roil the nation that individual policemen, police stations and police equipment have become frequent targets of attack by murderers and bombers. It was in this pattern that two Chicago policemen were killed a few days ago by sniper fire from windows in a housing project.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS FARM AID CEILING
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The House Agriculture Committee approved today an Administra tionsupported limit of $55,000 a year that any one farmer may be paid in subsidies for each of three cropswheat, cotton and feed grains.

title: City Agrees to Let Some Buses Run On 5th Ave. Mall
description: The Saturday closing of Fifth Avenue to vehicles will he ex tended south to 34th Street this week, but some southbound buses will be permitted among the pedestrians.

title: I.R.S. GUIDELINES LISTED FOR BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Internal Revenue Service issued guidelines today aimed at clari fying what types of interest payments banks that own tax exempt municipal bonds may deduct as a business expense.

title: Card of Thank
description: ROPERGeorge, on July 10, 1970, in Canada Family and friends, we thank you so much especially our tenants at 1016 Fifth Ave., NYC.

title: Bombings in California Traced To All Segments of Community
description: WASHINGTON, July 22A California official told the Sen ate today that the dramatically rising number of bombings in his state was being perpetrated by people from all segments of society.

title: Guidelines Urged for Chartered Buses
description: Representative Fred B. Rooney, whose Pennsylvania district was the scene last week of a bus accident that killed seven Long Island children. said yesterday that he would introduce legislation next week to impose broad new Federal regulatory authority over char tered buses.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Advanced Slightly in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 New orders for durable goods rose slightly in June from the May level but remained well below the order flow of the last half of 1969, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: MORTGAGE SIGNED FOR $100MILLION
description: One of the largest mortgage loans ever made here  $100 million  has been arranged to finance a 57story of fice building being erected just north of Madison Square Gar den.

title: In The Nation: Something to Coalesce With
description: WASHINGTON, July 22How can black Americans make the most of their developing po litical power, despite their mi nority position in the electorate? A pair of experienced political professionals, speaking to that question the other day at the National Urban League conven tion in New York, produced some hard common sense and some interesting ideas.

title: F.T.C. CRITIC CALLED CHOICE AS CHAIRMAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)  Miles W. Kirkpatrick, who headed a study panel that sharply criticized the Federal Trade Commission last year, has been offered the chairman ship of the agency, Senate sources said today.

title: Stronger Action Urged Against Unruly Lawyers
description: The nation's leading organ ization of trial lawyers called upon judges yesterday to ban from their courts, for as much as six months, any lawyer who willfully con tributes to disorder in the courtroom.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: American housewives may take umbrage, but I have ob served that many of them fail miserably In seafood cookery.

title: Miss Bastanchury Gains In Western Amateur Golf
description: ROCKFORD, July 22 (UPI)Jane Bastanchury and Martha Wilkinson, Curtis Cup team members, continued theirs winning ways today in the Western women's amateur golf tournament.

title: KING RESOURCES MAY BE TROUBLED
description: The King Resources Compa ny of Denver, which tried with out success to take over the fi nancially ailing Investors Over seas Services, Ltd., earlier this year, may now be facing some financial difficulties of its own.

title: Lefkowitz Figures Angels Lost Nearly $1.5Million in Theater
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that investors in 32 Broadway and 58 Off Broadway productions during the 196970 season suffered losses of $1,481,977 after investing 812.5million.

title: Policy on Castro
description: Fidel Castro's attacks on the Organization of Amer ican States are even more abusive than those of Communist China on the United Nations. In a Lenin centennial speech, Castro called the O.A.S. that trashcan of an organization, and said Cuba would rejoin only on the day the O.A.S. ousted the United States. Castro also swore that Cuba would never break its political or military ties with the Soviet Union and would continue to support genuine revolution aries in the Americasthe two issues on which the O.A.S. suspended Cuba in 1962.

title: 2 NEWSPAPERS SIGN PACTS WITH MAILERS
description: George E. McDonald, the president of Mailers Union Local No. 6, announced yester day that agreements on new contracts had been signed with The Daily News and The New York Times.

title: I.B.M. Files Reply On Xerox Copiers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yester day asked the Federal Courts to declare the Xerox Corpora tion's copier patents invalid and unenforceable.

title: Chess
Hanover Bank Elects
description: Thomas D. Sayles Jr. has been elected a senior vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and has been named administrative officer of the bank's metropolitan divi sion. The bank also elected these vice presidents: Joseph M. Adamko, Franklin Montross 3d and John G. Ramer.

title: Memorial Services
description: BRACKETTS. Cora. For the scar, without Cora, the road has been bare and cold and only her fine memories make things endurable.

title: 11 GOLD MEDALS WON BY U.S. PARAPLEGICS
description: STOKE MANDEVILLE, Eng land, July 22 (UPI)The United States increased its gold medals to 11 today to lead 28 other nations in the international Wheelchair Olympics.

title: Carillot, Tulsa Coach, Resigns Football Post
description: TULSA, Okla., July 22 (AP) Vince Carillot resigned to day as the head football coach at the University of Tulsa, admitting he had been wrong in the transportation of a prospective player.

title: Bridge:
description: A player on opening lead who is the lucky possessor of a suit headed by aceking queen might be forgiven for supposing that it does not matter which of the honors he leads. Expert views vary, but the point is apparently a trivial one.

title: Patterson to Box Green In Garden Bout Sept. 15
description: Floyd Patterson, who has not fought in nearly two years, agreed yesterday to return to the ring on Sept. 15 in a 10round bout against Charlie (Devil) Green of New York at Madison Square Garden.

title: CON EDISON LOSES 2D BIG GENERATOR FOR THE SUMMER
description: Consolidated Edison an nounced yesterday that its most powerful generator, with a capacity of one million kilo watts, broke down Tuesday night and would be out of serv ice for at least the rest of the summer.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Irving Anker, who has been Acting Superintendent of Schools since March 1, was named deputy chancellor of the city school system last night.

title: 3 Arrested in Bond Thefts
description: BROCKTON, Mass., July 22 (AP)Federal, state and local officers, aided by police spot ters in a helicopter, arrested three men and recovered $30, 000 worth of negotiable bonds and checks in raids here yes terday. Arrested on warrants charging receipt of stolen prop efty were Norman Weiner, 41 years old; Allen Kirchick, 36, and Kenneth Murphy, 30, all of Brockton.

title: Mikhail M. Gerasimov, 62, Dies; A Noted Russian Anthropologist
description: MOSCOW, July 22 (UPI) The Soviet Academy of Sciences announced today the death of Mikhail M. Gerasimov, a dis tinguished anthropologist and archeologist. He was 62 years old.

title: Agnew Denies That Nixon Is Growing More Liberal
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Ac cording to Vice President Ag new, the Nixon Administration has not liberalized its political outlook and does not plan to.

title: MRS. BINH RESTATES OFFER ON COALITION
description: NEW DELHI, July 22 (Reu ters) A Vietcong official said today that some members of the Saigon Government would be acceptable in a coalition Government for South Vietnam. [On the New York Stock Ex change the DowJones indus trial average gained more than 10 points following the re marks.]

Friday Newark (201) MArket 33900; White Plains (914) WHite Plains 95300; Hempstead (516) IVanhoc 36660; Commack (516) 5435400: Stamford (203) 3487767.

title: DISPERSAL URGED FOR U.S. AGENCIES
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 22 Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio called today for decentraliz ing Washington.

title: ExPolice Inspector Is Held on Contempt
description: A retired assistant chief in spector of the city's police force was arrested yesterday on a charge of contempt for refusing to tell a Manhattan grand jury whether he had been offered a bribe.

title: Croil Hunter, Former Chairman Of Northwest Airlines, Is Dead
description: ST. PAUL, July 22 (AP)  Croil Hunter, chairman emeri tus of the board of Northwest Airlines, died last night in a hospital here after a brief ill ness. He was 75 years old.

title: Dodge & Delano Sets Promotion of Officers
description: Dodge and Delano of Dodge & Delano are going to greet next week with brand new titlesthey're entitled.

title: MRS. BOWER UPSET IN TITLE TOURNEY
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 22 Mrs. Mandel Doppelt of Brae Burn upset Mrs. Albert B. Bower, Pelham Country Club, the defending champion and tourney medal winner, 3 and 2, at Burning Tree Country Club today in the quarterfinal round of the 26th annual Worn en's TriCounty Golf Associa tion tournament.

title: EARLY LOSSES CUT IN LONDON STOCKS
July 1120 Auto Sales
description: DETROIT, July 22The Big Four auto makers reported to day retail sales of 202,886 Americantype cars in the July 1120 period, nudging ahead of sales of 202,300 units in the corresponding period a year before. The report was another sign of growing strength in the automobile business.

title: Detroit's Pledge of Change After Riot Is Left Unfulfilled After Three Years
description: DETROIT, July 22Three years ago this city was swept by burning, looting and killing. It was the nation's worst black riot and it ended with a pledge by whitesin business, labor and governmentto solve the problems of the past while building a new Detroit.

title: Jersey Stakes to Rollicking
description: Jersey Stakes to Rollicking

title: Bolivia Frees 10 Prisoners As Ransom for 2 Germans
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 22 (Reuters)The Bolivian Gov ernment today freed 10 left wing political prisoners in ex change for two West German technicians kidnapped Sunday by guerrillas, who had threat ened to execute them.

title: Clearing It With Saigon
description: When President Nixon on July 1 named the new chief negotiator in the Paris peace parleys, he said that Ambassador Bruce would have great flexibility in the conduct of his talks except for two conditions. After this week's Presidential news conference, that flexibility appears to have been severely restricted.

title: Pepitone Here, Says He Won't Play Ball; Astros Suspend Him
description: Joe Pepitone, who is AWOL from the Houston Astros, said here yesterday that he had no intention of changing his mind and rejoining the team in St. Louis.

title: No Health Hazard Found in Saccharin
description: Present and projected use of saccharin poses no known hazard to man, a special panel of the National Academy of Sciences  National Research Council has advised the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: For Welfare Reform

title: Guides to Welcome Mexicans Here
description: Members of the New York and Westchester chapters of the American Jewish Com mittee will become tour guides this month when 45 Jewish teenagers from Mexico drop in for a four day stay here as part of a monthlong United States tour sponsored by the Camp on Wheels of the Beth Israel Community Center of Mexico City.

title: William John Heaslip, 73, Artist of Aviation Subjects
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 22 William John Heaslip, an art ist, died yesterday at Morris town Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old and live in Hackettstown.

title: ANTIWAR SUIT FILED BY MASSACHUSETTS
description: WASHINGTON, July, 22 (AP)  The state of Massachusetts urged the Supreme Court today to rule that the participation of the United States in the Viet nam war is unconstitutional.

title: Mayor, in Crown Heights, Asks Unity on Center
description: Mayor Lindsay dropped in at the opening of an Urban Task Force office in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn last night and called on a racially mixed audience to work together for neighborhood har mony.

title: N.F.L. Club Owners Agree to Join Mediation in Their Dispute With Players
description: The 26 team owners of the National Football League agreed yesterday to take their disputed labor issue with the Players Association to Federal media tion and also asked the asso cation if it would be willing to direct the Kansas City Chiefs to start practicing for the College AllStar Game scheduled for July 31 in Chicago.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Thursday, July 23, 1970

title: HARRY E. WESTLAKE
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 22 Harry E. Westlake, former vice president of the Kennecott Sales Corporation in New York, died at a hospital here after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Ramsey.

title: MURDER SUSPECTS FREED BY A CROWD
description: The Police Department re ported yesterday that an off duty patrolman who had caught two suspects in the holdup slaying of a Bronx grocer Tues day was forced by a hostile) crowd to let them go.

title: Psychiatrists in Boston Treating Patients 25 Miles Away Over a Historic New Television System
description: BOSTON, July 22A two way television system to per mit psychiatrists to treat pa tients 25 miles away has been put into operation between two Bostonarea hospitals.

title: MAJOR UNIVERSITY REOPENS IN PEKING
description: HONG KONG, July 22  Four years after it ceased nor mal academic functioning to make way for the Cultural Rev olution, Tsinghua University in Peking, Communist China's foremost engineering school, has started admitting a new student body and holding reg ular classes again.

title: MURRELL'S SINGLE BEATS RYAN, 5 TO 4
description: SAN DIEGO, July 22They San Diego Padres knocked Torn Seaver out of the box in the ninth inning tonight and scored off Nolan Ryan in the 10th to defeat the New York Mets, 54.

title: Gilhooley Planning Innovations for Jersey Bus Line
description: John J. Gilhooley, whose Ur ban Industries, Inc., has agreed to buy Public Service Coordi nated Transport Company, said yesterday that he would try using recent innovations to im prove service on the bus line, New Jersey's largest.

title: BONDS STUMBLE BUT RALLY LATER
description: The bond market stumbled early yesterday, briefly inter rupting the advance in prices that began five weeks ago, but then it regained its footing.

title: Music Hall's Rockettes Accept New Contract
description: Members of Radio City Music Hall's famous dancing troupe, the Rockettes, late last night voted unanimously to accept a new management contract proposal and to call off a threatened strike.

title: DETROIT HOUSEWIFE SEIZED AS BURGLAR
description: DETROIT, July 22 (UPI)  A 26yearold housewife has told the police that she is the pillowcase burglar responsi ble for 150 to 200 Detroitarea burglaries in the last eight months.

title: Big Buildup at Khamduc
description: KHAMDUC, South Vietnam, July 20The allies are back at this former Special Forces airstrip deep in the forested hills southwest of Danang, and are pouring in supplies for a massive operation along the

title: Four Pennsy Trustees From Varied Fields
description: The chairman of the board of the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad and for mer president of the Balti more & Ohio Railroad . . . He is a person who does not hesitate to speak his mind . . . He doesn't have an abrasive personality, but when he thinks he's right he has on occasion bearded such powerful entities as the Union Pacific Railroad, the Interstate Commerce Com mission and the Port of New York Authority . . . He is wellknown by veteran Pennsy and New York Cen tral employes, having started his career with a Pennsy subsidiary, the Lehigh Valley, in 1930 and having served the New York Central as its commerce counsel from 1934 to 1936. . . He was a captain in the Air Transport Com mand during World War II and still flies his own plane . . . He's a nephew by mar riage of Mark Twain and has enshrined in his office a huge picture of the famous writer . . . His wife is the former Irene Fortner.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: marines from the naval base of New London, Conn., passed through the area and were. picked up by sonar devices and killed by the destroyer Pierce and helicopters.

title: Karen Wattel To Be Bride
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I., July 22Dr. and Mrs. Har old L. Wattel have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Hope Wattel, to Gregory Keith Arenson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lewis Arenson of Skokie, Ill.

title: Article 2  No Title
Women Peeved at Being Blamed For U. S. Track Defeats Abroad
description: LENINGRAD, July 22Sex and scorekeeping are the only factors dividing the United States track and field team here for a twoday meet with the Soviet Union beginning tomorrow.

title: CONVICT HONORED BY WRITERS' UNIT
description: Edgar H. Smith, who has written a legal chronicle and a book of fiction on his 13 years on death row, has been elected a member of the American chapter of the P.E.N. Club.

title: LOCKHEED SEEKS FINANCING PLAN
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corpo ration confirmed yesterday that it had been negotiating with the Government and a group of 24 of the nation's major banks for a financing package totaling about $430million designed to keep the company In business in its present form.

title: Shubert Chain Leases Theater Being Built on Coast
description: The Shubert Theaters, one of the nation's largest play house owneroperator con cerns, has taken a 30year lease on a new theater now under construction in Cen tury City, the 180acre urban development in Los Angeles.

title: BILE GIVES H. E W. CONTROL ON DRUGS
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  A House subcommittee approved a drug abuse bill today that would give the Department of Health, Education and Welfare important jurisdiction in mat ters of research and classifica tion of dangerous drugs.

title: U. N. Council's 1967 Resolution
description: The Security Council.

title: Verdict on Addonizio an Echo Of Newark's Violent Recent Past
description: The guilty verdict last night against former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark may have rung down the curtain on the career of a politician whose tenure in office ended in a storm of controversy as turbu lent as the social tides engulf ing his troubled city.

title: POLICE TAXI SQUAD MAKES 5 ARRESTS
description: The Police Department's new taxi squad; whose men cruise the streets in dummy taxicabs, made its first five arrests yes terday in its drive to cut down on crimes against taxi drivers.

title: KODAK PROFIT OFF 3% IN 2D QUARTER
Search for Soviet Plane Finds Unidentified Debris
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 22 (Reuters)Unidentified debris that may be from a miss ing Soviet transport plane was spotted today of the coast of southern Greenland.

title: 2 Youths Walking by the Sea ...Then the Shooting Began
description: CAMP HERO, Montauk, L.I., July 22A. force of about 100 men turned back a commando invasion from the sea in a predawn war game today.

title: Rainy Tropical Storm Hits Florida Panhandle
description: PANAMA CITY, Fla., July 22 (UPI)  Tropical storm Becky struck the Florida Panhandle today with heavy rains that flooded the State Capitol and a tornado that flattened three houses. No injuries were reported nor any extensive damage.

title: Real Estate Shares Sold
description: Lomas & Nettleton Mortgage Investors, a real estate invest ment trust, has raised $19.8. million through the sale of 720,000 shares of beneficial interest at a price of $27.50. The proceeds from the offering. managed by Dominick & Dorn inick. Inc., and Rauscher Pierce Securities Corporation will he used to retire bank loans and for investments.

description: DEPUTY CHANCELLOR NAMED BY SCRIBNER

title: NEW JET IS PLANNED BY BONN AND LONDON
description: LONDON, July 22Britain and West Germany have agreed to develop a combat aircraft for service in the late nineteenseventies, Lord Car rington, the Minister of De fense, announced in the House of Lords today.

title: Liberal Reform Group Likely To Back Walinsky Candidacy
description: A Liberal party reform group that has attacked Alex Rose's domination of the party is ex pected tomorrow to repudiate the Liberal nomination of At torney General Louis J. Lefko witz, a Republican, and instead support his Democratic oppo nent, Adam Walinsky.

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYING OF 2 WONIEN SEIZED
description: MIAMI, July 22 (AP)A 37 yearold cab driver was arrested late tonight and charged with murdering two women who were taken hostage following the robbery of a suburban West ern Union office Monday, the police said.

title: Son to Mrs. John Saul
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. John M. Saul of Nairobi, Kenya, on July 6 there. Mrs. Saul is the former Miss Muriel Mazaltob of Paris. The child, the couple's second son, who is named Eric, is a grandson of Hyman Saul, a vice presi dent of Saks Fifth Avenue, and Mrs. Saul of New York. The infant's father is a con sulting geologist.

title: Children Rescued From Bus
description: BRAINTREE, Mass. July 22 (AP)Daniel Flynn, a state trooper, rescued 57 Chelsea school children from a burning bus yesterday. The bus was transporting the youngsters home from a day at Lincoln Park in Dartmouth when trou ble developed in a rear tire on the Southeast Expressway. The driver left the children in the bus and went for help. Minutes later the bus caught fire.

title: Revenues Advance
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday declines in net income for the June quarter and first half de spite higher operating revenues and net income in both periods. The Company's report placed, revenues and sales at $342,305, 000 for the three months ended June 30. This compared with $791,728,000 a year earlier. Net income slipped to $51,529, 000, or 48 cents a share, from the $57,742,000, or 54 cents a share, in the like 1969 period.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Transport News and Notes
description: A contract to buy 206 air conditioned buses for the Transit Authority from the General Motors Corporation will be signed at noon today in the offices of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority at 1700 Broadway.

title: Ship Mail to Britain Halted By U. S. in Dockers' Strike
description: The Post Office Department imposed an embargo yesterday on surface mail to Britain be cause of the weekold British dock strike.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
BLOCK TRADE SETS BIGBOARD RECORD
description: Shortly after noon yester day 1,184,300 shares of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company crossed the tape at 24, 2 points below Teesday's close, making history as the largest single block of stock ever traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Police Recruits Here Average 98.20 in I.Q. Tests, Lowest in Years
description: The average I.Q. scores of recruits entering the Police De partment here in 1969 were the lowest recorded in recent years, according to a study financed by the Justice Department.

title: Senate Vote Is Due Today on Controversial District of Columbia Crime Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Senate headed today for a showdown vote on the District of Columbia crime bill, with the odds favoring its approval but a stubborn band of oppo nents insisting that they have a chance of defeating the con troversial measure.

title: Text of Rogers Letter to Egyptian Aide
description: I have read carefully Pres ident Nasser's statement of May 1 and your sequent re marks to Mr. Bergus [Donald C. Bergus, principal United States diplomatic officer in Cairo].

title: ONE FOR ALL WINS $132,850 SUNSET
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 22 (AP)Favored One For All came up with a second effort in the stretch and prevailed by two lengths in the $132,850 Sunset Handicap as the Holly wood Park season ended today.

title: Victim Describes Her Slayer in Note; L.I. Laborer Held
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 22 A 23yearold unemployed laborer was charged today with homicide and rape in the slay ing of a young East Islip woman who was abducted from her car around midnight Monday.

title: ..While Jets, at Adelphi, Wonder Where Mates Have Gone
description: GARDEN CITY, July 22  Is this the freshman team a passerby asked in wonderment at Adelphi Uni versity today.

title: AMAX CHIEF BACKS PLANS FOR VOTING
description: Ian MacGregor, chairman and chief executive officer of Amer ican Metal. Climax, Inc., defend ed here yesterday, in an inter view, the arrangements for shareholder voting on a pro posed reorganization of an Amax affiliate, Roan Selection Trust, Ltd:

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Personal Finance
description: With the summer heatwaves, the rental season at the seashore and in the mountains of the Northeast is well under way. Owners who rent out their property to vaca tioners should be aware of the tax benefits available.

title: Australian Oil Strike Ends
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 22 The union that controls the refining and distribution of petroleum today ended its two weekold nationwide strike, which has cut off supplies of gasoline and fuel oil to Sydney.

title: VIETNAM RUMOR LIFTS AMEX LAST
description: Reports that the Vietcong might accept a coalition Gov ernment in South Vietnam had a buoying influence on Ameri can Stock Exchange prices yes terday.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES POST PRICE GAINS
description: The July soybean triobeans, meal and oilexpired on the Chicago Board of Trade yes terday and all went out show ing strength. Their vigor im parted some price strength to the more distant months as well.

title: At Metropolitan, a Show on Violence
description: The print department of the Metropolitan Museum, which can organize a good show any time by thumbing through its own bins, has pulled out 5 etchings by Cal lot, 10 by Goya, and 6 litho graphs by Daumier for Against Violence, an exhi bition that opened this week. Its title might more accu rately be Against War, since the Callots are from his series The Great Miser ies of War and the Goyas from Disasters of War, while the Daumiers are con cerned with the bloody in ternal conflicts and the for eign wars that drained France during Daumier's lifetime. But by either title this is an exhibition that makes sense both as protest and as art., which very little protest art does.

title: ANDREOTTI SEEKING TO OVERCOME A VETO
description: ROME, July 22  Premier designate Giulio Andreotti, apparently failing in his effort to form a fourparty coalition, sought today to find a loophole in an ally's veto of his political program.

title: Mrs. king Has Surgery; Will Miss U.S. Open
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 22 (AP)  Mrs. Billie Jean King underwent surgery on her right knee today and will not play in the $160,000 United States Open Tennis Championships that start Sept. 2.

title: Richey Beats Cornejo, Rosewall Tops McManus in Western Tennis
description: CINCINNATI, July 22 (UPI) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., continuing his quest for a third straight Western tennis. championship, was extended in beating Patiicio Cornejo of Chile, 60, 36, 63, today.

title: 2 Democratic Economists Support a Larger Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  Two leading Democratic econo mists told Congress in effect today to go ahead and increase President Nixon's budget.

title: Baitman, 9YearOld Gelding, Wins at Aqueduct
description: Good old man, said Angel Cordero in the winner's circle, patting Baitman's neck after the running of the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The good old man, a 9yearold gelding owned by Mrs. William Frankel, had just won the mile andasixteenth turf feature event, to the satisfaction of many in the crowd of 29,968. He paid $4 as the evenmoney choice, after beating five rivals.

title: Charges of Violence On Ocean Hill Issue Sent to Grand Jury
description: The Brooklyn District Attor ney, Eugene Gold, ordered yes terday a grand jury inves tigation of alleged threats, intimidation and physical vio lence against members of the recently elected Community School Board of District 23 in Brooklyn.

title: Roundup: Dal Canton Eases Problem
description: If the Pittsburgh pitching staff is to win an award this season, it will have to come from the American Medical Association.

title: G.O.P. UNIT ASKS END OF SOUTHERN TACTIC
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The Ripon Society urged President Nixon today to woo voters in the peripheral South and abandon the Southern strategy because George C. Wallace's victory in Alabama killed it as a national tactic.

title: Neighborhoods: In Fresh Meadows DoItYourself Is the Normal Thing
description: The Fresh Meadows sec tion of Queens, a neighbor hood of treeshaded streets, trimmed lawns and hedges and lots of playgrounds, is rapidly becoming, of neces sity, a sort of vocational school for homeowners.

title: Laborites Assail British Arms Sale Plan
description: LONDON, July 22  Amid scenes of furious uproar, the Labor party mounted a bitter attack today on the British Government's decision to con sider the sale of arms to South Africa.

title: Negro Named to Chase Boards
description: Thomas A. Wood, president of TAW International Leas ing, Inc., was elected yester day to the hoards of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and its parent, the Chase Manhat tan Corporation.

title: G.I.'s in Vietnam Who Use Marijuana Aided in Amnesty
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22 (AP)  The United States Army is trying to get soldiers in Vietnam who use marijuana or other drugs to turn themselves in and get help. It promises that those who do so will not be pun ished.

title: C. O. P. Senators Warmer to Nixon Welfare Plat
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Re publican Senators were meas urably more cordial toward President Nixon's welfare re form program today as hear ings continued in the Senate Finance Committee.

title: Miss Victoria Ford Joy '65 Debutante, to Wed
description: Miss Victoria Ford Joy and Richard Brown Emmons plan to be married in September.

title: Laroche Says Da to Russian Influence
description: PARIS, July 22The mixed media presentation threat ened to overwhelm them, but Guy Laroche's dresses man aged to come through as the prettiest in Paris.

title: Yanks Bow, 41, as Stottlemyre Gives 2 Homers
description: It was a bad afternoon at the Stadium yesterday for Mel Stottlemyre and the New York Yankees. Stottlemyre, bothered all year by pitching arm trou bles, almost got knocked into the box seats behind the Yan kee dugout on a play at the plate in the third inning. Then he gave up successive home runs in the fifth inning that lifted the Milwaukee Brewers to a 41 victory.

title: Stage: Grass on Brecht
description: LONDON, July 22The Royal Shakespeare Company presented a glorious failure last night at the Aldwych Theater, the kind of luxury that only a great national theatrical institution can af ford.

title: Teaching Device Introduced By Electronic Associates
description: Electronic Associates, the nation's leading producer of analog computers, introduced yesterday a new, lowcost teaching device.

title: Cambodia Gloomy on Thai Troop Aid
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 22  Cambodian officials who took part in the first round of talks today between Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia and Pre mier Thanorn Kittikachorn of Thailand expressed pessimism that there would be any signifi cant increase in Thai aid to Cambodia.

title: Books of The Times
description: Fortunately one can't remain mad at William F. Buckley Jr. longat least not much longer than it takes to read his latest book, a collection of columns and miscel laneous writings and certainly not the epigonus of The Jeweler's Eye. (Epigoni sing., epigonusis one of the more ac cessible of those Latinisms with which Mr. Buckley is so fond of sprinkling his prose, like semantic ground glass; and while the reader is leaf ing through his dictionary would he please look up defi, queren cia and tri cotensis, which weren't in my bargain  base ment Webster's?) I said fortu nately for, as it is well known, Mr. Buckley's charm, energy and sense of fun (often, say ingly, at his own expense) transcend some of his more un pleasant polemical quirks, of which syn ecdoche, historical fallacies and misrepre sentation of his opponents are a condensed listing. Sometimes reading Buckley one feels oneself sinking into murky depths, watching sentences like eels slither and flash by, gone before one can take hold of them.

title: COL. HARRY SCHREINER
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 22  Lieut. Col. Harry Z. Schreiner, a chaplain at Fort, Sam Houston, died today at Brooke Army General Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 58 years old.

title: New Bedford Inquiry Set
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass. July 22 (UPI)Four investigators from the Senate Committee on Government Operations began a study today of how $100mil lion in Federal assistance money was spent here. Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, who asked the committee to send the in vestigators, said on a recent tour of the city that he was appalled by the lack of results from the $100million in Fed eral funds spent in the city.

title: Senate to Reopen ABM Debate
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  With less vehemence than last year but with the Administra tion now on the defensive, the Senate will begin another pro tracted antiballistic missile de bate tomorrow.

title: BIG BOARD ASSAILED BY WOMEN HOLDERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  Wilma Soss, president of the Federation of Women Share holders in American Business, Inc., charged today that the membership of the New York Stock Exchange wants all the advantages of being treated like a public utility with none of the responsibilities.

title: Argento's Bird With Crystal Plumage
Arms for South Africa
description: Britain's Conservative Government bases its deci sion to resume the sale of arms to South Africa in defiance of the United Nations Security Council on two grounds. The official one is that the arms are necessary to implement the Simonstown agreement of 1955, pro viding for BritishSouth African cooperation in defense of sea lanes around the Cape of Good Hope.

title: MRS. CHAPOT SCORES IN CLEVELAND SHOW
description: CLEVELAND, July 22 (AP) Mrs. Frank Chapot of Wallpack, N. J., rode. White Lightning to victory today in the open jumper time class at the 21st annual Chagrin Valley Profes sional Horsemen's Association show.

title: Kennedy Proposes Series of Changes In Immigration Act
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who guided the 1965 immigra tion bill through the Senate, proposed today five revisions in immigration policy, among them better control over work ers coming in from Mexico.

title: EGYPT FIELD READY TO STOP SHOOTING AND BEGIN TALKING
description: CAIRO, July 22The United Arab Republic told the United States today that it was ready to stop shooting and start talk ing on the basis of United Na tions resolutions, according to a wellplaced diplomatic source.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JULY 23, 1970

title: Oregon Zoo Gets 2 Lions
description: MEXICO CITY, July 22 (UPI) Two young lions, born in cap tivity here, were flown yester day to a zoo in Portland, Ore., as replacements for two lions shot to death there by unknown attackers July 5.

title: STOCK RALLY EBBS TO GUT PRICE GAINS
description: Stock prices surged upward in heavy trading in a brief noonhour rally yesterday, only to lose most of their gains in slower and quieter trading later in the session.

title: Teresa Dainese Will Be Bride Of Stephen F. Sachs of Ohio U.
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 22Mr. end Mrs. Frank Thomas Dainese have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Teresa Dainese, to Stephen Fay Sachs, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Sachs of Pound Ridge. N. Y.

title: Music: A Mozart Series
description: A mountain is a mountain only when compared to a hill, and a masterpiece is a masterpiece only when com pared to a piece by a master. So, it was interesting to hear a threeconcert series of Mozart trios and sonatas launched Tuesday night with three of his lesser outcrop pings of talent. Alexander Schneider, Leslie Parnas and Claude Frank performed the Piano Trios in B Flat (K.254) and G (K.564), and the Sonata in E Flat (K.481) for piano and violin, at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum.

title: PANEL BIDS NIXON PROMOTE HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, July 22A highlevel panel has urged Pres ident Nixon to withhold all Federal aid from communities that refused to undertake pro grams to increase the supply of low and moderateincome housing.

title: Copper Saks Up
description: Earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, the largest integrated producer of Ameri can primary copper, soared to record levels in the second quarter and first half, the com pany reported yesterday.

title: PATMAN RELEASES REPORT ON PENNSY
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 Representative Wright Patman charged today that the Nixon Administration had planned to proceed with a $200million loan guarantee for the Penn Central Transportation Com pany even after the Federal Reserve Bank of New York had warned that the railroad might not be able to repay the debt.

title: J. E. McBride, Emilie E. Dean Plan to Marry
description: COHASSET, Mass., July 22 Miss Emilie Evans Dean, a graduate of the University of Colorado in Boulder, plans to be married in September to Jonathan Evans McBride, a graduate of Yale University.

title: Article 3  No Title
Executive Changes
description: J. W. Bailey, executive vice president and general manager of Overseas National Airways has been promoted to president and chief operating officer.

title: Chubby Checker Cleared Of Drug Charges Upstate
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 22 (UPI)Drug charges against Chubby Checker, the rock band leader, were dropped today in Niagara Falls City Court.

title: Addonizio and 4 Convicted Of Extortion by U.S. Jury
description: TRENTON, July 22Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other defend ants were found guilty by Federal jury tonight on 64 counts each, one of conspiracy and 63 of extortion.

title: Kaczenski Gains in Golf
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., July 22 Doug Kaczenski, 17yearold son of the Westhampton Coun try Club pro, gained the semi finals of the 53d Metropolitan Golf Association junior cham pionship at the Nassau Country Club today by turning back Paul R. Schottland of Holly wood Country Club, 6 and 5.

title: Advertising: More Award Pros and Cons
description: When asked to comment on the announcement by the Leo Burnett Company that it was withdrawing from adver tising  awards competitions and was putting the entry money into the educational area instead, several agency executives said exactly the same thing: I wish we had thought of it first.

title: CITY HEARING SET ON CABLE TV TODAY
description: An open hearing will be held at City Hall today to determine whether the city will award 20 year franchises to two of its current cable television opera tors and whether to authorize the Bureau of Franchises to award all future cable TV con tracts after competitive bid ding.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS TODAY
description: Avery Prods

title: U.S. Reports Positive Reply by Cairo
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The United States said today that it would quickly open discus sions with Israel and Jordan on the basis of what was viewed in Washington as a positive though qualified Egyptian re sponse to its proposal for a 90day ceasefire in the Middle East.

title: Information Chief Named
description: The appointment of Layhmond Robinson as chief information officer for the municipal hos pital system was announced yesterday. He has been public affairs director for the city's Health and Hospitals Corpora tion. Mr. Robinson, who is 45 years old, was formerly public relations director of the Na tional Urban League, a corre spondent for A.B.C. News and a reporter for The New York Times.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
GERRIT HONDIUS, 79, EXPRESSIONIST, DIES
description: HYANNIS, Mass., July 22  Gerrit Hondius, a painter, died at Cape Cod Hospital today af ter an illness of three weeks. He was 79 years old and lived at 210 West 72d Street, New York, and in Provincetown.

title: World Jurists' Group Accuses Brazil of Systematic Torture
description: GENEVA, July 22The In ternational Commission of Jurists today accused Brazil's military regime of making a Systematic and scientifically developed practice of Torture.

title: American Puts Off Hilo Run
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) Civil Aeronautics Board Airlines to postpone service to Hilo, Hawaii, at least to July 21, 1971. At the same time the C.A.B. said American could begin service to Honolulu and American Samoa on Aug. 1. American said it wanted to postpone service to Hilo in definitely because of a lack of traffic between Hilo and the Mainland.

title: Athens Agrees to Free 7 After Arabs Seize Airliner
description: ATHENS, July 22Six Arab commandos seized a Greek jet liner today and by holding the 55 other passengers and crew members as hostages, won promise of freedom for seven Arab guerrillas held in jails by the Athens Government.

title: U.S. PUTS OFF TALKS ON TRADE IN GENEVA
description: GENEVA, July 22 Talks that the United States was to hold here at the outset of next week with its major trading partners have been postponed until the end of the week at Washington's request.

title: 600 Indian Pilgrims Believed Drowned
description: NEW DELHI, July 22A flooded river in the Himalay an foothills swept 25 buses, 5 taxis and an army vehicle into a narrow gorge today and as many as 600 people may have died.

title: WATERWAYS BAND APPEARS DOWNTOWN
description: The American Waterways Wind Orchestra, a Pittsburgh based ensemble of 45 members that has played its way up and down the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers, along the Atlantic sea coast and on the Thames in England, arrived at Battery Park yesterday at noon for one of the concerts it is giving in this area this week.

title: E.E.C. ASKS BRITAIN FOR A CLARIFICATION
description: BRUSSELS, July 22Acri mony was introduced today in the British membership talks as deputies of the European Economic Community sought but did not receive clarification of remarks by the British chief negotiator raising the issue of apathy of the British public for the first time.

title: STRONG YEAR SEEN BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation had its top execu tive echelon take bows yester day before a special meeting of security analysts for its record firsthalf and secondquarter results announced last week.

title: City's Housing Crisis
description: As the dust has settled from the rent control battle and the apartment house strike, it has left a clear view of the desper ate condition of housing in New York City.

title: At IsraeliHeld Qantara, Guns Make Talk of Peace Seem Unreal
description: At IsraeliHeld Qantara, Guns Make Talk of Peace Seem Unreal

title: A Correction
description: A dispatch from Buenos Aires published in The New York Times on June 26 erro neously reported that ADELA, a Washingtonbased investment group, owned Frigorificos Ar gentinos S.A.I.C. (known as FASA), a meatpacking com pany that was accused by the Argentine Government of price manipulation. In fact ADELA is not among the present or for mer owners of FASA.

title: CITY IS CRITICIZED ON CHILDREN'S AID
description: New York City was accused yesterday by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies of having failed to use Federal funds and state facilities avail able for neglected children.

title: City Cites Subsidy for Renewal Tenants
description: City housing officials yester day assured groups interested in the completion of the West Side Urban Renewal Project that no work would start on the next building until Federal subsidy money was received.

title: Planning for Brooklyn
description: Despite the labels that have been affixed to it, Brooklyn is too heterogeneous a community to be encompassed by any simple stereotype. No borough has a more variegated network of ethnic groups or a greater diversity of living and housing conditions. Brooklyn is in fact one of the nation's greatest cities with a population almost as large as Los Angeles and much larger than Philadelphia.

title: DR. L. H. BRONSTEIN, IN HOSPITAL POSTS
description: Dr. Lewis H. Bronstein, asso ciate medical director of Beek man Downtown Hospital and medical director of Gracie Square Hospital, died of cancer Tuesday at the American Hos pital in Paris. He was 61 years old and lived at 46 East 91st Street.

title: ROBERT P. LAWRENCE
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., July 22 Robert Pearson Lawrence, an artist and a former investment banker with Wood, Struthers & Co: in New York, died yester day in Evergreens Episcopal Honie, Moorestown. He was 87 years old and lived at 202 Wil low Avenue.

title: 26 Savings Banks in State Report Net Deposit Inflow
description: Twentysix major New York State savings banks had a net deposit inflow of $27million in the first half of July, the Sav ings Banks Association of New York State reported yesterday. By contrast, in the yearearlier period, these banks15 in New York City and 11 upstatehad a net deposit outflow of almost $134million.

title: Keino Wins Run at Edinburgh, Ignoring Threats on His Life
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Jan. 22 (AP)An Olympic cham pion, Kip Keino of Kenya, dis dained threats on his life and won the 1,500meter run today in a highlight of the Common wealth Games.

title: Washington: For the Record
China Express' Will Open Museum Film Show Today
description: China Express, a Russian picture directed by Ilya Trau berg will be the opening feature today at the Museum of Mod ern Art of the retrospective showing of 43 feature and short films produced during he nineteentwenties. It re places, the previously announced Passion of Joan of Arc, directed by Carl Dreyer, which will be shown later in the series.

title: Educator Goes to the Dogs to Relax
description: J. Donald Jones is an edu cator who went to the dogs. Dean of student activity at Emory University in Atlanta, he deals with students and their problems all week. On weekends, he faces canine problems. He is in the center of a ring at a dog show eval uating the dogs in front of him. It's a corn plete change of pace, said the of educator. Al Dogs though it calls for a great deal of concentration, I find it re laxing.

title: 8Inning NoHitter Irks Fans on Coast
description: SAN DIEGO, July 22Preston Gomez is a tall, dignified man who was born in Havana 47 years ago. He lives in Mexico City and works in San Diego as the man ager of the Padres of the National League.

title: TRUSTEES NAMED FOR PENN CENTRAL
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 22  The Penn Central Transporta tion Company is to be operated under the supervision of four courtappointed trustees while it remains in reorganization un der Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Beck Sells Furniture Unit
description: Beck Industries, Inc., has sold its Watkins Furniture subsidiary to Broyhill Stores, Inc. of North Carolina, Newton Glekel, Beck's chairman, an nounced yesterday. The sales price was not disclosed. Beck acquired the 10store furniture chain in February. 1969, for stock valued at abalut $3.7 million.

title: Miss Devlin Allowed Work
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 21 (UPI)The Northern Ireland Government said Tues day it would allow Bernadette Devlin, 23yearold Member of Parliament for MidUlster, to conduct a limited amount of parliamentary work from jail. She began serving a six month term last month for her role in Londonderry riots last year.

title: Wandering Football Giants Settle on a Field in Hackensack...
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., July 22After wandering around a few days in the wilderness, the lockedout regulars of the New York Giants have finally found themselves a home away from homethe Hack ensack High School football field.

title: KINNEY PURCHASES ALL ELEKTRA STOCK
description: Kinney National Service, Inc., and the Elektra Corpora tion announced yesterday that Kinney had purchased all out standing stock of Elektra for cash notes and convertible debentures valued at slightly under $10million. Elektra produces records and special izes in folk, rock and classical music.

title: Witness Says Panther Leaders Listened to Tapes of Rackley
description: NEW HAVEN, July 22The man who is said to have fired the first shot into Alex Rackley the night he was murdered tes tified for the prosecution here today that members of the Black Panther party listened to a tape recording made after the victim had been tortured with hot water.

title: G.I. Held in Saigon In Effort to Hijack Plane to Hong Kong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22A 20yearold American soldier was taken into custody here this evening after trying to hijack an Air Vietnam pas senger plane Old force it to take him to Hong Kong.

title: WALTER S. PERKINS
description: SACO, Me., July 22Walter S. Perkins, former president and chairman of the board of direc tors of the Burnham and Mor rill, Portland food packers, died in his home here yesterday aft er suffering a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

title: In Baltimore It's Nothing to Cook Three Tons of Crab a Day
description: BALTIMOREThis is the blue crab capital of the world, and hard and soft shell crabs are to the gourmets of this town what bay prawns are to Dub liners, crawfish are to the Cajuns of Louisiana and toheroa, that rare shellfish, to the gastronomes of New Zealand.

title: He Loves Cops
description: There are three kinds of lawyers, you know  there are those who like cops, those who don't and those who know nothing about them, Charles Howard Rogovin said yesterday. I guess I'm the first kind.

title: South Africa States Policy Toward Her Chinese
description: CAPETOWN, July 22 The official racial policy on the 8,000member Chinese commu nity of South Africa was ex plained in Parliament here to day. The Chinese form a sepa rate racial group with a separate identity and may use facilities of the white group provided the white group does not object.

title: MRS. NIXON ATTENDS MRS. DEWEY'S RITES
description: Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, rep resenting the President, was among 500 people who attended a funeral service yesterday for Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey.

title: DR. CHARLES C. HEWITT
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 22 Dr. Charles C. Hewitt, a psychiatrist, died at Mount Auburn Hospital today after a short illness. He was 69 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: QANTARA, Israeli  occu pied Sinai, July 21  Half a dozen puffs of smoke, like balls of cotton against the blue desert sy, appeared suddenly over the once bus tling promenade of this Suez Canal ferrycrossing.

title: Urban League Attacks Links of Chase Bank to South Africa
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank was condemned for its finan cial links to South Africa by the National Urban League yesterday as the human rights group closed its 60th annual conference.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 22 (UPI)J. I. B. Farms' Rollicking won his second stakes race of the year today by beating the favored Hagley by three lengths in the $25,000 added Select Handicap at Monmouth Park.

title: J. J. Davis Is Fiance Of Betsy E. Karp
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 22 Miss Betsy Edith Karp, a sophomore at the University of Connecticut, plans to be married next June to Jeffrey J. Davis, a senior there.

title: 13 AMERICANS DIE IN VIETNAM CLASH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 23At least 13 American soldiers have been killed and more than 40 wounded in the last 48 hours around a small hilltop artillery outpost near the Ashau Valley.

title: Weather Blamed for Price Increases
description: Oranges, up nine cents pound; potatoes, up six cents; apples, up four cents, grapefruits, up four cents eachand so it goes.

title: Excitement Fuels Sambo, Touring Outdoor Show
SitIn Held to Protest Killing of 3 Workers in Granada
description: MADRID, July 22  Friends, relatives and sympathizers of three building workers shot to death by the police during a demonstration in Granada yes terday began a sitin this morn ing in the city's cathedral.

title: BUCKLEY BIDS VOICE BE TOUGH ON SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  William F. Buckley Jr., the fiery advocate of conservative caus es, said today that the Voice of America ought to be more realistic and aggressive in com mentaries on the Soviet Union even if it was diplomatically ir ritating.

title: Martin Elected to Board Of General Foods Corp.
