description: William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Re serve Board from 1951 until his retirement last Jan. 31, was elected a director of the General Foods Corporation at its annual meeting yesterday in Tarry town. N. Y.

title: MRS. E. J. SCHLESINGER
description: Mrs. Lucile Wolff Schlesinger, widow of Edwin J. Schlesinger, an investment counsel, died yes terday in Callicoon Center, N. Y. while on vacation. She was 80 years old and lived at 400 East 57th Street.

title: Hippies Flocking to. Mexico for Mushroom Trips
description: SIERRA MAZOTECA, Mexico, July 22 (Reuters)Hundreds of hippies are braving im prisonment and fines to pene trate this mushroom paradise in the State of Oaxaca, where the authorities are conducting a drive against mushroom eaters.

title: Rose Kennedy Is 80
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 22 (AP)Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy celebrated her 80th birthday today with a family lunch attended by her daughter Jean, the wife of Stephen Smith, and two grandchildren, Stephen, 13 years old, and William, 11. Mrs. Kennedy was invited here by Emperor Haile Selassie to help in the dedication tomorrow of a $1.8million library in hon or of President Kennedy.

title: Coast Police Will Test Gun That Stuns
description: The Berkeley, Calif., police hope to conduct tests soon of a new stun gun in lawen forcement situations.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Dave Meggyesy was sitting in his room talking football with a bunch of teammates when one of them asked him how much he was getting.

title: Tour Moves Into Palmer's Backyard
description: LIGONIER, Pa., July 22 The golf tour moves tomorrow into Arnold Palmer's backyard. Although Palmer lives a dozen miles away, in Latrobe, he is listed as the Laurel Valley Golf Club's touring pro. He and his partner, Jack Nicklaus, are the favorites to win the renewal of the $200,000 National four ball team championship.

title: Irish Shark Fishing Assailed by Briton
description: DUGORT, Achill Island, Ire land, July 13  As if the English and the Irish lacked enough issues to quarrel about, a controversy is devel oping between them here on Ireland's Atlantic coast over the destruction of a fish through sport angling.

title: U.S. Group Visits Kosygin
description: MOSCOW, July 22 (Reuters) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin today discussed international problems with Jerome Davis, an American sociologist and a group of United States intel lectuals, Tass the official press agency, reported. The report, which gave no details of Mr. Kosygin's remarks, was the first word here that Dr. Davis, of West Haven, Conn., and the group were in Moscow.

title: Miss Diane Richek Plans Nuptials
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., July 22The engagement of Miss Diane Richek to Rich ard Abbey, son of Henry Ab bey of Long Beach and Mrs. Shirley Abbey of Rockville Centre, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert G. Richek of Rockville Centre.

title: Reach, McClinton & Co. Elects a New President
description: At the age of 39, William Overmyer has been elected president of Reach, McClin ton & Co. And that's after only three months as execu tive vice president.

title: UNIT TO AID POLICE GETS A DIRECTOR
description: Charles H. Rogovin, who re signed in June as head of the Nixon Administration's program for assisting state and local law enforcement, has been named executive director of a new private agency to help police departments across the country improve their operations and training.

title: 2 Tie for Goss Golf Lead
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., July 22Kathy Linney of Plainfield and Mrs. James Noble of Mor ris County advanced to tomor row's final round of the Gar den State Women's Golf Association's 17th Elizabeth Goss roundrobin championship tied for the lead with 11 points apiece.

title: Fund Set Up to Accept Donations for Peruvians
description: Donations for the relief of victims of the recent earth quake in Peru are being ac cepted by a special fund set up by the Inter American Press Association in coopera tion with member newspa pers in Peru.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, marriages, births and engagements may be tele phoned to OXford 53311 until 11 P.M. in suburban offices. 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through. Friday Newark (201) MArket 33900; White Plains (914) WHite Plains 95300; Hempstead (516) IVanhoc 36660; Commack (516) 5435400: Stamford (203) 3487767.

title: White House Talk Held By Nixon and Kekkonen
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (Reuters)President Nixon and President Urho Kekkonen of Finland conferred for 90 minutes today on the outlook for a United StatesSoviet agreement on limiting strate gic armaments and proposals for an EastWest conference on European security.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA A  Plenty of blue fish, 2 to 4 pounds, being taken by jigging inshore boats from Mantoloking to Sea Girt, reports John Bogan Jr. Off shore boats chumming with mossbunkers from 17 to 21 miles east by south of Manas quan Inlet are doing well with bluefish in 5  to  14  pound class. Fluke pickings from Spring Lake to Seaside remain slim. Sea bass running in slightly better numbers from Mantoloking to Sea Girt.

title: ROSEWALL, RICHEY GAIN IN NET PLAY
description: CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP) All favorites advanced today in the Western tennis champion ships on a drizzly day when unseeded Turner Howard's up set bubble burst.

title: Tour of 7 Darien Homes
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 23 The Darien Young Women's Christian Association will benefit from a house tour here from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Tuesday. Mrs. John VanB. Aymar Jr. is chairman of the event, for which seven private homes will be opened to the public.

title: Airport Men Urge Caution by Senate On Noise of SST
description: RED BANK, N.J., July 23 The Airport Operators Council International urged today that the Senate get assurances on noise limits before authorizing further expenditures on the United States supersonic jet liner.

title: Theater: Strangers on the Stage
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, July 23Two new plays, Fernan do Arrabal's The Architect and the Emperor of the As syrians and Arnold Wes ker's The Friends, and one almost forgotten one, Shakespeare's rarely per formed Cymbeline, opened this week at the Startford Festival. It is almost a cer tainty that at present none of the three is being pro duced anywhere else in North America.

title: F.B.I. Is Reported to Find No Need for Kent Shooting
description: WASHINGTON, July 23A Justice Department analysis of the shooting incident in which four students were killed at Kent State University last May is reported to suggest that it was unnecessary for National Guardsmen to fire at the stu dents to protect themselves.

title: Article 1  No Title
Boating Outlook
description: The United States Weather Bureau issued this forecast at 8:30 P.M. yesterday for New York Harbor, Long Island South Shore and nearby coastal waters:

title: French Driver Ponders Problem Of a Fast Start in $30,000 Tro
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 23 Jean Mary, the Frenchman who will drive the favored Tidalium pelo at Roosevelt Raceway in tomorrow night's $30,000 Ro guepine Trot  the sequel to last week's $125,000 Interna tional  is not a student of Shakespeare. The chances are that if anyone mentioned Ham let to him, the man from Nor mandy, who knows next to nol English at all, probably would think in terms of an omelette.

title: Beam Confirms Remarks To Buckley About Voice
description: MOSCOW, July 23Ambas sador Jacob D. Beam said today that he had told William F. Buckley Jr. in May that he thought the Voice of America's broadcasts should have a crisper approach to get the American program across.

title: Presidential Power Urged To Adjust Federal Salaries
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) The Civil Service Commission proposed to Congress today a plan to enable the President to adjust pay scales for white col lar government workers auto matically in line with changes in the salaries pair their coun terparts in private industry.

title: New Books
description: Agnew: Profile in Conflict, by Jim G. Lucas (Award House: Scrib ners, $5.95).

title: 5 IN FIELD FINISH BY THE NUMBERS
description: Even though she stum bled slightly at the start. Princess Roycraft of the Fran lyn Stable had enough speec to win the sixfurlong feature event at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Los Angeles at New York (8:05 P.M.)Singer (73) vs. Koos man (55).

title: 17YEAROLD GIRL SETS WORLD MARK
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 23 (AP)Marilyn Neufville, 17 yearold London schoolgirl from Jamaica set a world rec ord of 51 seconds for the wom en's 400 meters at the British Commonwealth Games today and then refused to say a word about it.

title: POLICECRIME LINK IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: The Manhattan District At torney's office is investigating a network of city policemen who are controlled by orga nized crime, a highly placed law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: Washington: For the Record
ALBERT SCHILLER, GRAPHICS EXPERT
description: Albert Schiller, a retired graphics expert who created type pictures composed entirely of type ornaments, died Wednesday in. Memorial Hospi tal. He was 71 years old and Lived at 1671 54th Street, Brooklyn.

title: No Defense Cuts?
description: In a statement that points up one of the most impor tant political issues before the nation, President Nixon has made plain that he intends no significant reduc tions from the present level of defense spending.

title: ModernDance Troupe Maturing in Britain
description: OXFORD, England, July 23 The thing they said could never happen is just possibly happening. Obviously Britain was able to provide a good audience for moderndance as many American moderndance companies can testify, but the idea of indigenous modern dance companies emerging in Britain for a long time seemed at best doubtful and at worst impossible. Yet now they are beginning.

title: Bridge:
description: The death of Chancellor of the Exchequer lain MacLeod earlier this week was a loss not only to the British nation but also to the narrower world of contract bridge. Before he reached Cabinet rank in 1952 during a brilliant career as a statesman, he was a leading figure in English bridge cir cles.

title: DR. LOUIS C. CRATON, MINING GEOLOGIST
description: NEW HAVEN, July 23Dr. Louis C. Graton, a retired min ing geologist and professor emeritus of mining geology at Harvard University, died yes terday. He was 90 years old.

title: ITALIAN GIVES UP BID TO FORM A CABINET
description: ROME, July 23Italian Pre mierdesignate Giulio Andreotti admitted defeat today and re signed the conditional mandate given him to form a new center left government.

title: Eban Says That 90Day Truce Would Permit War Preparations
description: TEL AVIV, July 23Foreign Minister Abba Eban said today that while Israel stood ready to cooperate with the United Na tions to set up Arab  Israeli peace talks, a 90day ceasefire, as proposed by the United States, would only permit prep arations for renewed warfare.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: 200 of 500 Missing in Flood In India Ignored Warnings
description: DEHRA, India, July 23 (Reu ters)  Drivers of buses that were swept away by a flash flood said today that more than 200 of the 500 persons believed dead in the disaster had re fused to heed police warnings to leave the vehicles.

title: Nicklaus in Akron Series
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 23 (UPI) Jack Nicklaus will be seek ing his fourth victory in the $77,500 world series of golf here Sept. 12 and 13. He quali fied for the fourman tourney by capturing the British Open. He will be playing the 7,180 yard Firestone south course against the Masters' champion, Billy Casper; the United States Open winner, Tony Jacklin.

title: SETH M. MILLIKEN
description: Seth M. Milliken, a former vice president of Deering Milli ken Inc., textiles, 1045 Avenue of the Americas, died yesterday in a nursing home in Green wich, Conn. He was 95 years old and lived at 611 Harrison Avenue, Harrison, N. Y.

title: ADS FOR EXCEDRIN CALLED DECEPTIVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Consumer groups here have gone to court with a complaint that an advertisement for Ex cedrin, a headache remedy, was false, misleading and decep tive.

title: New York G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The Pentagon today identified 16 American servicemen as hav ing been killed in the war in Southeast Asia, including Spe cialist 4 Ross E. Bedient of Dun dee, N. Y. of the Army.

title: European Trade Group Names TopLevel Panel on American Bill
description: BRUSSELS, July 23  The Executive Commission of the European Common Market is taking an extremely serious view of the restrictive trade, bill, now on its way through Congress.

title: Wendy G. Browne, a Teacher, Fiancee of Donald Havens Jr.
description: The engagement of Miss Wendel Gilbert Browne to Donald Havens Jr. has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Gilbert Goodwin Browne of New York and Watch Hill, R. I.

title: Mediators Will Meet Both Sides in Football Dispute in Philadelphia Today
description: Despite a crossfire of threats and accusations aroused by, their labor impasse, the Na tional Football League owners' committee and the leaders of the N.F.L. Players Association have agreed to meet with Fed eral mediators today in Phila delphia.

title: Reputed Bookie Called a Friendly Type, but Elusive
description: Hugh Mulligan, believed by police officials and experts on organized crime to be a key figure in police corruption here, lives in a modest Cape Cod home in Queens, goes to sports events with important friends and is said to look like a pink cheeked King Farouk.

title: Miss Mulford, John Hover 2d Plan to Marry
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 John Mulford, a partner of the Philadelphia law firm of Drinker, Biddle & Reath, and Mrs. Mulford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Bid dle Mulford, to John Calvin Hover 2d of New York, son of John Curry Hover, a part ner of the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell, and Mrs. Hover of Short Hills, N. J.

title: Agnew Is Credited With Getting Indian Policy Past Bureaucracy
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  It is no accident that the cere monial leader of a White House delegation who arrived today in New Mexico for a tribal rite of the Taos Pueblo Indians is a 14yearold District of Co lumbia schoolgirl named Kim Agnew.

title: Man Slain in Penthouse
description: A 40yearold man was found dead last night of multiple stab wounds and a gunshot wound in the head in his penthouse apartment at 150 West 87th Street. The police, who tenta tively identified the victim as William Glanzman, declined to speculate on the motive for the killing.

title: SCHOOLS MAY AID BLACKS ON POSTS
description: The city school system is considering establishing special examination centers in Puerto Rico and in urban areas around the country to process quali fied black and Puerto Rican candidates who want to become elementary school principals here.

title: MONROE GENSLER, 63, A SALES EXECUTIVE
description: Monroe Gensler, general man ager of Forbes Advertising Company, Inc., 10 East 40th Street, died Wednesday at Long Island Jewish Hospital after a brief illness. He, was 63 years old and lived at 2520 Jill Court, Merrick, L. I.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLUMBetty. Two year; in heaven, you are so terribly missed. Always in our hearts.

title: KIMBRO DESCRIBES PANTHER SLAYING
description: NEW HAVEN, July 23 A crucial prosecution witness of fered no corroboration today of the testimony on which Bobby G. Seale, the national chairman of the Black Panther Party, has been held for allegedly ordering the murder of Alex Rackley.

title: TRADING IS QUIET IN LONDON STOCKS
description: Prices on the London stock market tended to firm slightly yesterday in continued quiet trading.

title: Stars Lose in Soccer, 21
description: ST. LOUIS, July 23 (AP) Varzim of Portugal battled hack from a 10 halftime defi cit to heat the SSt. Louis Stars, 21, tonight in a North Ameri can Soccer League match.

title: Leith Stevens of Paramount Dies After Wife's Fatal Crash
description: HOLLYWOOD, July 23 (UPI) Leith Stevens, director of television music at Paramount Studios, collapsed and died of a heart attack at his office to clay after learning that his wife. Elizabeth, had been killed in an automobile accident in the Santa Rosa Mountains near Palm Springs, Calif.

title: Substitutes for Eyes Tested by Blind
description: In New York City, a blind man taps his cane along the floor of an unfamiliar room. Suddenly a small box on his chest leaps into audible life with a click . . . click . . . click . . .

title: FOREIGNERS FEEL LEFT OUT IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, July 23  A committee of undergraduates at Hebrew University has cau tioned that foreign students half of them Americanare being made to feel too isolated from the Israeli student com munity.

title: DEPUTY SHERIFF HELD IN INQUIRY AT HOBART
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., July 23 (AP)Thomas Tongyai, an andercover sheriff's deputy known as Tommy the Trav eler, was jailed today as a material witness in the special state inquiry into disorders at Hobart College.

title: Mrs. Bettina Powell Is Wed on L.I.
description: SYOSSET, L. I., July 23 Mrs. Bettina Hollis Powell was married to John T. Haneman Jr. here tonight by Judge James A. Eisenman of the Village Court of Laurel Hollow at his home.

title: Diners Club Processing Will Be Moved to Denver
description: The Diners Club, Inc., an nounced yesterday that its elec tronic data processing opera tion will be moved from New York headquarters to its new regional office in Denver.

title: Hijacking for Blackmail
description: Arab guerrillas have provided another demonstra tion that their fanaticism recognizes neither national boundaries nor international law. By hijacking a Greek plane and threatening to blow it up with its passen gers and crew, they extorted a promise from the Greek Government to release seven Arab criminals now in an Athens jail for similar offenses. Then the hijackers released the passengers and forced the crew to fly the plane to Cairo where the guerrillas were greeted as heroes by a personal representative President Nasser.

title: 2 EXCHANGES BACK A COMPUTER PLAN
description: The governors of the New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange en dorsed yesterday a proposed computerized system aimed at sharply reducing the sale of stolen or missing securities.

title: Forest Fires in Alberta Park Threaten Whooping Cranes
description: CALGARY, Alberta, July 23 (AP)  Some 110 soldiers were sent to help fight a forest fire that was advancing on the nesting grounds of the rare whooping cranes in Wood Buf falo National Park today.

title: Armco Steel Down
Article 2  No Title
Fire Bombs Hurled In Business Area Of New Brunswick
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Friday, July 24Thirteen per sons were taken into custody last night during disorders in which windows were broken, fire bombs thrown and firemen hit with stones.

title: The New York Times Publishes A 1,949Page Index for 1969
description: The New York Times Index for 1969, summarizing in sub stantial depth virtually all news reported in The New York Times last year, has just been published.

title: Mrs. Sarraute, 70, Unwraps Old Ideas
description: PARIS  Twenty years ago Nathalie Sarraute, the French writer, composed the manifesto of le nouveau ro man (the new novel). Today the specter that haunts her is le nouveau nouveau ro man (the new new novel).

title: WILSON FILLS POSTS IN SHADOW CABINET
description: LONDON, July 23  Harold Wilson, the Labor party leader, named his shadow cabinet to day, appointing most of the 12 members to the same port folios they held before his government was defeated in the election last month.

title: Joan Bernard Is Engaged to George Zara
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., July 23Mrs. Robert B. Wil liams of Pompano Beach and John J. Bernard of Houston have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Joan Justice Bernard, to George Alexandre Zara, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael W. Zara of Huntington, L. I.

title: Department Stores Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Department of Commerce re ported today that department store sales for the latest week, ended July 18, were estimated at $652million, an increase of 3 per cent above the $632mil lion for the corresponding week of last year. Total retail store sales for the week were esti mated at $6.994billion, an in crease of 5 per cent above the 86.669billion sales for the sim ilar week last year.

title: The Hardin Follies
description: During the nearly two decades since outside critics began to question the wisdom of dumping huge quan tities of pesticides and herbicides on the nation's crops, some elements within the Agriculture Department have been stubbornly resisting reform and regulation this dubious practice. It cannot be said that any Secretary of Agriculture in recent administrations has been conspicuous for his enlightenment or energy on this issue, but surely the diehard bureaucrats have never had a department chief more agreeable to doing nothing than Secretary Hardin.

title: ILLINOIS UTILITY POSTS LOWER NET
description: The Commonwealth Edisor Company reported yesterday declines in net income for this year's first half and the 12 months ended June 30 despite increases in operating revenues.

title: 3 RIDING TITLES GO TO JANE BOSTWICK
description: CLEVELAND, July 23 (AP) Jane Bostwick of Blue Lakes Stables in Newbury, Ohio, led in today's beginners show in the 21st annual Chagrin Valley Professional Horsemen's Asso ciation Horse Show by winning three titles.

title: U.S. Agrees to Bolster Seoul's Forces
description: HONOLULU, July 23The United States has agreed to strengthen South Korea's armed forces and defense indus tries before making any sizable reduction in American troop strength in Korea, but it said today that it would proceed with some withdrawals this year.

title: F.T.C. Warns Elderly Of Sauna Bath Danger
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) Elderly or infirm persons who use sauna or steam baths may suffer adverse effects, the Federal Trade Commis sion warned today. It ordered a further study of the effects of the treatments.

title: FRITZ KORTNER,78, ACTORDIRECTOR
description: BONN, July 23Fritz Kort ner, the actor and director, died of leukemia in Munich yester day. He was 78 years old.

title: Art: A Chance to Reevaluate Archipenko's Stature
description: The sculpture of Alexander Archipenko (18871964) oc cupies a curious place in the history of modern art. Though an artist of undeni able power and originality, Archipenko never attained the status that his remark able gifts would seem to have entitled him to. He was a pioneer in several areas that are central to the esthetics of modernistic sculpture the use of socalled open form imagery, the applica tion of color as an integral part of sculptural form and especially the employment of unorthodox materials in un precedented combinations yet there has been a general reluctance to rank him among the major artists of the modern era.

title: N.A.S.D. Suspends Five And Three Counter Firms
description: The National. Association of Securities Dealers suspended three New York City overthe counter firms yesterday and took disciplinary action against five individuals for violation of its fair practice rules.

title: Opera: Filmed Carmen
description: If any opera in the world is foolproof and can't be tampered with, Bizet's Car men is the one. It has con tinuously glorious music, full fledged characterizations, and as drama it would be hard to find anything more basic and vivid.

title: Evans, Liguori, Triumph
description: MAASTRICHT, The Nether lands, July 23 (UPI)Lee Evans and Marty Liguori won two events each last night as American athletes dominated an international track and field meet.

title: Phils Lose Bowa for Month
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP)Larry Bowa, the Phila delphia Phillies shortstop, will be out of action three to four weeks because of a chip frac ture of the middle joint of a finger on his right hand. Bowa, a 25yearold rookie, injured the finger in San Francisco Tuesday.

title: Breakfast Cereal Critic
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 In a carpeted hotel hallway last December, between ses sions of the White House nutrition conference, a poor black woman stopped short. bile stares at a craggyraces man, a beard framing his chin. He looks so much like Lincoln, she said to her companion. Do you think he could be any rela tion?

title: Julie Heldman Upset
description: LEICESTER, England, July 23 (Reuters) Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., upset the American rankings by beating Julie Held man of New York, 63, 46, 75, in the semifinals of the Midland open lawn tennis tournament today.

title: Ulozas Takes Junior Title
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., July 23 James Ulozas of John P. Stevens High School was forced to an extra hole before beatin?? Dave De Rosa of Wayne Hills High today for honors in the 53d Metropolitan Golf Assoc??a tion junior championship at the Nassau Country Club. Ulozas shot a par 4 on the 19th hole after the finalists had finished 18th holes all even with 35, 3772 over the 6,463yard par 70 course.

title: NIXON IS ADVISED TO HEED STUDENTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 President Nixon's special ad viser on campus unrest urged the President today to under take serious efforts to improve his awareness of student atti tudes and to take them into account when formulating for eign and domestic policies.

title: EDWARD J. BASIS
description: Edward J. Babis, executive secretary to the vice president of the New York Stock Ex change, died Monday of cancer in his home at 7039 Juno Street, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 41 years old.

title: MIDEAST REPORT FUELS STOCK RISE
description: Hopes for an easing of ten sions in the Middle East sent stock prices into a brisk rally in the final half hour of trading yesterday.

title: Blacks on L. I. Kill Plan To House Poor Blacks
description: MANHASSET, L.I., July 23 A Federal housing program that would have enabled poor black families to own their own homes eventually has been killed by the Town of North Hempstead because of opposition from black res idents who are better off.

title: SOYBEANS STEADY AS VOLUME LAGS
description: Soybeans and soybean prod ucts remained strong in fu tures trading yesterday, but volume was slower than usual because many traders played a waiting game. The expecta tion of a report by the De partment of Agriculture on stocks on hand in all posi tions, which was released after the close made them wary.

title: Hunger Expert Says Many Dry Cereals Are Not Nutritious
description: WASHINGTON, July 23An independent expert on hunger charged today that 40 of the 60 leading dry breakfast cereals were so low in nutritional con tent that they constituted empty calories.

title: Mafia Loses Its Place In Federal Vocabulary
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI)With President Nix on's concurrence, Attorney General John N. Mitchell has told the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of In vestigation to stop using the terms Mafia and Cosa Nostra because they offend decent ItalianAmericans.

title: Nasser Accepts U. S. Plan, But Won't Yield One Inch
description: CAIRO, July 23President Gamal Abdel Nasser announced tonight that he had accepted the United States proposal for a threemonth ceasefire at the frontier with the Israelis.

title: OLIVER TO GO ALONG WITH JURY'S INQUIRY
description: The Rev. C. Herbert Oliver, chairman of the defunct gov erning board of the Ocean Hill Brownsville experimental school district in Brooklyn, said yesterday that he would cooperate with a grand jury inquiry into charges that mem bers of the new district school board were being harassed and intimidated.

title: Ulster Government Bans Parades for 6 Months
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, July 23The Northern Ireland government today banned public parades for six months in a move to ease tensions between Prot estants and Roman Catholics that have adversely affected the economy of Ulster.

title: QUICKENING SEEN IN MONEY GROWTH
description: The Federal Reserve System, which has been under heavy pressure from the Nixon Ad ministration to ease its mone tary policy further, has ap parently quickened the rate of growth of money and credit somewhat.

title: City Delays Its Decision on C ATV Policy
description: After seven hours and 75 witnesses, the Board of Esti mate last night postponed until Tuesday a decision on whether to; award two 20year cable television franchises for Man hattan.

title: MAX SLOMAN DIES; REALTY EXECUTIVE
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 23Max Sloman, chairman of the board of Bing & Bing, Inc., real estate, 119 West 40th Street, New York, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 88 Broadview Avenue.

title: BONN AND WARSAW WORKING ON TREATY
description: WARSAW, July 23West Germany and Poland began negotiations here today on the text of a treaty intended to establish formal relations.

title: Court of Inquiry Into British Strike Ends
description: LONDON, July 23A two day court of inquiry into the causes of the nationwide dock strike that has closed 40 British ports ended today as the walk out by 47,000 longshoremen entered its second week.

title: HOUSE BILL ASSISTS 4.4 MILLION JOBLESS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI)  The House approved legisla tion today that would extend unemployment benefits to 4.4 million more workers but de feated a move to cover some farm employes for the first time.

title: Lon Nol Unable to Gain Promise of Thai Troops
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 23 Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia returned to Pnompenh today after a twoday visit here that failed to produce what he soughtassurances of more ac tive Thai aid to Cambodia.

title: Last Intelsat 3 Orbited From Cape Kennedy
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 23 (UPI)The eighth and last in a series of commercial communications satellites was orbited tonight.

title: ARMY APPROVES MENINGITIS SHOT
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Army has approved a vaccine against bacterial meningitis and began using it today to halt an outbreak at Fort Dix in New Jersey.

title: PRESSMEN'S UNION AND 4 PAPERS AGREE
description: Agreement on a new con tract between Printing Press men's Union No. 2 and the publishers of the city's four major newspapers was an nounced yesterday by the union's president, William J. Kennedy.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: DIVIDEND MEETINGS TODAY

title: Lindsay and Garelik Split Over Police Investigation
description: City Council President Sanford D. Garelik, a political ally turned persistent critic of Mayor Lindsay, yesterday helped block an appropriation for the Mayor's special commission to investigate possible police corruption.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME SLIPS
description: Peace possibilities, both in Vietnam and in the Middle East, apparently fueled a rise on the American Stock Exchange yes terday. The price increases were not broadly dramatic but the index moved up to close at 20.30, up 0.08.

title: PARIS PEACE TALKS STILL MARKING TIME
description: PARIS, July 23The Vietnam peace conference went through its 76th plenary session today by marking time. It was consid ered likely to continue doing so at least until the arrival of the new United States delegate, David K. E. Bruce, on Aug. 3

title: Mrs. Dempsey's Team Wins
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 23 Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of Meadowbrook and John Hamilton of St. George's, scored 34, 3771 to win the Long Island Golf Association mixed Pinehurst championship at the Garden City County Club today. Par for the 6,379yard course is 72.

title: ARTHUR KOHLENBERG OF DATA PROCESSOR
description: BOSTON, July 23Arthur Kohlenberg of Cambridge, senior vice president of Codex Corporation, digital communica tions equipment maker, died here Sunday. He was 46 years old and had suffered from Hodgkin's disease.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JULY 24, 1970

title: DODD TO CAMPAIGN AS INDEPENDENT
description: HARTFORD, July 23Sena tor Thomas J. Dodd, a lifelong Democrat, announced today that he would campaign for reelection as an independent.

title: Optimism Found in Fur Industry
description: Stock market losses not withstanding, luxury furs are not a dead item, according to New York fur manufacturers. There is more than a glimmer of interest in all types of furs and it is reflected in an in crease in activity in New York's fur district.

title: Gas Bombs Plunge Commons Into an Uproar
description: LONDON, July 23  Shout ing Belfast! See how you like it! a demonstrator hurled two gas bombs into the packed House of Commons today, fill ing the gallery with thick white smoke and leaving members! gasping, shouting and crawling beneath benches.

title: Relations Between Administration and Fulbright Committee Near Breaking Point
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Diplomatic relations between the Nixon Administration and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, long strained by basic policy differences, are showing signs of reaching the breaking point.

title: SENATE APPROVES STIFF CRIME BILL FOR WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The Senate decisively approved today the controversial District of Columbia crime bill. The vote, 54 to 33, was far from the close outcome that critics of the measure had hoped to achieve after a week of de bate.

title: MONEY ALLOCATED FOR SLUM PROJECT
description: More than $700,000 for a program to train residents of the Brooklyn Model Cities area in the production of television programs was voted unani mously yesterday by the Board of Estimate after members ex pressed a series of reservations.

title: REFINANCING PLANS FOR KING CONTINUE
description: The King Resources Company of Denver said late yesterday that it was still working on plans to refinance some $17 million in loans due this year.

title: Big Board Is Sued Over Commissions
description: The New York Stock Ex change, the Association of Stock Exchange Firms and 43 major brokerage firms were accused of violations of the Clayton Act and the Sherman Antitrust Act in a suit filed yesterday in Federal Court here by a Cali fornia group known as the American Association of Securi ties Representatives.

title: GUARD IS ALERTED IN PEORIA CLASHES
description: PEORIA, Ill., Friday, July 24  The National Guard was placed on alert early today after a night of shooting, firebombing and rock throwing touched off by police evictions of two wo men from a black housing pro ject.

title: In Furniture The Designs Are Offbeat
description: Shapewith varying de grees of comfortis the thing in the new collection of mod ern imported furniture due on Gimbels' ninth floor on Mon day. The preponderance of unusual forms comes from France. There is, for example, an armchair rendered by a sculptor who goes under the single name of Cesar, that has a seat cushion ris ing up in a tri angular shape. If one fails to see how this is sittable, the mys tery is soon solved. The tri angle plumps down as soon as it is sat on, since the chair is made of foam and covered with a very soft black leatherlike vinyl. Why the triangle is there in the first place is answerable only by Cesar and his muse though it does have an inter esting sculptured effect. Jt is $595.

title: Americans Abandon Base As Foe Presses Buildup
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23American airborne troops hastily abandoned a hilltop ar tillery base today just north of the Ashau valley, an enemy stronghold controlling infiltra tion routes from. Laos. The ac tion was taken after heavy bombing strikes and artillery barrages failed to stop a North Vietnamese army buildup around the post.

title: Company to Pay for Oil Spill
description: UNION, N. J., July 23  The Carpenter Technology Corpora tion here has agreed to a settle ment of $500 for causing an oil spill of 7,000 gallons into the Rahway River June 5.

title: Foreign Affairs: Whose Fruits of Victory?
description: United States influence is be ing slowly squeezed out of three major areas, even if the process is but barely and tenta tively visible In one, Western Europe, not yet realized in a second, the Middle East, and still uncertain, in the third, Southeast Asia. The American people, emotionally confused by foreign policy, would do well to ponder these trends.

title: Screen: 'Darling Lili' Sets the Stage for Pure Comedy of Roman Gestures.:'Cowards' Gives War Views at the Carnegie Julie Andrews in Title Role at Music Hall
description: "Darling Lili" is a movie of heroic attitudes and romantic gestures, about a World War I British musical comedy star named Lili (Julie Andrews), who also happens to be a German spy, and the Eagle Squadron ace (Rock Hudson) whom she seduces in the cause of the Kaiser's victory.However, because the film is the work of Blake Edwards ("The Party," "What Did You Do in the War, Daddy?"), you may be sure that the heroic attitudes have been assumed for all the wrong reasons (if, in fact, they've been assumed for any reasons at all), and that the romantic gestures go disastrously awrywhich is what pure comedy is all about.There is, for example, something sweetly, intelligently insane in the sight of Lili, who spends a good deal of her time passing military secrets to men off of U-boats, leading a terrorized London theater audience through some patriotic choruses of "Pack Up Your Troubles" during a German air raid. This one brief moment is wiser, funnier and more sardonic than anything in last year's lugubriously well-meaning "Oh, What a Lovely War!""Darling Lili," which opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, is, in many ways, a pure if not perfect comedy. It is big, long, overproduced, but it has a lot of perverse charm and real cinematic beauty, especially in its scenes depicting the graceful, courtly dogfights between the Eagle Squadron ace and the notorious Red Baron.Its sense of humor moves easily from hilarious, potentially lethal slapstick (a plane crashing drunkenly through a tree) to satire of the conventions of movies. I particularly cherish a London newspaper headline that appears towards the end of the movie (and after the war), "Notorious Spy Sings for War Relief," an event that turns out to be a loving welcome home (to London) of the spy the boys had left behind them. Among other things, it's the sentimental, absolute end of the Mata Hari legend.Although Miss Andrews (the film, not stage, star) has always struck me as a very mitigated delight, she may be the perfect centerpiece for this sort of fantasy. That is, her angular, aggressive profile, combined with her coolness and precision as a comedienne and a singer, give the immediate, comic lie to the adventures of a supposedly irresistible femme fatale. She thus is immensely funny with Hudson in an extended bedroom scene in which she makes her lover, who is exhausted, try to carry her to the bed (he can't figure out how to put her down so that she faces in the right direction). If she really were sexy, it wouldn't be funny.Edwards sometimes goes too far in his admiration for the star. The film opens with a totally dark screen, in the center of which Miss Andrews slowly materializes in a stage spotlight, all glistening jewels and looking as awesome as Anapurna at sunrise. Later he gives her a comic striptease, which only goes to prove that when you take the clothes off a Girl Guide, you've got a very naked Girl Guide.She is, however, an often lovely comedienne, whether playing straight man to Hudson, when he cuts short a midnight rendezvous with a stoic reminder that "I fly at dawn," or making the regrettable decision to confess her espionage activities to the French police (a heroic gesture that only puts her lover in worse trouble).She is beautifully supported by Hudson, who is beginning to look a bit tired and overweight, and especially by Lance Percival, as a disconnected, always drunk, British flier who says thinks like "I'm glad to see you up and around, even if you're sitting down," and Andr Maranne and Jacques Marin, as two French investigators from the world of "A Shot in the Dark."Edwards has spared no expense in the film, which he shot all over France and Belgium, as well as in Hollywood. At one point, he apparently rented the chateau at Chantilly and hired 1,000 extras just for one quick, ironic scene of Lili being presented the Legion of Honor. The film grows weary from time to time, and the old, fine, schmaltzy World War I songs have been supplemented by some new, not-so-fine, schmaltzy Henry Mancini songs. It still is fun, however.As a historical note, I might also point out that "Darling Lili" is in itself the kind of romantic gesture we're not likely to see again for a very long time. It's the last of the mammoth movie musicals ("Dolly," "Paint Your Wagon") that were inspired by the success of "The Sound of Music" (and each of which cost two or three times as much as Alaska). I doubt that Hollywood, now practically broke and trying desperately to make a connection with the youth market, will ever again indulge itself in this sort of splendidly extravagant, quite frivolous enterprise.

title: Chase in Consolidation From Compton to Bates
description: Ted Bates & Co., which has shared the Chase Manhattan Bank advertising account with Compton for a decade, gets it all on Jan. 1.

title: Croninger Leaves as Head of Metromedia Radio Here
description: David C. Croninger, president of the Metromedia radio divi sion of Metromedia, Inc., has left that post effective immedi ately. Mr. Croninger had held the position since January of 1969.

title: Liberals Lose, 151 to 103
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Heeding President Nixon's crit icism of the big spenders, the House rejected today a liberal move that would have pumped $360million more into health Programs.

title: Shafer Signs Law Giving Strike Right To Public Employes
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 23 Gov. Raymond P. Shafer, while expressing misgivings and strong reservations, signed legislation today that makes Pennsylvania the first major state to give public employes a limited right to strike over wages or working conditions.

title: Walston Hayden Stone Sets Sept. 4 Merger
description: As expected, Walston & Co., and Hayden, Stone, Inc., announced yesterday the merger of the two brokerage firms into a company to be called Walston Hayden Stone, Inc.

title: PittmanPickett Triumph
description: JERICHO, LI., July 23Jerry Pittman dropped a 2foot putt for a par 4 at the third hole of a suddendeath playoff today and won the Metropolitan Golf Association proamateur tour nament with John Pickett of Creek at the Meadow Brook Club.

title: Bank Merger Set By Marine Midland
description: Banks, brokerage houses and a hotel chain figured in yes terday's major merger devel opments.

title: Knicks Get Rights to Suns' Dotson
description: The New York Knicks, looking to the future, ac quired the rights yesterday to Heyward Dotson, a Rhodes Scholar and former Colum bia star, from the Phoenix Suns for a future draft choice. The Suns had se lected Dotson on the seventh round of the college draft last March.

title: Common Market Facing A Counter Tariff by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The United States began today to strike back at the sweeping system of export subsidies of Farm products used by the Eu ropean Common Market.

title: Maylott Gets Housing Job
description: John B. Maylott was sworn in yesterday as director of the New York area office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Mr. May lott who is 61 years old, has been a Federal official for 13 years.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: City's Slumlords

title: Garden Official Says Foreman Is 18 Months From Title Bout
description: He's got as good a left hand as any heavyweight I've ever seen. He can tear a man's head off with itjust like Joe Louis used to do.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On District Crime Bill
Miss Englehorn Sets Mark With 71 in ProAm Tourney
description: OSTERVILLE, Mass., July 23 (AP)  Shirley Englehorn of Caldwell, Idaho, set a course record with a oneunderpar 71 today in the second half of the twoday proamatuer $10,000 Cape Cod Hospital golf classic at Oyster Harbors Country Club.

title: KY SEES SOME GAIN FROM U.S. PULLOUT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (UPI)  Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that the removal of American troops from Vietnam would ease his Government's problems by free ing it from political pressures brought about by stupid pacifists in the United States.

title: Producer to Head Unit of N.Y.U's Movie School
description: George C. Stoney, producer of documentary and other films, has been appointed chair man of the undergraduate department of the institute of Film and Television of New York University's School of the Arts. He will assume the post Sept. 1.

title: Hurd Confirmed as Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) The Senate confirmed by voice vote today President Nix on's nomination of John G. Hurd, a Texas rancher and oil man, as new United States Am bassador to South Africa.

title: Books of The Times
description: I grow daily to honor facts more and more, and theory less and less, wrote Thomas Carlyle to Ralph Waldo Emerson in 1836. A fact, it seems to me, is a great thinga sentence printed, if not by God, then at least by the Devil. What Ralph Nader and his band of young law yers and graduate students have provided for us is a swamp of facts, mostly printed by the Devil, about our Federal regulatory agencies. The reader is bound to get lost in this swamp, stopping here amazes, there outraged, without a compass in a world of rapacity, incompetence, collusion and criminal negligence. The reviewer wonders how to manage the facts, how to make the swamp into a comprehensible garden.

title: Common Currency In E.E.C. Expected To Affect Dollar
description: Europe's six Common Mar ket countries are growing weary of financing large Unit ed States balanceofpayment deficits and have accelerated their drive toward monetary integrationincluding a com mon currencya move that would have revolutionary implications for the status of the dollar.

title: JAZZ USED TO PRESS PAPP'S PLEA FOR AID
description: The vibrant sounds of the mobile jazz combo and cast of Sambo rocked City Hall Park yesterday as its sponsor, the New York Shakespeare Festival, made a public plea for $100,000 to complete the festival's sum mer program.

title: Auto Production Plunges
description: DETROIT, July 23 (AP) With more auto plants idle be cause of the changeover to the 1971 models, auto produc tion in the United States plunged to 56,688 units this week, compared with 117,404 last week and 58,552 in the corresponding week a year ago.

title: JAPANESE ACCUSED OF POLLUTING SEA
description: LONDON, July 23A British shipping official accused the Japanese today of being the worst offenders in polluting the world's sea lanes.

title: Odd Setting for Chinese Food
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Kissinger Declares ABM Key to Gains At Vienna Parley
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, told a Congressional group today that the United States must proceed with de ployment of a missile defense system to insure progress in negotiations with the Soviet Union on the control of stra tegic arms.

title: Lacey to Expand Investigations in Jersey
description: NEWARK, July 23  United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey said today that further investigations of Newark city af fairs will be undertaken as a result of material which has come to our attention during the prosecution of former Newark Mayor Hugh J. Ad donizio and other city officials.

title: Capital Sees Exodus to Coast as a Signal by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 President Nixon is heading west again tomorrow, with much of the United States Government in tow. This is news, quite apart from the serious economic and political. business to be considered in California. For in the sign language of the capital and of his own official fam ily, Mr. Nixon is News saying that he Analysis does not want to pass another sum mer in isolation. He does not wish again to leave the impression that only a few White House nobles have ac cess to the remote throne room in the castle at San Clemente or that a whole year's worth of policy is being ratified on the links with only Attorney Gen eral John N. Mitchell in at tendance.

title: EMBARGO ON ARMS TIGHTENED BY U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23The United Nations Security Council approved a tightened arms embargo against South Africa today because of its racialseparation policies.

title: PARSONS GIVES UP ACTIVE BANK ROLF
description: Donald H. Parsons, the fast moving Michigan lawyer and entrepreneur who in six years assembled a banking empire with about $3billion in assets, announced yesterday that he was pulling out of active man agement of his enterprise.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Friday, July 24, 1970

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Herman Hickman, an unrecon structed rebel from Tennessee, was head coach of football at Yale he decided to protect his flank one season by bringing in as his assistant another flower of the Confederacy, Douglas Clyde Walker. Since Yale was Yale, the nickname the new coach had borne for 40 years was almost never mentioned. Herman always referred to his long time eatin' and drinkin' com panion as D.C.

title: Brazil Denies Torture Charge
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 23 (Reuters)Brazil today reject ed accusations by the Geneva based International Commission of Jurists that prisoners in Brazil were tortured and de nied that there were any political prisoners here.

title: GOLDBERG ENDORSED BY STEEL WORKERS
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, the Dem ocraticLiberal candidate for Governor, was endorsed yes terday by the New York State district of the United Steel workers of America, which four years ago supported Governor Rockefeller.

title: COAST SENATE BACKS DRASTIC SMOG CURB
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 23 (UPI)  The California Stated Senate, which last year passed a bill outlawing the internal combustion engine, today ap proved one even more drastic.

title: Laird Predicts Draft Calls Will Fall to 10,000 a Month
description: WASHINGTON, July 23De Tense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today that draft calls for the rest of 1970 would return to preVietnam levels of under 10,000 a month.

title: Kathy Linney Triumphs
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 23Kathy Linney of Plainsfield won the 17th annual Elizabeth Goss roundrobin tournament today with a threeround point total of 17 at the Somerset Hills Country Club. The par72 course measured 5,640 yards.

title: World Bank Gets $200Million By Selling a Bond Issue in U. S.
description: The International Bank for Reconstruction and Develop ment, after an absence from the capital markets in the United States of almost two years, raised $200million yes terday by selling a bond issue priced to yield 8 per cent.

title: Con Edison to Get T.V.A. Power to Ease the Critical Shortage Here
description: The Tennessee Valley Au thority will make available to Consolidated Edison several hundred thousand kilowatts of power, normally used by the Atomic Energy Commis sion to ease the critical power shortage in New York City caused by the breakdown of Con Edison's largest gen erator. The official announce of Con Edison's largest gen erator. The official announce ment of the plan to guarantee the utility the right to pur chase the power came from the White House yesterday afternoon. Both the commis sion and the T. V. A. are Gov ernment agencies. Although arrangements are not expect ed to be completed before next week, the bulk of the power is to be diverted from that supplied to the A.E.C. by T.V.A. generating plants. The initial disclosure that Consoli dated Edison was acting on a suggestion from David Free man, director of the White House energy policy staff, to negotiate with the country's largest public power com pany, was made by William E. Wall, vice presidentpublic affairs, at a public news conference at the utility's plant in Ravenswood, Queens. The Ravenswood facility houses Big Allis, the utility's disabled millionkilowatt gener ator. The White House an nouncement said that several hundred megawatts would be made available. A spokesman for the energy policy staff, which is part of the President's, office of science and technol ogy, said the total was likely to be between 200,000 and 300, 000 kilowatts.

title: Miss Agnew Arrives
description: SANTA FE, N. M., July 23 (UPI)Kim Agnew visited a museum today as she opened her New Mexico visit.

title: AllBreed Match Show Set
description: An allbreed match show and obedience trial will be held on Sunday by the Brookhaven Kennel Club at the North Bell port Recreation Field, North Bellport, L. I. Entries will be taken from 10 A. M., with judging at 11.

title: Menus for Weekend Cooks
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: DEUTERON TAKES NAVIGATION TEST
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 23 Vincent C. Hall's custombuilt 60footer Deuteron and Roland Voorhees's 42foot Matthews Tyche were winners of predict edlog events that began the annual New York Yacht Club Cruise in a small way today and yesterday.

title: New Penn Central Trustees Hold Their First Meeting
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP)  The four trustees named to supervise the Penn Central Transportation Com pany in its reorganization un der the Federal bankruptcy laws held their first meeting today with the judge who selected them.

title: CONSUMER PLANS FOR BUYING WANE
description: Buying sentiment among American consumers was at a low ebb during May and June, according to the National In dustrial Conference Board.

title: 6 Arab Hijackers of Greek Jet Plan News Conference in Cairo
description: CAIRO, July 23 (Reuters) Six Arab commandos, includ ing a blond girl and her brother, spent a quiet day in Cairo to day after their hijacking of a Greek airliner yesterday, Pale stinian sources said.

title: Burns Sees Job Increase in '71; House Bars a Health Fund Rise
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that it was his hope and expectation that the nation's economy would return to full employment some time in 1971.

title: Embarrassing Inaction
description: President Nixon earned considerable domestic and foreign applause last November when he announced his decision to seek Senate ratification of the Geneva protocol banning first use of chemical and biological weapons. The failure of the United States to endorse the 1925 treaty, which Americans helped draft, has been an international disgrace for 45 years.

title: GOLF FINAL GAINED BY MRS. DOPPELT
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 23 Mrs. Mandel Doppelt of Brae Burn won on the 22d hole from Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill at the Burning Tree Country Club today to reach the final of the 26th annual Women's TriCounty Golf As sociation championship.

title: METE BACK HOME IN 12GAME STAND
description: The Mets and Yankees passed each other at 35,000 feet yes terday, hoping that they could regain some momentum on the ground and start passing teams in their respective divisions.

title: 2 POLICEMEN BEATEN NEAR HEADQUARTERS
description: One policeman suffered a fractured skull when he and a colleague, both in civilian clothes, were assaulted by a group of teenagers near Police Headquarters last night.

title: Miss Stulller Gains Final
description: SYRACUSE, July 23 (AP) The defending champion, Sara Jane Stuhler, and Chris Grygiel, medalist, survived today's semifinals and will meet tomor row for the New York State junior girls' title at the Tusca rora Golf Club.

title: New Plan on Hudson Crossings: No Toll West, Double Toll East
description: In an effort to speed traffic and cut labor costs, three trans portation agencies said yester day that they would introduce oneway toll collections Aug. 12 on nine Hudson River bridges and tunnels and three crossings between Staten Island and New Jersey.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE FELL 0.1% IN WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended July 18 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

title: Agnew Introduces Jumbo Jet Hailed as Larger, Cleaner and Quieter
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 23 (UPI) Vice President Agnew introduced today the McDonnellDouglas DC10 Trijet. The plane was hailed as larger, cleaner and quieter.

title: Park Sees Critical Period
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 23 President Chung Hee Park said today South Korea was op posed to a reduction of United States forces in Korea now be cause the next four or five years will be the most critical period for our national secur ity. He was speaking at the graduation ceremony of Korea's War College here.

title: FAIRMOUNT OARSMEN GAIN REGATTA LEAD
description: ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, July 23 (Canadian Press)Oars men and scullers from the Fair mont Rowing Association of Philadelphia put together a vic tory and two second places to day in the opening events of the 88th Royal Canadian Henley Regatta.

title: FORD SALES RISE; PROFIT SLIDES 8%
description: DETROIT, July 23The Ford Motor Company today reported record June  quarter sales but an 8 per cent drop in profits and warned of serious conse quences if the United Auto Workers win an excessive settlement in its new contract.

title: Laura Snyder Plans Nuptials
description: WINNETKA, Ill., July 23 Mr. and Mrs. John T. Snyder Jr., formerly of Pelham Man or, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Jenkins Snyder, to Stephen Hunter Morris. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Morris of Providence. R. J.

title: City Halts Eviction in Housing Set for Razing or Renovation
description: In response to rising tensions over the city's housing short age, the Lindsay administration called a temporary halt yester day to evictions by landlords who want to demolish or reno vate structurally sound, rent controlled buildings.

title: Stricken Yemen Gets Food
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 23Emergency food is being sent to Yemen to care for 1,500,000 people hard hit by droughts. The aid is being provided by the World Food Programa joint undertaking of the United Nations and the Food and Agriculture Organi zation.

title: Ayub's SoninLaw Held
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 23 Majibbullah Khan, soninlaw of the former President Mo hammad Ayub Khan was ar rested yesterday in the murder of Yaro Khan, a relative of his, and another person. The arrest was made in Hazara, the home district of the former Presi dent who was deposed in March, 1969.

title: Young French Radicals Seek to Spoil Vacations for Bourgeoisie
description: PARIS, July 23  Here and there on the French vacation scene, small bands of young New Left revolutionaries are trying to make good their warn ing that they intend to spoil the summer pleasures of the bourgeoisie.

title: 12 Insurance Concerns Form Investigative Unit
description: CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) The casualty insurance in dustry announced the forma tion of an organization today to investigate fraudulent in surance claims. It will give priority attention, to automo bile accident rings.

title: Sleuth Gets a Director
description: Clifford Williams has been signed by Helen Bonfils, Mor ton Gottlieb and Michael White to direct the New York produc tion of Sleuth, the Anthony Shaffer mystery drama co starring Anthony Quayle and Keith Baxter, which opens at the Music Box on Nov. 12. Mr. Williams directed the original London production.

title: U.S. PARAPLEGICS PACED BY MISS HIXON
description: STOKE MANDEVILLE, Eng land, July 23 (AP)The United States is now a close second to Britain in the medals count of the Paraplegic Olympic Games, which end tomorrow.

title: Draft Deferments Called Major Motivation at R.O.T.C. Camp
description: FORT KNOX, Ky., July 23 They're an outstanding bunch of young men, the general said. Well motivated, always smiling. Always moving.

title: YEARLING, KALKUN WIN YACHT RACES
description: CUTTYHUNK, Mass., July 23 Eugene W. Carder's Hughes 38foot sloop, Yearling, out of Stamford (Conn.) Yacht Club, was the Division I winner on the 39th annual American Yacht Club Cruise today when a fleet of 35 raced 34 miles from Block Island to Cutty hunk. With a second place and a first, Yearling had 2 points and a 6point lead for the title in the cruise series which ends tomorrow with a 24mile race to Jamestown, R.I.

title: Saint Laurent, Ungaro and Dior Many Styles, No New Look
description: PARIS, July 23It was the kind of clay when many people following the fashion showings here wished they were in another line of work. Three of the couture's big gest guns blasted off. Where the shots landed, nobody was Quite sure.

title: RONAN IS REVISING SUBWAY'S RULES
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that the city's sub way system's safety rules would be changed today to pro hibit any movement of a train on a red signal unless specifi cally authorized.

title: Martin Birnbaum Is Dead at 92; Art Dealer, Traveler and Writer
description: Martin Birnbaum, art dealer, friend of artists and confidant of the rich and the celebrated, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 92 years old.

title: Roundup: Pappas of Cubs Haunts Reds With Shutout
description: If Milt Pappas is remem bered for nothing else, he always will be recalled as the key player of the three Cincinnati wanted so badly that they wrapped up Frank Robinson in a pretty ribbon and gave him away to Balti more.

title: Laos Declares Emergency in South
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 23 (Agence FrancePresse)The Laotian Government has pro claimed a state of emer gency, effective today, in the nation's six southern prov inces, the official press agency announced today.

title: Accused Numbers Operator Says She Paid Detective
description: An admitted numbers opera tor testified today that she paid a detective $200 on the first of each month from the summer of 1967 until after she was arrested the following March. She was a prosecution witness at the Bronx Supreme Court perjury trial of a sus pended detective, Eugene God dard.

title: Personality Assigned 126 Pounds for Monmouth Handicap Aug. 8
description: OCEANPORT, N. J. July 23  The top thoroughbreds of 3yearold division, including Personality, High Echelon and Dust Commader, were among the high weights issued today for the $300,000 Monmouth Handicap on Aug. 8. The top dozen receive automatic invita tions to the event at Monmouth Park.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
African Nations Protest
description: LONDON, July 23Three Af rican nations, angered over Britain's decision to consider a resumption of arms sales to South Africa, sent a message of protest today to the British Government.

title: CITY CONSULTANT GETS $700 A DAY,
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame told the Board of Esti mate yesterday that the city had privately agreed to pay outside individual consultants rates as high as $500 and $700 a day.

title: SOVIET IRKS U.S. BY AID TO LIBYA
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 The United States today de clared its serious concern over the first Soviet arms shipments to Libya at a time of delicate peace initiatives in the Middle East.

title: EDWIN S. MALESKY
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 23 Edwin S. Malesky, a consultant at the Personnel Laboratory, Inc., Stamford died here today.

title: Market Place
description: You're a stockholder and you like to attend annual meetings. What kind of man impresses you with the gavel?

title: 10,000METER RUN TAKEN BY SHORTER
description: LENINGRAD, July 23The Soviet Union track and field team today survived rain, de risive hooting from its own fans and intermittent flashes of speed from the opposition and took the lead over the United States in the first day of a dual meet.

title: Excerpts From Memorandum to Nixon and a Note on Unrest
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Following are excerpts from a memorandum from Dr. Alex ander Heard, chancellor of Vandeibilt University, to Pres ident Nixon, summarizing what the temporary adviser to the White House learned about student attitudes to ward the Nixon Administra tion, and from a note on the recommendations of Dr. Heard and a coadviser, Dr. James Cheek, president of Howard University, regarding campus unrest:

title: Robert Starkey, Travel Aide, Marries Mrs. Elizabeth A. Fay
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Allen Fay of Huntington, L. I., widow of Richard Hull Fay, who was a radio engineer with the Columbia Broadcasting System, was married here at noon yesterday to Robert Starkey of Westport, Conn., a vice president of the Ask Mr. Foster Travel Service here.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES FOOD STAMP CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) The House Agriculture Com mittee attached to the food stamp program today new re strictions including work re quirements and minimum pay ments for recipients.

title: 20 Areas in City Expected To Suffer Housing Losses
description: WASHINGTON, July 23A New York City housing official said today that the problem of abandoned housing, now larg ely confined to Harlem, the South Bronx and the Browns ville and East New York section of Brooklyn, was threatening to turn 20 other city neighborhoods into verit able ghost towns.

title: Peonage in the Fields
description: Once again the nation's attention has been drawn to the appalling conditions that exist among its most exploited and miserable workers  migratory farm laborers. This time it is a group of physicians who visited these peons in Florida, Texas and Michigan who have been recounting the horrors they saw to the Senate Subcommittee on Migratory Labor. As medical men, they have been focusing on the sick nesses that plague the workers as a result of their abysmal poverty, poor housing and lack of medical care.

title: Nicklaus and Palmer Take Lead in Team Golf With a 61
description: LIGONIER, Pa., July 23 If Jack Nicklaus can win the Brit ish Open on his own score, what can he do when he has Arnold Palmer as a partner?

title: Future Shock: The Stress of Great, Rapid Change
description: Technology is both hero and villain of Future Shock, a new book by Alvin Toffler that has stirred interest in the pub lishing world even before it has reached the bookstores.

title: URBAN AIDE PICKED FOR POST ON F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Sherman Edward Unger, the general counsel of the Depart ment of Housing and Urban Development and an aide in Richard M. Nixon's political campaigns since 1960, will be the President's next nominee to the Federal Communications Commission, the White House announced today.

title: Henry J. Taylor Marries an Artist
description: Henry J. Taylor, syndicated columnist and former Ambas sador to Switzerland, and Marion Janet Elizabeth (Rikki) Richardson, an artist, were married in Paris in a civil ceremony on July 3. The couple returned to New York last week aboard the France, after a week in Deauville, France.

title: Tumor Costs Pearson an Eye
description: OTTAWA, July 23Former Prime Minister Lester B. Pear son had his right eye removed in an operation yesterday, the Ottawa General Hospital dis closed tonight. Dr. JeanJacques Laurier, the hospital's medical director said the eye had been removed because of a tumor. The former Liberal leader, aged 73, was said to be in excel lent condition.

title: 13 WEATHERMEN INDICTED IN PLOTS
description: DETROIT, July 23A Federal grand jury today indicted 13 persons, including the leaders of the Weatherman, on charges of conspiring to bomb and kill. Ten of the 13 are already being sought on fugitive warrants in other Federal or local cases.

title: U.S. ENCOURAGED BY JERSEY TRIAL
description: TRENTON, July 23  The conviction of Hugh J. Addoni zio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other defendants on all 64 counts each of extortion and conspiracy by a Federal jury last night has encouraged the Government in its prosecu tion of the other men accused in the case.

title: Miss Bastanchury Gains Western Golf Semifinals
description: ROCKFORD, Ill.,July 23 (AP)  Jane Bastanchury, the de fender, and Martha Wilkinson joined Mrs. Paul Dommers and Melanie Schiller in the semi finals of the 70th annual wom en's Western amateur tourna ment today.

title: Rates Drop for Treasury Bills At Government's Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: Earnings Mixed in Oil Industry; McDonnell's Profit Off Sharply
description: The oil industry continued yesterday to turn in mixed, gen erally lower earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

title: Advertising: SSC&B Marks Its 25th Year
description: SSC&B quietly celebrated its 25th anniversary the other Friday by giving its people a couple of hours off. You can't celebrate much more quietly than that.

title: That Crunchy Wunchy Stuff They Call Breakfast Food: Housewives' Opinions
description: Some were furious, and others were unaware that there was a tempest in the breakfast bowl. And then there were those who shugged their shoulders and asked, So what else is new?

title: HISS JACKSON RIDES HORSE SHOW DOUBLE
description: CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP) Suzie Jackson of Wilmington, Del., gained both championship and reserve honors of Section A of the junior hunter division today at the 21st annual Cha grin Valley Professional Horse men's Association Show. She rode Sudha Quill and Ambi tions to the victories.

title: $100,000 Stakes to Highlight Jersey, Chicago Racing Today
description: A pair of $100,000plus races at Monmouth Park and Arlington Park spice today's racing program with Untiy Hall and Corn Off the Cob the favorites.

title: T. R. Kinney to Wed Brenda J. Carlson
description: CHAPPAQUA. N. Y., July 24Miss Brenda Jean Carl son and Dr. Thomas Roberts Kinney who were graduated last month respectively from the School of Law and School of Medicine of Duke Uni versity will be married on Aug, 29 in Bedford.

title: CocaCola Will Improve Status Of Its Migrant Farm Workers
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) The president of one of the largest orange juice processors, CocaCola, condemned today the treatment of its migrant farm workers. He told a Senate subcommittee that his company would improve the workers' lot.

title: Roundup: Reds' Granger Buries ExMates Again
description: Wayne Granger was un happy when the St. Louis Cardinals traded him to Cin cinnati in 1968. Now it's the Cardinals who are unhappy.

title: Puerto Rican Bank Here Stresses Public Service
description: It's surprising how Puerto Ricans like to save money, prominent banker remarked here the other day.

title: Anaconda to Spend 100Million To Increase Aluminum Capacity
description: The Anaconda Company, major copper producer, an nounced yesterday that it would spend more than $100 million to increase the capacity of its aluminum subsidiary by at least 60 per cent.

title: Canada Announces Plan to End Uranium Stockpiling Program
description: OTTAWA, July 24  The Government announced plans today to end its $100million uraniumstockpiling program designed to support the indus try producing this fissionable material used in creating atom ic energy.

title: WNEW Concert Tomorrow
description: David Van Ronk, the folk singer, and Ten Wheel Drive, a soulrock group, will be pre sented in a free concert at the Central Park Mall at 2 P.M. tomorrow. Billed as Another Party in the Park, this will be the second annual Central Park event sponsored by Metro media Stereo WNEWFM.

title: FIRES AND SHOOTING RESUMED IN PEORIA
description: PEORIA, III., July 24 (AP) Fires and sporadic shooting flared briefly for a second con secutive night tonight on the predominantly black Near South Side of Peoria, the police said.

title: Valiant, Weatherly Withdrawn From N. Y.Y. C.'s Cruise Today
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 24 Boatwatchers who had hoped to see Valiant race Weatherly here tomorrow on the opening program of the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise will have to wait for another opportunity.

title: Squatters Put Life Into Ellis Island
description: Sixtytwo persons, many of them former convicts and for mer drug addicts, have taken over the abandoned brick buildings of Ellis Island, which they are busily refur bishing as part of their plan to turn the island into a re habilitation center for 2,500 people.

title: Hearings Slated in Jackson
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The President's Commission on Campus Unrest will hold three days of public hearings next month in Jackson, Miss., where two black youths were killed at Jackson State College by state troopers last May, it was announced today.

title: Choking Smog Hits Tokyo
description: TOKYO, July 24 (Reuters) Residents of western Tokyo were warned to stay indoors today as a cloud of choking smog settled over the city. By early afternoon at least 281 people had received hospital treatment for sore eyes and throats.

title: CHEMISTS PROPOSE REVISED TEACHING
description: ASPEN, Colo., July 24 Leaders in chemistry teaching and research from the United States and abroad, after four days of intensive discussion, have agreed that training in their science, from grade school to graduate school, is seriously deficient.

title: Granada's Labor Protesters End SitIn and City Is Almost Normal
description: GRANADA, Spain, July 24 The line of old men was back on the railings behind Granada's curly, biscuitcolored cathedral this morning. The nearby pas sageways were thronged with pedestrians once more.

title: A NEW ABM DRIVE BEGUN BY STENNIS
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI)Warning that the So viet nuclear threat grows ever more serious, Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Missis sippi began today the difficult campaign of winning Senate approval for an expansion of the antiballistics missile sys tem.

title: Israeli Says Nasser Bars Part of Plan
description: JERUSALEM, July 24  An Israeli Cabinet Minister charged today that President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic appeared to accept United States peace proposals but was actually ac cepting what coincided with his own policy and rejecting the rest.

title: Aide to U. S. Delegation at U. N. Quits Over Policy Differences
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., JULY 24  A 29yearold For eign Service officer has re signed his position on the United Stales delegation, say ing that he could no longer support American policies.

title: Cambodia Monsoon: Rain, Mud, Misery
description: KIRIROM, CambodiaEven in times of peace, the three months of the Asian monsoon brings special problems. The great inundation covers the lower levels of the countryside, soaking into the soft earth and welling up above its surface. The dirt roads become impassable for vehicles, restricting travel to villagers on foot and to plodding oxen. When war comes, the problems are magnified thousandfold. The battle that has been raging around Kirirom, 50 miles west of Pnompenh, provides a good case in point, as these photographs illustrate.

title: Milwaukee Road Off
description: The Milwaukee Road report ed yesterday a loss of 84,730, 137 in the second quarter of 1970 compared with a loss of $3,076,385 in the similar a year ago. The rail lines operating revenues advanced during the quarter to $72,094,488 from 68.792,246 in 1969.

title: Mets Top Dodgers, 21, as Agee Steals Home in 10th
description: Upsetting the umpire and catcher, but certainly not the 53,657 fans, Tommie Agee stole home last night in the 10th in ninng and the Mets skipped off the field with a 21 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended July 21:

title: U.S. Planes Blast an Abandoned Base Area Near Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 24 (AP)United States fighterbombers today attacked North Vietnamese positions around an abandoned Ameri can artillery base on a moun tain in the far north and struck repeatedly at the sum mit to destroy anything of value left behind.

title: Other Arab Reaction
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 Strong objection to President Nasser's move came from the leftist Government of Iraq and the Palestinian guerrilla move ment.

title: Dance: Latest by Robbins
CHARLES L. HOTCHKISS
description: Charles Lee Hotchkiss, a former New York advertising man, died Thursday in Middle sex Memorial Hospital, Middle town, Conn. He was 62 years old and lived in Essex, Conn.

title: VARNISH CONCERN TAKES BELGIAN BID
description: Much of the merger activity yesterday turned toward West Germany. In Everkusen, Far benfabriken Bayer, A.G., de clined comment on an an nouncement that directors of In ternational Coating Materials, N.V., had recommended accept ance of the Petrofina, S. A., group's bid to shareholders of the Dutch varnish maker de spite an apparently higher of fer by Bayer.

title: FLORENCE W. GOLDIN, AD AGENCY OFFICIAL
description: Mrs. Florence Weltfish Gold in, consultant and until recent ly vice president of Grey Advertising Inc., 777 Third Avenue, died of cancer yester day at her home, 185 West End Avenue. Her age was 65. Mrs. Goldin was the widow of Dr. Samuel Goldin, a dentist.

title: 3 Subsidiaries to Be Sold By National Environment
description: The National Environment Corporation, a small conglome rate based in Orange, Calif., announced yesterday plans to sell three of its subsidiaries in the foods and beverages fields in order to solve its serious liquidity problems. It was also disclosed that Elmer C. Sproul, who founded the company, was named president and chief executive officer, replacing Henry E. Clarke Jr., who re signed. Mr. Sproul had been serving as chairman.

title: HEMPSTEAD SCHOOL DESTROYED BY FIRE
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 24 A fire, said by the Nassau County police to be of suspici ous origin, virtually destroyed the threestory main building of Hempstead High School today.

title: MGM Reports Profit; Zenith Down
description: MGM Reports Profit; Zenith Down

title: Executive Changes
description: Herman E. Anstatt Jr. has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Electronic Assist ance Corporation.

title: JESSE SHWAYDER OF SAMSONITE DIES
description: DENVER, July 24 (AP) Jesse Shwayder, a mining camp youth who formed the Samsonite Corporation, died at his home here today at the age of 88.

title: Red Cross Scored P.O.W.Treatment In Con Son Prison
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Representatives of the Inter national Red Cross have pro tested the treatment of pris oners of war by the South Vietnamese Government. An inspection report shows that they told Saigon that its treat ment of seven of 24 North Vietnamese soldiers at the Con Son Prison violated the Geneva Convention on pris oners of war.

title: ALLEN, WITH 213, LEADS STATE GOLF
