description: ROCHESTER, July 24 (AP) Don Allen of Rochester, twice state amateur champion and twice a member of the Walker Cup team, took a twostroke lead today in the New York State amateur golf tournament with a twounderpar 70.

title: Article 5  No Title
New Chance for Home Rule
description: As one who has suffered at the hands of state gov ernments unsympathetic to the cause of city home rule, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner is an appropriate choice to head Governor Rockefeller's new State Com mission on the Powers of Local Government. Doubtless there are political overtones in a Republican Gover nor's selection of a Democrat and even in the crea tion of such an agency in an election year. But what is important is the fact that the cities of the state are to have another chance at prying greater powers of selfgovernment out of a reluctant Legislature.

title: WNDT TO CANCEL ITS NEWSFRONT
description: WNDTTV, Channel 13, the city's public television station, will cancel its Newsfront in September after five years on the air to make way for com munityparticipation programs.

title: PERSONALITY 2D TO BOLD FAVORITE
description: The feature event on yester day's card at Aqueduct saw the return to competition of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Person ality, the winner of the Preak ness on May 16 and the Jersey Derby on Memorial Day in his previous two starts. The crowd of 28,818 made Personality the oddson favorite despite the fact that he was the only 3 yearold against four older rivals.

title: Glen Cove Puts Off Tax Sale of Estate Of the Soviet Union
description: The Mayor of Glen Cove, L. I., agreed yesterday to postpone for 30 days a taxlien sale of the Soviet Union's 38acre es tate after the United Stales pointed out that the property was taxexempt under existing treaties.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Saturday, July 25, 1970

title: MIDDLE UTILITIES LISTS GAIN IN NET
description: Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries has reported firsthalf operating revenues of: $202,351,693, a gain of 11.6 per cent over the $181.322,258 reported a year ago. Net in come of $21.882,425, equal to 59 cents a share, ran 23.4 per cent ahead of the $17,735,902, or 50 cents a share, in the like period of 1969. Sales of elec tricity rose by 8.5 per cent in the like period of 1969. Sales of electricty rose by 8.5 per cent in the period. Middle South Utilities is a holding company with operating subsidiaries in parts of Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi.

title: AUSSIE FOUR SETS WORLD SWIM MARK
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 24 (AP)Australia set a world record in the men's 800meter freestyle relay tonight at the British Commonwealth Games.

title: ODETTA SINGS BLUES; FOURTH WAY ON BILL
description: The Jazz in the Garden series at the Museum of Modern Art served up an odd coupling on Thursday eveningOdetta, the artful, robustvoiced folk and blues singer, and the Fourth Way, an electric quartet that mingles jazz, country music and rock.

title: German Airline Is Suing Bonn To Gain Scheduled U. S. Flights
description: BONN, July 24  Atlantis Airways, the only West Ger man charter airline serving the United States and Europe, has brought a court action against the Bonn Government for its refusal to designate the company a scheduled carrier for lowcost transAtlantic serv ice.

title: Censured Company Protests the Finding Of Waterfront Unit
description: CC Lumber, Inc., the port's largest marine carpentry con cern, has charged that a Wa terfront Commission proceed ing aimed at revoking its li cense was conducted without regard to law.

title: Airport Project in North Worries Aides in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16  Senior American and South Vietnamese planners are concerned over the implications of a very large airfield report ed to be under construction in the southern section of North Vietnam.

title: ALFRED N. WHEELER
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 24Al fred N. Wheeler, a retired vice president of the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company, died last night at his home on South Trail. His age was 71.

title: Chart on Breakfast Cereals Erred on Vitamin Contents
description: A rating chart of the nutri ents contained in 60 breakfast cereals published yesterday in The New York Times was inac curate in one respect.

title: JOSEPH SHAW FINLEY
description: Joseph Shaw Finley, for many years with the Hearst or ganization advertising depart ment, died yesterday at his home. 333 East 69th Street. after a long illness. His age was 55.

title: Peking Reported Set to Name Ambassador for Warsaw Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 United States officials have re ceived word from friendly dip lomats that Communist China is preparing to upgrade its diplomatic representation to the ambassadorial level in Warsaw, site of the periodic meetings between American and Chinese diplomats.

title: 3 Blacks in the House Admonish Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  Three black Congressmen, un happy because the President has been unwilling to meet with them for five months, released today a joint letter to him saying the patience of many black Americans is exhausted.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The North American Rock well Corporation has been awarded an Air Force contract valued at $65,689,000, accord ing to an announcement from the office of Senator George Murphy, Republican of Califor nia. The contract covers pro duction of guidance and con trol systems for the Minuteman III Missile.

title: U.S. AID DWINDLES ON BASIS OF G.N.P.
description: PARIS, July 24 (AP)The United States last year con tributed a smaller part of its gross national product than any other industrialized na tion to help the world's devel oping countries, the Organiza tion for Economic Cooperation and Development reported to day.

title: Courrges Proves a Hero on 2 FrontsFashion and Prices
description: PARIS, July 24  They didn't bother with the bra vos. As the audience crowd ed around Andre Courrges after his showing in the tiny salon at 40 Rue Franois Premier, they cried fervently, enfin moderne.

title: GIRL IS HELD IN BAIL ON BOMBING CHARGE
description: An employe of the Neighbor hood Youth Corps here was held in $50,000 bail yesterday on charges that she conspired with a dozen other alleged members of the militant Weath erman group to kill policemen and bomb certain targets.

title: State Recreation Chief Sworn In at Ceremony
description: New York State's first Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, Dr. Sal J. Pre zioso, was sworn in yester day at the Gotham Hotel's Palace Ballroom.

title: Keyes Injures Foot
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (UPI)  Leroy Keyes, double duty backfield star of the Phil adelphia Eagles, tore his right Achilles tendon while playing basketball and will miss at least six weeks of training.

title: SENATORS' INQUIRY INTO CRIME GOES BEYOND THE MAFIA
description: A new investigation into the structure and activities of or ganized crime in the United Statesspecifically not limited to the highly publicized Mafia, or Cosa Nostrahas been initi ated by the Senate Subcommit tee on Investigations.

title: Miss Bastanchury to Meet Mrs. Dommers in Golf Final
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., July 24 (AP) Jane Bastanchury and Mrs. Paul Dommers will meet to morrrow in a 36hole final of the 70th annual Women's West ern amateur golf tournament over the 6,346yard Rockford Country Club course.

title: Bridge:
description: Sometimes the defenders can make an accurate guess about the declarer's distribu tion. At other times they have no chance, as on the diagramed deal.

title: LEHIGH LINE ASKS REORGANIZATION
description: The Lehigh Valley Railroad, an independently operated but 97 per cent controlled subsidi ary of the Penn Central Trans portation Company, followed its parent into reorganization yes terday under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy laws.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Call OX 53311

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Los Angeles at New York (2:15 P.M.)Foster (68) vs. Sadecki (73).

title: At Stake in Colombia
description: President Carlos Lleras Restrepo of Colombia has called the bluff of the followers of the former dictator, Gustavo Rojas Pinilla. Despite their violent tactics, he has convened the new Congress on schedule. There seems little doubt that Mr. Lleras will be able to trans fer power to his elected successor, Misael Pastrana Borrero, on Aug. 7, as provided by law, even if Colom bia remains under a state of siege.

title: Out of Order
description: Several months ago a New Yorker dispatched a tele gram from his Manhattan office 10 his wife's grammar school class on Staten Island to demonstrate one aspect of modern communications, which the class was then studying.

title: Dance: Kirov in London
description: LONDON, July 24Classic ballet has many children but only one cradle. The cradle is St, Petersburg (the mother was French and the father Italian) and from there every thing we know in classic dance originates. Smart peo ple in Moscow, in New York and in London have made unusual use of their St. Pe tersburg legacy. Yet once in a while St. Petersburg itself sallies forth to show us our beginnings. And if we in the dance world are sensible, we feel humble, even when we occasionally criticize.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Mickey Mantle hit 536 home runs in the major leagues 373 of them lefthanded, 163 of them righthanded, all of them before Ken Singleton joined the New York Mets last month.

title: Soviet Appears to Back Nasser's Positive Reply on U.S. CeaseFire Plan
description: MOSCOW, July 24The So viet Union appeared tonight to endorse Cairo's positive position of the latest United States initiative for achieving a political settlement in the Middle East.

title: Petty Betters Track Mark In Tennessee 200 Victory
description: MARYVILLE, Tenn., July 24 (AP)Richard Petty gained his ninth NASCAR Grand National victory this season and 110th of his career tonight by beating Bobby Isaac by half a car length in the East Tennessee 200.

title: Teller Says Unrest On Campus Perils Defense Research
description: WASHINGTON, July 24Dr. Edward Teller, the nuclear physicist, warned today that radical political movements in universities were seriously jeopardizing scientific research related to national defense.

title: Nijinsky Seeks No. 10
description: LONDON, July 24 (AP) Nijinsky, the wonder horse of European racing owned by Charles W. Engelhard of Far Hills, N.J., carries a ninerace winning streak into tomor row's King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes at Ascot.

title: TRANSPORT NOTES: CAR SAFETY MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)The Transportation De partment today issued a new safety standard to prevent the threat of death or injury to children from poweroperated car windows.

title: Washington: For the Record
War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) The Defense Department to day identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: Sherman Joins Nanette
description: Hiram Sherman, twotime Tony award winner, has been signed to costar with Ruby Keeler in No, No, Nanette. The 1925 musical, adapted by Charles Gaynor from the ori ginal book by Frank Mandel and Otto Harbach, is to open on Broadway Dec. 10.

title: W. LEE WHITE DEAD; FINANCIER, BREEDER
description: W. Lee White, sportsman and a former financier and piano manufacturer, died Wednesday at his summer home in Willimantic, Conn. He was 81 years old and also lived in Pinehurst. N. C.

title: Brazil Assails Death Squads, Vigilantes Who Kill Criminals
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 24 Gen. Emilio G. Mdici, the Pres ident of Brazil, today con demned his country's death squads, the vigilante groups that have killed 11 petty crim inals in So Paulo and 3 in Rio de Janeiro in the last week. The President said that the squad members, who are believed to include policemen, would be punished.

title: Hartman Retains Net Title
description: ORANGE, N.J., July 24 Leonard Hartman of Long Is land City, Queens, retained his Eastern clay courts champion ship at the Berkeley Tennis Club today, when he defeated Ed ward Tarangioli of Yonkers, 97, 64.

title: FOES OF BIENNALE OPEN SHOW HERE
description: After a series of tribulations that included several postpone ments and what might be called an artnapping, the promised show of prints withdrawn by United States artists from the Venice Biennale has finally opened at Museum, secondfloor exhibition loft at 729 Broadway.

title: Schwab's 69 Leads 9 Qualifiers In Westchester Classic Play
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 24Pat Schwab of Crestmont led the way through the pre liminary qualifying round for the Westchester Classic today by posting a score of 34, 35 69 at Wvkagyl Country Club.

title: Ashe Wins Opening Match
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 24 (Reuters)Arthur Ashe of Rich mond, defeated Dick Crealy of Australia, 64, 64, 64, in the first match of the Champion Cup roundrobin tournament.

title: AllStar Football Game to Be Played, Players Disclose
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24 Sufficient progress devel oped today in the Federal mediation of the profootball labor impasse to save next Friday night's College All Star Game in Chicago.

title: Subway's NoGoonRed Rule Takes Effect Smoothly
description: The city subway system's new safety rule prohibiting movement of a train past a red signal unless specifically au thorized, went into effect yes terday without causing the de lays many transit personnel had, predicted.

title: Hearings Will Begin Aug. 4 On PoliticalBroadcast Rules
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)  Hearings have been set for Aug. 4 before a Senate com munications subcommittee to work out guidelines for the use of broadcast time by the Presi dent and other political lead ers.

title: Keyserling Asserts Unsound Policies Promote Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The chief economist of the Truman Administration charged today that unsound and up sidedown economic policies of subsequent administrations had spurred the inflationary trends that they were intended to check.

title: STOCKS MEANDER TO A MIXED CLOSE
description: Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after a session of in decisive and slow trading that reflected the rapid decline of optimism generated late Thurs day by Egypt's acceptance of an American proposal for a temporary ceasefire with Is rael.

title: Scribner Vows to Visit Many Schools
description: Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the Chancellorelect of the city school system, intends to go into the schools and the com munities to get a feel of the situation he will face after he takes over on Sept. 1.

title: SIR IVAN THOMPSON; LED CUNARD FLEET
description: LONDON, July 24Sir Ivan Thompson commodore of the Cunard Steamship Company from 1954 until his retirement in 1957, died in Liverpool Wednesday after a long illness at the age of 75.

title: A Dance Ensemble Lures Its Audience To a Beach Frolic
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 24Erin Martin made her pub lic choreographic debut today at Connecticut College's Ameri can Dance Festival here. Things being as they are in the current transitional stage of modern dance, the work was presented not on the stage of Palmer Aud ??torium as might be expected but outdoors at twilight at near by Harkness State Park.

title: MRS. GERRISH MILLIKEN
description: Mrs. Agnes Gayley Milliken of 723 Park Avenue and North east Harbor, Me., widow of Gerrish H. Milliken, a president of Deering Milliken Inc., tex tiles, died Sunday in Northeast Harbor. Hee age was 83.

title: ASHER GERSTENFELD
description: Asher Gerstenfeld, a lawyer who practiced in New York for 20 years, died Sunday after long illness at his home in Mon treal. He was 64 years old.

title: U.S. Will Sue 8 Concerns Over Dumping of Mercury
description: WASHINGTON, July 24Attorney General John N. Mitchell authorized today the filing of suits against eight companies in seven states on charges of dumping mercury into lakes and rivers. United States attorneys in those states are being instructed to file the suits under the Refuse Act of 1899, which prohibits the dumping of refuse, except in liquid form from streets and sewers, into navigable waters without a permit from the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: School Percentomania
description: It is a measure of the American public school establishment's lack of imagination and initiative that industrial concerns and other private agencies have been entering the critical business of trying to upgrade the schooling of disadvantaged children. The extent to which private enterprise can help solve these prob lems remains to be demonstrated by far more sus tained efforts than have been made to date; but would be folly to reject expert aid through innovative experimentation from any source simply because such aid did not originate within traditional pedagogic channels.

title: Mrs. Gloria Cluett Wed in Wyoming
description: SHERIDAN, Wyo., July 24 Mrs. Gloria Prudden Cluett and J. Carvel Lange, both of Greenwich, Conn., were mar ried this morning in St. Peter's Episcopal Church by the Rev. William Ebertz, a Congregational minister.

title: Mailers and L.I. Press Agree
description: George E. McDonald, presi dent of Mailers Union Local No. 6 announced agreement yesterday on terms of a new contract with The Long Island Press. Mr. McDonald said the terms were the same as those announced on Wednesday, when the union reached agree ment with The New York Times and The Daily News. Mr. Mc Donald said he hoped to reach agreement with The New York I Post on Monday.

title: LEVEL OF T.V.A. AID STUDIED BY CON ED
description: Tennessee valley Authority engineers and powerpool dis patchers sought in an allday meeting yesterday to determine the maximum help the system could give the Consolidated Ed ison Company to meet its crit ical shortage of electrical gen erating capacity.

title: Top Cruise Honors Of American Y.C.Go To Yearling, Mariah
description: JAMESTOWN, R. I., July 24 Eugene W. Carder's Yearling, out of the Stamford (Conn.) Yacht Club in Cruising Division I, and Mariah in Divisibn II were the principal trophy win ners on the 39th annual Ameri can Yacht Club cruise that ended here today: Mariah is under charter to Eric W. Penis ton and George M. Isdale Jr. of the host club.

title: Celtic Juniors Bow in Soccer
description: TORONTO, July 24 (Canadian Press)The Glasgow Celtic jun ior soccer team lost its open ing game, 40, to the Toronto City Juniors in an exhibition match last night.

title: SAMPLE SUES JETS FOR $1,07MILLION
description: Johnny Sample, the defensive back released almost a year ago by the New York Jets, has sued the club for $1,070,000.

title: INDICTED OFFICIAL SUSPENDED BY CITY
description: The city's Relocation Com missioner, Earl A. Rawlins, was suspended yesterday without pay from his $35,000  a  year post as a result of a Federal indictment charging him and seven other persons with con spiring to violate the immigra tion laws.

title: RICHEY TOPS HEWITT IN WESTERN TENNIS
description: CINCINNATI, July 24 (AP) Cliff Richey, wearing borrowed shoes and socks, defeated Bob Hewitt, 64, 1210, today in a quarterfinal match of the West ern tennis championships.

title: Sightseeing Grows Up, but Awe Remains
description: The hick has become al most extinct among the city's visitors.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Historical Society Fills Post
description: Mary Childs Black, a special ist in American folk art, has been appointed the newly cre ated post of curator of painting, sculpture and the decorative arts at the NewYork Historical Society, 170 Central Park West. Mrs. Black, until recently the director of the Museum of American Folk Art, is also a former director and curator of the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Folk Art Collection at Villiams burg. Va.

title: Syracuse Hires Black Coach
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 24 (AP)  Syracuse University has a black assistant football coach for the first time in its history. The new coach is Carlmon Jones, a recent Florida A. and M. graduate. His appointment will become effective Aug. I.

title: Soviet Conquers U.S. in Track, 200173, as Its Men Post 2d Series Victory
description: LENINGRAD, July 24  The Soviet Union track and field team defeated the United States 200173 today.

title: Artistically, Cosi on Film Is a Success
description: Mozart's Cosi fan tutte is a piece of fine crystal that if touched properly can give out sounds that creep into the ear and stay for a life time. Both farcical and deep ly poignant at once, and am biguous in the way that the greatest art always seems to be, this is an opera to be handled only by artists of discrimination.

title: Special Session Scheduled
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 24 (AP)Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. called today for a special legislative sessionthe second this yearto rewrite West Vir ginia's bribery and conspiracy laws and to help solve the state's financial problems. The Governor said the special ses sion would convene at 10 A.M. next Tuesday.

title: FREDERICK J. FOX
description: JERSEY CITY, July 24  Frederick J. Fox, a lawyer here, died yesterday after be ing stricken in the Hudson County Administration Build ing. He was 66 years old and lived at 366 Hillside Avenue, Orange.

title: Miss Escher, Luis A. Simian To Wed in '71
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 24Mr. and Mrs. David A. Escher have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Chapman Escher, to Luis Al berto Simian, son of Mr. Mrs. Eduardo Simian of Santiago de Chile.

title: Golden Streets to Open Traveling Theater Aug. 12
description: The Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, under the direction of Miriam Colon, founder of the bilingual outdoor troupe, will open its four consecutive sum mer season on Aug. 12 at Riverside Park, Riverside Drive and 103d Street.

title: Firm Council Chief
description: Five years ago, when he was a Police Department in spector in the midtown area, Sanford Daniel Garelik stood outside Governor Rockefel ler's office at 22 West 55th Street.

title: Tax Aide Here Promoted
description: Alfred L. Whinston, assist ant district director for the In ternal Revenue Service in Man hattan, has been named district director in Philadelphia, with jurisdiction over most of east ern Pennsylvania. Mr. Whin ston 51 years old, is a native of New York City And has been with the Internal Revenue Se?? ?? since 1946.

title: Many Honor lain Macleod At Funeral in Yorkshire
description: CARGRAVE, England, July 24  Iain Macleod, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, was buried today in the York shire dales where he was born.

title: GARELIK SHOWING HIS INDEPENDENCE
description: The words of City Council President Sanford D. Garelik spoke even louder than his ac tion yesterday in proclaiming his independence of the man who made him in politics, May or Lindsay.

title: Ticket Sale Nears 100,000
description: ONTARIO, Calif., July 24 (UPI)The Ontario Motor Speedway announced today it was closing in on 100,000 tic kets sold for its opening race, the California 500. The race will be held Sept. 6.

title: Carole A. Aikman To Marry Aug. 15
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa,., July 24 Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Aikman have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Carole Ann Aikman, to Richard Arthur Baum busch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth R. Baumbusch of Hastings, N. Y. The wedding is planned for Aug. 15.

title: U.S. OFFERS SOVIET PACKAGE ACCORD TO CURB MISSILES
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The United States formally pre sented a package proposal for a strategicarms agreement to the Soviet Union today under which there would be a freeze on or a reduction in the size of offensive and defensive mis siles systems without restrict ting major improvements in them.

title: OAKLAND TALLIES 7 TIMES IN FIRST
description: OAKLAND, July 24Steve Kline's mother and brother drove 1,000 miles to see him pitch tonightand the young righthander retired one batter for every 500 miles his family traveled.

title: Rawlings Senate Candidate For Democrats in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, July 24George C. Rawlings Jr., a 48yearold Fredericksburg lawyer, today became the Democratic nomi nee for the Senate from Vir ginia.

title: PANTHER WITNESS TELLS OF MISSION
description: NEW HAVEN, July 24  Warren Kimbro testified today that a report was made to two black Panthers on a mission that resulted in the death of Alex Rackley. The two Panthers had been charged with over seeing the reorganization of the party's chapters here and in New York, he said.

title: Plastics Development Corp. Plans Disposable Camera
description: The development of an in expensive disposable plastic camera, that will include a film cartridge and return processing mailer, is proceeding on sched ule, Earl M. Slosberg, president of the Plastics Development Corporation of America told stockholders at the company's first annual meeting yesterday. The concern was established in May, 1968. The meeting was held at the company's offices at 9810 Ashton Road in Phila delphia.

title: NASSER DECLARES HIS YES IS FIRM
description: CAIRO, July 24President Gamal Abdel Nasser said to night that his acceptance of the United States plan for ceasefire and peace negotia tions was not qualified, not conditional.

title: Bendix Contract Extended
description: The Bendix Corporation re ceived an extension of National Aeronautics and Space Admin. istration contract for mainten ance and operations of the manned spaceflight tracking network at an estimated cost of more than $25million.

title: Coast Guard Searches Erie For Plane With Five Texans
description: CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP) The Coast Guard Was searching Lake Erie today for a missing light plane that it said was car rying a family of five from El Paso. Tex.

title: Tariff Commission Split On ImportInjury Cases
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 The Tariff Commission's vote was divided, 22, today, in two worker adjustment assist ance cases and was unani mous in finding no injury in a third.

title: NIXON WELCOMED IN SALT LAKE CITY
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 24 President Nixon left his bigcity problems behind him today for a look at the concerns of rural America and a bit of politick ing along the way.

title: AMEX INCHES UP IN LIGHT TRADING
description: In slow preweekend trading, the American Stock Exchange managed to inch upward yes terday. The exchange index closed at 20.32, up 0.02. Ad vances almost balanced de clines at 355 versus 349, while 244 issues remained un changed. Volume eased to 1, 795,285 shares, somewhat low er than Thursday's 2.184.245.

title: Antiques: The Plohns' English Silver
description: The London auction of the Plohn Collection of English silver at Sotheby's last week was a great comfort to those interested in the category.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JULY 25, 1970

title: Jan Kadar Will Direct Film Here
description: Jan Kadar, the Czechoslo vak director of the Academy Awardwinning 1965 Czech movie, The Shop on Main Street, whose first Ameri can film, The Angel Le vine, opens here Tuesday, will direct his second Ameri can feature, I Never Prom ised You a Rose Garden. The drama will star Liza Minnelli and Estelle Parsons, who also won an Oscar for her role in Bonnie and Clyde.

title: Miss Laurie Schneider Is Married
description: Miss Laurie Schneider, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Schneider of New York and East Hampton, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to John Brett Adams of London, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. C. Adams of Banstead, England.

title: Hanson Called a Megalomaniac By Prosecutor as Trial Begins
description: LOS ANGELES, July 24 Charles M. Manson, the hippie cult leader accused of planning and ordering the murder of seven persons in the Los An geles area last year, was de scribed in court today as a megalomaniac who coupled his insatiable thirst for power with an intense obsession for violent death.

title: Scientist Gives New View on How LDopa Curbs Parkinson's Disease
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 24 A neurochemist at the Massa chusetts Institute of Technology offered evidence today that LDopa, the drug used with dramatic success in treating Parkinson's disease, may work by entirely unsuspected means.

title: Eastman Kodak Exploring Film Venture in Japan
description: A spokesman for the East man Kodak Company has in dicated that the company, is exploring the possibility of manufacturing camera film in Japan.

title: Mayor, Still Fought by Garelik, Wins Funds for Police inquiry
description: Mayor Lindsay got the money yesterday for his commission on possible police corruption that City Council President San ford D. Garelik had blocked the day before.

title: NEW BRUNSWICK ORDERS CURFEW
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 24Mayor Patricia Q. Sheehan today declared the city to be in a state of emer gency in the face of potentially explosive racial situation and order a curfew from 8 o'clock tonight to 6 A.M. to morrow.

title: BROKER FAVORS RISE IN CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Charles H. Brunie, a partner in Oppenheimer & Co., said to day that the future of the entire capitalistic system in this country could be threat ened if the sales commissions charged by brokers were not increased by an adequate amount.

title: Miss Stuhler Retains Title In State Amateur Golf
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 24 (AP)Sara Jane Stubler of Amsterdam won the State ama teur junior girls golf tourna ment today for the second straight year by defeating Chris Grygiel, the medal winner 4 and 3.

title: Topics: Central Park West Side Story
description: Take the normal household er's headachesthe mortgage, the garbage, the stoppedup sink, the ridiculous light bill then multiply by twenty, and you can understand the prob lems in our selfowned, self managed West Side apartment building. A few years ago we were just impersonal New York apartment dwellers who were forced to form a cooperative or face having our house torn down.

title: Aetna Insurance Income Down Sharply for Half
description: The Connecticut General In surance Corporation reported yesterday that the Aetna In surance Company, a major subsidiary, showed a sharp decline in income from opera tions for the first half of 1970.

title: Market Place:
description: If you have a feeling that business is keeping secrets in this bear market, you'll be interested to know that busi ness doesn't think as you do.

title: Buying Aid Translated Into Guia de Compras
description: The Department of Con sumer Affairs has translated into Spanish its basic infor mational booklet Con sumer and has sent copies to organizations dealing with Spanishspeaking citi zens.

title: GUARD HEAD UPSET BY REPORT ON KENT
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 24 (AP)  The adjutant general of the Ohio National Guard has called unbelievable a newspaper re port of assertions by the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation about guardsmen in the deaths of four Kent State University students during a campus con frontation last May 4.

title: TV Maker Lists Loss
description: The 12week trucking strike in the Chicago area, which forced a sixweek shutdown of most manufacturing plants of the Zenith Radio Corporation, severely depressed second quarter and halfyear results, Joseph S. Wright, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

title: Wagner and ExDetroit Mayor Form a Concern for Consulting
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner has joined former Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh of Detroit in forming a consulting concern that will specialize in the problems of cities.

title: Times Research Manager
description: The New York Times has named Thomas W. Black to be research manager, effective Aug. 3. Mr. Black joined The Times in 1967 from The New York WorldJournal Tribune where he had been marketing and research manager. He suc ceeds David L. Sanders, who resigned in April to become an associate professor of journal ism at New York University.

title: Head of Continental Telephone Is Killed by a Bomb in His Car
description: ST. LOUIS, July 24  Philip J. Lucier, president of the Con tinental Telephone Company, was killed today when a bomb exploded in a company auto mobile on the parking lot of the Pierre Lacleve Center in Clay ton, a suburb of St. Louis. Mr. Lucier was 49 years old.

title: Unveilings
description: DULBERG In loving memory. Unvell ing will be held on Sunday, July 26 at 12 Noon. Block 116, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing

title: Britons Wait as E. E. C. Deliberates
description: BRUSSELS, July 24It was an embarrassingly long wait, but no one has yet found a way to speed up deliberations inside the Com mon Market.

title: Klecatsky Gains Final Rounds In 2 Canadian Rowing Events
description: ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, July 24Dr. Larry Klecatsky of the New York Athletic Club started his quest for five cham pionships in the 88th Royal Canadian Henley Regatta to day with an impressive six length victory in the second heat of the Association singles.

title: Packaged Cereals A Morning Favorite In the White House
description: FARGO, N. D., July 24 (UPI) The First Lady and her daughter Tricia discussed the new consumer controversy cereals  when they toured North Dakota State University's department of cereal chemistry today.

title: Books of The Times
description: We all have our favorite ages. I have long thought that it would be very pleasant to be a fifthcentury (B. C.) Athenian, with a handful of Phoenician slaves to do the household chores and an uncomplaining wife to rear the kids. Rising early and shaking the dust of the slums off my feet, I'd wander off to the agora, take in a neat wrestling match or two in the stadium or watch a couple of stylish discoboli, and then, after a leisurely lunch and bath, listen to that old gadfly Socrates provide an afternoon's entertainment: Tell me, Charm ides, is not readiness of the mind a sort of nimbleness of the soul . . . ? If I were Charmides, I'd take my time answer ing that one.

title: Screen: 'You Can't Win' Em All' Proves a Cliche:Collinson's Caper Film Written by Gordon
description: If you pay close attention, near the middle of "You Cain't Win 'Em All," a new Post-World-War-I Turkish caper movie at the Loew's State II and Loew's Orpheum theaters, you will notice with an unpleasant shock, that the reckless troop of cavalry being decimated before your eyes are falling off their horses and gamely biting the dust in exactly the same manner and with exactly the same gestures as were another supposedly quite different reckless troop of cavalry being decimated scarcely a minute before. From this you may learn that an action film director assaying the Valley of Death should make sure that the extras to the right of him are not recognizably also the extras to the left of him. And that, I fear, is all you will learn from this film, which tries every other trick of its dull trade, and fails at all of them.Peter Collinson, whose career until now (for example "The Penthouse," "The Italian Job") does not inspire confidence, has directed "You Can't Win 'Em All" for clichs not only of the adventure movie and the caper movie and the warfare nostalgia movie (biplane bombers, and armored train, old staff cars, etc.), but also of the exotic picturesque. Lacking a plot of any interest, it settles instead for spectacular scenerywhich it keeps revealing by drawing back or up and away from the file of mercenaries or the speeding train or whateveras if the matter in view were to become less uninteresting the further you get from it  which in the case of "You Can't Win 'Em All" is pretty much true.Tony Curtis plays one adventurer and Charles Bronson plays another adventurer and Michele Mercier plays the sex interest (not much) and a cast of hundreds (or maybe dozens; that cavalry charge puts me on my guard) plays the last of the Ottoman Empire, the Young Turks, the Greek army, and, providentially, the United States Marines. But for that sweet sense of male companionship that in one form or another has sustained the best of the genre from Ford through Peckinpah, the film discovers no resources. It is therefore aimless in its energies, lost in its landscapes, and hopelessly wasteful of its ancient conventions.

title: WEST POINTER FAILS IN OBJECTOR APPEAL
description: BALTIMORE, July 24  A Federal judge ruled here today that a West Point graduate who has a selective conscien tious objection to the war in Vietnam was not entitled to a discharge from the Army.

title: Computer Gauges Alcohol in Bloodstream
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 A computer that was patented this week tells when a per son is statistically drunk. It keeps track of the percentage of alcohol in his bloodstream, taking account of his weight, the strength and volume of the beverages, and the elapsed time. The Alcolometer is pro tected by Patent 3,521,045, assigned to the BissettBer man Corporation, Santa Monica, Calif., by the in ventor, John B. Murphy, a member of the company's technical staff. BissettBer man expects to put the Alocolometer on the market at less than $100. The com pany, a subsidiary of Plessey Alloys Corporation, makes oceanographic instruments and a miniature device called the ECell.

title: Richfield Pact Set In U.S. Trust Case
EMERGENCY BILL ON HOUSING SIGNED
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 President Nixon signed today an emergency bill intended to put new vigorand as much as $10billion a year in mort gage moneyinto the sagging home construction industry.

title: Rose Knox Is Married Upstate To Lieut. Bernard P. Beaudoin
description: JOHNSTOWN, N. Y., July 24  Miss Rose Ann Knox and Lieut. Bernard Paul Beau doin, U.S.A., were married this afternoon in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Thomas Carr.

title: The Charm of Mr. Buckley
description: He is a downtheline sup porter of President Nixon's pol icy in Vietnam. He thinks the students were wrong at Kent State. He favors the District of Columbia crime bill, with its provision for preventive deten tion. Next to his name on his campaign literature and bumper stickers is an American flag.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: *Apprentice.

title: Poisoned Water
description: A major environmental scandal has come to light as the full implications of the mercury poisoning of the nation's rivers and lakes have at last begun to be understood. Interior Secretary Bickel has acted correctly and swiftly in trying to meet the newly uncovered menace, and Justice Department suits against ten mercury polluters are the direct result of his initiative. But a great deal of environmental dam age has already been done; and its consequences will not be easily dealt with even if all additional mercury pollution were ended immediately, which it will not be.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Psychiatry as Tactic

title: Louis Harris, 67, Is Dead; Oil and WaterColor Artist
description: Louis Harris, a painter, died last Saturday, apparently of heart attack, in his studio at 203 Bleecker Street, where he also maintained a residence. He was 67 years old.

title: CRUZEIRO DEVALUED IN BRAZIL BY 0.63%
description: RIO DE JANIERO, July 24 Brazil, following an export boosting flexible exchange policy, devalued the cruziero today for the second time in a fortnight.

title: Business Records
description: EASTERN DISTRICT

title: Museum Extends Exhibition Of 100 Borrowed Paintings
description: The exhibition of 100 paint ings, on loan from the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been extended for a week to Aug. 2. It had been scheduled to close Sunday.

title: Fresh Yankee Beats Tidalium Pelo to Wire Again in Rich Trot at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 24 Fresh Yankee, Americanbred and Canadianowned, won the $30,000 Roquepine Trot tonight as well as what might be termed permanent possession of France's Tidalium Pelo.

title: Lettuce Workers on Coast End Strike With New Pact
description: SALINAS, Calif., July 24 (AP) The settlement of a oneweek strike by nearly 400 teamster members sent more than 6,000 workers back to their jobs to day, harvesting the nation's main supply of lettuce crops.

title: Power's Daughter to Wed
description: ROME, July 24 (AP)  Romina Power, daughter of the late Tyrone Power, the actor, and of Linda Christian, the actress, has announced her en gagement to Al Bano, an Italian singer. The couple said yester day that the ceremony would take place on Sunday.

title: Bail Posted for Jailed Police Agent
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., July 24Tommy the Traveler, an undercover agent for the On tario County sheriff's office, was freed on $7,500 hail to night, less than 24 hours after he was imprisoned at the re quest of two special state prosecutors investigating stu dent disorders on the Hobart College campus in Geneva.

title: ISRAEL IS PRESSED BY U.S, TO ACCEPT TEMPORARY TRUCE
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The full weight of American diplomacy was aimed at Israel today to persuade her to agree to a temporary ceasefire along the Suez Canal and to follow Cairo's example of saying yes before adding but.

title: PROTECTIVE GLASS IN COMMONS URGED
description: LONDON, July 24Installa tion of a bulletproof glass screen across the public gallery of the House of Commons was fore most among suggestions made today after two gas bombs were thrown in the chamber, yesterday.

title: Polstein Tops De Blaseo As Title Tennis Starts
description: MANHASSET, L. I.Mitch ell Polstein of New York, Nor man Knittle of Hewlett, L. I., and Howard Kalb of Hollis, Queens, were second  round winners today in the United States championships for men 35 years of age and over at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club. A field of 106 was entered.

title: Budd to Close Foundry
description: DETROIT, July 24The Budd Company will close its Detroit gray iron foundry and stop making auto brake drums and hubs next June. Onefifth of the 4.200 workers at Budd's plant here will be laid off. The company blamed the closing on the switch to disc brakes from drum brakes in cars and said the foundry and machine op erations had caused substantial financial losses in the last few years.

title: U.S. Monetary Reserves Rose $163Million in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 United States international mon etary reserves rose by $163 million in June as foreigncur rency holdings increased fol lowing three months of siz able decline, the Treasury re ported today.

title: Rise in Racial Tension Among Firemen Stirs Fears
description: When Wesley Williams was assigned to the Broome Street firehouse on the Lower East Side on Jan. 10, 1919, every fireman in the company asked for a transfer.

title: Ottinger and Walinsky Win Aid of Dissident Liberals
description: A Liberal party reform group last night endorsed Richard L. Ottinger, the Democratic can didate for the United States Senate, over Republican Sena tor Charles E. Goodell, who has the official Liberal party nomi nation.

title: SportsLoving South Africans Feel Pressure of World Boycotts
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica  The most popular men in South Africa today are the AllBlacks, a racially integrated rugby team from New Zea land.

title: JAMES B. CONNOLLY
description: MALVERNE, L. I., July 24 James B. Connolly, a stereo typer for The New York Times since 1953, died Wednesday of a heart attack near his home at 628 Cornwell Avenue. His age was 50.

title: NEW TECHNIQUES IMPROVE CENSUS
description: JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., July 23  Dr. George Hay Brown, director of the Bureau of the Census, said today the factors that caused 5 million Ameri cans to be omitted from the 1960 census had become more widespread in the intervening decade but he was hopeful 1970 counting techniques would re duce similar errors.

title: U.S. to Study Dates on Food
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The Agriculture Department said today that it would make a preliminary study of whether grocery items should be date stamped to advise consumers if the food products were over aged. The department said it would look at smallscale studies undertaken by one grocery c hair and by Rutgers University.

title: Peanut Butter to the Rescue
description: All those children who'd rather have a peanut butter and jelly sandwich for break fast than shredded wheat much to their mothers' dis maymay have been right after all.

title: Accused of Threat on Nixon
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 (AP)The Secret Service re ported today the arrest of a man accused of threatening the life of President Nixon. John M. Woolf, 52 years old, an itin erant, was taken into custody at Stockton, Calif., the Secret Service said.

title: U.S. Pledges Spain Defense Support for Use of Bases
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The United States has pledged to support the defense system of Spain in return for rights to continue using naval and air bases there, State Department officials disclosed today.

title: A Poe Letter, Sold for $5,250, Says He Got $20 for Black Cat
description: One of the great rarities in the autograph fieldan unpub lished letter by Edgar Allan Poewas auctioned on Thurs day night for $5,250. It is a brief letter, revealing the au thor's chronic financial distress and disclosing that the pay ment for his story, The Black Cat, had been $20.

title: Court Ruling Aids Soldier
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 24 (AP)A Federal judge has ordered the Army to discharge a Maryland soldier as a con scientious objector as a result of a Supreme Court ruling. Pvt. John D. Aquilino Jr. of Baltimore had sought a dis charge last May, but Federal District Court Judge Adrian Spears had denied the request. Judge Spears reversed the de cision yesterday, basing his move on a Supreme Court ruling of June 15 holding that personal and philosophical be liefs, as well as religious beliefs applied in conscientious objec tion

title: AN AUSTRALIAN DOVE WOULD AID CAMBODIA
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 24 A prominent Australian dove has shocked his colleagues and upset opposition in political circles by reversing his widely publicized stand against aid for Cambodia after visiting that country as a member of a bipartisan parliamentary delegation.

title: Cards Farm Out Kennedy
description: ST. LOUIS, July 24 (UPI) Jim Kennedy was sent hack to the St. Louis Cardinals' farm club at Tulsa today. Kennedy's departure leaves room on the roster for Ted Simmons, a rookie catcher who has been on two weeks of Army Reserve duty.

title: WESTERN EUROPE IN SPACE GAIN BID
description: BRUSSELS, July 24 (AP)  Western Europe wants full partnership in America's post Apollo space program and ac cess to any inventions that emerge, Theo Lefevre, presi dent of the European Space Conference, said today.

title: MARKET LIVELIER FOR NEW ISSUES
description: The newissue market con tinued to emerge ever so slight ly this week from the dol drums of the last several months.

title: Rockefeller Reaffirms Support For Goodell in Senate Election
description: Governor Rockefeller reaf firmed yesterday his support for Senator Charles E. Goodell and then met with the Senator to discuss how they could work together and coordinate their campaigns.

title: Rise Noted in Requests for Objector Status Since Court Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, July 24In the five weeks since the Su preme Court broadened the grounds for conscientious ob jection to military service, there has been a substantial increase in the number of ap plicants for C.O. status, spokesman for the Selective Service system said yesterday.

title: Soybean Futures Fall as Traders Take Quick Profit
description: Tumbling soybean prices yesterday indicated traders were busy taking quick profits in the beans. The selling followed the Government's stocksonhand report, which apparently disappointed some traders despite the fact that beans on hand on farms, in storage centers and elsewhere were about 11 per cent lower than a year ago at this time.

title: Senator Out of Hospital
description: Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, was released yesterday from the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, where she had undergone hip surgery July 6.

title: NADER WINS ROUND ON I.T.T.'S MERGER
description: HARTFORD, July 24 (UPI) Ralph Nader won the right to day in a Superior Court decis ion to bring the International Telephone and Telegraph. Cor poration to court for its mer ger with the Hartford Fire In surance Company.

title: Barbara Smedley Is a Bride Here
description: Miss Barbara M. Smedley Stephen H. Greenberg were married here yesterday morn ing. State Supreme Court Justice Harold Baer perform ed the ceremony in his chamhprs.

title: SneadDickinson Team Ties PalmerNicklaus at 128 for Ligonier Golf Lead
description: LIGONIER, Pa., July 24 Sam Snead, who occasionally mentions he is 58 years old, and Gardner Dickinson, who recently said he wanted to quit the golf tour, put together a 61 today and tied Jack Nick laus and Arnold Palmer in the $200,000 national team championship. Their 10under par spurt at the Laurel Valley Golf course gave them a best ball aggregate of 128 for 36 holes.

title: In Memoriam
description: QUINFrank, July 25, 1962, New York news paperman. Remembered in his favorita medium.

title: Article 1  No Title
Capital Gains Help
description: MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc., reported yesterday a profit for the 12  week and 40  week periods ended June 4 but only because of extraordinary cap ital gains.

title: Aides Deny Rogers Made Protest to Soviet on Libya
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 State Department officials said today that the United States had not complained directly to the Soviet Union about its re cent arms shipments to Libya, evidently in the interest of encouraging cooperation from Moscow on peace initiatives in the Middle East.

title: ARMY SETS TRIAL ON THEFT IN CLUBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The Army ordered today a general courtmartial for M. Sgt. William E. Higdon, a dec orated 23year veteran of mili tary service accused of theft and bribery while in charge of servicemen's clubs in South Vietnam.

title: C.A.B. Backs Airline's Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it had authorized (American Airlines to spend $2 million more to protect an ear lier $5million aid program for the disintegrating Trans Carib bean Airways. The two airlines lare seeking approval to merge, but the board said its action did not mean it was prejudging the merger proposal.

title: Fund Move Clarified
description: The Atalanta Asset Manage ment Corporation, which was described in a July 7 article in The New York Times as hav ing been discharged as one of eight managers of Competitive Associates Fund, resigned the account five clays previously, it said.

title: TRANSIT POLICEMAN IS FOUND DERELICT
description: A Transit Authority patrol man suspended after making an arrest March 7 against his su perior's orders was found dere lict yesterday by the authority. The finding will cost him 16 days' pay.

title: STOCKS ARE FIRM ON LONDON BOARD
Poverty Is a Boast at Tougaloo College
description: TOUGALOO, Miss.  Three miles north of Jackson lies Tougaloo College, a 100year old black institution surround ed by tall pine trees and ancient oaks festooned with Spanish moss.

title: COAST GUNMAN KILLS FOUR, THEN HIMSELF
description: LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP) A man fatally shot four wo men in two houses and then killed himself in southcentral Los Angeles today, sheriff's deputies said.

title: Lakers to Open Oct. 23
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (UPI)The Los Angeles Lakers will open their home schedule Oct. 23 a Friday night, against the Philadelphia 76ers, the Na tional Basketball Association club announced today.

title: Drama Elusive As O'Neill Play Is Put on Tape
description: Watching a play being put on in a recording studio is rather like nibbling on hors d'oeuvres for several hours and then being told, as the lights go out, that one has attended the feast.

title: Hickel Seeks Ban On Oil Discharges Producing Slicks
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Wal ter J. Rickel proposed new regu lations today prohibiting any oil discharge big enough to cause a visible slick.

title: City Is Acting to Preserve Queens Cove
description: Two top city officials made commitments yester day to halt development in at least one area of the city and preserve it in its natural state.

title: France Delivers Submarine, First of 3, to South Africans
description: LORIENT, France, July 24 (Reuters)  South Africa took possession of its first sub marine, built in France, here today.

title: ERNEST B. HORWATH
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., July 24 Ernest B. Horwath, a found ing partner of Laventhol Krek stein Horwath & Horwath, an accounting firm in New York, died in a hospital here Wednes day. He was 84 years old and lived in Largo.

title: RUTGER B. MILLER JR.
description: Rutger Bleecker Miller Jr., an assistant vice president of the First National City Bank, died of cancer Thursday at Roose velt Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 14 East 90th Street.

title: City Says Pollution Is Near Unhealthy Smog to Continue
description: A warm gray haze hung over the city yesterday, and air pollution levels rose to what the city's Department of Air Resources called near un healthy levels.

title: Pueblo's Officers Disagree on Who Stopped the Ship
description: MONTEREY, Calif., July 20 A bitter dispute flared up among officers of the Pueblo while the crew of the electron ic surveillance vessel was in jail following her capture off North Korea in January, 1968.

title: Manhattan Light Opera Stages A Lively Pirates of Penzance
description: Style and spirit are the essen tial ingredients for a successful production of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas. The Light Opera of. Manhattan (known to its friends as LOOM) may be wanting in the former attribute, but its singers would seem to display, sufficient energy and zest to disarm all but the most nartieular Savoyard.

title: HOT TUNA PROVIDES A FOLKBLUES BILL
description: Hot Tuna, a subsidiary of Jefferson Airplane, the San Francisco band, played as quiet a concert as has ever been heard at the Fillmore East Fri day and last night.

title: Miss Joseph Plans Wedding for Aug. 30
description: Miss Jaye Leslie Joseph and David Scott Minton have planned their wedding for Aug. 30 at the Lido Beach (L. I.) Hotel.

title: WALSH, WAKE WIN IN THISTLE SAILING
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., July 25 Fourteenyearold Dan Walsh of Delanco, N. J., created the biggest stir today as the Thistle Class Atlantic Coast champion ship sailing series got under way.

title: Germany: Eastern Policy Tangled in Politics
description: BONNA little over four years ago West Germany's Christian Democratic Union Government sent peace notes to the gov ernments of Communist Europe proposing bilateral pacts re nouncing the use of force to each of them. The exChancellor, Konrad Adenauer, who had built his formidable career on cold war confrontation with the Com munists, was still alive and had acquiesced to the peace notes. His successor, Ludwig Erhard, and the Foreign Minister, Ger hard Schrder of the Christian Democratic Union, were directly responsible for the initiative.

title: Friday Night Fights
description: Sao Paulo, Brazil  Miguel Oliveira, Brazil, knocked out Leonardo Reralta, Argentina, 7 rounds, middleweights.

title: Floridians Sign Davis
description: MIAMI, July 25 (AP)Warren Davis signed today with the Miami Floridians of the Ameri can Basketball Association. Da vis was acquired from Pittg burgh last month.

title: BUCKLEY SEEKING 2D LINE ON BALLOT
description: Petitions for a new political party to be known as the In iependent Alliance are being irculated to give James L. Buck cy, the Conservative party candidate for United States Senator, a second line on the voting machine.

title: Italian to Try to Form a Cabinet
description: ROME, July 25  Emilio Colombo, a 50yearold Chris tian Democrat who has been Italy's Treasury Minister for the last seven years, agreed tonight to try to form a new govern ment composed of all four cen terleft partieshis own, the Republicans and the feuding Socialists and Social Democrats.

title: On a Train in Austria: It's Hard to Believe I Nearly Perished Here
description: THE YOUNG Scotsman sitting by the window speaks German badly, so we talk in English. He seems glad of the chance, and after 10 weeks away from home my desire to speak nothing but German has abated somewhat.

title: Conference Moves Office
description: KANSAS CITY, July 25 (AP)  The Missouri Valley Confer ence, one of the oldest in the country, will move its head quarters to Dallas as part of its plan to expand and improve its athletic program.

title: 2 P.O.W.'s Explain Roles in War
description: KOMPONG SPEU, Cambodia, July 22Two days ago when they were captured, Mong Sur, a 21yearold North Vietnamese soldier from Hanoi, and Khieu Horn, a 20yearold Cambodian farmer, both fought on the same side against the Cambo dian Army.

title: A MillionDollar Hotel Where the Oldest Guest Is 12
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Three young ladies from Wilton, accompanied by two visiting cousins from Ohio, checked into a hotel here recently for a three  day stay. They had such a good time that when the cousins returned to the Mid west, they extended their stay for a few more days.

title: 2 Are Indicted in Bombing Of 36 Texas School Buses
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) A Federal grand jury has in dicted two men in connection with the Fourth of July bomb ing of 36 school buses essen tial to desegregation of schools in Longview, Tex.

title: Is the University Too Much With Us?
description: AREMARKABLE phenomenon has been taking place during the past dozen years or so, namely, the extent to which, in America at least, the new music movement has moved onto the, university campus. Nw adays one rarely reads the biographical data of a native composer born after 1930 without finding mention of the academic institution where he studied composition, or where he now teaches, or at the very least, where his music has been nerformed. Even without refer ence to statistics, we know that a large proportion of contemporary musicmak ing takes place at university centers. The institution supplies the, hall, the performers, and the audience, and some times even a paying job for the com poser. What more can a creative mu sician ask?

title: Son to Clive Davises
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Clive J. Davis of New York on July 14 in Mount Sinai Hospital's Klingenstein Pavilion. Mrs. Davis is the former Miss Janet Adelberg, daughter of Harry. Adelberg of Baltimore and the late Mrs. Adelberg. The child, whose father is president of Columbia Records, a division of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., is named Mitch ell Jay.

title: An Old Prospector Still Hunts for Gold
description: GRANITE, Colo.  In his 93 years,. Karl Musick has made his living as at soldier, sailor, railway switchman, stagecoach driver and waiter on the fast, fashionable trains that used to run be tween Chicago and San Francisco.

title: LAWYER FOR PRIEST PROTESTS IN LISBON
description: LISBON, July 25Dr. Joaquim Pires de Lima, a lawyer, has protested to the Government that he is being impeded in defending a priest who was ar rested on a political charge.

title: Floating Marina Is Made in Advance
description: A floating dock system; pre engineered in various widths and lengths for easy placement, has been introduced to the pleasure craft market.

title: Roast Beef Dinner's Cost Drops 9c to $5.87 Here
description: The average cost of prepar ing a Sunday roast beef dinner at home for a family of four in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area declined by 9 cents to $5.87 last month, it was reported yesterday.

title: Southern Strategy Seems Badly Dented
description: ATLANTA  Republican par ty leaders in the South had a funny way of going blank when ever the subject of the South ern strategy was brought up in public during the past 18 months. With a bland smile and a benign denial, they challenged the existence of a political deal that would win state houses and electoral votes for the party in exchange for a slowdown on school desegregation. More often than not they dismissed the Southern strategy as an illusion created by the Democrats, a canard to stem an inexorable Republican tide in Dixie.

title: Article 5  No Title
Tiher Pollution Alarms Rome
description: ROME, July 25 (AP)Rome officials said today that the pol lution level of the Tiher River was very much higher than the maximum tolerable level. An emergency City Council meeting was called to consider the situation.

title: FRANK QUINLAN
description: GLEN RIDGE, N.J., July 25 Frank Quinlan, a former vice president of Hanes Hosiery Corporation, 630 Fifth Avenue, lied of heart failure this morn ing at his home, 255 Forest Avenue here. He was 59 years Old.

title: W. L. McHenry Weds Miss Curtis
description: Miss Christina Curtis was married here yesterday aft ernoon to William Lee Mc Henry. The Rev. Charles H. Rowins performed the cere mony in the chantry of St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: MethadoneOnly Program Undergoing Crucial Tests
description: Methadone, a synthetic drug used to break heroin addiction, is quietly undergoing what is probably the most important and critical test it has ever had in its controversial history in New York.

title: Science/Space
description: ASPEN, Colo.Now every one must remain absolutely silent or the experiment won't work, said the professor, and the shuffling and mur murs of some 400 Columbia University students of ele mentary chemistry ceased.

title: Barnett Newman 19051970
description: BARNETT NEWMAN's art represented a daring ex treme among the many challenging styles of the Abstract Expressionists. His reduction of the pic torial field to areas of relatively flat color divided by sparsely placed verticalor, more rarely, horizontal bands, went beyond the painting of his contemporaries its sacrifice of the traditional components of style. The point of this reduction was not to create a large scale version of the type of severe, architectural painting exem plified by Mondrian; nor could anything have been further from Newman's goals than such a rigorously intellectual, Cubistderived style. On the contrary, Newman's painting was first and foremost an art of the senses, and it there fore focused upon color, that element of the painter's vocabulary traditionally associated with the sensuous and the passionate.

title: For a Price, New TVChairs in Bus Terminals Take the Boredom Out of Waiting
description: MILWAUKEE, July 25 Weary travelers waiting in Milwaukee's Greyhound bus depot now have an alterna tive to staring at blank walls. For a price, they can stare at a television set.

title: Home Improvement
description: HOMEOWNERS who would like to install a second kitchen in their basement or fam ily room, or those who would like to put a small kitchen into their summer cottage, vacation retreat or office, will no doubt be interested in a new line of compact kitchen units that have re cently been introduced by the Crane Company, 300 Park Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022.

title: F.T.C. STUDIES ADS AND DRUG ABUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 The Federal Trade Commission has begun a study to see if there is any connection be tween massive advertising for overthecounter medicines and other products and the na tion's rising drug abuse prob lem.

title: Nasser's Reply to Rogers
description: Egypt's reply to Secretary of State Rogers' proposal for a ninetyday standstill ceasefire and indirect ne gotiations with Israel leaves the new. American peace plan for the Mideast alive and well but still floating in midair.

title: STUDENT WORKERS AID EAST GERMANY
description: BERLIN, July 25 Some 20,000 East German students this week began to put in four to six weeks of labor at con struction sites to help over come lags in East Germany's building industry.

title: Article 4  No Title
ISAAC TAKES FIRST IN NASHVILLE 420
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 25 (AP)Bobby Isaac of Catawba, N.C., drove his 1969 Dodge to victory today in the nationally televised Nashville 420 Grand National Stock Car race.

title: Reilings Have Child
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., July 25  A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Reiling on July 15 in St. Barnabas Hospital here. Mrs. Reiling is the former Miss Susan Goetz. The child has been named Jill Robin. Her father is marketing director of Standard Plastic Products Division of Mattel, Inc., the toy manufacturer.

title: 2 Women to Aid Governor
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day named two women, both longtime Rockefeller supporters, to head the Housewives for Rockefeller and his Team Com mittee, a group established to mobilize the support of women for Rockefeller's bid for re election this fall. The two wom en, Mrs. Dorothy McHugh of New York City and Mrs. Eunice Whittlesey of Scotia, N.Y., will direct the group from Mr. Rockefeller's state campaign headquarters at 575 Madison Avenue.

title: Moving On
description: Moving On, the latest novel by Larry McMurtry, who attracted attention with Horse man, Pass By (filmed as Hud) and Leaving Chey enne, is an exhausting work nearly 800 pages longfilled with characters and encounters. One has a right to expect big meanings from such big read ing, but power of insight is not McMurtry's forte here. His forte is words, words, words. And sex, sex, sex. The marriage of Patsy and Jim Carpenter is so badand their separation and extramarital affairs so unsuc cessfulthat the effect of the novel can only be to threaten that a dark emotional chasm awaits those who try for more than life has dealt them.

title: Summertime and Ice: Youngsters Admitted to the Rugged World of Hockey
description: The second week of Achilles Gerol's in troduction to hockey begins tomorrow when he returns to the summer school at Skateland in New Hyde Park, L. I.

title: Educator Stressing Real World
description: BOULDER, Colo.  Fred Chernow looked every bit the prosperous Coloradan as he strode into his office in the Engineering Center at the University of Colorada here recently. Tall, wearing Levi's and a teeshirt, tanned some what, balding, a bit over weight and beaming.

title: Bermuda: Pressures in Paradise...
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda  We are what we are: beautiful, quiet, peaceful and friendly, and that is what we are trying to preserve.

title: U.S. TIE IS HAILED BY PUERTO RICANS
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 25 Puerto Ricans celebrated the 18th year of their common wealth government today with the usual parade and speeches, but strong and diverse voices are pressing for change in the island's political relationship with the United States.

title: A.A.U.'s Junior Title Track Slated at Wantagh on Aug. 2
description: The National Amateur Ath letic Union junior track and field championships will be held on Long Island for the first time since 1966. The meet is scheduled for Sunday, Aug. 2, at Wantagh High School, beginning at noon.

title: Swoboda Goes Charging Into the Plate and Jars Ball From Dodgers' Catcher During Rally in Fifth Inning
Central Americans Attempt to Preserve Market
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 25A plan to salvage the Cen tral American Common Market, which has been skirting a breakdown since Honduras and El Salvador fought a war last year, has been adopted by the five member countries.

title: Ulster Judge's Home Hit.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 25 (UPI)A bomb dam aged the empty house tonight of Lord Justice Lancelot Cur ran, one of three judges who last month rejected the appeal of Bernadette Devlin, Catholic civil rights leader, and a Mem ber of Parliament, the police said. Miss Devlin was given six months in prison for her role in rioting last August.

title: Rediscovered Painter of the Mormon Trek
description: VISUAL oddities are nothing new to the Whitney Museum of American Art, but they are usually confined to that boring margin of novelty and innovation which in some quarters still passes for being avantgarde. This summer, however, the Whitney has reached farther back in his tory to come up with one of the oddest exhibitions it has ever mounted  a show of Mormon historical paintings by Carl Christian Anton Chris tensen, a 19thcentury ar tist heretofore all but un known to connoisseurs of American painting. It turns out (to whose surprise, I wonder?) that Christensen's long obscurity was eminent ly welldeserved.

title: Southern Golf Title Won By Wake Forest Junior
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 25 (AP) Lanny Wadkins, a 20year old collegian from Richmond, shot a soggy oneunderpar 71 today and won the Southern Golf Association championship by eight strokes.

title: Vatican Says It's Not Really All That Rich
description: ROMESpeculating about the number of angels who can dance on the head of a pin used to be a popular theological diversion in Rome. A more modern and profane puzzle here is the ques tion of how rich and financially powerful is the Vatican. Last week, the Holy See got into the game by insisting it was no where near as wealthy as a, lot of people and papers have been saying. The unusual denial, however, raised more questions than it answered.

title: Letters:
description: Seaboard Discusses Deposits

title: NICKLAUSPALIIER IN TIE FOR LEAD
description: LIGONIER, Pa., July 25 Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer received a challenge from an unexpected quarter to day and found themselves in a tie for first after 54 holes in the $200,000 national team golf championship.

title: Bill on Alcoholism Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee has ap proved a bill that would set up a national health institute to deal with alcoholism. The bill, which would authorize $360 million in grants over the next three years to enable Mate and local public and private agen cies to finance alcoholic treat ment projects, was voted out unanimously Thursday.

title: BONN AND WARSAW END 3DAY TALKS
description: WARSAW, July 25  Three days of negotiations on the normalization of relations be tween West Germany and Poland ended inconclusively here today with an agreement to meet again in Bonn in Sep tember.

title: A Matter of Accountability
description: Were this book fiction, it would have been an engrossing yarn of the sea, the intrigue of intelligence, and the perils of a harsh prison in a faraway land. But the story it tells is painfully true. Trevor Armbrister, who was a staff writer with The Saturday Evening Post at the time of its demise, has written an objec tive, dispassionate and graphic piece of reportage about perhaps the most controversial incident in mod ern American naval history.

title: Mercury: Action That May Be Long Overdue
description: WASHINGTONLast Tuesday, Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel sent to the Department of Justice the names of 8 in dustrial firms with a recommen dation that they be prosecuted under the 1899 Refuse Act on charges of dumping mercury into the rivers and lakes of seven states.

title: Education
description: The debate over the education of Negro and Puerto Rican chil dren in the urban slums has be come a stalemated chickenegg argument: Which must come first  improvement of the chil dren's inferior schooling or im provement of their debilitating environment?

title: The Amazing Success Story of Spiri Who?
description: WHAT, in fact, is it all about? After 16 months, no one can question the force of Spiro T. Agnew's per sonality, nor the Impact of his speeches, nor his Midas talent as fundraiser for his party, nor his rare skill in rejoicing his friends, infuriating his enemies and con founding the press, nor his astonishing success in transmuting himself from a buffoon and bumbler, complete with mala propisms and pratfalls, into a formidable political figure. The question remains: What does the Agnew phenomenon mean?

title: F.B.I. FINDS $200,000 AND 2 DUCHAMP OILS
description: The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation announced the recov ery yesterday of two paintings by the late cubist artist Marcel Duchamp and $200,000 in United States Treasury notes.

title: Plant Hailed as AntiPollution Model
description: LINDEN, N.J.  A new sulphuric acid plant that has been called the ultimate in the art of airpollution con trol has gone into full pro duction at the American Cyanamid Company's War ners facility here.

title: Monmouth jockeys
Bruce Confers in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25 (Reuters)  David K. E. Bruce, the new chief American negotiator at the Paris peace talks spent today in consulta tion with officials at the United States Embassy in preparation for taking up his new post, an embassy spokesman said.

title: Stamps
description: FREQUENTLY discussed by American stamp collectors, as well as postal officials, has been the matter of the United States Post Office Depart ment issuing what philatelists call semipostal stamps  postage stamps with two denominations, one for the carriage of the letter, the second with a small plus fee as a contribution to a health, youth or social service program.

title: East Germany Wins 7 Titles As Vienna Swim Meet Opens
description: VIENNA, July 25 (UPI)A surprisingly strong East Ger man swimming team took seven of 11 titles today to dominate the opening round of the Tournament of Nations meet.

title: NIXON CRITICIZED ON MINE SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The Nixon Administration was charged today with calculated Indifference to the unneces sary and avoidable hazards of life in the nation's coal mines.

title: Miss Pickett Randolph Is Bride Of John C.L. Hulley in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, July 25In the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer here this afternoon Miss PickettDavis Randolph, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Middleton Elliott Randolph, was married to John Charles Lincoln Hulley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Mayhem Hulley of Hyannis, Mass. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Francis O. Chapelle, was followed by a reception at the Elkridee Club.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: 2 Maritime Academy Sailors Voted to AllAmerica Team
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 25 (AP)San Diego State, New York Maritime Academy and Southern California placed two men each on the 15man All America collegiate sailing team named today by the Intercolle giate Yacht Racing Commission of North America.

title: the traveler's world
description: PORT ANTONIO, Jamaica  The Ja maica Tourist Board officials looked ask ance when I insisted on driving over here from Kingston via Hardwar Gap, cutting directly across the Grand Ridge of the Blue Mountains in my rental car. They had two apparently legitimate causes for concern:

title: In Spite Of Myself
description: It was obvious that most people Jived on the plane called reality and experienced no serious mental disorientation in doing so. And it was equally obvious that I was accus tomed to feeling safe only on an other plane. Evidently I had con structed for myself a substitute world, or part of one... . This world contained no people except myself, not even my wife or my close friends. It was, as I have said, a safe world.

title: DRUG SITIN STAGED AT HARLEM HOSPITAL
description: A group called United Harlem Drug Fighters last night oc cupied an empty 36bed ward on the seventh floor of Harlem Hospital to press demands for more drugaddiction care for Harlem youth. A spokesman for the 30 sitins said they would remain in the hospital until their demands were met.

title: 6 BATTLES FOUGHT IN SOUTH VIETNAM AS WAR STEPS UP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25Allied forces reported kill ing 119 North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers in steppedup fighting in South Vietnam today and yesterday, but a lull was reported on Cambodian battle fields.

title: Federal Sign Sues Bangor Punta
description: CHICAGO, July 25 (UPI) The Federal Sign and Signal Corporation has filed a pat ent infringement suit against Bangor Punta Operations, Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a Federal company spokesman said today.

title: Vietnam: Coalition Is the Stumbling Block
description: WASHINGTON In almost every important international ne gotiation, certain words come to be endowed with special magic and special menace. They emerge as symbols of the vital political and military stakes each side is fighting for or against. In the Vietnam talks the code word, as President Nixon put it last Monday, is coalition.

title: Kim Agnew Joins Indians Celebrating Nixon Aid Pledge
description: TAOS, N.M., July 25 (AP) Kim Agnew, the daughter of the Vice President, danced with ju bilant Taos Pueblo Indians to day as they celebrated White House support of legislation which would give the tribe ownership of mountain lands they hold sacred.

title: 1,190 Abortions in 23 Days Reported by City Hospitals
description: The Health and Hospital Corporation reported yesterday that 1,190 abortions had been performed in the city's munici pai nospitals between July 1 and midnight Thursday.

title: T.V. Commercial, at $6.60, Wins San Diego Handicap
description: DEL MAR, Calif., July 25 (AP) T. V. Commercial wore down Imaginative in the stretch to win the $21,950 San Diego Handicap by a length today at Del Mar.

title: Olympic Unit Picks O'Connor
description: Arthur W. O'Connor of Flush ing, Queens, Fordham's track and field and crosscountry coach for the past 25 years, has been named to the United States Olympic Track and Field Committee for the 1972 Olym pics.

title: EXJUNIOR STARS IN GOLF SPOTLIGHT
description: Several weeks ago, the Wom en's Metropolitan Golf Associ ation conducted the 36th an nual sisterbrother champion ship over the Richmond County Country Club course in Staten Island. When all the scores were in there was a tie for first between Kathy Linney and her brother, Jim, of Plainfield, and Cynthia Ferro, 15yearold junior golfer, playing with her 18yearold brother, Stephen, from the Forest Hill Field Club. They had identical scores of 40. 3878.

title: Quiz No. 105
description: The position below is the final phase of a problem that was composed about 30 years ago by professor Orin Frink. It is White's move. How does he win?

title: JOHN FERREN, 64, PAINTER, IS DEAD
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 25John Ferren, an abstract artist whose works are in many museums, died yesterday of cancer in Southampton Hos pital. He was 64 years old and lived on Fire Place Road.

title: 2D ECHO BAY RACE TAKEN BY O'NEAL
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 25Patrick O'Neal, sailing the Shields Class sloop, Theresa, was a winner on Long Island Sound today for his second straight race during the first half of Echo Bay Yacht Club's 61st annual regatta.

title: Susan Botnick Plans Marriage Next Month
description: Miss Susan Rose Botnick, an elementary school teacher, in Lindenhurst, L. I., and Joel Martin Better, an air traffic control specialist at the New York Air Route Traffic Con trol Center in Islip, plan to be married next month.

title: KNICKS AGAIN PICK FARMINGDALE SITE
description: For the third consecutive year, the New York Knicker bockers will do their preseason training at the State University of New York at Farmingdale, L. I., it was announced by Ned Irish, club president, and the general managercoach, Wil liam (Red) Holzman. Arrange ments for the use of the univer sity's facilities were completed through the cooperation of the school's president, Dr. Charles W. Laffin Jr.

title: Michele Carpenter Is Wed to R. R. Day
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 25 Miss Michele Marie Car penter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J.
