Carpenter, was married this afternoon to Richard Risley Day, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Day of Barrytown, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Vincent Santo in the garden of the bride's parents' home here.

title: Advertisirig:
description: New York agency men be ware. There is a Minnesota man who at this very mo ment could be thinking about the best way of relieving you of a client or two. Or three.

title: Margaret Helm Becornes Bride Of T. K. Bonney
description: MARION, Mass., July 25 Miss Margaret Seymour Helm and James Kemper Bonney were married here this after noon at St. Gabriel's Episco pal Church. The ceremony was performed by the. Rev. James P. McAlpine.

title: Filipino Outpoints Thai
description: MANILA, July 25 (AP)Er bito Salavaria of the Philippines outpointed Berkrerk Chartvan chai of Thailand the World Box ing Association flyweight cham pion in a nontitle 10round fight tonight. Salvaria the Orient champion weighed 113 pounds to 115 for Chartvanchai.

title: School Post Filled
description: The Board of Education an nounced yesterday the appoint ment of Miss Gertrude E. Unser as chairman of the Board of Examiners of which she has been a member since 1959. She succeeds Dr. Jay E. Greene whose oneyear term as chair man has expired. Miss Unser had been serving as the ex aminer's vice chairman since September, 1968.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Levitt and Sons, Inc., the home building concern, is getting into the real estate brokerage business.

title: Vatican Aide Condemns Homosexual Marriages
description: ROME, July 25Attempts to consecrate the union between two people of the same sex through a formal marriage ceremony are simply moral aberrations that cannot be ap proved by human conscience, much less Christian conscience, a leading Vatican theologian declared yesterday.

title: Catching Musky Madness Out in Wisconsin
description: SPOONER, Wis. While vacationing at the Spooner home of my inlaws re cently, I detected an unusual behavior pattern developing in my wife's father. He would mope about the house sullenly silent, occasionally forcing a smile at our baby. And then about midmorning, he would get into his car and hurry off. He would return around dinnertime dis traught and on edge. After several days I asked my motherinlaw about this strange condition.

title: Philadelphia Plans a Major CarImport Terminal
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 22 The city of Philadelphia has initiated a project aimed at increasing the automobile im port business from a trickle to a flow.

title: Miss Till Raymond Married Here
description: Miss Jill Raymond, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Jurgen George Raymond of Darien, Conn., and Sarasota, Fla., was married in the Central Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon to Ronald Macdonald Goidsack, an in stitutional salesman here for Wood, Gundy & Co., Inc., a Canadian investment bank in e house.

title: New Lab Started
description: Philip Morris, Inc., has started construction of a new $6million research lab oratory in Richmond, Va. The new building, scheduled to open in mid1972, will increase by more than 60 per cent the concern's research and development space.

title: Goodby City, Hello Farm
description: It was one room on East 37th Street. Or rather, down a few steps from the street, so you could see a lot of legs, human and canine, if you were ever rash enough to pull the cord on the grimy blind and look out of the window.

title: Tunnel to Ease Traffic Is Opened Under Etoile
description: PARIS; July 25The Paris authorities opened a tunnel under the Place de l'Etoile to day in an effort to ease the heavy traffic that for years has been swirling  or inching  around the Arc de Triomphe.

title: Golfer, Getting 2 Aces, Finds Life Begins at 48
description: JAMESTOWN, N. Y., July 25 (AP) Bob Lindahl of Corry, Pa., celebrated his 48th birthday yesterday by scor ing two holesinone and missing a third by two inches.

title: Photography
description: THE first thing you see, in the large and bril liantly theatrical exhi bition of photographs by Richard Avedon currently at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts through Aug. 30, is a largerthanlifesize picture of two hairy men locked in a loving embrace and gaz ing down the length of three galleries toward the entrance where you stand. They seem to be hosts at a marvelous party waiting at the end of a hall to greet the guests, but they are naked as frogs, and unlike Adam and Eve they feel no shame at their nakedness, or at any rate have decided to brazen it out.

title: Gaucho gals
description: Look who's coming to town this fall  gauchos. One of autumn's strongest looks evokes the faraway pampas and their swagger ing Latinstyle cowboys. Whether women range down city streets or country lanes, they can adopt the belowtheknee leather pants or skirts. Teamed with boots, wide belts and big hats, the look is so appealing there needn't be a lonesome cowgirl in sight.

title: LISBON SAID TO SEEK CLOSER AFRICAN TIES
description: LISBON, July 25Dr. Rui Manuel de Madeiros d'Espiney Patricio, Portugal's Foreign Minister, says that his country's policy in Africa is to improve relations with countries adja cent to Angola, Mozambique and Portuguese Guinea.

title: APLANT STRIKERS CHARGE HAZARDS
description: DENVER. July 25Striking workers at a key Atomic Energy Commission plant have slowed American production of nuclear weapons and raised charges thlat management has been care less handling radioactive mate rials.

title: Joan O'Brien Wed in Jersey
description: CAPE MAY, N. J., July 25 Miss Joan O'Brien was mar ried here today at noon to Edward Cranch Ernst in the, Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Star of the Sea. The nuptial mass was cele brated by the Rev. William Buchler.

title: Alan Millers Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Alan B. Miller of New York on July 10 at Beth Is rael Hospital. The child has been named Marc Daniel. Mrs. Miller is the former Miss Jill Stein. Her husband is vice president of American Medi corp, Inc., owners of private hospitals.

title: COMPANY TO TEACH GARY, IND., PUPILS
description: The Gary, Ind., public school system has contracted with a private company, Behavioral Research Laboratories, to run one of its elementary schools this fall. It is believed to be the first city in the nation to turn over the entire operation of a single school to such an ex periment.

title: John B. Jessup, 75, Dies; Civic Leader in Delaware
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 25 (AP)John B. Jessup, banker, community leader and crime fighter, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Garbage Collection Poses Mounting Political Problem for Lindsay
description: For years, collecting garbage has been an almost, intractable problem for the city's Depart ment of Sanitation. Now it has also become a political problem for the Environmental Protec tion Administration and the Mayor.

title: De Gaulle Speaks Through His Memoirs Of Hope
description: PARISCharles de Gaulle, who has been selfemployed since April 28, 1969, has just turned over to his publisher the fruits of more than a year of labor.

title: Linda Daniels Becomes Bride Of Fred Finley
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., July 25St. John's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Linda Ann Daniels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard DeVoe Daniels of West Hartford and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Fred Butler Finley.

title: A Deputy Editor of Pravda Heads Publishing Industry
description: MOSCOW, July 25 (Reuters) A deputy editor of Pravda took charge of the Soviet Union's publishing industry yes terday.

title: Wife Sues Norton Simon
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25 (UPI) The wife of Norton Simon. the millionaire industrialist, filed suit yesterday to end their 37 year marriage because of ir reconciable differences. Mr. Simon was recently an unsuc cessful candidate fur the Re publican Senate nomination.

title: To Some Latin Revolutionaries, It Is Marxism, Si! Castro, No!
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24 As you Yankees would ex press it, a young Chilean Marxist said, Fidel Castro has turned fink.

title: Dorothy Miner, J. E. O'Driscoll Are Wed Here
description: Miss Dorothy Marie Miner, a lawyer now studying for a master's degree in urban planning at Columbia Uni versity, and James Edward O'Driscoll, a lecturer in the American language program at Columbia, were married here yesterday at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church.

title: Brothers, 4 and 2, Injured In 4Story Fall to Ground
description: Two young brothers fell four stories from a bedroom window yesterday afternoon and were critically injured when they landed on the ground in the rear yard of the tenement in which they lived in Brooklyn's Park Slone section.

title: Dance
description: LONDON. HOME thoughts from abroad. I want to write about a number of as pects of European bal let, but it just so happens that no one aspect is com pletely explored. So here I am, not precisely at a loss for words but looking for one of those perhaps all too glib unifying themes that go to make up what we critics call a Sunday piece.

title: Penelope Wick Wed in Suburbs
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 25  Miss Penelope Wick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Arms Wick Jr., was married at Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon to James Winston De Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Cornell De Young of Kenil worth, Ill.

title: Zone Defense, No Doubt
description: Lock Haven State defeated Mansfield State in basketball, 201, in 1902.

title: Q:
description: Victorian

title: Warnings by Palestinians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 The two main Palestinian com mando organizations threatened today to resort to force to halt acceptance of the United States peace initiative.

title: Four Counties Designated To Provide Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) Four more counties in three states have been designated by Secretary of Agriculture Clif ford M. Hardin to begin food, stamp programs for needy fam ilies.

title: $953,228 GIVEN NEEDIEST CASES
description: The final accounting of the 196970 appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund showed that a total of $953,228.60 was received from 15.578 contributors.

title: Paul Henry De Forest Marries Alice Michele Cornacchia
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. T., July 25Miss Alice Michele Cornacchia, a research as sistant at National Endow ment for the Arts in Wash ington, and Paul Henry De Forest, assistant professor of political science at Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago, were married here today. A nuptial mass was periormen in St. Agnes Ca thedral by Msgr. John R. McGanr

title: Coins
description: WINNERS in the 1970 National Coin Week competition were announced fol lowing the judging of 53 club and numerous individual reports at the American Nu mismatic Association Library in Colorado Springs. John Dunn, Harold H. Hartman and Clark A. Yowell served as judges.

title: The Theater Is Born Within Us
description: I AM told I am born a playwright at a time when the Theater is dy ing. Somehow I think if my birth were better un derstood, it would show that the Theater is breathing quite autonomously and will con tinue to do so until the last man on earth raises a pistol and blasts his head off (an occasion I am quite devoted to helping avoid).

title: Mother of Sihanouk Moved From Palace
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 25 (UPI)  The Cambodian Government moved Queen Sisowath Kossamak Neari reath, the mother of the de posed Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, from the royal palace to a villa guard ed by troops early today.

title: WIGGER INCREASES MARGIN IN SHOOTING
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 25 (AP)Army Maj. Lones Wigger of Carter, Mont., who already has won the threeposition smallbore and air rifle titles, appears to be on his way to the 300meter threeposition free rifle crown at the 10th United States international shooting championships.

title: Job Changes:
description: Executive vice presidents were named last week at ACF Industries, Inc., and ForemostMcKesson. Inc.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
In The Nation: Beyond the Flame and Rhetoric
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Jo seph D. Tydings of Maryland, who led the successful effort to impose a punitive anticrime bill on the District of Columbia, said after the battle that he was glad the measure had survived all the flame and rhetoric of its opponents.

title: OPERA BY HENZE MAKES FINE FILM
description: Of the 11 works shown in Lincoln Center's Opera on Film series at Philharmonic Hall this month, only one, alas, was composed in recent years. But it, Hans Werner Henze's The Young Lord, proved to be so strong that the viewer was able to go away from it with renewed confidence in the performance andfilming of the niece.

title: Westbury Breaks Its Betting Mark as Public Affair Wins Closing Feature
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 25 The distinction of winning the final feature of the Roosevelt Raceway summer meeting, which ended before 31,259 fans tonight, went to the Carmine Abbatiellodriven Public Affair. The 5yearold Darn Flashy Eula Mae Hanover gelding paced threewide through the stretch and beat Sunnie Tar by a nose.

title: Fund Set Up to Accept Donations for Peruvians
description: Donations for the relief of victims of the recent earth quake in Peru are being ac cepted by a special fund set up by the Inter American Press Association in coopera tion with member newspapers in Peru.

title: Leslie Bryant Affianced to G. H. Hume
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., July 25Mr. and Mrs. A. Parker Bryant have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Leslie Parker Bryant to Cpl. George Holli day Hume, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jaquelin Holliday Hume of San Francisco.

title: AUSTERITY MARKS FETE IN BAALBECK
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 Lebanon's International Festi val of Baalbeck is well into its 15th season, though a tone of austerity seems to characterize this year's program when com pared with some or the opu lence of the past. The mood of the audience is more subdued and while still elegant, Beirut society is inclined to less dis play The discreet but noticeable presence of government troops in the monumental temple compound where per formances take place, or in the unanimated streets of the town of Baalbeck itself,, are precau tions to make sure that this region's political and military troubles do not mar its leading cultural festival.

title: Dome Stadium Rejected
description: BUFFALO, N. Y., July 25 (UPI)  The proposed Erie County domed stadium issue is apparently dead as members of the Erie County Legislature, in an allnight session, voted down a proposed lease agreement be tween the county and Domed Stadium, Inc., early today.

title: Western Union Fails One Independent Test
description: Western Union, sensitive to complaints about its service, recently asked analysts at the Arthur D. Little Company to determine how good or bad its service really was. Accord ing to the analysts' report, 99.75 of all telegrams appear to be delivered within three hours.

title: Architecture
description: IT don't change, said a Ford worker of the River Rouge factory as the contract bar gaining began between the United Auto Workers and the car manufacturers last week. It's still the same nasty old plant.

title: CAMARO GAINS LEAD IN 24HOUR CONTEST
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, July 25 (UPI)Ivo Grauls of Belgium, driving a Chevrolet Camaro, jumped into a com manding early lead in the 24 hour Tourism car race.

title: Lhasa Apso Best in Providence Show
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 25  Although a last  minute change of show location gave the Providence County Kennel Club some bad moments, it didn't faze Marvin Frank's Lhasa Apso Ch. KyiChu Friar Tuck one little bit today as he gained the bestinshow spot in a field of 833.

title: The Life of Ezra Pound
description: Ezra Pound will be 85 on Oct. 30, and one can still arouse fury in cer tain circles by taking one or another extreme position concerning him. Was (is) he really a Fascist? A traitor? A paranoid village ex plainer (Gertrude Stein's phrase for him) who overreached his intellec tual and moral limits? A literary operator par excellence who puts the current little cliques to shame? A great poet? A great failure?

title: The Youthful Passion of Juilliard Abroad
description: SPOLETO, ITALY THE morning after the 1970 Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds open ed with a perform ance of Mercadante's op era, Il Giuramento, a re view in La Nazione of Flor ence appeared with a head line that read A new spirit is brought by the young peo ple of the Juilliard School of New York. The review was explicit: They made a tre mendous impression not only for their enthusiasm but for a passion far beyond other pro fessionals, and especially in the orchestra, they reached a technical level of exceptional value.

title: South Africa Constructing Uranium Enrichment Plant
description: CAPETOWN, July 25 (Reu ters)Prime Minister John Vorster has announced that construction is under way in South Africa on a uranium en richment plant to compete with existing plants in the west.

title: Ohio Republican Party Seeking To Ease WriteIn Vote Casting
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 22 The aftermath of a scandal continued to trouble Ohio's Republican party this week.

title: Susan Smith Fiancee Of Bradley Waterman
description: BALTIMORE, July 25Dr. and Mrs. Timothy L. Smith have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Smith, to Bradley. Stuart Waterman, son of Brig. Gen. Bernard S. Walterrnan, U. S. A. retired and Mrs. Waterman of Alex andria, Va.

title: Two Men Beaten in Saigon For Raising Vietcong Flag
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25  Two young Frenchmen held aloft the Vietcong flag from a war statue in down town Saigon today until it was torn down and they were driven from their perch by crowd that pelted the air with stones and then beat them.

title: The Oldest Street in The Nation
description: NEW PALTZ, N. Y.Creeping urbaniza tion has been diverted to spare the Street of the Huguenots, this upstate town's unique monument to early Amer ica. Visitors will be able to see the fruits of the campaign to save the country's oldest original street when the 20th annual Stone House Day is held from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. next Saturday.

title: Costs for SoHo Lofts Are Rising Drastically
description: When Blanche Imerman, an artist, and her husband, Arthur, a writer, found the Lower Manhattan loft they wanted to live in six months ago, they had to pay $3,000 for the right to move in. It's called fixture money in the argot of loft dwellers. In ef fect, $3,000 for a huge refrig erator that didn't work, a kitchen sink, a water heater, two gas space heaters, a stall shower, an oven and a ramshackle toilet with two little steps to it.

title: Letters: Minority Group Is Oppressed In Japan
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Celtics to Open Oct. 21
description: BOSTON, July 25 (UPI)The Boston Celtics will mark their 25th season in the National Basketball Association with a 39game home schedule, start ing Oct. 21 against Detroit.

title: Economy: Which Expert Do You Read?
description: WASHINGTONNow that the ninemonth slide in the economy has apparently about touched bottom, how vigorous should the Government be in pushing the upturn toward full employment? This wholly new issue emerged dramatically last week as the Congressional Joint Economic Committee held an important set of hearings on the state of the economy at midyear.

title: 5 Cut From Giants' Squad, Leaving 20 Rookiesin Camp
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 25 (AP)The New York Giants of the National Football League announced today that five players had been dropped, re ducing the squad of free agents and rookies to 20.

title: Demonstration on Culebra
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 25 (UPI)The 14squaremile is land of Culebra swarmed today with liberators whose leader said they would force the Unit ed States Navy to quit using the island as a target range.

title: Lines Are Drawn for Battle On Arms Spending
description: WASHINGTONSenator John Stennis, a magisterial figure who tends to treat his colleagues like unruly school children, is a much beleaguered man these days. As chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, it is his re sponsibility in the coming weeks to steer a $19.2billion military authorization bill through the Senate, but he is finding that many of his younger, more lib eral colleagues are raising their voices in organized dissent.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Colombian Auto Ferry To Bridge Highway Gap
description: PANAMA CITY, July 25 Colombia is prepared to bridge the last remaining gap in the InterAmerican High way system with a seagoing vehicle ferry, Colombian of ficials visiting here have announced.

title: Flora, Miss.: Time Passed It By
description: FLORA, Miss., July 24 There is only one cotton gin left now and it's down at the end of Main Street on the other side of the railroad tracks.

title: SAMUELS GETS ROLE AS LINDSAY ADVISER
description: Howard J. Samuels has been given an added role in the Lind say administration, his second such appointment since he was defeated for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Migrant Workers Workers: A Life Of Brutal Hardship
description: WASHINGTON  For a child born with brown skin in one of the southern tier of states, of farmmigrant parents who speak a different language from most Americans, the future is already charted.

title: Steam Buffs Plan a Long Hot Summer
description: THE GIANT grain threshing rig came chugging and clanking, its steam whistle whooping, past the grandstand of the Fulton County Fairgrounds in Wauseon, Ohio. Some 8,000 people responded with a standing ovation, a tribute to the rig (a Port Huron 2475 ho) and to its own erengineerdriver, LeRoy Blaker, a vig orous 81yearold from Alvordton, Ohio. The Blaker entry was the acknowledged star of an hourlong parade of these rattling, earsplitting behemoths.

title: MAGAZINE SCORES PENNSY DIRECTORS
description: Most of the blame for the fi nancial problems of the Penn Central Company lies with the directors, Fortune Magazine says in its August issue.

title: List Mixed On Counter And Amex
description: Investors were still avoid ing speculative issues last week. In the period since the May lows for stock prices, the New York Stock Ex change index has gained about 12 per cent, but in the same period the American Stock Exchange index, gen erally more speculative, has risen less than 5 per cent.

title: Chess
description: AFTER the finish of the Belgrade 10board match between the U.S.S.R. and the Rest of the World, four Soviet players and six World players, including the Americans, Bobby Fischer and Sammy Reshevsky, motored to HerzogNovi, Yugoslavia's resort on the Adriatic shore. They were joined by David Bron stein of Russia and M. Ostojic of Yugo slavia. All 12 were scheduled to contest a doubleround 12man round robin in blitz style in five minute games.

title: New Hamashire Negro Runs
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 25 (AP) Melvin Bolden, 51 years old, a commercial artist, this week became the first Negro ever to seek a seat on the five member New Hampshire Execu tive Council.

title: Public Works
description: As a reformed reformer, I think there is something sad, if not tragic, about our en thusiastic young political re formers, the reincarnated Sav anarolas, the professional up lifters suddenly given access to the public treasury to exploit their ideals and notions, the baboons given a bright ball to toss about.

title: Con Ed Under Criticism For Its Sulphur Fumes
description: Consolidated Edison, the company that is by far the largest emitter of sulphur dioxide into the city's atmos phere, is coming under in creasing attack for declining to install devices to trap the noxious gas instead of re leasing it.

title: Maureen Miller Is Bride in California
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., July 25Miss Maureen Miller, daughter of Mrs. Bruce H. Sage of South Laguna and the late Marvin G. Miller, was married in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon to Michael Stephen Grace. The bride groom, known as Stephen, is a son of J. Peter Grace, pres ident of W. R. Grace & Co., the international industrial concern, and Mrs. Grace of Manhasset, LI., and a great grandson of the late William Russell Grace, who founded the company and was twice Mayor of New York.

title: DECLINE REPORTED IN HOTEL BUSINESS
description: The nation's hotels have be gun to feel a slump stemming largely from the general busi ness downturn.

description: ROME, July 25 (AP)Italy's national airline, Alitalia, can celed more than 50 internation al flights today because of a 24hour pilot's strike.

title: Financial Vise Grips Owners In the Bronx
description: A cloud of uncertainty is hanging over uncounted numbers of landlords in the Bronx who bought rent controlled apartment buildings during the active real estate market of the late nineteenfifties and early sixties.

title: City Architects and Builders Join in Lobby at Washington Protesting the War
description: WASHINGTON. July 25In contrast to recent demonstra tions by construction workers supporting President Nixon's policies in Indochina, a group of New York City area archi tects, engineers and builders who plan the projects the con struction workers build lobbied here this week against those policies.

title: 11 Arrested in Drug Raid On a Queens Apartment
description: A narcotics raid in the Woodside section of Queens yesterday resulted in the arrest of 11 persons and the seizure of what the police estimated to be $75,000 to $100,000 worth of illicit drugs. The raid was at the apartment of Michael Delgado, 27 years old, at 4826 44th Street.

title: Criminals At Large
description: A good bit of suspense is inherent in the unveiling of a murderous conspiracy  for example, the slaying of a series of perhaps dimly related peo ple for no discernible motive. Philip MacDonald played this theme exceedingly well in his 1959 novel The List of Adrian Messenger, and Loren Singer now also uses it as his point of departure in THE PARAL LAX VIEW (Doubleday, $4.95). But Mr. Singer's prose has a deliberate and annoying tur bidity, and the telling is heavy with social and political impli cation. Twentyfive people wit nessed some terrifying earlier event, and of these only four still live. To them it becomes apparent that many of the 21 deaths were arranged. The sur vivors, driven together by fear but no mutual trust or affection, inquire, strike tender nerves, provoke and commit violence, react in different ways accord ing to their psychological frameworks (guilt, zest), and plunge toward a fatal inevita bility. What, the author seems to wonder in all this, are the means human (but not neces sarily humane) society might itself?

title: New Men to Be Inducted Into Baseball's Hall of Fame
Pop
description: HE IS, everyone agrees, the hottest thing in Nashville right now and If you're hot in Nashville, man, you're hot everywhere. He's just been in Peru with Dennis Hopper, writing and singing songs for Hopper's The Last Movie. Johnny Cash, Roger Miller and Ray Stevens have been recording his numbers. He sings three songs on the soundtrack of Ned Kelly, the Tony Richardson movie in which Mick Jagger plays the title role of a notorious Australian outlaw. And though he, started off as a songwriter, he's just cut an album of his own.

title: Riggs Thrills Retarded Children With Tennis Clinic, Exhibition
description: The little boy appeared mes merized as Bobby Riggs bounced a tennis ball off his racquet several times.

title: Schools in Pittsburgh I old To End Paddling of Pupils
description: PITTSBURGH, July 25 (UPI) A plan to eliminate the pad ding of students in the city schools has been approved by the Pittsburgr Board of Public Education.

title: Larchmont Entries System Scored
description: There were four weekend days of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week sailing on which competition was scheduled for cruising yachts, and the fact that there was a gratifying number of starters every time was due to an extremely leni ent policy about entry closings, said Donald B. King, the race committee chairman last week. This season's new system for obtaining and mailing entry blank was a handicap, not a help, he said.

title: INTELSAT SATELLITE IS LOST OVER PACIFIC
description: WASHINGTON, July, 25 (UPI)  The Communications Satellite Corporation said:, to day, that a $13million satellite planned for an orbit above the Pacific Ocean had been lat in space.

description: LONDONAfternoon sunlight glistened inside the Gothic cham ber. Tourists, gripping Europe on Five Dollars a Day, sat on wooden benches. Members of the House of Commons and visitors crowded the aisles and leaned against the pale gray oak walls.

description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 25  King Hussein postponed a cru cial Cabinet meeting that had been scheduled for today to endorse the declaration of ac ceptance by President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United States proposals for a Middle Eastern settlement.

description: The Garden State Parkway had its biggest day on record on Saturday, July 18, when nearly 700,000 passenger ve hicles used it, causing much congestion, according to John P. Gallagher, chairman of the New Jersey Highway Author ity.

title: . . .Yet Paradise Enow for This City Dweller
description: MARK TWAIN braved the ocean in roughriding tubs to get to Bermuda. The island, he commented, is like Para dise, but one has to go through Purga tory to get there. Exactly.

description: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., July 25 (UPI)Rudy Vallee, the singer, said today he wanted to run for the Senate from California to clean up the mess in the Pentagon.

title: Law
description: It was, undeniably, a victory for the President  he had promised to be tough on crim inals, and the District of Co lumbia Crime Bill, passed on Thursday by the Senate, was very tough indeed. It was a vic tory for Attorney General John Mitchell to  he, after all, had devised the bill and had then held it up as a model code. And it was a victory also for all the Senators and Con gressmen who in 1968 rode into Washington on the lawand order wave, and for the voters who built the wave as well.

title: Computers Help Reduce Costs. Of Lining Up Coast Horse Shows

Doolittle pre dicted log test. The 25.45mile event, which drew 12 competi tors, started and finished off the Stamford Yacht Club.

description: PORT WASHINGTON,. L. I., July 25Harold Hecht captured Ensivn Class honors today in the Cow Bay area, Yacht Racing Association of Long Is land Sound competition, spon sored by the Knickerbocker Yacht Club.

title: MARSHALL STARS
Operation Overflight
description: On the morning of May 1, 1960, a 30yearold pilot from a coalminer's family in Appalachia took off on a secret recpnnaissance mission over Russia under orders from the Cen tral Intelligence Agency. To Francis Gary Powers, an Air Force pilot with a tottering marriage, a restless yearn ing for excitement and an ephemeral feeling that he hadn't really proved himself, the C.I.A.'s offer of an 18 month contract had seemed, almost too easily, ideal.

title: Tony Perkins: All Steamed Up About Directing
description: HEALTHY trees the color of fresh dill brushed the upstairs windows of the neat little house Chelsea. Tony Perkins, the director and accidental star of Steambath, leaned out and told me ring the bell next to the note for the airconditioning man. The door swung open. Someone had thrown a book of Pauline Kael movie reviews down the stairs. I straight ened its spine, climbed over the famous Tony Perkins bicycle that shocked everybody recently when he rode it to the Dick Caveit show in bluejeans, and climbed the stairs to the secondfloor living room where the man who (after Psycho)made impossible to take a, shower without anxiety was waiting.

title: Miss Ellen Carter Plans Marriage
description: The future bride, a gradu ate of the Walden School and Bennington College, has been administrator of the Phoenix Institute, the education de partment of the Phoenix House programs in New York.

title: Bob & Carol & Then What?
description: HOLLY WOOD IT is a graduation, of sorts. As the children sing Over the Rainbow, a giraffe and two small elephants, led by handlers in red silk robes, stroll by. Fif teen men in black suits and the kind of widebrimmed black hats favored by Feder ico Fellini watch the proceed ings from the top of a shed in the schoolyard. A small horde of Vietcong run past. A huge woman dressed as a baby and a statuesque blonde midget in a lowcut dress look on from the sidelines. A horse drawn landau, driven by a man in wig and livery, passes by, carrying two passengers who might well be Jeanne Moreau and Donald Suther land.

title: Jane L. Batten Becomes Bride Of P. S. Wild Jr.

title: Point of View:
description: With attention focused on violence in the Parrot's Beak, Kent State, and countless city streets, there is danger of losing sight of a desper ate conflict underlying much of the violence. This is the conflict between Economic Man and Social Man.

title: But Not For Love
description: But Not For Love, Eliza beth Savage's second novel, de scribes agreeably familiar terri toryand I know I have been there before, with a dozen ac complished writers. But it has not previously occurred to me that the familyenclave novel (But Not For Love's category) is governed by conventions as demanding as those of the de tective and Western genres.

title: Allen Takes State Amateur Golf Title
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 25 (AP)Don Allen of Rochester won his fourth state amateur golf championship today at Locust Hill Country Club with a twounderpar, 72hole total of 286.

title: Speaking of Books: Chekhov in English
description: Two months after the great San Francisco earthquake of 1906, Cosmo politan magazine introduced its read ers to a Russian writer of whom most intelligent Americans of that day had never heard. Sharing the pages of the June, 1906, issue with an installment of In the Days of the Comet by H. G. Wells and Jack London's novella Planchette was Anton Chekhov's brief story Sleepy Eye, presented in an excellent, idio matic (and anonymous) translation and illustrated with four stylish art nouveau woodcuts by James Pres ton. It is indeed a somber tale, the introductory editorial note warned the American reader, but its deep significance will not fail to be ap preciated by our readers. Fiction writing in Russia today is no purely diverting matter. Art, under the ex isting conditions, must express what lies nearest to the heart . . .

title: U.S. Disturbed as Mexico Fails To Arrest Narcotics Fugitives
description: WASHINGTON, July 25At least 14 major violators of Fed eral narcotics laws are fugi tives from American justice in Mexico despite this Govern iment's request nearly a year ago that they be brought to trial in Mexican courts.

In the last few weeks, as a result of sev eral Administration decisions on desegregation, some liberals have seen hopeful signs and some conservative supporters of Mr. Nixon, including Senator Strom Thurmond, have worried aloud that liberal advisers around the President are misleading him.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 25 (AP)A cereal breakfast is every bit as good as bacon and eggs, in fact better, says Dr. Frederick J. Stare, chair man of the department of nutrition at Harvard Univer sity.

title: COPLAND PREVAILS AT TANGLEWOOD
description: LENOX, Mass., July 25 Aaron Copland will reach his 70th birthday on Nov. 14. Al though his 70th may not open the floodgates to music by Cop land as Beethoven's 200th (on Dec. 16) will to music by Beethoven, there will be a re spectable supply of Copland around this year, especially at Tanglewood.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: NEW YORK STATE

title: Headliners
description: A 39yearold photographer and his family were some where on the Atlantic in a 31foot sailboat last week in a flight from the easy life. The family, including two children aged 10 and 12, was headed for Africa and expected to at sea about 18 months except for brief port calls. We're doing this mainly because of the kids, the father, Matt Herron, explained before the sloop left New Orleans. We see this as pulling them out of the televisionspectator scene. Mr. Herron said he and his wife felt that a material istic society provided too little challenge and participation. You have fewer experiences like fear, hunger, cold, and the feeling of coming through hardship and knowing you did it on your own, he said. We see our kids growing up without this, and I sense that they don't feel as deeply as they should.

title: COUNCIL SUPPORTS U.N. AID REFORMS
description: GENEVA, July 25The Eco nomic and Social Council has given its approval to extensive reforms in the United Nations aid machinery for developing countries.

description: Two statisticians from a life insurance company, have re ported that the men listed in Who's Who in America Live longer than unlisted men.

I., July 25 The lateness in the arrival of Gretel II, Australia's candi date to remove the America's Cup from its small circular room at the New York Yacht Club, probably has hurt her chances to beat the French challenge candidate, France, in the qualifying races that lie ahead. But there were miti gating circumstances.

title: Philip Wiggenhauser Jr. Weds Miss Mary Breck, '65. Debutante

title: Tigers Horton Out 3 Weeks

An examination at Ford Hospital disclosed Horton had torn ligaments in the left ankle. It was placed in a walk ing cast for at least 10 days.

Saputelli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saputelli of Haddonfield, N. J. Msgr. F. Harold Nott performed the ceremony in St. Agnes Ro man Catholic Church.

description: LONDON, July 25 (AP) Britain's potteries are facing crucial times, according to a Government report.

title: Concern Fights Crime in Business
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 International Intelligence, Inc.  Intertel for short sounds like a title by Ian Fleming, and the analogy is not completely inappropriate.

title: Squatters to Leave Ellis Island On Saturday butWill Be Back
description: The 63 squatters who have occupied the crumbling build ings and overgrown land of Ellis Island since last Monday, plan to evacuate it next Satur day but hope to return later to make it a rehabilitation center where 7,000 people would live and be selfsupporting.

title: Television
description: PHILADELPHIA.WHO'S that handsome fellow on the flying trapeze? Who, that lanky, barechested, tall and winsome figure in pretty pink tights and gold sequined belt, swinging in midair, as the band plays a funky circus waltz and the TV cameras grind? By Jove, by gum and heavenstoBetsyit's none other than George Plimpton!

title: Front Page 1  No Title
2 Soviet ATests Recorded
description: UPPSALA, Sweden, July 25 (AP)The Uppsala Seismologi cal Institute reported today that it had recorded two Soviet un derground nuclear tests during the last four days near Semipa latinsk in Siberia, some 300 miles from the border of Sinki ang province in China.

title: Maine's Poor Debtor Law Is Declared. Unconstitutional
description: PORTLAND, Maine, July 25 (UPI)Maine's socalled poor debtor law has been ruled un constitutional in Federal Dis trict Court.

title: POWER PROBLEM THREATENS CITY
description: New Yorkers confront possi ble electric power problems this week because of forecasts of sustained hot and humid weath er at least into Wednesday.

title: Mrs. Erickson Is Remarried
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 25Mrs. Emily Deans Erickson, head of the Lower and Middle Schools at the Lenox School in New York, was married today to Ken neth Stirling Brown, a senior program engineer with the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corpora tion in Groton, Conn.

title: Asian Yacht Sails Cape Cod Waters
description: HYANNIS, Mass.Yachts men and boatmen skirting the coast of New England this year may have been sur prised and perplexed at the sight of an unusual ketch from overseas being piloted alone by her owner, John A. Hastings of South Yarmouth.

title: Miss Goldberg Fiancee Of Richard. H. Drucker
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 25 Mrs. Max Goldberg has an nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Linda Ann Goldberg, daughter also of the late Mr. Goldberg, to Richard Howard Drucker. He is the son of. Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Drucker of Brook lyn, New York.

title: Eisenhowers Serve at Wedding Of Their Classmates in College
description: HOUSTON, July 25 (AP) When Julie Nixon married David Eisenhower on Dec. 22, 1968, in New York, Susan Elizabeth Harvin of Houston was a bridesmaid. Today, Mrs. Eisenhower was a bride maid at Miss Harvin's wed ding to Army Lieut. Robert A. Lawhon, also of Houston in St. John's Episcopal Chuch here. David Eisen hower, who was a classmate of the bridegroom at Am herst College, was an usher.

title: British Set Depth Record
description: VALETTA, Malta, July 25 (UPI)A British Royal Navy team from the submarine Osiris, practicing new submarine es cape techniques, has set a depth record with an escape from 600 feet, a team spokesman said. The old record of 485 feet was set in 1965.

title: Rail Trustee's Job: Theory Easy, Reality Endless
Miss Virginia Rynne, Lawyer Betrothed to Donald L. Maggin
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., July 25The engagement of Miss Virginia Rynne to Donald L. Maggin, former chief national officer for Project Head Start, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Rynne.

title: Orioles Triumph Over Twins, 65, On Buford Homer
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 25Don Buford powered the Baltimore Orioles to a 65 vic tory over the Minnesota Twins today, with a tworun, eighth inning homer.

title: CITY NEGLECTING CHILDREN'S HOMES
description: Our problem is that this is a court of last resort. said George F. Freeman, acting ex ecutive director of the Chil dren's Center. These are the children who have been re jected by their homes, and, in nine out of ten cases, by the voluntary agencies. We get the most deprived of the deprived.

title: Italian Expert Denies Charge
description: ROME, July 25  A leading Italian hydrologist said here this week that it is ridiculous for French officials to blame sewage from Italy for the pol ution along France's Riviera beaches, since there are no major shore currents in this part of the Mediterranean to (tarry the filth from one coun try to another.

title: Mozambique Echoes With Talk of Military Victory
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mo zambique, July 11 There is a new wave of hope among Portuguese settlers in this pros perous colonial capital that it will be possible to end the six yearold guerrilla war in the north.

title: Births
description: ROSINDr. and Mrs. Henry David Rosin (nee Nancy Claire Peikin) of Englewood, NJ are delighted to announce the arrival of their son, Robert Bradley, on July 16, 1970 Diane Sue, Matthew Lawrence, and Laura Elizabeth are his lucky brother and sisters.

title: Anniversaries
description: BRENNERJack and Bertha. Congratulations on your 50th wedding anniversary from your children and grandchildren.

title: Tips and Hints
description: Doityourself painters often do their outside painting at this time of yearin spite of the hot weather  because this is when they have time for outdoor jabs. However, work should be planned to avoid working in direct sun when temperatures climb up close to the 90s since this makes paint dry too fast to provide a good bond and may result in blistering. In most cases this can be done by following the sun around the housein other words, by starting on the shady side in the morning and then moving to another side when the sun strikes the first side.

title: Three Studies Planned by Fund
description: Studies that will cover multinational corporations, problems of underdeveloped countries and Federal eco nomic policies since the New Deal era were announced last week by the Twentieth Century Fund.

title: Child to Tuerkheimers
description: A daughter was born June 27 to Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Tuerkheimer of Brooklyn at the LeRoy Hospital in New York. Mrs. Tuerkheimer is the former. Barbara Wolfson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Wolfson of Rego Park, Queens. The child has been named Deborah Beth.

title: William D. Colby And Betsey Taft To Be Married
description: TENAFLY, N: J., July 25 Mr. and Mrs. Harold Hum phrey Whittemore have an nounced the engagement of Mrs. Whittemore's daughter, Miss Eliza (Betsey) Williams Taft, to William Dutton Col by, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Howard Colby of Brookline, Mass.

title: Son to Mrs. John Saul
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. John M. Saul of Nairobi, Kenya, on July 6 there. Mrs. Saul is the former Miss Muriel Mazaltob of Paris. The child, the couple's second son, who is named Eric, is a grandson of Hyman Saul, a vice presi dent of Saks Fifth Avenue, and Mrs. Saul of New York. The infant's father is a con sulting geologist in Africa.

title: F. A. Craven Weds Jane Dorrance
description: CRANBURY, N. J., July 25 The First Presbyterian Church here was the setting this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Jane Ellen Dorrance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Dorrance Jr. of Penn Valley, Pa., to Frank Alfred Craven. He is the son of Mrs. Frank Tempest Craven of Yardley, Pa., and the late Mr. Craven. The Rev. Carl Wolf per formed the ceremony. the son of Mrs. Frank Tempest Craven of Yardley, Pa., and the late Mr. Craven. The Rev. Carl Wolf per formed the ceremony.

title: EXPOS WIN, 105, AND QUIT CELLAR
description: MONTREAL, July 25 (AP) Ron Fairly's grandslam homer in the fourth inning helped propel the Montreal Expos to a 105 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight.

title: SQUATTERS OCCUPY FLATS ON WEST SIDE
description: More than 100 persons moved into two nearly vacant build ings at 112th Street and Am sterdam Avenue late last night in an effort to keep an agency of the Episcopal Church from building a home for the elderly on the site.

title: French Office Here Seeks U.S. Investment
description: If a documentary were be ing made on the new French drive to attract American in vestment, a key bit of script might read: Fade out de Gaulle; zoom in on Marie Moniaue Steckel.

title: SCHOOL PROMISES READING SUCCESS
description: OSSINING, N.Y. July 25A public school in a lowincome neighborhood here has guar anteed parents of the incoming kindergarten class that by next June 90 per cent of the children in the class will be reading at the nationwide average level and that 70 per cent of these, will be above that level.

title: Lombardi Elected to Board
description: Vince Lombardi, coach of the Washington Redskins; has been elected to a threeyear term on the Fordham University Board of Trustees.

title: Drills by Chiefs Cause Division In Pro Football Players' Union
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 25A rift in the professional football Players' Association became evident today. It evolved from the decision by some members of the Kansas City Chiefs to begin training for Friday night's game against the Col lege AllStars in defiance of the association.

title: TOY SOLDIER TAKES HORSE SHOW CROWN
description: CLEVELAND, July 25 (AP) Steve Stephens of Palmetto, Fla., rode Toy Soldier to the $4,000 Cleveland Grand Prix championship today in the 21st annual Chagrin ValleyProfes sional Horsemen's Association horse show.

title: Court Records Show Weatherman Charged With Bombing Conspiracy Used Different Names
description: Inquiries into the back ground of one of the 13 Weathermen indicted Thursday for conspiracy to plant bombs around the country have led to a mysterious web of name changes and intrigue.

title: Virginia Nuptials for Irene Kobus
description: GREAT FALLS, Va., July 25  Miss Irene Kobus, a former administrative secre tary at the C.B.S. Television Stations division of the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem Inc in New York, was married here today to Ashby Kendall Raine Jr., a vice president in the international division of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York.

title: Virginia Cracker, $153, Wins Delaware Oaks
description: STANTON, Del., July 25 (AP) Virginia Cracker, the longest shot in a field of a dozen 3yearold fillies, scored a stun ning upset at Delaware Park today when she defeated Office Queen by 1 lengths in the $60.800 Delaware Oaks.

title: NIJINSKY EXTENDS UNBEATEN STRING
description: ASCOT, England, July 25 (AP)Nijinsky, the American owned wonder horse of Euro pean racing, looked like the multimilliondollar colt he is today by winning the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes here.

title: Suit on Broken Tooth Fails
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) Judge Edward A. Beard has ruled that a pit in a martini olive is not a foreign object, even if a restaurant customer breaks a tooth on it. In the Court of General Sessions. Philip R. Hochberg's $5,000 damage Suit against O'Donnell's Restau rant, where he unsuspectingly bit into the olive and cracked a molar, was dismissed.

title: ExCity College Baseball Star Hopes to Rise in Cardinal Chain
description: From riding the subway in New York to traveling on the team bus in Lewiston, Idaho, Barry Poris has tasted life in a large eastern city and a small town in the far west. A former City College base ball star, he is now playing in the St. Louis Cardinals organi zation.

title: Long Branch Fears Plans for Signal Corps School
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J.,Local public apathy and a noncom mittal posture in the Pentagon have given a quixotic air to crusade here to save the Army's Signal Corps school at nearby Fort Monmouth.

title: Role of Women Sparks Debate By Congresswoman and Doctor
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The suitability of women for impor tant jobs has become the sub ject of intense personal attacks within the high councils of the Democratic party, and Hubert H. Humphrey's intervention has not sufficed to make peace.

title: 16 Bills Players Organize Training Base Near Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, July 25 (AP)Six teen experienced players of the Buffalo Bills and three newcom ers opened a training camp to day in nearby Hamburg, 40 miles from where Coach John Rauch is working with 29 rook ies.

title: Swazi King Marks 71st Birthday
description: MBABANE, Swaziland, July 22King Sobhuza II, the world's longest reigning mon arch, celebrated his official birthday today. He is 71 and has been Ngwenyama or King of the Swazis, since 1921.

title: What's New in Art
description: NEW YORK CITY Recent Openings

title: GREECE SENTENCES MEN IN EL AL ATTACK
description: ATHENS, Sunday, July 26 An Athens court today gave prison sentences to two of the seven Arab commandos whose release has been pledged by the Greek Government in exchange for the lives of 55 passengers and crewmen on an Olympic Airways plane.

title: French Health Plan Faced With Crisis Over Rising Deficit
description: PARIS, July 25France's sys tem of partly socialized medi cine is facing a crisis as a result of huge deficits that the Gov ernment is unable to overcome in the short run.

title: Dance Mailbag
description: Stravinsky vs. Barnes on That Firebird

title: BAE2A IS ABOARD VICTOR ON GRASS
description: CHICAGO, July 25 (UPI) Ogden Phipps's The Pruner, given a flawless ride by Bra ulio Baeza, moved in front at the 16th pole and captured the $110,300 American Derby on the grass today at Arlington Park by threequarters of length.

title: All About Betsy Banal
description: DON'T call me Bog ey's baby, baby. With these words the sultry actress led me into her plush coopera tive apartment in the Dako ta Staton, a Gothic hotel on New York's Upper West Side. I mean I'm me. I had come to interview the new toast of Broadway, Lena (Betsy) Banal  once a siren of the silver screen and now a Tony winner for her role in the new smash Broadway musi cal, Boo! Miss Banal was referring, of course, to her famous daddy  Bogey Bo linsky, opposite whom she had starred in her first mo vie at the age of 12, playing the role of a gun moll be ing kept by a Mafia gang ster (Bolinsky). Movie fans will long remember the scene where Bolinsky picks her up after recess and she utters the immortal screen lines  If you want me, ask mother.

title: French Act to Curb Maoists
description: PARIS, July 25 (UPI)The Interior Ministry today ordered the police to tighten security measures and stop young Mao ists trying to spoil the sum mer pleasures of the wealthy. Small hands of leftists have damaged expensive cars and daubed yachts, villas and cars with slogans

title: REDS BEAT CARDS FOR CLONINGER, 53
description: CINCINNATI, July 25 (UPI) Johnny Bench hit a threerun homer in the first inning and the Cincinnati Reds went on to a 53 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight and stretched their lead over the secondplace Los Angeles Dodgers to 12 games in the National League's Western Division.

title: The Van Wyck Brooks Lewis Mumford Letters
description: This remarkable exchange of let ters tells a story that really begins in the spring of 1920, when Lewis Mumford was invited to serve in London as acting editor of the Soci ological Review. Not yet 25 years old, he was already known in New York as a most promising young man. In England he dreamed of a career in city planning with his Scot tish master Patrick Geddes, but some thing happened to change his mind. He read A Reviewer's Notebook, the column that Van Wyck Brooks was then contributing to the weekly Freeman. Years later he was to say in a letter to Brooks, Your words made me come back to America when I read them . . . they seemed di rected personally at me, and I can still remember the train journey from London to Scarborough on which I read them and realized that they settled my fate for me and made only one decision possible: to return.

title: 9 Seized atJones Beach On Marijuana Charges
description: WANTAGH, L.I. July 25 Nine persons were arrested at Jones Beach State Park yester day and charged either with possession of marijuana or loi tering to use it.

title: Susan Scranton Plans Bridal to Richard Wolf
description: DALTON, Pa., July 25 Mr. and Mrs. William Warren Scranton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Scran ton, to Richard Anthony Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Wolf of New York.

title: BULGARIAN AIDES ARRIVE IN HAVANA
description: MIAMI, July 25Todor Zhiv kov First Secretary of the Bul garian Communist Party and chairman of the Bulgarian Council of Ministers, arrived in Cuba today for an 11day of ficial visit.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: ANEW type of self powered Flashcube that is fired without elec tricityin other words, without need for batteries has just recently been in troduced by Sylvania Elec tric Products and the Gen eral Electric Company. Called Magicubes (both companies use the same name) these new fourinone flash bulbs look almost exactly like the electrically powered Flash cubes and give off about the same amount of light. How ever, they are fired mechani cally by means of a per cussion system which is actuated by a special builtin torsion spring.

title: UNESCO RESEARCH ON SEA PLANNED
description: PARIS, July 25More than 20 countries, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Israel and Syria, are expected to cooperate next year in a vast program of research concerning the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Nelson, said Luciano Re bay over the telephone, I remember that last year you said you would like to shoot my well. Would you still like to do it?.

title: Mourning Becomes the English
description: BRIGHTON, EnglandAnyone visiting London might want to run down to Brighton for the dayto see George IV's gorgeously ludicrous Royal Pavilion or simply to ride the Brighton Belle, the train that drew from Lord Olivier as much wrath as he ever displayed on the stage by removing kippers from its breakfast menu. But that's the tour for the quick; a tour geared to the dead is currently proving to be even more lively.

title: Astor Cup Sailing Postponed by Fog At Newport Site
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 25 Two hours 40 minutes of wait ing in the starting area ended in a postponement of the Astor Cup sailing that was to have begun the New York Yacht Club cruise today.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: AGAINST the background of a stabiliz ing economy and abating price pres sures, top Administration officials from President Nixon down have suddenly begun a jawboning process on behalf of a new stimulus for the economy.

title: Mary C. Goett Becomes Bride
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 25 Miss Mary. Carolyn Goett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Joseph Goett of Wil mington, and Joseph Thad deus Greco were married here this morning in St. Mary Magdalen Roman. Catholic Church. Msgr., John H. Dew son performed the ceremony.

title: ISRAELI JETS STRIKE ALONG ENTIRE CANAL
description: TEL AVIV, July 25 (AP)Is raeli planes returned to the Suez Canal zone today to con tinue their daily bombing and strafing attacks against United Arab Republic positions, an army spokesman said.

title: Theater: London Enigma
description: LONDON, July 25.  Why do some plays run, and some plays fold? It is the basic question of the commercial theater, and if you are a producer your whole future may depend upon your answer.

title: WELFARE REFORM MAY BECOME RIDER
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Senator Russell B. Long, the powerful chairman of the Sen ate Finance Committee, has de cided to attach President Nixon's welfare reform plan probably in a somewhat revised form  to the pending omnibus Social Security bill.

title: Mideast 2: Israel Finds Herself in Tough Spot
description: JERUSALEM  Nasser sets the trapthat was the first edi torial reaction of the Jerusalem Post after President Gamal Abdel Nasser's national day speech last Thursday night. As the text fell under more careful expert scru tiny, Israeli fears of a trap only deepened.

title: Music
description: MARLBORO, VT. FRANK SOLOMON, who for years has been an official at the Marl boro Music Festival, is naturally full of statistics. The other week end, at the opening of the festival in Vermont, he was talking about the ac tivity of the 80 participants. At Marl boro there are no students. There are carticipants, Rudolf Serkin is a partici ??ant. Pablo Casals is a participant. The Young cellist Miklos Perenyi, who is at Marlboro for the first time, is a par ticipant. Anyway, Solomon was giving visitor a rundown on the quantity of music played at Marlboro during the summer.

title: Police Killing of Unarmed Black Stirs Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES. July 25 Early last June 20, in an inci dent that Police Chief Edward Davis later described as trag ic, Jerry Lee Arnie, a 24year old black veteran of the Viet nam war, was shot to death by the nonce in front of his home.

title: Acquired Concerns Look Back in Happiness
description: The conglomerates, such high fliers in the boom days, have been among the most severely injured casualties of the socalled Nixon bear market. It would seem logical that some of the lesser com panies gobbled up by the conglomerates between 1965 and 1968 would have some regrets.

title: Amateur Owners and Handlers Often Successful Showing Dogs
description: For the average onedog owner who gets up the cour age to show his pet, it is a formidable experience. After a few shows, if his dog fails to get a ribbon, the owner becomes discouraged, decides there is no opportunity for an amateur and either stops showing or turns his pup over to a professional handler.

title: Austrian Boy Picks a Golf Camp In New Jersey Over Tour of U.S.
description: HILLSBOROUGH, N. J.  A 15yearold Austrian boy, of fered a choice of touring thel United States or spending three weeks at a golf camp, surprised his friends by passing up the tour.

title: VATICAN UNIT DRAFTS! A NEW CONSTITUTION!
description: ROME, July 25Roman Cath olic bishops will soon receive a final draft of the new Funda mental Law of the Church, form of constitution that was initiated by Pope John XXIII in 1962 and formally requested by the bishops at their 1967 synod.

title: Britain 2: Dock Strike Begins to Hurt the Housewife
description: LONDON  A housewife from Battersea: Every morning I go to the market, and the apples, the pears, the tomatoes are a couple of coppers [pennies] higher. My husband says, Don't buy no fruit. But I like a nice piece of fruit in the afternoon.

title: Calendar of Horse Show Events
description: TodayMeadowbrook Hounds, Charles Hickock Estate, Whit ney Lane, Old Westbury. L. I. Green, amateurowner and junior working hunters; ponies, equita tion. 9 A.M.

title: British Delay Use of Troops As Dock Walkout Continues
description: LONDON, July 25 (UPI)The British Government kept troops out of the country's strike bound ports and held back ac; tion to control food prices today in preparation for new peace moves next week.

title: NoHitter What Doctor Ordered To Cheer Up Singer of Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES, July 23 Bill Singer's determined comeback from hepatitis to nohit fame this week was acclaimed as little short of a miracle by the Los Ange les Dodgers pitcher's physi cian.

title: Nuptials Held for Miss Jill D. Friedman
description: WESTON, Conn., July 25 Miss Jill Diane Friedman and GiariniPonzini of Milan and Bellagio, Italy, were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fried man. The ceremony was per formed by Justice of the Peace Daniel Forbes. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Italo Ponzini of Bellagio.

title: Garrett Sticks to Decision
description: LIBERTY, Mo., July 25 (UPI) Mike Garrett, star running back of the Kansas City Chiefs, said today there was no way he would play football in 1971. Garrett plans to pursue a base ball career, and has been draft ed by the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: A Tourist's Calendar of Events for August
description: 1 International Sea Festival, Long Beach, Calif. Until Aug, 16.

title: Another Ransom Hijack
description: Olympic Airlines Flight 255 from Beirut to Athens last Wednesday was flying over the island of Rhodes. The firstclass passengers had just had break fast. Among them were a young man and a pretty girl, both Arabs, acting like newly weds, as another passenger was later to recall. Suddenly the man stood up and threatened a stewardess with a pistol. The girl brandished a grenade. Four other Arabs brought out weapons. It was yet another hijack.

title: Europe Asks Space Aid
description: In the beginning of the space age, Western Euro pean nations made the delib erate decision not to become great space powers like the United States or the Soviet Union. Now, European coun tries, singly and collectively, are showing signs of wanting a more sizable role in the fu ture exploitation and explora tion of space.

title: Wyeth: His Nostalgia for a Vanished America Is Still a Best Seller
description: THE current Andrew Wyeth retro spective at Boston's Museum of Fine Arts shows this painter at his best, which means that his best work rises well above his weakest. For Wyeth's admirers, who are legion upon legion, this best is perfect. For his detractors, a small group with a large vocabulary, Wyeth's very best is barely tolerable. America's most pop ular painter is unloved by the critics at least by the majority of the New Yorkoriented coterieand by the deal ers and artists whose cause these critics serve.

title: Tigers Top White Sox, 94, as Kaline Bats In 4 Runs and McLain Wins No. 2
description: DETROIT, July 25 (AP)A1 Kaline drove in four runs, three with a homer and one with a single, to pace the Detroit Tigers to a 94 triumph over the Chicago White Sox today and give Denny McLain his sec and victory.

title: POLICE IN BOSTON AGAIN UNDER FIRE
description: BOSTON, July 25James Clark, a retired shopkeeper, lounged on a park bench and glanced indifferently at two police cruisers, a paddy wagon and a K9 carrier as they ar rived on Hemenway Street.

title: Mexican Jetliner Hijacked
description: MEXICO CITY, July 25 (UPI) Four men armed with pistols and bombs hijacked an Aero naves de Mexico DC9 jetliner today while on a flight from the resort city of Acapulco and forced the pilot to fly to Cuba. Most of the passengers were United States citizens. The plane, carrying 27 passengers and a crew of four, made a brief refueling stop at its orig inal destination here before con tinuing to Havana. The hijack ers did not permit anyone to leave the plane.

title: Rosalind V. Lanier Plans to Wed
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., July 25Mr. and Mrs. George Huguley Lanier Jr. have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosalind Vereen Lanier, to Joseph Rush Shull 3d. He is son of Mr. and Mrs. Shull. Jr. of Charlotte, N. C.

title: Bomb Disarmed in Time
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25 (UPI) A time bomb was discovered in the lobby of The Los An geles Times Building today and disarmed about 45 minutes after it was set to explode. The bomb, a length of pipe filled with black powder, was set to go off at 1:45 P.M. It was dis covered at 1:24 and disarmed at 2:30.

title: Sorry, There Is No Perfect Golf Swing
description: MILLIONS of Americans are deeply concerned about infla tion, student riots, Vietnam, the Black Panthers, strikes, bombings, the specter of Abbie Hoffman and the decline of the stock market. Millions are also concerned about what to them is a problem that seems equally important and far less capable of being solved. This is their golf swing.

title: 121 SHOT SNARES $105.110 SORORITY
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 25 Frank Iannelli, the talented jockey from Providence, R. I., played the waiting game with telling effect today to score in the rain with Aisco Stable's Forward Gal in the $105,110 Sorority at Monmouth Park.

title: Nixon: Many Motives Behind All Those Trips
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.  When Richard Nixon arrived at El Toro Marine Air Base near here a few weeks ago, report ers were astounded to hear him lecture his Senate critics on the virtues of sampling the public pulse. I think that sometimes the Senate would do better to do what the House does, to get out throughout the country and see what the country is think ing. . . . There is sort of an intellectual incest [in Washing ton] which really reduces the level of the dialogue, and you have to go to the country now and then to get a real feeling of what people thinking.

title: WALLACE IS DEALT BLOW IN ALABAMA
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 25 Democrats loyal to the na tional party, embarrassed by a takeover of the Alabama party by George C. Wallace two years ago, shut the door today on any such attempt in 1972.

title: The Familiar Telegram: A Dying Institution
description: Western Union is trying to get out of the business of delivering telegrams into American homes.

title: Pasta revolution
description: Pasta is one of the glories of cooking, but until the gastronomic revolution of the past decade the vast majority of home cooks in this country had the pitiful choice of spaghetti or macaroni. Only those who were in the know sometimes succeeded in finding spaghettini, lasagne, linguine and vermicelli. But times have changed. Today, supermarket shelves are filled with such tanta lizing forms as rigatoni, perciatelli, tripolini, tufoli and rotelle. One recipe on this page is for spaghetti carbonara with cheese and prosciutto; the other for rotelle with mushrooms and herbs.

title: REPORTER BACKED IN SUBPOENA CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 The Justice Department has in fringed on Earl Caldwell's First Amendment rights as a news reporter by trying to force him to testify to a grand jury in vestigating the Black Panther party, The New York Times argued in an amicus curiae brief filed this week with the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

title: Recordings
description: SO now, blessed be Saint George and Colin Davis, we have it at last: that halflegendary operatic dragon with two heads, Ber lioz's Les Troyens, deliv ered on a platter  or rather five longplaying platters. Whatever else 1970 may pro duce, it brings from England the first complete perform ance on disks of a master work whose merits and draw backs most of us have had to take on faith until now (Philips 6709002, stereo).

title: Movie Stars Take Old Political Roles
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 Some of the old style has returned to California politics this summer With celebrities from the entertainment world signing up in support of es tablished candidates instead of running for public office them selves.

title: Office of Fishkill Mayor and Police Chief Is Her Purse
description: FISHKILL, N. Y.Her office is a big black pocketbook stuffed with zoning ordinances and holding her police chief's badge. She has loved this vil lage at least since Oct 21, 1922, when she was married wearing jodhpurs and clutch ing a bouquet of crimson ma ple leaves covered with frost at a sunrise service on a hill top.

title: Snyder Rides Both Winners Of Detroit's Stake Divisions
description: LIVONIA, Mich., July 25 (AP) Larry Snyder rode both win ners in the twodivision fea ture of the Graduation Stakes today at Detroit Race Course.

title: Soviet Track Coach Terms Defeated U.S. Squad Weak
description: MOSCOW, July 25 (AP) Vladimir Popov, coach of the Soviet national track team, was quoted today as saying the United States team defeated in Leningrad had been weaker than we expected.

title: New York State Economy. Seen Leading U.S. Pace
description: ROCHESTER, July 25 (UPI) Top business executives in New York State show uncer tainty about what the gen eral economy will do during the second half of 1970 but express confidence that the state's economy will continue to outstrip that of the na tion as a whole, according to a survey by Lincoln First Banks, Inc.

title: 2 Million Jobs to Be Affected By Reduced Defense Spending
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 The winding down of the Viet nam War and the reduction of other defense spending will af fect the employment of two million persons from mid1969 to mid1971, new Government estimates reveal.

title: Ohio State Police Complete Study of Kent State Killings
description: WARREN Ohio July 25 (UPI) The Ohio Highway Patrol has completed its invetigtion without drawing conclusions, into the May 4 shooting deaths of four Kent State University students in a confrontation with the Ohio National Guard.

title: Betsy Keen Wins 4 Classes, Youth Honors at Upstate Show
description: MIDDLETOWN. N. Y., July 25  Betsy Keen entered four classes and won them all today to capture the allround Youth Activities championship at the opening session of the Orange County Horse Show.

title: Jersey's Battle of the Flowers
description: CELEBRATING the coro nation of King Edward VII and Queen Alexan dria in 1902, Jersey in the Channel Islands estab lished a festivalThe Battle of Flowers, a display of grow ers' and designers' art in flower arrangement, although not for the dinner table. The festival continued annually until World War I, was re vived for a few years starting in 1928, was interrupted at the outbreak of World War II, and resumed in 1951.

title: China: A More Flexible Foreign Policy
description: HONG KONGDuring the last month, Communist China's ac tivity in the field of foreign af fairs has been at a higher level than at any time since the sullenly isolationist days of the cultural revolution in 196768.

title: India Considers an Atomic Test To Check on Economic Benefits
description: NEW DELHI, July 25India Is examining the advantages of an underground nuclear explo sion for peaceful purposes, Dr. Vikram Sarabhai, chairman of the Government's Atomic En ergy Commission, reported to day.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JULY 26, 1970

title: 5,000METER RUN WON BY STEWART
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 25Jan Stwart of Scotland up set Kipchoge Keino of Kenya, the favorite, and Ron Clarke of Australia today to capture the 5,000meter gold medal at the British Commonwealth Games in a record time of 13 minutes 22.8 seconds.

title: Report of Chileans Fighting in Bolivia Distresses Santiago
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24 The disclosure that Chilean Marxist guerrillas may be fight ing, Bolivian forces in the jungles, north of La Paz has embarrassed the Chilean Gov ernment.

title: ACE IN LUFTWAFFE TELLS WHY IT LOST
description: LONDON, July 25The Luft waffe lost the Battle of Britain because it was simply not equipped for an offensive war, according to a former German fighter ace.

title: Darby Kolishe To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Baxter of New York, formerly of Wheeling, W. Va., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Darby Marlowe Kolishe, to Thomas Ward Wasson 3d.

title: Police Kill Escaped Boa
description: Enrico Torres of 334 West 17th Street, Manhattan, called the police yesterday after he found a neighbor's fivefoot boa constrictor in his apart ment. Patrolmen from the West 20th Street station arrived and killed it. The police said the boa had been roaming through the fivestory tenement for two weeks since escaping from its owner.

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: CRAIG McGREGOR'S ra ther spurious and mis leading analysis of the pop music scene and the Beatles' role in it (So In the End the Beatles Have Proved False Prophets) should not remain unchal lenged.

title: Pulp Process Shown
description: STOCKHOLM (AP)  A new method for cleansing pulp that might reduce pol lution by the paper pulp industry has been intro duced. The originator of the method, engineer Lars Gun ner Hellman, believes that his innovation will clean the pulp more effectively and at a lower cost than traditonal methodsand also result in a cleaner discharge from the industry.

title: DUTCH TO COMPETE IN BASEBALL HERE
description: THE HAGUE, The Nether lands, July 25 (UPI)  The Netherlands, where thousands of young Dutchmen have taken up baseball, will send a team to compete for the first time in the Babe Ruth Baseball Tour nament of Champions at Wel lington, Kans., in August.

title: Umpires: Errors, Yes
description: Umpires frequently get in volved in controversies, but they always come out on top of the situations. Some times, though, they come out something else, too.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: JOSEPH SULLIVAN'S let ter about Child's Play leads me to do some thing I've wanted to do ever since I saw the play namely, salute it in print as one of the most stimulating and exciting of many seasons.

title: Van Dillen Leaves U.S.C. For Pro Career in Tennis
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25 (UPI) Erik Van Dillen, the Univer sity of Southern California's No. 1 player as a 19yearold freshman, has quit the team to become a tennis tiro, George Tolev. U.S.C. coach, said today.

title: The ManyVlovied Malamud
description: BERNARD MALAMUD is getting to be the grooviest, moviest author around. A film version of his novel The Fixer appeared last season, the movie of his short story The Angel Levine opens at the Little Carnegie Tuesday, and adaptations of his Black Is My Favorite Color and The Assistant have also been an nounced. Now Malamud's latest book, Pictures of Fidelman, has been pur chased by producers Stuart Millar and Elliott Kastner. They're playing it cagey when it comes to saying how much they've paid for the movie rights to the book, but they do admit that Mala mud will participate in the profits of the film, which will be shot in Italy next year.

title: DARTMOUTH ADDS INDIAN STUDENTS
description: Several years before founding Dartmouth College in 1769 for the schooling of Indian and English youths, the Rev. Eleazar Wheelock observed: None know, nor can any, without Experience, Well conceive of, the Difficulty of Educating an Indian.

title: Banker Fiance Of Miss Wright
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., July 25  Miss Susanna Marie Wright, an official assistant at the First National City Bank in New York, and John Dickson Harper Jr., an assist ant treasurer at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company there, plan to be married here Sept. 19 at St. Paul's Epis copal Church.

title: U.S. Open Adopts SuddenDeath Set
description: In the most revolutionary step in tournament tennis scor ing since love became syn onymous with losers, a sudden death scoring system will be instituted for all matches in the $160,000 United States Open championships, Sept. 2 through 13, at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: MOODY IS UPSET IN TITLE TENNIS
description: MANHASSET, L.I., July 25 In hot, muggy weather that took the bounce from their aging legs, the top favorites went into action today in the national clay  court tennis championship for men 35 years and over at the Shelter Rock Club.

title: Rep. Keith Runs Again
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  Representative Ha stings Keith, a Republican, has for mally announced that he will seek a seventh consecutive term in the 12th Congressional Dis trict in Massachusetts.

title: The Converts
description: The jacket photograph of Tereska Torres today is the most memorable feature of this book, because it con vinces us that she's here, now, among us. Without it, her presence today would be hard to believe, for this memoir of her European girlhood in the very recent past has a strange effect: while it skillfully recreates that past, it makes it almost shock ingly remote and irrelevant to us.

title: Showers Ease the Threat Of Extreme Air Pollution
description: The city's air pollution lev els bordered on the unhealthy range yesterday until after noon and early evening thun dershowers washed the air clean, meteorologists at the Weather Bureau said. More than a third of an inch fell during the two storms.

title: Abel
description: This is the true story of a remark able  and remarkably innocent  friendship. The friends were New York artist Burt Silverman and Rus sian spy Rudolph Abel. Sometime be fore they first met, Abel had slipped into the United States. In 1953, under the name of Emil Goldfus, he took some rooms in a grubby old Brooklyn studiotype apartment where Silver man worked.

title: Paul Grand to Marry Anne P. Morgenthau
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Morgenthau of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Anne Pattridge Morgenthau, to Paul Robert Grand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Grand of St. Louis.

title: Kennedy Probation Lifted
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 25 (UPI)Senator Edward M. Ken nedy was released today from the probation that he was placed on for waiting nine hours to tell the police about the ac cident that, resulted in the death of Mary Jo Kopechne.

title: Stock Car Racing Collision Kills Three Pit Crewmen
description: DARLINGTON, Wis., July 25 (AP)Three pit crewmen at a county fair stock car race died last night and four more were injured when a racer collided with another car. The racer skidded backward into the pits and overturned a wrecking truck.

title: James Sirnsarian, 63, Is Dead; Expert on Scientific. Ventures
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 James Simsarian, a, lawyer who became a State Department ex pert on international scientific ventures, died yesterday at George Washington Hospital here at the age of 63.

title: Reader's Report
description: A Tale of Two Families

title: C. & O. to Build Cars
description: The Chesapeake & Ohio Railway said recently it would build 1,600 hopper cars in its car shops at Russell, Ky., at a cost of $18.8million.
