description: Howard J. Samuels, the chair man of the city's new Offtrack Betting Corporation, said yes terday that the $50million the city hoped to make in the first year of offtrack betting was an unrealistic goal.

title: COMPANY PROFITS DOWN IN QUARTER
description: The nation's corporate prof its in the second quarter made as little progress moving up ward as the feminine hemline appears to be making in com ing down.

title: U.S. YACHT IS HOME 3D IN BRITISH RACE
description: PLYMOUTH, England, July 27 (AP)  After weathering un seasonable English Channel gales, Trumpeter, the only Unit ed States entry, arrived here today and finished third in the roundBritain yacht race.

title: Shana J. Dash Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Miss Shana J. Dash to Dr. Leslie M. Unger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Unger of Brook lyn, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Earl Dash, also of Brooklyn.

title: MRS. EDWARD A. WEEKS
description: BEVERLY, Mass., July 27 (AP)Mrs. Edward A. Weeks, wife of the former editor of The Atlantic Monthly, died Satur day at her Beverly Farms sum mer home after a long illness. She was 66 years old.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Cornelia Green Is Future Bride Of Park Palmer
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 27 Mr. and Mrs. Ronald C. Green Jr. have made known the engagement of Mr. Green's daughter, Miss Cor nelia E. Green, to R. Park Palmer. He is a son of Mrs. Stephen Palmer of South Hamilton, Mass., and Soto grande, Spain, and the late Maj. Harry Winfield Schenck, U.S.A. He is the adopted son of Mr. Palmer. A Sept. 12 wedding is planned.

title: F.E.P.C. Data on Microfilm
description: A microfilm collection of the records of the President's Com mittee on Fair Employment Practices from 1941 to 1946 will be published by The New York Times and its subsidiary, the Microfilming Corporation of America, it was announced yes terday. The collection, available in September, will consist of 500,000 pages of text repro duced on 220 rolls of micro film. A separate index and guide will be published.

title: Oxide Mass In Air Here Adds Woes
description: A type of air pollution that had been considered of such low priority that it was re ported only once a month has been strongly linked to the discomfort that has accom panied the stagnant air over the city for the last few days.

title: WORKERS IN VISTA MAY FORM A UNION
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 More than 350 antipoverty vol unteers assembled in this city today to consider forming their own union.

title: U.S. and Koreans Set Talks On Bolstering Seoul Forces
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 27  Defense Minister, Jung Nae Hiuk, said today that South Korean military officials would begin talks this week with United States officials on the modernization of this country's armed forces.

title: AMERICAN SMELTING OFFERS CABLE STOCK
description: The American Smelting and Refining Company announced here yesterday that it planned to dispose of its remaining in terest in the General Cable Corporation  2,820,509 com mon shares  by offering the stock in exchange for Asarco shares.

title: STOCK DIP SPURS SAVINGS INFLOW
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The decline in the stock market was a factor in bringing about a big improvement in the flow of sav ings to savings and loan asso ciations in June and July, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The larger sav ings flows will help housing construction.

title: DR. WILL M. MYERS, FOUNDATION AIDE, 59
description: Dr. Will M. Myers, a vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation, died of a heart at tack Sunday in Fargo, N.D. He was 59 years old and lived in Port Chester. N.Y.

title: Manson Counsel Objects to Key Witness
description: LOS ANGELES, July 27 Mrs. Linda Kasabian, 21year old former member of a hippie group who is testifying for the prosecution in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson, began her testimony today amid a barrage of objections from de fence lawyers.

title: Soviet Ship's Presence Delayed Poseidon Shot
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 27 (AP)A Soviet trawl er that came within 200 yards of the nuclear submarine James Madison last Friday apparently caused the post ponement of the first launch ing of a multiplewarhead Poseidon missile from the submarine.

title: In The Nation: How to Help the Motorist
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Many an American has recently been trapped in a crawling line of freeway traffic, awash in fumes and frustration, as he headed with his family for the seashore or the mountains. In the heat of that ordeal, his first impulse surely would be to egg on a Congress that is getting ready to increase the national investment in the Interstate Highway System to $75 billion. But maybe we all ought to think again about the implications of that investment.

title: SCIENTIST KILLED ON ARCTIC ICE FLOE
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) After hopscotching across the Arctic for nearly three hours, two Navy investigators arrived on a tiny ice floe by helicopter today to begin looking into the fatal shooting of a civilian sci entist stationed there.

title: ROBERT P. CLARKE SR
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 27  Robert P. Clarke Sr., retired chemical executive and partner in a brokerage firm, died Friday at Greenwich Hos pital. He was 82 years old and lived at 19 Pilgrim Drive.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES ARMY PHYSICALS
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The armed forces annually accept an average of 20,000 men who should have been rejected for physical defects, the General Accounting Office reported to day.

title: TWO WOMEN LEAD GOLF QUALIFIERS
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., July 27 (AP)Mary Dwyer of Geneva, N.Y.. and Mrs. W. B. Mahan of Corpus Christi, Tex., each shot par 73's today at Manor Coun try Club and tied for the medal in qualifying for the women's TransMississippi golf chain pionship.

title: Gromyko Reported Cool To Bonn Treaty Demands
description: MOSCOW, July 27The So viet Government was reported to have reacted coolly today to new West German conditions for agreement on a treaty re nouncing the use of force.

title: PENNSY BORROWED FROM SWISS BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) The Penn Central Railroad borrowed almost $60million this year from Swiss banks to pay off some United States creditors, Congressional testi mony showed today.

title: Andre Previn Is Divorced In Brief Hearing on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, July 27 (Reuters)  Andre Previn, the composerconductor, divorced his wife, Dorothy Langdon, to day in a hearing that lasted less than 60 seconds.

title: Kekkonen Opens Consulate; Leaves City for Helsinki
description: President Urho Kekkonen of Finland raised a Finish flag and cut a ribbon at ceremonies yes terday officially opening Fin land House, the new home of the Finnish consulate.

title: Candidate's Son Sentenced
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 27 (AP) Eugene Daniell 3d, 23year old son of Eugene Daniell, the Mayor of Franklin and a Demo cratic Congressional candidate, received a twoyear prison sen tence today for failing to regis ter for induction into military service. Mayor Daniell, who is running on a platform calling for the withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam by the end of the year, is seeking his party's nomination for the seat held by Representative James C. Cleveland, a Republi can.

title: RAGAN'S 67 PACES GOLF QUALIFIERS
description: HARRISON, N.Y., July 27 Dave Ragan of Orlando, Fla., led the way through the quail eying round for the fourth an hual Westchester Golf Classic today with a 32, 3567 over the West Course at the West chester Country Club.

title: MEDICAID FAULTED IN AUDIT ON COAST
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Government auditors have found that nursing homes in California were paid by Medic aid for care of patients after their deaths or discharges. In other cases, nursing homes have been paid twice for the same nursing care under the Medicare and Medicaid pro grams. The blame in most cases was placed in the system, not the nursing homes. The General Accounting Office, in a report to Congress, said that weaknesses in procedures and practices had led to the pay ments under the Medicaid program in California.

title: State Plans to Hold Forums To Discuss Drug Problems
description: Governor Rockefeller an nounced yesterday that a series of forums would be held throughout the state, on a coun tywide basis, to discuss prob lems of drug abuse.

title: In Memoriam
description: HENNWilllam (Bill). July 28, 1967. 3 long years have passed; my love and Precious memories of you will eternally last You will dwell in the house of the Lord for ever. Your devoted wife, HELEN

title: Alvin Ailey Troupe Loses Base At Brooklyn Academy of Music
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater of Brooklyn, now on tour in Africa under State Department sponsorship, no longer has a home at home. Its twoyear residence at the Brooklyn Academy of Music has been terminated by mutual agreement, or mutual disagree ment, with the academy.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Holiday Inns Picks J. Walter Thompson
description: The world's largest inn keepers (Holiday Inns) yes terday selected the world's largest ad agency (J. Walter Thompson) to handle its esti mated $2.5million a year of advertising. This is not the world's largest ad budget, but who's complaining.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Tuesday, July 28, 1970

title: New Sears Building in Chicago Planned as the World's Tallest
description: CHICAGO, July 27Sears, Roebuck and Company, the world's largest retailer, an nounced today that its new cen tral headquarters in downtown Chicago would be the world's tallest building and the largest private building in the world.

title: 37 Nations Send Aid to Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, July 27 (UPI) Thirtyseven countries on five continents have sent relief aid to Peru since an earthquake May 31 devastated a large sec tion of the north and left 70, 000 dead and missing, the news paper El Comercio reported

title: 25,000 Are Delayed by Fire in Penn Central Tunnel Under Park Avenue
description: The second major fire in two weeks delayed 25,000 Penn Central commuters from West chester and Connecticut for up to three hours during the morning rush hours yesterday.

title: 3 SHOT IN CHICAGO DURING ROCK RIOT
description: CHICAGO, July 27Severa?? thousand Negro and white youths, hurling rocks, battled the police for more than six hours tonight. They roamed in to the Loop business district and smashed windows.

title: Future Defense Contracts To Be Awarded in Stages
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 27Secretary of Defense Mel vin R. Laird said today that fu ture defense contracts would be negotiated on a fly before you buy basis designed to prevent massive losses to taxpayers be cause of cost overruns.

title: COL. LEONARD NASON, WAR STORY WRITER
description: WEST NEW YORK, N.J., July 27Col. Leonard H. Nason, an author who specialized in war stories, died Saturday in Dufur Hospital, Ambler, Pa. He was 74 years old and lived here at 6040 Boulevard East.

title: 2 Young American Conductors Display Skills at Tanglewood
description: Young American conductors are on the spot today when they lead major American sym phony orchestras, because there are so many older European born conductors around who will not be here forever.

title: The Tea Break Lauded by British Labor Experts
description: LONDON, July 27The Brit ish tea break, a national insti tution that stirs a cool welcome among employers, was warmly praised today by labor experts.

title: British Dock Employers Accept Proposal to End Strike
description: LONDON, July 27  Hopes for a settlement in Britain's 13 dayold dock strike rose today when port employers accepted the recommendations of a court of inquiry Into the dead locked wage dispute.

title: More Jumbo Jet Flights
description: Pan American World Air ways has announced it will extend its Boeing 747 jumbo jet services, starting this week. On Saturday it will begin twiceaweek service with the plane between New York and Bermuda, leaving New York Saturdays and Sundays.

title: Coed Shot by Robber Dies
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 27 (AP)An Ohio State University coed, wounded by an armed robber in her apartment yester day died last night at the Uni versity Hospital, the police re ported. The coed was Susan Ada Clark, 23 years old, of Fairfield Iowa.

title: Mete Down Giants, 53, for Seaver's 15th
description: In a mainevent match be tween a pair of 14game win ners, Tom Seaver outpitched Gaylord Perry last night as the New York Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants, 53.

title: GOVERNOR TO SEEK AID FOR CHILDREN
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he would ask the next session of the Legisla ture to appropriate $10million in emergency funds for the con struction of facilities to house neglected and abandoned chil dren.

title: New Con Son Study Sought
description: GENEVA, July 27 (UPI)The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that it would conduct a new inspection of the Con Son prison in South Vietnam as soon as it received permission from the Saigon Government. Committee spokes men said Red Cross delegates in South Vietnam had formally requested such permission.

title: 6th French Nuclear Blast
description: PARIS, July 27 (Reuters) France exploded a lowpowered nuclear device over the deserted Mururoa Lagoon in Polynesia, the Defense Ministry announced tonight. A spokesman said the blast was the sixth in the cur rent series of nuclear tests started earlier this year.

title: Israel's Acceptance Needed
description: The sharp reaction of Palestinian guerrillas and some Arab states to EgyptianJordanian acceptance of United States peace proposals only emphasizes the urgent need of a favorable reply from Israel.

title: For Indians of Brazil's Interior, the Choice Is the Past or the Future
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 27 Tens of thousand of forest in dians in Brazil who live along the path of the quickening march westward into the Ama zon Basin face a choice be tween a probably fatal fight against civilization and the abandonment of their culture to become part of Brazil's.

title: Amiable Administrator
description: Strolling along Madison Avenue one day in 1937, soon after his graduation from Harvard, Richard Lewisohn happened by a storefront political headquarters for Thomas E. Dewey, who was running for District Attorney.

title: FULBRIGHT ACCUSES PENTAGON OF DECEIT
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Senator J. W. Fulbright, Dem ocrat of Arkansas, accused the Pentagon today of engaging in a deliberate deception. Mr. Ful bright said that Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird told the Senate last year that the Defense Department would not go on to further phases of the Safeguard and antiballistic mis sile system until assured the first phase was a success.

title: OFFICES CHANGED BY SALOMON BROS.
description: While most other Wall Street firms are retrenching and see ing their earnings shrivel, Sal omon Brothers moved into new superduper $8million head quarters yesterday and indi cated that profits are holding up well.

title: 5 British Students Get A Royal Tourist's Tips
description: LONDON, July 27 (UPI) Prince Charles today told five British high school students going to Washington next month to behave themselves in the White House.

title: Salazar of Portugal
description: Dean Acheson regarded Antnio de Oliveira Salazar as the nearest approach in our time to Plato's philoso pherking but most democrats more perceptively likened him to a despot of the Middle Ages. I coldly do my duty, said Dr. Salazar in an accurate descrip tion of his unflamboyant, lowkey style of ruleand by his own standards he did.

title: Go Slow on CATV Franchises
description: Twenty years ago an enterprising television dealer in a rural Pennsylvania community placed an antenna on a mountaintop and strung a coaxial cable into town in order to bring clearer signals from distant city broadcasting stations to his customers.

title: People
description: James P. Andrews named vice president at Coordi nated Comunications, Inc.

title: Autos Conauer the Heights and Some of the Spirit of Glacier Park
description: WEST GLACIER, Mont. The Going to the Sun Road snakes its way for 50 miles through Glacier Na tional Park, first under the upward thrust of pines, cedars, spruce and firs, then high above timberline, cling ing to the sheer walls of jagged mountains patched with snow. Well paved, but nar row. Dizzying to the Eastern driv er, his palms sweating as he negotiates its unending curves. Thousands of feet above the valley floor, its low stoneblock guardrails shrinking in perspective. And here and there a stomach chilling stretch unguarded.

title: Lawyers Ask Safety Tests
description: The New York State Trial Lawyers Association urged yes terday that Congress pass legis lation empowering the Federal Government to require manu facturers to give their products adequate safety tests. The group, the state's largest trial bar, charged that unsafe prod ucts were causing a national epidemic of 20 million injuries a year.

title: S.E.C. Suspension Hits Dreyfus & Co. Along With Partner
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yester day the suspension for 25 days of certain overthecounter opeiations of Dreyfus & Co., New York securities dealers and brokers, and the 15day suspension of Thomas B. Bligh, a Dreyfus partner, from doing business through the firm. Both suspensions begin tomorrow.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: San Francisco at New York (8:05 P.M.)Robertson (66) vs. Mc Andrew (58).

title: Twice Worthy Is First to Accept Bid to Rich Monmouth Handicap
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 27 (AP)Twice Worthy, owned by Saddle Rock Farm, today be came the first horse to accept a bid to run in the Monmouth Handicap Aug. 8 at Monmouth Park.

title: MITCHELL YIELDS ON COURT CHOICES
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Attorney General Jahn N. Mitchell announced today that he would consult leaders of the American Bar Association be fore recommending to Presi dent Nixon nominees for the United States Supreme Court.

title: Opposition in Saigon Fears for Its Political Future
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27Antiwar and antiGovern ment members of the National Assembly say that harassment over their views is continual, but their most serious fear is for their political survival.

title: A 19thCentury Ruler
description: In March, 1966, this corre spondent sat for three hours with Antonio de Oliveira Salazar in the turnofthecentury sitting room of the Portuguese Pre mier's private residence in Lis bon. The offtherecord conver sation, held during this writer's three year assignment in Portugal and Spain, followed the deliv ery of Salazar's written answers to a list of written questions and was more evealing of the man than any public statement he had ever made or any of his numerous and rather stilted writings.

title: Phils Victors Get 3 Homers
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (UPI) Tony Taylor, Deron Johnson and Larry Hisle hit home runs tonight to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to their 10th victory in the last 12 games, a 103 rout of the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Chou, on French TV, Criticizes the Great Powers
description: PARIS, July 27Premier Chou Enlai of Communist China told a French radio and television audience tonight that France and China shared a common opposition to domination and intervention by the great pow ers in world affairs.

title: Shoshi Zukor Is Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Zukor of Montreal have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shoshi Zukor, to Howard Nusbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodwin Nus baum of Rochester. An Aug. 30 wedding is planned.

title: Bank Merger Planned
description: The Port Washington Savings and Loan Association would be merged into the East Brooklyn Savings and Loan Association under an application submitted to the New York State Banking Department, the department's weekly bulletin disclosed yes terday.

title: Black Militant Slain By Houston Police; Gun Fight Injures 4
description: HOUSTON, July 27Carl Hampton, the 21yearold leader of a black militant or ganization in Houston, was fatally shot by the police early this morning in an exchange of gunfire that left four other persons wounded.

title: Melbourne Mayor Here
description: Edward W. Best, Lord Mayor of Melbourne, Australia, visited with Mayor Lindsay at Gracie Mansion yesterday. The mayors chatted on the porch of the mansion for about 45 minutes, discussing problems common to their cities, as their wives sat by.

title: 91Day Bill Rates Dip to 6.345% At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Treasury bill races declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government re ported late this afternoon.

title: LADIES JOURNAL HAS LIB SECTION
description: Four months after more than 100 militant feminists occupied its offices to demand the chance to put out a liberation issue, the Ladies Home Journal pub lished yesterday a special sec tion written by supporters of the Women's Liberation move ment.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Washington: For the Record
Old Baseball Feats Recalled at Hall of Fame Induction
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 27Lou Boudreau said his prayers were answered, Pop Haines was a thousand times obliged, Earle Combs called it his greatest thrill, and Ford Frick said he felt honored, proud and humble.

title: HOUSE BACKS END OF TELLER VOTES ON AMENDMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The House, heeding the demands of reformers, voted today to scrap the system under which it has shaped much of its legislation by secret vote since the first Congress in 1789.

title: Strike at Civilian Concern Halts War Pilot Training
description: OZARK, Ala., July 27 (UPI) Military officials at Fort Rucker said today that they had can celed the contract of a strike plagued civilian concern that had been training military pilots for duty in Vietnam.

title: Antonio Salazar: A Quiet Autocrat Who Held Power in Portugal for 40 Years
description: An anomaly among modern dictators, Antonio de Oli veira Salazar exemplified the power of a negative personal ity. He was ascetic rather than exuberant; aloof rather than gregarious; professorial rather than demagogic; understated; rather than ostentatious. Yet he held Portugal in thralldom for more than 40 years, a rec ord of durability unmatched by Francisco Franco, Benito Mus solini or Adolf Hitler, his flashier Fascist counterparts and) good friends.

title: MONEY LOSS CITED BY GIANTS OWNER
description: Wellington mare, the owner of the New York Giants, warned yesterday that if the pro football labor impasse forced the cancellation of the first weekend of exhibition games on Aug. 7 and 8, less than two weeks away, the Na tional Football League regular season would be in jeopardy.

title: Doubt Voiced on Atom Inspection Plan
description: VIENNA, July 21Not until 1972 are inspectors supposed to take up posts to insure com pliance with the treaty ban ning the spread of nuclear weapons. But disarmament ex perts in Geneva have already voiced misgivings about the ef rectiveness of the planned in spection system.

title: GOVERNOR REJECTS ANY BUCKLEY TIE
description: Governor Rockefeller and Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday they were supporting their own, separate party slates and were not interested in any coalition ticket that included James L. Buckley, the Con servative party candidate for United States Senator.

title: WEEKEND OF ROCK BARRED BY JUDGE
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 27  A state Superior Court judge ruled today that a three day rock festival scheduled for the Power Ridge Ski Area in nearby Middlefield this week end would create a public nuisance and could not be held.

title: REPORTERS' LISTING OF FINANCES SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  Representative Fletcher Thompson, Republican of Geor gia, introduced a resolution today to make Washington newsmen subject to the same financial disclosures required of House members and their staffs.

title: Xerox to Offer Debentures to Holders
HIGH CITY DEMAND FOR POWER MET BY VOLTAGE CUTS
description: The Consolidated Edison Com pany met a nearrecord demand by New Yorkers for electricity on a steaming hot day yester day, aided by power imported from outside the city and by a nearly fourhour reduction of voltage by 3 per cent.

title: The Mood of the Campus
description: It would have been nothing short of miraculous if Dr. Alexander Heard, who is acting as special Presi dential adviser on campus unrest, had been able to tell Mr. Nixon much that is not already known, at least outside the White House. To say this is not to take issue with Dr. Heard's generally perceptive essay on the mood of at least the most socially conscious and most vocal students.

title: LOMBARDI RESTS AFTER OPERATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) Vince Lombardi, the Wash ington Redskin coach, under went surgery for the second time in a month today at Georgetown University hospital here and was reported resting comfortably.

title: Mrs. Meir Said to Seek Cabinet Unity
description: JERUSALEM, July 27Pre mier Golda Meir was reported to be striving today to achieve unanimity in her broad coali tion Cabinet for a positive response to the United States proposal for a limited cease fire and peace talks with the Arabs. She is said to be hope ful of averting abstentions by certain Ministers.

title: London Festival Ballet Ends Mixed Season
description: LONDON, July 27  Lon don's Festival Ballet should be to the Royal Ballet what the American Ballet Theater is to the New York City Bal let. It is not, but it is at least still trving.

title: Morningside Heights Squatters Hope They'll Be Allowed to Stay
description: In apartment 2C, a naked baby lay asleep on a bare mat tress. His mother, Mrs. Guller mina Sorial, sat on an other mattress on the floor as she watched him. A bare light bulb shone down from a wall. The apartment was otherwise empty.

title: Adyertising: No Changes for Dry Cereals
description: The five big companies that supply the multimillion dollar dry cereal market do not appear to be planning any changes in their adver tising as a result of the blast leveled at them in Washing ton last Thursday.

title: Senate Unit Finds U.S. Has Secret Base In Morocco for Navy Communications
description: WASHINGTON, July 27A Senate Foreign Relations sub committee has discovered that when the United States with drew its military forces from bases in Morocco in 1963 it entered into a private arrange ment with the Moroccan Gov ernment to retain a large naval communications center.

title: Monmouth Jockeys
John Wayne's Brother Dies
description: GLENDALE, Calif. July 27 (UPI)Robert Emmett Mor rison, brother of John Wayne, the actor, died here of cancer, Saturday. He was 58 years old. Mr. Morrison was a motion pic ture production executive. Sur vivors, in addition to his brother include his widow. Mary Patrica.

title: Remains of Dutch Stockade Dug Up in Kingston
description: The fragile remains of a Dutch colonial stockade have been unearthed in Kingston, N. Y., by a team of arche ologists who got to the site before a modern enemy, the bulldozer, did.

title: Francis and Winkles Named PanAmerican Games Aides
description: Alex Francis, head track coach at Kansas State Colleg at Fort Hayes, and Bobby Win kles, baseball coach at Arizona State, were selected yesterday as coaches of the United State teams for the 1971 PanAmeri can Games.

title: DETECTIVE'S TRIAL ON PAYOFFS ENDS
description: A Police Department trial commissioner reserved decision yesterday on charges that a Police Department detective ob tained $5,000 as a reward from Montgomery Ward for the re covery of $100,000 in stolen merchandise.

title: Rep. Michael J. Kirwan Is Dead; Led House Public Works Unit
description: BETHESDA, Md., July 27 (AP)  Representative Michael J. Kirwan, an Ohio Democrat who wielded great power with in Congress and the Democratic party, died today at Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Protected Textiles

title: BIG BOARD MOVES IN NARROW RANGE
Tokyo Smog in 5th Day
description: TOKYO, July 27 (AP)The Tokyo city government issued a smog warning for the fifth consecutive day at noon today, asking citizens of the world's largest city to stay indoors as much as possible. The warning was lifted three hours later.

title: Laird Says He Has Power To Order Incursions in Laos
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reu ters)  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, in testimony before a House subcommittee released today, said that he felt he had authority to permit short incursions into Laos.

title: Miss Erikson To Be Married
description: SMOKE RISE, N. J., July 27The engagement of Miss Pamela Jean Erikson to Wal lace Franklin Caldwell has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Harold Erikson Jr., parents of the future bride. Her finance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert W. Caldwell of Kensington, Md.

title: Stephanie Lee a Prospective Bride
description: Miss Stephanie Lee and Frederick P. Ostmann will be married on Aug. 10 in the Bond Chapel on the campus of the University of Chicago, where both are candidates for master's degrees.

title: ASARCO WILL CLOSE COAST LEAD PLANT
description: The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday that it would close its Selby lead plant near San Francisco within the next several months.

title: Check Writing Rose 2.7% in June
description: Charges against checking accounts in New York City banks rose in June by 2.7 per cent from the May level to $4.37trillion, the Federal Re serve reported yesterday.

title: A WOMAN IS RESCUED FROM MOUNTAIN TOP
description: RUIDOSO, N.M., July 27 (UPI)A Texas woman was rescued today from the wreck age of a plane 9,000 feet up Capitan Mountain three days after the plane crashed.

title: YONKERS REOPENS WITH SPEED SPREE
description: YONKERS, July 27  With 20,000 gallons of paint having turned the dull, ancient grand stand into a shiny, psychedelic dreamland, Yonkers Raceway's 72card, secondhalf meeting opened tonight in electrifying fashion.

title: Army Target at Coast Blasts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (AP)Two bombs blew a hole through a wall at the Armed Forces Police Headquarters and damaged a Nike missile on display at the Army Presidio today. There were no injuries. The earlymorning explosions, about four miles apart, oc curred within five minutes.

title: Printer Seized in Counterfeiting $250,000 Worth of Paychecks
description: More than a quartermillion dollars worth of counterfeit paychecksmany of them said to be from the city's Police and Fire Departmentshave been cashed at banks here over the last year, the Manhattan Dis trict Attorney's office said yes terday. A Long Island printer has been arrested as a suspect.

title: U.S. Says Jordan Must Bar Guerrilla Forays in Truce
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  United States officials said to day that under the American proposal for a ceasefire along the IsraeliEgyptian and Israeli Jordanian defense lines, the Jordanian Government would be committed to controlling Palestinian guerrilla organi zations.

title: Vietcong Aide Ends Controversial Visit to India
description: NEW DELHI, July 27Indian officials seemed relieved today that the visit of Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, foreign minister of the Vietcong's provisional revo lutionary government, was over.

title: The Women Aquanauts Did the Job, Despite Male Chauvinism
description: Aside from a minor earth quake, it wasn't too much different from living on terra firma. Except that most of them lost a few pounds, the one smoker among them had to give up her habit because her cigarettes wouldn't stay lighted (not enough oxygen), and the soda pop didn't bub ble up.

title: Executive Changes
description: Paul W. Douglas has been elected a director and an executive vice president of the Freeport Sulphur Company.

title: GERDA ZIMMERMANN SHOWS DANCE RANGE
description: Gerda Zimmermann presents herself in a variety of dance moods. At one moment she is a serious, stark, angular figure and at another she is a fluttery, semicomic apparition who has wandered almost inadvertently onto the stage. Last night at the Cubiculo, she presented six of her solo dances, two of which were premieres.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON RISE IN QUIET DAY
description: London stocks maintained steady tone throughout trading and closed higher yesterday in quiet dealings.

title: Gretel II Is in Tampa En Route to Newport
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 27 (AP) The 12Meter yacht Gratel II, which will carry Aus tralia's honors in the Ameri ca's cup trials off Newport. R. I., next month, arrived here today aboard the steam shin New York Star.

title: G.M. PROFIT ROSE IN JUNE QUARTER
description: DETROIT, July 27The Gen eral Motors Corporation re ported today a Junequarter profit rise of 5 per cent from a year before, on a sales gain of 6 per cent. The profits were no record  in fact, they topped last year's because G.M. was hurt by strikes in 1969. Otherwise the June quar ter profit was the lowest since 1963.

title: Salazar, Ruler of. Portugal for 40 Years, Dies
description: LISBON, July 27Dr. Antnio de Oliveira Salazar, ruler of Por tugal for 40 years until he suf fered a stroke in September, 1968, died today at the age of 81. He suffered a heart attack and vascular collapse two weeks ago.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JULY 28, 1970

title: Richey Enters Buckeye Net
description: COLUMBUS. Ohio, July 27 (UPI)Cliff Richey of San An gelo, Tex., who finished second in the 83d Western tennis championships, has accepted an invitation to play in the first annual Buckeye tennis tourna ment here Aug. 14 through 16.

title: GEN DAVIS RESIGNS AS AIDE TO STOKES
description: CLEVELAND, July 27Ben jamin O. Davis Jr., charging that the administration of Mayor Carl B. Stokes was pro viding support and comfort to enemies of the police, re signed today after six months as Cleveland's safety director in charge of the Police and Fire Departments.

title: Train Stalled in 59th St. Tunnel Delays Queens Subway Service
description: Rushhour subway service to Queens was delayed for as much as two hours last night when a stalled EE train in the 59th Street tunnel produced a chain of circumstances that snarled most of the system north and east of the Queens Plaza station.

title: MRS. BERTRAND TAYLOR
description: Mrs. Olive McClure Taylor, wife of Bertrand L. Taylor, formerly a governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died yes terday at the American Hospi tal in Paris after a long illness. She was 65 years old and had lived in Paris for 21 years.

title: A Correction
description: In the engagement an nouncement of Miss Alice Pinckney Hamilton to James Prescott Hyatt in yesterday's New York Times, the couple's wedding day was incorrectly given as Aug. 2. The cere mony is scheduled for Aug. 22.

title: Allen Connects Twice
description: CINCINNATI, July 27 (UPI) Richie Allen hit two home runs and Mike Shannon con tributed a threerun triple to night as the St. Louis Cardinals pounded the Cincinnati Reds, 169, to snap an eightgame los ing streak.

title: Foe Said to Encircle Cambodian Town
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 28 (AP)Heavy fighting was reported yesterday around the former resort town of Kirirom in Cambodia, on plateau 50 miles west of Pnom penh. Four Cambodian battal ions that seized the town 11 days ago were said to be sur rounded by enemy troops and the situation was described as serious.

title: 2 RUNS FORCED IN ON DOYLE'S WALKS
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 27 The Yankees broke their four game losing streak tonight in silent but effective fashion, beating the California Angels, 52 in the 10th inning.

title: Butterfly McQueen Has a Family Now
description: No one in the world has a voice more memorable than Butterfly McQueen the itsylittle voice fading over the far horizon of com prehension. as a critic once described it.

title: STEEL OUTPUT UP IN JUNE AND HALF
description: Steel production in the non Communist world increased slightly in June and in the first halfcompared to 1969 levels but both gains reflected al most entirely the higher output of the burgeoning Japanese steel industry.

title: Skyscraper Is Planned Over Expanded Bus Terminal
description: Plans to build an $80mil lion addition to the midtown bus terminal and a $50million office skyscraper above it were announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

title: Net Income Up 16.7%
Militant Jews Paint Slogans at Estate Of Soviet on L.I
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., July 27  Members of the Jewish Defense League climbed over the wall surrounding the Soviet Union's 38acre estate here today and used a spray can of red paint to write slogans in Hebrew and English on the walls, a gatepost and on the roadway.

title: MORE AID IS URGED IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: The United States, Japan and Australia were urged yester day by the Committee for Eco nomic Development to step up their development assistance to Southeast Asia, particularly be cause of the withdrawal of American, British and allied mil itary forces from that area.

title: CHIEFS ARE RATED 10POINT FAVORITE
description: CHICAGO, July 27 (AP)The world champion Kansas City Chiefs will be at least a 10 point favorite for the 37th an nual College AllStar game in Soldier Field Friday night.

title: Drop in Jewelry Sales of 5 to 10% Spurs Marketing Programs
description: Jewelry business has been better than most people thought it would be, although it hasn't been as good as a lot of peo ple would like it to be.

title: Foreman and Chuvalo Work Out Before Veterans at Brooklyn Hospital
description: George Foreman and George Chuvalo, who will meet in a 10round heavy weight battle at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday night, will hold six public workouts each at the Felt. Forum in the Garden.

title: Egypt's Jets in First Canal Raid in Month
description: TEL AVIV, July 27  Egyp tian jet fighterbombers struck at Israel today for the first time in a month, coming in low over the Suez Canal to raid positions in the Sinai peninsula.

title: Queens Residents Stage Community Center SitIn
description: A group of community resi dents staged a sitin at a com munity center in South Jamaica, Queens, last night and this morning to protest their griev ances.

title: Nixon on TV Thursday In Coast News Parley
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 27 (Reuters)President Nixon, who is spending a working vacation here, will hold a televised news confer ence in Los Angeles Thursday at 8 P.M11 P.M., Eastern daylight time  the White House announced today.

title: Javits Submits Bill to Let U.S. Guarantee Loans to Companies
description: Jacob K. Javits, the senior Republican Senator from New York, introduced a bill in Con gress yesterday that would al low the Government to guaran tee up to $5billion in loans to private corporations that were experiencing trouble in getting funds to pay their debts but were otherwise basically sound.

title: JERSEY BANKS WIN MERGER APPROVAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The Federal Reserve Board an nounced today its approval of a new bank holding company in New Jersey that will ac quire the assets of the state's fourth largest bank, People's Trust of New Jersey, and four other banks.

title: BOMB JOLTS BANK IN FINANCIAL AREA
description: A pipe bomb exploded early yesterday at the entrance of the Bank of America at 41 Broad Street, shattering glass doors and fracturing marble walls leading into the 10story build ing in the heart of Manhattan's financial district.

title: Diners Club Planning $3Million Campaign
description: Diners Club, which has been pretty quiet on the advertising scene lately, is about to pop close to $3mil lion worth of communica tions on the public at large.

title: Eight Collegians and Agnew to Be Honored at Golf Dinner Tonight
description: The eight members of the 1970 college golf team who will be honored guests to night at the sixth AllAmeri can collegiate golf dinner at the WaldorfAstoria enjoyed a practice round (of lunch) yesterday.

title: June Export Surplus Set Highest Level Since 1966
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The United States recorded in June its largest surplus of ex ports over imports for a single month since 1966, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: HARRIS FAHNESTOCK, IN M.I.T. RESEARCH
description: CONCORD, Mass., July 27 Harris Fahnestock, assistant di rector of the Massachusetts In titute of Technology's Lincoln Laboratory, died at his home here yesterday, apparently of heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: FUTURES IN COCOA RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Cocoa futures jumped the onecentapound daily permis sible limit yesterday on a light volume of 574 contracts.

title: Use of PainKilling Drug Limited to Horse Injuries
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  The Food and Drug Admin istration approved today the first marketing of a painkilling drug called DMSO, or dimethyl sulfoxide, but limited its use to swelling in horses caused by external iniury.

title: A Paradise for Vegetarians That Has Yielded to Carnivores
description: OJAI, Calif.After seven years and two million pies, Alan Hooker decided he wanted more out of life than managing a wholesale pie bakery in Columbus, Ohio, could provide.

title: CITY ORDERS STUDY OF OPEN ADMISSIONS
description: The Board of Higher Educa tion authorized the American Council on Education last night to make a twoyear study of the City University's new open amissions program, at a cost of more than $594,000.

title: British Refuse to Disclose Where Sultan Is Hospitalized
description: LONDON, July 27 (UPI)The Foreign Office refused to say today where the deposed Sultan of Muscat and Oman, Said bin Taimur, was being treated for gunshot wounds apparently re ceived last Thursday in a palace coup led by his son.

title: Bolt Sees Play on Queens, Set in 1500's, Still Relevant
description: LONDON, July 27  In a hotel rehearsal room in Lon don's Earl's Court Square last April, Robert Boll nerv ously watched the unfolding drama that pitted two rival Queens. Mary Queen of Scots and Elizabeth I of England against each other.

title: BELLE HAVEN GAINS JUNIOR SAIL LEAD
description: NOROTON, Conn., July 27 The Belle Haven Club crew from Greenwich, Conn., cap tained by Steve Hicks, took a fourpoint lead today in the qualifying series for the 47th annual junior sailing cham pionship of Long Island Sound. The first two races were held in Lightning sloops off the Noroton Yacht Club.

title: ExNavy Back to Get Gold Medal
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 27 (UPI)Tom Hamilton, former player, coach and ath letic director at the United States Naval Academy and presently commissioner of the Pacific Eight Conference, was named recipient today of the National Football Founda tion and Hall of Fame's Gold Medal Award of 1970.

title: Profits Surge at I.T.T. And American Express
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation is observing its 50th year with the highest secondquarter and halfyear profits in its history and the best gains for the pe riods on record. LT.T.'s figures include results of the recently acquired Hartford Fire Insur ance Comoanv.

title: Closeun Pictures of 2 Planets Planned
description: The scientific instruments to be carried on the first space craft to fly by and photograph Venus and Mercury on a single mission were announced yester day by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Sharon F. Salembier to Be Wed Aug. 29 to John Russell Cornell
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., July 27Miss Sharon Forester Salembier, an assistant ana lyst with Smith, Barney & Co., stockbrokers in New York, plans to be married here on Aug. 29 to John Rus sell Cornell, who is with the New York law firm of Cad walader, Wickersham & Taft. The ceremony will be held in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Jewelry That's Meant to Be Wornand Remembered
description: The problem with a new piece of fine jewelry is that if it isn't different, it tends to look like more of the same old thing and if it is too dif ferent, the wearer is likely to get bored with it.

title: Mara Says the Cancellation of Exhibitions Would Jeopardize N.F.L. Season
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 27 Hold the ball this way! shouted Alex Webster, the New York Giants' football coach.

title: Extra Wire on Course Scratches Horse Race
description: HENDERSON, Ky July 27 (UPI)The fourth race at Ellis Park was declared no contest today after lightning struck a film tower and a wire from the tower to the clubhouse fell across the track.

title: Frustration is Said to Set Off Attacks by Youths in Village
description: Late last Saturday night, aft er a hot, airless day on Aven?? C on the Lower East Side where the smells from the outdoo?? vegetable stands mingle with the stench of garbage, about 200 restless youths shattere?? the windows of George Selig man's drugstore.

title: JOHN C. KUNKEL
description: HARRRISBURG, Pa., July 27 (AP)  Former Representative John C. Kunkel died today in Harrisburg Hospital where he was taken after suffering a stroke. He was 72 years old last Tuesday.

title: Card of Thanks
description: ROTHMrs. Irene Roth Wishes to thank her numberous friends for the wonderful tribute paid to her late husband Profesor Cecil Roth. Mrs. Roth hopes to reply individu ally at a later date.

title: Predictable, Under Baeza, Triumphs at Aqueduct for 2d Straight Victory
description: Predictable did exactly what was expected of her, according to the figures, at Aqueduct yesterday, but she made it close, indeed. Bet into favor itism by the crowd of 28,819, the Wheatley Stable's home bred won the onemile feature race by a neck. The Hobeau Farm's Someday was another neck ahead of the third place Mereworth Farm's Hasty Hit ter in the field of eight fillies and mares. Predictable's pay off price was $4.80 for $2.

title: Bank Opens Branch Here
description: Governor Rockefeller offici ated yesterday at the opening of the sixth branch of the Bancc Popular de Puerto Rico at 501 Seventh Avenue, at 37th Street.

title: Article 2  No Title
Miss Baroody Rides Her Ponies Into Lead At Middletown Show
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 27Nancy Baroody of Lake yille, Conn., sold Midget, he fourtime national high poin small pony champion early this year, but she still manages to win her share of classes with her two new mounts.

title: Korvette Seeking East 57th St. Site
description: The Korvette discount depart ment store chain, one of New York's largest retailers, is ne gotiating to acquire a site for a large new store in Manhat tan, virtually within the shadow of Alexander's at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue and only one block from Blooming dale's on 59th Street and Lex ington Avenue.

title: Slight Rise in Quarterly Profits Is Reported by Southern Pacific
description: The Southern Pacific Com pany, the operator of one of the wealthiest railroads in the nation, reported yesterday a slight increase in its earnings in the second quarter, but its president, B. F. Biaggini, said he had not seen evidence of the upturn in the economy or of his road's freighthauling operations that he had ex pected to develop by midyear.

title: EARNINGS DECLINE AT OIL COMPANIES
description: Down was the direction of earnings reported yesterday by major oil companies for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

title: Faubus, White Resistance Symbol, Barely Mentions Race Issue in Campaign
description: HAZEN, Ark., July 25It was raining when he arrived at the political rally here this afternoon, and the people had huddled under the great oaks to eat their catfish.

title: Market Place
description: If you're like a lot of tour ists on their first trip abroad, you have discovered that the First National City Bank got there before you. The sea soned traveler suspects the truth: First National City of fices dot the globe to a far greater degree than those of any other United States bank.

title: HotDog Truck Called HotGoods Base
description: A Bronx vender who has sold hot dogs and sodas from a truck at the same Bronx inter section for 18 years was ar rested yesterday and charged with using the truck as a base for the sale of stolen merchan dise and forged documents.

title: U. of Kansas Board Ousts A Black Linked to Unrest
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., July 27 (APThe University of Kansas Board of Regents has ordered the dismissal of a black part time assistant to the dean of men.

title: House 6Termer in Race
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 27 (AP)Representative Silvio O. Conte, 49yearold Republican of Massachusetts, said today that he would seek a seventh term in Congress.

title: Brooklyn G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that Pfc. Peter P. Auletti of Brooklyn, of the Army, had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Return of the Native
description: Charlie, me boy, said the hearty voice on the other end of the phone. Tis your Uncle Mike, it is.

title: Disadvantaged City Boys Given Experience by Fresh Air Fund
description: Six disadvantaged youths from Brooklyn's Brownsville section have arrived home after an eightday camping trip that reflected the Fresh Air Fund's recent emphasis on cultural activitiec.

title: Prices of Abrasives Lifted
description: WORCESTER, Mass., July 27 (UPI)The Norton Company's abrasive materials division an nounced price increases today averaging 4 per cent on its line of abrasive materials and crude ores effective Sept. 1. The company said higher costs of raw material, power and labor were the primary reasons for the increases.

title: RICHARDSON PLANS REFORMS AT H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, July 27In his efforts to master the De partment of Health, Education and Welfare, which others have found unmanageable, Elliot L. Richardson, the new Secretary, is emphasizing the consolidation of grants, the decenralization of authority and the building of new administrative capacity by state and local governments.

title: Lindsay Has Expanded City's Use of Law Firms
description: The Lindsay administration has substantially expanded the use of private law firms, a marked departure from the philosophy and practices of the Wanner administration.

title: Wigger Wins 3d Gun Title
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 27 (AP)Maj. Lones Wigger of the United States Army cap tured the threeposition, 300 meter free rifle event with threeday score of 3,388 yester day as the 10th United States shooting championships end. Previously, Wigger had won the threeposition smallbore rifle event and airrifle shoot in the National Rifle Associationspon sored competition.

title: Bridge:
description: American experts visiting Europe have seldom achieved victory in pair contests re tricted to players of the high est class. Such events are much commoner in Europe than they are here, because European organizers are will ing to invite selected experts at the cost of irritating those who are passed over.

title: JERSEY INFANT DIED OF METHADONE DOSE
description: NEWARK, July 27 (UPI)A twomonth old boy died here after accidentally swallowing some of his mother's metha done tablets, the state medical examiner said today.

title: MRS. OGDEN REID DIES HERE AT 87
description: Mrs. Helen Rogers Reid, for mer president of The New York Herald Tribune, died of arterio sclerosis yesterday at her home, 834 Fifth Avenue.

title: The Screen: Entertaining Mr. Sloane
Dr. Milner B. Schaefer, 57, Headed Marine Institute
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 27 (AP)Dr. Milner B. Schaefer, director of the Marine Re sources Institute at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography here, died yesterday in Mercy Hospital after a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

title: ABORTION REQUESTS OUTRUN OPERATIONS
description: Requests for abortions at cityowned hospitals are in creasing faster than the hos pitals are performing the oper ations, hospital statistics showed yesterday.

title: Two Persian Leopards Born
description: CINCINNATI, July 27 (UPI) Two Persian leopards were born yesterday at the Cincin nati Zoo, bringing the rare animal's population to five in the United States. The two cubs, a female and male, were delivered by Caesarean section, along with a third cub that was stillborn.

title: Hofstadter Estate Is Left To a Fellow Judge Here
description: Samuel H. Hofstadter, a jus tice of the State Supreme Court here for 37 years, has left the bulk of his estate, estimated at between $20,000 and $50,000, to a longtime friend and fellow judge, Shirley R. Levitan of the Criminal Court.

title: Mrs. Abzug Complains About WOR Time Offer
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Attorneys for Mrs. Bella S. Abzug, the Democratic candi date for Congress in New York's 19th District, made a rare complaint today: That it would be an unfair burden to have to match Barry Farber, her Republican opponent and a professional radio inter viewer, in equal time broadcasts of her own.

title: Cotton Growing All Played Out, Georgia Site Gets Catfish Farm
description: MAYFIELD, Ga., July 26  The cornmealcoated hands of Cleveland Dargan and Tom Rushing moved swiftly, pick ing up catfish fillets and drop ping them into the boiling oil of six iron cooking cots.

title: Books of The Times
description: The Modern Masters series, edited by Frank Kermode in England, consists of long essays by distinguished critics on men who have changed and are changing the life and thought of our age. Viking brought out three books in the series this spring and will bring out another three this fall, in simultaneous hardcover and paperback editions. By choosing to review only two of the first three. I mean no dis respect for Alasdair MacIntyre's Hebert Marcuse. Mr. Maclntyre contends that almost all of Marcuse's key positions are false, and proves it. But Marcuse, like the hula hoop, seems to have had his day; even the young no longer wear his slogans as a sort of sandwich board advertising the revolution.

title: Wagner Festival Agrees To Become Public Trust
description: BAYREUTH, Germany, July 27 (AP)Agreement has been reached in principle to trans form the familyrun Richard Wagner opera festival into a public foundation, Mayor Hans Walter Wild of Bayreuth said yesterday.

title: Vague Pledge to Franco
description: After the long and divisive debates about the legal and constitutional bases for United States military actions in Indochina, the last thing the Nixon Admin istration ought to be considering is another vague overseas defense commitment. It appears ready, how ever, to sign a pledge to support the defense system of Spain in return for continued use of air and naval bases there.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Twelve years ago, when I lived in New Hampshire, an abnormal influx of outof state deer hunters in our area left most of the natives quaking with fear.

title: Westinghouse Sees Import Problem
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., July 27 The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is giving serious consideration to filing dump ing charges against foreign turbinegenerator manufactur ers, Gordon C. Hurlbert, execu tive vice president of power veneration, said here today.

title: AMEX STOCKS UP BY TINY MARGIN
description: It was a day of fencesitting yesterday for stocks on the American Stock Exchange. The index closed with a tiny change  up 0.02 to 20.34. There were 354 stocks advancing in price to 343 issues that de clined.

title: Seattle Brokerage House Is Punished by the S.E.C
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it had revoked the brokerdealer regis tration of a Seattle concern and barred its president from fur ther association with any se curities firm.

title: 25Mile New York Y.C. Sail Is Canceled by a Heavy Fog
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 27A second New York Yacht Club cruise event of the three scheduled since Saturday was blotted out by fog today. It was to have been a 25mile squadron run from Padanaram.

title: Survivors Recall Day 25 Years Ago When Bomber Struck Empire State
description: It was something you never forget. It was a hazy morning, that Saturday 25 years ago today, and a B25 bomber, lost in the mist, crashed into the Empire State Building 913 feet above the street at the 79th floor.

title: Negro on Board at Georgetown U.
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Georgetown University has appointed to its board of di rectors the first Negro in this century and also the youngest member in the school's 181 year history.

title: Charges Dropped Against 2 Held in Kansas City Killing
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 27 (AP)Charges against two men accused of slaying State Repre sentative Leon M. Jordan, Negro Democratic leader, were dropped today, Joseph Teas dale, prosecuting attorney, said.

title: Seewagen, Cornejo and Howard Score Upsets in Clay Tennis
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 27 (UPI) A mild upset occurred in the raindelayed opening round of the $50,000 National ClayCourt Tennis Tournament today wher Jim Osborne of Honolulu, the country's ninthranked player lost to unseeded Patricio Cor neio of Chile. 64, 119.

title: EARL WARREN SIGNS FOR BOOK ON CAREER
description: Earl Warren, whose 45 years of public service ranged from district attorney in San Fran cisco to Chief Justice of the United States, will cover his career in a book he has been signed to write for Doubleday & Co.

title: $19.200 for RunnersUp
description: MILAN, Italy, July 27 (AP) Second place in the World Cup soccer championship at Mexico City will yield $19,200 to each of the 22 squad members of the Italian national team, it was announced by Italian Soccer Federation sources today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
DOUBLE IS. SCORED BY MISS BAROODY
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 28Nancy Baroody of Lake ville, Conn., rode Shenandoah Flintstone to the small pony hunter championship and Neat 'N Tidy to the large pony fox chaser title today to score double at the Orange County horse show.

title: Hanoi Charges U.S. Raids
description: PARIS, July 28 (Reuters) North Vietnam charged today that United States B52 bomb ers and other aircraft carried out three consecutive days of raids last week on its territory in the northern part of the de militarized zone. Hanoi's dele gation to the Paris peace talks demanded that the American authorities immediately end all acts violating North Vietnam ese sovereignty and security.

title: AMEX ADVANCES AS VOLUME GAINS
description: After teetering indecisively on the fence Monday, stocks on the American Stock Ex change took a hop forward yes terday. The exchange's index gained 0.07 points to close at 20.41. Advances outnumbered declines by 404 to 334.

title: I.B.M. Adds a Director
description: Maersk M. Moller, chairman of the board and chief execu tive officer of the Maersk Lines, a worldwide shipping organiza tion, has been elected to the board of directors of Interna tional Business Machines Cor poration.

title: Michigan Lets Anyone Sue on Pollution
description: LANSING, Mich., July 28 (AP)Gov. William G. Milliken has signed a law that permits anyone to file suit to protect the air, water and other nat ural resources. Not even the state is immune from court, action.

title: Opening of Oh! Calcutta! Is Disappointing to Critics
description: LONDON, July 28Oh! Calcutta! opened here last night to disappointing re marks from critics, the public and local officials.

title: Continental Airlines Sets Purchase of DC10 Planes
description: CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) Continental Airlines, Inc., an nounced today a $160million deal calling for purchase of eight McDonnell Douglas DC 10 widebodied trijet aircraft and an option for eight others.

title: Mary Pickford Gives 50 Films to U.S. Film Institute
description: Mary Pickford has donated 50 of the many short films that were made for the pio neer Biograph company here to the American Film Insti tute Collection in the Library of Congress.

title: For These Families, a Happy Solution to Relocation Problem
description: CAMDEN, N. J.The children said they liked the bunk beds. And the air conditioning. And the bunk beds. And playmates who didn't beat them up. And the bunk beds. And the pretty furniture. And the bunk beds.

title: Advertising: TV Bureau Presents Its Case
description: We need more advertis ing in this country, not less.

title: Plant Accused on Mercury
description: BUFFALO, July 28The Olin Corporation chemical plant in nearby Niagara Falls was ac cused today in Federal Court of discharging mercury into the Niagara River. United States Attorrey H. Kenneth Schroeder Jr. sought an injunction against further discharges of mercury. The waste flows over Niagara Falls and eventually into Lake Ontario, where mercury pollu tion has killed some fish and made others unfit to eat.

title: Paramount Officer Is Named President
description: Stanley R. Jaffe, who joined Paramount Pictures last Octo ber as executive vice president, has been appointed president of the motion picture and tele vision company, a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc.

title: Foreign Affairs: Atoms and Pounds for Europe
description: This week, with the resump tion of bilateral negotiations between Bonn and Moscow, Europe finds itself well launched on the diplomatic search for a new future. This future seems postulated on the assumption of declining Ameri can influence in its western half and the somewhat less warranted hope of declining Soviet influence in its eastern half.

title: World Survey Finds City Lagging in Subway Safety
description: There have been more seri ous accidents on the New York subways in the last 10 years than on any other major sub way system in the world; in the last year there have been more accident injuries here than on any other subway, system.

title: Manson Family Member Testifies on Tate Killings
description: LOS ANGELES, July 28 The star prosecution witness in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three of his hippie band tearfully described today what she said were de tails of the killing of, five per sons in Lose Angeles last year.

title: Lynda Brooks, T. A. Crowley Plan Marriage
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 28Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Brooks of Chappaqua and Wayne, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynda Lee Brooks, to Thomas Adam Crowley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John. A. Crowley Jr. of Chappaqua, formerly of Scarsdale.

title: CITY MOVES TO AID CHILD SHELTERS
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday di rected the Commissioner of Social Services, Jack R. Gold berg, to take immediate steps to reduce overcrowding in two Manhatan child shelters by leasing additional facilities.

title: Dance: Oh! Oh! Romeo!
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, July 28The first thing to be, said in favor of Rudi Van Dantzig's staging of Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet for the Netherlands National Ballet is that it is original That is also almost the last thing to be said in favor of Rudi Van Dantzig's staging of Prokcifiev's Ro meo and Juliet for the Neth erlands National Ballet. Seen at the Municipal Opera House during the company's current ballet festival in Amsterdam, this is a version that makes long work of a long ballet.

title: Senator Hansen Will Oppose SST Because of Its Boom
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 Senator Clifford P. Hansen. Republican of Wyoming, said today he had decided to vote against further appropriations for the supersonic transport, principally because of the plane's sonic boom and other environmental hazards.

title: Brooklyn's New School District 13 Names Chief
description: There are six communities in Brooklyn's Community School District 13, and Monday night, after two months of often bitter wrangling, campaigning and screening, a superintendent was chosen to oversee the children's education.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Washington: For the Record
Books of The Times
description: In 1966 Richard Nixon confided to Jules Witcover in an interview that I'm not one of those guys who reads his press clippings. I believe in never being affected by reports about me. . . . I never look at myself on TV, either. I don't want to develop those phony, selfconscious, con trived things. One thing I have to be is THE RESURRECTION OF RICHARD NIXON. By Jules Witcover. 479 Pages. G. P. Put nam's Sons. $7.95. always be my self. If there is a single striking im pression in Wit cover's meticulous and invaluable ac count of Richard Nixon's extraordi nary comeback, it is that he was al ways himself. In the tumultuous six years spanning his crushing defeat in California in 1962 and his Presiden tial victory in 1968, Nixon was the One, the one constant persona in American poli tics. Witcover's achievement In portraying exactly the calculation, detachment and insulation of the Nixon campaign is all the more remarkable in that he is already the author of the most diligent account of the last campaign of Robert F. Kennedy.

title: JOSEPH P. SCHNEIDER
description: JERSEY CITY, July 28  Joseph P. Schneider, founder and president of Schneider, Allen, Walsh, Inc., a New York adver tising agency, died Sunday, after a brief illness, at Christ Hospi tal. He was 66 years old and lived at 93 Fairview Avenue.

title: Vacation and the Sin le Girl: Tireless Pursuit of a Dream
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas She comes from the Corn Belt in Iowa.

title: Jets Plan Scrimmage With Bulls Saturday
description: The New York Jets and the Long Island Bulls will meet in a controlled scrimmage game on Saturday night if the managementlabor dis pute in pro football is settled by then.

title: Profit Fell Sharply In Con Ed's 1st Half As Revenues Rose
description: While the Consolidated Edi son Company was struggling to meet its power demands yes terday, the giant utility re leased its firsthalf earnings re port, which showed sizable de clines in net income despite higher operating revenues.

title: Ford Calls on U.A.W. to Agree To Tough Curb on Absenteeism
description: DETROIT, July 28  The Ford Motor Company called to day for tougher factory disci pline to curb employe absen teeism.

title: Theater: Company Anew
description: Shortly Ether Company opened, Dean Jones, playing the lead role of the bachelor Robert, became ill. His standby, Larry Kert, filled in and subsequently took over the role. Robert now belongs to Kertnot just contrac tually.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
SLUGGER BETTERS RECORD FOR CLUB
JERSEYANS TIED BY WESTCHESTER
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 28Westchester rallied in afternoon singles matches to day to tie New Jersey for the Stoddard Cup in the 39th an nual triangular matches that also involve amateurs from the Long Island Golf Association.

title: DOUGLAS A. YORKE
description: RUMSON, N. J. July 28  Douglas A. Yorke, former head of the Hansen & Yorke Com pany of New York, which was merged with Graybar Electric Company in 1968, died Sunday at Riverview Hospital, Red Bank. He was 46 years old.

title: HOUSTON BLACKS DENOUNCE POLICE
description: HOUSTON, July 28Leader of this city's Black Coalition accused the police today of de liberately creating a situation to draw fire last Sunday night that resulted in the death of Carl Hampton, a 21yearold black activist here. Mr. Hamp ton was killed in a threehour gun battle with the authorities, the police say.

title: TEXAS SCHOOL SUITS PLANNED IN 10 DAYS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 28 (UPI) The Justice Department said today it would file suit to inte grate 39 Texas school districts within 10 days unless the dis tricts submitted to Federal guidelines.

title: BULOVA IS SCORED ON DEFENSE ISSUE
description: The military industrial com plex and the antiwar move ment met headon yesterday at the annual meeting of the Bulova Watch Company.

title: Article 4  No Title
Egypt Said to Release 80 Jews; French Diplomacy Is Credited
description: PARIS, July 28  Discreet French diplomacy has contrib uted to the release of 80 Jews from a prison in the United Arab Republic, according to rehable reports here.

title: House Repulses Attempts To Change Seniority Rule
description: WASHINGTON July 28The House refused today make any changes in its seniority system, by which mem bers move into positions of power solely through length of service. Acting committee chairmen defended the sys tem, impatient young first termers berated it, and the ranks of those who are at neither the top nor the bot tom of the seniority ladder were openly split over the issue.

title: 2 CATV OPERATORS GET 20YEAR PACTS
description: The city awarded 20year noncompetitive contracts yes terday to two Manhattan cable television operators and au thorized the development of cable television on a competi tivebidding basis in the four other boroughs.

title: DAYAN INDICATES HE BACKS U.S. PLAN
description: JERUSALEM, July 28De fense Minister Moshe Dayan said tonight that Israel is not so strong that she can afford to lose allies  an apparent allusion to the United States. He was believed to be acknowl edging his feeling that Israel, was compelled to accept the United States proposals for a limited ceasefire in the Middle East conflict.

title: Israel Says Her Jets Raided Egyptians at Canal All Day
description: TEL AVIV, July 28 (Reuters)  Israeli jets continued their bombardment of United Arab Republic military targets along the Suez Canal with a daylong attack today, a military spokes man said.

title: Mormon Pilgrims Hail Church's 14 0th Year
description: PALMYRA, N.Y., July 27 Hundreds of Mormon pil grims from over the country have gathered this week in this area of undulant fields of wildflowers and seemingly endless rows of corn as part of a commemoration of the 140th anniversary of the founding of their church.

title: M'CORMICK VICTOR BUT NEEDS RELIEF
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 28 Tom Egan, a husky young catcher with the California An gels, committed five passed balls and one error tonight, most of them contributing to the. Yankees' 65 victory over the Angels.

title: THREE URGE TESTS OF DONATED BLOOD
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 Three specialists here have ad vocated that all blood banks capable of doing so should test donated blood for a substance found only in association with hepatitis.

title: Second Fire in 2 Days Hits Pennsy
description: The second fire in as many days delayed Penn Central riders last night.

title: CUT IN POWER USE HELPS CITY GET BY IN 94DEGREE HEAT
description: New Yorkers wriggled through an electric power crisis yesterdaythe hottest day of the yearaided by voltage re ductions throughout eastern New York State and three hours of voluntary cutbacks in power consumption.

title: Too Much for. Highways...
description: Congress and the American people are nearing a fundamental decision on transportation policy revolv ing about the Highway Trust Fund, which is scheduled to go out of existence on Sept. 30, 1972. The Nixon Administration has asked Congress to extend it for another four years, and House and Senate committees have begun hearings.

title: Cambodians, Out of Ammunition, Yield Factory
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 28Enemy troops occupied the state cement works at Kampot yesterday after the Cambodian defenders ran out of ammu nition and abandoned the fac tory, the Government military spokesman said today.

title: Find Another Holder for Kicks, Pete Gogolak Is Told by Bride
description: The Professional Football Players Association can relax because the young woman who has been holding the football for Pete Gogolak, the Giants' kicker, doesn't want to play professionally.

title: German Deciphers 50 Inca Symbols
description: BONN, July 28A German ethnologist, Prof. Thomas Bar thel, reports that he and a Peruvian colleague have suc ceeded in deciphering the 500 yearold script of the Inca nation, regarded until now merely as ornamentation.

title: Article 3  No Title
SOCIALISTS RESIST ON ITALIAN CABINET
description: ROME, July 28  Italy's So cialist party administered a set back today to the efforts of Premierdesignate Emilio Co lombo to put a governing co alition together again and form a Cabinet to end a 22day Gov ernment crisis.

title: Meritus Takes Aqueduct Sprint by Neck
description: Meritus made an early lead stand up against the closing rush of Teddy's True to win the featured sprint at Aqueduct yesterday by a neck. The finish close as it was, was satisfac tory to the favorite players in the crowd of 25,601. They made Meritus, who campaigns for James Cox Brady, the favorite at even money in the sixfur long event for older fillies.

title: BANK BOND ERROR COSTS CITY $65,250
description: A bank employe's error has cost New York City $65.250.

title: Agnew, College Stars Get Golf Honors Here
description: Vice President Agnew was honored last night at the sixth annual AllAmerican Collegiate golf dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: JUNE LAG IS SHOWN BY ECONOMIC INDEX
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Government's composite index of leading indicators of the economy continued to sig nal a sluggish outlook in June, the Commerce Department dis closed today.

title: ERNEST B. WOOD
description: SUMMIT, N. J., July 28 Ernest B. Wood, a former member of the technical staff of Bell Telephone Laboratories, died Monday at Overlook Hos pital here. He was 81 years old and lived in Tangerine, Fla. He retired in 1953.

title: CARELESS DEALING IN ART CONCEDED
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Officials of the Smithsonian Institution conceded at a House subcommittee hearing today that paintings from the Nation Collection of Fine Arts had been sold without adequate re view by museum directors.

title: Dividend to Be Same
description: The United States Steel cor poration reported yesterday that its earnings declined in the second quarter and first half of 1970down about 27 per cent in both cases from the 1969 levelsalthough sales and other revenues continued to advance slightly.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON REGISTER A DROP
description: London stock prices moved lower despite persistent optim ism that the dock workers strike would be settled soon. Trading was quiet.

title: Relay Racing, English Import, Is a Bit Fussy, but Good Fun
description: What is a relay motor race? It is a participant sport, pop ular in England, that has been imported for some years to the, Lime Rock Park road course in western Connecti cut, where Jim Haynes, a promoter, is happy to try anything. A fivehour relay will be run Saturday, Sept. 5, by the Liverpool Motor Club as part of Lime Rock's Labor Day camping and mo tor sports week end. The principal attraction will be a 107mile Formula A race on Labor Day, the 10th of a 14event series counting toward the Continental cham pionship of the Sports Car Club of America.

title: EDWARD F. BRESLIN, RETIRED JUDGE, 71
description: Edward F. Breslin, former justice of the city Court of Special Sessions and the Crimi nal Court, died of a heart at tack Monday at Union Hospital, the Bronx. He was 71 years old and lived at 306 East Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx.

title: New Day on Capitol Hill
description: Those who were not quite convinced by the moon landings that this is an era of change should be per suaded by the recent behavior of the House of Repre sentatives. A few days ago it agreed to reveal, on request, the way its members vote in committee and to allow hearings to be televised. Now it has decided, at least in a preliminary way, that if only 20 members object, the rest may no longer hide behind that monu ment of secrecy, the unrecorded teller vote. The amending process, in which the teller vote is used, may not much longer allow Representatives to Vote on such vital matters as the. CooperChurch proposal, Federal outlays for pollution programs and controversial anti crime procedures without their constituents ever being, able to tell how they stood.

title: Australians Act on Pollution After Outcry Over Noxious Sydney Smog
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 28 Stringent moves to control environmental pollution here were announced today fol lowing an uproar over a wave of noxious industrial waste gas that enveloped Sydney with a strong odor of rotten eggs last Saturday night.

title: Cab Driver Shot in Face After a Holdup in Harlem
description: A cab driver was shot in the face early yesterday in the first shooting since the police started driving decoy cabs 10 days ago in an effort to cut down on at tacks upon taxi drivers.

title: Wallis Acquires the Rights For a Movie on Thoreau
description: Hal Wallis has acquired film rights to The Night Thoreau Spent in Jail, the play by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee, for production for Universal Pictures. The playwrights will also do the movie adapta tion of their drama, which deals with Thoreau's decision to serve a jail sentence rather than pay a $2 tax that would support the MexicanAmerican War.

title: MRS. TROWBRIDGE
description: TORRINGTON, Conn., July 28 Mrs. Mason Trowbridge, a sculptor and the widow of a former counsel to the Col gatePalmolivePeet Company, died yesterday at Charlotte Hungerford Hospital here. She was. 87 years old and lived in West Cornwall.

title: Groth Leaves Jets' Camp
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 28 Walter Groth, a defensive tackle who was the 13thround draft choice of the New York Jets, departed for his Freeport, Tex., home today after advising the coaching staff that he's not sure he wants to play pro foot ball. Groth, a 6foot4inch, 240 pounder, played college football at Baylor University.

title: Union Is Said to Reach Grape Grower Pacts
description: DELANO, Calif., July 28 (UPI)Cesar Chavez's farm workers union has reached tentative agreements with 26 large table grape growers, which would bring 85 per cent of the California crop under union contract.

title: Hints on Saving Power
description: Following is a list of power conservation hints prepared by Consolidated Edison for its customers:

title: F.C.C. BACKS SALE OF TWX BY A.T.&T.
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Federal Communications Com mission gave its approval today to the sale of the American Telephone and Telegraph Com pany's teletypewriter exchange (or TWX) system to the West ern Union Corporation.

title: Celtics Sign Garfield Smith
description: BOSTON, July 28 (AP)Gar Field Smith, a 6foot9inch, 225 pound standout rebounder for Eastern Kentucky, signed with the Boston Celtics today for the coming National Basketball Association season.

title: Reserve Challenge?
description: One of the oldest issues in American historythe degree of independence of the central bank from Presidential author ity  is heading for a new round. Its outcome may have a crucial impact on the future course of the economy and on the political fortunes of the Republican Party. The reemer gence of this issue now stems from the policy differ ences between Ar thur Burns, chair man of the Federal Reserve Board, and Paul W. McCracken, chairman of Presi dent Nixon's Council of Eco nomic Advisers.

title: CANADA STUDYING HOCKEY EXPENSES
description: OTTAWA, July 28 (AP)The House of Commons Finance Committee was informed today that Bobby Orr of the National Hockey League, a superstar of the Boston Bruins, spent more than $15,000 a year sending autographed pictures to his fans.

title: Bridge
description: The organizers of last week's international tourna ment in Deauville went to great trouble to insure world wide participation in their invitational pair champion ship.
