The eight pairs included one from France, one from Great Britain, two from Italy, two from the United States, one from the Re public of China, and a cos mopolitan partnership of movie star. Omar Sharif play ing with a French expert.

title: Card of Thanks
description: THE DUCHESS OF BEDFORD was over, whelmed by the number of kind friends who sent her Birthday Greetings and will, be writing to everyone during the next few weeks.

title: Sato Plans Action to Meet Pollution Crisis in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 28The pol lution of soil, water and at mosphere has reached crisis proportions in this narrow land, where more than 100 million people are jammed together in an area the size of Montana.

title: NIXON PANEL ASKS RADICAL CHANGES FOR THE PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, July 28A Presidential commission recom mended today a radical reor ganization of the Defense De partment  including the re moval of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from involvement in mili tary operationsand a number of other steps designed to achieve more efficiency and save money in weapons pro curement.

title: WALTER VAN SCHOICK
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., July 28  Walter Van Schoick, chair man and president of the Ocean County National Bank, died at Point Pleasant Hospital here yes terday. He was 62 years old. He was a graduate of Rider College, Trenton. Surviving are two brothers and a sister.

title: BROTHER OF COUNSEL TO NIXON IS ACCUSED
description: ELLOREE, S. C. July 28 W. P. Dent, an older brother of Harry S. Dent, a special counsel to President Nixon, was bound over tonight to face a grand jury on charges of robbery and assault and battery.

title: It's Not Exactly Fashion Country, But...
description: A lucky thing happened to Stanley Provus during his two years as a Peace Corps volunteer in Ethiopia. He didn't have a supervisor. The result is a small new in dustry for the African country and more colorful fashion for the Western world.

title: Malfunctions and Delays Mar jumbo Jet Service
description: Six months after going into commercial service, the Boeing 747 jumbo jet still is bedeviled by a variety of technical ail ments that have made ontime performance a spotty phe nomenon.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Arming South Africa

title: U. N. Moves Toward World Peace Corps
description: GENEVA, July 28The Unit ed Nations took a decisive step today toward the creation of a world peace corps to assist the poorer nations toward eco nomic development.

title: SOVIET PARTY AIDE BECOMES DIPLOMAT
description: MOSCOW, July 28The So viet Union today announced the appointment of Nikolai N. Ro dionov, a regional Communist party official, as a Deputy For eign Minister.

title: TRUST EXEMPTIONS APPROVED BY NIXON
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 28 (AP)President Nixon, a White House source said to day, has signed into law a bill providing antitrust law exemp tions for joint commercial op erating agreements between newspapers in 22 cities.

title: Seoul Reports Jets Sink Red Spy Ship Near Eastern Coast
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 28 South Korean fighter planes sank a 50ton North Korean speedboat, believed to have been used to put Communist agents ashore, early today off the east coast, the Defense Ministry announced.

title: Chiefs Rushing in 90Degree Heat to Get Ready for AllStars
description: LIBERTY, Mo., July 28 The Kansas City Chiefs, the champions of pro football, will fly to Chicago on Thurs day, play the College All Stars on Friday night and then disband if no agreement has been reached between the Players Association and the National Football League owners.

title: Steel Companies' Outlays For Pollution Curbs Rise
description: The American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday in Washington that spending by domestic steel companies to control air and water pollu tion last year was about $138 million, up from $102million the previous year.

title: STAGNANT AIR LIKELY TO STAY OVER CITY
description: The city's Department of Air Resources reported air pollution levels as unsatisfactory yester day as a stagnant air system continued to hang over the area. The situation was ex pected to continue through today.

title: C. Ernest Smith Is Dead; A Former State Senator
description: C. Ernest Smith, a former Municipal Court judge and State Senator, died after a long illness yesterday at Staten Island Hospital. He lived at 260 Benedict Road, Staten Island.

title: Article 5  No Title
Heath's Crucial Choices
description: It would be difficult in the best of circumstances to have to replace so able and experienced a British Cabi net minister as lain Macleod. Prime Minister Heath had to find that replacement as Chancellor of the Exchequer from a Conservative. Government barely a month in office after nearly six years in oppositionand his difficulties did not stop there.

title: Market Place
description: The stock market may have bottomed out, but the pessimism lingers on. It is very difficult to generate ex citement in a market that produces so little volume that brokerage houses con tinue to operate in the red.

title: TOP TENNIS PROS JOIN HUNT'S UNIT
description: Lamar Hunt, who as owner of the Kansas City Chiefs helped engineer the merger in professional football, expanded his sports empire yesterday by acquiring the contracts of six top tennis prosRod Layer, Ken Rosewall, Roy Emerson, Fred Stolle, Andres Gimeno and Richard (Pancho) Gonzales.

title: RAYMOND BRANCHEAU
description: SILVER CITY, N.M., July 28, (AP)Raymond Brancheau, a former football player at the University of Notre Dame and a Western New Mexico Univer sity athletic director, died to day at his home here. He was 60 years old.

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS IN OHIO URGE DAVIS TO RUN
description: CLEVELAND, July 28Re publican party officials here today urged Benjamin O. Davis Jr., who resigned yesterday as Cleveland's safety director, to run for Mayor next year.

title: Hoffman Asks Cuba Trip
description: CHICAGO, July 28 (UPI) Abbie Hoffman, one of the five convicted members of the Chi cago Seven, has asked court permission to travel to Cuba. The 33yearold Hoffman is ap pealing his conviction for incit ing riots during the 1968 Demo cratic National Convention.

title: U.S. FILES ACCORD IN RICHFIELD SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)The Justice Department today filed a proposed settle ment requiring the Atlantic Richfield Company to sell with in three years 2,500 former Sinclair Oil Corporation gaso line stations in the. South and West.

title: Pentagon Panel Members
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 The President's panel on the Defense Department, which spent a year studying the Pentagon for a report issued today, had as its chairman Gilbert W. Fitzhugh, chair man of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

title: A Master Control Center Charts Con Edison Flow
description: A middleaged man sits quiet ly in a big redleather swivel chair, his eyes fixed on a green, board with flashing red lights that forms a large horseshoe arcund him.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The New York Times on July 16 inadvertently suggested that officials of the Overseas Press Club, 54 West 40th Street, had barred a non union television crew from covering a news event on club premises. The club did not bar, and has no policy that calls for barring union or nonunion members of any medium from covering news conferences.

title: Scholarship to Cite Weaver
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., July 28 (AP)The Jim Weaver Memo rial Graduate Scholarship Fund has been established in memory of the commissioner of the At lantic Coast Conference for 16 years. Weaver died July 11.

title: Lost Art by Deaf ls Found And Placed on Exhibition
description: A Smithsonian Institution collection of 44 paintings and graphics by deaf and hard of hearing children and adults was placed on display yesterday at the New York League for the Hard of Hearing, 71 West 23d Street. The exhibition will con tinue through Sept. 12.

title: NOROTON JUNIORS ADVANCE TO FINAL
description: NOROTON, Conn., July 28  The defending champion Noroton Yacht Club crew, skippered by David Campbell, led the way through the quali fying series of the 47th annual junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound today, when the final three preliminary races were held, in lightning glass sloops on the sound off the Noroton club.

title: American Ballet Theater, Away Since 1956, Returns
description: LONDON, July 28Ameri can Ballet Theater last night opened a twoweek season at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. This was the company's fifth Covent Gar den appearance since 1946, but its first in 14 years.

title: Panther Testifies He Assumed Party Leaders Ordered Murder
description: NEW HAVEN, July 28 Warren Kimbro testified today that he was told for the first time that Alex Rackley was to be killed only instants before a pistol was placed in his hand and he was given the order to pull the trigger.

title: Corporate Bond Yields Up as TaxExempts Dip
description: Yields on new issues of cor porate bonds, which dropped so sharply over the last five and a half weeks, are climbing once again, but taxexempt bond rates are still declining. This mixed picture emerged yester day as a heavy schedule of bond sales got under way.

title: JACOB H. BLITZER, 77, OF LIGHTOLIER, DEAD
description: Jacob H. Blitzer, former ex ecutive vice president and di rector of Lightolier, Inc., died Sunday, at the Dewitt Nursing Home on East 79th Street fol lowing a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 111 East 56th Street and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: MEETING WILL SEEK NEW GRAINS ACCORD
description: GENEVA, July 28A pre paratory committee will meet here from Aug. 3 to Aug. 7 to prepare the draft text of a new international grains agreement, a spokesman for the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development said today.

title: Earnings Tumble at U.S. Steel And at 3 Major Oil Companies
description: Earnings Tumble at U.S. Steel And at 3 Major Oil Companies

title: U.S. Approves Sale of Trucks With G.M. Engines to Chinese
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Department of Commerce has approved the sale by an Italian company to Communist China of 80 dump trucks con taining General Motors Cor poration engines, United States officials said tonight.

title: Robin, Zephyros Victors Again in N.Y.Y.C. Cruise
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., July 28  Ted Hood's Robin, one of several of his yachts of the same name and all painted blue, and John Baringer's Zephyros, a Fastnet 45, remained the only unbeaten boats on the New York Yacht Club cruise today.

title: Screen: Kadar's 'The Angel Levine':Belafonte Is the Angel of Malamud's Tale Zero Mostel Portrays a Troubled Tailor
description: Bernard Malamud's short story, "Angel Levine," about how a black Jewish angel comes to earth to save the health, the wife, and the fortunes of a New York teller, is a charming, if slightly sensational, success in a minor genre. Jan Kadar's new movie. "The Angel Levine" (the article added, perhaps, so you shouldn't think it's about a Puerto Rican-Jewish angel), is, given the reputations of the talents involved, a failure of major proportions. I have seen worse movies. But I cannot remember having seen a movie so nervously at odds with itself, so timid in its impulses, and so mistaken in its choices.The Malamud story is very brief, as befits the limited potential of its cheerful anecdote. Like other Malamud fiction of the 1950's, like many of the stories collected with it in "The Magic Barrel," (New York, 1958), it plays with a certain parochial pride in the notion of being Jewish. When the tailor finally recognizes the angel and thus preserves his universe, his pleased reaction is: "A wonderful thing . . . Believe me, there are Jews everywhere"and you must accept the attitude behind this punch line as somehow completing an ethnocentric world-view in which miracles are second nature.The movie accepts very little though it adds a lotincluding two useless characters and an unhappy ending. Actually, it seems to add three or four endings, repeatedly stopping and starting up again, and the ending on the screen, when the houselights come up, happens to be unhappy.For the Malamud sense of community it substitutes an improbable tenement surrounded by gleaming apartment houses in the high-rise 60's. And for the Malamud world-view (really, a somewhat too mystical cozy cosmology), it substitutes a scattered sociology much influenced by current events.Not only does the film provide naturalistic death for Levine, but also once it has him dead it keeps doubting his immortality and even then saddles him with a sullen, soulful girl friend (the silliest role and, from Gloria Foster, the worst performance in the movie) whom, for reasons that he seems too embarrassed to explain, he can't marry. Levine says he is Jewish but he acts angry black, and for the tailor's ethnic protectionism there are many humiliating words. The effort to produce a now "Angel Levine" seems misguided at best, and Kadar's film generally falls with the worst.Nobody in the cast escapes unscathed, but Harry Belafonte, by dint of sheer ordinariness, suffers least. Milo O'Shea, as the friendly Jewish family physician, struggles pointlessly through an international variety of accents, mostly Irish. Between Zero Mostel and Ida Kaminska (the tailor and his wife) it is difficult to say whether the greater misplaced energy has been expended in making his miserable old age seem shabby, or in making hers seem grand. I admire the calculations of neither performance.Mostel's ancient orthodoxy is more Old Testament than old country, and you can pretty well sense each shamble in the characterization clicking into place. But Miss Kaminska plays the noble dying matriarch with an inappropriate elegance that might challenge the histrionic ambitions of a coven of Jewish grandmothers, and it is her performance that chiefly pushes "The Angel Levine" into sentimental idiocy.She is amply assisted by Kadar ("The Shop on Main Street," also with Ida Kaminska) whose tricky, inexpressive directing offers no discoveries but many well-worn clichs.Kadar's ideas about the fiction are diffuse and simplistically humanistic (as Malamud's really are not), and he seems afraid of each necessary hint of a super-nature. To make up the deficiency there is a dreadful musical background, a kind of middle-European choir of heavenly voices that sings loudly and insistently and almost all the timeas if the spirit that moved upon the face of the waters were standing off the set, waiting for the services to begin.

title: Baughan of Rams Unretires
description: FULLERTON, Calif., July 28 (UPI)Maxie Baughan, middle linebacker and defensive sig nalcaller, is coming out of re tirement to play with the Los Angeles Rams again this sea son, the club reported today.

title: SILVER FUTURES CONTINUE TO RISE
description: The bandwagon theory of trading worked vigorously yes terday in two leading commod ities. Some traders jumped aboard fastrolling silver and others were taking a notso pleasant leap out of soybeans, either to conserve their profits or to cut their losses.

title: PENNSY'S TRUSTEES APPROVED BY I.C.C.
description: The appointment last week of four trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Com pany by Federal District Judge John P. Fullam in Philadelphia was formally ratified yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Panther's Trial Is Delayed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 (AP) The trial of David Hil liard, a Black Panther leader, on charges of threatening the life of President Nixon was re set today for Oct. 5. The delay was granted because his attor ney, Charles Garry, is involved in the trial of six Latin Amer ican youths accused of slaying a San Francisco policeman.

title: EDWIN H. KING
description: GREENPORT, L. I., July 28 Edwin H. King, a retired farmer and former Suffolk County Republican committee man, died today at Eastern Long Island Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Orient.

title: Irene von Dorrer Wed in Stuttgart
description: Miss Irene Ingrid Helene von Dorrer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wolfgang von Dor rer of Bonn and Stuttgart, West Germany, was married in Stuttgart on Saturday to James Leslie Hildebrand 3d, of Chardon, Ohio. The Rev. Rederick Schneeberg, a Lu theran minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Schloss Solitude.

title: Miss Wachtenheim Planning Nuptials
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., July 28  Mr. and Mrs. William Wachtenheim have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Wacht enheim, to William Ira Denberg. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs Jerome A. Den berg of Manhasset Hills.

title: City Feels Impact of Power Shortage
description: From the tops of its sky scrapers to the sweltering depths of its sprawling sub way system, the city ab sorbed the impact yesterday of renewed cutbacks in elec trical power from the crippled Con Edison system.

title: STOCK INSURANCE HITS SENATE SNAG
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Congressional committees ap proved three different bills af fecting the securities industry today, but a fourth hit an im mediate snag in the Senate Banking Committee.

title: House Committee Votes To Keep OH Quota System
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee voted formally to day to hold President Nixon to the oil import quota system in effect since 1959.

title: 27th Arms Meeting Held
description: VIENNA, July 28Soviet and American negotiators in the talks on the limitation of stra tegic arms held their 27th meet ing and agreed to have another working session on Friday. They set no date for a recess.

title: FIAT WILL ENLARGE CITROEN OWNERSHIP
description: PARIS, July 28 The French Government today authorized the Fiat Company of Turin, Italy, to increase its ownership in the Citroen company of France, cementing a transEuro pean partnership accounting for production of 2 million vehicles a year.

title: Jean Starr Unterrneyer Dead; Poet, Translator and Teacher
description: Jean Starr Untermeyer, poet and former wife of the poet Louis Untermeyer, was found dead Monday, apparently of, a heart attack, in her apartment at 235 East 73d Street. She was 84 Years old.

title: Merck & Co. Plans Starch Acquisition
description: Merck & Co. and the Na tional Starch and Chemical Corporation announced last night preliminary agreement on a merger plan that would in volve stock valued at about $189million.

title: BOWERY MAN SLAIN; YOUTH, 19, IS HELD
description: An unidentified man was re peatedly and fatally stabbed near a Bowery hotel early yesterday morning as he tried to elude a neighborhood youth who had accosted him, the police said.

title: INDUSTRIAL LAWS IMPOSED BY PERU
description: LIMA, Peru, July 28 (Reuters) The President of Peru, Gen Juan Velasco Alvarado, tonight announced a new industrial law that forces Peruvian companies to hand over 10 per cent of their annual pretax net profit to workers, and also forces the companies to buy 50 per cent of their own shares for workers. and television speech on the 149th anniversary of Peruvian independence.

title: Details of 2d Operation On Lombardi Withheld
description: WASHINGTON, July 28, (AP).  New concern devel oped today over the physical condition of Vince Lombardi, head coach and general man ager of the Washington Red skins, following his second abdominal operation in a month.

title: Jersey Inspectors Order Repairs Made On 11 Tedesco Buses
description: Eleven buses owned by Frank A. Tedesco have been ordered out of service by the New Jer sey Public Service Commission. A bus owned by Mr. Tedesco crashed on July 15 near Allen town. Pa., killing seven children.

title: Article 1  No Title
Soviet Is Resisting Changes in West German Treaty
description: MOSCOW, July 28  West German efforts to obtain So viet approval of changes in their projected treaty renouncing the use of force apparently ran into expected Soviet resistance to day when the two sides began pointbypoint discussion of the document.

title: A LAG IN REVENUES PUSHES US. DEFICIT UP TO $2.9BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Government announced today that the Federal budget showed a relatively small deficit of $2.9 billion in the fiscal year that ended June 30.

title: Aide of Retail Group in Shift
description: Robert R. Thiel, vice presi dent of the credit management division of the National Retail Merchants Association has re signed to become a vice presi dent of Gracious Lady Service, Inc. Gracious Lady, Phildelphia, specializes in creditcard mar keting and public relations for retailers, banks, oil companies and large merchandisers.

title: NEWSDAY WORKERS GRANTED A HEARING
description: A hearing will be held Aug. 11 by the National Labor Rela tions Board here on a petition filed by editorial workers of Newsday, the Long Island news paper, seeking to be represent ed in collective bargaining by the United Automobile Work ers.

title: Nixon Daughter in Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) Mrs. David Eisenhower, the 22yearold daughter of Presi dent Nixon, underwent tests to day for a chronic urinary tract infection. She was scheduled to be released tomorrow from Georgetown University Hospi tal. The White House announced that she had been suffering from the infection for several months and had entered the hospital yesterday, afternoon.

title: GEORGE SEGET
description: ELIZABETH, N. J. July 28  I. George Seget of this city, chairman of the board of the Service Machine Company of Elizabeth, died yesterday in St. Anthony's Hospital, St. Petersburg, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 79 years old.

title: New Pentagon Critic
description: Gilbert Wright Fitzhugh, the board chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, keeps a small wooden triangle on his desk in New York. It is engraved with a thought that he be lieves is pretty good: Are you here with the solution or are you Dart of the prob lem? Apparent Man ly, President Nix on feels that Mr. Fitzhugh is here with the solution. About a year ago he named him as chairman of a blue ribbon defense panel to conduct a yearlong study of the Defense Department and to suggest reforms.

title: Whitmore Conviction Affirmed, But He Is Planning New Appeal
description: The conviction of George Whitmore Jr. for attempted rape and assault on a Brook lyn practical nurse was af firmed unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division, Sec ond Department.

title: Katzenbach, Who Termed Tonkin Resolution Equivalent of Declaration of War, Now Backs Its Repeal
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, for mer Under Secretary of State, urged Congress today to repeal the Tonkin Gulf resolution of 1964, which he once described as the functional equivalent of a declaration of war in Vietnam.

title: In Memoriam
description: KROLLMurray. Lovingly remembered and sadly missed today on your birthday and every other day. Rest in peace.

title: Minnesota Bishop Is Named
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) Msgr. Kenneth Povish of Bay City, Mich., has been named by Pope Paul VI to succeed the Most Rev. Laurence A. Glenn, 69, as bishop of the diocese of Crookston, Minn., it was an nounced today.

title: Egypt's Role Changes By DANA ADAMS SCHMIDT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 28 Since 1967 the Jordanians and the Lebanese have had con frontations with the Palestin ians, and the United Arab Re public was able to act as mediator.

title: Ellin R. Schechter Is Wed in Suburbs
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 28 Miss Ellin Rita Schechter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Schechter of Ma maroneck, was married here this eyening to Douglas Frank Maxwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Maxwell of New York. The ceremony was performed in the Fen way Golf Club by Rabbi Arnold Kaiman of Larch mont.

title: Michigan Jeer Romney Over Suburbs' Integration
description: WARREN, Mich., July 28 George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment, has run into an uproar here in his home state over Federal efforts to press for de segregation in suburban hous ing.

title: LAWSON H. BROWN, CIVIC LEADER, DIES
description: Lawson H. Brown, a Brook lyn civic leader from the 1920's through the 1950's, who cam paigned vigorously for im proved public facilities in the borough, died yesterday in Hamden, Conn. He was 82 years old.

title: Fun for the Young
description: THE RED BALLOON at 10:30 A.M. Fri day at New York Public Library, 125th Street Branch, 224 East 125th Street, and 4 P.M. Friday at the 96th Street Regional Branch, 112 East 96th Street; The Camel Who Took a Walk and other films at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. Tuesday at Tompkins Square Regional Branch, 331 East 10th Street near Avenue A, and Cattle Ranch, and other films at 3:30 P.M. Tuesday at Hamilton Fish Park Branch, 415 East Houston Street, near Avenue D. For other branches, call 7906161.

title: TV: A Program of Readings From Gertrude Stein
description: My writing is clear as mud, wrote Gertrude Stein, an assertion for which, over the years, she furnished copious evidence. But when she was good she was good she was good, as illustrated in When This You See Re member Me, last evening's halfhour program of readings from her work on Channel 13.

title: Onassis Gives a Yacht To His Wife on Birthday
description: ATHENS July 28 (UPI) Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis ob served her 41st birthday to day on the Island of Skorpios, and as a present her husband ordered construction of a yacht, to be named Jac queline.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Rosenman, Prominent Democrat, To Join Rockefeller's Campaign
description: Samuel I. Rosenman, aide and counselor for a generation to Democratic Presidents and Governors, announced yester day that he was supporting Governor Rockefeller for re election and would head a group called Democrats for Rockefeller.

title: Roundup: Clemente Wins Games as Consultant Too
description: Roberto Clemente, baseball fans know, has won innumer able games with his hitting and fielding, but Joe Brown, the Pittsburgh general man ager, tells of another way in which Clemente is a most valuable Pirate.

title: CANADIAN CONTROL OF BUSINESS URGED
description: OTTAWA, July 28  The Government was urged by a House of Commons committee today to set a goal of Canadian control of all foreign subsidi aries operating in Canada.

title: Gimbels Will Build Entrances To Subway at Yorkville Store
description: A longstanding dispute be tween Gimbels and community groups on the Upper East Side has apparently been settled with an agreement by Gimbels to build subway entrances as part of a store under construc tion at 86th Street and Lex ington Avenue.

title: Harness Trainers Distressed, With Owners Cutting Stables
description: YONKERS, July 28Ex cept for a special few, things are, going so badly for trainers of harness horses that most have had to sell a yacht, snowmobile or other bricabrac ta carry on.

title: SECRET BASE ACCORD DENIED BY MOROCCO
description: RABAT, Morocco, July 28 A government spokesman de nied today that there was any United States military installa tion in Morocco and asserted that there had been no secret agreement between Washing ton and the Moroccan Gov ernment for maintenance of United States Navy communica tions center in this country.

title: TAIWAN REDUCING SIZE OF ITS ARMY
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 28 Qualified Western sources say that the Chinese Nationalist Government, under insistent pressure from the United States, has quietly cut the size of its standing army from about 600,000 to 550,000 and prom ises to make still further cuts.

title: U.S. Controls on Investing Abroad Assailed
description: United States controls on di rect investments abroad have not brought any improvement in the American balance of payments, George Ball, former Under Secretary of State and Ambassador to the United Na tions, said here yesterday.

title: FRANULOVIC WINS AT NATIONAL NET
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 28 (AP) Three seeded players lost to unseeded players in the $50,000 national clay courts tennis tour ament today, but the defending champions and top United States seeded stars posted easy victories.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 29, 1970

title: Judge in Guerrilla Cases Is Kidnapped in Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 28 (AP)A criminal court judge who sent several con victed terrorists to jail was kidnapped today by youths who identified themselves as Tupamaros members of an urban guerrilla organization.

title: Judge Still Adamant: Na Rock Festival
description: MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., July 28The promoters of a three day rock festival scheduled for this weekend lost another round today in their legal battle to hold the event here at the Powder Ridge Ski Area. But crowds of young people continued to stream in, while others went on with prepara tions for the festival.

title: TIMES WILL OFFER DAILY FORUM PAGE
description: A daily forum providing a wide variety of views and opinions will be established on the page opposite the editorial page of The New York Times, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, pub lisher of The Times, announced yesterday.

title: STOCKS REGISTER GAIN ON BALANCE
description: Stock prices closed slightly higher on balance yesterday aft er another session of fence sit ting.

title: 3 Prisoners Sought Here After Escape From Wagon
description: Three prisoners escaped from a police patrol wagon taking them from the rear of the Criminal Courts Building at 60 Baxter Street early today to Police Headquarters, about mile away. They had arrived at court after midnight, too late to be arraigned, and were being transferred for overnight de tention.

title: London Bunk Fighting A Road Through Vault
description: LONDON, July 27 (AP)  When you are Coutts bank, and all the English kings and queens have been your cus tomers since George III, it comes as frightful news that a road is going to be run through your vault.

title: N.F.L. Labor Negotiations Are Recessed Indefinitely at Request of Owners
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (UPI)  Negotiations between the National Football League owners and players were re cessed indefinitely tonight at the owners' request. The play ers immediately charged the owners with breaking off the talks.

title: Baptists Worship in a Mountain Retreat
description: RIDGECREST, N. C.The early morning clouds hung low over the Blue Ridge Mountains, and the only sound was the soft rustling of leaves heavy with dew. Sud denly, at 7 o'clock, the silence was broken by a carillon playing Adestes Fideles.

title: GARELIK'S CAREER FROZEN IN PLASTIC
description: The memento on the bookcase in Mayor Lindsay's City Hall of fice could be a reminder that politics sometimes estrange bed fellows.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES CONSUMER AID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) A tough new consumer pro tection bill that would allow individuals to band together in class action suits was ap proved today by the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: New Adventure for Hudson's Bay Company
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 16Since 1670 the Hudson's Bay Company has burgeoned across Canada from a few scat tered trading posts into an adventurous multimilliondollar company that today even sells refrigerators to Eskimos.

title: MISS BASTANCHURY IS UPSET ON LINKS
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., July 28 (AP)Jane Bastanchury, the defending champion, was beat en today in 19 holes in the first round of the women's amateur TransMississippi golf cham pionship by Mrs. Richard Can ney of nearby Centreville, Va.

title: Smog Over Washington Approaches Alert Level
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 Temperatures in the 90's, high humidity and the vir tual lack of breeze held a blanket of polluted air over the Washington metropolitan area tonight in the closest approach that this area has yet known to a pollution alert.

title: $4.4BILLION IN AID TO SCHOOLS VOTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 The Senate approved unani mously and sent to President Nixon today a $4.4billion edu cation bill that, despite White House warnings, is $453million higher than the President's budget request.

title: Stern, 50, Reflects On 35Year Career
description: Isaac Stern took an hour in the middle of a turbulent schedule yesterday to down six mugs of coffee and talk about what is wrong with the life of a musician and what keeps him going.

title: A Hairdo And a Veil All in One
description: Will today's bright young thing take to the Veil? Vidal Sassoon seems to think so. His new coiffure involves hair cut two inches short at the crown, sleeked to the ears and falling like a curtain in front of the face. It blows and sways as the girl moves or talks, says the British hairdresser with a salon at 803 Madi son Avenue (between 67th and 68th Streets). It should also do a lot to prevent smoking  and possibly even eating.

title: Doctors at Lincoln Hospital Threaten to Resign
description: Twelve doctors at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx have asked to be relieved of their jobs in the pediatrics clinic and others have threatened mass resignations because of alleged harassment and intimidation by the Young Lords and other groups.

title: 3 INJURED TRYING TO CLOSE HYDRANTS
description: A police sergeant in the Bronx and two firemen in Brooklyn were injured yester day as a result of attempts to close illegally opened fire hy drants on city streets.

title: DR, PAINE RESIGNS AS HEAD OF NASA
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Dr. Thomas O. Paine resigned to day as head of the space agency that he had led during its greatest successthe land ing of men on the moon.

title: Rising Costs Cited
description: Three major oil companies the Gulf Oil Corporation, the Cities Service Company and the Getty Oil Companyissued midyear reports yesterday, all showing a drop in earnings. Among the reasons they cited were rising operating costs, the effects of rubber and truck ing industry strikes, increased taxes and depressed prices.

title: Rusk Undergoes Surgery
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk was operated on at Walter Reed Hospital about two weeks ago. Friends said it was prostate surgery. Mr. Rusk, who is 61 years old, is expected to go home in a few days.

title: Daley Says Rioting at Rock Concert Was Planned
description: CHICAGO, July 28Mayor Richard J. Daley charged today that the rioting that broke, out yesterday at a rock music con cert in a lakefront park had been planned.

title: Pentagon Reverses Decision To Sell Surplus Pesticide
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 The Department of Defense re versed today a decision to sell a surplus quantity of dieldrin, a controversial pesticide.

title: Executive Changes
description: Francis J. Honn has been named vice president, technical services and development, chemicals divi sion, by the Olin Corporation.

title: 7 Army Officers Face a Further Inquiry on Songmy
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Army moved today to hold further investigations of seven officers implicated in the sup pression of information about the alleged mass killing of civil ians two years ago in Songmy, South Vietnam.

title: Samara Takes Decathlon In Meet at Rider College
description: TRENTON, July 28  Fred Samara, a University of Penn sylvania sophomore represent ing the New York Athletic Club, scored 6,466 points to win the decathlon event, spon sored by Rider College and the United States Track and Field Federation at Rider.

title: Article 6  No Title
... Not Enough for Rails
description: My God, my God, now I know what hell looks like, a dazed young woman gasped as she was led from a stalled train through the Penn Central Rail road's smokefilled Park Avenue tunnel.

title: Yeshiva Gets Cancer Grants
description: A spokesman for the Amer ican Cancer Society yesterday announced the award of six re search grants totalling more than $315,000 to the Albert Ein stein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University. In announc ing the award, Dr. S. B. Gus berg, president of the American Cancer Society, said the grants would be used to fund research into the cause, development and treatment of cancer.

title: 25 VOTEMOBILES TO ROAM THE CITY
description: Twentyfive votemobiles will start roaming the city Saturday in search of unregis tered voters as part of the an nual summer registration drive, the Board of Elections said yesterday.

title: Mrs. Reid of The Tribune
description: Helen Rogers Reid, tiny, spirited, thoroughly fem inine and every inch a newspaperman, was a vital and constructive figure in the life of New York and the nation. She had the curiosity and wideranging interests which are the hallmarks of a born journalist. She had, too, the energy, persistence and acumen of a good business executive. She brought all of these attributes to the service of The New York Herald Tribune and its predecessor, The New York Tribune, for nearly four decades.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Some time in the indeterminate future a teasing question is certain to flash on one of those modern, everbusy scoreboards. It will ask: Was there ever a lefthanded second baseman in the big leagues? For most of my adult life the only one I ever had heard of was Hal Chase, ordinarily a glove magician as a first baseman. But he also saw service as a lefty second base man for the Giants and the Reds half a century ago.

title: Weyerhaeuser Reports Profit Drop
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, a major producer of pulp, paperboard and containers, had record sales but lower earnings in the second quarter and first, half of this year, it reported yesterday.

title: Miss Griswold To Bea Bride
description: The engagement of Miss Penelope Pearce Griswold to John Pollard McWilliams Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. M. Bright Alloo of New York and Southampton, L. I., stepfather and mother of the future bride. Her fi anc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McWilliams 2d of Dwight Ill., and Manasota Key, Fla. Mr. McWilliams is retired chairman of the Bank of Dwight.

title: DRUG RESISTERS STAY IN HOSPITAL
description: I came here before to Har lem Hospital's narcotics pro gram and I was told I would have to go to another place for group therapy for five days before I would be given medi cation, the you?? said.

title: ASPIRA IS SEEKING TO CUT DROPOUTS
description: The executive director of Aspira said yesterday that more than 60 per cent of Puerto Rican college students dropped out of school in the first two years.

title: Goslin's Condition Is Fair After Removal of Larynx
description: BRIDGETON, N. J., July 28 (AP)Leon (Goose) Goslin, a former major league outfielder, remained in fair condition today in Bridgeton Memorial Hospital after undergoing an operation for the removal of his larynx yesterday.

title: PEGGY LEE SINGS IN CENTRAL PARK
description: Peggy Lee was given the royal treatment Monday night at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park. August Heck scher, Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, was there to welcome the sing er. The Thad JonesMel Lewis band was recruited to accom pany her along with eight strings and three guitars, plus an additional percussionist, or ganist, tuba and French horn.

title: Daley Questions Discipline
description: CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) Mayor Daley told a news con ference today: Monday's con cert was held to provide enter tainment for young people. The hope, the belief, was that they would govern themselves. How can we achieve a condition in which young people will disci pline themselves?

title: D'Inzeo of Italy, on Bellevue, Triumphs in London Show
description: LONDON, July 28 (Reuters)  Capt. Raimond D'Inzeo of Italy soared over a 6foot9 inch wall on his Irishbred mount Bellevue to win the high jump event at the Royal Inter national horse show at Wem bley tonight.

title: Heath Names Rippon for TradeBloc Talks
description: LONDON, July 28  Prime Minister Heath today appointed Geoffrey Rippon to be Brit ain's negotiator for entry into the Common Market.

title: Dock Workers in Britain Cold to Settlement Plan
description: LONDON, July 28 (UPI) Striking dock workers today voiced rejection of a plan by a court of inquiry to settle the 13dayold walkout even before their leaders had an oppor tunity to vote on it.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Governor Rides Another Train And Promises Another Miracle
description: Commuters on the 7:25 A.M. train from Brewster, N.Y. got 10 newly refurbished cars, free coffee and a handshake from Governor Rockefeller yester day, but they said what they really wanted was for the trains to run on time.

title: Norfolk & Western Railway Cuts Quarterly Dividend
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway, whose stock has been one of the hardest hit of the rail issues in recent weeks, yesterday cut its divi dend to $1.25 a share for the September quarter from the $1.50 a share it paid in March and June.

title: MICELI RECORDS TRIPLE IN JERSEY
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 28 (AP)Briardale Farms' Ad Ma jora pushed through along the rail to win the $10,000 Ocean port Purse in the final strides at Monmouth Park today and gave Mike Miceli his third rid ing victory of the day.

title: Egypt Halts Broadcasts By Palestinian Guerrillas
description: CAIRO, July 28  The United Arab Republic suspend ed today the radio broadcasting privileges of two Palestinian commando organizations in retaliation for criticism of Cairo's acceptance of the United States initiative for an ArabIsraeli settlement.

title: Theater: London Companies Shine on Subsidies;The Idiot Flawed but Interesting Venture
description: LONDON, July 29  one from the American theater who does not feel mansized stab of envy when faced with Britain's Nation al Theater is too noble for this life. This organization, apparently opulent, selfevi dently splendid, is a model to the Englishspeaking world, but a model that un fortunately only its rival English twin, the Royal Shakespeare Company, can match. If only Joe Papp and his New York Shakespearean colleagues had their advan tages!

title: PREGNANT WOMEN ADVISED TO GAIN
description: WASHINGTON, July. 29 The current practice of re stricting a woman's weight gain during pregnancy may be contributing to the nation's high infant mortality rate, a report from the National Re search Council suggests.

title: U.S.L.T.A. TO STUDY CHARGES OF BIAS
description: The United States Lawn Tennis Association will inves tigate reports of racial and religious discrimination at var ious invitation tournaments in its Middle Atlantic section, Ala stair B. Martin, the associa tion president, said yesterday.

title: WRIGHT IS ROUTED IN 2RUN FOURTH
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 29 The Yankees swept the three game series from California tonight by defeating the An gels, 83, as Jack Aker finished up the sloppy game by pitching four scoreless innings.

title: 2 INDICTED IN RAID ON N. Y. U. CENTER
description: A history professor at New York University and a former teaching aide there were ar rested yesterday following their indictment on charges of threat ening to destroy a computer installation if the university would not give them $100,000 to provide bail for a Black Panther here.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES CONTINUE TO SLIP
description: In what was described by one broker as very, very active trading, soybean prices con tinued to slump yesterday, fol lowing their recent sharp de clines.

title: Lefkowitz Criticizes Child Shelters
description: After a sevenhour inspec tion tour yesterday of the city's three shelters for homeless children, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said he found many conditions dreadful and inadequate and added that the shelters were seriously overcrowded. He promised to continue his investigation until the situation was ameliorated.

title: Bethlehem Steel Earnings Off Sharply
DOW Chemical to Increase potassium Product Prices
description: The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterdays that it would raise prices on a variety of potassium bromide and potassium bromate products ef fective Aug. 1. The changes were traced to increasing costs of raw materials and small order handling. A sample in crease calls for potassium bro mate granular in carloads and truckloads of 200pound drums from 55 to 59 cents a pound; in less than truckload (mini mum of five drums), from 59 to 64 tents a pound and less than truckload (minimum of forty 25pound drums), from 60 to 65 cents a pound.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Illegal Actions

title: Advertising: Independent Buyers Panned
description: Over the last two years, as the independentmediabuy ing services started to be come a topic in the business with their promises of better buyingthroughbargaining, an interesting onlooker has been Jerome Bess, ad man turned broadcaster turned ad man.

title: Hogan Gets Early Starting Time in Golf Today
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 29 Ben Hogan visited New York today to attend an unveiling in his honor. Then the diminutive Texan returned to the West chester Country Club for a lastminute tuneup before the start tomorrow of the $250,000 Westchester Classic.

title: Movie Houses to Sell Book Film Is Based On
description: A prose version of the forthcoming film The Mas ter by James Drought will be sold for a dollar in the lobbies of movie houses where it will be shown.

title: PANEL OF 5 SWORN IN POLICE INQUIRY
description: The head of Mayor Lindsay's commission to investigate pos sible police corruption said yes terday that District Attorneys were inhibited in their efforts to investigate the police.

title: Earthquake Recorded In Northeastern Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Thursday, July 30, (Reuters)An earth quake early today shook the northeastern Iran province of Khurasan where more than 10,000 people died two years ago in a violent quake.

title: G.I. Killed and 13 Injured As Bolt Strikes at Fort Dix
description: FORT DIX, N. J., July 29 (UPI)One soldier was killed and 13 were injured this after noon when lightning struck a group of privates receiving basic training here.

title: MRS. FRANCIS E. CULKIN
description: OSWEGO, N. Y., July 29 (AP) Mrs. Louise Hosmer Culkin, widow of Representative Fran cis E. Culkin, died today in Oswego Hospital. She was 92 years old, and had been an in valid several years.

title: I.C.C. Chief Suspends Aide Accused by a House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)  H. Neil Garson, secretary of the Interstate Commerce Commission, who has been ac cused by a Congressional sub committee of altering check stubs, was suspended today by George M. Stafford, chairman of the commission.

title: City Goes Along As Usual But Flashlight Sales Rise
description: Powered by 175,000 kil owatts from Con Edison, the subway system rumbled through the afternoon at its normal pace yesterday.

title: Chess:
INTEREST BY CHINA IN U.S. TRADE SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Wellplaced informants re ported today that Communist China took the initiative in ask ing an Italian manufacturer to use American engines and spare parts in a shipment of trucks for China.

title: ALLEN COLT WINS BY FOUR LENGTHS
description: Right now it's not raining, said Herbert Allen, immediate ly after the running of the $28,300 Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Actually, it was coming down, but Allen's colt, the 4yearold Distinctive, had just turned in a crackling performance in winning the sixfurlong dash.

title: Hearing in Bus Crash Set
description: The National Transportation Safety Board announced yester day that it would hold a public hearing starting Sept. 22 to try to determine the cause of the July 15 crash of a chartered bus near Allentown, Pa., in which seven children were killed and 52 other persons, in cluding the bus driver, were in jured.

title: SHRIVER DENOUNCES NIXON VISTA MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, July, 29Sar gent. Shriver, who helped lead the attack on poverty in the mid1960's criticized the Nixon. Administration today for failing to support voluntary efforts to combat poverty in this country

title: ENCARNADO SETS MONMOUTH MARK
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 29 (AP)Woodcrest's Encarnado moved from well off a rapid pace, set by Predominio and favored Top Bid, to win the $16,150 Midsummer Hurdles Handicap at Monmouth. Park today. Atrevido was second and Predominio third.

title: Washington For the Record
Personal Finance: Special Stock Case
description: There has been a trend lately for companies to buy their own shares at today's cheap market prices. How ever, that doesn't necessarily make the same shares a good additional buy for current stockholders or even for ini tial investment.

title: New Yorkers Taking Smog in Stride
description: With smarting eyes and raw throats, New Yorkers went about their business yesterday under a sixdayold blanket of stagnant smog.

title: At G.I.Post Near DMZ, Nothing Seems to Go Right
description: QUANGTRI COMBAT BASE, South Vietnam, July 28We planted $17 worth of flowers out there and What have we gotone damn zinnia!

title: Successful Venezuelan Fancier Using Old Yankee KnowHow
description: One of the best known kennels in Venezuela carries the McCool's prefix, which doesn't exactly have a His panic ring to it. I was at the American Kennel Club to register my kennel, said Mrs. William Haas. I guess my English wasn't too good and the clerk couldn't under stand me. She wrote McCool's, so that's been the kennel name. The Haases emi grated to Vene zuela from Germany 30 years ago. For the last dec ade, Haas has been presi dent of the Federacion Ca nana de Venezuela.

title: Gilford in L. I. Cabaret
description: Jack Gilford temporarily re placed Joe Leon in the touring production of Cabaret, star ring Leslie Uggams, at the Westbury (L. I.) Music Theater last night. Mr. Gilford will play the role of Herr Schultz, which he created on Broadway, through Saturday evening.

title: RUSSELL GOLDING
description: BAYONNE, N. J., July 29 Russell. Golding, a Bayonne fire captain, died yesterday while vacationing at Silver Lake. He was 51 years old and lived at 130 West 57th Street here.

title: GAP OWNER KEEPS BARRY ON A HOOK
description: A sevenhour session that ended yesterday morning be tween Rick Barry's lawyers and the owner of the team he wants to leave, the Washing ton Caps, apparently wound up in defeat for the 26year old basketball star.

title: Jackson State Shootings Called Justified by County Grand Jury
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 29 The Hinds County grand jury said today that law officers had a right and were justi fied in shooting into a Jackson State College girls' dormitory during a campus disorder last May.

title: Ball to Aid Fire Company
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., July 29Proceeds from the an nual Litchfield Horse Show Ball, to be held at Walter Mack's Top O'World Farm here on Saturday night, will go to the Litchfield Volunteer Fire Company. A rock group and an orchestra will provide dance music. Tickets are $5 a person. They may be ob tained in advance from Crutch & MacDonald's, Out door Traders and Superior Foods or at the door.

title: Dr. Faith Preston Plans Nuptials
description: CHESTER, N. H., July 29 Dr. Faith Preston, founding president of White Pines Col lege here, plans to be married to Winthrop Wadleigh, senior partner of the Manchester law firm of Wadleigh Starr, Peters, Dunn & Kohls.

title: SCHILLER ASSAILS U.S. IMPORT CURBS
description: BONN, July 29Economics Minister Karl Schiller issued a stern warning today against proposed limitations by the United States on imports of textiles and shoes.

title: Britain's Smith Wins Cup At London Horse Show
description: LONDON, July 29 (Reuters) Harvey Smith of Britain won the King George V Gold Cup at the Royal International horse show tonight after a jumpoff with Jimmy Elder of Canada and David Broome of Britain.

title: Lefrak Joins City's Program To Build LowIncome Housing
description: The Lefrak Organization, one of the world's largest builders, gained approval yesterday of a plan to construct a public housing project in Brooklyn, then sell it to the city's Hous ing Authority for rental to low income families.

title: Lions Are Identified by Pattern of Whisker Holes
description: What do the spots on al giraffe's neck, the wrinkles in the snout of a black rhinoceros, the shape of an elephant's ear and the human fingerprint have in common? They are all, in varying degrees of reliability, ways of distinguishing one member of a species from an other.

title: Marines Held 10 Hours By Vietnamese Crowd
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, July 29 (AP)A crowd of angry South Vietnamese sur rounded a truck carrying six United States Marines and held it for almost 10 hours until American officials paid nearly $2,500 as compensa tion for a boy killed by the vehicle, reliable sources said today.

title: Panmunjom Guards Scuffle
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 29 (UPI)  North Korean guards and American military police men, scuffled at the truce site of Panmunjom today when the North Koreans harassed a West German television cameraman. The cameraman was taking pictures of a North Korean building when one of the se curity guards blocked his view, a United Nations Command spokesman said.

title: ISRAEL BLASTS SITES IN JORDAN AND SUEZ
description: TEL AVIV, July 29 (Reuters)  Israeli jets attacked three Arab guerrilla bases in. Jordan today and hit Egyptian military targets along the Suez Canal, military spokesman said.

title: Revere to Reduce Prices Of Copper Items by 3%
description: Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., said yesterday it would reduce truckload prices to its distributors on standardsize sheet roll and strip copper by about 3 per cent, effective Monday, because, of the large increase in importa from Eu rope at prices below domestic levels.

title: NIXON SAID TO BAR ANY TAX INCREASE IN BUDGET FOR '72
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 29President Nixon has, for the time being, ruled out any request for new taxes or tax increases when he presents his budget for the fiscal year 1972 to Congress early next year, informed sources disclosed to day.

title: MITCHELL DECRIES RUMOR ON '72 VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The Justice Department is in vestigating to determine who originated the rumor that the Nixon Administration was con templating canceling the 1972 elections and repealing the Bill of Rights.

title: Birrell Is Sentenced To TwoYear Term For Fraud in Stocks
description: Lowell M. Birrell, a lawyer and former financier who once amassed a fortune, fled the country when he was being in vestigated for stock fraud and came back to face the charges in 1964, was sentenced yester day to two years in jail.

title: Daily Power Peaks
description: Following are the peak power outputs handled by Consolidated Edison during the heat wave that began Fri day, with maximum tempera tures and temperaturehu midityindex levels. The Weather Bureau says almost everybody is uncomfortable when the index reaches 80.

title: Church in Taiwan Quits World Council Over Peking Issue
description: TANISUI, Taiwan, July 29 The Presbyterian Church in Taiwan has voted to withdraw from the World Council of Churches on the ground that the ecumenical organization has undermined the interests of Nationalist China by sup porting efforts to conciliate Peking. The action was taken this week at the church's an nual general assembly at this old port city on the northern coast.

title: VOTE OF CONFIDENCE WON BY MRS. GANDHI
description: NEW DELHI, July 29 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi survived a noconfidence mo tion in Parliament today by 241 votes to 134 after angrily rejecting accusations that she was a dictator and had made India a satellite of the Soviet Union.

title: Market Place
description: The stock of Computer Sciencesa company that. like many of its rivals, has had setbacks in the computer: software and leasing business led the list of active stocks on the Big, Board yesterday on massive, Volturie sparked by a startling. share trade.

title: Goldwater Charges LeftWing Elements Seek to Downgrade U.S. Defense
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The Senate settled, down today to a prolonged military debate, with Senator Barry Goldwater charging that leftwing politi cal elements were engaged in an organized effort to down grade and weaken the defense posture of this nation.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JULY 30, 1970

title: Two City Bills Signed
description: Mayor Lindsay signed a measure yesterday that will raise election inspectors' daily pay on election day to $35 from the current $26. He, also signed into law a measure al lowing stores until July 1 to dispose of existing stocks of American alligator skin prod ucts whose sale was made illegal in the city last Decem ber.

title: Quick Action Asked on Arrested Youth Worker
description: The city's Human, Resources Administrator ordered a local antipoverty agency yesterday to take immediate action in the case of a youth counselor who is accused of having drawn a 45caliber revolver on four policemen Monday night while allegedly'trying to crash a Cen tral Park concert.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL ON URBAN SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) The House sent to the Senate by voice vote today an $18 billion appropriation bill pro viding $541million more than President Nixon asked.

title: 5Year Atom Plan in France
description: Paris July 29 (Reuters)The French Cabinet approved a budget today of 93.5 billion francs, about 517.3billion for a fiveyear program to develop a nuclear striking force. The program will start next year.

title: Ferry Runs Aground on. Canadian Island Spilling Oil
description: PRINCE RUPERT, British Columbia, July 29 (Canadian Press)  a ferryboat, with 342 persons aboard, ran aground on West Kinahan Is land early today and oil spill ing from her ruptured tanks threatened to pollute the har bor of this north coastal British Columbia port.

title: American Electric to Sell 4 Million Common Shares
description: The American Electric Power Company announced plans yes terday to raise about $100mil lion through the sale in late September of 4 million new common shares.

title: Accord on Postal Reform Clears Way for Rate Rise
description: WASHINGTON, July 29House and Senate conferees reached tentative agreement today on a final version of the post office reorganization bill, including a section that paves the way for an increase in most postal rates by next spring.

title: Ship Passengers Delayed For Narcotics Search Here
description: Some 2,600 passengers on two liners docking at Hudson River piers yesterday were de layed about four hours while 135 United States Customs agents conducted an unan nounced, intensive search for contraband narcotics.

title: Accounting Rule Makers Adjourn Without a Vote
description: The Accounting Principles Board, the senior rulemaking body of the accounting profes sion, adjourned its meeting yes terday evening without reach ing a formal vote on its con troversial proposal to tighten the rules governing corporate merger accounting, a spokes man for the board announced.

title: Officers Named at Edie
description: Ralph D. Creasman has been elected board chairman of Lionel D. Edie & Co., the in vestment counseling concern that is a subsidiary of Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. Douglas D. Milne Jr. has been named president of Edie.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although these two books differ enor mously in accomplishment, they begin with the same premise: that policemen lie. In People vs. Blutcher, the lying has to do with shakedowns, false arrest and brutality. In The Crime of Martin Sostre, the lying has to do with political persecu tion, the planting of evidence and brutality. That some policemen take bribes is a fact known to every reader of this newspaper.

title: Prison Denies Berrigan Is Mistreated
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., July 28 The acting warden of North eastern Federal Penitentiary de nied today that the Rev. Philip Berrigan was being held in an isolated cell.

title: City Will Seek Law to Require Stores to Institute Unit Pricing
description: The city, blocked by legal action from putting unit pric ing into effect by administra tive regulation, will try to do it by legislation.

title: Installation of Phones Speeded in City
description: It was easier to get a tele phone installed in the metropol itan area in June than it has been for more than a year, but after the phone was installed it usually took longer to make a call, the Public Service Com mission reported yesterday.

title: Mrs. Meir Is Faced With a Threat to Her Coalition
description: JERUSALEM, July 29When he became immersed in the in tricacies of Middle Eastern poli tics, former Secretary of State Dean Rusk used to say, These governments are too weak to be wise.

title: barrio Museum: Hope Si, Home No
description: El Museo del Barrio, the city's first museum of Puerto Rican culture, has no build ing, no collection, no guards. Arid right now, all its belong ings are stashed in cardboard boxes, awaiting a move to another site from its present headquarters in P.S. 125 at 425 West 123d Street.

title: SUBURBS BOOMING IN NEW ENGLAND
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Suburban areas of Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Hamp shire increased dramatically in population in the nineteensix ties, while New England cities continued to decline.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
California Court Affirms New Trial for Newton
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 The California State Supreme Court today affirmed an ap peals court finding that Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther minister of defense, should have a new trial.

title: Dr. Otakar Machotka, 70, Dies; Sociologist at State University
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., July 29Dr. Otakar Machotka, pro fessor of sociology at the State University of New York at Binghamton, died of cancer today at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: FARBSTEIN TO SEEK ADVERTISINGINQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Representative Leonard Farb stein, Democrat of Manhattan, said today he would ask the Federal Communications Com mission to investigate pressures from food advertisers against news coverage of consumer issues.

title: They Don't Mind Saying It's Terrible on You
description: When 21yearold Randese Owen and her sister, Barbara, 20, decided to go into business last January with their mother's backing, they planned to sell handtailored suits from England for women and some accessories for men.

title: Paris Couture and Its ReadytoWear: Will the Tail Soon Be Wagging the Dog?
description: Readytowear is rapidly replacing perfume as the most marketable byproduct of the French couture. Even the couture houses admit that the number of women who are willing and able to spend the time and money for madetoorder clothes is diminishing. Picking up amus ing clothes in a boutique has its own status and charm, even for women who don't flinch from spending as much for an elaborate dress as they do for a simple auto mobile.

title: Songmy Suspect Cleared
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., July 29 (UPI)Sgt. Esiquiel Torres, charged in connection with the Songrny massacre, was found not guilty today of firing a rifle near a Brownsville tavern July 19. The jury deliberated 1 hour 15 minutes following day long testimony.

title: Noroton Crew Takes Lead In Junior Title Yachting
description: Noroton, Conn., July 29 The Noroton Yacht Club crew, with David Campbell as helms man, sailed into a 2point lead today in the 47th annual junior championship of Long Island Sound as the first two races in the final round robin were held off Noroton Y. C.

title: RECORDING LINKS SEALE TO MURDER
description: NEW HAVEN, July 29The jury in the trial of Lonnie Mc Lucas listened today to a tape recording in which the defend ant could be heard, softly but unmistakably, confessing to having fired a shot into Alex Rackley.

title: Perlman Lays Pennsy Woes To Outside Economic Forces
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)A former vice chairman of the Penn Central Company hinted today at dissension in the executive suite but in sisted it was mostly outside economic forces that caused the railroad to file for reor ganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Treasury's Refunding Offering Sets a Bit Lower Interest Rate
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The Treasury today presented hold ers of $5.6billion of maturing securities with a threepart of fering having interest rates little lower than in the last big refunding.

title: $2Million Suit Is Filed
description: LOS ANGELES, July 29 (UPI) A $2million suit was filed in Federal court today against Charles Manson and four of his followers Charging the wrongful death of Voityck Frykowski.

title: Stock Takes an Upward Turn For HouseHunting Trot Driver
Long Island Lighting Fined $1,000 for Polluting Sound
description: The Long Island Lighting Company was fined $1,000 yes terday for polluting Long Island Sound.

title: TECHNOLOGY TOPIC OF CULTURE PANEL
description: An international panel of scientists, writers and philos ophers will meet next month in Aspen, Colo., to ponder the impact that technology has upon culture and to recom mend ways of helping improve man's environment.

title: Bridge:
description: Some deceptive plays by the declarer are easily diag nosed by alert defenders. Others, such as the one played in the diagramed deal, have a good chance of success unless the opponents are quite expert.

title: Lack of Trend Found In Active Bond Trading
description: As the credit markets awaited the terms of the Treas ury's $6.45billion financing plan, most bond prices and in terest rates showed little change yesterday, and trading activity slackened.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Iowa Bars Rock Festival For Lack of Adequate Site
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, July 29 (AP)An Iowa Supreme Court justice issued an injunction yes terday barring a proposed rock festival at tiny Wadena in northeast Iowa.

title: BIG BOARD PRICES AND VOLUME GAIN
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange continued their push yesterday toward the 740 support level before backing off slightly in the afternoon.

title: REA Will Ask the C.A.B. To Review Rate Rejection
description: REA Express, warning of the possible deiniseot the com pany, said yesterday it would ask the Civil Aeronautics Board to reconsider its rejection of new airexpress rates calling for an overall rise of 3 per cent.

title: Western Electric Project
description: The Western Electric Com pany yesterday received two additions to Army contracts totaling $11.9million. The first, valued at $7.9million, is for production of Phase 1 of the Safeguard ballistic missile de fense system and the second is for a $4million addition for in tegrated circuit packages.

title: West Germany and Soviet Meet Again in Treaty Talks
description: MOSCOW, July 29 (AP)  ale foreign ministers of the Soviet Union and West Ger many met today for two and a half hours on treaty riegotia tions.

title: HIGHER STANDARDS URGED FOR RIVERS
description: State and local agencies from New York and New Jersey en dorsed proposals yesterday to raise the purity standards for waterways in the metropolitan area.

title: Transport News and Notes
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that current do mestic air fares would remain in effect until Oct. 15 while new lawful rates are being es tablished.

title: School Superintendent Named At Stormy Brooklyn Meeting
description: At a tumultuous public meeting last night that broke up in a general melee, the community school board of Dis trict 23 in Brooklyn, which in cludes the former Ocean HillBrownsville demonstration district, officially named Mrs. Nellie R. Duncan as district superintendent.

title: 3,000 Fish Are Found Dead In a River in Connecticut
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., July 29  For the second time in three weeks thousands of fish have been found dead in the Shetucket River, the State Board of Fisheries and Game reported today.

title: Fanny May's Auction Results
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Mortgage prices rose at this week's auction, the Federal National. Mortgage Association disclosed yesterday.

title: Pan Am Reports Talks of Merger
description: Pan American World Air ways, Inc., has held merger discussions with two or three carriers, according to its president, Najeeb E. Halaby.

title: Cassie E. Bolton Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Miss Cassie Elizabeth Bolton, who will enter. Hood College this fall, to Arthur H. Webb, a member of the class of '72 at the University of Notre Dame, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carl L. Bolton of New York and Monroe, N.Y.

title: ACQUISITION IS SET BY PHILIP MORRIS
description: Philip Morris, Inc., an nounced yesterday it had agreed to acquire all of the re maining 47 per cent of the shares outstanding of the Mil ler Brewing Company.

title: Yes, Some People Actually Go to Maxwell's Plum for the Food
description: Once, when Warner LeRoy went to buy seats for a Broadway show, the ticket seller glared at him. Aren't you the owner of Maxwell's Plum?

title: Army Will Transport Nerve Gas Across South for Disposal in Sea
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 The Army will move two train loads of small rockets filled with the lethal nerve gas GB through the South to be dumped into the Atlantic Ocean, Repre sentative Cornelius Gallagher said today.

title: MAX REISS, AIDED MENTAL PATIENTS
description: Dr. Max Reiss, who founded and directed the neuroendo crine research unit at the Wil lowbrook. (S.I.) State School for the mentally retarded, died Monday of an embolism at Wolfeboro, N.H., while on, va cation. He was 70 years old and lived at 350 Richmond Ter race, New. Brighton, S.I.

title: NET INCOME ROSE 6% AT ALLEGHENY POWER
description: The Allegheny Power System, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 10.2 per cent in firsthalf operating rev enues. They rose to $139,135, 346 from $126,245,039 in the like 1969 period. Net income rose by 6.1 per cent to $22, 210,792, or $1.07 a share, from the $20,938,013, or $1.02 a share, reported in the com parable six months ended June 30. Total kilowatt hour sales at 10.1 billion ran 11.6 per cent higher than a year ago.

title: Association Reminds Players: No Penalty for Not Reporting
description: CHICAGO, July 29The National Football League Players Association accepted tonight the challenge of the club owners and indicated in a statement its 1,200 mem bers were on strike.

title: Witness Says Manson Led 2d Murder Expedition
description: LOS ANGELES, July 29 Linda Kasabian, the chief states, witness in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson, said today that the hippie cult leader him self led a second murder ex pedition the night after his fol lowers had killed five persons.

title: In The Nation: The Great Vietnam Turnabout
description: WASHINGTON, July 29One of the most important facts of American political life, just eighteen months after the Nixon Administration took of fice, is that it is now the de fender of the war in Vietnam while the Democratic party has all but officially swung into op position to it.

title: President Signs Bill to Fight Crime in the Capital
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 29 (AP)President Nixon, re peating his assertion that Con gress has been slow to act on anticrime legislation, signed to day the controversial District of Columbia crime control bill.

title: LOAN BOARD ADDS CONFLICT RULES
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates the $167billion savings and loan industry, proposed yester day a general tightening of its rules covering conflicts of in terest at the 4,400 associations under its supervision.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX ROSE DURING JULY
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The heartening improvement in the wholesale price index in re cent months was reversed in July as farm products and processed foods began to go up again, the Labor Department re ported today.

title: Army Adds to Raytheon Job
description: The Raytheon Corporation yesterday received an $8.7mil lion addition to an Army con tract for engineering develop ment of the SamD missile system.

title: LINCOLN DOCTORS TO AID MILITANTS
description: Doctors at Lincoln Hospital yesterday sidestepped the ques tion of possible mass resigna tions because of alleged intimi dation and harassment by mili tants who moved into the, hos pital July 14. They voted in stead to work with members of the militant group to resolve the problems at Lincoln Hos pital.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CANADIAN FOOTBALL

title: MEANY SEEKS RISE TO $2 IN PAY FLOOR
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) George Meany president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indus trial Organizations, urged Con gress today to increase the minimum wage to $2 an hour from the present $1.60.

title: GOLDBERG FINDS FUNDS RUN SHORT
description: Confronted with an acute shortage of campaign funds, Arthur J. Goldberg has can celed virtually all his public appearances next week to de vote almost full time to raising money for his Democratic Liberal gubernatorial drive.

title: 26 Grape Growers Sign Union Accord; Boycott Nears End
description: DELANO, Calif., July 29 Farm workers and table grape growers signed an agreement in this dusty rural town today that both sides said would bring a new day to American agriculture.

title: 200 Jews Said to Remain In Egypt After Freeing of 80
description: PARIS, July 29 (AP)Jewish community leaders here said to day that 200 Jews remained in the United Arab Republic after the recent release from prison and transfer to France of 80 Jews.

title: Earnings Reports Continue to Drop At Oil Companies
description: The oil industry continued yesterday to churn out earn ings news, but none of it was good.

title: Writer in Soviet Defends Suicide of Story's Hero, 7
description: MOSCOW, July 29Chingiz Aitmatov, a popular writer, has aroused a literary controversy by having his latest story end with the suicide of its hero, a 7yearold boy.

title: Chinese to Visit France in '71
description: PARIS, July 29 (AP)Com munist China will send an of ficial delegation to France for a state visit next year, a French Government spokesman an nounced today. The announce ment follows the trip this month to Peking of Planning Minister Andre Bettencourt, who met there with Premier Chou Enlai and Chairman Mao Tsetung.

title: Strike Shuts Madrid Subway
description: MADRID, July 29  Mad rid's subway system, which normally has 1.5 million pas sengers a day, half of the city's population, was shut down to day by a strike of its 3,800 workers.

title: RAIL MEDIATOR SEES ROLE NEAR COLLAPSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  Frederick R. Livingston, the chairman of President Nixon's emergency board on the road firemen's dispute, said to day that his extended effort to mediate a settlement was on the verge of collapse.

title: Roundup: Melton Ceases His Exercise in Futility
description: Bill Melton has gone to bat five consecutive times with out striking out.

title: Margaret R. Feild to Be Bride Of W. T. Kresge Jr. on Sept. 26
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 29Miss Margaret Ruth erfoord Feild, who is study ing for a master's degree in education at the University of Virginia, will be married to William Theodore Kresge Jr. of New York, a graduate of the University of Virginia School of Law.

title: In Memoriam
description: BAUMANMorris. In sacred memory of our beloved father & grandfather who left us on July 30, 1962. HIS CHILDREN & GRANDCHILDREN

title: Suit Calls on S.E.C. To Release Report
description: Morris A. Schapiro, the na tion's leading dealer in bank securities and long a sharp critic of the New York Stock Exchange, went to court yes terday to force the Securities and Exchange Commission to divulge the contents of a long secret S.E.C. staff report on trading by Big Board members off the floor of the exchange.

title: Nixon Visit to Mexico Is Now Set for Aug. 20
description: SAN CLEMENTE Calif., July 29President Nixon will confer with President Gus tavo Diaz Ordaz of Mexico on Aug. 20 and 21, the White House announced today.

title: ALABAMA JOB BIAS BANNED BY COURT
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 29Seven agencies of the State of Alabama have been ordered by a Federal Court to stop dis criminating against Negroes in their hiring practices.

title: PRICES ARE HIGHER IN LONDON STOCKS
Commando Aide Flies to Cairo To Discuss New Nasser Moves
description: CAIRO, July 29A leading official of the Palestinian com mando movement flew here to day for urgent consultations on President Gamal Abdel Nasser's tentative moves toward a set tlement with Israel and the suspension yesterday by the Cairo radio of broadcasts by the Palestinians.

title: Daytop Village Gets Grant
description: ALBANY, July 29  The State Narcotics Addiction Con trol Commission has approved a $1.5million grant to Daytop Village in New York City to finance its treatment program for addicts. Governor Rocke feller, who made the announce ment today, said, the latest grant raised to $3.9Jmillion the total amount of funds provided to Daytop Village by the com mission since 1968.

title: NIXON POPULARITY INCREASES IN POLL
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 29 Public confidence in President Nixon is at its highest level in five months, the Gallup Poll re ported today.

title: Plan to Revamp Pentagon Meets Silence at Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, July 29A Presidential commission's many faceted plan for a major over haul of the Pentagon, an nounced yesterday, was greet ed warily and with almost stony silence on Capitol Hill today.

title: BILL WOULD SET UP DEVELOPMENT BANK
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 The chairmen of the House and Senate Banking Committees introduced legislation today to establish a National Develop ment Bank that could provide financing for both business and state and local governments.

title: Fear of Intervention by Chilean Army Becoming a Strong Factor in Election
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24 The threat of military interven tion in Chilean politics, real or imaginary, has become a factor that could affect the decision on the next President.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW SLIGHT GAIN
description: In rising volume, the stocks on the American Stock Ex change moved up yesterday by 0.04 to 20.45, as measured by the exchange's index. Volume rose to 2,827,190 from 2,637, 910 on Tuesday. Advances out numbered declines, 424 to 344.

title: Ramapo Group Sues to, Block LowIncome Housing Project
description: More than 300 residents or Ramapo filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday in an at tempt to block the construction of a lowincome housing proj ect mainly for the elderly in their Rockland County town.

title: Model of Injustice
description: The omnibus crime control bill for the District of Columbia signed by President Nixon yesterday is the first piece of law and order legislation to be enacted on behalf of the Administration. Although it has been heralded as a model code, several of its major features are so patently in violation of long accepted legal procedures that the result will be not a shortcut end to crime in the capital but a steady series of chal lenges in the courts.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
COLLEAGUES URGE A M'CARTHY RACE
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Most of the Democratic Repre sentatives from New York have sought Arthur J. Goldberg's help in getting Representative Richard Max McCarthy back in the race for his House seat in Erie County.

title: Monmouth Jockeys
Tyson Steps Down at U.S. Steel
