description: After 40 years in the money market, the last 14 of them as the top financial officer of the nation's largest steel company, Robert C. Tyson stepped down yesterday. As he made the move, he offered several acute observations on steel, money and men.

title: Cubs Acquire Pepitone on Waivers
description: CHICAGO, July 29 (UPI) The Chicago Cubs acquired Joe Pepitone on waivers to day from the Houston As tros for $20,000.

title: Cunard Official Named Director of Subsidiary
description: The appointment of C. N. (Nick) Anderson, the presi dent of the Cunard Line of North America, as managing director of H. E. Moss & Co., Ltd., of London was an nounced yesterday.

title: RED CROSS LIMITED IN VISIT TO CON SON
description: GENEVA, July 29  The In ternational Committee of the Red Cross said today that its representatives who visited the Con Son prison in South Viet nam failed to learn of the ex istence of the socalled tiger cages.

title: POLICEMAN CLEARED IN FATAL SHOOTING
description: HARTFORD, July 29 (UPI) A Superior Court jury returned a verdict of not guilty today in the trial of former city po liceman, Anthony Lombardi, accused of manslaughter in the shooting of a 19yearold youth he was chasing after an al leged traffic violation.

title: BRITISH DOCKERS CALL OFF STRIKE
description: LONDON, July 29Leaders of Britain's striking dock work ers called off their nationwide strike today, after tying up 40 ports for two weeks.

title: CITY PUT ON ALERT AS AIR POLLUTION HITS CRISIS LEVEL
description: Mayor Lindsay, declaring that air pollution had reached crisis levels here, put the city on an alert yesterday that could ulti mately mean steps as drastic as banning private automobiles from congested parts of the city.

title: Bank of America Division
description: The Bank of American an nounced yesterday the forma tion of a multinational division to serve companies doing busi ness in many parts of the world. Ralph F. Young, formerly the bank's regional vice president in London, will head the new division.

title: WORTY WILL ADD A NEWS PROGRAM
description: WORTV, Channel 9, will have a daily, halfhour, prime time newscast beginning this fall. The independent station; owned by R.K.O. General, has been the city's only outlet with out an evening news program.

title: Bus Drivers Object to Policing a Smoking Ban
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 AP)  Bus drivers asked today how they could enforce a ban on smoking in intercity, buses if the Government imposed it. They Fare drivers, not police men, they said.

title: Protest Is Upheld on Yacht Club Cruise
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., July 29  George Lewis's Breeze lost a 16th place in Class Three to day, when a protest filed by Arnold C. Gay's Babe, which placed 12th, was sustained at a hearing aboard the race com mittee yacht, Incredible.

title: Handwriting in the Sky
description: Through the polluted haze that for days has hung over East Coast cities from New York to Atlanta, noth ing is clear but a timely warning. Urban areas are getting perilously close to the point where they may have to choose between the internal combustion engine and breathable air. That Tokyo should be undergoing the same harrowing ordeal in the same week demon strates that the problem is worldwide and not even primarily an American phenomenon.

title: Controller of Power
description: Although he would shudder at the description of himself as a power broker, that is just what Tom Griffin is.

title: MRS. COOPERSTEIN ADDS TO GOLF LEAD
description: RUMSON, N. J., July 29  Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks staged a strong fin ish today and increased her lead to 13 strokes after two rounds of the Women's Metro politan Golf Association 54hole Jersey Shore medal play cham pionship.

title: Miss Devlin's Aide Accused In Commons Gas Attack
description: LONDON, July 29 (AP) Bowes Egan, a law lecturer and adviser to Bernadette Devlin, was charged in court today with having plotted a tear gas attack on the House of Com mons last week.

title: Louisiana Aide Arraigned
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 29 (AP) 7 Louisiana Attorney General Jack P. F. Gremillion passed out candy in his cam paign for reelection minutes after his arraignment on five counts of perjury today. Mr. Gremillion pleaded not guilty to all five counts in Federal District Court here. The per jury indictments were brought for statements he made during testimony on his connection with Louisiana Loan and Thrift Corporation in a 1969 investi gation.

title: Girls Nation Elects Leader
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) Rebecca Lynn Wrede of Monticello, Ind., has been elect ed president of the Girls Nation convention, meeting here this week.

title: Indian Flood Toll Put at 78
description: NEW DELHI, July 29 (UPI) Official reports today listed 78 persons who have died In flooding of major rivers in three states of northern and eastern India caused by mon soon rains. The dead included 54 in northern Uttar Pradesh, 18 in Assam state and 6 in Bihar state.

title: POPE IS PREPARING MESSAGE ON DRUGS
description: ROME, July 29  Pope Paul VI is planning to issue a spe cial message to youth on the dangers of drug abuse, a sub ject on which President Nix on's special envoy to the Vati can, Henry Cabot Lodge, held long and detailed talks during his first official visit to Rome.

title: Acceptance by Egypt and Jordan Peril Arabs' Unity
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29 For the three years since the ArabIsraeli war of 1967 the Arab world has been able to achieve only a minimum of unity. Now, as a result of the acceptance by the United Arab Republic and Jordan of the United States proposal for a settlement of the Middle East conflict, even this threatens to col lapse.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Opera

title: ALBERT O. MARTIN
description: CRAWFORD, N. J., July 29 Albert O. Martin, a safety en gineer at the Metuchen plant of the Ford Motor Company for 20 years, died yesterday at the Rahway Memorial Hospital, Rahway, after a brief illness. He was 65 years old and lived at 32 Ramapo Road. He retired in 1967.

title: DONALD CLEMENT, ACTOR, DIES AT 29
description: Donald Clement, a 29year old actor who had been appear ing as Cowboy in The Boys in the Band off Broadway died of electrocution Tuesday in an accident in his apartment at 19 East 74th Street.

title: Pasarell and Hewitt Upset in National Clay Court Tennis
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 29 (UPI)Cliff Richey, the top seeded American, fought off a challenge by Ray Ruffels of Australia today to advance in to men's singles of the $50,000 national clay court tennis tour nament.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Nantucket Island's second annual billfish (in this case, swordfish and blue and white marlin) tournament will be held Aug, 10 to 14, accord ing to the sponsoring organi zation, the Nantucket An gler's Club.

title: Mary Prauenheim Is Affianced
description: BUFFALO, July 29Miss Mary Ann Frauenheim and Dr. Mark Edward McGovern will be married here Sept. 19 in St. Benedict's Roman Cath olic Church.

title: Golf Facts and Figures
description: ScheduleToday through Sunday. 18 holes daily. Sudden death follows end of Sunday play in event of tie for first place. Start ing field of 158. Low 70 scorers and ties and those within 10 strokes of leader after second round continue for third and fourth rounds. Purse $250,000. First prize, $50,000. CourseWest Course of Westches ter Country Club, Harrison, N. Y. Par 72, 6,700 yards.

title: Buffalo Six Opens Oct. 15
description: BUFFALO, N.Y., July 29 (AP) The new Buffalo Sabres said today they would play, their first National Hockey League game Oct. 15 against the Mon treal Canadiens in Memorial Auditorium. The general man agercoach, George (Punch) Imlach, said 39 home games would be played19 on Sun days, 12 on Thursdays, six on Fridays and two on Tuesdays.

title: M'MAHON EXCELS IN RELIEF STINT
description: Bobby Bonds hit two home runs  two innings and two hours apart  at Shea Stadium yesterday as the San Francisco Giants defeated the New York Mets on a muddy track, 42.

title: GORDON M'INTIRE, 59, ONCE F.A.O. OFFICER
description: A memorial service for Gor don McIntire, an international distributor of encydlopedias, art books and visual aids, was held yesterday in Rome, where he lived for 18 years. He died of a heart attack earlier this week in New Delhi while, on vacation. He was 59 years old.

title: City Parking Bill Signed
description: Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday a bill suspend ing alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations on holi days. The rules are now sus pended for each holiday by ad ministrative action. The holi days involved are Christmas, Yom Kippur, Rosh haShanah, Good Friday, the first two and last two days of Succoth, Shabuoth, the first two and last two days of Passover and all state and national holidays.

title: Music: Earl Wild Heard
description: Earl Wild, dressed as if for a stroll along a resort boardwalk, took a brisk turn through Rachmaninoff's Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini on Tuesday night in Central Park. The prema turely whitehaired pianist, appearing as soloist with the New York Philharmonic un der the direction of Sixten Ehrling, gave an efficient, highly fluent performance whose broad lines and sharp contrasts suited the outdoor, amplified setting.

title: Nixons' Daughter Home
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)Mrs. David Eisenhower was released from Georgetown University Hospital today fol lowing tests to determine the cause of a chronic urinary infection. Mrs. Eisenhower, the 22yearold, daughter of President Nixon; entered the hospital Monday.

title: Storms Cut Power Needs But Also Knock Out Lines
description: Showers on another 90degree day came to the aid of New York City's beleaguered electric power supply yester day as hot and humid weather elsewhere reduced supplies of power from out of town.

title: Vietnam Peace Plan
description: President Nixon's news conference today, President Thieu's radiotelevision address tomorrow and Ambas sador Bruce's projected arrival in Paris Monday could open a new phase in the efforts to negotiate a political settlement of the Vietnam war. Mr. Thieu will clarify his proposals on a ceasefire in Vietnam, which pre sumably could be laid on the table in Paris next Thursday.

title: TV and Radio to Carry News Parley Tonight
description: The following television stations will carry President Nixon's news conference live from the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles tonight at 11 o'clock, Eastern daylight time: WCBSTV (Channel 2). WNBCTV (Channel 4), WNEWTV (Channel 5), WABCTV (Channel 7), WPIXTV Channel 11), WNDTTV (Channel 13) and WNYCTV (Channel 31).

title: Marine Midland Troy Bank Plans Catskill Acquisition
description: An agreement in principle to merge the Catskill National Bank and Trust Company, Cats kill, N. Y., with assets of $7 million, into the Marine Midland National Bank of Troy, N. Y., with assets of $141million, has been announced by both insti tutions.

title: Four Women at J.W.T. Named Vice Presidents
description: Every day may not be ladies' day at J. Walter Thompson, but yesterday must have been. Four of the gals were raised to the pur ple of the vice presidency, bringing the total number of female officers in the world's largest agency to 12.

title: John Wayne Rides Again in 'Chisum'
description: As "Chisum" opens, there sits John Wayne on his horse, both of them frozen in profile by a lonesome pine. "Chisum, Chisum," thunder a chorus and orchestra, "he'll still keep goin' on." And you'd better believe it, especially with the same business repeated at the fadeout. In between, there are few surprises.In this typical range-war exercise for Big John he plays his tough, laconic self of yore, a settled-down rancher who watches a New Mexico community slide under the heel of the villainous Forrest Tucker. It takes a lot to rouse Wayne, but the climax is a deafening tribute to justice triumphant, with a town leveled by a cattle stampede through a blazing gun were in the streets. You'll never be able to tote up the corpses.Essentially, this is a conventional Western, not the kind that such directors as John Ford and Henry Hathaway have pulled up taut with sharp character components. As such, it has a couple of things in its favor, such as the excellent, panoramic color photography by William H. Clothier. A large, sprawling cast, trotting at the heels of Wayne, performs vigorously. And under the direction of Andrew V. McLaglen, it looks as Western as all get-out. It may ramble but it does move.Tucker, for instance, comes across with snap and bite. Patric Knowles conveys the same, as an altruistic Englishman on the prairie. Young Geoffrey Deuel cuts a personable swath as Billy the kid, and several other hardies such as Ben Johnson, Glenn Corbett and Richard Jaeckel pitch in accordingly, with Pamela McMyler and Lynda Day as fetching ornaments.Forget substance. Settle for color and commotion and you won't feel cheated.

title: Preliminary Census Data for 42 States
2 U.S. Agencies to Join in Fight on Drug Traffic
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The two Federal agencies re sponsible for stamping out il legal narcotics trafficking agreed today to stop fighting each other and to concentrate on their main enemy at home and abroad.

title: MOONQUAKES TIED TO EARTH GRAVITY
description: Each month, when the moon orbits closest to earth, its scarred and pitted crust bulges 20 to 30 inches, cracks and shifts and quakes for nearly an hour.

title: James Charney, Diane Gillman Plan to Marry
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 29Dr. and Mrs. Louis Gill man have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Joy Gillman, to James Charney. Mr. Charney, son of Dr. and Mrs. I. Rich ard Schwartz of Hewlett Harbor, L. I., changed his sur name. The couple will be mar ried next month.

title: BRITISH RECOGNIZE REPUBLIC OF YEMEN
description: LONDON, July 29  Britain formally recognized the repub lican Government of Yemen to day.

title: Sir John Barbirolli, Conductor, Dead
description: LONDON, July 29Sir John Barbirolli, the internationally, renowned conductor, died in, London Way. He was 70 years Old.

title: Cluttering Up the Ballot
description: Dissident groups must have the opportunity to take their case directly to the people through independent political candidates, but the use of socalled inde pendent party designations by major party candidates who are already on the ballot adds nothing to the electorate's range of choice. On the contrary, this prac tice subverts the intent of the law that permits inde pendent candidacies. It is a form of political litter more obnoxious than the broadside use of leaflets, stickers and posters. It confuses the voter.

title: United Utilities
description: United Utilities, Inc., reported yesterday a decline of 8 per cent in firsthalf earnings Paul H. Henson, president, attributed the drop to higher costs of in terest, labor and materials.

title: Peking to Release Briton
description: LONDON, July 29 (AP)  Communist China advised the British Foreign Office today that it would release George Watt, a Briton seized on spy ing charges in September 1967, within a matter of days. His release would come nearly eight months before the com pletion of his threeyear sen tence. Mr. Watt was a Vickers Zimmer engineer on contract work near Lanchow.

title: 8 Top Films in Esquire Contest Will Be Presented at Colleges
description: Preparations are under way for the distribution of eight prizewinning, studentmade short films chosen from more than 150 international entries in Esquire magazine's first College Film Festival.

title: 2 U.S. ACES UPSET IN 5,000 METERS
description: STOCKHOLM, July 29 (AP) Dane Korica of Yugoslavia scored a surprise victory over Frank Shorter and Ken Moore of the United States in the 5,000meter run tonight.

title: Saigon Gets Landing Craft
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, July 29 (AP)The United States Navy: turned over five landing craft and a small drydock to the South Vietnamese Navy to day at a ceremony in Danang. The Navy announced that 2,000 of its men had left. Vietnam during July under President Nixon's troopwithdrawal pro gram. By last Thursday Ameri can Navy strength in Vietnam totaled 24,300 men, but this does not include ships of the Seventh Fleet operating off the coast.

title: HEAD OF TREASURY BARS BOOK SEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Secretary of the Treasury, David M. Kennedy said today that his department strongly opposed any general searches of library records to find out who had read specific books. But he said it would allow its agents to investigate what books a specific suspect had checked out.

title: Swiss Arrest a Japanese In WatchSecrets Theft
description: GENEVA, July 29A Jap anese who was arrested two weeks ago on suspicion of having stolen manufactur ing secrets of three promi nent Swiss watch companies has been released on bond, a spokesman for the Justice and Police Ministry said in Berne today.

title: OREGON TO FILE SUIT ON 18YEAROLD VOTE
description: SALEM, Ore., July 29 Gov. Tom McCall announced today that Oregon would file suit in the Supreme Court in a few days opposing the lower ing of the voting age to 18.

title: Avoid Another '68, Democrats Told
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)  The Democratic na tional chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, told party reformers today that the way to win the youth vote was to strive for peace, focus on pressing do mestic issues and avoid an other convention like the one in 1968.

title: G.M. WARY ON SALE OF CLEANAIR KITS
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 29 (AP)  The General Motors Corpo ration says that its $50,000 test sale of pollution control kits for pre1968 automobiles here was so poor that it will take a long look before attempting to mar ket the kits nationally.

The company's earnings for the first six months of this year were reported Tuesday as hav ing dropped to $1.02 a share, compared with $1.24 a share in the comparable period last year.

Such dis putes, he said, are seriously delaying Consolidated Edison's ability to bring new electric power into New York City.

Miss Elizabeth Frazier Webb, to John Williams Sanford 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Jr. of Cooperstown, N. Y., and Provincetown, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

title: Instant Black Studies Program
description: John Henry Lloyd, a shortstop, was known in Cuba as El Cuchara, The Shovel, because he scooped up chunks of infield along with ground balls. In the United States, Lloyd was sometimes referred to as The Black Wagner, once prompting Honus Wagner to comment, It is a privi lege to have been compared with him. But the two were never able to compete as major league equals because baseball's conscientious exclusion of blacks from 1898 1996. Said Lloyd in 1949, I do not consider that I was born at the wrong time. I felt it was the right time, fort had a chance to prove the ability of our race in this sport, and because many of us did our very best to uphold the tradi tions of the game and of the world of sport, we have given the Negro a greater opportunity now to be accepted into the major leagues with other Ameri cans.

title: Books of The Times
description: Mad King George is one of the butts of history, so little admired or liked that even his lunacy hasn't attracted much sympathy. Now two London psychiatrists, mother and son, have written an unex pectedly moving account of the ordeal of England's and psychiatry's most famous patient and the unappreciated influence of his case on the history of psychi atry in its stum bling infant stages. The authors have made a controver sial diagnosis, widely publicized in 1966, of the physical ailment that deranged the King's mind. Their book's interest doesn't depend on this but on their ability to entangle the reader in a nightmare: what if you came down With mysterious, undiagnosable ab dominal pains, fever and sleeplessness, and you felt your mind clouding over? It is a touching fact, they write, that the King realized earlier than those around him that he was losing control over his body and mind. A witness recorded that the King talked for 19 hours without scarce any inter mission, and when his helpless physician told him that he ought not to do so, he said I know that as well as you, it is my complaint; cure me of that, and I shall be well.

description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 30 Peter Zinman's Wee Ken and Michele McEvoy's Amabette won the two junior working hunter championships by forg ing to the front in the final classes today at the Orange County horse show.

title: Dining at 2 New Restaurants
description: Alda's, 332 East 86th Street, 2886335. If there is a tremendous sameness about 99 per cent of all the Italian menus in Manhattan, the fault lies to a large part with the public. Americans, by and large, comfort themselves with spaghetti with meat sauce, meat balls or tomato sauce, veal Parmigiana, chicken cacciatore and noth ing more adventurous gener ally than fettucini all'Alfredo.

The yachts that had established themselves as favorites by suc cesses in two earlier events re mained at or near the ton.

description: The trustee of the Central Railroad of New Jersey told the Interstate Commerce Commis sion yesterday that the carrier now faced the possibility that it will have to cease operations in December, possibly before that date, unless it received financial assistance.

title: Spies in the Library
description: The Internal Revenue Service has discontinued a practice so dubious that it could have been initiated only through the gravest lapse of administrative judgment. For some weeks, it seems, I.R.S. agents in severa cities have been requesting access to the circulation records of public libraries in order to get the names of those who borrowed books on explosive devices. An official of the Service at first dismissed the practice as routinejust a continual building of information . . . In line with the proliferation of bombings across the country.

description: In a Bronx office, a secre tary and her employer dis cussed the difference between smart and shrewd.

title: Accountant Gets Jail Term
description: Norman H. Egenberg, an ac countant for top opera stars and other celebrities, was sen tenced yesterday to five years in jail and fined $16,200 for miling fraudulant income tax returns. Egenberg, 45 years old, was found guilty June 25 on 25 counts involving income tax violations. He would have re ceived 55 years and a $240,000 fine. He had been acquitted on 27 bribery counts.

title: Abercrombie & Fitch Names President
description: William E. Humphreys, ex ecutive vice president of Lord & Taylor, has been named presi dent and chief executive officer of the Abercrombie & Fitch Company effective Sept. 1. He succeeds Earle K. Angstadt Jr., who has resigned as chairman, president and chief executive officer of the sporting goods chain based in Manhattan.

title: $6Million in Bonds Are Missing On Flight From New York Bank
description: CHICAGO, July 30Negotia ble bonds worth $6,050,000 dis appeared last March, presuma bly while being transported from New York City to Chicago, and no trace of them has been found.

title: SIDEROWF GAINS IN AMATEUR GOLF
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 30Dick Siderowf, a 33 yearold stockbroker from Westport, Conn., took aim to ward a third successive Metro politan Golf Association Ama teur championship today de spite a bad start and a heavy rainstorm that soaked the Upt. per Montclair Country Club course.

title: RISE IS MODERATE IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: Monetary expansion proc eeded at a moderate pace the last few weeks, banking data published yesterday showed.

title: Unassuming Chancellor
description: When Dr. Ernest Leroy Boyer's family first learned he was being considered for the job of chancellor of the State University of New York, some of his four children had initial doubts about the position.

title: Metro Gives Free Rides In Move to Save Money
description: PARIS, July 30 (AP)The Mtro has started giving free rides to save money.

title: Pollution Alert Continues With Relaxation of Curbs
description: The city continued yester day the alert it called to deal with the air pollution crisis but, as levels of contamination dropped, it relaxed some re strictions on the use of in cinerators.

title: OLIVER ARRESTED IN OCEAN HILL
description: The Rev. C. Herbert Oliver, chairman of the defunct gov erning board of the Ocean Hill Brownsville demonstration school district, and 11 other persons were arrested last night and charged with trespassing in the board's administrative of fices.

title: BRITON HELD 3 YEARS IS FREE PEKING SAYS
description: HONG KONG, July 30Com munist China today announced the release of George Watt, a 41yearold British engineer ac cused of spying and detained in Lanchow since September, 1967. A report by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, said he would be deported.

title: Article 2  No Title
Szell, the Greatest Since Toscanini, Achieved Glamour With No Tricks
description: George Szell on the podium exuded confidence, power and mastery. No professional musician ever disputed his sheer mastery of the craft of conducting. There were those who called him arrogant, and there were others, who ac cused his interpretations of being somewhat pedantic. But none ever had anything but ad miration for his knowledge, his ear, his incisive and clear beat, his ability to balance the vari ous choirs of the orchestra into a homogeneous, breath ing texture.

title: THREE BODIES FOUND IN A CAR IN QUEENS
description: The bodies of three young men were found in the charred wreckage of an automobile early yesterday morning in South Ozone Park, Queens. Each had been shot in the head.

title: Habib, Leaving Post in Paris, Bids Hanoi Avoid Propaganda
description: PARIS, July 30  Philip C. Habib ended his tenure as the ranking American at the Viet nam peace talks by telling the enemy today the negotiations can be successful if not mis used for propaganda.

title: SEAWANHAKA TAKES 5RACE SAIL SERIES
description: NOROTON, Conn., July 30 The Seawanhaka  Corinthian Yacht Club crew from Oyster Bay, L. I., captained by Terry Neff, won the 47th annual junior sailing championship of Lone Island Sound today.

title: Kennedy and Mitchell Debate on Crime Rate
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)  Attorney General John N. Mitchell and Senator Edward M. Kennedy dis agreed politely today over whether the crime rate was rising or declining under the Nixon Administration.

title: Air New Zealand Is Planning Order. For 3 DC10 Jets
description: WELLINGTON, New Zea land, July 30New Zealand's international airline, Air New Zealand, Ltd., intends to buy at least three DC10 long range jets for delivery in 1973 and 1974.

title: Madrid Subways Resume Operation as Strike Ends
description: MADRID, July 30The sub ways resumed operation here this morning after the system's 3,800 workers returned to their jobs rather than face being drafted into the army.

title: Draft Office Bombed
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 30, (UPI)Homemade pipe bombs exploded early today in the Se lective Service offices in five towns in Puerto Rico.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The controversial Alaska oil pipeline project is undergoing a management shakeup in an effort to end a series of legal entanglements and bureaucratic delays that have set it back in definitely.

title: $911,000 Raised in 3 Years For Westchester Hospitals
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 30 The Westchester Golf Classic has raised $911,000 in three years for the benefit of six hos pitals in Westchester County.

title: Police Consider Weapons Search
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 30 (AP)The police said today, they were con sidering obtaining search warrants for strongholds where they believe persons who fired at policemen last night might have hidden weapons.

title: CALCUTTA AIDE LOSES HIS LICENSE
description: The boxoffice treasurer at Oh Calcutta!, now playing at the Eden Theater, 187 Second Avenue, was ordered suspended for 11 months yesterday fol lowing charges of having ex acted iceor payments over the listed pricefor tickets to the Off Broadway hit.

title: Advertising: A.N.A. Forms Unit to Study AgencyClient Problems
description: The Association of Na tional Advertisers, whose member companies place an estimated three  quarters of the country's national adver tising, has disclosed the for mation of a new committee whose deliberations could have farreaching effects on the agency side of the busi ness.

title: Dr. Boyer Is Named To Direct State U.
description: Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, a 42 yearold educational adminis trator and expert on speech and hearing disorders, was ap pointed yesterday as the new chancellor of the State Univer sity of New York, the largest such system in the country.

title: Theater: 3 Philip Roth Stories Beyond the Ethnic
description: EAST HAMPTON L. I., July 30The Three Philip Roth Stories, which the Yale Repertory Company has chosen to dramatize as the current chapter in its sum mer season of Story Theater at the John Drew Theater, are firmly entrenched in their Jewish milieu. To remind us that the plays are about Jews in America, the stage is set with one backdrop: a huge American flag with a Star of David in the center.

title: SUGAR PRICES OFF IN HEAVY TRADING
description: World sugar prices slumped yesterday in very heavy vol ume after a report issued by F. O. Licht, the European sta tistical service. The report, con strued by traders as bearish, sharply increased estimates of world sugar supplies above a previous forecast made in April.

title: WILFRID K. HUGHES OF AUSTRALIA DIES
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, July 30 (AP)  Sir Wilfrid Kent Hughes, one of Australia's most colorful members of Parliament and a leading sports figure, died today at his home. He was 75 years old.

title: 3.55 Billion People in World
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. July 30 (AP)The world's popula tion increased by 69 million in one year to a total of 3,552 bil lion in mid1969, the United Nations said today in the quarterly Population and Vital Statistics.

title: What's in a Name? Ask a Miller
description: The Miller Brewing Company has come up with a nice and fairly inexpensive directmail advertising campaign. And they have few fears that it will be copied by a competitor.

title: Miss Evert in Tennis Final
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 30 (AP)Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., topseeded, and Laurie Tenney of Los An geles meet Saturday in the final of the United States Lawn Ten nis Association's national girls' 16andunder tennis champion ship.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Commerce Department today estimated last week's depart ment store sales at $651mil lion, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $620million. Last week's retail store sales totaled about $6,916,000,000, up 7 per cent from $6,460,000,000.

title: Wednesday Fights
description: Shizuoka, JapanCassius Naito, 158 pounds, Japan, outpointed Turtle Okabe, 155, Japan, 10 rounds.

title: Quake in Iran Kills at Least 100
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 30 (AP)More than 100 bodies have been pulled from the ruins after scores of villages in northeast Iran were struck early today by a powerful earthquake.

title: U.S. PLANS TO CURB CEREAL NUTRIENTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) In the midst of a controversy over the nutritional value of breakfast cereals, the Govern ment is moving, ahead with a proposed regulation that would remove from the market the cereals a nutrition crusader called the best available.

title: Sesame Street Called Hit With Young and Poor
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  A study conducted in several com munities across the country in dicates that 90 per cent of the three to fiveyearolds in fam ilies with annual incomes of $5000 or less watch the educa tional television program Ses ame Street, according to Joan Ganz Cooney, president of the Children's Television Workshop.

title: Article 5  No Title
NIXON REASSURES ISRAELIS U.S. PLAN POSES NO DANGER
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  President Nixon tonight sought to assure Israel that she can accept the United States pro posal for a limited ceasefire in the Middle East without fear that by entering negotia tions her position may be com promised or jeopardized in that period..

title: Arts Council Authorizes $50,000 More to Papp
description: Governor. Rockefeller's of fice said yesterday that the New York State Council on the Arts had authorized an additional $50,000 to the New York Shakespeare Fes tvial. The sum is in addition to the $100,000 committed to the festival by the Coun cil last month.

title: TROOPS KILL MAN IN BELFAST CLASH
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Friday, July 31 (Reuters) A civilian was shot to death dur ing street battles between Ro man Catholic rioters and British troops early today.

title: Susan Shapiro Becomes Bride
description: MUTTONTOWN, L.I., July 30Miss Susan Robin Shapi ro and Steven Douglas Lev koff were married tonight at the Muttontown Country Club by Rabbi Jerome David son, who was assisted by Cantor Robert Harmon.

title: George Szell, Conductor, Is Dead
description: George Szell, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra since 1946, died last night in Hanna House of University Hospital in Cleveland, where he had been under treatment since June 16. He was 73 years old.

title: 4th Panther in Bomb Case Released on $50,000 Bond
description: The fourth of 13 black Panthers facing trial here on bomb conspiracy charges was released on $50,000 bond yes terday.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE DROPS 1.1% IN WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage last week were both below the volume in the year earlier week.

title: DR. C. D. TREXLER, LUTHERAN LEADER
description: The Rev. Dr. Charles D. Trexler, who served as an Ar my chaplain in both World Wars, died Tuesday, in Physi cians Hospital, Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 86 years old and lived at 3520 77th Street, Jackson Heights.

title: The Gloom of Blackouts Has Vanished in Cairo
description: CAIRO, July 30The ordeals of war with Israel may not yet be over for the Egyptians, but already the gloom of last winter's blackout has disap peafed from downtown Cairo.

title: 75 Firemen Stage SickCall Protest In Brownsville
description: Most of the 100man comple ment of firemen in the Browns ville section of Brooklyn called in sick last night, it was re ported early today, in protest against the suspension of three of their number Wednesday night for their refusal to ride on unprotected fire trucks that had been assaulted by bricks and bottles.

title: REV. GEORGE O'CONNOR
description: The Rev. George O'Connor, a retired Paulist missionary, who served in Los Angeles, Chi cago, Toronto, New York, Min neapolis, Detroit and. Winches ter, Tenn., died Wednesday in Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: FRANCE TO UPGRADE HER NUCLEAR FORCE
description: PARIS, July 30  Defense Minister Michel Debr said to day that France's nuclear ar senal would grow larger and stronger during the next decade with thermonuclear weapons re placing atomic bombs between 1975 and 1980.

title: ALASKA OIL SYSTEM TO BE REORGANIZED
description: ALASKA OIL SYSTEM TO BE REORGANIZED

title: PRESIDENT PUTS BLAME ON MANY IN CAMPUS STRIFE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 30In an indirect criticism of the re cent Heard report on campus unrest, President Nixon said tonight that it was unfair to put the entire blame for stu dent disorders on the national Government.

title: 71 Senators Back a Firm Mideast Policy
description: WASHINGTON, July 30A group of 71 Senators today pub licly endorsed a firm Adminis tration position on the Middle East, asserting that the Soviet Union should be warned of the dangers of provoking the Unit ed States.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW SOLID GAINS
description: Prices on the London stock exchange staged a solid ad vance across the board in mod erate trading. The impetus for the advance came from the set telment of the British dock strike.

title: Article 9  No Title
Harvard Costs Rise
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 30 (AP)  Harvard University an nounced today that the cost of board for undergraduates would go up to $800 from $720 beginning next September.

title: Priority for Mr. Richardson
description: The most urgent taskfor Elliot L. Richardson in his new job as Secretary of Health, Education' and Welfare is to pilot through Congress the Nixon Administra tion's complex welfare reform bill. When he became Secretary, the House had already acted favorably but the bill was in deep trouble in the Senate Finance Committee.

title: Hitler Meeting Ban Upheld
description: RICHMOND, July 30 (AP)  Denial of the use of Arlington school facilities to the Socialist White People's party for a meeting to commemorate the 81st birthday of Adolf Hitler was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The court agreed with District Judge Oren R. Lewis of Alexandria that the school board acted properly to safeguard the peace and tran quility of the community.

title: Jacque Neff Fiance Of Anne La Bonte
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 30Miss Anne Patrice La Bonte and Jacque Alan Neff will be married Aug. 21 in Bay Head.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: San Diego at New York (8:05 P.M.)Coombs (88) vs. Gentry (76).

title: CURTIS OF COLTS REPORTS TO DRILL
description: The owners of the 26 teams in the National Football League opened their training camps to their striking players at 6 o'clock last night, but few of the 1,200 professionals broke ranks to attend.

title: Executive Changes
description: Carl S. Forsythe has been elected chairman of the board of Crompton & Knowles Corporation, suc ceeding Frederic W. Howe, Jr., retired.

title: Quarterly Profit Virtually Steady At Union Pacific
description: The Union Pacific Corpora tion, which owns 93 per cent of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, reported yesterday secondquarter consolidated net income of $18,126,000, equal to 86 cents a share, virtually un changed from last year.

title: ExHead of Center In Bronx Indicted In Theft of Funds
description: The former executive direc tor of the Claremont Neighbor hood Centers in the Bronx was indicted yesterday on 67 charges of grand larceny and forgery in connection with the alleged embezzlement of $46,000 from the center over the last year.

title: Mercedes to Break Ground For Jersey Headquarters
description: A groundbreaking ceremony for the new corporate head quarters of MercedesBenz of North America will take place today in Montvale, a northern New Jersey residential com munity.

title: Indian Handicrafts: Demand Is Up, Supply Down
description: GALLUP, N. M.Business has never been betterand the future has never been bleakerfor traditional In dian handicrafts.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: STONE TOPS KODES IN UPSET, 63, 61
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 30 (AP)  The first and third seeded foreign men were eliminated from the national clay courts tourney in today's thirdround singles.

title: Joint Venture Set in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 30 (Reuters) Hydron International, Inc., of the United States will set up a joint company in Japan next month with the Nippon Sheet Glass Company, the Japanese company announced today.

title: Hal C. Davis Is New Head of Musicians' Federation
description: Hal C. Davis has been elect ed to succeed Herman Kenin as president of the American Federation of Musicians. Mr. Kenin died on July 21.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein, on 229, Wins in Jersey by 13 Shots
description: OCEAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 30Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen, Oaks maintained her 13 stroke margin today with a 40, 38, 78 for a threeround total of 229 to win the Women's Metro politan Golf Association 54hole medal play championship at the Hollywood Golf Club.

title: A Fur Auctioneer Planning Switch To a New Line
description: In the secondfloor furauc tion room of the New York Auction Company on West 26th Street, a shaft of sunlight fo cused on light dust hovering on row after row of empty seats. Not too many years ago, those seats were occupied by frantic bidders seeking to acquire the best mink or other furs for robes for Pope John or for coats for the Duchess of Wind sor and Mrs. Jacqueline Ken nedy.

title: Israelis Report Downing 4 U A .R. MIG's
description: TEL AVIV, July 30Israel reported today that four Egyp tian MIG21 fighter planes were shot down in dogfights this afternoon when they tried to intercept Israeli jets on a bomb ing mission in the Suez Canal area.

title: Doctors Deny Woman's Hormones Affect Her as an Executive
description: Nonsense, out of date, a male puton. With these and other rebuttals, endocrinologists, psy chiatrists and practitioners of industrial medicine con tradicted a physician's recent assertions that physical and psychological inhibitants, particularly the raging hormonal influences of the menstrual cycle and meno pause, limit women's potential in the executive spheres of business and polities.

title: Golf Facts and Figures
description: ScheduleToday through Sunday. 18 holes daily. Sudden death follows end of Sunday play in event of tie for first place. Start ing field of 158. Low 70 scorers and ties and those within 10 strokes of leader after second round continue for third and fourth rounds. Purse $250,000. First prize, $50,000.

title: Over 10,000 Dodge Trucks Recalled for Brake Check
description: DETROIT, July 30. (AP) The Chrysler Corporation an nounced today that it was re calling more than 10,000 Dodge trucks for inspectionand re pair if necessaryof possible brake defects.

title: STATION IN FRAUD WINS A RENEWAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Federal Communications Com mission today renewed the li cense of a Florida radio station that had admitted overbilling its advertisers by nearly $42, 000 between mid1966 and the end of 1968.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JULY 31, 1970

title: Smog Here Kindling Fear of Possible Disease Agents
description: The muggy, noxious air hov ering over New York City has rekindled concern about the diseaseproducing capacity of the many chemicals that man has introduced into his environ ment.

title: PRICES INCH AHEAD IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange inched upward yesterday as volume slipped. The exchange's index closed at 20.48, up 0.03 for the day.

title: S.E.C. Suspends 2 Men In Coast Brokerage Firms
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)  The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended Dean Ruffell Burwell, the principal stockholder of the Meyerson Company and a director of Win field Underwriters, Inc., both of San Francisco, from the securi ties business for nine months. Harry Meyerson was suspended for 60 days.

title: 19 Found Collapsed At a Mental Center; Hysteria Suspected
description: Nineteen persons, all resi dents of a psyychiatric after care center for former mental patients, collapsed yesterday, as the result of what an official of the institution said might be group hysteria.

title: Stanley Edgar Hyman Is Dead; Critic, Author and Teacher, 51
description: NORTH BENNINGTON, Vt., July 30Stanley Edgar Hyman, literary critic, author and pro fessor of literature at Benning ton College, died last night ap parently of a heart attack. He was 51 years old. His first wife, Shirley Jackson, the novelist and short story writer, died in 1965.

title: Publicity Aide, Mrs. Reynolds Wed in Monaco
description: PARIS, July 30Mrs. Mari anne O'Brien Reynolds, the former wife of Richard J. Reynolds, the tobacco heir, was wed to Lee Meyers, a public relations executive, in a private ceremony in Monte Carlo, Monaco, today.

title: Thieu Sees a Need For 50,000 Troops From U.S. After 73
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 30  President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that residual force of about 50, 000 American troops would be required in South Vietnam after 1973 to guarantee the peace.

title: The Iceman Cometh to Westchester
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 30Preferential treatment is part of the reward for star dom and respectable starting times inva riably are allotted to the name performers in any golf tournament. The dawn patrol is usually manned by eager kids who don't mind getting their feet wet in the morn ing dew. But the entire field for the West chester Classic got whacked in the ears by alarm clocks for early starting times, half today and the other half tomorrow.

title: Cranis Advances
description: MANHASSET, L.L., July 30 Paul Cranis of New York, seeded sixth, upset Bob Barker of Port Washington, L.I., seeded fourth, 60, 63, today in the quarterfinals of the United States men's 35 years and over claycourt tennis champion ships.

title: Beck Industries Appoints Chief Executive Officer
description: Manuel F. Rothberg has been elected president and chief ex excutive officer of Beck Indus tries, Inc., a diversified retail ing company.

title: Arkansas Air Crash Kills 6
description: PIGGOTT, Ark., July 30 (UPI) An Air Force C130 transport plane crashed, and burned at dusk today in a pasture in this town in northeastern Arkansas, killing all six persons aboard. The plane left Little Rock Air Force Base and was flying to an Air Force base in Blytheville, Ark., when the crash occurred.

title: Drop of $44Million In City's Stock Tax Is Reported for Year
description: The city reported a $44mil lion loss in stock transfer tax receipts yesterday in the Fi nance Administration's final re port for 196970.

title: BonnMoscow Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 30Al though the wars in Asia and; the Middle East are getting; most of the public attention here, the managers of Ameri can foreign policy are casting wary glances at Moscow these days to monitor what they think may be an even more fateful diplomatic exercise  the effort of the Soviet Union and West Germany to reach a new un derstanding about the future of Cen tral Europe.

title: Third Murder Plan Is Laid to Manson
description: LOS ANGELES, July 30  Charles M. Manson and three of his followers planned still another murder the night two Los Angeles residents were killed, but the hippies were thwarted at the last minute, a key prosecution witness tes tified today.

title: Reserve Banks' Income Rose to a Record in 1969
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reut ers)Net income of Federal Reserve member banks rose to a record $3.45billion in 1969 From $2.96billion in 1968, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA AWhat John Fal kiewicz of Surf City, N. J., calls the best fishing in quite a few years in Barnegat Bay has netted pleasing catches of kingfish, blues, flounder and a few weakfish.

title: Price of Technology
description: Life in New York City this week seems almost too much for man to bear.

title: 3 BANKS ARE SUED UNDER USURY LAW
description: ST. PAUL, July 30 (AP) Minnesota's Attorney General, Douglas Head, has filed suit against three banks in St. Cloud and Rochester, and Omaha, alleging that they are violating Minnesota's 8 per cent usury law in a credit card operation.

title: Jersey City to Raise Pay
description: JERSEY CITY, July 30 Wage increases of $600 a year will be given to 2,000 non uniformed city employes, it was announced today at City Hall. The increases resulted from negotiations completed yester day between the city and Local 1959 of the American Federa tion of State, County and Mu nicipal Employes.

title: ROJAS AND RUIZ JOIN IN ROCKETTES DANCE
description: There are few auditoriums of unselfconscious splendor left in New York, and Radio City Music Hall is unique, not only among movie theaters but among all other performing arts houses. Currently, in its lush embrace, Carmen Rojas and Paco Ruiz have joined their Flamenco troupe to the resident ballet company and the Rock ettes in a Latin stage show.

title: Nerve Gas Trains Will Cross 7 States
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The Army disclosed today that seven Southern states would be crossed when two trainloads of deadly nerve gas are trans ported to the sea for disposal next month.

title: British Thalidomide Verdict
description: LONDON, July 30 (AP)A British high court today ap proved damages of $1.16million for 28 children described as de formed at birth by the drug thalidomide. The sum, to be paid by Distillers Company, Ltd., which distributed the drug in Britain under license from West Germany, represents 40 per cent of the sum attorneys for the children and attorneys for the company agreed would be full liability.

title: 20 Artists Awarded $7,500 Fellowships
description: Twenty young painters and sculptors of exceptional tal ent have been nominated by the National Council on the Arts to receive fellowships of $7,500 each. Drawn from every region in the country, they constitute the first group of artists to receive individ ual grants under the direction of Nancy Hanks, who became council chairman in Septem ber.

title: East Room Is Repainted In White at White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)  The East Room of the White House, where the Presidential family's formal social events are held, has been repainted for the first time since 1965.

title: News Parley Delayed By Balky Microphone
description: LOS ANGELES, July 30 (Reuters)A temperamental microphone caused a delay tonight in the start of Presi dent Nixon's nationally tele vised news conference.

title: Beame Protests Sanitation Consultant
description: A consultant has been hired to do a study of the Sanitation Department although there is a city office specifically charged with doing the same sort of study, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: HOGAN PULLS OUT AFTER CARDING 78
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 30 Five professional golfers crowded into the opening round lead in the $250,000 Westchester Classic today. But the tourney lost Ben Hogan, who withdrew after a 78 with a painful knee, and Lee Tre vino, a former United States Open champion, who failed to appear at the starting tee on time.

title: BIG POWERS MEET FOR TRADE TALKS
description: GENEVA, July 30  High level trade officials of the world's major industrial powers met here informally tonight as they prepared for two days of talks aimed at heading off a slide back into protectionism.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Proposal for Vietnam

title: ExRuler Doomed in Africa
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, July 30 (Reuters)  Brig. An drew JuxonSmith, former mili tary ruler of this West African nation, was sentenced to death today for treason. He sus pended the Constitution in 1967 and ruled with a military junta for 13 months. He was overthrown by the present civilian Government. The brig adier has 21 days to appeal the sentence.

title: Power Shortage
description: The power shortages bedeviling this city in recent days provide a reminder that adequate electricity for all communities and the nation's needs can no longer be taken for granted. Moreover, there is every reason to suppose that present problems will grow increas ingly acute over the passing years as the population rises and as ever more difficult compromises must be sought between growing power demands and the environmental damage caused by hydrocarbon and nuclear fuels.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: President Nixon was in. San Clemente at the Western White House, where he ap pointed Rolf Eliassen as a member of the General Ad visory Committee to the Atomic Energy Commission. Mr. Eliassen, who is acting head of the department of civil engineering at Stanford University, succeeds Stephen Lawroski, whose term ex expires Aug 1. Mr. Nixon also reappointed Howard G. Vesper of Oakland, Calif., and William Webster of Bos ton as members of the Advisory Council on sup plementary Centers and Serv ices, which reviews admin istration of Title III of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965; Arthur Ballantine of Duran go, Colo.; Dallas H. Smith of Tunstall, Va.; Howard Jordan Jr. of gavannah, Ga.; Dorothy Robinson of Long meadow, Mass., and Janet Borgen of Ketchikan, Alaska.

title: Jersey Publisher's Editorial Brings Contempt Sentence
description: PATERSON, N. J. July 30 Joseph Matzner, publisher of the Daily newspaper Wayne Today; was sentenced today to two days in jail on a contempt of court judgment based on a July 19 editorial in his paper. The sentence was stayed pend ing appeal.

title: Amex's Earnings in First Half Declined by 70%
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday 70 per cent decline in net in come coupled with a drop in overall share volume of 36 per cent for the first half of 1970.

title: Exchange Called Unusual
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The exchange of weapons for foreign bases is considered an unusual practice, a Pentagon spokesman said, although he would not confirm the transfer of F4 phantom jets to Spain.

title: SALAZAR BURIED NEAR BIRTHPLACE
description: LISBON, July 30Portugal's austere former dictator, Dr. Antenio de Oliveira. Salazar, was buried today in a simple country cemetery, near Santa Comba Do, where he was born 81 years ago.

title: MRS. REID'S RITES ATTENDED BY 300
description: Three hundred people, induct ing many newspaper associates, attended a funeral service yesterday for Mrs. Helen Rodgers Reid, former publisher of The New York Herald Trib une.

title: PRICE RISE LIKELY FOR NATURAL GAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Federal Power Commission an nounced today its intention to review and probably revoke the price ceiling that has been in effect for a year and a half on natural gas produced in southern Louisiana. About threequarters of all the natural gas that is used in New York State and City comes from this area.

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, July 30, 1970

title: Article 8  No Title
First Computer Auction Gives a Negative Readout
description: Steven Ross came to the ParkeBernet Galleries on East 84th Street yesterday hoping to pick up a used computer cheap, something under $10.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: Marshmallow Pie, by Graham Lord (CowardMcCann, $4.95). Mysti cism and murder among Lon don's flower people.

title: SENATE GROUP URGES ACTION ON P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)A group of Senators made an effort today to stir national indignation over treat ment of United States prisoners of war, whom they termed the forgotten men, of the Viet nam war.

title: CHRYSLER SEEKING NEW LINE OF CREDIT
description: The Chrysler Corporation an nounced yesterday that it was negotiating for a twoyeat: line of credit of up to $100 million in Eurodollars (dollars on deposit abroad), to be provided by an international syndicate of banks headed by Manufacturers Hanover Ltd., in London, the merchant bank ing subsidiary of the Manufac turers Hanover Trust Company, New York.

title: Mrs. Nixon to Make Tour
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 30 (UPI)  Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will have a separate schedule in Denver, Colo., on Monday when she and the (President spend a few, hours there on a homeward trip.

title: TIMES IS PICKETED BY PROTEST GROUP
description: A group of ItalianAmericans picketed The New York Times's West Side Plant in the Lincoln Center area of Man hattan for five and a half hours yesterday morning, protesting the use of Italian labels for a section of organized crime.

title: Giants: One Reports
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 30 Tim McCann, a defensive tackle, was the only hold over to accept the New York Giants' invitation to attend training camp today. The other Giant regulars will meet tomorrow to decide whether they should heed the strike call of the National Football League Players As sociation.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
MOSCOW ASSAILS NASSER'S CRITICS
description: Moscow, July 30  The Communist party newspaper Pravda today denounced Arab critics of the Egyptian decision co accept the latest American nitiative for a Middle East settlement.

title: Rolling Stones Dismiss Allen Klein as Manager
description: LONDON, July 30 (AP)  The Rolling Stones parted company today with the group's Ameri can manager, Allen Klein, who also manages the Beatles.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
Mets, 2 Games Behind 1969 Pace, Still in Race
description: While Casey Stengel, their in defatigable manager emeritus, was merrily celebrating his 80th birthday yesterday in Glendale, Calif., the New York Mets  less heroic types aft er completing 100 of the 162 games of their current season enjoyed a day of rest.

title: Samuel Clark Waugh, 80, Dies; ExHead of ExportImport Bank
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)  Samuel Clark Waugh, for mer head of the ExportImport Bank and an official of the State Department, died early today after a short illness. He was 80 years old.

title: U.S. COURT URGED TO FREE CHICAGO 8
description: CHICAGO, July 30  The United States. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit was asked today to reverse the con victions of all defendents in the Chicago conspiracy trial be cause of recently disclosed elec tronic surveillance of Bobby G. Seale.

title: Pornography Curb Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) Senator Hugh Scott, Republi can of Pennsylvania, today urged Senate action on meas ures to curb the distribution and mailing of pornographic mate rials.

title: UTILITY REPORTS GAIN IN EARNINGS
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company and subsidiaries re ported yesterday gains in oper ating revenue and net income for the first half and 12 months ended June 30. The report iiliced total operating revenues at $250,455,000 for the first half, up from $217,202,000 a year before. Net income rose to $35,917,000, or $1.02 a share, from the $34,178,000, or $1.08 a share on fewer shares, reported for the six months ended June 30. 1969.

title: P.S.C. Plans Gas Hearing
description: ALBANY, July 30The Pub lie Service Commission will begin public hearings in Albany on Aug. 19 to determine what action it should take to reduce the impact of a possible future naturalgas shortage. The P.S.C. pill consider restrictions on new gas customers and promo tional activities by the state's gas distributing companies in the face of a potential shortage of gas from out of state.

title: Foreign Affairs: The Fruits of War or War
description: On July 31, 1963, the world was startled to hear Peking de nounce Moscow for initialing a nuclear testban treaty and thus having betrayed the peoples of the Socialist camp by a move most capitals regarded as an encouraging step toward sanity.

title: STOKES LISTS NAMES OF ENEMIES OF LAW
description: CLEVELAND, July 30The identities of four groups and three men who had been classed as enemies of law en forcement by Benjamin O. Davis Jr. when he resigned Monday as Cleveland's safety director have been disclosed by Mayor Carl B. Stokes.

title: Article 10  No Title
WHITE CUTS CAKE AND SLICES SLUMP
description: MILWAUKEE, July 30Roy White packed his new silver and purple scarf but left his motherinlaw's chocolate cake behind him in the clubhouse. He wasn't sure whether the batting slump was going or staying.

title: Grounded Ferry Floated
description: PRINCE RUPERT, B. C., July 30 (Canadian Press)  Four powerful tugs early today pulled the 352foot Alaska Fer ries vessel Taku off the rocky shoreline of Kinahan Island. The Taku ran aground yester day with 324 persons aboard. A three  mile oil slick that flowed from the Taku's rup tured oil tanks appeared to be headed seaward.

title: Brasilia, Far From Anywhere, Is Becoming Someplace
description: BRASILIAThe sun takes a long time to set in the immense, clear sky. When it does, it leaves Brasilia pretty much alone except for the shirring and clicking of insects in the short, twisted trees and in the cracks in the dry earth.

title: Seaport Museum Acquires 1899 IronHulled Steam Tug
description: A 72foot ironhulled steam tug built in 1899 in Sorel, Que bec, joined the historic fleet at the South Street Seaport Mu seum yesterday.

title: Board Investigating Schools Promoting Students Who Fail
description: The Board of Education is investigating reports that stu dents in certain schools are being promoted without having achieved proper credit, simply to get them out of their par ticular school.

title: ABM'S OPPONENTS SELECT STRATEGY
description: WASHINGTON, July 30A bipartisan coalition in the Sen ate agreed today: upon strategy for a fight to prevent the Nixon Administration from expanding the Safeguard antimissile sys tem.

title: Thais Reexamining Policy in Light of U.S. Pullback
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 30  Thailand is undergoing an intensive reexamination of her foreign policy as a result of President Nixon's policy of low ering the American profile in Asia. The most acute expres sion of Thailand's reappraisal is the debate that has been go ing on here over whether Thai land should send ground troops to Cambodia.

title: OTTINGER SCORED ON FUND SOURCES
description: Neither Senator Charles L. Goodell nor Representative Richard L. Ottinger, his Demo cratic opponent, even stepped into the ring yesterday, but their campaign managers sparred furiously for advantage on the eve of an upcoming endorsement.

title: U. S. War Deaths 77 in Week, Up From 66
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 31 (AP)  The United States command an nounced yesterday that 77 Americans were killed in action in South Vietnam in the week ended Saturday, 11 more than the week before. However, it said the number of American combat dead in the last four weeks, 276, was the lowest in four years.

title: Challenge to Mideast Leaders
description: The United States peace initiative has posed a se vere challenge to leadership on both sides of the Arab  Israeli conflict, as was to be expected. It is always easier to rally people with emotional rhetoric for mili tary confrontation than to lead them with reason political accommodation, especially in a region with the bitter historical memories and deeprooted Sus picions that prevail in the Middle East.

title: Panther Reportedly Wanted to Testify in Senate
description: NEW HAVEN, July 30  A detective who interrogated Lon nie McLucas three weeks after the Alex Rackley slaying testi fied today at Mr. McLucas's trial that the defendant was ready then to appear before a Senate committee that was in vestigating the Black panther party.

title: Gardner Organizing A Lobby of Citizens
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 John W. Gardner, chairman of the National Urban Coalition, is organizing a national citizens lobby whose goals will include reshaping, government and par ty politics, at all levels to make the system Work.

title: Claud Allister, 76, Actor of Stage and Movies, Dies
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 30 (AP)Claud Allister, an actor with a long career in this country and in his na tive England, died here Sunday in a hospital after a long ill ness. He was 76 years old.

title: Lawlessness in Mississippi
description: The confidence of students and blacks in the impar tiality of the law cannot have been increased by the latest denial of justice in Mississippi. A county grand jury investigating the killing of two Negro youths at Jackson State College last May by local police officers and state highway patrolmen has concluded that the officers had a right and were justified.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Friday, July 31, 1970

title: Power and Artistry
Catherine Soussloff Planning Nuptials
After Breaking Ice in Arctic, the Manhattan Returns to Tanker Service
description: The world's biggest ice breaker, the key performer in the pioneering expedition last summer through the Arc tic waters of the Northwest Passage, is returning to its relatively humdrum career as a plodding supertanker.

title: 3 MORE INDICTED IN TAX BRIBERIES
description: A Federal grand jury in dicted three former special agents of the Internal Revenue Service yesterday, bringing to 10 the number here who have been charged with bribery in a twoyear investigation called Project S.

title: J. & L. STEEL CO, SHOWS A PROFIT
description: The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation, which had sus tained a loss and omitted the dividend on its common stock in the first three months of 1970, reported yesterday in Pittsburgh that it had earned a small profitless than a cent a sharein the second quarter.

title: 4 Big Mercury Polluters In State Reported Halted
description: ALBANY, July 30Governor Rockefeller said today that four of eight companies found to have been discharging mer cury into state waters had ceased that form of pollution.
